revision.text:
{{recipesummary|Fermented food recipes||soak: 6-8 hours
prep: 10 minutes
ferment: 12-48hours
cook: 5 minutes each dosa|3|Image=[[Image:Dosa-chutney-sambhar.jpg|300px]]}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of India|Indian Cuisine]] A '''dosa''' is a thin, spicy, crispy crêpe-like food made from fermented rice, very popular in restaurants in South [[Cookbook:Cuisine of India|India]]. It may be served plain with [[Cookbook:Sambar|sambar]] and chutneys such as [[Cookbook:Coconut Chutney|coconut chutney]] (as pictured), or other curry or gravy. When served with [[Cookbook:Aloo masala|alu masala]] folded inside, it is known as '''masala dosa'''. To make omelette dosa, simply pour beaten egg on the dosa before it is turned over. The procedure for making dosa starts out almost identical to that for making [[Cookbook:Idli|idli]]. The idli recipe in this cookbook has some very good [[Cookbook:Idli#Notes, tips, and variations|tips and variations]] that apply equally to dosai. == First Variation == ===Ingredients=== * 3 cups white [[Cookbook:Rice|rice]] * 1 cup [[Cookbook:Urad Dal|urad dal]] (black gram) * handful of cooked rice (if required) * pinch of [[Cookbook:sugar|sugar]] (if desired) * ¼ teaspoon [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] ===Procedure=== ====Batter==== # Put the rice and dal in a large pot and wash twice. # Fill with water until submerged by 2 inches. # Soak for 6 hours. # [[Cookbook:Purée|Grind]] in an [[Cookbook:Blender|blender]], water and all, for 30 minutes. If the weather is cold, grind in a handful of rice and a pinch of sugar to help in fermentation. # Let ferment overnight in a warm place. Make sure the pot is twice as large as the amount of batter, as it will rise a great deal. # Add salt; at this point the batter can be kept in the refrigerator for more than a week until you wish to fry the dosas. ====Dosas==== # Heat a [[Cookbook:Tava|tava]] (large flat pan) or [[Cookbook:griddle|griddle]] over a high flame. # Sprinkle water on the pan to cool it a little. # Pour ½–¾ cup batter in the middle of the pan, depending on preferred thickness and crispiness. # Spread the batter with the back of a spoon, starting from the centre and spiralling outwards until the dosa is about 10 inches across and very thin. # Sprinkle a little [[Cookbook:oil|oil]] around the edges of the dosa. # Cover until the dosa shows brown through the thinnest parts. # Turn the dosa around on its back and allow it to cook for a few seconds. # Fold in half and remove with a metal spatula. Makes 10–15. == Second Variation == === Preparation === Makes about 20 *2 cups (360 g) rice, preferably parboiled *1/2 cup (90 g) split and husked [[Cookbook:Urad Dal|urad dal]] ('dhuli urad') *1/2 tsp [[Cookbook:Fenugreek|fenugreek seeds]] (methi dana) *2 tsp salt *Oil for cooking doshas '''Method ''' # Soak rice, dal, and fenugreek seeds together overnight. # Grind these ingredients together to a very smooth consistency. # Add the salt and enough water to make into a dropping consistency, and leave to rise for 5-6 hours, or overnight. # Check consistency of the batter, and if needed, add enough water to make into a smooth pouring consistency. # Heat [[Cookbook:Tava|tava]] (dosa pan) very hot, splash a little water over it, and with a ladle, immediately pour some batter onto it, spreading it thin, with a circular motion, without pressing too hard. (You will need some practice to get it right). # Lower the heat and dribble a little oil around the edges. When edges start browning a bit, it is almost done. # Turn the dosa around on its back and allow it to cook for a few seconds. # Add desired filling and fold over. == Masala Dosa (Mysore style) == === Ingredients for preparation === ====Batter==== *Ponni or Sona Masuri [[Cookbook:Rice|rice]]: 1 Cup *Boiled Rice: 1 Cup *[[Cookbook:Urad Dal|Urad dal]] (whole skinless black gram): ¾ Cup *Non iodized [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]]: To Taste ====Filling==== *[[Cookbook:Potato|Potatoes]]: 6 Medium Sized, [[Cookbook:Boil|Boiled]] and coarsely mashed *[[Cookbook:Onion|Onions]]: 2 Medium Sized, Finely chopped *[[Cookbook:Chili Pepper|Green Chili Pepper]]: 3 to 6, Finely Chopped *[[Cookbook:Ginger|Ginger]]: 1 Tsp, finely grated *[[Cookbook:Garlic|Garlic]]: 1 Tsp, finely grated *[[Cookbook:Cooking oil|Oil]]: 2 Tbsp *[[Cookbook:Mustard|Mustard Seeds]]: ½ Tsp *[[Cookbook:Cilantro|Cilantro]]: 1 TBS, finely chopped *[[Cookbook:Channa dhal|Chana Dal]]: 1 Tsp *[[Cookbook:Turmeric|Turmeric]]: 1 Tsp *[[Cookbook:Curry Leaf|Curry Leaves]]: 1 Tsp, coarsely chopped *[[Cookbook:Onion Chutney|Onion Chutney]] *[[Cookbook:Coconut Chutney|Coconut Chutney]] ====For Assembly==== *Mixture of [[Cookbook:Ghee|Ghee]] and vegetable shortening: ½ cup === Preparation Method === ====Batter==== On the day before, grind all the ingredients in a [[Cookbook:Blender|blender]] or specialized dosa grinder with water. The final consistency of the batter must be similar to [[Cookbook:Pancake|pancake]] batter. Leave it overnight in a warm spot and allow it to [[Cookbook:Fermentation|ferment]]. This is a very important process and must not be skipped. During fermentation the batter may rise to almost twice its volume and therefore the container for the batter must allow for this. ====Chutneys==== Prepare the two chutneys as described in [[Cookbook:Onion Chutney|Onion Chutney]] and [[Cookbook:Coconut Chutney|Coconut Chutney]] ====Filling==== In a [[Cookbook:Wok|wok]] or other deep vessel heat the oil. When the oil is hot add the mustard seeds and allow it to splutter. When spluttering starts to recede add the chopped green chilies, curry leaves and the channa dal. Stir until the channa dal turns brown. (Be careful as channa dal can go from browned to burnt within seconds). Add the onions and fry until browned and add turmeric and stir for 2 minutes. Add ginger and garlic and stir it in for a few seconds. Add the boiled and coarsely mashed potatoes into the mix and fold well. Turn off the heat and add lemon juice and the coriander leaves. Fold well. === Making a Dosa === Dosai can easily be made on a [[Cookbook:Tava|tava]], iron [[Cookbook:Frying Pan|frying pan]] or non-stick pan. Heat the pan on a medium heat until a drop of water evaporates on contact. Spread about 1/2 cup of batter on the pan (like pancakes) slowing spreading it outwards forming a thin, flat circular dosa. Allow it cook for a minute and using a flat, sharp [[Cookbook:Spatula|spatula]] flip it over. As the other side cooks spread a layer of ghee-shortening mixture on the topside. Flip it over again. As the bottom crisps add a Tsp of the onion chutney on the top and spread it evenly. Add some of the filling onto one half of the dosa and fold the other side over. Serve with coconut chutney. == Media == {{wikipedia|Dosa}} {{multi-video start}} {{multi-video item|filename=Dosa preparation.ogg|title=Preparation of a Dosa|description= A colour film with sound showing a plain dosa being prepared. (2.5[[:w:Megabyte|MB]], [[:w:ogg|ogg]]/[[:w:Theora|Theora]] format).|format=[[:w:Theora|Theora]]}} {{multi-video end}} [[Category:Vegan recipes|Dosa]] [[Category:Indian recipes|Dosa]] [[Category:Rice recipes|Dosa]] [[Category:Recipes with videos|Dosa]] [[Category:Fermented food recipes|Dosa]] [[Category:Breakfast recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Flatbread recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Side Dish recipes|4-6|20 minutes|3}}
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of India|Indian recipes]] | [[Cookbook:Vegan cuisine|Vegan]]
{{Need Photo}}
'''Potato masala''' or uralai kehazhangu masala is a potato mixture that is often served alongside, or folded inside, a [[Cookbook:Dosa|dosa]]. This combination, widely eaten in South [[Cookbook:Cuisine of India|India]], is known as '''masala dosa'''. [[Cookbook:Coconut Chutney|Coconut chutney]] is a common accompaniment.
==Ingredients== * 4 large [[Cookbook:Potato|potatoes]], cubed and par-boiled * 1 medium [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]], chopped thin * 4-5 split green [[Cookbook:Chilli pepper|chillies]] * ½ teaspoon [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * ½ tablespoon [[Cookbook:Channa dhal|chana dhal]] (optional) * ½ teaspoon [[Cookbook:Mustard seed|mustard seed]] * 5 [[Cookbook:Curry leaf|curry leaves]] * pinch of [[Cookbook:Turmeric|turmeric]] powder * 1 tablespoon [[Cookbook:oil|oil]]
==Procedure== # Heat oil. # [[Cookbook:Sautéing|Sautée]] the mustard seed first, then add chana dhal, curry leaves, onion and chillies. # Fry until the onions begin to change color. # Add potatoes. # Sprinkle the turmeric evenly and stir well to mix all the ingredients # Cover and cook on a medium flame for about 5 minutes, stirring well, until the potatoes become very soft and somewhat mashed.
[[Category:Indian recipes|Aloo masala]] [[Category:Vegan recipes|Aloo masala]] [[Category:Side Dish recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[category:Gluten-free recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Bread_Recipes|Bread Recipes]]
'''Garlic croutons''' can be purchased but are much better when made from old bread. They are a crucial ingredient of [[Cookbook:Caesar_Salad|Caesar Salad]].
==Ingredients== *4 slices day-old French bread, cubed *2 cloves [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]], minced *4 tablespoons [[Cookbook:Olive_oil|olive oil]] *[[Cookbook:Salt|Salt]] to taste
Makes enough croutons for 4 servings of salad.
==Procedure== # Pour the olive oil into a shallow bowl over the garlic and let it soak. Soaking it longer will yield more garlic flavor # Preheat the oven to 350 degrees Fahrenheit (~180 degrees Celsius). # Strain the olive oil into a pan and fry the bread cubes in it, tossing to coat with oil. # Spread the bread cubes on a baking sheet and garnish with salt. Bake for 10 minutes or until crispy and dry.
==Variants==
To make non-garlic croutons, simply omit the garlic.
One may omit the prep work of mincing the garlic by adding the whole cloves of garlic to the oil and then crushing the garlic (either with a mortar or a fork).
By using very small bread cubes, frying crisp, and omitting the baking, these croutons may be used in place of potatoes.
[[Category:Bread recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Garlic recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{cookwork}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Baking]]
== Introduction == There are many types of bread. Each type of bread has its own history, style, and of course taste. The more you experiment with different types of bread, the better you will be at creating new and interesting recipes.
The basic elements of bread are [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] (ground grain) and water. [[Cookbook:Wheat|Wheat]] flour is the most popular, having many qualities that contribute to good bread. Other flours that are used include [[Cookbook:Rye|rye]], [[Cookbook:Corn|corn]], and [[Cookbook:Barley|barley]].
Bread is generally assumed to be made with [[Cookbook:Yeast|yeast]]. Sometimes the term "bread" is meant to include quickbreads (raised with something other than yeast, commonly [[Cookbook:Baking Powder|baking powder]]) and flatbreads (not raised at all).
==[[Cookbook:Cuisine of Italy|Italian]] breads== === How to prepare Italian bread dough === Please note that where I work, the dough comes in already mixed and stretched, we just have to prepare it. But, here is how to obtain the proper length and thickness. <!-- WE NEED A LOCAL RECIPE If you don't have already made dough, there is a recipe at http://www.lisashea.com/lisabase/bread/italian.html which you can use. --> Roll your dough into a "stick" approximately [[Cookbook:Inch|14 to 16 inches]] long, and about 2/3 the thickness of a Pringles can. Optionally, you can cut the top in three diagonal hash marks, approx. [[Cookbook:Inch|1/8"]] deep.
=== How to prepare Mini Italian bread dough === Prepare one Italian bread but do not put the hash marks on top. Cut the dough in half widthwise so that you have two pieces half the length of the original dough. Optionally, you can cut two diagonal hash marks, approx. 1/8" deep.
==[[Cookbook:Cuisine of France|French]] Breads== === How to prepare French bread dough === Prepare one Italian bread but do not put the hash marks on top. Stretch the dough until it is approx. twice its length. Optionally, you can cut four diagonal hash marks, approx. 1/8" deep.
=== How to prepare French Sticks bread dough === Prepare one Italian bread but do not put the hash marks on top. Cut the dough in half lengthwise so that you have two pieces the same length of the original dough. Optionally, you can cut three diagonal has marks, approx. 1/8" deep.
==Other types of breads== === How to prepare Sub Bun bread dough === Prepare one Italian bread but do not put the hash marks on top. Cut the dough in half lengthwise, and once again widthwise, so that you have four pieces half the length of the original dough. Optionally, you can cut two diagonal hash marks, approx. 1/8" deep.
*[[Cookbook:Beer_Bread|Beer Bread]]
==Flourishes== === Adding [[Cookbook:Sesame Seed|sesame seeds]] or [[Cookbook:Poppy Seed|poppy seeds]] to your bread === Paint the top of the bread with an [[Cookbook:Egg|egg]] white, then lightly sprinkle the desired seeds onto the top.
==[[Cookbook:Baking|Baking]] methods== === Baking with a Proofer system === Place prepared product onto a metal tray/[[Cookbook:Cookie Sheet|cookie sheet]] lined with [[Cookbook:Parchment Paper|parchment paper]]. Make sure you leave room for your product to grow to twice its size. Place tray in proofer for one hour. Check with your fingertips if the dough is still sticky. If so, leave in the proofer and check every 5 minutes. Once the dough no longer sticks to your finger tips, you can remove it from the proofer and place it in the [[Cookbook:Oven|oven]]. Bake it at [[Cookbook:Oven Temperatures|400 degrees]] until golden brown.
=== Baking without a Proofer system === Lightly dust a baking tray with a small amount of flour, place the bread dough onto the tray ensuring enough room for the bread to gain in size, Cover the bread dough with a dry, clean [[Cookbook:Tea|tea]] towel. Place the bread into a moderatly warm environment and allow to rise, the time to rise will depend on the bread recipe.
A good environment for bread rising is above a large oven, turn the oven onto the lowest setting or [[Cookbook:Oven Temperatures|gas mark 1]]. You can also just put it in an oven and turn on the oven light. This, too, will provide enough warmth to help the bread rise. Also try a laundry room or furnace room.
[[Category:Bread recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Beverages|Beverages]]
'''Orange Hot Chocolate''' is a twist on the old childhood favorite. Note that this hot chocolate is not sweet. Those who like it sweeter should use a chocolate with a higher sugar content, or add 1 tablespoon [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] with the chocolate.
==Ingredients== *4 cups [[Cookbook:Milk|milk]] *1 stick [[Cookbook:Cinnamon|cinnamon]] *4 oz. [[Cookbook:Chocolate|bittersweet chocolate]], chopped (can substitute semisweet) *½ tsp. [[Cookbook:Orange extract|orange extract]] *¼ tsp. [[Cookbook:Vanilla extract|vanilla extract]]
Serves 4.
==Procedure== # Place the milk and cinnamon in a [[Cookbook:Saucepan|saucepan]], and gently heat to just below a simmer, about 180 °F. # Add the chocolate, and stir while allowing to melt. Do not allow to come to a boil. # When the chocolate has melted, strain the chocolate milk into another container, add the extracts, and whisk or blend until frothy. Transfer to mugs or heatproof glasses and serve.
[[Category:Beverage recipes|Orange Hot Chocolate]] [[Category:Chocolate recipes|Orange Hot Chocolate]] [[Category:Dairy recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Orange recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Dessert recipes|6|prep: 20 minutes
baking: 35 minutes|3}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Dessert|Dessert]] A '''chocolate pear bake''' is a dessert that resembles a brownie in appearance, yet contains no flour, instead using whipped egg whites to provide structure. The pear adds a nice mild fruit tone to the chocolate. ==Ingredients== *7 oz (200g) [[Cookbook:Chocolate|semisweet chocolate]], chopped or chips *½ cup (120g) [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]] or [[Cookbook:Margarine|margarine]] *4 [[Cookbook:Egg|egg]]s, separated *½ cup (120g) [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] *2 [[Cookbook:Pear|pear]]s, sliced *lightly [[Cookbook:Whipped cream|whipped cream]], to serve ==Procedure== #Grease a 9x9 inch (22cm x 22cm) [[Cookbook:Baking Dish|baking dish]], and pre-heat the oven to [[Cookbook:oven temperature|325°F]] (170°C). #In a [[Cookbook:Double Boiler|double boiler]], [[Cookbook:Melting|melt]] the chocolate and butter or margarine. When melted, remove from the heat. #[[Cookbook:Whisk|Whisk]] the [[Cookbook:egg yolk|egg yolk]]s and sugar together until they become thick and pale yellow. #In a separate bowl, whisk the [[Cookbook:Egg White|egg white]]s until firm. #Combine the chocolate and egg yolk mixture, and mix well. #Beginning with about ⅓ the egg whites, gently [[Cookbook:Folding|fold]] them into the chocolate/egg yolk mixture. #Add the slices of pear, and stir once or twice. Add the entire mixture to the baking dish. #[[Cookbook:Baking|Bake]] for 35-40 minutes, until the bake is springy yet firm to the touch. #Serve hot with whipped cream. ==Notes, tips, and variations== *Substitute sliced peaches, apples, or orange segments for the pears. ==Warnings== *Overmixing after the egg whites have been added to the batter can result in the bake being too dense. [[Category:Dessert recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Chocolate recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Pear recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[category:Gluten-free recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Recipes with metric units|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Italian recipes|12|2-3 hours|4}}
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Italy|Cuisine of Italy]] | [[Cookbook:Pasta Recipes|Pasta Recipes]]
'''Lasagne''' is a baked pasta dish.
==Ingredients== * 1 lb. sweet Italian sausage * 1/2 lb. minced (ground) [[Cookbook:Beef|beef]] * 1/2 [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]], chopped fine * 2 cloves garlic, crushed * 3 1/2 tablespoons sugar * 1 tablespoon salt * 1 1/2 teaspoons dried basil * 1/2 teaspoon fennel seed * 1/4 teaspoon black pepper * 1/4 cup chopped [[Cookbook:Parsley|parsley]] (divided) * 4 cups canned whole tomatoes, undrained, halved, seeds removed * 12 oz tomato paste * 1/2 cup water * 1/2 tablespoon salt * 2 cups [[Cookbook:Ricotta cheese|ricotta cheese]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Egg|egg]] * 16 oz. package lasagna * 16 oz. package of [[Cookbook:Mozzarella cheese|mozzarella cheese]], thinly sliced (a wire cutter is nice for semi-soft cheeses like this) * about 3 Tbsp. grated [[Cookbook:Parmesan cheese|Parmesan cheese]]
==Procedure== #Remove sausage casings, and break sausage into small bits. #Sauté sausage and ground beef in 5-quart saucepan or Dutch oven over medium heat with onion and garlic until the meat is browned. #Add sugar, 1 tablespoon salt, basil, fennel, pepper, and half the parsley; mix well. #Add tomatoes, tomato paste and water, mashing the tomatoes a bit. Bring the sauce to a boil then reduce heat and simmer, covered and stirring occasionally for 1 1/2 hours. #Preheat oven to 275 degrees F. #Cook and drain pasta. #In a medium bowl mix ricotta, egg, 1/2 teaspoon salt and remaining parsley. #Assemble your lasagna in a 13" x 9" x 2" roasting pan (listed bottom to top): #*bottom layer of sauce (approx. 1 1/2 cups) #*layer of pasta (overlapping slightly) #*layer of 1/2 the ricotta mixture #*layer of 1/3 of the mozzarella #*sauce layer (again, about 1 1/2 cups) #*layer of grated Parmesan sprinkled over sauce (not so much that the sauce layer is covered entirely) #*layer of pasta #*layer of remaining ricotta #*layer of 1/3 of the mozzarella #*layer of remaining sauce #*layer of sprinkled Parmesan #*layer of remaining mozzarella #Cover the lasagna with foil and roast 30 minutes covered, then 25 minutes uncovered (or until bubbly and lightly browned). Cool for at least 20 minutes before serving.
Uncooked lasagnas freeze very well so the extra work can be done well in advance. You can make several batches at a time and freeze the extras to thaw out and cook later.
[[Category:Pasta recipes|Ricotta Lasagne]] [[Category:Lasagne recipes|Ricotta Lasagne]] [[Category:Italian recipes|Ricotta Lasagne]]

revision.comment: Revert to revision 511227 dated 2006-07-03 17:29:15 by Ants Go Marching using [[:en:Wikipedia:Tools/Navigation_popups|popups]]
revision.text:
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Vegetarian cuisine|Vegetarian Cuisine]]
==Ingredients== *1 cup uncooked [[Cookbook:Brown rice|brown rice]] or white [[Cookbook:Rice|rice]] *2 tablespoons [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]] *1 teaspoon [[Cookbook:Curry Powder|curry powder]] *1/2 chopped [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]] *1/2 cup [[Cookbook:Raisin|raisin]]s *2 cups [[Cookbook:Water|water]] *3 vegetarian [[Cookbook:Bouillon Cubes|bouillon cubes]] (non-vegetarians can use chicken bouillon cubes)
Makes 3 servings.
==Procedure==
*Find a large saucepan or frying pan which has a lid, place on a medium heat, add butter, and then add chopped onion. Cook the onion for a couple of minutes until it starts to brown slightly. *Add curry powder stir with onions for a minute. *Add vegetarian bouillon cubes, raisins, rice, and water. *Put on lid and simmer until water is absorbed. (about 15 minutes)
[[Category:Rice recipes|Curried Rice]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|Curried Rice]] [[category:Gluten-free recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Breakfast recipes|1 person|~10 minutes|2}}
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Vegetarian cuisine|Vegetarian]] | [[Cookbook:Breakfast|Breakfast]]
'''French toast''' (or "poor knights") is a common [[Cookbook:Breakfast|breakfast]] item made by [[Cookbook:Frying|frying]] an [[Cookbook:Egg|egg]] [[Cookbook:Batter|batter]] soaked piece of [[Cookbook:Bread|bread]]. French toast was developed as a way to use day-old stale bread. Lacking day-old bread, [[Cookbook:Toasting|toasting]] your bread lightly can help it absorb more of the egg and milk batter. [[Image:frenchtoast.jpg|thumb|300px|right|French toast serving]] French toast is usually served with toppings similar to those used for [[Cookbook:Pancake|pancakes]], [[Cookbook:Waffle|waffles]], and [[Cookbook:Toast|toast]]. Suggested toppings are:
* real [[Cookbook:Maple Syrup|maple syrup]], table syrup * [[Cookbook:Jam|jam]], [[Cookbook:Jelly|jelly]], fruit syrup * [[Cookbook:Whipped Cream|whipped cream]] * [[Cookbook:Powdered Sugar|powdered sugar]] * [[Cookbook:Nut|nuts]] * [[Cookbook:Honey|honey]] (as served in [[Cookbook:Cuisine of China|China]]) * [[Cookbook:Bacon|bacon]] * [[Cookbook:Raspberries|raspberries]] or [[Cookbook:Strawberries|strawberries]] or [[Cookbook:Blueberries|blueberries]] or all 3!
This recipe is easily scalable. The simplest thing is to memorize the recipe for two slices (1 serving), and then multiply to make more. You can coat 2.25 to 2.5 slices from this, or perhaps less than two if the bread slices are large.
==Ingredients== * 1 [[Cookbook:Egg|egg]] for every 2 slices of bread * approximately 1/4 [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] (60ml) [[Cookbook:Milk|milk]] (more for softer, less egg-like French toast; less for firmer, more egg-like toast) * 2 slices [[Cookbook:Bread|bread]] (I cut 1" thick slices of French bread) *[[Cookbook:Butter|butter]] (best), [[Cookbook:Margarine|margarine]], or [[Cookbook:Oil|oil]]
Optional:
*1/2 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoon]] [[Cookbook:Vanilla|vanilla]] extract or similar extract *1/4 - 1 teaspoon [[Cookbook:Nutmeg|nutmeg]], [[Cookbook:Cinnamon|cinnamon]] or other powdered [[Cookbook:Spice|spice]] suitable for sweet items *1/2 teaspoon [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] *1/4 teaspoon [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] *1/4 teaspoon [[Cookbook:Pepper|pepper]]
Makes roughly 2 slices of French toast.
==Procedure== #In a bowl mix eggs and milk, and optional ingredients as desired. #Heat up a [[Cookbook:Frying Pan|frying pan]], [[Cookbook:Skillet|skillet]] or [[Cookbook:Griddle|griddle]] to a medium-low temperature. #Use butter, margarine, or cooking spray on the pan. #Soak a slice of bread in the egg-milk mixture and place on pan; repeat until pan is full. #[[Cookbook:Browning|Brown]] both sides of the French toast. #Serve on plates, usually two slices per person, with toppings as desired.
==Tips== The goal is to get both sides of the French toast nicely browned, while making sure the center is cooked. Using excessive heat could scorch the outside of the toast while leaving the inside undercooked.
Also, unless you are making French toast for dozens of people, it is easier to make sure that each slice of bread is evenly soaked in the egg and mix mixture if you make it up in small batches, one egg and 1/4 cup of milk and two slices at a time in one bowl. Then soak the two slices until almost all of the mixture has been absorbed. If your bowl is small, place the two slices on top of each other, then keep switching their position and flipping them (so that all four faces will be down into the mixture) until the mixture is absorbed.
The cooking process is too short to use most raw [[Cookbook:Spices|spices]], but some fresh [[Cookbook:Herbs|herbs]] might be very tasty. {{Wikipedia|French toast}}
[[Category:Breakfast recipes|French Toast]] [[Category:Egg recipes|French Toast]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|French Toast]] [[Category:Featured recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Southwestern recipes|4||2}}
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Southwestern cuisine|Southwestern Cuisine]]
==Ingredients== *2 tablespoons [[Cookbook:Chilli Powder|chilli powder]] *1.5 tablespoons [[Cookbook:Paprika|paprika]] *1 cups diced [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]]s *1/2 tablespoon [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] *2 cloves minced [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]] *1 dash [[Cookbook:Red Pepper|red pepper]] *1 pound [[Cookbook:Ground Beef Substitute|ground beef substitute]] (I use MorningStar Farms Grillers Recipe Crumbles) *1 cup [[Cookbook:Water|water]] *8 [[Cookbook:Floured Tortillas|floured tortillas]]
Makes 8 vegetarian tortillas.
==Suggested Toppings== *1 can [[Cookbook:Refried beans|refried beans]] *1 chopped [[Cookbook:Tomato|tomato]] *1 cup chopped [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]] *2 cups shredded [[Cookbook:Lettuce|lettuce]] *1 cup shredded [[Cookbook:Colby-Jack cheese|Colby-Jack cheese]] (or cheddar) *[[Cookbook:Sour Cream|sour cream]]
==Procedure== *In a [[Cookbook:Frying Pan|frying pan]] brown onions on medium-low heat. *Add garlic, chilli powder, paprika, salt, and red pepper. Stir and cook for one minute. *Add beef substitute and water. Cook for 10-15 minute until most of the water is gone. *Meanwhile chop and shred topping. Put toppings in bowls on table. *Start to warm refried beans in a small pot. *Heat another [[Cookbook:Frying Pan|frying pan]] on medium-low heat. *Put vegetarian taco meat and refried beans in bowls and place on table. *Put floured tortilla in pan and lightly brown both sides.
As tortillas are ready allow guests to select their own toppings.
The filling and refried beans keep well in the refrigerator.
[[Category:Vegetarian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Southwestern recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Dessert recipes|4|30 minutes|2}}
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of France|Cuisine of France]] | [[Cookbook:Dessert|Dessert]]
'''Mousse au chocolat''' (French for "chocolate foam") is a sweet food, normally served as dessert.
==Ingredients==
* 200 g (8 oz) [[Cookbook:Bittersweet chocolate|bittersweet chocolate]], chopped (see Note) * 3 [[Cookbook:Egg|egg]]s (see Note) * 250ml (1 cup) [[Cookbook:Cream|cream]] * 40g [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] * 30 ml (2 tablespoons) hot water
==Preparation== # Melt the chocolate in a [[Cookbook:Double Boiler|double boiler]]. # Separate the eggs. # Whisk the egg whites and cream separately until very firm. Put both in the refrigerator. # Combine the egg yolks and hot water in a mixing bowl (maximum tap water temperature is enough, approx. 50°-60°C or 120°-140°F). Using a [[Cookbook:Mixer|mixer]], beat slowly while adding the sugar, then speed up the mixer until the mixture is thick and becomes a light yellow color. # Stir the melted chocolate into the yolk mixture (the chocolate should have cooled enough that it does not hurt if you insert your finger). Mix immediately, otherwise this will cook the egg yolks, and you'll have chocolate scrambled eggs! # With the whisk (from now on do not use the mixer) add the egg whites in three parts to the chocolate mixture, followed by the whipped cream. # The finished mousse should be light brown and very fluffy. While it is still liquid, divide it into individual serving dishes. Allow to chill in the refrigerator for 4-6 hours before serving. The mousse will be quite firm when ready.
==Notes, tips and variations==
* This recipe is not the "purest" form, which contains only bittersweet chocolate and eggs: 6 eggs for 200 g (8 oz) of chocolate; no cream, no sugar. * It is one of the easiest recipes for untrained cooks. The only "difficult" parts are separating the eggs and folding the egg whites. * Use only the best quality chocolate available. Chocolate from Lindt & Spruengli or their U.S. subsidiary Ghirardelli is highly recommended. * For the more advanced cook: use a fourth yolk (and ''only'' the yolk!); it ensures that the mousse becomes firm. However, the mixture must be worked faster, beginning with the addition of the chocolate to the yolk/sugar mixture. * Instead of the water, use an alcoholic spirit such as Cognac, Cointreau, Kahlua, Triple Sec, etc., for all or part of the 30 ml. However, the mousse is then not suitable for children or pregnant women. * Coffee can also be satisfyingly substituted for the liquid. * Almond powder, almond butter, or orange rind can also be used to add flavor to the mousse (one tablespoon per 6 eggs) * There is also an [[Cookbook:Atkins-friendly Chocolate Mousse|Atkins-friendly recipe]].
==Warnings==
* This mousse is best consumed within 24 hours. * Do not keep substantially longer, even if refrigerated.
[[Category:Dessert recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Chocolate recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:French recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Medium expensive recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Gluten-free recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Recipes_with_metric_units|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[de:Kochbuch/ Mousse au chocolat ohne Sahne]] [[de:Kochbuch/ Mousse au chocolat]] [[fr:Cuisine:Mousse au chocolat]] [[lt:Receptai:Šokolado musas]] [[nl:Kookboek/Chocomousse]]

{{recipesummary|Pasta recipes|4||2}}
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Pasta Recipes|Pasta Recipes]] | [[Cookbook:Vegetarian cuisine|Vegetarian]]
==Ingredients== * 1/2 Tbsp. [[Cookbook:Olive oil|olive oil]] * 1/2 small [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]], minced * 1 400g (15. oz) can of [[Cookbook:Navy beans|navy beans]], drained and chopped * 1/2 tsp. [[Cookbook:Oregano|oregano]] * 1/4 tsp. [[Cookbook:Pepper|pepper]] * one package lasagna noodles * 240ml (1 cup) [[Cookbook:Cottage cheese|cottage cheese]] * 1 clove [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]], minced * 240g (1 cup) [[Cookbook:Tomato Sauce|tomato sauce]] * 240g (1 cup) [[Cookbook:Tomato Puree|tomato puree]] * 1 Tbsp. [[Cookbook:Tomato Paste|tomato paste]] * 1/2 tsp. dried [[Cookbook:Basil|basil]] * 100g - 170g (4-6 oz.) package of [[Cookbook:Mozzarella cheese|mozzarella cheese]], grated * 60ml (1/4 cup) grated [[Cookbook:Parmesan cheese|Parmesan cheese]]
==Procedure== #Cook lasagna noodles. #Start preheating oven for 180 C (350 F). #Saute garlic and onions. #Add the chopped beans and cook for 5 minutes. #Add tomato sauce, tomato puree, tomato paste, oregano, basil, and pepper and cook for 5 minutes. #In a 30cm x 20cm (13 x 9 in.) baking dish, form a layer using half the noodles, cottage cheese, and mozzarella. #Repeat to form a second layer. #Sprinkle top with Parmesan cheese. #Bake uncovered at 180c (350 degrees) for 25 minutes, until noodles are tender and sauce is bubbling.
4 servings.
[[Category:Pasta recipes|Lasagne with bean sauce]] [[Category:Italian recipes|Lasagne with bean sauce]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|Lasagne with bean sauce]] [[Category:Lasagne recipes|Lasagne with bean Sauce]]

{{recipesummary|Breakfast recipes|4|15 minutes|2}}
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|United States]] | [[Cookbook:Breakfast|Breakfast]]
A '''Southwestern Scramble''' is a scrambled eggs recipe with many spicy ingredients, such as onions and chilis. For a complete breakfast, serve with sliced, fried [[Cookbook:Wiejska|wiejska]] ([[Cookbook:Cuisine of Poland|Polish]] [[Cookbook:Sausage|sausage]]), [[Cookbook:Toast|toast]], and [[Cookbook:Orange Juice|orange juice]].
==Ingredients== *8 [[Cookbook:Egg|egg]]s *2 tablespoons (30 [[Cookbook:mL|mL]]) [[Cookbook:Milk|milk]] *1 medium red [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]], chopped *1 medium green [[Cookbook:Chili Pepper|chili pepper]], such as [[Cookbook:Jalapeño|jalapeño]], seeded and chopped *1 green [[Cookbook:Bell Pepper|bell pepper]], seeded and sliced *[[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] and [[Cookbook:Black Pepper|black pepper]], to taste *Serve with [[Cookbook:Hot Sauce|hot sauce]], such as [[Wikipedia:Tabasco sauce|Tabasco sauce]] *[[Cookbook:Butter|butter]], [[Cookbook:Margarine|margarine]], or [[Cookbook:Cooking Spray|cooking spray]], for [[Cookbook:Frying Pan|frying pan]]
==Procedure== #Chop the onion and chili, and slice the bell pepper. Crack the eggs into a large mixing bowl, add the milk, and beat until well combined. #Place a large [[Cookbook:Frying pan|frying pan]] over medium heat, add the butter, margarine, or cooking spray, and allow to melt. Add the onions, chili, and bell pepper, and sauté for 2-4 minutes. #Add the eggs to the pan, and allow to cook for 30 seconds to 1 minute, until they just begin to set. Turn the heat up to high, and begin ''scrambling'' the eggs by scraping the bottom of the pan with a spatula and folding the cooked egg into the egg mixture. #When the eggs are still moist, but mostly cooked, remove from the fire and plate. #Serve while still hot.
==Tips and tricks== *To adjust the spicyness, use more or fewer chili peppers, or use types varying levels of heat. *The chilis are seeded because of the intense heat in the seeds, where the majority of the ''[[w:Capsaicin|capsaicin]]'' is. The seeds can be left in, but the scramble will be much hotter. *Be sure to scrape the entire bottom of the pan, as well as the sides. Otherwise, those areas where the egg is not scraped will burn. *Carryover heat will continue to cook the eggs, so they should be removed from the fire while still slightly underdone, otherwise they will be over cooked.
[[Category:Breakfast recipes|Southwestern Scramble]] [[Category:Egg recipes|Southwestern Scramble]] [[Category:Southwestern recipes|Southwestern Scramble]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Chile recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

revision.text:
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Vegan cuisine|Vegan cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Tex-Mex cuisine|Tex-Mex cuisine]]
This is a kind of [[Cookbook:Chili|Chili]] that needs no meat (and uses no ersatz meat). Many variations are possible; the recipe is very flexible. The molasses gives this chili a somewhat Louisiana flavor.
==Ingredients== * 2 cans red [[Cookbook:Kidney Bean|kidney bean]]s * 1 can [[Cookbook:Black Bean|black bean]]s * 1 can [[Cookbook:Navy Bean|navy bean]]s * 1 can [[Cookbook:Corn|corn]] kernels * 1 can [[Cookbook:Tomato Paste|tomato paste]] * 1 medium [[Cookbook:Tomato|tomato]], chopped (canned diced tomato works too) * 2 fresh [[Cookbook:Jalapeño|jalapeño]]s (or your favorite [[Cookbook:Chili Pepper|chili pepper]] works too; more if you like it really hot) * 1 green [[Cookbook:Bell Pepper|bell pepper]], chopped * 1 red or yellow bell pepper, chopped * 2 medium [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]]s, chopped * 4 medium cloves of [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]], chopped or crushed * 10 [[Cookbook:mL|mL]] [[Cookbook:Chili Powder|chili powder]] * large pinch [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] (to taste; not needed) * pinch of [[Cookbook:Oregano|oregano]] * 10 mL [[Cookbook:Olive Oil|olive oil]] (or any other kind of vegetable oil) * 50 mL [[Cookbook:Molasses|molasses]] * [[Cookbook:Chili Garlic Sauce|chili garlic sauce]] (optional)
==Procedure== In a large pot, heat the olive oil with a few drops of water. When the water starts sizzling, add the onions and garlic. Stir until the onions are soft (optionally until they are slightly brown). Add the chili peppers and fry for a few more seconds. Add the tomato paste and tomato, and the chili powder, salt, and oregano. Stir a few times then let [[Cookbook:Boiling|boil]] and [[Cookbook:Simmering|simmer]].
Wash the slime from the cans off the beans. Add the beans and corn. Add the molasses. Taste the chili; if it needs more seasoning, add it now (perhaps with the exception of salt, as people can add this at the table). It is probably better not to add more jalapeños at this point, but if the chili is not spicy enough, some chili sauce or chili garlic sauce can be added. Let the pot simmer, covered, for at least 30 minutes - longer will distribute the flavor better. If the chili is too thick, add a little water; if it's too thin, uncover the pot.
Add the bell peppers, stir, and simmer for a minute or two (peppers should stay crunchy). Serve with [[Cookbook:Bread|bread]]; makes about 8 bowls, which are very filling. Keeps well, perhaps even better the second day.
''Cook's Note:'' In making this recipe, when I got to the [[Cookbook:Boiling|boil]] part, there was no liquid in the pot to boil. I added two cups of vegetable broth, which seemed to work well, but next time I'll try a large can of diced tomatoes.
''Cook's Note:'' It's not clear how large each of the cans should be. Canned tomatoes in particular can come in much larger sizes than canned beans.
[[Category:Vegan recipes|Chili]] [[Category:Southwestern recipes|Chili]] [[Category:Chili recipes]] [[Category:Stew recipes]] [[category:Gluten-free recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

revision.text:
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|US Cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:New England cuisine|New England cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Southern cuisine|Southern Cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Soup|Soup]]
'''Chowder''' is any of a variety of soups, most of them thick and made with [[Cookbook:Potato|potato]]es. To some Americans, it means clam chowder, made with [[Cookbook:Cream|cream]] or [[Cookbook:Milk|milk]] as [[Cookbook:New England Clam Chowder|New England Clam Chowder]], or with [[Cookbook:Tomato|tomato]] as [[Cookbook:Manhattan Clam Chowder|Manhattan Clam Chowder]]." [[Cookbook:Corn Chowder|Corn Chowder]] is a thick soup filled with whole corn ([[Cookbook:Maize|maize]]) kernels. Chowder is often commonly associated with the [[Cookbook:New England cuisine|New England]] region of the United States.
The recipe below for "New England chowder" is, oddly, not a clam chowder.
From the 1881 ''Household Cyclopedia''
==New England Chowder==
Have a good haddock, cod, or any other solid fish; cut it in pieces three inches square, put a pound of fat salt pork in strips into the pot, set it on hot coals and fry out the oil; take out the pork and put in a layer of fish, over that a layer of onions in slices, then a layer of fish with slips of fat salt pork, then another layer of onions, and so on alternately until your fish is consumed; mix some flour with as much water as will fill the pot; season with black pepper and salt to your taste, and boil it for half an hour. Have ready some crackers (Philadelphia pilot bread if you can get it) soaked in water till they are a little softened; throw them into your chowder five minutes before you take it up. Serve in a tureen.
This is similar to the traditional Scottish soup [[Cookbook:Cullen skink|cullen skink]].
==Daniel Webster's Chowder==
Four tablespoonfuls of onions, fried with pork; a quart of boiled potatoes well mashed; 1 1/2 pounds of sea biscuit broken; 1 teaspoonful of thyme mixed with one of summer savory: 1/2 bottle of mushroom catsup; one bottle of port or claret; 1/4 of a nutmeg, grated; a few cloves, mace, and allspice; 6 pounds fish (sea-bass or cod), cut into slices; 25 oysters, a little black pepper, and a few slices of lemon. The whole put in a pot and covered with an inch of water, boiled for an hour and gently stirred.
[[Category:Soup recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:American recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Fish recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Pork recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Oyster recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Vegetarian cuisine|Vegetarian cuisine]]
== Ingredients ==
* 4 large [[Cookbook:Mushroom|Portobello mushrooms]] * [[Cookbook:Balsamic vinegar|balsamic vinegar]] * [[Cookbook:Garlic|Garlic]], minced * 1 [[Cookbook:Egg|Egg]] * 1/2 cup [[Cookbook:Cottage Cheese|cottage cheese]] * 4 oz [[Cookbook:Mozzarella cheese|mozzarella cheese]] (fresh or regular), diced or grated * 10 [[Cookbook:Saltine crackers|Saltine crackers]], crushed or 1/2 cup [[Cookbook:Bread Crumb|bread crumbs]] * Garlic * [[Cookbook:Salt|Salt]], [[Cookbook:Pepper|pepper]], other seasonings to taste
== Procedure == #Generously sprinkle vinegar over the mushrooms, and top with garlic. Leave for 30 mins or so. #Combine the rest of the ingredients in a bowl (egg, cheeses, crackers and seasonings). Mix well. Spoon the mixture onto the mushrooms. #Bake at 350 °F for 40 minutes.
Serves 4.
[[Category:Mushroom recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Cheese recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Vegan cuisine|Vegan Cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Soups|Soups]]
== Ingredients ==
* 1 or 2 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoons]] [[Cookbook:Olive oil|olive oil]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]], diced * 2 [[Cookbook:Carrot|carrots]], diced * 2 cloves [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]], minced * 1/2 [[Cookbook:Pound|lb]] dry red [[Cookbook:Lentil|lentils]] * 6 [[Cookbook:Cup|cups]] water or [[Cookbook:Stock|stock]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Bay leaf|bay leaf]]
== Procedure ==
#Pick over the lentils and remove any stones etc. Rinse well. #Heat the olive oil in a large pan over medium heat. Once oil is hot, add the onion and carrots. Cook for a few minutes, until the vegetables have started to soften, then add the garlic. #Add the lentils, bay leaf, and water to the pot. Simmer over low-medium heat for 20-30 minutes, until lentils are softened.
Serves 4.
== Optional Additions ==
Herbs and/or spices can be added to the sauteing vegetables, such as [[Cookbook:Cumin|cumin]], [[Cookbook:Thyme|thyme]], [[Cookbook:Oregano|oregano]], [[Cookbook:Red Pepper|red pepper]] flakes.
[[Cookbook:Hot sauce|Hot sauce]] can be added to taste. Freshly squeezed [[Cookbook:Lemon juice|lemon juice]] is a nice addition, preferably immediately before serving.
[[Category:Vegan recipes|Lentil soup]] [[Category:Soup recipes|Lentil soup]] [[Category:Lentil recipes|Lentil soup]]

page.title: Cookbook:Ceviche of Shrimp and Sea Bass

revision.text:
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Seafood|Seafood]] | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Peru|Cuisine of Peru]]
Ceviche (or cebiche) is the most famous dish of Peru. In its classic form, it is composed of chunks of raw fish, lime juice, chopped onion, and minced ''ají limo'' or ''rocoto'', both types of [[Cookbook:Chilli Pepper|chile]]s. The recipe below for '''Ceviche of Shrimp and Sea Bass''' is not "authentic" but should be edible.
==Ingredients== *1 pound [[Cookbook:Shrimp|Shrimp]] (16/20 per pound), peeled and cleaned *2 pounds meaty [[Cookbook:white fish|white fish]], such as [[Cookbook:Sea bass|Sea bass]], boned, and cut into large dice *1 red [[Cookbook:Onion|Onion]], minced *1 piece [[Cookbook:Ginger|Ginger]], peeled, minced *1 clove [[Cookbook:Garlic|Garlic]], minced *1/4 Habañero or Scotch bonnet [[Cookbook:Chile Pepper|Pepper]], minced (no seeds or ribs) *1 [[Cookbook:Celery|Celery]] rib, minced *[[Cookbook:Salt|Salt]] and [[Cookbook:Black Pepper|Black Pepper]] *5 [[Cookbook:Lemon|Lemon]]s, juiced *5 [[Cookbook:Lime|Lime]]s, juiced *1 bunch [[Cookbook:Cilantro|Cilantro]], chopped *2 ears of [[Cookbook:Maize|Corn]], grilled with husk on
==Procedure== #[[Cookbook:Boil|Boil]] salted water. Have ice water ready on the side. [[Cookbook:Poach|Poach]] shrimp for just 30 seconds and cool in ice water and drain. #Combine with fish and toss with onion, ginger, garlic, hot pepper, celery, salt, and black pepper. Allow to cool in the refrigerator at least 30 minutes and up to 2 hours. #Add lemon and lime juices and refrigerate 1 additional hour. Finish with cilantro and corn, check seasoning.
Yield: 8 to 12 servings Prep Time: 2 hours
{{wikipedia|Ceviche}}
[[Category:Peruvian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Fish recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Shrimp recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[category:Gluten-free recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:California cuisine|California cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Seafood|Seafood]] | [[Cookbook:Appetizers|Appetizers]]
A ''ceviche'' is a raw seafood dish, originating in [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Peru|Peru]]. This recipe adds a bit of a [[Cookbook:California cuisine|California]] twist by adding sliced [[Cookbook:Avocado|avocado]] to the dish.
==Ingredients== *1 [[Cookbook:Pound|pound]] (450 [[Cookbook:g|g]]) [[Cookbook:Scallop|bay scallops]] *1/2 [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] (125 [[Cookbook:mL|mL]]) [[Cookbook:Lemon Juice|lemon juice]] (about 3-4 lemons) *4 red [[Cookbook:Bell Pepper|bell peppers]], roasted, peeled, and seeded *2 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoons]] (30 mL) [[Cookbook:Balsamic vinegar|balsamic vinegar]] *2 tablespoons (30 mL) extra-virgin [[Cookbook:Olive Oil|olive oil]] *1/2 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoon]] (2.5 mL) [[Cookbook:Cayenne pepper|cayenne pepper]], ground *[[Cookbook:Salt|salt]], to taste *1 [[Cookbook:Avocado|avocado]], peeled and sliced
==Procedure== #In a non-reactive bowl, combine the scallops and lemon juice, add more juice as needed to cover the scallops. Refrigerate, covered, and stir often for 2 hours, until the scallops become opaque. #For the [[Cookbook:Sauce|sauce]], add the bell peppers, vinegar, oil, cayenne, and salt into a [[Cookbook:Food Processor|food processor]] or [[Cookbook:Blender|blender]], and [[Cookbook:Purée|purée]]. #To serve, spoon the sauce onto individual plates, drain the scallops and place on the sauce. Garnish with slices of avocado.
Serves 4 as a main dish, 6 as an appetizer.
==Variations== *For a more [[Cookbook:Southwestern cuisine|Southwestern]] flavor, replace 1/4 cup lemon juice with [[Cookbook:Lime Juice|lime juice]], and replace the bell peppers with New Mexico [[Cookbook:Chili Pepper|chili peppers]].
==Warning== Eating raw seafood is an effective way to get sick. Scallops are filter feeders found near shore, which makes them particularly filthy if sourced from a polluted area. Make sure you buy your scallops the day you plan to serve them, from a reputable fishmonger who can tell you something about where the scallops have come from, and when they were collected.
[[Category:Californian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Scallop recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Raw recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Soups|Soups]] | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Italy|Cuisine of Italy]]
'''Soup with Supplì''' - This recipe is not traditional in Italy, where the preparation stops at the cooking of the ''supplì'' (risotto balls), which are actually a little bigger than eggs.
==Ingredients== *left over [[Cookbook:Risotto|Risotto]], *[[Cookbook:Egg|Egg]]s, beaten *[[Cookbook:Bread crumbs|Bread crumbs]] *clear or brown soup
==Procedure== If you have some good risotto left, you can use it up by making it into little balls the size of nuts. Egg and bread crumb and fry them in butter; dry them and put them into a soup tureen with hot soup. The soup may be either clear or brown.
{{decameron}}
[[Category:Rice recipes|Soup with Supplì]] [[Category:Italian recipes|Soup with Supplì]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Soup recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Flatbread recipes||1-2 hours|1|Image=[[Image:Hartkeks offen.jpg|300px]]}}
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Flatbread|Flatbread]] | [[Cookbook:Vegan cuisine|Vegan Cuisine]]
'''Hard tack''' was used during long sea voyages and military campaigns as a primary foodstuff usually dunked in water, brine, coffee or some other liquid or cooked into a skillet meal. This cracker was little more than flour and water which had been [[Cookbook:Baking|baked]] hard and would keep for months as long as it was kept dry. Also known as a sea biscuit, sea bread, or ship's biscuits.
==Ingredients== *2 cups of [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] *½ to ¾ cup water *6 pinches of [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] *1 tablespoon of [[Cookbook:Shortening|shortening]] (optional)
==Procedure== # Mix all the ingredients into a dough and press onto a cookie sheet to a thickness of ½ inch. # Bake in a preheated oven at 400°F (205°C) for one hour. # Remove from oven, cut dough into 3-inch squares, and punch four rows of holes, four holes per row into the dough (a fork works nicely). # Flip the crackers and return to the oven for another half hour.
==Notes, tips, and variations== {{wikipedia|Hardtack}} * Some recipes also recommend a second baking at 250°F (120°C) to thoroughly dry out the bread.
[[Category:Vegan recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Flatbread recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Baked recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

revision.text:
{{cookwork}}
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Japan|Cuisine of Japan]]
== Introduction to Sushi == Beginning as a method of [[Cookbook:Pickling|pickling]] [[Cookbook:Fish|fish]] centuries ago, '''sushi''' has evolved into an artful, unique dining experience. In its earliest form, fish was placed between two wads of [[Cookbook:Rice|rice]], producing a moderately complex chemical reaction as the fish fermented helping preserve it. Sometime between the 14th and 16th centuries, rice vinegar started to be added to the rice to help speed up the process which took several months. Around this time the rice also started to be consumed with the fish it was used to preserve. ''[[Cookbook:Nori|Nori]]'' (red algae [[Cookbook:Seaweed|seaweed]] paper) was added about this period as a way to keep one's fingers from getting sticky, thus creating the first ancestor of modern 'makizushi', or rolled sushi.
Sometime in the mid to late 18th century a restaurant in Edo (modern Tokyo) started serving sushi rice alone with thinly sliced fresh fish pressed into it. This was the start of Edo-Mae sushi, which is also known as 'nigirizushi', or pressed sushi.
Sometime after this, some chef took this one step further and eliminated the sushi rice all together, the birth of sashimi. It is important to note that sashimi specifically refers to thinly sliced raw or mostly raw fish and shellfish.
It is hard to tell when exactly the wasabi and pickled ginger were added, but it is probable they came in with the Edo-Mae sushi, as this was when the focus of sushi became enjoying the taste of the exceedingly fresh fish, and the condiments heighten the experience.
Technically, the word "sushi" refers to the vinegared rice, but, colloquially, the term is used to describe a finger-size piece of raw fish or [[Cookbook:Shellfish|shellfish]] on a bed of vinegared rice. This can be eaten as is or dipped into ''shoyu'' (Japanese [[Cookbook:Soy Sauce|soy sauce]]) and then eaten. Much care is put into the creation of the dish and the many methods of preparing the food indicate the importance of appearance to the educated consumer.
==Types of Sushi== Sushi types include ''makizushi'', ''nigirizushi'', ''oshizushi'', and ''inarizushi''.
Makizushi (''rolled sushi''), or maki for short, is the kind that is most common to North American consumers (see [[Cookbook:California Roll|California Rolls]]) as it is basically sushi layered on top of nori, rolled into a tube, and cut into thick slices. Easy to make and even easier to mass produce, it has found a wide proliferation as a new form of fast food, but still manages to be found in Japanese restaurants that still respect the tradition.
Nigirizushi (''hand formed sushi''), or nigiri for short, is, as stated above, a hand-formed small bed of rice with an ingredient on top (ranging from [[Cookbook:Tuna|tuna]] or [[Cookbook:Salmon|salmon]] to [[Cookbook:Eel|eel]] or [[Cookbook:Egg|egg]]). Nigiri sushi that is served without the rice is called ''sashimi''. Gunkanmaki (''battleship roll or boat sushi'') is a nigirizushi where an oval piece of sushi rice is surrounded by nori and topped with a topping such as fish eggs.
Oshizushi (''pressed sushi'') is similar to nigirizushi but it is formed by pressing with the aid of an oshibako, a wooden mold. Generally, the topping is placed in the oshibako first, the rice is added on top, then the combination is pressed together with the oshibako top or lid. After pressing, the sushi is removed and cut to serving sizes.
Inarizushi (''stuffed sushi'') is generally a pocket or pouch containing the rice and other ingredients. Materials used to make the pocket include tofu, egg, and cabbage leaves.
Sashimi (basically "sliced raw fish without any rice") is often the most artistic form, with thin slices of fish and shellfish being formed into a range of diffrent shapes, especially flowers. While technically not sushi, sashimi is often grouped together with the different types of sushi.
''Saikuzushi'' is an artistic type of sushi, which makes a beautiful image. It is quite difficult to make this, and also quite expensive when bought. Rice is tinted with different colors and later sliced to make an image.
''Chirashizushi'', or scattered sushi has rice in a box or bowl and seaweed on top. Different kinds of seafood and fish is placed on top, including octopus, squid, tuna, alongside with chopped cucumbers and green onion.
''Edomae'' - or ''Temakizushi'' - is one of the most common sushi, with rice and fish rolled up in seaweed. Crab, octopus, tuna, shrimp, and several other types of seafood is rolled up inside the rice. It is even found in convenience stores in Japan.
== How to try sushi for the first time == Make sure your order is a complete sushi experience that, at minimum, includes [[Cookbook:Miso_Soup|miso soup]], [[Cookbook:Maki|makizushi]] (rolls), [[Cookbook:Sashimi|sashimi]] (pieces of fish), [[Cookbook:Nigirizushi|nigirizushi]], and garnishes of [[Cookbook:Wasabi|wasabi]], [[Cookbook:Soy Sauce|soy sauce]], and pickled ginger. Hot, fresh, green tea is an excellent beverage to drink with your meal.
Mix a small amount of wasabi and soy sauce in the small dish, which will be provided in a sushi restaurant, to a consistency and spicyness that you find enjoyable; you will dip your sushi into it to enhance the flavor. Note: In Japan, it is considered poor dining etiquette to mix wasabi into one's soy sauce. This is because Japanese sushi chefs will apply a small amount of wasabi to the appropriate types of sushi during preparation. For example, sushi that features its own unique sauce will be prepared sans wasabi so as not to compromise the flavor.
Start your meal with simple miso soup but do not spend too much time on any one item as this is the proper [[wikipedia:Customs and etiquette of Japan#Eating and drinking|Japanese etiquette]], instead rotate through your meal to appreciate the quality of each aspect. Many people start with a mild sushi, such as tamago — a sweet, cold omelette — and end with a stronger taste at the end of the meal, like darker fish. Between different items it is recommended that a piece of pickled ginger be eaten to cleanse the palate and ensure that none of the subtle flavor of the sushi is missed.
Enjoy!
==Recipes== * [[Cookbook:Sushi Rice|Sushi Rice]] * [[Cookbook:Maki|Rolled Sushi (Maki)]] * [[Cookbook:Stewed Vegan Maki|Stewed Vegan Maki]] * [[Cookbook:Inarizushi|Inarizushi]] * [[Cookbook:Nigirizushi|Nigirizushi]] * [[Cookbook:Gunkanmaki|Gunkanmaki]]
==Serving Sushi== There are different types of seafood used for sushi, and the most common ones are tuna, salmon, squid and octopus. Using expensive seaweed makes sushi taste much better. Expensive seaweed is darker in color, and is less likely to break when folded or rolled. Cheap seaweed is usually greenish in color. The type of soy sauce (shoyu) used also affects the taste of the sushi; the most commonly used brands are Kikkoman and Yamasa. Many people like to mix wasabi with their shoyu, which makes it quite spicy and wakening.
===Condiments=== Sushi is generally served with * [[Cookbook:Wasabi|wasabi]] * green [[Cookbook:Horseradish|horseradish]] (a cheap wasabi substitute) * gari ([[Cookbook:Pickling|pickled]] [[Cookbook:Ginger|ginger]]) * [[Cookbook:Soy Sauce|soy sauce]] * kabayaki sauce ([[Cookbook:eel_sauce|eel sauce]]) (often served on some sushi, may be used for dipping instead of soy sauce)
[[Category:Japanese recipes|Sushi]] [[Category:Rice recipes|Sushi]] [[Category:Fish recipes|Sushi]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Salad Recipes|Salad Recipes]]
==Ingredients== * 1 can [[Cookbook:Tuna|tuna]] * 1 can [[Cookbook:Water Chestnut|water chestnuts]], drained and chopped * ½ small [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]], chopped * 1-2 stalks [[Cookbook:Celery|celery]], chopped * ½ cup [[Cookbook:Carrot|carrot]], shredded * ½ cup [[Cookbook:Mayonnaise|mayonnaise]] * 1 tablespoon [[Cookbook:Dijon Mustard|Dijon mustard]] * 1 teaspoon [[Cookbook:Soy Sauce|soy sauce]] * [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] and [[Cookbook:Pepper|pepper]] to taste
==Alternative Ingredients== * 1 can [[Cookbook:Tuna|tuna]], drained * 2 tablespoons [[Cookbook:Mayonnaise|mayonnaise]] * ¼ small [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]], chopped
==Procedure== #Mix ingredients in a bowl. #Chill before serving.
Best served on toast.
2-4 servings.
[[Category:Salad recipes|Tuna salad]] [[Category:Seafood recipes|Tuna salad]] [[Category:Tuna recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]
