{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Peru|Cuisine of Peru]]
{{recipesummary|Chicken recipes|16|60 minutes|3}}
'''Arroz con Pollo''' means "Rice with Chicken" in Spanish. It is a traditional dish that is common throughout Latin America (with regional variations).
==Ingredients == *8 small boneless and skinless [[Cookbook:Chicken|chicken breasts]] *5 cloves of fresh [[Cookbook:garlic|garlic]] *1 small finely chopped [[Cookbook:onion|onions]] *3 cups [[Cookbook:rice|rice]] (not instant) *10 cups [[Cookbook:bouillon|chicken bouillon]] *1 cup chopped [[Cookbook:cilantro|cilantro]] (see notes, below) *4 cups [[Cookbook:peas|frozen peas]] *2 [[Cookbook:Peppers|red bell peppers]] cut in very thin strips *2 cups of green pitted [[Cookbook:olive|olive]]s *1/2 teaspoon [[Cookbook:paprika|paprika]] *2 tablespoons [[Cookbook:olive oil|olive oil]] *1 medium [[Cookbook:onion|onion]], chopped *1 can (15 ounce) [[Cookbook:tomato|tomato]]es, diced, drained *2 large cloves [[Cookbook:garlic|garlic]], minced *1/4 teaspoon [[Cookbook:Red Chile Sauce|hot pepper sauce]] *2 1/2 cups [[Cookbook:chicken broth|chicken broth]] *8 [[Cookbook:saffron|saffron]] threads *[[Cookbook:Salt|Salt]] and [[Cookbook:pepper|pepper]] to give taste
==Preparation (1 hour)== #Add the rice and red bell pepper. #[[Cookbook:Sauté|Sauté]] salted and peppered chicken breasts in oil until browned and cooked completely; remove. #In the same oil, cook the garlic and onion until tender. #Cook over medium heat until liquid is absorbed. #Combine the chicken to the garlic and onion. #Add the cilantro and boullion and [[Cookbook:boil|boil]]. #Add peas and continue to simmer over low heat until rice is cooked.
== Notes and Tips == *To reduce the amount of servings to 4, divide each ingredient by 4. *In the original recipe, the procedure called to blend the cilantro with 1/2 cup [[Cookbook:water|water]] and then [[Cookbook:drain|drain]] the water. However, this is not necessary.
[[Category:Peruvian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[category:Gluten-free recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Rice recipes|6|45 minutes|3}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Peru|Cuisine of Peru]]
[[Image:ArrozTapado.jpg|A serve of ''Arroz Tapado'']]
==Ingredients== * 3 cloves of [[Cookbook:garlic|garlic]], minced * 2 tablespoons of [[Cookbook:olive oil|olive oil]] * [[Cookbook:Lemon juice|Lemon juice]] * [[Cookbook:Salt|Salt]] * 4 cups [[Cookbook:water|water]] * 1 pound washed [[Cookbook:rice|rice]] * 1 [[Cookbook:onion|onion]], finely chopped * 2 pound of ground beef * 2 [[Cookbook:tomato|tomato]]es, finely chopped * 1 tablespoon [[Cookbook:tomato paste|tomato paste]] * 4 tablespoons of [[Cookbook:raisins|raisins]] * 5 [[Cookbook:black olive|black olive]]s, chopped * 2 [[Cookbook:hard boiled egg|hard boiled egg]]s, chopped * 1 tablespoon of finely minced [[Cookbook:parsley|parsley]]
==Preparation== # [[Cookbook:Sauté|Sauté]] the garlic in oil, add a few drops of lemon juice, salt and the water and bring to a [[Cookbook:boil|boil]]. Add rice and cook for 20-25 minutes or just tender # In other pan, stir in onions and sauté, add meat, tomatoes, tomato paste, raisins, olives, egg and parsley # Take a one-cup glass [[Cookbook:measuring cup|measuring cup]] and coat the inside with a little oil. Fill halfway with rice, add some meat filling and add more rice to top of cup. Invert onto a plate and carefully remove cup
[[Category:Rice recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Peruvian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[category:Gluten-free recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}}
This eggy, sweet pie is easy to make—it forms its own crust as it cooks! Delicious for dessert or a sweet breakfast.
== Ingredients == *2 cup [[Cookbook:milk|milk]] *1/2 cup [[Cookbook:flour|flour]] *1/3 teaspoon [[Cookbook:baking powder|baking powder]] *1 pinch [[Cookbook:salt|salt]] *3 tablespoon soft [[Cookbook:butter|butter]] *4 large [[Cookbook:egg|egg]]s *1/3 cup [[Cookbook:sugar|sugar]] *1 teaspoon [[Cookbook:vanilla extract|vanilla extract]] *grated [[Cookbook:coconut|coconut]]
== Procedure == # [[Cookbook:Blend|Blend]] all ingredients for one minute in a [[Cookbook:blender|blender]]. # Pour into a buttered 9-inch pie plate. # [[Cookbook:Bake|Bake]] 30 minutes at 400°F (200°C) (Gas Mark 6) or until a knife inserted one inch comes out clean.
[[Category:Pie recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Dessert recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Pudding and Custard recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Peru|Cuisine of Peru]] {{recipesummary|Appetizer recipes|6-8|3 hours|2|Image=[[Image:Ceviche.png|300px]]}}
==Ingredients== * 2 pounds of [[Cookbook:white fish|white fish]] ([[Cookbook:mahi mahi|mahi mahi]] is an excellent choice) * juice from about 6 large [[Cookbook:Lime|limes]] * 2 [[Cookbook:Chili Pepper|red peppers]], diced * 2 finely diced [[Cookbook:Jalapeño|jalapeño pepper]]s (to your preference) * [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] and [[Cookbook:pepper|pepper]] to taste * 1 large [[Cookbook:onion|onion]], sliced into half-rings * bunch of finely chopped [[Cookbook:cilantro|cilantro]]
;Sides: * 2 [[Cookbook:lettuce|lettuce]] leaves per plate * 12 to 16 [[Cookbook:Corn|corn]] cobs cut into 2 inch pieces, cooked as usual * 3 or 4 [[Cookbook:Sweet Potato|sweet potato]]es, boiled and peeled
==Procedure== # Wash and de-bone the fish and cut them into ½ inch x ½ inch chunks. # Season the fish with salt, pepper, red pepper and jalapeño. [[Cookbook:Marinating|Marinate]] the fish for 1 hour to ”cold cook”. You should have enough lime juice to completely cover the fish. # Add onion. Mix gently. Marinate for 1 more hour. # Serve on a bed of lettuce and add two pieces of corn on the cob and a portion of the sweet potato.
==Notes== * Ceviche (an alternate spelling) can be eaten as an entrée as well. In this case, this will be enough for about two people. * More traditional recipes call for much less marinating. In fact, some will marinate it for as little as 10 minutes total (basically just the time it takes to get the sides ready). If marinating for a small amount of time be aware that the acidity of the lime is the only thing that "cooks" the fish.
[[Category:Gluten-free recipes]] [[Category:Peruvian recipes]] [[Category:Fish recipes]] [[Category:Corn recipes]] [[Category:Sweet Potato recipes]]
--[[User:190.42.220.16|190.42.220.16]] 18:26, 29 September 2007 (UTC)

{{recipesummary|Potato recipes|6 or more|1 hour|2}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Peru|Cuisine of Peru]]
==Ingredients== * 10 medium [[Cookbook:Potato|potatoes]] (new or red a good choice) * 1 pound of [[Cookbook:Cheese|cheese]] (Romano, Mexican or feta work well) * 2 small [[Cookbook:Jalapeño|jalapeño peppers]] * 1 cup [[Cookbook:Evaporated milk|evaporated milk]] * ½ cup [[Cookbook:Vegetable oil|vegetable oil]] * 2 cloves [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]] * 8 [[Cookbook:Saltine Cracker|saltine crackers]] * 1 tablespoon prepared [[Cookbook:Mustard|mustard]] * [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] and [[Cookbook:Pepper|pepper]] * [[Cookbook:Lettuce|lettuce]] * 3 [[Cookbook:Hard Boiled Eggs|hard boiled eggs]] * [[Cookbook:Olive|black olives]]
==Preparation== # Peel and boil potatoes as you normally would. Drain water, and allow them to cool. # In a blender, mix the cheese, peppers, milk, oil, garlic, crackers, mustard, salt and pepper. The sauce should be fairly thick; add more crackers if not, or add milk if too thick # Lay a bed of lettuce in a serving dish and place the potatoes on top. Cover with the sauce. Cut the hard boiled eggs in half and place on top of the potatoes. Add black olives if desired # This dish can be served slightly cold # Some recipes suggest the use of Huacatay, but this is a confusion. Huacatay is a key ingredient of Ocopa, another peruvian sauce
{{wikipedia|Papa a la huancaina}}
[[Category:Potato recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Cheese recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Peruvian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Fish|Fish]]
These '''Fried Fish''' are battered and [[Cookbook:Deep frying|deep-fat fried]]. You'll need thin fish filets that don't fall apart when cooked. Fried fish go well with soda (pop). They can be served with [[Cookbook:Ketchup|ketchup]] (catsup), [[Cookbook:Lemon Juice|lemon juice]], or a mixture of the two. They could also be served with [[Cookbook:Sweet and Sour|sweet-and-sour]] sauce or [[Cookbook:Teriyaki Sauce|teriaki]] sauce. Fried fish are a part of [[Cookbook:Fish and Chips|fish and chips]].
==Ingredients==
* ''thin'' [[Cookbook:Fish|fish]] filets (suggested: catfish, tilapia, or the less-durable flounder) * [[Cookbook:Oil|Oil]] with a high [[Smoke point|smoke point]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Egg|Egg]] white * 1 [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] * 1 cup [[Cookbook:Beer|beer]], or 1 cup cold water and 1/2 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoon]] [[Cookbook:Baking Powder|baking powder]] * extra flour to dust the fish
==Procedure== #Start heating the oil. This recipe is intended for fast cooking in very hot oil. #Get the batter ingredients ready to mix. #Microwave the fish, to ensure that the inside is hot. Flip the fish as you microwave it. When done, the fish should be hot and should look half-cooked. #Mix the flour, egg white, and beer. #Pat a fish dry with a paper towel, then lightly dust it with flour to ensure that it is really dry. #Dip the fish, and your hand, into the batter. Coat them well. The batter will help protect your hand from splatter. #Hold the fish right above the oil, then gently slide the fish into the oil. #With tongs, nudge the fish as needed to keep it from sticking to the bottom. Turn the fish over as it cooks. #Remove the fish when it looks good, then serve it immediately.
==Warning== When a pot of hot oil catches fire, the flames will reach up for 2 or 3 feet. If you must work under flammable cabinets or shelves, be sure to have a fire extinguisher handy. [[Cookbook:Soybean Oil|Soybean oil]], [[Cookbook:Shortening|shortening]], and [[Cookbook:Peanut Oil|peanut oil]] withstand heat better than most cooking oils.
==Variation== Whip the egg white, or leave it out entirely. Add [[Cookbook:Cornmeal|cornmeal]] to the batter.
[[Category:Fish recipes|Fried Fish]] [[Category:Beer recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Meat Recipes|Meat Recipes]] [[Image:CookbookTurkeyWrap.jpg|thumb|192px|turkey wrap]] The '''Turkey Wrap''' works well as an everyday meal. Chicken may be used in place of turkey, but is not as nice and often costs more per pound.
==Ingredients==
* 8 large ([[Cookbook:Burrito|burrito]]-size, about 12-inch) [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] [[Cookbook:Tortilla|tortillas]]. * 6 [[Cookbook:Ounce|ounce]] can of [[Cookbook:Tomato Paste|tomato paste]] * 6 ounce (net drained weight) [[Cookbook:Black Olive|black olives]] * several [[Cookbook:Cup|cups]] of cooked [[Cookbook:Turkey|turkey]]
==Procedure== #Cut the olives in half. #Cut the turkey into 3/4-inch chunks. #Mix the olives and tomato paste. #Mix in turkey, adding as much as will be covered by the paste. #Optionally, warm the mixture. #Place some of the mixture on a tortilla. #Wrap the tortilla around the mixture. #Place the finished wrap on an ungreased cookie sheet, with the exposed edge (flap) downward to prevent the wrap from coming undone before it is cooked. #Keep making wraps as needed. #Place the cookie sheet in an oven set to [[Cookbook:Oven_temperatures|350°F]]. #Remove the wraps when they start to brown, which should be about 15 minutes. #Let the wraps cool a bit on the outside while heat sinks into the inside.
[[Category:Turkey recipes|Turkey Wrap]] [[Category:Olive recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Tomato recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine_of_Japan|Cuisine of Japan]]
'''Ume juice''' is extracted by preserving the fruits in sugar. It tastes sweet and acidic, and is a refreshing drink, often enjoyed in the summer. '''Ume-shu''' is sweet and smooth. The taste and aroma of ume-shu can appeal to even those people who normally dislike the taste of [[Cookbook:Alcohol|alcohol]]. ==Ingredients== *Raw ume: 1kg *Hard rock sugar: 1kg *[[Cookbook:Honey|Honey]]: to taste *(White liquor: a bit to taste) *A container: preferably a sealable glassware container.
==Procedure== #Wash raw ume and wipe clean of moisture. #Cram tightly into container with rock sugar. White liquor can be poured in at this time. #Pour honey into container on top of ume. #Leave in a cool, dark place until fruit are shriveled and leathery. #Remove fruit from container.
Dilute this liquid with two times as much water to drink. Should be kept in a cool place during summer.
[[Category:Japanese recipes|Ume-shu]] [[Category:Ume recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Beverage recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Recipes_with_metric_units|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine_of_Japan|Cuisine of Japan]]
'''Umeboshi''' (梅干, pickled [[Ume|Japanese plum]]) is a kind of [[Cookbook:Pickling|pickled]] food . It's one of the Japanese traditional foods and it has been popular in Japan. It is red, round, and its taste ranges from sour to sweet. Texture ranges from dry and crunchy to saturated and globby, depending on the method it was preserved.
==Ingredients== *Japanese plums *Red shiso *Salts
==How to make umeboshi== #Wash Japanese plums and wipe them dry. #Remove their stems. #Put salt and newly destemmed plums in the jar. #Turn them repeatedly and vigorously. #Put on inner lid. #Place big, heavy rock on top of lid to increase the pressuring done to the plums. #Wait until the water increases in the jar. #Weather the Japanese plums for 3 days and 3 nights of sunny day in high summer. (Don't throw away the water in the jar.) #During step #8, rub salt into red shiso to remove scum. #Put the Japanese plums and red shiso into the jar with the water.
[[Category:Japanese recipes|Umeboshi]] [[Category:Plum recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Mexico|Cuisine of Mexico]] [[Image:BurritoAbove.jpg|right|thumb|250px|Burritos]]
==General Philosophy of the Burrito== Every burrito is a [[Cookbook:Tortilla|tortilla]] filled with some prescribed acceptable fillings. Generally, the filling includes meat such as [[Cookbook:Pork|pork]], [[Cookbook:Beef|beef]], or [[Cookbook:Chicken|chicken]], but also often includes beans and/or rice.
==Ingredients==
===Necessary Ingredients=== * large [[Cookbook:Flour Tortilla|flour tortilla]] * filling
===Possible Fillings=== {| class='wikitable' | style='vertical-align: top' | * meat **[[Cookbook:Pork|pork]] **lean ground or shredded [[Cookbook:Beef|beef]] ** ground or shredded [[Cookbook:Chicken|chicken]] ** ''[[Cookbook:Chorizo|Chorizo]]'' - a [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Spain|Spanish]] [[Cookbook:Sausage|sausage]] ** Picadillo (Mexican meat and potato filling) **cooked and shredded [[Cookbook:Fish|fish]] * vegetables ** beans/pulses - e.g. [[Cookbook:Pinto Bean|pinto bean]]s, [[Cookbook:Black Bean|black bean]]s, [[Cookbook:Refried Beans|refried beans]] ** crushed [[Cookbook:Tomato|tomato]]es ** sliced [[Cookbook:Olive|black olive]]s ** [[Cookbook:Lettuce|lettuce]] ** [[Cookbook:Avocado|avocado]]s ** [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]]s ** [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]]s | style='vertical-align: top' | * grains * [[Cookbook:Rice|rice]] (usually [[Cookbook:Mexican Rice|Mexican rice]]) * dairy ** shredded mild [[Cookbook:Cheddar Cheese|cheddar]] ** [[Cookbook:Sour Cream|Sour cream]] * spices / flavorings ** [[Cookbook:Cumin|cumin]] - about 1 to 4 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoons]] per pound / 500g of filling ** [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] ** [[Cookbook:Oregano|oregano]] - about ¼ to ½ teaspoon per pound of filling ** [[Cookbook:Pepper|black pepper]] ** [[Cookbook:Chili Pepper|chili]]s ** [[Cookbook:Salsa|salsa]] ** [[Cookbook:Guacamole|guacamole]] sauce |} See below for more unusual ideas.
==Procedure==
===Beans=== #If using dried beans, wash them and examine them for any rocks, then soak overnight in plenty of water. Discard the soak water before cooking - your pot plants will love it! #Cook the beans until soft: #*If using a stove-top method, [[Cookbook:Simmering|simmer]] them in lots of water until they are very soft. You'll need to cook the beans a very long time on very low heat. You may add salt or black pepper to the water. You may add onion halves or a [[Cookbook:Ham|ham]] bone, which you can remove at the end. Changing the water from time to time will reduce the risk of [[w:Flatulence|gas]]. Expect the cooking to take at least 3 hours, if not 6 or more. #*If using a [[Cookbook:Pressure Cooking|pressure cooker]], place the beans and some flavoring (typically [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]]) in enough water to cover all the beans fully, and bring to pressure. Keep the pressure for about 20 minutes, turn off the heat, and let the pressure fall naturally (about 15 minutes).
===Rice=== #If using rice, cook as steamed rice (usually 2 cups of water for every 1 cup of rice) #Rinse rice well, until the water runs clear #Add 2 cups of water per cup of rice, and bring to a boil, then reduce to the lowest heat and simmer for 15-20 minutes. #Set aside with the lid secured, for at least 5 minutes before use.
===All fillings=== #Get a large wide pot or tall-sided [[Cookbook:Frying Pan|frying pan]]. #[[Cookbook:Sautéing|Sauté]] any onion or garlic in a little oil. #Add uncooked meats to the pan and fry, stirring to ensure it browns all over. If using a ground (minced) meat, break it up as it cooks. Drain any excess grease. #Add any other well-cooked meat or beans. You'll might want to smash the beans, perhaps with a potato masher. When using beans alone, you might want to add up to 20% home-rendered [[Cookbook:Lard|lard]] (lard substitutions are obvious, but will lack flavor). #Add spices and other flavorings as necessary. #Add tomatoes, and cooked rice if using it. Reduce the heat. Simmer in open pan for about 40 minutes or until the liquid from the tomatoes is gone. #Soften the tortillas by heating them up. Use a small amount of oil to prevent sticking, if heating in a pan that isn't non-stick. Cover with [[Cookbook:Aluminum Foil|aluminum foil]] if heating them in an [[Cookbook:Oven|oven]], to protect the tortillas from moisture loss. #Place the filling mixture onto a tortilla. Add non-cooked fillings like cheese, olives, avocados, shredded lettuce, salsa. #Roll up the tortilla. (and then make the next one, and so on)
===Rolling=== # Position your tortilla flat on a suitable surface such as a kitchen counter top. (12-[[w:inch|inch]] tortillas are suggested. If you can find bigger tortillas, use them!) # Place your fillings on the flat tortilla in any order. # Fold the bottom flap up. Ensure that there is a sufficient amount of tortilla used for the flap. A small flap will allow the fillings to escape, possibly falling in your lap and burning you. # Bring the side up and over your filling. Tucking the edge of the tortilla under your filling is an excellent extra step. # Create a small fold with the remaining side of the tortilla. This is the ''key'' to maintaining burrito integrity. Failure is a given if you do not follow this step! (The small, diagonal flap is an extra "lock" for the bottom flap of the tortilla… without it, the weight of the filling has the power to force the bottom flap right out of itself.) # Bring the remaining tortilla flap over the filling. Eat with confidence, though the fillings may be very hot. # And remember to sing, "... Taco-flavoured kisses! Taco, taco, burrito, burrito." Actual lyrics may vary depending on language, way in which the burritos are being prepared, or feelings toward the burrito.
==Variation== The filling might be changed to involve any of the following: * [[Cookbook:Mushroom|mushroom]]s * [[Cookbook:Chile|Anaheim chiles]] (mild canned green chiles) * [[Cookbook:Jalapeño|Jalapeño pepper]] (spicier chiles) * dried mild red chili peppers * fresh diced onions * fresh chopped garlic * shredded [[Cookbook:Cabbage|cabbage]] * other shredded cheeses such as [[Cookbook:Monterey Jack Cheese|jack]], soft Mexican cheese ([[w:Queso Blanco|Queso Blanco]], [[w:Oaxaca cheese|Oaxaca]], or [[w:Asadero cheese|Asadero]]) or other [[w:Farmer cheese|Farmer cheese]] * [[Cookbook:Cilantro|cilantro]] * [[Cookbook:Oil|oil]] * [[Cookbook:Chili Powder|chili powder]] * [[Cookbook:Pepper|black pepper]] * small [[Cookbook:Shrimp|Shrimp]] (''Camarones'') * Just about any other meat. Common ingredients in Mexican burritos include fried pork, fried [[Cookbook:Fish|fish]], beef [[Cookbook:Tongue|tongue]], beef [[Cookbook:Brain|brains]], ''birria'' ([[Cookbook:Goat|goat]] meat), [[Cookbook:Tripe|tripe]], and ''chicharrones'' (fried [[Cookbook:Pork Rind|pork rinds]], stewed)
Burritos, [[Cookbook:Taco|tacos]], [[Cookbook:Egg Roll|egg rolls]], [[Cookbook:Tamale|tamales]], and vegetable wraps have similar construction. The fillings and shells can be interchanged as desired.
{{wikipediapar||Burrito}} [[Category:Bean recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Beef recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Chicken recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Southwestern recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Mexican recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Recipes with metric units|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}}
[[Image:Brun ris.jpg|250 px|right|thumb|Uncooked brown basmati rice.]] This is a fragrant, long-grain variety of [[Cookbook:Rice|rice]] often used in Indian recipes.
== Ingredients == *1 cup [[Cookbook:Basmati rice|basmati rice]] *2 cups [[Cookbook:water|water]] *dash of [[Cookbook:salt|salt]] *dash of [[Cookbook:olive oil|olive oil]] (optional)
== Procedure == Add rice, water, and a dash of salt and oil to a small pot over high heat. The oil will keep the rice from sticking together. Cover with lid. When water begins to boil, turn heat to low.
For brown basmati, let simmer for 40 minutes; for white basmati, let simmer for 15 minutes.
Serve hot. Makes 3 cups cooked rice.
== Nutrition == *Serving Size: 3/4 cup *Calories: 180 calories *Protein: 4g
[[Category:Ingredients|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Rice recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Rice recipes|5|20 minutes|2}}
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of India|Indian Cuisine]]
'''Puliyodarai''', is a speciality of the South [[Cookbook:Cuisine of India|Indian]] coastal state of [[w:Tamil Nadu|Tamil Nadu]].
==Ingredients==
===For Puliyodarai=== * 4 cups cooked white (add a little oil to the raw rice before cooking it. This gives rice a better texture ) [[Cookbook:Rice|rice]] * 2 tsp Mustard seeds * 3 tbsp gingely oil ("Til" oil in Hindi, "NaLEnnai" in Tamil, sesame oil) * 2 tbsp split-pea * 2 tbsp groundnuts (peanuts) * 1/2 tsp asafoetida ("Heengh" in Hindi, "Perungayum" in Tamil) * 3-4 dry red chillies * 4-5 curry leaves * 1.5 tbsp tamarind concentrate * 1 tsp turmeric powder * 3/4 tbsp salt
===For Garnishing Powder=== * 1 tbsp split-pea * 1 tbsp Coriander Seeds * 1/2 tsp fenugreek seeds * 2-3 Dry Red Chillies
==Procedure==
===Garnishing Powder Preparation=== * Dry Roast all ingredients in a pan until deep brown (No Oil required) * Grind to a fine powder after the mix cools down.
===Puliyodarai Preparation=== # Heat the oil in a pan. # Add groundnuts and split-peas, fry until golden brown. # Add mustard seeds, asafoetida and red-chillies (broken into pieces). Wait till the mustard seeds splutter and remove pan from stove. # Mix rice, salt, turmeric powder and tamarind concentrate. # Add the garnishing powder, Curry leaves and mix well.
==Notes, tips, and variations== # Serve with Yogurt/Curd # Garnishing powder can be prepared ahead of time and can be stored for upto 2 months (no refrigeration needed) # vary amount of salt/spices as needed. # 1 TSP Sesame can be powdered and added for more taste #Pinch of Jaggery can be added
==Comments==
[[Category:Vegan recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Indian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Rice recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Dessert recipes|16 servings|1.5 hours|3|[[Image:Chocolatefortcake.jpg|300px]]}}
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United Kingdom|Cuisine of the United Kingdom]] | [[Cookbook:Dessert|Dessert]]
This recipe is for our Chocolate Fort Cake, a chocolate sponge designed like a desert fort. The cake is a perfect birthday cake for children, being visually attractive and having a simple taste: [[Cookbook:Chocolate|chocolate]]. This cake is enjoyed by the many people who like chocolate, cake, and toy soldiers.
==Ingredients== ===Cake mix=== *12 [[Cookbook:Ounce|oz]] (~335g) [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]] *12 oz (~335g) [[Cookbook:Castor Sugar|castor sugar]] *6 [[Cookbook:Eggs|eggs]] *12 oz (335g) self-raising [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] *2 oz (55g) [[Cookbook:Almond|ground almonds]] *1 oz (28g) [[Cookbook:Cocoa|Cocoa]] ===Icing=== *1 [[Cookbook:Pound|lb]] (450g) [[Cookbook:Chocolate Butter Icing|chocolate butter icing]] ===Decoration=== *Toy soldiers and flags
==Procedure== #Using an electric mixer, mix the butter and castor sugar until smooth. If the butter is very hard, heat it for a few seconds in a microwave. #Add the eggs one by one to the mixture, mixing all the time. #Add the ground almonds, cocoa and flour to the mixture, again mixing all the time. Mix until it has a droopy consistency and is the same colour throughout. If it is not viscous enough to pour into a cake tin, add some [[Cookbook:Milk|milk]].
[[Category:Dessert recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Cake recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Chocolate recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Recipes_with_metric_units|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{cookwork|Needs an actual recipe}}
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Basic foodstuffs|Basic foodstuffs]] | [[Cookbook:Cereal|Cereal]] | [[Cookbook:Corn|Corn]]
'''Grits''' are coarsely ground [[Cookbook:Hominy|hominy]] ([[Cookbook:Corn|corn]], treated with [[Cookbook:Lye|lye]]). [[Cookbook:Corn Masa|Corn masa]] is similar, but more finely ground.
Grits are a common breakfast food in the southern USA. They are often served much like [[Cookbook:Oatmeal|oatmeal]] or as a side dish with fried or scrambled eggs. Unlike oatmeal, grits are often topped with [[Cookbook:Cheese|cheese]].

{{recipesummary |Category = Ethiopian recipes |Servings = 6 - 8 |Time = ferment: 12-24 hours
cook: 5 minutes per injera |Rating = 2 |Image = [[Image:Alicha 1.jpg|300px]] }} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Ethiopia|Cuisine of Ethiopia]] '''Injera''' is a [[Cookbook:Flatbread|flatbread]] eaten in [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Ethiopia|Ethiopia]] and neighbouring countries. It is made with [[Cookbook:teff|teff]]—a tiny round grain that is grown in Ethiopia. While teff is very nutritious, pure teff flour contains no [[Cookbook:Gluten|gluten]], and little else in the way of binding proteins. This makes teff ill-suited for making raised bread, however injera still takes advantage of the special properties of [[Cookbook:Fermentation|fermentation]]. A short period of fermentation gives it an airy, bubbly texture, and also a sour taste. ==Ingredients== * 1 cup [[Cookbook:Teff|teff flour]] * 1½ cups [[Cookbook:Water|water]] (warm - but not hot!) * a [[Cookbook:Pinch|pinch]] of [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * [[Cookbook:Oil|oil]] for frying * optional: fermentation starter (see notes) ==Procedure== [[Image:Falasha gondar injera 2006.jpg|right|thumb|Making injera]] # Mix the flour with the water, and the salt. Add your fermentation starter if using one (see notes). # Set aside to ferment overnight, or at least 12 hours. There should be bubbles on the surface from fermenting, before you use it. # Heat a large, flat [[Cookbook:Frying Pan|pan]] until it is hot enough to make a droplet of water sizzle. Oil it very lightly, just enough to make the pan shine. # Pour or [[Cookbook:Ladle|ladle]] some batter onto the pan, spiralling outwards from the centre. Only a thin cover is required, a little thicker than a [[Cookbook:Crêpe|crêpe]] but not by much. # As it cooks, the surface of the injera will become covered in holes or pits. When the entire injera has changed colour and the edges start to lift from the pan, remove it and set aside, then pour the next injera and repeat until finished. ==Notes, tips and variations== * If you can't get it to ferment by itself, try a good fermentation starter like a teaspoonful of [[Cookbook:Kefir|kefir]]. [[Cookbook:Yeast|Baker's yeast]] alone will not make for good flavour, as bacteria are needed also, but a teaspoonful of [[Cookbook:Yoghurt|yoghurt]] plus a pinch of yeast might do the trick if you can't get kefir. * Traditional injera is made with teff, however if this is difficult to get, it can be made with [[Cookbook:Sorghum|sorghum]] or [[Cookbook:Flour|wheat flour]]. * Since teff is often quite expensive outside of Africa, it is often mixed with wheat flour to give the injera some of the teff flavour but for less expense. Mix ¼ cup of teff flour with ¾ cup of sorghum or wheat flour, for the recipe above. {{Wikipedia|Injera}} [[Category:Flatbread recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Ethiopian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Gluten-free recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

revision.comment: added instruction not to boil dashi
revision.text:
{{mergefrom|Cookbook:Miso soup}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Soup|Soup]] | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Japan|Cuisine of Japan]]
Miso soup is supposed to be served for breakfast every day. It also should be served with meals.
==Ingredients==
* 90% to 94% [[Cookbook:Dashi|dashi]] (consider using instant dashi mix) * 6% to 10% ''aka'' or ''shiro'' [[Cookbook:Miso|miso]] * odds and ends for garnish
The garnish would typically be two items that contrast in color, flavor, buoyancy, shape, texture, etc. [[Cookbook:Wakame|Wakame]] with [[Cookbook:Tofu|tofu]] is pretty standard. Likely items for garnish would be:
* finely sliced and [[Cookbook:Deep Fat Fry|deep-fat fried]] [[Cookbook:Tofu|tofu]] (Agedashi tofu) * finely cubed raw [[Cookbook:Tofu|tofu]] ('''recommended''') * [[Cookbook:Wakame|wakame]] [[Cookbook:Seaweed|seaweed]] ('''recommended''') * [[Cookbook:Konbu|konbu]] (kelp) seaweed, perhaps left over from making dashi * [[Cookbook:Spinach|spinach]] * chopped [[Cookbook:Scallion|scallion]] * grated [[Cookbook:Daikon|daikon]] radish * boiled and finely cubed [[Cookbook:Potato|potato]] * [[Cookbook:Clam|clams]] (asari or shijimi) * grated [[Cookbook:Eggplant|eggplant]] * [[Cookbook:Shrimp|shrimp]] * [[Cookbook:Mushroom|mushrooms]]
==Procedure== #Put dashi in a pot. #Add any garnish that needs cooking. #Heat the dashi, letting it simmer, cooking any garnish that needs cooking. (Do not boil it, as this degrades the flavor). #Add any garnish that does not need cooking, and remove from heat. #Add the miso to the soup. (never boil the miso; this destroys the flavor)
[[Category:Soup recipes|Miso Soup]] [[Category:Japanese recipes|Miso Soup]] [[Category:Duplicate recipes]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Soup|Soup]] | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Japan|Cuisine of Japan]]
Dashi is a broth used to make [[Cookbook:Miso Soup|miso soup]].
==Ingredients==
One or more of:
* dried [[Cookbook:Konbu|konbu]] (kelp) seaweed (''konbu'') * [[Cookbook:Clam|clams]] (''asari'' or ''shijimi'') * [[Cookbook:Bonito Flakes|dried bonito flakes]] (''katsuo-bushi'') * [[Cookbook:Mackerel Flakes|dried mackerel flakes]] (''sababushi'') * dried [[Cookbook:Sardine|sardines]] or [[Cookbook:Anchovy|anchovies]] (''niboshi'') * dried shiittake mushroom [[Cookbook:Mushroom|mushrooms]] (''hoshi-shiitake'')
* dried young "flying fishes" (飛魚;''tobiuo'' or あご;''ago'',unique name to Japanese-oceanside.)
==Procedure== #If using sardines or anchovies, rip off the heads and rip out the guts. Discard these, keeping the bodies. #Boil stuff in water, as if you were making tea. #Filter the liquid or scoop the solids out of it. The liquid is your dashi.
When only kelp (''konbu'') is used, you get ''kombu-dashi''. This is bland, and appears to be unpopular for use in miso soup. A chunk of kelp about 6 inches across might be reasonable for a [[Cookbook:Quart|quart]] of broth.
When sardines or anchovies also used, you get ''niboshi-dashi''. This seems to be the most popular choice for making [[Cookbook:Miso Soup|miso soup]]. You might add a bit of [[Cookbook:Sake|sake]] in this case. About 10 little [[Cookbook:Fish|fish]] (guppy-sized) per [[Cookbook:Quart|quart]] of broth should do.
When both kelp (''konbu'') and bonito flakes (''katsuo-bushi'') are used, you get ''katsuobushi-dashi''. This appears to be the second most popular choice for making miso soup. About 1 [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] of bonito flakes per [[Cookbook:Quart|quart]] of broth should do. At first you produce primary dashi (''ichiban-dashi''). This is good for clear soups. If you use the solids a second time, you get secondary dashi (''niban-dashi''). This is good for thick soups and for cooking vegetables.
{{wikipedia|dashi}}
[[Category:Soup recipes|Dashi]] [[Category:Japanese recipes|Dashi]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of France|France]] | [[Cookbook:Meat Recipes|Meat]] | [[Cookbook:Stews|Stews]]
Classic French [[Cookbook:Beef|beef]] stew in red wine.
==Ingredients== * 3 large [[Cookbook:onion|onion]]s. * 1kg [[Cookbook:beef|beef]], [[Cookbook:blade steak|blade steak]], or stewing shoulder cut. * 300g of chopped [[Cookbook:Carrot|carrot]]. * 300g of button [[Cookbook:Mushroom|mushrooms]]. * bouquet of herbs: [[Cookbook:basil|basil]], [[Cookbook:rosemary|rosemary]] and [[Cookbook:Thyme|thyme]] tied with string. * 2-4 cups of [[Cookbook:Wine|red wine]]. * 1-2 cloves of [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]]. * [[Cookbook:salt|salt]] and [[Cookbook:pepper|pepper]]. * [[Cookbook:olive oil|olive oil]]. * [[Cookbook:flour|flour]].
==Directions== # Cut beef into large 5cm chunks, season with salt, pepper and olive oil. # Cook beef a small amount at a time in a [[Cookbook:dutch oven|dutch oven]] or large [[Cookbook:saucepan|saucepan]] until its golden brown on the outside, remove each portion as it's done and set aside. # Add 3 large onions and garlic to the same pot and cook till golden brown. # Sprinkle with 2 tablespoons of flour. Cook a few minutes longer. # Add 1-2 cups of red wine. # bring wine to a [[Cookbook:boil|boil]] then [[Cookbook:simmer|simmer]] for 5 minutes. # Add beef, carrots, herbs, mushrooms. # Add another couple of cups of red wine and water - enough to cover the meat and vegetables. # Cook for 2-3 hours, stirring occasionally. Remove surface scum as required.
Serve on [[Cookbook:mashed potato|mashed potato]]; with any leftovers make some [[Cookbook:beef pies|beef pies]] with [[Cookbook:puff pastry|puff pastry]].
==Related recipes== [[Cookbook:Beef_bourguignonne|Beef bourguignon]]
[[Category:French recipes|Boeuf Bourguignon]] [[Category:Beef recipes|Boeuf Bourguignon]] [[Category:Stew recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Bread|Bread]]
These are soft pretzels.
==Ingredients==
* 4 [[Cookbook:Cup|cups]] [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|t]] [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|T]] [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] * 1 package [[Cookbook:Yeast|yeast]] (1/4 [[Cookbook:Ounce|oz]] active dry yeast, 2.25 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|t]] dry yeast, or one 0.6 [[Cookbook:Ounce|oz]] yeast cake) * 1.5 cups warm water * [[Cookbook:Egg|egg]] white (or beaten whole egg) * coarse [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] (margarita or kosher salt)
==Procedure==
#Dissolve the yeast in the water #Mix in the salt, sugar, and flour #Knead the dough until it is smooth #Roll out (do not cut) a blob of dough until it is about 18 [[Cookbook:Inch|inches]] long. #If a traditional shape is desired: Make a loop with the middle of the dough, crossing the dough over itself at about the 15% and 85% areas. Give this contact point a 180° twist, then flip it (and the ends) over toward the middle of the dough piece so that the ends overlap the more-central part at about the 45% and 55% areas. #Brush the pretzel with egg. #Sprinkle coarse salt onto the egg. #Bake at [[Cookbook:Oven Temperatures|425°F]] for 15 minutes.
[[Category:Bread recipes|Pretzel]]

revision.comment: Reverted edit of [[Special:Contributions/Michael Natkin|Michael Natkin]], changed back to last version by 60.234.152.251
revision.text:
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Pasta|Pasta]]
== Ingredients == * 1/2 lb (227g) elbow macaroni * 3 tbsp butter * 3 tbsp flour * 1 tbsp powdered mustard * 3 c milk * 1 red onion finely chopped * 2 tsp Tabasco Pepper Sauce * 1 bay leaf * 1/2 tsp paprika * 1 large egg * 12 oz (340g) sharp cheddar, shredded * 1 tsp kosher salt * Fresh black pepper
=== Topping === * 3 tbsp butter * 1 c panko bread crumbs
== Procedure == # Preheat oven to 350 degrees [[Cookbook:F|F]]. # In a large pot of boiling, salted water cook the pasta until it is al dente. # While the pasta is cooking, melt the butter in a separate pot. # Whisk in the flour and mustard and keep it moving for about five minutes. Make sure it is free of lumps. # Stir in the milk, onion, bay leaf, and paprika. Simmer for ten minutes and remove the bay leaf. # Temper in the egg. # Stir in 3/4 of the cheese. # Season with salt and pepper. # Fold the macaroni into the mix and pour into a 2-quart casserole dish. # Top with remaining cheese. # Melt the butter in a saute pan and toss the bread crumbs to coat. # Top the macaroni with the bread crumbs. # Bake for 30 minutes. # Remove from oven and rest for 10 minutes before serving.
[[Category:Pasta recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Cheese recipes|Macaroni & Cheese (Baked)]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|Macaroni & Cheese (Baked)]]

revision.comment: the ingredient amounts as given made 1 dozen cookies, not 2 dozen
revision.text:
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Dessert|Desserts]]
'''Ginny's Toll House Cookies''' - Traditional chewy chocolate chip cookies with oatmeal added to provide a bit of extra body to the cookie.
==Ingredients==
For 12 medium-sized cookies:
*1 stick [[Cookbook:butter|butter]], softened *1/3 cup [[Cookbook:sugar|sugar]] *½ cup brown sugar *1 [[Cookbook:egg|egg]] *½ teaspoon [[Cookbook:vanilla extract|vanilla extract]] *½ teaspoon [[Cookbook:salt|salt]] *½ teaspoon [[Cookbook:baking soda|baking soda]] *1 cup plus 2 tablespoons [[Cookbook:flour|flour]] *¼ cup [[Cookbook:rolled oats]] (oatmeal) *½ cup [[Cookbook:chocolate chip|chocolate chip]]s
==Procedure== #Preheat oven to 375F. #Cream butter and sugars. #Add egg and vanilla and mix. #Add salt, baking soda, and flour; mix. #Add oatmeal; mix. #Add chocolate chips; mix. #Bake 9 to 11 minutes at 375 degrees F.
[[Category:Dessert recipes|Ginny's Toll House Cookies]] [[Category:Chocolate recipes|Ginny's Toll House Cookies]] [[Category:Cookie recipes|Ginny's Toll House Cookies]] [[Category:Oat recipes|Ginny's Toll House Cookies]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Dessert|Desserts]]
[[Image:ChewyGingerCookies.jpg|thumb|Chewy Ginger Cookies]] These '''chewy ginger cookies''' are soft and delicately flavored.
This recipe makes about 4 to 4½ dozen cookies.
==Ingredients== *¾ [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]], softened *1 cup [[Cookbook:Brown Sugar|brown sugar]] *1 [[Cookbook:Egg|egg]] *¼ cup [[Cookbook:Molasses|molasses]] *2 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|tsp.]] [[Cookbook:Baking Soda|baking soda]] *2½ cups [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] *½ tsp. ground [[Cookbook:Cinnamon|cinnamon]] *1 tsp. ground [[Cookbook:Ginger|ginger]] *1 tsp. ground [[Cookbook:Clove|cloves]] *½ tsp. [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] *extra sugar for coating
==Procedure== #Preheat [[Cookbook:Oven|oven]] to [[Cookbook:Oven Temperatures|350°F (200°C)]]. #Cream the butter and the sugar. #Add the egg and stir in the molasses. #Combine the baking soda, flour, spices and salt in a separate bowl. #Combine the wet and dry mixtures. #Shape into small (2 cm diameter) balls and roll in granulated sugar. #Place on greased [[Cookbook:Cookie Sheet|cookie sheet]]. Do not flatten balls. #[[Cookbook:Baking|Bake]] for about 11 minutes.
[[Category:Dessert recipes|Chewy Ginger Cookies]] [[Category:Ginger recipes|Chewy Ginger Cookies]] [[Category:Cookie recipes|Chewy Ginger Cookies]] [[Category:Featured recipes|Chewy Ginger Cookies]]

{{recipesummary|Cookie recipes|5 1/2 dozen [[Cookbook:Inch|4 1/2 inch]] cookies|prep: 15 minutes
baking: 15 minutes|2|[[Image:CrispyGingerbreadCookies.jpg|300px]] }} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Dessert|Desserts]] This recipe makes '''crispy gingerbread cookies''' that are perfect for gingerbread men. To keep the cookies crisp, store them in an air-tight container. ==Ingredients== *2/3 [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] (~160g) packed light [[Cookbook:Brown Sugar|brown sugar]] *2/3 cup (~160g) [[Cookbook:Molasses|molasses]] *1 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoon]] [[Cookbook:Ginger|ginger]] *1 teaspoon [[Cookbook:Cinnamon|cinnamon]] *1/2 teaspoon [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] *1 1/2 teaspoon (1/2 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoon]]) [[Cookbook:Baking Soda|baking soda]] *2/3 cup (~160g) [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]] *1 [[Cookbook:Egg|egg]] *4 cups (1 [[Cookbook:Quart|quart]]) [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] ==Procedure== #Put sugar, molasses, spices and salt into large [[Cookbook:Saucepan|saucepan]]. #Bring to [[Cookbook:Boil|boil]] and remove from heat. #Add the baking soda and butter and stir until butter melts. #Quickly stir in egg, and then add flour. Mix well. #Chill for several hours until firm enough to roll. #Preheat oven to [[Cookbook:Oven Temperatures|325°F]] (170°C) #Roll out until thin on lightly floured surface. #Cut with [[Cookbook:Cookie Cutter|cookie cutters]] and place on [[Cookbook:Cookie Sheet|cookie sheet]] sprayed with non-stick cooking spray. #Cook for about 15 minutes at [[Cookbook:Oven Temperatures|325°F]] (170°C) and cool on racks. #Cookies can be decorated with [[Cookbook:Royal Icing|royal icing]]. [[Category:Dessert recipes|Crispy Gingerbread Cookies]] [[Category:Cookie recipes|Crispy Gingerbread Cookies]] [[Category:Ginger recipes|Crispy Gingerbread Cookies]] [[Category:Featured recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Recipes with metric units|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Japan|Japanese Cuisine]]
'''Tempura''' is one of the fried foods of [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Japan|Japan]]. Various [[Cookbook:Meat|meats]], [[Cookbook:Fish|fish]], and [[Cookbook:Vegetable|vegetables]] are dipped in [[Cookbook:Batter|batter]] and then [[Cookbook:Deep-fat Frying|deep fried]] until lightly golden.
==Ingredients== * 1 [[Cookbook:egg|egg]] * 1 [[Cookbook:cup|cup]] ice cold water * 1 cup all-purpose [[Cookbook:flour|flour]] * Enough oil to fry food
==Procedure== # Heat cooking oil (peanut oil is best) in a deep pan to 340 - 350° F (~171 - 176°C) # Beat the egg in a bowl and add ice cold water (warmer water will produce a sticky batter and more oily tempura). # Add flour and mix lightly. Do not overmix batter (a few lumps actually improve the result, adding crispiness). # Dip meat or vegetables briefly in the batter and fry until brown. # Remove from the oil and drain. # Serve hot.
If using [[Cookbook:Shrimp|shrimp]], score them a few times crosswise on the underside, to prevent them from curling up during [[Cookbook:Deep-fat Frying|deep frying]]. Alternatively, [[Cookbook:Skewering|skewer]] them before cooking. Remove the skewers before serving.
Serve over white [[Cookbook:Rice|rice]] garnished with black [[Cookbook:Sesame Seed|sesame seeds]], in a bowl of [[Cookbook:Udon Noodle Soup|udon noodle soup]], or in a bowl of [[Cookbook:Soba Noodle Soup|soba noodle soup]]. Serving in [[Cookbook:Soup|soup]] makes the breading get mushy of course.
[[Category:Japanese recipes|Tempura]] [[Category:Batter recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Desserts|Desserts]]
Sponge cake is the most commonly recognised variety of baked confectionery in Britain. It has a sweet taste, often flavoured with vanilla, chocolate or other additions, and can be cut and displayed in a number of different ways.
An [[Cookbook:Sponge Cake|easier version of this recipe]] is available that does not require a kitchen scale.
==Ingredients== ===For the cake=== * 2 [[Cookbook:Egg|eggs]], USDA large (2 to 2.25 [[Cookbook:Ounce|oz]], 56.6 to 63.7 [[Cookbook:g|g]]) or EU size M (53 to 63 [[Cookbook:g|g]]) '''Important: Weigh the eggs and substitute ''n'' for the eggs' weight.''' * self-raising [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] (''n'') * [[Cookbook:Caster sugar|caster sugar]] (''n'') * butter (''n'') * sodium bicarbonate (2tsp) (baking powder, baking soda or bicarbonate of soda)
====Extras (optional)==== * [[Cookbook:vanilla|vanilla extract]] (1-2 tsp) * food colouring (a few drops) * chocolate powder (unsweetened baking cocoa) (according to taste. Use 3g less flour for every 4g added.)
===Filling=== Choose one of these to spread between two cakes if making a cake with more than two eggs. * 2-4 tbsp jam (softened with pallette knife or similar) or * buttercream (cream together 100g caster sugar and 100g butter)
===Dredging=== One of the following: * 75g icing sugar (superfine) * 70g caster sugar (fine) * 65g granulated sugar (medium) * 55g [[Cookbook:Demerara sugar|demerara sugar]] (large crunchy crystals)
==Equipment== * 1 large mixing bowl * 1 set of scales * 1 wooden spoon
==Method== #Preheat an oven to 200 degrees Centigrade.
===Preparation=== #Cream together the sugar and butter in the mixing bowl. They should achieve a creamy texture with quite a thick consistency. The longer, harder and faster the butter and sugar are creamed the lighter the cake will be when cooked. #Add both eggs and mix well. #Add all the flour and mix well. #Add any food colouring, flavouring, etc. at this point. If you add liquid ingredients, add the same volume again of sugar and flour mix to compensate. If adding dry ingredients, ensure to use 3g less flour for every 4g of extra dry ingredients added. #Beat with wooden spoon in a circular motion, trying to incorporate as much air as possible.
===Cooking=== #Grease one or two cake tins with butter. #Spoon, then scrape, as much cake mixture as possible into the tins. If using two tins, try to ensure that each tin contains an equal amount of cake mixture and is not more than 3/4 filled. #Put the tins into the oven and leave them for approximately 10 minutes before checking them. The cooking time should reach around 15 minutes: keep checking them regularly after about 8 minutes since all ovens vary.
===Post-cooking===
====One cake==== #Turn the cake out onto a wire rack to cool. #When cool, dredge with sugar using a spoon.
====Two or more cakes==== #Turn the cakes out onto a wire rack to cool. #When cool, turn one of them upside down and spread your filling onto it. #Place the other cake (top up) onto the upside-down cake and dredge the cake with sugar using a spoon.
[[Category:Cake recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cooking techniques|Cooking techniques]] | [[Cookbook:Camp Cooking|Camp Cooking]]
'''Campfire Banana Boat''' - This popular camping dessert is very easy, and requires no dishes - you eat it straight from the peel!
==Ingredients== *1 [[Cookbook:Banana|Banana]] *Mini [[Cookbook:marshmallow|marshmallow]]s *[[Cookbook:Chocolate chips|Chocolate chips]]
==Procedure== #Peel back a 1 1/2 inch (4cm) wide strip of peel from the inside curve of the banana, leaving one end attached to the banana. #Cut out and remove a wedge-shaped cavity from the length of the banana. #Fill cavity with mini-marshmallows and chocolate chips #Replace peel and wrap well in heavy duty foil. #Place on coals for about 5 minutes. #Open carefully and eat with a spoon right from the banana peel.
Makes 1 Serving
[[Category:Dessert recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Banana recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Chocolate recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Recipes with metric units|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Camping recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Camp Cooking|Camp Cooking]]
'''Campfire S'mores''' - This classic campfire snack is a favorite with children.
==Ingredients== *2 [[Cookbook:Graham Cracker|graham crackers]] *1 [[Cookbook:Marshmallow|marshmallow]] *4 squares [[Cookbook:Chocolate|milk chocolate]]
Makes 1 serving.
==Procedure== #Toast marshmallow until golden brown over campfire on long green stick with bark peeled off. #Place on graham cracker, top with chocolate and remaining cracker.
==Warnings== *Be careful; when the marshmallows are ready they are very hot and can catch fire. Don't burn yourself!
[[Category:Dessert recipes|Campfire S'mores]] [[Category:Chocolate recipes|Campfire S'mores]] [[Category:Marshmallow recipes|Campfire S'mores]] [[Category:Camping recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cooking techniques|Cooking techniques]] | [[Cookbook:Camp Cooking|Camp Cooking]] | [[Cookbook:Microwave Cooking|Microwave Cooking]]
{{recipesummary| | Category = Potato recipes | Servings = As many as you like | Time = 15-60 minutes | Rating = 1 | Energy = | Image = [[Image:Microwaved potatoes.JPG|300px]] }}
'''Baked Potatoes''' - Potatoes are perfect for camping, they don't take up space in the cooler and cooked in foil they are easy to prepare.
Also known as: stuffed potatoes
==Ingredients== * 1 large baking [[Cookbook:potato|potato]] * cooking [[Cookbook:oil|oil]] * [[Cookbook:salt|salt]] and [[Cookbook:butter|butter]] or [[Cookbook:sour cream|sour cream]] (optional) * other possible toppings: spicy [[Cookbook:beans|beans]], [[Cookbook:avocado|avocado]], [[Cookbook:salsa|salsa]], [[Cookbook:mushroom|mushroom]]s, grated [[Cookbook:cheese|cheese]] ... whatever's left in the fridge!
==Procedure== ===Camp=== #Scrub potato and pierce the skin all over with a fork. #Wrap in lightly oiled heavy-duty foil and seal. #Cook over medium-hot coals for 45 minutes or until soft. #Serve with salt and butter or sour cream
===Microwave=== # Clean and prepare potatoes as above, but wrap them in waxed paper, NOT foil. # Place a piece of paper towel in the microwave and microwave potatoes on high for 8 minutes. Note: potatoes will be extremely hot when finished. # Cut potato into four and serve with toppings of your choice.
Serves 1
[[Category:Potato recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Camping recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

page.title: Cookbook:Corn on the Cob with Husks

revision.text:
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cooking techniques|Cooking techniques]] | [[Cookbook:Camp Cooking|Camp Cooking]]
'''Corn on the Cob, With Husks''' - Corn can be roasted over the fire or on the grill without using tinfoil by simply leaving the husks on. Soaking in advance prevents the husks from burning.
==Ingredients== *[[Cookbook:Corn on the cob|Corn on the cob]], with husks left on *[[Cookbook:Butter|Butter]] and [[Cookbook:salt|salt]], optional
==Procedure== #Carefully peel back husk without detaching it and remove silk. #Replace husks and soak ears in cold water for 1/2 hour. #Place corn on [[Cookbook:grill|grill]] or on a rack above an open fire. #Cook for about 15 minutes, turning occasionally to ensure even cooking.
Each ear of corn serves 1
[[Category:Corn recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}}
The salad recipe reminds me of those quiet and peaceful Sunday brunches at the local [http://www.cornerbakery.com/default.asp Corner Bakery] and is an attempt to duplicate the bakery's original, secret recipe.
== Ingredients ==
* 1 cup or more of finely chopped fresh [[Cookbook:Cilantro|cilantro]] * 1/2 cup chopped fresh green onions or [[Cookbook:Scallion|scallions]] * 1 and 1/2 cups of thinly sliced fresh [[Cookbook:Carrot|carrots]] * 1 Tablespoon table [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * 1/2 cup of [[Cookbook:Sesame Oil|sesame oil]] * Approximately 1 cup [[Cookbook:Olive Oil|olive oil]] as an additional supplement * 16 oz. or 1 lb. of [[Cookbook:Angel Hair Pasta|Angel Hair pasta]] noodles
== Procedure ==
* Cook Angel Hair pasta according to package instructions * Add Sesame & Olive oil and Salt (to taste) to drained pasta * Combine cilantro, green onions, and carrots * Chill before serving
== Notes, tips, and variations ==
Not a low-fat, low sodium, or low carbo-calorie diet substitute.
[[Category:Pasta recipes|Sesame Noodle Salad]] [[Category:Cilantro recipes|Sesame Noodle Salad]] [[Category:Salad recipes|Sesame Noodle Salad]] [[Category:Noodle recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Sesame recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Sauces|Sauces]]
'''Ketchup''', sometimes known as '''catsup''', is a term used for a type of [[Cookbook:Sauces|sauce]] containing [[Cookbook:Spices|spices]] and a large amount of acid ([[Cookbook:Vinegar|vinegar]] or [[Cookbook:Lactic Acid|lactic acid]]), typically [[Cookbook:Tomato|tomato]]-based. Some recipes, particularly those from [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Australia|Australia]], may use the ambiguous term [[Cookbook:Tomato Sauce|tomato sauce]] to mean tomato ketchup.
Ketchup is commonly used on [[Cookbook:Deep Fat Frying|deep fat fried]] foods, [[Cookbook:Meat|meat]], and [[Cookbook:Egg|eggs]]. Ketchup is normally applied at the table as a condiment, but it is also commonly used as an ingredient for [[Cookbook:Meatloaf|meatloaf]] and [[Cookbook:Barbecue Sauce|barbecue sauce]].
Interestingly, the original ketchup did not include tomatoes. It was probably a Chinese sauce called "ke-tsiap", based on [[Cookbook:Fermentation|fermented]] [[Cookbook:Brining|brined]] fish or shellfish. The sauce was brought back to Europe by sailors, and appropriated into local recipes. Later, tomatoes were added.
==Ingredients==
* 1 [[Cookbook:Peck|peck]] tomatoes (approximately 8 quarts/950ml) * 1/2 [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] (120g) [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] * 2 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoons]] dry [[Cookbook:Mustard|mustard]] * 1 tablespoon ground [[Cookbook:Allspice|allspice]] * 2 cups [[Cookbook:Cider vinegar|cider vinegar]] * 3 tablespoons [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * 1 tablespoon [[Cookbook:Pepper|black pepper]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoon]] ground [[Cookbook:Clove|cloves]]
==Preparation== Select good, ripe tomatoes. Scald and strain through a coarse sieve to remove seed and skin. Measure 1 gallon (3.8 litres). When the tomatoes become cold add the remaining ingredients. Let simmer slowly for 3 hours. Pour into hot sterilized 1-pint jars and seal. Process for 15 minutes in boiling water bath. Add 5 minutes processing time for altitudes from 1,001 to 6,000 feet (300 - 1800 metres), and another 5 minutes if over 6,000 feet (1800 metres).
==Recipes using ketchup as an ingredient== {{Wikipedia|Ketchup}} * [[Cookbook:Meatloaf|Meatloaf]] * [[Cookbook:Barbecue Sauce|Barbecue Sauce]] * [[Cookbook:Hot and Spicy Dip|Hot and Spicy Dip]] * [[Cookbook:Louis Dressing|Louis Dressing]] * [[Cookbook:Thousand Island|Thousand Island]]
[[Category:Sauce recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Tomato recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Recipes_with_metric_units|{{PAGENAME}}]]

revision.comment: Reverted edit of [[Special:Contributions/163.153.43.205|163.153.43.205]], changed back to last version by Jessicapierce
revision.text:
{{recipesummary|Breakfast recipes|1|5-10 minutes|2||888 Cal}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Breakfast Recipes|Breakfast Recipes]] | [[Cookbook:Omelet Recipes|Omelet Recipes]]
==Ingredients== *3 large [[Cookbook:Egg|eggs]] *2 medium (10 oz) slices of cooked [[Cookbook:Bacon|bacon]] *2 12-oz slices of American [[Cookbook:Cheese|cheese]] *2 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoons]] of [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]] <br clear="all">
==Equipment== *10" Non-stick [[Cookbook:Frying pan|skillet]] *Non-stick [[Cookbook:Spatula|spatula]] *[[Cookbook:Fork|Fork]] or [[Cookbook:Whisk|whisk]] <br clear="all">
==Procedure== #Cut or break bacon into one-inch pieces. #Cut or break slices of cheese into one-inch-wide strips. #Beat or whisk eggs until evenly colored. #Heat pan over high heat until butter is melted and spread over entire pan surface. #Turn heat to medium, pour in eggs, and rotate the pan so that eggs cover the entire surface of the pan. #Continue rotating until the edges become thick, then use a spatula to draw back a downside edge allowing the remaining liquid egg to flow to the pan and start cooking. Continue to rotate the pan and move the spatula to adjacent areas until most of the liquid egg is cooked. #Lay the cheese down the center of the omelet. #Place the bacon on top of the cheese. #Flip one side over the bacon and cheese strip, then the other. #Turn to low heat and serve when cheese has melted.
== Nutritional Information ==
[[Cookbook:Calories|Energy]]: 888 kCal [[Cookbook:Fats|Fat]]: 79g [[Cookbook:Sugar|Sugar]]: 1g [[Cookbook:Carbohydrates|Carbohydrate]]: 1g [[Cookbook:Glycemic|Glycaemic Load]]: 0
[[Category:Breakfast recipes|Bacon Cheese Omelet]] [[Category:Egg recipes|Bacon Cheese Omelet]] [[Category:Low-GI recipes|Bacon Cheese Omelet]] [[category:Gluten-free recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Omelette recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Lamb recipes|4-6|80 minutes|1}}
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Meat_Recipes|Meat recipes]]
'''Lancashire Hotpot''', originating from [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United Kingdom|England]], is a very easy but delicious dish that consists of lamb, onions, potatoes and the cook's choice of [[Cookbook:Herbs|herbs]]. This is [[Cookbook:Baking|baked]] in an oven.
==Ingredients== *2 [[Cookbook:Pound|lb]] (900[[Cookbook:g|g]]) neck of [[Cookbook:Lamb|lamb]] *2 large [[Cookbook:Potato|potatoes]] *1 large or 2 small [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]](s) *choice of mixed [[Cookbook:Herbs|herbs]] *500 [[Cookbook:mL|mL]] boiling water
==Procedure== Dice the lamb and set aside. Preheat [[Cookbook:Oven|oven]] to [[Cookbook:Oven_Temperatures|325F / 170C / Gas Mark 3]].
Slice the potatoes and dice the onions. Add a layer of the potatoes to the bottom of a casserole dish, and cover with a handful of the diced onion. Layer the diced lamb over the top of this, sprinkling with your choice of herbs. Repeat these layers until the dish is full. Top with a final layer of the potatoes.
Pour boiling water into the dish until filled - if more water is needed, continue to add until topped. Bake for at least one hour, though traditionally the dish was left baking all day.
==Notes, tips, and variations== *A handful of mixed [[Cookbook:Vegetable|vegetables]] such as [[Cookbook:Parsnip|parsnips]], [[Cookbook:Turnip|turnips]], [[Cookbook:Leek|leek]] or [[Cookbook:Carrot|carrots]] can be added to the dish. It is worth experimenting to find out what combination of flavours you prefer. *The dish was once cooked with [[Cookbook:Oyster|oyster]]s when they were more affordable. *Flavour can be improved by adding a stock cube to the boiling water. *A [[Cookbook:Suet|suet]] crust can be applied to the hotpot an hour before cooking time is finished. *Many people like to add in small quantities of instant gravy granules to add a little flavour to the dish.
[[Category:Lamb recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:English recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Pasta recipes|6|30 minutes|2|560 Cal}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Pasta Recipes|Pasta]]
'''Spaghetti alla Carbonara''' literally means "Spaghetti in the Manner of the Charcoal Maker". Some believe that the dish was once popular with Charcoal makers who lived on the Mountains near Rome because the ingredients were easily portable and cooking was fairly uncomplicated. Others believe the dish derives its name from all the freshly ground pepper that is added to the spaghetti at the last minute. Actually, the origin of the dish is quite recent, since it was unknown before Second World War. The dish uses pancetta or guanciale, which are similar to bacon. If you want to stay true to the Roman heritage of the dish, you must use grated Pecorino Romano cheese, but it can be substituted by Parmesan. A mix of the two cheeses is also common.
Most Anglo-American recipes add cream to the dish.<ref>Herbst, Sharon Tyler. ''Food Lover's Companion, Third Edition'': Comprehensive Definitions of nearly 6000 food, drink, and culinary terms. ©2001 Barron's Educational Series. Hauppauge, New York. [http://www.barronseduc.com Barron's website]</ref><ref name="OnCooking">Labensky, Sarah R. & Alan M. House. ''On Cooking, Third Edition'': Techniques from expert chefs. ©2003, Pearson Education, Inc., Upper Saddle River, New Jersey.</ref> This is not how the original Roman/Italian dish is made, however.<ref>Gossetti Della Salda, Anna. ''Le Ricette regionali Italiane''. ©1965 Solares, Milan.</ref>
==Ingredients== *[[Cookbook:Pasta|spaghetti]]: 1 lb (450g) *[[Cookbook:Pancetta|pancetta]]: ½ lb (225g) *[[Cookbook:Egg yolk|egg yolks]]: 5 *[[Cookbook:Pecorino Romano Cheese|Pecorino]] or Parmigiano-Reggiano cheese, grated: 1½ cups (360ml) *[[Cookbook:Olive Oil|olive oil]], extra-virgin: 3-4 tablespoons *[[Cookbook:Pepper|pepper]], freshly ground: ½ tablespoon *[[Cookbook:Salt|salt]]
==[[Cookbook:Utensil|Utensils]]== *large pot *large skillet *bowl *measuring cups and spoons *fork
==Preparation== #Dice the pancetta into small pieces (1 inch [2.5cm] will do). #The Pot: Bring a big pot of water to a boil and add salt when it begins to simmer. #The Pot: Cook the spaghetti until it is [[Cookbook:al dente|al dente]] and drain it, reserving ½ cup of water. #The Skillet: Heat the olive oil in a large skillet over a medium-high heat. When the oil is hot, add the pancetta and cook for about 10 minutes over a low flame until the pancetta has rendered most of its fat but is still chewy and barely browned. #The Bowl: In a bowl, slowly whisk about ½ cup of the pasta water into the egg yolks, using a fork. Add the Parmesan cheese and pepper. Mix with a fork. #The Skillet: Transfer the spaghetti immediately to the skillet with the pancetta. Toss it and turn off the heat. Add the egg mixture to the skillet with the pasta and toss all the ingredients to coat the pasta. Taste the pasta and add salt and black pepper, if necessary.
==Beverages== Ideally this dish is served with a red [[Cookbook:Wine|wine]] (Merlot, Chianti, Montepulciano d’Abruzzo), allowed to decant for several hours, and served at 65°F (18°C).
==See also== *[[Cookbook:Carbonara pasta sauce|Carbonara pasta sauce]] *[[Cookbook:Carbonara, American Version|Carbonara, American Version]]
==Notes== <references/>
[[Category:Italian recipes]] [[Category:Pasta recipes]] [[Category:Bacon recipes]] [[Category:Egg recipes]] [[Category:Cheese recipes]] [[Category:Recipes_with_metric_units]]
[[it:Libro di cucina/Ricette/Spaghetti alla carbonara]] [[no:Kokeboka:Spaghetti alla carbonara]]
