This tempers the egg so it won't scramble when added to the hot pie filling. #Pour tempered egg mixture into pan of hot pie filling. Stir constantly and cook for 2 more minutes. #Remove from heat, add butter and vanilla. Stir until mixed. #Slice 2 bananas. Dip slices in lemon juice, shake off excess and distribute banana slices in the bottom of baked pie shell. #Pour half of pie filling over bananas in bottom of pie shell. Make sure banana slices are covered by pie filling. #Slice remaining 2 bananas. Dip in lemon juice, shake off excess and arrange on top of filling in pie. #Pour remainder of pie filling over second layer of bananas in pie shell. Cover all bananas with filling. #Chill for about 1 hour before adding topping. ===Pie topping=== #In a large bowl, whip cream with [[Cookbook:electric mixer|electric mixer]] until peaks are just forming. #Beat vanilla and sugar into cream and continue mixing until peaks form in cream. #Don't over beat the mixture or it will form lumps and begin to turn to butter. #Spread whipped cream mixture over pie filling on chilled pie. Keep chilled until served. ==Warnings== The pie filling is quite hot when pouring it into pie shell. Keep this pie refrigerated. [[Category:Dessert recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Pie recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Banana recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:American recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Breakfast|Breakfast]]
[[Image:ToastedWhiteBread.jpg|right|180px|thumb|American Toast.]]
'''Toast''' generally consists of [[Cookbook:Toasting|toasted]] [[Cookbook:Bread|bread]] with a topping.
Toast often goes well with [[Cookbook:Milk|milk]], especially with [[Cookbook:Honey|honey]] or [[Cookbook:Jam|jam]] as the topping. Toast generally goes well with [[Cookbook:Breakfast|breakfast]] foods, particularly [[Cookbook:Eggs|eggs]] and either [[Cookbook:Bacon|bacon]] or [[Cookbook:Sausage|sausage]]. In this case one might prefer to have [[Cookbook:Orange Juice|orange juice]] with toast.
A particularly good combination of toppings is [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]] with [[Cookbook:Cinnamon|cinnamon]] and [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] sprinkled on top. The butter should be well-spread and well-melted first, so that the cinnamon and sugar will stick to the toast. Try using about 2 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoons]] of sugar and ¼ [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoon]] of cinnamon for each slice of bread.
Butter would be the best topping choice when using [[Cookbook:Raisin Bread|raisin bread]] to make toast.
==Ingredients== *one or more slices of [[Cookbook:Bread|bread]], sized to fit your [[Cookbook:Toaster|toaster]] *topping (optional)
==Toppings== *[[Cookbook:Butter|butter]] *[[Cookbook:Cinnamon|cinnamon]] *[[Cookbook:Honey|honey]] *[[Cookbook:Jam|jam]] *[[Cookbook:Jelly|jelly]] *[[Cookbook:Lard|lard]] *[[Cookbook:Margarine|margarine]] *[[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]]
==Procedure== #Ensure that the [[Cookook:toaster|toaster]] is plugged in, generally clean, and functional. #Place some bread slices into the toaster. Usually, you must place each slice into a separate slot. Some toasters can hold two slices in an extra-wide slot. If you use a [[Cookbook:Toaster Oven|toaster oven]], you may need to lay the bread slices flat on a metal grill inside the toaster oven. #If the toaster has a darkness control, adjust it as desired. #Activate the toaster. #Watch the bread turn into toast. If it starts to get excessively dark, carefully remove the toast. If you are unable to make the toast pop out, unplug the toaster. Do not reach into a slotted toaster, whether with your hand or a metal tool, while it is plugged in or very hot. #Spread your choice of topping on the toast with a [[Cookbook:Knife|knife]], [[Cookbook:Spatula|spatula]], or [[Cookbook:Spoon|spoon]].
==Variations== *The bread crust can be cut off after the toast has been cooked. The topping can be added to both sides. *Replace bread slices with a [[Cookbook:Bagel|bagel]] or [[Cookbook:English Muffin|English muffin]] cut across the axis. *Replace each slice of bread with a [[Cookbook:Waffle|waffle]] or [[Cookbook:Scone|scone]].
[[Category:Breakfast recipes|French Toast]] [[Category:Bread recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Jams_and_Jellies|Jams and Jellies]]
'''Cranberry sauce''' is a [[Cookbook:Jelly|jelly]] or a [[Cookbook:Jam|jam]] made by cooking cranberries, sugar, and often other ingredients together. Many, if not most, Americans are more familiar with the canned cranberry sauce which is a clear, solidified, jelly that is often valued for the property of maintaining the shape of the can in which it is packaged.
The fruit will generally come apart when vigorously [[Cookbook:Boiling|boiled]], so there is no need to crush or puree it when a jam-style cranberry sauce is desired. Cranberry sauce can be made from cranberries and sugar alone.
==See also== *[[Cookbook:Jam|Jam]] *[[Cookbook:Jams_and_Jellies|Jams and Jellies]] (recipe) *[[Cookbook:Jelly|Jelly]] *[[Cookbook:Marmalade|Marmalade]]
[[Category:Jam and Jelly recipes]] [[Category:Cranberry recipes]] [[Category:Sauce recipes]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Beverages|Beverages]] | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of India|Indian Cuisine]]
'''Lassi''' are [[Cookbook:Yogurt|yogurt]]-based shakes in either sweet or salted flavors. The most common flavors include [[Cookbook:Mango|mango]], [[Cookbook:Rosewater|rose water]], and plain [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] sweetened lassi.
==Traditional salty (''namkin'') lassi==
* 4 [[Cookbook:Cup|c]] (1 [[Cookbook:Liter|L]]) [[Cookbook:Yogurt|yogurt]] * 3 c (750 [[Cookbook:mL|mL]]) cold water * 1 c (250 mL) crushed ice * fresh green [[Cookbook:Chili Pepper|chili peppers]] (quantity according to taste), chopped * 1 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|tsp]] [[Cookbook:Cumin|cumin]], roasted and ground * 3 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tbs]] [[Cookbook:Lime|lime]] or [[Cookbook:Lemon|lemon]] juice * 2 tsp salt
Combine all ingredients except ice in blender and blend until smooth. Then add ice and continue blending until frothy.
==Mild salty lassi==
Here is one possible recipe for a Salty Lassi:
* 250 [[Cookbook:mL|mL]] (1 [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]]) full-fat [[Cookbook:Yogurt|yogurt]] * 250 mL (1 cup) chilled [[Cookbook:Milk|milk]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoon]] (4[[Cookbook:Gram|g]]) [[Cookbook:Cumin|cumin]] seeds * 2 teaspoons lime or lemon juice * ½ - 1 teaspoon (2-4g) [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * 100 mL (½ cup) ice cubes * ¼ teaspoon [[Cookbook:Mint|mint]] (finely crumbled, dried; optional) * small pinch of [[Cookbook:Cayenne pepper|cayenne pepper]] (optional)
Dry-roast cumin seeds by cooking them over low heat in small pan until you can smell the seasoning, about 2 to 3 minutes. Cool and grind. In blender, blend cumin seed powder with yoghurt, milk, lemon juice, salt and ice cubes. Optionally scatter with crumbled mint, and a small pinch of cayenne if for piquancy. Serve chilled. (4 servings)
==Sweet (''mithi'') lassi==
* 4 [[Cookbook:Cup|c]] (1 [[Cookbook:Litre|L]]) [[Cookbook:Yogurt|yogurt]] * 3 c (750 [[Cookbook:mL|mL]]) cold water * 1 c (250 mL) crushed ice * 6 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tbs]] [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] or [[Cookbook:Honey|honey]] * 1 tbs [[Cookbook:Rosewater|rosewater]] * ¼ [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|tsp]] ground [[Cookbook:Cardamom|cardamom]]
Combine all ingredients except ice in [[Cookbook:Blender|blender]] and blend until smooth. Then add ice and continue blending until frothy.
==Sweet mango lassi==
* 1 [[Cookbook:Litre|L]] (4 [[Cookbook:Cup|cups]]) [[Cookbook:Mango|mango]] nectar * 500 [[Cookbook:mL|mL]] (2 cups) full-fat [[Cookbook:Yogurt|yoghurt]] * 500 mL (2 cups) chilled [[Cookbook:Milk|milk]] * 250 mL (1 cup) [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]]
Mix sugar with the mango nectar until dissolved. Next, gradually add the milk to the yoghurt. Finally, mix together the two resulting mixtures. (6 servings)
==Other countries==
===Pawpaw Lassi===
*½ [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] water *4 cups plain [[Cookbook:Yogurt|yogurt]] *⅔ cup [[Cookbook:Honey|honey]] *½ teaspoon [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] *1 cup [[Cookbook:Pawpaw|pawpaw]] pulp *½ [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoon]] ground [[Cookbook:Cinnamon|cinnamon]]
Put everything in a blender. Blend.
[[Category:Indian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Milk recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Beverage recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Pawpaw recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Bread recipes|12 buns|prep: 30 minutes
rise: 90 minutes
cooking: ~20 minutes|3}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Bread Recipes|Bread recipes]] This is a yeast dough bun that is stuffed with a meat filling and steamed until cooked. ==Ingredients== ===Steamed buns=== *1 1/2 [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]]s warm water (95°F.) *3 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoon]]s active dry [[Cookbook:Yeast|yeast]] (or 1 packet) *3 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoon]]s granulated white [[Cookbook:Granulated Sugar|sugar]] *4 cups white bread [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] *2 tablespoons cooking [[Cookbook:Oil|oil]] *1 teaspoon [[Cookbook:Baking Powder|baking powder]] *1/2 teaspoon [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] ===Bun filling=== *8 [[Cookbook:Ounce|ounce]]s shredded cooked [[Cookbook:Pork|pork]] or [[Cookbook:Chicken|chicken]] *1/2 cup [[Cookbook:Barbecue Sauce|barbecue sauce]] *1 tablespoon [[Cookbook:Soy Sauce|soy sauce]] *1 tablespoon cooking oil *1 tablespoon granulated white sugar *1 tablespoon [[Cookbook:Teriyaki Sauce|Teriyaki sauce]] *1 teaspoon [[Cookbook:Garlic Chili Sauce|garlic chili sauce]] *1/4 teaspoon [[Cookbook:Five Spice Powder|five spice powder]] *1/4 teaspoon toasted [[Cookbook:Sesame Oil|sesame oil]] ==Procedure== ===Steamed buns=== #Stir yeast and 1 tablespoon of sugar into 1-1/2 cups of warm water (95°F.). Let stand for 15-minutes. #Mix yeast water, 2 more tablespoons of sugar, flour, cooking oil, baking powder and salt in mixing bowl. #Stir until dough forms. Knead dough for 10-minutes. #Allow dough to rise in a warm place for 1-1/2 hours. #Punch dough down and divide into 12 pieces. #Roll each piece of dough into a ball, then flatten with rolling pin into a 6-inch circle. #Place 1 tablespoon of meat filling in center of each flattened piece of dough. #Lift the edges of the flattened dough up arround the filling and bring edges together. #Pinch edges closed to form filled bun. #Place buns on parchment paper. #Allow to rise in warm place 1 hour, until doubled in size. #Steam buns, in steamer, over boiling water for 20-minutes. #Remove from steamer. When cool enough to handle, remove parchment paper from bottom. #Serve warm. ===Bun filling=== #Place all ingredients in food processor. #Process until ingredients are blended and chopped fine. #Use 1 tablespoon of mixture per bun. ==Warnings== Keep leftovers refrigerated. Reheat in microwave for 30 to 45 seconds. [[Category:Bread recipes|Steamed Buns with BBQ Pork]] [[Category:Chinese recipes|Steamed Buns with BBQ Pork]] [[Category:Pork recipes|Steamed Buns with BBQ Pork]] [[Category:Barbecue sauce recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

revision.comment: Changed 'Bake' into 'Shape': the recipe doesn't actually require you to heat up the dough at that point
revision.text:
{{recipesummary|Pastry recipes|20 pastries||4}}
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Finland|Cuisine of Finland]]
[[Image:Karjalanpiirakka-20060227.jpg|thumb|300px|right|Karjalanpiirakka, made by Leipomo Eho (a bakery in Helsinki)]]
'''Karelian pasties''' (''Karjalanpiirakat'' in Finnish) are traditional pasties from North Karelia, Finland. Today they are eaten throughout Finland. According to the traditional recipe the pasties are made from a thin rye crust with a filling of rice. Butter, often mixed with boiled egg (''munavoi''), is spread over the hot pasties before eating.
There are also versions with carrot or potato filling.
== Ingredients == === Filling === * 0,5 litre of [[Cookbook:Water|water]] * 3 dl [[Cookbook:Porridge|porridge]] [[Cookbook:Rice|rice]] * 9 dl [[Cookbook:Milk|milk]] * 1,5 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoons]] [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]]
=== Crust === * 2 dl cold water * 1,5 tsp salt * 3,5 dl rye [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] * 1,5 dl [[Cookbook:Wheat|wheat]] flour
=== Moistening === * 1 dl milk * 50 [[Cookbook:g|g]] [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]]
=== Egg-butter spread (munavoi) === * 2 [[Cookbook:Egg|eggs]] * 50 g butter * 0,25 tsp salt (optional) * 0,5 cans, 125 g, [[Cookbook:Cottage cheese|cottage cheese]] (optional)
== Procedure == === Filling === # Mix the rice into boiling water reserved for the filling. Boil until the water has saturated the rice. # Add the milk and stir the filling for a few minutes. Reduce heat and agitate the porridge. The cooking time is about 40 minutes. Stir the porridge every now and then. # When the porridge is ready, it will seem thickish. Then add the salt. Cool the porridge.
=== Crust === # Mix the flours and salt into the cold water. # Make the dough smooth and pliable by moulding it by hands on a panification support. # Shape the dough into a smooth bar and divide it into about twenty pieces. # Roll the pieces into balls, flatten them into small cakes and cover them with plastic. # Roll the cakes into thin sheets that have approximately 17 cm in diameter.
=== Baking the pasties === # Lay porridge on each cake so that the porridge reaches the ends. # Pinch the edges together with your fingers. #
=== Finishing === # Moisten the pasties from both sides with boiling hot mixture of milk and butter. # Lay the pasties on each other and brew them under a towel and bacon paper. # Mix the ''munavoi'' ingredients (boil the eggs for 12 minutes) and use it as butter on the pasties.
{{Wikipedia|Karelian pasties}}
[[Category:Pastry recipes|Karjalanpiirakat]] [[Category:Finnish recipes|Karjalanpiirakat]]

{{recipesummary|Confection recipes|~50 pieces|1+ hours|2}}
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Confections|Confections]]
'''Honey Taffy''' – This recipe entails a good workout with the reward of unmistakably honey-flavored candies. This recipe can be completed by a single chef, but is much more fun with the help of friends and family.
==Ingredients==
*2 cups [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] *1/2 tsp [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] *2 tablespoons [[Cookbook:CornStarch|cornstarch]] *1 cup liquid [[Cookbook:Honey|honey]], any variety *3/4 cup [[Cookbook:Water|water]] *2 tablespoons [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]]
==Procedure==
#In a 3 or 4 quart heavy-bottomed [[Cookbook:Saucepan|saucepan]] combine the sugar, salt and cornstarch until uniform. #Using a wooden or metal spoon, stir in the honey and the water. Place the saucepan over medium-high heat and continually stir until all the sugar dissolves. #Continue to stir the mixture until the mixture begins to boil. Once boiling begins, let the solution cook undisturbed until it reaches 270°F also known as the [[Cookbook:Cold Water Candy Test#Soft Crack|soft crack stage]]. Add the butter. #Remove the hot mixture from heat and pour onto a greased, lipped cookie sheet, a greased marble slab, or a silicone mat, such as a [[Cookbook:Silpat|Silpat]]. #When taffy is cool enough to handle with greased cleaned hands, gather the taffy and continually stretch, fold and recombine it until it lightens in color and gains a satiny gloss. This step is best accomplished with a friend. This step requires 10 to 15 minutes of constant pulling. #Once taffy has been properly pulled, roll into 1/2 inch (ropes and cut into 1 inch long pieces with a knife or greased scissors. Once all the taffy is cut, wrap in small squares of waxed paper and twist the ends.
==Notes, tips, and variations== *Be extremely careful around the boiling solution, as it gets extremely hot and sticks like tar. *Use a wooden or metal spoon for this recipe, as most plastic spoons will melt or deform. A wooden spoon is best because a metal spoon will get very hot in the sugar syrup. *You can add extra flavoring or coloring to the taffy if you mix it in at the same time as the butter. *If you don’t like honey, or don’t want to use a lot of it, you can substitute [[Cookbook:Corn Syrup|corn syrup]] for equal parts of the missing honey. *If you want some extra reward for extra effort, try making two batches with different colors and/or flavors at once, and twisting or braiding the taffy ropes before cutting to make interesting combinations. *If you don't have cornstarch, you can use 1 tsp. of vinegar instead to help prevent recrystallization.
[[Category:Confection recipes|Honey Taffy]] [[Category:Honey recipes|Honey Taffy]]

{{recipesummary|Side Dish recipes|4|prep: 10 minutes
cooking: 60 minutes|1}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Vegan cuisine|Vegan cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Side dishes|Side dishes]] '''Rosemary Garlic Baked Potatoes''' are a delicious side dish of baked potatoes infused with rosemary and garlic. ==Ingredients== *4 Baking potatoes *4 Tablespoons [[Cookbook:Olive Oil|olive oil]] *2 to 4 cloves [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]], [[Cookbook:Chopping|chopped]] *1 teaspoon dried, crushed [[Cookbook:Rosemary|rosemary]] *¼ teaspoon [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] *⅛ teaspoon fresh ground [[Cookbook:Pepper|pepper]] ==Procedure== #Heat oven to 400ºF (205°C). #Wash potatoes and pierce all over with fork. #Lay each potato on an individual 9 inch square piece of [[Cookbook:Aluminium foil|aluminum foil]] (or sized to fit potato). #Pour 1 tablespoon of olive oil on each potato. Make sure the entire potato skin is coated in oil. #Sprinkle ¼ of the chopped garlic, rosemary, salt and pepper over the entire skin of each potato. #Wrap each potato in aluminum foil. #Place foil-wrapped potatoes on cookie or baking sheet (to catch any leaking olive oil). #Bake in oven for 1-hour. 4 servings ==Notes, tips, and variations== * Sea salt or Kosher salt can be used in place of table salt. Fresh, chopped Rosemary can also be used. [[Category:Vegan recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Potato recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Rosemary recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Side Dish recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Garlic recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}}
Uses for [[Cookbook:Egg|egg]] wash: * For coating the top of baked goods, especially pies, to give a shine when baked. * For battering fish, etc. for [[Cookbook:Deep Fat Frying|Deep-frying]].
==Ingredients== * 1 [[Cookbook:Egg yolk|egg yolk]] , [[Cookbook:Egg white|egg white]] , or whole [[Cookbook:Egg|egg]] * 1-2 tablespoons water or milk
==Procedure== Beat all ingredients together.
[[Category:Egg recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}}
A pleasantly-suprising recipe encountered in [[Cookbook:Cuisine of China|China]]. Also, a good first attempt for beginning deep-fryers. Makes a good substitute to chips or [[Cookbook:French Fries|fries]].
==Ingredients==
* canned or frozen [[Cookbook:Corn|corn]] * [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] * [[Cookbook:Egg Wash|egg wash]] (optional) * [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] and [[Cookbook:Pepper|pepper]] * [[Cookbook:Oil|oil]]
==Procedure==
# If using frozen corn, thaw. If using canned corn, microwave in a glass bowl or gently heat on the stove until warm. # Coat corn with a light layer of [[Cookbook:Egg Wash|egg wash]]. # Mix salt and pepper into the flour, [[Cookbook:MSG|MSG]] or other [[Cookbook:Spice|spices]] optional. # Move corn from the egg wash and cover with flour. # Heat oil to moderate to high heat. # Deep-fry floured corn until golden brown on the outside (less than two minutes). # Serve as a complement to another dish
==Warning== When a pot of hot oil catches fire, the flames will reach up for 2 or 3 feet. If you must work under flammable cabinets or shelves, be sure to have a fire extinguisher handy. An oil with a high [[Cookbook:Smoke Point|smoke point]] is less likely to cause problems, including indoor air pollution and fire. See [[Cookbook:Deep Fat Fry|Deep-frying]] for more warnings.
==Variation== Substitute moderately-chopped [[Cookbook:Vegetable|vegetables]] such as [[Cookbook:Carrot|carrots]] and [[Cookbook:Green Bean|green beans]] for additional flavors.
[[Category:Chinese recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Corn recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{cookwork}}
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of France|French cuisine]]
'''Bouillabaisse''' is a traditional Provençal [[Cookbook:Fish|fish]] [[Cookbook:Stew|stew]] originating from the port city of Marseille.
It is usually a simple fish stock containing different kinds of cooked fish and [[Cookbook:shellfish|shellfish]]. This is complemented with a variety of [[Cookbook:Spices and herbs|herbs and spices]] such as [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]], [[Cookbook:Chili peppers|chillies]], [[Cookbook:Bay Leaf|bay leaves]], [[Cookbook:Fennel|fennel]] and [[Cookbook:Saffron|saffron]]. Vegetables such as [[Cookbook:Leek|leeks]], [[Cookbook:Onion|onions]], [[Cookbook:Tomato|tomatoes]] and [[Cookbook:Celery|celery]] are boiled together to produce a rich flavour. The exact proportions vary by cook and region.
The [http://www.toquentete.net/deran_charte_de_la_bouillabaisse.php Charte de la Bouillabaisse Marseillaise] was signed in 1980 by 11 restaurants in an attempt to standardize the definition of a bouillabaisse. According to the charter, a bouillabaisse must be prepared with at least four of the following fish: [[Cookbook:Monkfish|monkfish]], [[Cookbook:John Dory|John Dory]], [[Cookbook:Galinette|galinette]] (or [[Cookbook:Gunard|gunard]]), [[Cookbook:Mullett|mullett]], [[Cookbook:Rascasse|rascasse]], [[Cookbook:Conger eel|conger eel]], and [[Cookbook:chapon|chapon]] ([[Cookbook:Rascasse rouge|rascasse rouge]]). Most versions will contain at least rascasse and chapon.
Bouillabaisse is often only served when there are large groups of people, as it is time-consuming to prepare and its ingredients are expensive. The stew and the fish are usually served in separate bowls, with the stew poured over slices of French bread seasoned with a spicy garlic mayonnaise called [[Cookbook:Rouille|rouille]].
==For a typical soup base== ===Ingredients=== *1/4 cup extra virgin [[Cookbook:olive oil|olive oil]] *2 large [[Cookbook:onion|onion]]s, small dice *2 [[Cookbook:leek|leek]]s (white portion), washed thoroughly and sliced *4 cloves [[Cookbook:garlic|garlic]], crushed *3 pounds [[Cookbook:sculpin|sculpin]], dressed and cut into 1- to 2-inch pieces *8 small [[Cookbook:plum tomato|plum tomato]]es, skinned, seeded, and quartered *[[Cookbook:Zest|zest]] of 1 [[Cookbook:orange|orange]] *1 stalk [[Cookbook:celery|celery]], small dice *2 tsp fresh [[Cookbook:thyme|thyme]] (or 1 tsp dried) *3 [[Cookbook:bay leaves|bay leaves]], whole *1/2 teaspoon [[Cookbook:red chili flake|red chili flake]] *4 medium [[Cookbook:fennel|fennel]] bulbs, cleaned and quartered *4 quarts boiling [[Cookbook:water|water]] *[[Cookbook:salt|salt]] as [[Cookbook:pepper|pepper]] as needed for seasoning adjustment
===Method=== # In a large, heavy [[Cookbook:stockpot|stockpot]], heat the olive oil over medium heat. Sweat the onion and leeks with a bit of salt (stirring often and making sure not to brown them) for about 10 minutes. Add garlic and continue to sweat, stirring often until onions and leeks have lost their main texture - approximately 15 min. # Increase to high-heat and add the fish. Stir vigorously until the fish falls apart and dissolves into the onion, leek, and garlic mash - approximately 10 min. # Add all other ingredients - except water - and continue to cook over medium heat for approximately 10-min. Make sure to stir often to prevent scorching. # Pour in the boiling water, lower the heat to a medium [[Cookbook:simmer|simmer]], and cook for 20- to 30-min. # Process the entire product through a [[Cookbook:food mill|food mill]] or [[Cookbook:chinois|chinois]], ensuring to puree the mixture into a fine, homogenous soup base. # Adjust seasoning with salt and pepper. Do not add additional salt during the cooking process as some water will evaporate during the simmer and you could possibly over-salt the base.
The soup base can be used immediately or cooled (in a cold-water bath in a large sink) and refrigerated for up to two days.
==For the completed soup==
===Ingredients=== *6-7 pounds of assorted [[Cookbook:fish|fish]] (with bones) or 5-6 pounds of dressed fish fillets. Choose from any of the fish described in the 1980 charter. *1/2 cup [[Cookbook:olive oil|olive oil]] *2 medium [[Cookbook:fennel|fennel]] bulbs, sliced thinly *1 tsp [[Cookbook:saffron|saffron]] threads, bloomed in 1/2 cup boiling water *1 recipe of the bouillabaisse stock *1 [[Cookbook:baguette|baguette]], sliced into rounds *2 lbs Yukon gold [[Cookbook:potato|potato]]es (or other firm boiling potato) peeled and cut into 1/2-inch cubes *ground [[Cookbook:cayenne pepper|cayenne pepper]] to taste *1 recipe [[cookook:rouille|rouille]] *2 cloves [[Cookbook:garlic|garlic]], halved *20 to 30 cooked [[Cookbook:mussels|mussels]] *fresh [[Cookbook:thyme|thyme]] leaves
===Method=== # Cut the fish into equal pieces, approximately 2- to 3-inch pieces. # [[Cookbook:Marinate|Marinate]] all the fish pieces and fennel in a large [[Cookbook:mixing bowl|mixing bowl]] with 1/2 of the bloomed saffron and water and oil. Cover and place in a refrigerator for at least 2 hours but not more then 6. # Bring the soup base to a rapid [[Cookbook:boil|boil]] and add the remainder of the saffron. # [[Cookbook:Toast|Toast]] the bread slices until just browned in a [[Cookbook:toaster|toaster]], [[Cookbook:toaster oven|toaster oven]], or an [[Cookbook:oven|oven]] set on low-heat. Rub with the halved garlic cloves and set aside. # Add the fish and potatoes to the boiling stock and cook until the potatoes are easily pierced with a fork. Adjust seasoning with salt, pepper, and cayenne. # Remove the fish and potatoes from the stock and place in a large dish. Put a slice of bread in the bottom of a bowl and ladle the soup base over it. Sprinkle thyme over the fish and potatoes. Serve separately.
[[Category:French recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Fish recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Stew recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Dessert recipes|6|30 minutes|3}}
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Dessert|Desserts]]
'''Hermits''' are chewy [[Cookbook:Molasses|molasses]] [[Cookbook:Spices and herbs|spice]] [[Cookbook:Cookie|cookies]]. This version is on the strong side of the spectrum so those who prefer less hot-tasting food should hold back on the cloves and ginger.
==Ingredients==
*2 [[Cookbook:Cup|cups]] [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] (AP) *⅔ cup seedless [[Cookbook:Raisin|raisins]] (a handful more if you like them) *⅔ cup dark [[Cookbook:Brown Sugar|brown sugar]], packed *2½ [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoon]] ground [[Cookbook:Ginger|ginger]] *2 teaspoon ground [[Cookbook:Cinnamon|cinnamon]] *1 teaspoon ground [[Cookbook:Clove|cloves]] *1 teaspoon [[Cookbook:Baking Powder|baking powder]] *½ teaspoon [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] *½ cup molasses *6 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoons]] [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]], melted *2 teaspoon [[Cookbook:Vanilla|vanilla]] extract *1 [[Cookbook:Egg|egg]]
==Procedure==
#Preheat oven to [[Cookbook:Oven temperatures|375°F/190°C]] (yes, first thing). #Line a sheet pan with parchment paper (a buttered sheet pan works as well but makes cooling and cutting more difficult and more damaging to the sheet pan). #In a large bowl, stir together flour, raisins, brown sugar, ginger, cinnamon, cloves, baking powder, and salt until well combined; watch the brown sugar to ensure that it doesn't clump, it will want to do so and brown sugar clumps coated in flour look a lot like raisins coated in flour. #Stir in molasses, butter, vanilla, and egg until fully integrated. Spread the batter in two strips (approximately 6" by 3") separated by at least 1½" on the sheet pan. #Bake for 12 – 15 minutes or until a toothpick inserted into the center of the strips comes out dry. #Allow to cool slightly then remove the hermits (on their parchment) to cooling racks to cool completely; be sure the bottoms have cooled (just reach under and feel -- if its more than a little warmer than room temperature its not there yet). #Move the hermits (still on their parchment) to a counter for portioning and removal from parchment. Cut hermits into 1½ [[Cookbook:Inch|inch]] wide strips (a [[Cookbook:Pizza Cutter|pizza cutter]] should work well) then carefully scrape them away from the parchment with a good thin [[Cookbook:Spatula|spatula]]. #Enjoy with a glass of [[Cookbook:Milk|milk]] or [[Cookbook:A Nice Cup of Tea|a nice cup of tea]].
Although nice warm these hermits will be even better after a night in an air-tight tin. They should last about a week in that tin though at my house they've never lasted more than a day.
[[Category:Dessert recipes|Hermits]] [[Category:Cookie recipes|Hermits]] [[Category:Molasses recipes|Hermits]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:East Asian cuisines|Asian Cuisine]]
'''Wonton wrappers''' are thin [[Cookbook:Pasta|pasta]]-like wrappers used for wontons. They are suitable for [[Cookbook:Wonton Soup|wonton soup]]. Oversize (7" square) wrappers may be used as [[Cookbook:Egg Roll|egg roll]] wrappers. Round wrappers are best for making [[Cookbook:Potsticker|potstickers]].
Most people will prefer to buy wrappers ready-made. This is especially easy for wontons, because egg roll wrappers may be cut in quarters to make wonton wrappers. Look in a supermarket near the [[Cookbook:Tofu|tofu]] and Asian [[Cookbook:Mushroom|mushrooms]].
For the stubbornly determined expert cook though, here you go:
==Ingredients== *2 [[Cookbook:Cup|cups]] [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] *1 [[Cookbook:Egg|egg]] *1 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoon]] [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] *1/3-1/2 [[Cookbook:Cup|cups]] water
==Procedure== #Sift flour and salt into a large bowl; create a well-like indentation in the center. #Beat egg lightly, pour into indentation in the flour and mix well. #Sprinkle with cold water, wet your hands and knead the mixture into a smooth dough. #Place dough in a bowl and cover with a damp cloth, refrigerate for 30 minutes to an hour. #Sprinkle a wide work area or board with flour. Roll out the dough until it is paper thin and its edges are even in thickness. The wonton skins will be partially transparent. #Cut dough in 2 to 3 inch strips, flour lightly then stack one on top of the other and cut the strips into 2 to 3 inch squares. #Place skins on tray and cover with a damp cloth until ready to use.
==Recipes using wonton wrappers include== *[[Cookbook:Potsticker|Potsticker (Gyoza)]] (circles are best; hexagons may make sense) *[[Cookbook:Wonton Soup|Wonton Soup]] *[[Cookbook:Egg Roll|Egg Roll]] (make 7" squares)
[[Category:Chinese recipes|Wonton wrapper]]

revision.comment: Pretty sure a cup is 250 ml
revision.text:
{{recipesummary|Bread recipes|8-10|30 minutes|3}}
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:North American cuisines|North American Cuisines]] | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Ontario|Cuisine of Ontario]]
'''Sweet Cornbread''' is a variant of the [[Cookbook:Skillet Cornbread | Skillet Cornbread]] made throughout the Southern United States. Sweet Cornbread is common in central and eastern Ontario and Quebec and is sometimes known by the alternative name of Johnny Cake. Its presence in these southern regions of Canada is thought to be due to the influx of British Loyalists from what is now the Southern states moving to the then-English-controlled colonies during the [[:w:American War of Independence | American War of Independence]].
== Ingredients ==
* 256 [[Cookbook:mL|mL]] (1 cup) of cornmeal * 512 mL (2 cups) of flour * 8 mL (1 1/2 teaspoons) of baking powder * 128 mL (1/2 cup) of maple syrup * 128 mL of brown sugar * 128 mL of butter * 5 mL (1 teaspoon) of salt * 2 eggs
== Procedure ==
# In a large bowl beat eggs lightly to break the yolks as one would for scrambled eggs, then mix in the butter. Soften the butter beforehand if you must by heating it a little. # The butter/egg mixture should be loose. Add the sugar and maple syrup, mix well, then add the salt to the liquid mixture. # Mix the cornmeal and baking powder, then blend them into the liquids. # Slowly add the flour as needed to reach a proper cake batter texture. This should be softer than a cookie dough, able to stick to the mixing spool and come off in blobs. You may not need all of the flour, or may even need a little more based on your eggs and how closely you measured. # Pour into a greased pan and put into an oven heated to 200°C (400°F) and let bake for between 15-25 minutes.
== Notes, tips, and variations ==
* When mixing the batter, be sure it is soft enough for a typical cake; you do not want it too moist or dry. Use milk to fill in liquid you need and a half-and-half mix of flour and cornmeal if you are too moist.
* Keep a close eye on the cake while it bakes: it will become hard fast if you do not take it out in time.
* If you want to make a crisper crust take a 3 part mix of equal amounts of flour, cornmeal and brown sugar, mix well. Add to the top of the cake half way into the baking process, but do this very quickly: leaving the door open too long will make your cake a rock. The amount required varies based on the pan you use, so use your eyes for what you need (less than a cup total). Despite the call for opening it halfway through baking, adding it at the beginning should work fine as well.
* You can substitute honey for the maple syrup, or plain sugar. Maple is used for its flavouring as much as its sweetness.
* Margarine or vegetable oil will do as well as butter for this. Butter was used traditionally and is thus listed.
* This dish is usually made for after meals and outside them rather than with them, which is how its cousin [[Cookbook:Skillet Cornbread | Skillet Cornbread]] is used. However, when having [[Cookbook:Maple Beans | Maple Beans]] and Ham, Sweet Cornbread is often served with it.
[[Category:Bread recipes|Sweet Cornbread]] [[Category:Cake recipes|Sweet Cornbread]] [[Category:Corn recipes|Sweet Cornbread]] [[Category:Canadian recipes|Sweet Cornbread]] [[Category:Featured recipes|Sweet Cornbread]]

revision.comment: fix weird volumetric conversion of cups to metric
revision.text:
{{recipesummary|Cookie recipes|12-18 cookies|20 minutes|1}}
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Ontario|Cuisine of Ontario]] | [[Cookbook:Cookie|Cookies]]
'''Grannie Gilbert's Sugar Cookies''' are a recipe of sugar cookies running with the Gilbert women of Ontario, Canada for more than 100 years. No one knows where the recipe started, but it's been that way as long as any can recall with no real change.
==Ingredients==
* 2-3 [[Cookbook:Cup|cups]] (250-375 [[Cookbook:Gram|g]]) of [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] * 2 teaspoons (10 g) of [[Cookbook:Baking Powder|baking powder]] * 1 cup (200 g) of [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] * 1 cup (230 g) of [[Cookbook:Shortening|shortening]]/[[Cookbook:Butter|butter]] * a pinch of [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * [[Cookbook:Vanilla|vanilla]] * 3 [[Cookbook:Egg|eggs]]
==Procedure==
# In a large bowl beat eggs lightly to break the yolks as one would for scrambled eggs, then mix in the shortening. Soften the butter before hand if you must by heating it a little. # The shortening/egg mixture should be loose, add the sugar, mix well then add the salt to the liquid mixture. # Add the baking powder then slowly add the flour as needed to reach a proper doughy state, you may not need all of the flour, or may even need a little more based on your eggs and how closely you measured. # Make balls and place onto a pan then into an oven heated to 175°C (350°F) and let bake for between 15-20 minutes.
==Notes, tips, and variations==
* Feel free to switch out half the sugar with another sweet item, like honey. * Using three tablespoons of [[Cookbook:Cocoa Powder|cocoa powder]] one can get a slight chocolate flavour to the cookie, without being overtly chocolatey. * Try adding chocolate chips to it.
[[Category:Cookie recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Canadian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

page.title: Cookbook:Pork Tenderloin with Asparagus and Proscuitto

revision.text:
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Meat Recipes|Meat Recipes]]
'''Pork Tenderloin with Asparagus and Proscuitto'''
== Ingredients ==
* pork tenderloin (approx 1/2 lb) * 1 lb [[Cookbook:Asparagus|asparagus]] * 50g of [[Cookbook:Proscuitto|proscuitto]] * 175ml [[Cookbook:Cream|whipping cream]] (35% [[Cookbook:Milkfat|milkfat]]) * 6-10 cloves garlic * 3-4 [[Cookbook:Shallot|shallots]] * 2 sundried tomatoes * approximately 500g linguine * 4 tbsp olive oil * 100ml white wine
==Procedure ==
#Dice the shallots and garlic and set them aside. #Wash and slice the asparagus into small pieces, using angled cuts for improved presentation. #If you wish, you may include a few slices of proscuitto (chopped) to set aside as you may want to include it in the sauce. #Preheat the oven to 375 degrees F (200 C). #Place the pork on a clean cutting board. Wrap the tenderloin with the slices of proscuitto, trying to wrapp as tightly as possible so it will stay in place. #While you are doing this, also preheat an oven-safe pan to medium. Pour a few tablespoons of olive oil into the pan and place the pork inside. Start browning the meat on all sides. Once that is done, place the entire pan into the oven. #While you are doing this, heat up another pan (preferably a [[Cookbook:Saucepan|saucepan]]) and pour a few tablespoons of olive oil into it. Once it's heated up, toss the garlic and shallots in and saute them lightly. #Once the garlic has been sauteed to a very light brown colour, add a small amount of olive oil and the asparagus. #When the asparagus is slightly sauteed, add about 1/2 of the cream and about 1/4 of the wine. #Fill a medium-sized pot 3/4 full with salted water and set on high heat on a back burner. #Turn the tenderloin over in the pan, ensuring that the proscuitto does not fall off the meat. Sprinkle with a bit of salt and pepper. #Reduce the sauce to about half of the original volume, and pour in the rest of the cream and wine. #Turn the tenderloin over again. #Put the linguine in the boiling water and sti occasionally. You may choose to put the chopped proscuitto in at this point. #Once the sauce has reduced down again, lower the heat and remove the pork from the oven. Place it on a clean cutting board and let it sit for a few minutes. #Strain the linguine and start slicing the tenderloin into small medallions. #Place the desired amount of linguine on each plate, and place a few medallions on top. Spoon sauce over the top.
Serves 3-4 people.
[[Category:Pork recipes|Pork recipes]] [[Category:Asparagus recipes|Asparagus recipes]] [[Category:Ham recipes|Ham recipes]]

{{recipesummary|Appetizer recipes|6|5 minutes|1}}
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Appetizers|Appetizers]] | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|Cuisine of the United States]]
This fusion recipe combines hot chili sauce and sweet peaches with Asian spices for a tasty, spicy peach salsa. ==Ingredients== *2 (15-oz) cans [[Cookbook:Peach|peaches]], drained and chopped, although If you want to make this California style—use fresh peaches. *2 [[Cookbook:Green Onion|green onions]], sliced thin, including tops *2 tablespoons [[Cookbook:Lime|lime]] juice *2 teaspoons chopped fresh [[Cookbook:Cilantro|cilantro]] *2 teaspoons [[Cookbook:Garlic Chili Sauce|garlic chili sauce]] *1/2 teaspoon [[Cookbook:Five Spice Powder|five spice powder]] *1/4 teaspoon [[Cookbook:White Pepper|white pepper]]
==Procedure==
*In a bowl, mix the drained, chopped peaches, sliced green onions, chopped cilantro, garlic chili sauce, lime juice, five spice powder, white pepper. *Mix well. *Chill before serving.
==Notes==
Serve as a salsa with tortilla chips or as a garnish for meat dishes.
[[Category:Appetizer recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Californian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Peach recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Salsa recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Gluten-free recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Dessert recipes|6|30-60 minutes|3||1500-2100 kJ (358-502 kcal) per serving}}
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of India|Indian Cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Dessert|Dessert]]
'''Kheer''' or '''payasam''' is a thick rice pudding.
==Ingredients== *1 [[Cookbook:L|L]] (4 [[Cookbook:Cup|cups]]) [[Cookbook:Milk|milk]] *250 [[Cookbook:mL|mL]] (1 cup) long grain white [[Cookbook:Rice|rice]] *125 mL (½ cup) white [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] *65 mL (¼ cup) [[Cookbook:Sultana|sultanas]] *6 [[Cookbook:Cardamom|cardamom]] pods *65 mL (¼ cup) slivered blanched [[Cookbook:Almond|almonds]] *15 mL (1 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|T]]) [[Cookbook:Rosewater|rosewater]]
==Procedure== # Bring the milk to a boil. # Add rice and cook slowly until thick (about 20 minutes). # Stir in the sugar, sultanas (raisins), and the ground seeds from the cardamom pods (cook a further 5 minutes). # Stir in the almonds and rosewater, and cover until ready to serve.
==Notes, tips, and variations== *Stir the milk while bringing it to the boil. *You may also want to leave the kheer boiling for much longer (several hours), until it has been significantly reduced; this provides a stronger flavour and a light-pink colour. *You can use rice flour instead of plain rice. *For kheer that is not too thick when cold, use 170 mL (⅔ cup) of rice instead. *If to be eaten cold, it's nicer to use double the quantities of sugar, sultanas, and almonds.
==Warnings== *The main difficulty in this dish is preventing the kheer from sticking to the bottom of the pan, that requires care.
{{Wikipedia|Kheer}}
[[Category:Dessert recipes]] [[Category:Indian recipes]] [[Category:Pudding and Custard recipes]] [[Category:Rice recipes]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of South Africa|South Africa]]
Krummelpap is traditionally eaten at breakfast, mostly with a bit of milk, butter, and sugar, or at dinner, where it is served with a sauce like gravy.
It is slowly cooked on a stove.
==Ingredients== *1 tsp. [[Cookbook:salt|salt]] *250 ml water (boiling/hot) or more as needed *700 ml maize
==Procedure== #Add maize and salt to a large pot (like the one used for rice). #Add a third af the water and mix with a fork so that it makes little balls or crumbs. #Add more water but only a little at a time while mixing. Make sure that you don't add too much water. #Put the stove on a LOW heat and stir with a fork every 10 minutes. Keep the lid on; it is the steam that cooks the maize. #Taste it after 35 minutes to test if it is done. If it still tastes like maize, leave it - the wonder of this porridge is that you can't overcook, but you can burn it. #It takes approximately 50 minutes to cook.
[[Category:Corn recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:South African recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Confection recipes|aprox 72 pieces|3.5 hours|3}}
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Confections|Confections]]
This recipe describes how to make home-made ''Marshmallows''. They can be used in [[:Category:Marshmallow recipes|any recipe that calls for marshmallows]].
==Ingredients== *About 1 cup confectioners' sugar *3 1/2 envelopes (2 tablespoons plus 2 1/2 teaspoons) unflavored gelatin *1/2 cup cold water *2 cups granulated sugar *1/2 cup light corn syrup *1/2 cup hot water (about 115 degrees) *1/4 teaspoon salt *2 large egg whites *1 teaspoon vanilla extract
==Procedure== Oil bottom and sides of a 13 by 9 by 2-inch rectangular metal baking pan and dust bottom and sides with some confectioners' sugar.
In bowl of standing electric mixer or in a large bowl sprinkle gelatin over cold water and let stand to soften. In a 3-quart heavy saucepan cook granulated sugar, corn syrup, hot water, and salt over low heat, stirring with a wooden spoon, until sugar is dissolved. Increase heat to moderate and boil mixture, without stirring, until a candy or digital thermometer registers 240 degrees, about 12 minutes. Remove pan from heat and pour sugar mixture over gelatin mixture, stirring until gelatin is dissolved.
With standing or a hand-held electric mixer beat mixture on high speed until white, thick and nearly tripled in volume, about 6 minutes if using standing mixer or about 10 minutes if using hand-held mixer. In a large bowl with cleaned beaters beat whites (or reconstituted powdered whites) until they just hold stiff peaks. Beat whites and vanilla into sugar mixture until just combined. Pour mixture into baking pan and sift 1/4 cup confectioners' sugar evenly over top. Chill marshmallow, uncovered, until firm, at least three hours, and up to 1 day.
Run a thin knife around edges of pan and invert pan onto large cutting board. Lifting up 1 corner of inverted pan, with fingers loosen marshmallow and let drop onto cutting board. With a large knife trim edges of marshmallow and cut marshmallows into roughly 1-inch cubes. Sift remaining confectioners' sugar into a large bowl and add marshmallows in batches, tossing to evenly coat.
==Variation== Coat with toasted coconut or cocoa powder instead of powdered sugar.
[[Category:Confection recipes|Marshmallow]] [[Category:Marshmallow recipes| ]]

{{recipesummary|Bread recipes||2 hours 30 minutes|3}}
{{recipe}}
'''Grotten Hans''' is a recipe that has been called a big dumpling but is basically steamed sweet bread. The recipe was traditional in the German areas of Russia.<ref>[http://www.lib.ndsu.nodak.edu/grhc/archrecipes/index.cgi?cat=German-Russian NDSU Recipe Index]</ref>
==Ingredients== *¼ [[Cookbook:Cup|c]]. [[Cookbook:Lard|lard]] or [[Cookbook:Corn oil|oil]] *1 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|tsp]]. [[Cookbook:salt|salt]] *1 c. [[Cookbook:Milk|milk]] *2 tsp. [[Cookbook:Baking Powder|baking powder]] *½ c. [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] *3 [[Cookbook:egg|eggs]], beaten *3 c. [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]]
==Procedure== # Cream lard, sugar and salt. Add eggs. Mix flour and baking powder. # Add this flour mixture to the lard mixture alternatively with the milk. Mix well. # Pour into a well-greased 2-pound coffee can. A piece of wax paper on the bottom of the can works well. Cover with foil, and tie this on with a string. # Set this tin into a large kettle of hot water several (3) inches deep. This will steam the dumpling. Cook for 2 hours. The old way was to dip a towel in hot water, then cold water, then sprinkle with flour. # Pour dumpling onto towel and tie up. Drop into boiling water and cook 2 hours.
==Notes, tips, and variations== Raisin Sauce: *2 c. [[Cookbook:raisin|raisins]] *2 c. [[Cookbook:water|water]] *1 tsp. [[Cookbook:Lemon Juice|lemon juice]] *1 scant tsp. [[Cookbook:Cinnamon|cinnamon]] *½ c. [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]]
Mix raisins, water, lemon juice, cinnamon and sugar. Simmer for 1 hour. Thicken with cornstarch. Serve over Grotten Hans. Cherry sauce is nice also.
Serve with ham.
==References== <references/>
[[Category:German recipes]] [[Category:Bread recipes]]

{{recipesummary|Soup recipes|8 persons|15-20 minutes|2|Energy=80 kcal/335 kJ}}
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Soup|Soup]]
'''Easy Wedding Soup''' is a simple variation on [[Cookbook:Italian Wedding Soup|Italian Wedding Soup]] that requires only four ingredients and water.
==Ingredients==
* 6 cups [[Cookbook:Broth|chicken broth]] (from [[Cookbook:Bouillon Cubes|bouillon cubes]] is fine) * 2 cups [[Cookbook:water|water]] * 1 10 oz packet frozen [[Cookbook:spinach|spinach]] * 12 oz spicy [[Cookbook:Chicken|chicken]] [[Cookbook:Sausage|sausage]] (pre-cooked) * 3 tbsp [[Cookbook:acini di pepe|acini di pepe]] (''pastina'', little bead-like [[Cookbook:Pasta|pasta]])
==Procedure== # Bring broth and water to [[Cookbook:Boiling|boil]] in 4 quart [[Cookbook:saucepan|saucepan]]. # Add frozen spinach. # Cut sausage into small pieces. # Add sausage and acini di pepe # Bring back to boil and allow to boil for 10 minutes.
==Notes, Tips, and Variations== * Calorie content may vary depending on the specific ingredients you use; 80 kcal is reasonable. * The spicy sausage will impart more subtle flavor to the soup, making further spicing unnecessary. Using different types of sausage will vastly change the character of the soup. * This recipe may require salt if you use home made chicken stock. Bouillon cubes tend to be heavily salted already.
[[Category:Spinach recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Soup recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Chicken recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Bread|Bread]] | [[Cookbook:Breakfast|Breakfast]]
'''Biscuits''' are a type of [[Cookbook:Quickbread|quickbread]] usually served with [[Cookbook:Dinner|dinner]], especially for a holiday meal. Rarely, biscuits are served for [[Cookbook:Breakfast|breakfast]]. Eaters typically apply [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]], [[Cookbook:Honey|honey]], [[Cookbook:Jam|jam]], or [[Cookbook:Jelly|jelly]] to their biscuits. For breakfast, an eater might add a [[Cookbook:Fried Egg|fried egg]], fried [[Cookbook:Ham|ham]], or [[Cookbook:Cheese|cheese]]. Sometimes biscuits are served with [[Cookbook:Gravy|gravy]].
Biscuits come in two forms, cut and dropped. Cut biscuits use a fairly normal dough that is [[Cookbook:Rolling Pin|rolled]] out and cut with a circular [[Cookbook:Cookie Cutter|cookie cutter]]. Drop biscuits use a somewhat more liquid dough that is dropped onto a [[Cookbook:Cookie Sheet|cookie sheet]] with a spoon.
==Ingredients== *2 [[Cookbook:Cup|c]] (240 [[Cookbook:mL|mL]]) [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] *1/3 c (80 mL) [[Cookbook:Lard|lard]] or [[Cookbook:Shortening|shortening]] *1 c (240 mL) [[Cookbook:Milk|milk]] for drop biscuits, or 3/4 c (180 mL) milk for cut biscuits *1/3 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|t]] (2 mL) [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] *1 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|T]] (15 mL) [[Cookbook:Baking Powder|baking powder]]
==Procedure== #Mix the dry ingredients. #Cut (mix) in the [[Cookbook:Fat|fat]], preferably as you would for an [[Cookbook:Apple Crisp|apple crisp]] or traditional pie crust. #Add the milk, mixing only as needed to wet the dough or batter. #If doing drop biscuits, you'll plop the batter by spoonfuls (large spoonfuls) onto the cookie sheet. Otherwise, for cut biscuits: ##Give the dough a quick [[Cookbook:Kneading|knead]]. ##Roll the dough out to 1/2[[Cookbook:Inch|"]], using flour as needed to avoid sticking. ##Cut circles with a 2.5" cookie cutter, or carve hexagons (a honeycomb pattern) with a knife. #Space the biscuits 1" apart on the cookie sheet. #[[Cookbook:Baking|Bake]] 10 to 12 minutes in a [[Cookbook:Oven_Temperatures|450°F]] [[Cookbook:Oven|oven]], stopping when lightly browned on top. #Serve hot.
[[Category:Bread recipes|Biscuit]] [[Category:Breakfast recipes|Biscuit]] [[Category:Southern recipes]]

{{cookwork|Page should be split}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Italy|Italian Cuisine]]
== Authentic Italian Marinara Sauce == The recipe below has way more ingredients than any marinara sauce I've seen. It may still be to your liking. This sauce is easy and tastes great over any kind of pasta. It could also be used on toast or as a pizza sauce.
=== Ingredients === *1/4 cup of [[Cookbook:Olive Oil|olive oil]] *A clove of [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]] *1 35-[[Cookbook:Ounce|oz.]] can imported (Pelati preferred) Italian [[Cookbook:Tomato|tomatoes]], or 2 16-[[Cookbook:Ounce|oz.]] cans crushed tomatoes) *1 handful [[Cookbook:Basil|basil]] leaves, washed, patted dry, and chopped *[[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] and [[Cookbook:Black Pepper|pepper]] to taste *chopped [[Cookbook:Onion|onions]] (optional) *1/2 teaspoon [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] (optional)
=== Procedure === #Gently heat the olive oil in a large saucepan. #Add a thin slice of garlic to the hot oil. #Once the garlic starts to turn brown, carefully remove it from the oil and discard. #Crush the tomatoes and add their juices. Diced tomatoes can be substituted for easier crushing. [[Cookbook:Tomato_Paste|Tomato paste]] can be combined with the tomatoes, but you must add the sugar to cut down on the tart flavor of the paste. #Fill the empty tomato can 1/4 of the way with water and pour in with the tomatoes. Skip this if the diced or stewed tomatoes seem to have enough liquid. #Add the basil, salt, and pepper. Fresh basil is best, but dried can be used. #Bring to a [[Cookbook:Boiling|boil]]. #Lower heat to a [[Cookbook:Simmering|simmer]]. #Cook until thickened.
== Modified Marinara Sauce ==
Goes well with rotini!
=== Ingredients === *[[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] *[[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] *3 cloves of [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]], chopped *1/3 [[Cookbook:Onion|onions]] *2 [[Cookbook:mm|mm]] deep [[Cookbook:Olive Oil|olive oil]] *56 [[Cookbook:Ounce|oz.]] crushed [[Cookbook:Tomato|tomatoes]] *1 [[Cookbook:Pound|lb.]] ground beef *[[Cookbook:Red Wine|red wine]] *[[Cookbook:Oregano|oregano]] leaves *[[Cookbook:Basil|basil]] leaves *[[Cookbook:Black Pepper|black pepper]] *crushed [[Cookbook:Chili Pepper|red peppers]]
=== Procedure === #[[Cookbook:Sauteeing|Saute]] the chopped onions and garlic in the olive oil. #When the onions are translucent, add more oil, and stir. #Brown the [[Cookbook:Beef|beef]] and [[Cookbook:Browning|brown]] in a separate pan. When it is brown, add to the saute. #Add the tomatoes. #After 5-7 minutes, add the salt, sugar, red wine, basil leaves, oregano, black pepper and red peppers. #Stir. #Lower temperature. After 15 minutes, taste.
[[Category:Pasta sauces|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Sauce recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Italian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Duplicate recipes]]

{{cookwork|Page should be split}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Sauces|Sauces]] | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Italy|Italian Cuisine]]
Roman Sauce (Salsa Agro-dolce)
==Ingredients== *[[Cookbook:Espagnole Sauce|espagnole sauce]] (No. 1) *[[Cookbook:Stock|stock]] *burnt [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] *[[Cookbook:Vinegar|vinegar]] *[[Cookbook:Raisin|raisins]] *[[Cookbook:Pine Nut|pine nuts]] or [[Cookbook:Almond|almonds]]
==Procedure== #Mix two spoonsful of burnt sugar with one of vinegar, and dilute with a little good stock. #Then add two cups of Espagnole sauce, a few stoned raisins, and a few pinocchi (pine nuts) or shredded almonds. #Keep this hot in a [[Cookbook:Bain-Marie|bain-marie]], and serve with cutlets, calf's head or feet or tongue.
----
Roman Sauce (another way)
==Ingredients== *[[Cookbook:Espagnole Sauce|espagnole sauce]] *an [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]] *[[Cookbook:Butter|butter]] *[[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] *[[Cookbook:Lemon|lemon]] *[[Cookbook:Herbs|herbs]] *[[Cookbook:Nutmeg|nutmeg]] *[[Cookbook:Raisin|raisins]] *[[Cookbook:Pine Nut|pine nuts]] or [[Cookbook:Almond|almonds]] *burnt [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]]
==Procedure== #Cut up a small bit of onion, fry it slightly in butter and a little flour, add the juice of a lemon and a little of the peel grated, a bouquet of herbs, a pinch of nutmeg, a few stoned raisins, shredded almonds or pinocchi, and a tablespoonful of burnt sugar. #Add this to a good Espagnole sauce, and warm it up in a bain-marie.
{{decameron}}
[[Category:Sauce recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}}
These little confections are great one-per-afternoon snacks. These badboys are dense and will give you an euphoric high on sweets but make you want to go work out after.
==Ingredients==
*1 [[Cookbook:Pound|lb.]] (450g) [[Cookbook:Cream Cheese|cream cheese]] *2 [[Cookbook:Eggs|eggs]] *3/4 [[Cookbook:Cup|cups]] (180g) [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] *semi-sweet [[Cookbook:chocolate chips|chocolate chips]]
==Equipment== *[[Cookbook:Cupcake papers|cupcake papers]] *[[Cookbook:Cupcake Pan|cupcake pan]] *[[Cookbook:Microwave oven|microwave oven]] *[[Cookbook:Oven|oven]] *[[Cookbook:Mixing bowl|mixing bowl]] *[[Cookbook:Double boiler|double boiler]] (optional)
==Procedure==
#Preheat your [[Cookbook:Oven|oven]] to [[Cookbook:Oven Temperatures|350°F]] (180°C). #Soften the cream cheese in the [[Cookbook:Microwave Oven|microwave]] in a bowl. Thirty seconds on a medium setting should be sufficient. #Combine the cream cheese, eggs, and sugar. #Line the pan with the papers. #Put chocolate chips in the bottom of the cupcake papers - less than a full layer; do not completely cover the bottom of the papers. #Fill the cups with the mixture, then place into the oven. #[[Cookbook:Bake|Bake]] for about 15 minutes. The chocolate will melt and create a bottom to your cakes, but part of that chocolate will also bubble up through the cream cheese for an added effect. #Remove and allow to cool for 20 minutes, until the chocolate hardens on the bottom and becomes crunchy.
You can also garnish the top of the cakes with chocolate that you melt in a [[Cookbook:double boiler|double boiler]]. I added a dollop of chocolate little larger than a quarter on the top.
[[Category:Dessert recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Chocolate recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[category:Gluten-free recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Recipes_with_metric_units|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Indonesia|Cuisine of Indonesia]]
'''Nastar''', or '''tananas''', are [[Cookbook:pineapple|pineapple]] jam filled cookies. These are popular treats for Eid ul-Fitr and Christmas celebrations in Indonesia.
==Ingredients== ===Cookie=== * 0.5 kg [[Cookbook:Margarine|margarine]] * 0.5 kg all-purpose [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] * 6 [[Cookbook:Egg|egg]] yolks * 2 egg yolks, for painting the top of the cookies * 1 ounce [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] * 5 gr [[Cookbook:Vanilla|vanilla]] powder * 1 ounce Gouda [[Cookbook:Cheese|cheese]] grated, or Cheddar as substitute * 0.5 ounce [[Cookbook:Raisin|raisin]] for garnish
===Jam=== * 2 [[Cookbook:Pineapple|pineapples]] * 300 gr [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Cinnamon|cinnamon]] stick
==Procedure== ===Jam=== # Peel pineapple, wash and make pineapple [[Cookbook:Purée|purée]] # Put pineapple purée in a pan, add sugar and cinnamon, cook while mixing in medium fire until set # If the jam still tastes sour, add more sugar to taste # Let it cool, pineapple jam has to be thick enough to roll into small marbles
===Dough=== # Batter 6 egg yolks with margarine and sugar # Add grated cheese to mix # Add flour and vanilla little by little to make dough
===Cookie=== # Roll the dough smaller than golf ball, fill with pineapple jam # Cut raisin into two, put it on top # Paint the cookie with egg yolk # Use [[Cookbook:Cookie Sheet|cookie sheet]], bake in oven (30 minutes) until golden yellow.
[[Category:Cookie recipes|Nastar]] [[Category:Indonesian recipes|Nastar]] [[Category:Holiday recipes|Nastar]]

[[Image:Vegemiteontoast large.jpg|right|250px]] {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Australia|Australian Cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of New Zealand|New Zealander Cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Sandwiches|Sandwiches]]
The '''Vegemite sandwich''' is a simple dish, which is known to frequent the lunchboxes of school children and the plates of casual breakfasters alike. The lunchbox variety often involves two slices of bread, whereas the breakfast variety usually only involves one, and is often toasted. Margarine may be used as a replacement for the butter, however in modern times it is becoming common for margarine/butter to be considered an optional ingredient.
==Ingredients== * [[Cookbook:Bread|bread]] * [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]] * [[Cookbook:Vegemite|Vegemite]]
== Procedure == # Spread butter thickly and unevenly on bread. # Spread Vegemite a little less thickly, and unevenly on bread. # A slice of cheese can be added at this point. (optional)
==Notes, tips and variations== * A variation is to add avocado for an avocado and Vegemite sandwich. * Yet another variation is to spread Vegemite and then place sliced onions and a slice of cheese on toast and then place under a grill or toaster to melt the cheese. * Some consumers assert that white sliced bread will give a superior result.
[[Category:Australian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:New Zealand recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Sandwich recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Denmark|Danish Cuisine]]
The '''frikadeller''' - as [[w:Denmark|Danish]] as the [[w:Dannebrog|Dannebrog]].
This is standard Danish fare, made of ground [[Cookbook:Pork|pork]] and [[Cookbook:Veal|veal]]. Traditionally served with [[Cookbook:Boiling|boiled]] [[Cookbook:Potato|potatoes]], [[Cookbook:Gravy|gravy]] and [[Cookbook:Rødkål|rødkaal]] ([[Cookbook:Braising|braised]] red [[Cookbook:Cabbage|cabbage]]). Originally, this dish was made so that the meat would feed more people, and thus, the possibilities as to what can be added are numerous.
These can be frozen and reheated.
==Ingredients== *250 [[Cookbook:g|grams]] ground [[Cookbook:Veal|veal]] *250 grams ground [[Cookbook:Pork|pork]] *1 large [[Cookbook:Egg|egg]] *1 finely chopped [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]] *20% by volume of [[Cookbook:Bread Crumb|bread crumbs]] (or approx 3/4 [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]]) *[[Cookbook:Pepper|pepper]] and [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] to taste
*[[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]] (optional) *substitute bread crumbs with [[Cookbook:Wheat Germ|wheat germ]] and/or [[Cookbook:Oat Bran|oat bran]] *ground [[Cookbook:Parsley|parsley]] to taste *Any ingredient will work. Many people add a quantity of milk also, and the mixture is then thickened again with more flour, bread crumbs and/or oat bran.
==Procedure== #Mix all ingredients. #Make small patties. #[[Cookbook:Frying|Fry]] in hot [[Cookbook:Skillet|skillet]] with (lots of) butter.
[[Category:Danish recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Veal recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Pork recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|US Cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Breakfast|Breakfast]] | [[Cookbook:Omelet Recipes|Omelet Recipes]]
The '''Denver omelet''' is a bit like the [[Cookbook:Spanish Omelet|Spanish omelet]], but with different non-[[Cookbook:Egg|egg]] ingredients. This recipe makes 2 servings.
*4 large [[Cookbook:Egg|eggs]] *1 [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] [[Cookbook:Chop|chopped]] [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]] *1/2 cup chopped red [[Cookbook:Bell Pepper|bell peppers]] *1/2 cup chopped green bell peppers *1/2 cup [[Cookbook:Dicing|diced]] cooked [[Cookbook:Ham|ham]] *8 slices cooked [[Cookbook:Bacon|bacon]], drained and crumbled *2 [[Cookbook:Tablepoons|tablespoons]] [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]] *1/2 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoon]] [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] *1/2 teaspoon [[Cookbook:Pepper|pepper]] *a couple drops of your favorite hot sauce (optional)
==Procedure== #Melt butter in a large [[Cookbook:Skillet|skillet]] or on a [[Cookbook:Griddle|griddle]]. #[[Cookbook:Sauteeing|Saute]] onion, bell pepper, ham and bacon in the butter until the onion starts to become opaque. #In a small bowl, [[Cookbook:Whipping|whip]] the eggs lightly. Add salt, pepper, and hot sauce if desired. #Slowly stir the eggs into the mixture in the skillet. #Lightly [[Cookbook:Browning|brown]] on one side. #Turn over and lightly brown other side.
[[Category:Breakfast recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Egg recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Omelette recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:American recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Appetizer recipes|10|15 minutes|2}}
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Middle Eastern cuisines|Middle Eastern Cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the Mediterranean|Mediterranean Cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Vegan cuisine|Vegan Cuisine]]
'''Baba ganoush''' is a common Middle Eastern and Mediterranean dip with a creamy, somewhat smoky flavor. It is usually eaten with [[Cookbook:Pita|pita bread]] although [[Cookbook:Naan|naan]] or a crispy [[Cookbook:Flatbread|flatbread]] also work well.
==Ingredients== * 1 medium-large [[Cookbook:Eggplant|eggplant]], any variety, 1 to 1½ [[Cookbook:Pound|pounds]] * 2 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoons]] raw [[Cookbook:Tahini|tahini]] * Juice of 1 [[Cookbook:Lime|lime]] * 1 clove [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]], crushed * 3 tablespoons [[Cookbook:Olive oil|olive oil]] * ½ [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|tsp]] [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * [[Cookbook:Paprika|Paprika]] or [[Cookbook:Cayenne_pepper|cayenne pepper]], as a garnish
==Procedure== # Roast the eggplant. This can be done in a variety of ways, but the flesh should be fully cooked and the skin should be burned and falling off easily. An effective method is to prick the eggplant and place it a few inches under a broiler, turning it as the exposed skin blackens, about every 3-4 minutes. Place a pan underneath to catch the juices, and discard them. # Scrape off the eggplant skin. It's all right if you miss a few burned bits. # Finely chop or blend the eggplant flesh with the rest of the ingredients. The consistency should be smooth. Reserve a bit of the olive oil, and drizzle that over the top. Sprinkle with some paprika or cayenne.
[[Category:Vegan recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Middle Eastern recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Mediterranean recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Appetizer recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Featured recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[category:Gluten-free recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Spain|Spanish Cuisine]]
==Ingredients== *5 [[Cookbook:Egg|eggs]] *1 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|tsp.]] [[Cookbook:Vanilla|vanilla]] *1 can of sweet and condensed milk,or sweetened condensed coconut milk *1 can of evaporated milk (Large can) *caramel topping
==Instructions== #Heat oven to [[Cookbook:Oven Temperatures|375°F]] #Combine all ingredients (except caramel topping) in blender #Blend for 2 minutes #Place thin layer of caramel topping on bottom of bundt pan. Pour mixture on top of caramel topping. #Place loaf pan in a larger pan with water. It will act as a [[Cookbook:Double Boiler|double boiler]]. Place both pans in [[Cookbook:Oven|oven]]. #Cook for ''1 '' hours or until center is firm. Remove from oven. #'''Wait until cool.''' #Place a round dish over the top of the bundt pan and flip over the pan. The flan can be served on the dish.
[[Category:Spanish recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Pudding and Custard recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Dairy recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]
