{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Desserts|Desserts]] | [[Cookbook:Confections|Confections]]
'''Chocolate truffles''' are soft chocolate balls. This recipe makes about 24.
==Ingredients== *8[[Cookbook:Ounce|oz]] (227[[Cookbook:g|g]]) bittersweet/plain [[Cookbook:Chocolate|chocolate]] (chopped into small pieces) *6 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoons]] (likely Imperial ones: 108 [[Cookbook:mL|mL]], 7.2 US tablespoons, or 2 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoons]] shy of 1/4 [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]]) [[Cookbook:Double Cream|double cream]] (48% fat) *[[Cookbook:Cocoa Powder|cocoa powder]] *[[Cookbook:Icing sugar|Icing sugar]]
In the [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|USA]], try using 2 tablespoons unsalted [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]] with 5 1/3 tablespoons heavy cream.
==Procedure== # Put the chocolate in a bowl and set over (a [[Cookbook:Double Boiler|double boiler]]). # Heat until melted and smooth, stirring occasionally. # Remove from the pot of hot water. # Add the cream and stir well. # Leave to cool. # Cover and refrigerate for 35 minutes or until the mixture is just firm enough to hold its shape. # [[Cookbook:Sifting|Sift]] a layer of cocoa powder and icing sugar together onto a plate. The icing sugar is to make sure the cocoa powder isn't too bitter. # Take a heaped [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoonful]] of the chocolate mixture and shape it into a ball. # Roll each truffle in the cocoa powder/icing sugar to coat all over in an even layer. Shake off the excess and set on a tray. # Continue shaping and coating the remaining truffles. Set on a tray, making sure they don't touch each other. # Cover and refrigerate. Remove 15 minutes before serving.
[[Category:Confection recipes]] [[Category:Chocolate recipes]]

{{recipesummary|Dessert recipes|10-12|10 minutes prep,
~30 minutes cooking|3}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the Netherlands|Dutch Cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Dessert|Desserts]] This is an old [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the Netherlands|Dutch]] recipe for a very 'powerful' chocolate pie. == Ingredients == === Crust === * 2-3 packs of 'maria' biscuits (also known as '[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rich_tea Rich Tea Biscuits]') * cold black coffee (important) === Filling === * 150/200 gram [[Cookbook:Cocoa Powder|cocoa powder]] * 150/200 gram [[Cookbook:Granulated_Sugar| granulated sugar]] * 250-500 [[Cookbook:g|grams]] of real [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]] (use about 750grams or something for more then 2 layers of biscuits, and adjust cocoa/sugar amount to match or adjust to taste :) * some [[Cookbook:Milk|milk]] (about 1 [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]]) === Topping === * chocolate sprinkles (dutch: hagelslag) === Tools === * a dish of some sort with high enough edges (this is important too, an [[Cookbook:Pie Pan|apple pie baking mold]] or similar '[[Cookbook:Springform Pan|springvorm]]' will probably do. about 26[[Cookbook:cm|cm]] in diameter) * cooking pot that can take all the filling ingredients * a spoon (preferably a [[Cookbook:Wooden_Spoon|wooden spoon]]) == Procedure == # take a wide/big pan and melt the butter # add the sugar and stir/disolve this this into the butter # stir the cocoa through the sugar/butter mixture. optionally make this a little more liquid with some milk (not too much!!) # take the biscuits and dip them into the cold black coffee. put these on the bottom of the dish. # after creating a layer of biscuits pour/smear the chocolate mix ontop of it. # then make another layer with dipped biscuits and pour/smear another layer of chocolate # repeat this until you run out of chocolate/biscuits. # finally place the chocolate sprinkels on top and put it in the fridge until it's hard enough to consume. # enjoy! == Notes, Tips, and Variations == * measurements shouldn't be taken to precise, play with the ammounts to your likings * milk is optional.. and too much will make the cake less solid ===Vegan Variation=== Remove the milk, remove the chocolate sprinkles(unless you have vegan ones) and replace the butter by 2/3 [[Cookbook:Soy|soy]] butter and 1/3 [[Cookbook:Margarine|margarine]], or just all margarine. [[Category:Vegan recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Dessert recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Pie recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Dutch recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|American]]
This is a great dressing to use for, just not salads, but for sandwiches and as a dip with crudites.
==Ingredients==
*3 cloves [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]], minced *1/2 cup [[Cookbook:Onion|onions]], minced *1/4 cup [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] *1/4 cup red wine [[Cookbook:Vinegar|vinegar]] *1/2 cup [[Cookbook:Olive Oil|olive oil]] *2 cups [[Cookbook:Mayonnaise|mayonnaise]] * [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] and [[Cookbook:Black Pepper|black pepper]] *2 teaspoons dry [[Cookbook:Mustard|mustard]] *1 tablespoon fresh [[Cookbook:Oregano|oregano]], minced *1 tablespoon fresh [[Cookbook:Basil|basil]], chopped
==Procedure== #Mix all the ingredients in a large bowl.
Makes 3 1/2 cups
15 minutes 15 mins prep
[[Category:Salad Dressing recipes|Ranch Dressing]] [[Category:American recipes|Ranch Dressing]]

page.title: Cookbook:Pancetta Fusilli with Herb Shallot Cream

revision.text:
{{recipe}}
==Ingredients==
* 250g of [[Cookbook:Pancetta|pancetta]] * 1 tbsp [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]] * 1 tsp [[Cookbook:Mincing|minced]] [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]] * 1 lb [[Cookbook:Shallot|shallots]] (12-15 large) * 1/2 tsp of [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]], [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]], [[Cookbook:Pepper|pepper]] * 1.5 cups of [[Cookbook:Chicken Stock|chicken stock]] * 1/4 cup of [[Cookbook:Heavy Cream|heavy cream]] * 1 cup tightly packed [[Cookbook:Herbs|herbs]] ([[Cookbook:Rosemary|rosemary]], [[Cookbook:Sage|sage]], [[Cookbook:Thyme|thyme]], [[Cookbook:Marjoram|marjoram]], [[Cookbook:Parsley|parsley]], [[Cookbook:Basil|basil]]) * 500g [[Cookbook:Fusilli|fusilli]] * 1 tsp [[Cookbook:Olive Oil|olive oil]] * 1.5 cups [[Cookbook:Parmigiano Reggiano|parmigiano reggiano]]
==Procedure==
# Place pancetta in a large saute pan and cook over medium-low heat stirring occasionally until crisp about 15 minutes. Using a slotted spoon remove from pan and drain on paper towels. Set aside. Pour off all but 1 T of the fat. # Add butter to the fat in the pan. Add garlic, shallots and sugar and season lightly with salt and pepper. Reduce heat to lowest setting and cook covered until shallots are soft and transparent about 15 minutes. Remove lid raise heat to medium high and cook stirring constantly until they have a deep golden-brown coating about 10 minutes. Do not allow to burn. # Add the stock and simmer until reduced by one-third stirring to loosen brown bits from bottom of pan about 7 minutes. The sauce can be prepared up to this point several hours ahead and kept covered in the refrigerator. # Bring a large pot of water to a boil for the pasta. (Reheat the shallot mixture if it was prepared in advance.) If using add cream to shallots and simmer for 2 minutes over high heat until sauce thickens slightly. Keep warm. Coarsely chop all but a small handful of herbs. # Cook pasta according to package directions. Drain and return to pot. Add chopped herbs to sauce and cook for another minute. Season to taste with salt and pepper. Add pasta to sauce and toss together over low heat for 1 minute. (As pasta and sauce heat, saute remaining herbs in 1/2 t olive oil until crisp for garnish.) Stir in pancetta and 1/2 C of the grated cheese. Divide the pasta among 4 bowls. Garnish with sauteed herbs. Serve remaining cheese on the side.
This makes 4-6 servings.
==Variations and Additions==
Given the strong and flavorful nature of this dish, when choosing a meat or other food to go along with this you must keep in mind that the two must not overpower each other. Grilling a small medallion of sirloin steak with garlic and red wine would go along perfectly with this, or perhaps a seared pork tenderloin medallion with white wine and ground pepper.
[[Category:Pasta recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Italian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Italy|Italian Cuisine]]
'''Marsala Chicken Scallopini''' is a meal in the style of Italian cuisine, with mouthwatering flavors gotten from the fortified Marsala wine.
==Ingredients== *2 boneless skinless [[Cookbook:Chicken|chicken]] breasts * 4 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|tsp]] [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]] * 3 tsp [[Cookbook:Olive Oil|olive oil]] * 1/2 [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] dry [[Cookbook:Marsala Wine|marsala wine]] * 1/2 cup [[Cookbook:Beef|beef]]/chicken [[Cookbook:Stock|stock]] * 1/2 [[Cookbook:Pound|lb]] of fresh [[Cookbook:Asparagus|asparagus]] * [[Cookbook:Parsley|parsley]] * [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * [[Cookbook:Pepper|pepper]] * [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] * [[Cookbook:Oregano|oregano]] * fresh [[Cookbook:Basil|basil]]
==Preparation== # Put each chicken breast in a plastic bag and flatten with a [[Cookbook:Meat Tenderizer|meat tenderizer]]. Coarsely [[Cookbook:Chop|chop]] the basil, and then [[Cookbook:Throwing|throw]] it in a deep [[Cookbook:Baking Pan|baking pan]] along with some flour, oregano, and [[Cookbook:Tossing|toss]] the chicken with it. # Melt 2 tsp of butter in a medium fry pan on low-medium heat. When the butter stops bubbling, add the chicken and brown each section approximately 3 minutes for each side. Once this is done, cover and set aside on a separate plate. # Drain off most of the liquid from the pan, and raise the heat. Pour a dollop of olive oil in, and sear the asparagus quickly. Remove this and set aside. # Keep at high heat, add the marsala and 1/4 of the stock. [[Cookbook:Boiling|Boil]] off for a few minutes. Lower the heat, and return the asparagus to the pan. Add the remaining stock and boil off to reduce. Add a tsp of butter, and cover chicken with sauce. # Sprinkle with parsley and serve.
At various points during this, you may want to grind some fresh pepper and sprinkle salt over top of the sauce or chicken,;do so according to your tastes.
This serves 4-6, depending on serving size.
[[Category:Chicken recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Italian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Asparagus recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Marsala Wine recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

revision.comment: single-crust proportions tend to get overmixed
revision.text:
{{recipesummary|Pastry recipes|1-2|prep: 30 minutes
baking: 1 hour|3|[[Image:23-pies finished.jpg|300px]]}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Dessert|Dessert]] | [[Cookbook:Vegan_cuisine|Vegan Cuisine]] This recipe makes enough dough for one 9 inch covered pie. If your pie only requires a bottom crust, use half this recipe. Note: for best results, make the full recipe. If only a single crust is required, make the full recipe and freeze half for later. In contrast to [[Cookbook:Bread|bread]], pie crust and other pastries should be made in a way that minimizes the development of [[Cookbook:Gluten|gluten]]. Once the water has been added, the dough should be worked as little as possible, to minimize toughness in the finished crust. == Ingredients == * 2 1/2 cups (310 grams) [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] * 1 teaspoon (6 grams) [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * 1 teaspoon (4 grams) [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] (optional) * 1 cup cold (225 grams) [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]] * 1/3 cup plus 1 Tablespoon (80 mL plus 15 mL) cold water == Procedure == # Whisk 2 1/2 cups flour, 1 teaspoon salt and 1 teaspoon sugar together in a deep bowl. # Cut 1 cup cold butter into small pieces and add to the flour mixture. # Using a [[Cookbook:Pastry Blender|pastry blender]] or two butter knives, cut the butter into the flour until the butter is in small pea-sized pieces. # Add 1/3 cup plus 1 Tablespoon cold water; cut the water into the flour-butter mixture with the edge of a rubber [[Cookbook:Spatula|spatula]] until it is evenly moistened and will hold together when pressed. # Form the dough into a ball with your hands, kneading in any loose flour. This should be done as quickly as possible to avoid melting the butter in the dough. # Chill the dough for 10-20 minutes. # Cut the dough evenly in half. # On a lightly floured board, roll each half out until it will cover a 9 inch pie dish, with about 3/4" inch overhang. Image:07-crust dry ingredients.jpg|dry ingredients Image:08-crust butter.jpg|added butter Image:09-crust blended.jpg|blended butter Image:10-crust with water.jpg|with added water Image:11-crust balled.jpg|dough rolled into a ball Image:12-crust on board.jpg|dough on a lightly floured board Image:13-crust flattened.jpg|dough flattened Image:14-crust rolled.jpg|dough rolled out Image:15-crust size.jpg|rolled dough compared to pie dish Image:16-crust in dish.jpg|crust in pie dish == To Form a Covered Pie == # Lay the bottom crust in the pie dish, ensuring that there are no gaps between the crust and the bottom of the dish. # Fill the crust with the pie filling. # Place the top crust on top, leaving equal overhang on all sides. # Cut the overhang to about 3/4 of an inch all around the pie. # Working around the pie, hold the bottom and top crust overhangs together and tuck the combined overhang into the pie dish behind the bottom crust. # With the forefinger and thumb of each hand, pinch the ridge formed by the tuck into a decorative edge, or press this ridge with a fork. # Brush the top of the pie with milk, and sprinkle with sugar. # Cut vents in the top crust so that steam can escape. # For a fruit pie, bake on the lower-middle rack of an oven at 425 degress Fahrenheit for 30 minutes to set the crust, then at 350 degreess Fahrenheit for 30 minutes to cook the filling. Note: When baking two pies at once, rotate the pies 180 degrees at 15 minutes and 45 minutes to ensure the crust does not burn due to its proximity to the oven walls. Image:17-crust filled.jpg|crust filled with fruit Image:18-pie covered.jpg|top crust laid over filled bottom crust Image:19-pie edge.jpg|3/4" overhang Image:20-pie edge fold.jpg|how crust is folded over Image:21-pie folded.jpg|edge completely folded over Image:22-pie crimped.jpg|edge of crust decoratively crimped Image:23-pies finished.jpg|finished pies Image:24-pie milk sugar detail.jpg|milk brushed on top crust and sprinkled with sugar Image:25-pie ventholes.jpg|vents cut in top crust Image:26-pies in oven.jpg|pies in the oven ==Notes, tips, and variations== ;Vegan: Use a [[Cookbook:Vegan_Substitutions|hard vegan fat]], such as [[Cookbook:Margarine|margarine]] in place of the butter. (used for the images shown above) ;Traditional: Use [[Cookbook:Lard|lard]], which is less saturated than butter and produces the flakiest crusts. ;Top Crust Colouring: Brush on lightly beaten egg white to colour crust instead of milk. [[Category:Vegan recipes|Pie Crust, Flaky]] [[Category:Pastry recipes|Pie Crust, Flaky]] [[Category:Featured recipe candidate|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisines|Cuisines]] | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of El Salvador|Cuisine of El Salvador]] [[Image:Pupusas2.gif|right|thumb|pupusas]]
A '''pupusa''' is a stuffed [[Cookbook:Tortilla|corn-tortilla]], usually served with a spicy [[Cookbook:Coleslaw|coleslaw]] called '''curtido'''. This recipe makes both.
Pupusas are hand-made and thick. Like all corn tortillas, they are made using [[Cookbook:Corn Masa|corn masa]]. They are stuffed with one or more of the following: *[[Cookbook:Cheese|cheese]] ''(queso)'' (usually a soft Salvadoran cheese called Quesillo) *[[Cookbook:Frying|fried]] [[Cookbook:Pork Rind|pork rind]] ''(chicharrones)'' *[[Cookbook:Chicken|chicken]] ''(pollo)'' *[[Cookbook:Refried Beans|refried beans]] ''(frijoles refritos)'' *''queso y [[Cookbook:Loroco|loroco]]'' (loroco is a shrub flower bud from [[Cookbook:Central American cuisines|Central America]]) There is also the ''pupusa revueltas'' (with mixed ingredients of cheese, pork, and [[Cookbook:Bean|beans]]). Pupusas are from El Salvador, but immigrants have brought the dish to Southern [[Cookbook:California cuisine|California]], where there are now many pupuserias (places where pupusas are sold). Pupusas are usually served with curtido and [[Cookbook:Tomato Sauce|tomato sauce]]. They are eaten with the fingers.
==Preparing the dough== There are different brands of corn masa to make the dough. MASECA, which can be found in most large supermarkets in the international section, is one of them but there are others. Follow the instructions on the bag for making tortilla dough, and make as much dough as needed. (One pupusa uses about as much dough as two tortillas.) Once the dough has been prepared set it aside while you prepare the filling.
==Three Fillings== ===Cheese=== *3 [[Cookbook:Cup|cups]] of shredded [[Cookbook:Cheese|cheese]] (use hard and cream cheese mixed together; you can mix frying cheese, [[Cookbook:Mozzarella Cheese|mozzarella]] and [[Cookbook:Ricotta Cheese|ricotta]]) *3 or 4 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoons]] of [[Cookbook:Heavy Cream|heavy cream]] *1/2 to 1 cup of ''[[Cookbook:Loroco|loroco]]'' (this will be hard to find in the [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|U.S.]] So you can use very finely chopped [[Cookbook:Green Pepper|green peppers]] or [[Cookbook:Scallion|scallions]] instead) *[[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] to taste **Or to avoid all these complications, try find a specialty store and buy queso con loroco( you won't get the authentic flavor from a pupusa if you use american ingredients)
Make a paste with these ingredients. To avoid the paste leaking, it should not be too soft.
===Chicharron (Pork Rind Filling)=== *1 cup cooked [[Cookbook:Bacon|bacon]] (cooked with [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]], see below). *4 - 5 [[Cookbook:Tomato|tomatoes]] *1 [[Cookbook:Green Pepper|green pepper]] *salt to taste.
Cook bacon with some garlic (optional). Set [[Cookbook:Fat|fat]] aside but do not discard. Once cooked, grind bacon with the tomatoes, 1 green pepper, and salt to taste. Mix with some of the bacon fat until it has a soft consistency
===Revueltas=== Ground and [[Cookbook:Frying|fried]] beans (they can be canned or prepared from your favorite recipe).
When filling the pupusas add beans, chicharrón and cheese (or combine two of the three).
==Making the pupusas== With two tablespoons of dough make a ball using your hands and later clap your hands until you make a round, thin ([[Cookbook:Inch|1/8 of an inch]] thick) tortilla. Continue making more tortillas this way. Put filling over one tortilla, cover with another and push down the sides to close them. This is the "beginners" method.
People who have experience do it this way: make a ball with the dough. Insert your thumb in the ball and make a hole in the center. Fill that hole with the filling, close the hole by pushing the dough on the sides up. Clap your hands carefully so that the filling doesn't come out and flatten the ball.
Cook on a slightly greased [[Cookbook:Griddle|griddle]], [[Cookbook:Frying Pan|pan]] or electric pancake griddler and cook over low-medium heat ([[Cookbook:Oven Temperatures|325-350°F]]) first one side, then the other until they are cooked. Each side will be ready when it no longer sticks to the pan (depending on the thickness of the tortillas, this might take 4 minutes or more per side).
Pupusas are topped with pickled cabbage and tomato sauce.
==Curtido (pickled colesaw)== *chopped [[Cookbook:Cabbage|cabbage]] that has been quickly passed through [[Cookbook:Boiling|boiling]] water *medium [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]], sliced *[[Cookbook:Carrot|carrot]], finely shredded *cooked [[Cookbook:Green Bean|green beans]], not too soft (optional) *[[Cookbook:Beet|beets]] (optional) *[[Cookbook:Horseradish|horseradish]] (optional). *[[Cookbook:Red Pepper|red pepper]], finely chopped (optional) *[[Cookbook:Vinegar|vinegar]] *water *1 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoon]] [[Cookbook:Oregano|oregano]] *[[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] to taste
In a glass or plastic jar with wide opening mix all the ingredients. Add vinegar and water to taste. Mix with a [[Cookbook:Wooden Spoon|wooden spoon]] (never metal). Put the mix in the refrigerator and let it rest for a week so that the ingredients [[Cookbook:Pickling|pickle]].
[[Category:Salvadoran recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Pork recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Cheese recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Cabbage recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

[[Image:CookbookRefriedBeans.jpg|right|thumb|160px|looks done]] [[Image:BeansHamPot.jpg|right|thumb|160px|cooked beans and ham bone]] {{recipe}}
Oddly enough, '''refried beans''' ''(frijoles refritos)'' are only [[Cookbook:Frying|fried]] once. The prefix "re" is a [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Spain|Spanish]] prefix meaning "very" or "well", inappropriately tacked onto a non-Spanish word.
==Ingredients== *[[Cookbook:Bean|beans]], especially pinto beans or [[Cookbook:Black Bean|black beans]] *home-rendered [[Cookbook:Lard|lard]]
==Procedure== #If using dried beans, wash them and examine them for any rocks, then cover with water in a medium pot and [[Cookbook:Simmering|simmer]] until they are very soft. You'll need to cook the beans a long time on very low heat. You may add salt to the water. You may add onion halves or a [[Cookbook:Ham|ham]] bone, which you can remove at the end. You may wish to soak the beans overnight in the refrigerator before cooking them. Expect the cooking to take at least 3 hours, if not 6 or more. #If using canned beans, rinse them. Try to make sure they are not slimy or too salty. #Get a large wide pot or tall-sided [[Cookbook:Frying Pan|frying pan]]. #Smash the beans, perhaps with a potato masher. #Add home-rendered [[Cookbook:Lard|lard]], totalling up to 20% of the total. (25% of the amount prior to adding) #Fry the beans, stirring and turning them until they thicken as desired.
==Recipes using refried beans include== *[[Cookbook:Burrito|Burrito]] *[[Cookbook:Pupusa|Pupusa]]
[[Category:Mexican recipes|Refried beans]] [[Category:Southwestern recipes|Refried beans]] [[Category:Bean recipes|Refried beans]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Dessert|Desserts]] | [[Cookbook:Pie Crust|Pie Crust]]
==Ingredients== *1 [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] all purpose [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] *1/2 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoon]] [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] *10 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoons]] solid vegetable [[Cookbook:Shortening|shortening]] *1 whipped [[Cookbook:Egg|egg]] *1/2 tablespoon distilled white [[Cookbook:Vinegar|vinegar]] *2 tablespoons cold water
==Procedure== #Mix flour and salt. Cut shortening into the flour/salt mixture with a [[Cookbook:Pastry Cutter|pastry cutter]], until mixture resembles the texture of tiny [[Cookbook:Pea|peas]]. #In separate bowl, wisk the egg, vinegar and water until well mixed. #Drizzle water/egg mixture into flour mixture. Stir with fork, stir until dough is formed. #Gather dough into a ball, flatten into a [[Cookbook:Inch|4-inch-wide]] disk. Wrap in plastic, and refrigerate 30 minutes. #Roll dough into 9-inch circle and place in a 9-inch pie pan. #Line the unbaked [[Cookbook:Pie Shell|pie shell]] with foil or parchment paper, fill with dried [[Cookbook:Bean|beans]] or [[Cookbook:Rice|rice]]. #Bake at [[Cookbook:Oven Temperatures|425°F]] until light golden brown (about 15 - 18 minutes). #Cool before filling.
==Recipes using this crust== *[[Cookbook:Grandma's Lemon Meringue Pie|Grandma's Lemon Meringue Pie]] *[[Cookbook:Banana_Cream_Pie|Banana Cream Pie]]
[[Category:Pastry recipes|Pie Crust, Grandma's]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|Pie Crust, Grandma's]]

{{cookwork|needs amt. of pickle juice}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Side dishes|Side dishes]] | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|US Cuisine]]
[[Image:GrammysPotatoSalad.jpg|thumb|Grammy's Potato Salad]] This is a classic [[Cookbook:New England cuisine|New England]] potato salad. Chopping the potatoes into small pieces allows more surface to be coated and improves the flavor.
Makes about 10 servings.
== Ingredients ==
*3 [[Cookbook:Pound|pounds]] [[Cookbook:California cuisine|California]] long white [[Cookbook:Potato|potatoes]] *3 hard boiled [[Cookbook:Egg|eggs]], [[Cookbook:Chop|chopped]] *1 medium [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]], [[Cookbook:Mince|minced]] *3/4 [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] [[Cookbook:Mayonnaise|mayonnaise]] *1/4 sweet pickle juice (from jar of [[Cookbook:Pickle|pickles]]) *1 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoon]] dried [[Cookbook:Parsley|parsley]] *1/2 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoon]] [[Cookbook:Celery Seed|celery seed]] *3/4 tablespoon [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] *[[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] *[[Cookbook:Pepper|pepper]] *[[Cookbook:Paprika|paprika]]
== Procedure ==
#Cut unpeeled potatoes in half and cook until they are tender when tested with a knife. Do not overcook. #Peel the potatoes by scraping them lightly with a knife and cut them into 1/2 inch cubes. #Place potatoes in a large bowl and let them come to room temperature. #In a small bowl, combine the mayonnaise, pickle juice and sugar and stir until smooth. #Add the mayonnaise mixture, minced onion, parsley, celery seed and chopped eggs to the potatoes. #Add salt and pepper to taste. Stir lightly to combine. #Place in large serving bowl and sprinkle with paprika. #Cover and refrigerate until ready to serve.
[[Category:Potato recipes|Grammy's Potato Salad]] [[Category:Salad recipes|Grammy's Potato Salad]] [[Category:Egg recipes|Grammy's Potato Salad]] [[Category:American recipes|Grammy's Potato Salad]] [[Category:Side Dish recipes|Grammy's Potato Salad]]

{{recipesummary|Meat recipes|2|~30 minutes|2}}
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Meat Recipes|Meat Recipes]] | [[Cookbook:Vegetarian cuisine|Vegetarian]]
This is a very quick, easy Pineapple Teriyaki entrée, to be served over rice. It is listed as both meat and vegetarian because it works around the pineapple, veggies, and teriyaki, not the protein. Put the rice on to cook first, and the rest will probably be finished by the time the rice is ready.
A [[Cookbook:Teriyaki|Teriyaki recipe]] is available for those who cannot or do not wish to purchase prepared teriyaki sauce.
==Ingredients== ===For the rice=== * 2 [[Cookbook:Cup|c]] [[Cookbook:Rice|rice]] (your choice, but a short-grain white rice is most traditional) * 2 [[Cookbook:Cup|c]] [[Cookbook:Water|water]] * a little [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] Bring all to a boil in a pot or rice cooker. In a pot, cover, turn the heat down when it boils. Simmer for 20 minutes with the lid on, then turn off the heat, fluff with a fork, and let stand for a few minutes.
===For on top of the rice=== *1-2 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|T]] vegetable or olive [[Cookbook:Oil|oil]] *2 c cubed [[Cookbook:Chicken|chicken]] '''or''' *2 c cubed [[Cookbook:Tofu|tofu]] or vegetarian "chicken" (usually flavored, pressed [[Cookbook:Gluten|gluten]]) *1 yellow or white [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]] *1-2 [[Cookbook:Bell Pepper|bell peppers]], whatever color(s) you prefer. Red and green stand out nicely against yellow pineapple. *1 14-16 oz. can of cubed [[Cookbook:Pineapple|pineapple]], drained (Pineapple is often canned in juice, so you may wish to save what you drain.) * 1/4 c (approx.) prepared [[Cookbook:Teriyaki Sauce|teriyaki sauce]]. Soy Vay! Veri Veri Teriyaki is excellent, if available. ===Optional=== If you’d like more or thicker sauce, mix * 1/4 c of water or reserved pineapple juice * 1 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|T]] [[Cookbook:Cornstarch|cornstarch]]
You might also like to toss in *some sliced [[Cookbook:Mushroom|mushrooms]] *1-2 cloves [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]], [[Cookbook:Mincing|minced]], depending upon your teriyaki sauce
==Method==
#Put rice on to cook, as outlined above. #Cut up the chicken/tofu, onion, and bell pepper(s) into bite-sized chunks. Cut up everything before turning on the stove. #Heat a deep 12" pan or wok over high heat. #Add the oil. #[[Cookbook:Sautéing|Sauté]] everything in the oil, adding ingredients in the following order, so as to cook heavier items longer: #*Chicken #*Onion/garlic #*Bell peppers #*Mushrooms #*Pineapple #*Tofu #Add the teriyaki sauce and the cornstarch mixture. If using cornstarch, heat to boiling to thicken and correct with extra water or juice as necessary. #Serve over rice.
[[Category:Pineapple recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Chicken recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

revision.comment: Reverted edit of [[Special:Contributions/72.235.196.222|72.235.196.222]], changed back to last version by Kellen
revision.text:
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Bread|Bread]] | [[Cookbook:Vegetarian_cuisine|Vegetarian Cuisine]]
'''Cardamom bread''' is a sweet yeast bread of Scandinavian origin which is good served at breakfast, with coffee, or as a light dessert. This recipe makes two loaves.
==Ingredients== * 1 pkg [[Cookbook:Yeast|yeast]], around 2.5 tsp * 1/4 c warm water * 3/4 c warm [[Cookbook:Milk|milk]] * 1/2 c [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] * 1/2 t [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * 2 [[Cookbook:Eggs|eggs]] * 1 tsp ground [[Cookbook:Cardamom|cardamom]] (about 20 green pods) * 4 1/2 c [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] * 1/2 c [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]] * grated peel of 1 [[Cookbook:Orange|orange]]
==Procedure== # In a large [[Cookbook:mixing bowl|mixing bowl]], mix flour, salt and orange peel; [[Cookbook:whisk|whisk]] gently to distribute the ingredients. # Split green cardamom pods and remove the seeds inside. With a [[Cookbook:Mortar and pestle|mortar and pestle]], grind the seeds into a powder and add this to the other dry ingredients. # In a small bowl, combine yeast, warm water and sugar. Stir gently for a few seconds, then let stand until the yeast is frothy. # In a small saucepan on low heat, combine butter and milk until the butter is just melted. # In a separate bowl, beat 2 eggs and set aside. # Check that the milk and butter mixture is not hot, then add the it into the dry ingredients and mix. # [[Cookbook:Knead|Knead]] the dough until it is smooth and elastic. # Place the kneaded dough in a greased bowl and let [[Cookbook:rise|rise]] in a warm place (in the oven, for example) until it doubles in size, about one hour. # [[Cookbook:Punch down|Punch down]] the dough, and cut in two parts (one for each loaf).
=== Braiding ===
# For each of the halves, ## Split the dough into three equal sized portions. ## Roll these into "ropes" about 18 inches long. ## Pinch one end of each rope together. ## Braid the ropes together: ### Take the left rope and cross it over the middle one. ### Take the right rope and cross it over the middle one. ### Repeat this procedure until the ropes are fully braided. ## Pinch the other end of the ropes together. ## Tuck each pinched end underneath the main loaf. # Put finished braids on a greased [[Cookbook:cookie sheet|cookie sheet]]. # Let rise again until doubled in size, about 45 minutes. # Prepare an egg wash by beating 1 egg thinned with water. # Brush the top of each braid with the egg wash. # Sprinkle each braid with [[Cookbook:Pearl Sugar|pearl sugar]] and sliced [[Cookbook:Almond|almonds]]. # Bake at 180 °C (350 °Fahrenheit) for 25 minutes.
==Variations== * For a [[Cookbook:Vegan cuisine|vegan]] version, substitute [[Cookbook:Soy_Milk|soy milk]] for milk, [[Cookbook:Egg_Replacer|egg replacer]] for eggs, and a vegan [[Cookbook:Margarine|margarine]] for butter.
==Notes== * Store-bought ground cardamom can be used in this recipe, but has a less intense flavor than freshly ground cardamom. * Orange peel is not traditional in cardamom bread.
[[Category:Vegan_recipes|Cardamom Bread]] [[Category:Bread recipes|Cardamom Bread]] [[Category:Cardamom recipes]] [[Category:Scandinavian recipes]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Breakfast|Breakfast]]
'''Hash browns''' are like [[Cookbook:Hamburger|hamburgers]] made from [[Cookbook:Potato|potatoes]]. Usually they are served with [[Cookbook:Ketchup|ketchup]]. This recipe makes enough for 2 to 4 people.
==Ingredients== * two [[Cookbook:Potato|potatoes]], washed * one half [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]], finely chopped (Optional) * plenty of cooking [[Cookbook:Oil|oil]] ([[Cookbook:Canola Oil|Canola]] is good — see [[Cookbook:Smoke Point|smoke point]] information) * two tablespoons of [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] OR one [[Cookbook:Egg|egg]]
==Procedure== # Grate the raw potatoes with a [[Cookbook:Grater|cheese grater]], place them into a bowl and cover completely with water. Let sit for 10 minutes. # Place a large [[Cookbook:Frying Pan|frying pan]] on medium-high heat and add enough oil to provide a thin coating over the entire bottom of the pan. # Drain the grated potatoes and mix in chopped onions by hand. # Mix the one egg OR two tablespoons of flour into the hash brown mixture evenly. This will allow the hash browns to stay together when frying. # When the oil has come up to temperature apply a large handful of potatoes to the pan and reshape into a patty that is about [[Cookbook:Inch|1/4 in]] ([[Cookbook:mm|6 mm]]) to 1/2 in (12 mm) thick. The thinner the patty the crispier the hash browns will be throughout. # The hash browns are ready to flip when they are crisp and brown on the cooking side. They should also stick together nicely before they are flipped. This should take about 5 to 8 minutes. # The hash browns are done when the new side is brown and crispy. This should take another 3-5 minutes.
==Variation== Try using [[Cookbook:Rosemary|rosemary]] instead of the onion.
[[Category:Potato recipes|Hash Browns]] [[Category:Breakfast recipes|Hash Browns]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Breakfast|Breakfast]]
'''Breakfast Burrito''' - Makes 4 breakfast burritos which serves 2-4 people.
==Ingredients== * eight large [[Cookbook:Egg|eggs]] either [[Cookbook:Scrambled Eggs|scrambled]], [[Cookbook:Fried Egg|sunny-side up]], or [[Cookbook:Poaching|poached]] * four large [[Cookbook:Flour Tortilla|flour burrito skins]] * eight strips of cooked [[Cookbook:Bacon|bacon]] or 1 [[Cookbook:Pound|lb]] (400 [[Cookbook:g|grams]]) cooked breakfast [[Cookbook:Sausage|sausage]] * one full order of [[Cookbook:Hash Browns|Hash Browns]] * [[Cookbook:Hollandaise Sauce|hollandaise sauce]], [[Cookbook:Cheese|cheese]], [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]], and [[Cookbook:Pepper|pepper]] to taste
==Procedure== # Place one-quarter of the hash browns in a burrito skin. # On top of this place two strips of bacon or one quarter of the breakfast sausage. # Add two eggs, cheese, salt, and pepper. # Roll up the burrito skin. If you used poached or sunny-side up eggs you can squeeze the burritos to pop the egg yolks and then work the yolk around to form a [[Cookbook:Sauce|sauce]].
[[Category:Burrito recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Egg recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Potato recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Bacon recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Breakfast recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Dessert|Dessert]] | [[Cookbook:Rice|Rice]]
This is a simple rice pudding recipe, dating to at least 1965, in Columbus Ohio USA.
== Ingredients ==
*2 cups [[Cookbook:Milk|milk]] *4 [[Cookbook:Eggs|eggs]] *2/3 cup [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] *3 cups cooked [[Cookbook:Rice|rice]] (brown rice works as well as, if not better than, white rice) *1 cup [[Cookbook:Raisin|raisins]], if desired *[[Cookbook:Cinnamon|Cinnamon]], [[Cookbook:Nutmeg|nutmeg]], [[Cookbook:Vanilla_extract|vanilla extract]] to taste
== Preparation ==
#Mix milk, eggs, sugar in a 3 quart casserole dish until thoroughly mixed and frothy. #Mix in cinnamon, nutmeg, vanilla. #Mix in rice, then put in raisins. Do not mix in raisins, or they will all wind up on the bottom! #Place casserole in a larger baking pan with about 1 inch of water. #::This will keep the bottom from cooking too fast and burning. #Bake in a 325 degree oven until set, about 1.5 hours.
[[Category:Rice_recipes|Rice Pudding]] [[Category:Dessert recipes|Rice Pudding]] [[Category:Pudding and Custard recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Rice|Rice]]
'''Microwave Risotto'''. This risotto is made using the microwave. It requires very little stirring and turns out quite well.
==Ingredients==
*3 cups simmering hot chicken broth *1/2 Teaspoon Salt *dash ground white or black pepper *2 Tablespoons butter *2 Tablespoons olive oil *1/2 cup minced yellow onion *1 cup uncooked medium grain rice
==Procedure==
#In a saucepan, bring chicken broth, salt and pepper to a low simmer, keep warm until needed. #In 8" x 8" x 2" pyrex dish (or 10" [[Cookbook:Quiche|quiche]] dish), heat oil and butter in microwave for 2-minutes. #Add minced onion to pyrex dish, stir to coat with oil, cook in microwave for 4-minutes. #Add uncooked rice to pyrex dish, stir to coat with oil, cook in microwave for another 4-minutes. #Pour simmering chicken broth into pyrex dish and stir well. Microwave 9-minutes. #Stir rice and chicken broth well and microwave another 9-minutes. #If a creamier risotto is desired, add 1/4-cup warm water, stir well and microwave for another 2-minutes.
Makes 3 main dish servings or 6 side dish servings.
==Notes, tips and variations==
#For a 750-watt microwave, use 100% power settings for each time interval. For 1000 or 1500-watt microwaves, use 70% power settings for each time interval. #As a variation, use 2 1/2-cups chicken broth and 1/2-cup white wine. #Freshly grated parmesan cheese may also be added after cooking.
[[Category:Rice recipes|Microwave Risotto]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Salad Recipes|Salad Recipes]]
== Ingredients ==
* 2 cups elbow macaroni pasta, cooked, drained, and chilled * 1/3 cup red [[Cookbook:Onion|Onion]], chopped * 1/3 cup [[Cookbook:Celery|Celery]], chopped * 1/2 cup [[Cookbook:Mayonnaise|Mayonnaise]] * 1 teaspoon [[Cookbook:Dry mustard|Dry mustard]] * 1 teaspoon [[Cookbook:Sugar|Sugar]] * 2 tablespoons [[Cookbook:Cider vinegar|Cider vinegar]] * [[Cookbook:Salt|Salt]] and [[Cookbook:Pepper|Pepper]] to taste
== Procedure ==
#Whisk mayonnaise, mustard, sugar and vinegar in small bowl. #Mix remaining ingredients in a large bowl. #Pour the dressing onto the salad and stir to combine. #Cool before serving.
8 Servings.
[[Category:Salad recipes|Macaroni Salad]] [[Category:Pasta recipes|Macaroni Salad]]

revision.comment: Revert to revision 630481 dated 2006-10-30 13:17:13 by Herbythyme using [[:en:Wikipedia:Tools/Navigation_popups|popups]]
revision.text:
{{recipe}}
[[Image:CookbookPlacentaBroccoli.jpg|right|thumb|192px]] This is a tasty dish that the whole family will love. It might go well served with rice, especially if the rice is loose and firm.
You'll need about 1/2 the placenta of a 6.2 pound baby, or 1/3 the placenta of a 9.3 pound baby. Chopped and packed, this is just a bit more than 1/3 cup. (but like any raw meat, you don't exactly chop it — try sniping away at it with a kitchen scissors)
==Ingredients== *1/3 [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] chopped fresh human [[Cookbook:Placenta|placenta]] *2/3 cup chopped [[Cookbook:Broccoli|broccoli]] *2 [[Cookbook:Egg|egg]] whites *1/8 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|t]] [[Cookbook:Thyme|thyme]] *[[Cookbook:Oil|oil]] for [[Cookbook:Frying|frying]]
==Procedure== #Wash the placenta well, in a [[Cookbook:Colander|colander]], then shake it to drain. (it will still leak juices) #Stir the egg whites with a fork until they are without lumps. #Mix all ingredients well, squishing them by hand. #Add a decent amount of oil to a suitable frying pan. #Set a burner to high heat, and put the pan on it. #Start frying, stiring as if stir-frying or scrambling an egg. #The small amount of liquid (seeping from the placenta, plus the egg whites) will come to a boil. You might turn down the heat slightly at this point. #Let the liquid boil away and/or solidify onto the broccoli and placenta. #When it looks yummy, serve it.
==Warning== As with any meat from uncontrolled sources (such as hunting or scavanging) people should be cautious of risks involved. Certain blood borne diseases can live in blood and tissue outside the body for some time. Be sure that sensible precautions have been taken.
[[Category:Placenta recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Broccoli recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Soup recipes|12|35 minutes|3}}
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Soup|Soup]]
'''Zuppa Toscana''' is a soup available at The Olive Garden restaurant.
==Ingredients== *1 lb. Spicy Italian Sausage - Crumbled *1/2 lb. Smoked Bacon - Chopped (One can also use precooked bacon bits for this) *1 qt. Water *(2) 14.5 Oz. Cans Chicken Broth *(2) lg. Russet [[Cookbook:Potato|Potato]]es - Cubed *2 [[Cookbook:Garlic|Garlic]] Cloves - Crushed *1 med. Onion - Chopped *2 cups Chopped Kale or Swiss Chard *1 cup Heavy Whipped [[Cookbook:Cream|Cream]] *Salt and pepper to taste
==Procedure== #In a [[Cookbook:Skillet|skillet]] over medium-high heat, brown sausage, breaking into small pieces as you fry it. Drain and set aside. #In skillet over medium-high heat, brown bacon. Drain and set aside. #Place water, broth, potatoes, garlic, and onion into a pot. Simmer over high heat until potatoes are tender. #Add sausage and bacon to the pot. Simmer for 10 minutes. #Add kale/chard and cream to the pot. Seasons with salt and pepper; heat through.
''Bon appétit!''
==Notes, tips, and variations== Potatoes can be substituted with cauliflower for a low carbohydrate version of this soup. I also used 1/2 mild 1/2 spicy turkey sausage instead of pork sausage. Sometimes, fennel is used.
[[Category:Soup recipes|Zuppa toscana]] [[Category:Italian recipes|Zuppa toscana]] [[Category:Bacon recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}}
A classic dessert, with a light texture and a mild flavor. This recipe is for "boiled" custard, but ironically, as Mrs. F.L. Gillette said in ''[http://www.gutenberg.org/files/13923/13923-h/13923-h.htm The Whitehouse Cookbook]'', "it must ''not'' boil or it will curdle." See more on custard in general at [[Cookbook:Custard]].
== Ingredients == *2 [[Cookbook:Cup|cups]] [[Cookbook:Milk|milk]] *2 [[Cookbook:Egg|eggs]] *1/4 to 1/2 cup [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] *1 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoon]] [[Cookbook:Vanilla|vanilla]] extract *1 [[Cookbook:Pinch|pinch]] [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] (optional) *1 [[Cookbook:tablespoon|tablespoon]] [[Cookbook:Cornstarch|cornstarch]] (optional) *2 tablespoons [[Cookbook:Water|water]] (optional)
== Procedure == # Heat milk and salt (if using) in a [[Cookbook:Double Boiler|double boiler]] until bubbles form around the edges. # Beat eggs with sugar until uniform. # Gradually mix approximately 1/2 cup hot milk into the egg mixture to ''temper'' it. # Slowly stir egg mixture into remaining hot milk. # Mix cornstarch and water (if using), and stir into custard. # Stir over heat until thickened (should coat the spoon), ''without'' bringing to a boil. # Remove from heat, and continue stirring to dry the custard slightly. # Stir in vanilla before the dish has cooled completely. # Serve warm or chilled.
==Variations== *Replace vanilla extrace with [[Cookbook:Almond_Extract|almond]] or [[Cookbook:Maple Extract|maple extract]], [[Bartending:Brandy|brandy]] or grated [[Cookbook:Lemon|lemon zest]].
*Stir 1/2 cup of sugar in a small frying pan until it becomes liquid and just begins to smoke. Stir it into the hot milk before adding the egg mixture.
[[Category:Dessert recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Pudding and Custard recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{cookwork|Modify recipe to use fresh ingredients, closer to a real quiche recipe than this Americanised version}} {{recipesummary|French recipes|6|75 minutes|2|Image=[[Image:Quiche Lorraine.jpg|300px]]}}
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of France|Cuisine of France]]
A '''quiche''' is a [[Cookbook:Baking|baked]], [[Cookbook:Sweeteners|unsweetened]] [[Cookbook:Custard|custard]] [[Cookbook:Dessert#Pies, Tarts|pie]], often made with [[wiktionary:savory|savory]] fillings. Originally served in [[wikipedia:Germany|Germany]], quiche was adopted by neighboring [[wikipedia:France|France]] and is now considered a traditional French dish. The French (and now English) word ''quiche'' comes from a [[wiktionary:dialectal|dialectal]] form (''Küchle'') of the German word for [[Cookbook:Dessert#Cakes, cupcakes|cake]] (''Kuchen''). Quiche became popular in [[wikipedia:Britain|Britain]] after [[wikipedia:World War II|World War II]] and in the [[wikipedia:United States|United States]] during the [[wikipedia:1960s|1960s]] and [[wikipedia:1970s|70s]].
==Ingredients== *5 chicken [[Cookbook:Egg|egg]]s *1 1/3 [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] (320 [[Cookbook:mL|mL]]) [[Cookbook:Cream|cream]] (approximately 30% [[Cookbook:Oil and fat|fat]]) *1/2 [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] (120 [[Cookbook:mL|mL]]) ''[[Cookbook:Condensed|condensed]]'' cream of mushroom [[Cookbook:Soup|soup]] *1 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoon]] (5 mL) chopped ''fresh'' [[Cookbook:Tarragon|tarragon]] *1 [[Cookbook:Dash|dash]] ground [[Cookbook:Nutmeg|nutmeg]] *1/4 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoon]] (1.25 mL) [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] *1/8 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoon]] (0.7 mL) ground [[Cookbook:Pepper|pepper]] *1 prepared frozen pie crust *3/4 [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] (180 [[Cookbook:mL|mL]]) freshly-grated [[Cookbook:Swiss Cheese|Swiss cheese]]
==Procedure== #Preheat [[Cookbook:Oven|oven]] to [[Cookbook:Oven Temperatures|375° Fahrenheit]] (190° Celsius) #Place the eggs, cream, condensed soup, tarragon, nutmeg, salt, and pepper in a [[Cookbook:Blender|blender]]; blend ''as briefly as possible'' until they form a [[wikt:homogeneous|homogeneous]] mixture #In the pie crust, create alternating layers of the shredded cheese and the mixture from the blender until the crust is full #Bake the quiche for 35-40 minutes; a toothpick or fork inserted into its middle should come out "clean" #Remove the quiche from the oven and let it cool for at least 20 minutes before serving
==Notes, tips, and variations== *Use nutmeg sparingly *Fresh tarragon will be better than dried tarragon *Placing a very hot pan in under the quiche will give it greater volume *Try making quiches with [[Cookbook:Sautéing|sautéed]] [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]]s, sautéed [[Cookbook:Broccoli|broccoli]], and shredded sharp [[Cookbook:Cheddar cheese|cheddar cheese]]; feel free to experiment
==Warnings== *The quiche mixture may drip over the edge of the pie crust while cooking; place it on a cookie sheet or place foil on the oven rack below it *The quiche will continue to cook after it is removed from the oven; be careful not to overcook it or cut it before it has had a chance to set *[[Cookbook:Half and Half|Half-and-half]] (cream with approximately 12% fat) can be substituted for regular cream to make this dish less fattening; however, be cautious of using milk because low-fat dairy products curdle more easily
==External links== {{wikipedia|Quiche}}
[[Category:French recipes]] [[Category:Egg recipes]] [[Category:Dairy recipes]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes]] [[Category:Featured recipe candidate]] [[Category:Recipes_with_metric_units|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Meat recipes|4|prep: ~10 minutes
marinating: ~30 minutes
cooking: ~10 minutes|2}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Meat Recipes|Meat Recipes]] | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of China|China]] '''Kung Pao Chicken''' is a spicy Chinese-Szechuan recipe made with diced chicken, chili peppers and peanuts, named after a court official. It is a popular dish served at Chinese restaurants throughout the United States and the UK. ==Ingredients== ====Chicken/Marinade:==== * 1 lb [[Cookbook:Chicken|Chicken]]. Boneless, skinless, uncooked. Cut into a 1-inch dice. * 2 T. oyster sauce * 2 T. sherry or rice wine * 1 t. cornstarch ====Spices:==== * 4 T. cooking oil * 1/2 cup shelled peanuts * 5 to 10 dried small red chili peppers * 1/4 t. crushed red pepper flakes * 1 t. crushed garlic ====Vegetables:==== * 1 green bell pepper, cut into 1/2-inch dice * 1 red bell pepper, cut into 1/2-inch dice * 1 can (5-oz) sliced bamboo shoots, drained (optional) * 3 stalks cut celery * 4 green onions, cut into 1/2-inch pieces, including tops ====Sauce:==== * 2 T Soy Sauce * 2 T rice vinegar * 4 T Chicken broth * 1 t garlic powder * 1 t sugar * 1 t cornstarch * 1 t sesame oil 2 teaspoon Hoisin sauce ==Procedure== #Measure and prepare all ingredients before cooking. #Mix all '''Chicken/Marinade''' ingredients in a bowl, stir well and allow to marinate for 1/2-hour. #Mix '''Sauce''' ingredients in another bowl and set aside until needed. Stir out any lumps. #Heat wok or large frying pan until water drops bead up and dance on the hot surface. #Add cooking oil to wok. Wait a few seconds for oil to heat up. #Add remaining '''Spice''' ingredients to wok and stir fry for 30-seconds. #Add '''Chicken/Marinade''' to wok and stir fry for about 4-minutes (until chicken is cooked through). #Add '''Vegetables''' to wok and stir fry for about 2 or 3-minutes. #Stir '''Sauce''' and add to wok. After the sauce comes to a boil, cook for about 1-minute (until sauce thickens). #Stir to coat other ingredients with thickened sauce. #Pour onto large platter and serve immediately. ==Notes, tips, and variations== * Serve with steamed or [[Cookbook:Fried rice|fried rice]]. ==Warnings== * Don't eat the dried, small red chili peppers unless you like spicy-hot foods. They are mainly used to season the pot and are not usually eaten. * Use care in handling the raw chicken. Wash hands and utensils that come into contact with raw chicken. Don't allow raw chicken or its juices to come into contact with other foods, unless they are to be cooked afterwards. [[Category:Chinese recipes|Kung Pao Chicken]] [[Category:Chicken recipes|Kung Pao Chicken]] [[Category:Stir fry recipes|Kung Pao Chicken]]

{{recipesummary|Sandwich recipes|1|5 minutes|1}}
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Sandwiches|Sandwiches]]
These '''Cucumber Sprout sandwiches''' are stuffed with cucumbers, alfalfa sprouts, tomatoes, and avocados.
==Ingredients==
* 2 slices [[Cookbook:Whole Wheat|whole wheat]] [[Cookbook:Bread|bread]] * 2 tbs. [[Cookbook:Cream Cheese|cream cheese]], softened * 6 slices peeled [[Cookbook:cucumber|cucumber]] * 2 tbs. [[Cookbook:Alfalfa|alfalfa sprouts]] * 1 tsp. [[Cookbook:Olive Oil|olive oil]] * 1 tsp. [[Cookbook:Wine vinegar|red wine vinegar]] * 1 [[Cookbook:tomato|tomato]], [[Cookbook:sliced|sliced]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Lettuce|romaine (cos) lettuce]] leaf * 2 tbs. [[Cookbook:Pepperoncini|pepperoncini]], sliced * 1/2 [[Cookbook:avocado|avocado]], peeled and mashed * [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] and [[Cookbook:pepper|pepper]] to taste
==Procedures== #Spread 1 tablespoon cream cheese on each slice of bread. #Arrange cucumber slices in a single layer on one slice of bread. #Cover same slice of bread with alfalfa sprouts, sprinkle with oil and vinegar. #Layer same slice of bread with tomato slices, lettuce, and pepperoncini. #Spread mashed avocado on other slice of bread. #Add salt and pepper to taste #Assemble sandwich and serve immediately.
[[Category:Sandwich recipes|Cucumber Sprout Sandwich]] [[Category:Cucumber recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Sprout recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Avocado recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Tomato recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

revision.comment: Revert to revision 729969 dated 2007-01-23 00:32:53 by Webaware using [[:en:Wikipedia:Tools/Navigation_popups|popups]]
revision.text:
{{recipesummary|Chicken recipes|4|45 minutes|3}}
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Meat Recipes|Meat Recipes]] | [[Cookbook:California cuisine|California]]
'''California Curry Chicken''' - This dish is an attempt to duplicate the flavor of Curry Chicken dishes that are served at Indian restaurants in California.
==Ingredients==
===Meat & Vegetables=== * 4 T. [[Cookbook:cooking oil|cooking oil]] * 1 cup of yellow [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]]s, diced * 2 t. [[Cookbook:garlic|garlic]], [[Cookbook:Mincing|minced]] * 1-lb [[Cookbook:Chicken|Chicken]]. Boneless, uncooked. Cut into cubes. * 6 small [[Cookbook:potato|potato]]es, peeled, quartered, already cooked (boiled, baked or steamed)
===Spices=== * 4 T. mild [[Cookbook:Curry|curry]] powder * 1 T. [[Cookbook:Chili Powder|Chili powder]] * 1 T. [[Cookbook:Paprika|Paprika]] * 1 t. [[Cookbook:Cumin|Cumin]], ground * 1 t. [[Cookbook:garlic powder|garlic powder]] * 2 t. [[Cookbook:Cardamon|Cardamon]] powder * 1 t. [[Cookbook:Turmeric|Turmeric]] powder * 1 t. [[Cookbook:mustard|mustard]] powder * ¼ t. [[Cookbook:Cinnamon|Cinnamon]], ground * 1 [[Cookbook:Bay Leaf|bay leaf]]
===Sauce=== *1 ½ cups (12-oz can) [[Cookbook:coconut milk|coconut milk]] *3 cups [[Cookbook:water|water]] *1 cup [[Cookbook:yogurt|yogurt]] *1 can (12-oz) diced [[Cookbook:tomato|tomato]]es, with liquid *4 T. [[Cookbook:Butter|Butter]]
===Thickener=== *¼ to ½ cup of instant [[Cookbook:mashed potato flakes|mashed potato flakes]]
*[[Cookbook:salt|salt]] and [[Cookbook:pepper|pepper]] to taste
==Procedure== #Heat cooking oil in a 4-qt [[Cookbook:stockpot|stockpot]]. #Add onions and garlic. [[Cookbook:Fry|Fry]] for about 1-minute. #Add chicken. [[Cookbook:Stir-frying|Stir-fry]] for about 5-minutes. #Add cooked potatoes. #Add '''Spices''', stir to coat chicken and potatoes. Cook for about 5-minutes more. #Add '''Sauce''' ingredients, stir well, bring to a simmer and cook for 10-minutes. #Add ¼ cup of '''Thickener''', stir until curry is thickened. If a thicker curry is desired, add additional '''Thickener''' (instant mashed potato flakes) a tablespoon at a time until desired thickness is achieved. #Add salt and pepper to taste.
==Notes, tips, and variations== *Serve with [[Cookbook:Steaming|steamed]] [[Cookbook:Rice|rice]].
[[Category:Chicken recipes|California Curry Chicken]] [[Category:Californian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[category:Gluten-free recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Dessert recipes|8|prep: 5 minute
chilling: 60 minute|1}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Dessert|Dessert]] '''Ambrosia Fruit Salad''' is a sweet mixture of mandarin oranges, fruit cocktail, coconut, and marshmallows coated in whipped cream. This is a favorite dessert salad at family gatherings. ==Ingredients== * 2 (11 oz) cans [[Cookbook:mandarin orange|mandarin orange]] segments, drained * 2 (15 oz) cans [[Cookbook:fruit cocktail|fruit cocktail]], drained * 2 cups flaked [[Cookbook:coconut|coconut]] * 2 cups miniature [[Cookbook:marshmallow|marshmallow]]s * 1 (8 oz) container [[Cookbook:whipped cream|whipped cream]] ==Procedure== #Mix the mandarin oranges, fruit cocktail, and coconut in a large bowl. #[[Cookbook:Fold|Fold]] in the whipped cream and marshmallows. #Chill for at least an hour. #Stir again before serving. [[Category:Dessert recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[category:Gluten-free recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Confection recipes|8|20 minutes|2}}
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Confections|Confections]]
'''Peanut Brittle''' is a sugar based hard candy, with peanuts embedded in it.
==Ingredients== * 1 cup granulated white sugar * 1/2 cup light corn syrup * 1/4 teaspoon salt (omit if using salted peanuts) * 1/4 cup water * 1 cup shelled peanuts - raw (Roasted may be used. See Notes below.) * 2 tablespoons butter, softened * 1 teaspoon baking soda (Optional. See Notes below.)
==Procedure== #Grease a 9" x 12" cookie sheet. Set aside until needed. #Over medium heat, in a heavy 2-qt saucepan, bring the sugar, corn syrup, salt, and water to a boil. #Stir until sugar is dissolved. #Stir in peanuts. (Roasted peanuts can be added at a later stage of cooking to prevent burning.) #Attach a candy thermometer to pan with tip in sugar mixture. #Keep stirring and cooking until temperature reaches 300 degrees F (150 degrees C). #Remove from heat. #Stir in butter and baking soda. #Pour mixture onto cookie sheet. #Using a fork or wooden spoon, spread the mixture evenly across the entire surface of the 9" x 12" cookie sheet. #Allow to cool to room temperature. #Break peanut brittle into bite size pieces.
==Notes, tips, and variations== *Baking soda adds an "easier bite" to the peanut brittle, causing it to break when less force is applied. It also causes the sugar base around the peanuts to be opaque. It does this by "foaming up" and introducing small bubbles in the sugar syrup. If you desire a clearer almost transparent sugar base around the peanuts and a "harder bite", reduce or omit the baking soda. *If you use roasted peanuts instead of raw, be careful not heat the mixture above 300-degrees F. or the peanuts may taste burned. Roasted peanuts can also be added at the end of cooking to prevent burning. *If you use salted peanuts, omit the salt in the recipe. *See also [[Cookbook:Microwave Peanut Brittle|Microwave Peanut Brittle]]
==Warnings== *Be very careful while working with boiling sugar mixtures, as they can cause severe burns.
[[Category:Dessert recipes|Peanut Brittle]] [[Category:Peanut recipes|Peanut Brittle]] [[Category:Confection recipes|Peanut Brittle]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Australia|Australian Cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of New Zealand|New Zealander Cuisine]]
The '''lamington''' is a type of sponge cake (or more traditionally, butter cake), cut into squares and coated in a layer of chocolate or strawberry icing and topped with coconut.
==Ingredients== * [[Cookbook:Sponge Cake|Sponge cake]] * [[Cookbook:Chocolate|Chocolate]] * [[Cookbook:Coconut|Dessicated coconut]]
==Preparation==
# Make a sponge cake # Cut up the sponge cake to desired shapes. (commonly 5 to 7 cm cubes) # Prepare a bowl of (thin) chocolate icing # Prepare a flat tray containing an even layer of dessicated coconut shavings # Dip the sponge cake cubes into chocolate icing # Then immediately dip or sprinkle the dessicated coconut over the wet chocolate icing and put aside to dry (set)
[[Category:Australian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:New Zealand recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Cake recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Dessert recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Vegan_cuisine|Vegan Cuisine]]
'''"Sauce of the Harlots"'''
==Ingredients==
*1/4 - 1/2 [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] of extra virgin [[Cookbook:Olive oil|olive oil]] *6 [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]] cloves, minced *1 can (28 [[Cookbook:Ounce|oz]]) of crushed [[Cookbook:Tomato|tomatoes]] *1/2 cup of chopped pitted Kalamata [[Cookbook:Olive|olives]] *1/2 cup of chopped pitted salt-cured black olives *2 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoons]] of [[Cookbook:Caper|capers]] (rinsed) *1 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoon]] of crushed [[Cookbook:Red pepper|red pepper]] *1 teaspoon of dried [[Cookbook:Oregano|oregano]] *1/8 teaspoon of [[Cookbook:Black pepper|pepper]] *2 tablespoons of [[Cookbook:Parsley|parsley]]
==Directions:==
# Heat oil in a large skillet. # Add garlic and saute over medium heat until garlic starts to brown lightly. # Add oregano, pepper, olives, capers, and tomatoes. # Simmer for about 15 minutes. # Add parsley and cook for another 2 minutes. # Add salt to taste. # Pour over 1 pound of pasta. # Eat. Enjoy. Savor.
[[Category:Vegan recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Italian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Sauce recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Vegan cuisine|Vegan Cuisine]]
==Ingredients==
*2 cups dried [[Cookbook:black beans|black beans]] *8 cups [[Cookbook:water|water]] *4 cloves [[Cookbook:garlic|garlic]], minced *1/4 cup diced [[Cookbook:white onion|white onion]] *1/4 cup chopped [[Cookbook:green onion|green onion]] *2 whole [[Cookbook:cloves|cloves]] *1/2 teaspoon ground [[Cookbook:cumin|cumin]] *1 tablespoon [[Cookbook:caribe|caribe]] or another ground [[Cookbook:chili pepper|hot pepper]] *juice of 1 [[Cookbook:lime|lime]] *[[Cookbook:salt|salt]] and [[Cookbook:pepper|pepper]] to taste
==Directions== # If using dried beans, place beans in a large pan and cover with water. Bring to a [[Cookbook:boil|boil]] and remove from heat. Cover and let stand for 1 hour. [[Cookbook:Simmer|Simmer]] for 2 hours and drain. # Place beans in a large pan and add 8 cups water, garlic, salt, white onions, cumin, ground chile and lime juice. Tie cloves in [[Cookbook:cheese cloth|cheese cloth]] for easy removal if desired. Bring to a boil; reduce heat, cover and simmer for 2 hours or until beans are tender and soup is thick. # Mix in green onions and serve with lime wedge.
Serves: 4-6 servings
[[Category:Vegan recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Soup recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Bean recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Brazilian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Japan|Cuisine of Japan]]
'''Kinpira''' is a [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Japan|Japanese]] cooking term that roughly translates to ''[[Cookbook:Sautéing|sauté]] and [[Cookbook:Simmering|simmer]]''. The aim is to cook root vegetables such as carrots and [[Cookbook:Burdock|burdock root]] in a minimum amount of water so that they end up tenderly cooked and with none of their flavour or nutritional value lost into discarded cooking water.
==Ingredients== *250g (½lb) [[Cookbook:Carrot|carrot]]s, [[Cookbook:Julienne|julienne]] *1 Tbs [[Cookbook:Vegetable oil|vegetable oil]], preferably [[Cookbook:Sesame Oil|sesame oil]] *[[Cookbook:Water|water]] *[[Cookbook:Tamari|Tamari]] or [[Cookbook:shoyu|shoyu]] ([[Cookbook:Soy Sauce|soy sauce]]), to taste
==Procedure== # cut the carrots into thin matchstick pieces (sen-giri, or julienne) # pour a small amount of oil into a [[Cookbook:saucepan|saucepan]] and sauté the carrot pieces for two to three minutes # add only enough water to half-cover the carrot pieces # place the lid on the pot and let the carrots simmer on medium-low heat # towards the end of the cooking process when most of the cooking liquid has been absorbed, add a little tamari or shoyu to enhance flavour
[[Category:Japanese recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Carrot recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegan recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{cookwork}} {{recipe}} {{recipesummary|Beef recipes|2|20 minutes|2}}
'''Chicken Fried Steak''' is a hearty food dish in the southern USA. The dish is commonly served with mashed potatoes smothered in chicken fried steak gravy.
Chicken Fried Steak is, simply, a cut of steak (usually cheap round steak)pounded until tender and then breaded like you would bread chicken, and fried in oil. Milk, salt, and pepper are added to the grease drippings and used to make a thick gravy, which is generously poured over the steak and, usually, mashed potatoes. Many people think the gravy makes the steak!
==Ingredients== *1 cup of [[Cookbook:white flour|white flour]] *1 tsp of [[Cookbook:pepper|pepper]] *1/2 tsp of [[Cookbook:salt|salt]] *2 [[Cookbook:egg|egg]]s *[[Cookbook:milk|milk]] *[[Cookbook:steak|steak]] *[[Cookbook:potato|potato]]es
==Procedure==
#Pour cooking oil in pan (NOT olive oil!). #Preheat pan at middle setting. #*Wet hand, drip 1 drop of water in pan to test the heat. If it sizzles, it's hot enough. Not too much water though or it may sizzle so much you get hot grease on you! #Mix 1 cup of white flour with 1 tsp of pepper and 1/2 tsp of salt. #Beat eggs with milk in bowl. #Dip tenderized round steak into egg/milk mixture and make sure both sides are drenched with egg mixture. #Dip steak into flour mix thoroughly on both sides. #When the pan is hot enough, put steak in pan. #Fry until golden brown on bottom, and flip. #Fry until golden brown on the other side. #Remove steak(s) from pan. #Pour milk into pan slowly, while stirring the grease and drippings. #*Don't let the gravy get too thick. #Add salt and pepper into pan, to taste. #Pour generously over steak and mashed potatoes.
==Notes, tips, and variations==
==Warnings== * When heating the pan in step 2. Wet hand, drip 1 drop of water in pan to test the heat. If it sizzles, it's hot enough. Not too much water though or it may sizzle so much you get hot grease on you! *Don't let the gravy get too thick.
[[Category:American recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Beef recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Beverages|Beverages]] [[Image:Met_Flasche_und_Glas.jpg|right|200px]]
'''Mead''' is a fermented alcoholic beverage made of honey, water, and yeast. It is sometimes known as "honey wine" (for obvious reasons) and is generally pronounced "meed" (IPA: /miːd/), though South Africans usually pronounce it "med", to rhyme with "red" (IPA: /mɛd/).
Mead can have a wide range of flavors, depending on the source of the honey, additives including fruit and spices, the yeast employed during fermentation, and aging procedure. Mead can be difficult to find commercially, though some producers have been successful marketing it.
Many meads retain some measure of the sweetness of the original honey, and some can even be considered as dessert wines. Drier meads are also available, and some producers offer sparkling meads, which (like champagne) can make for a delightful celebratory toast.
A mead that also contains spices (like cloves, cinnamon or nutmeg) or herbs (such as oregano or even lavender or chamomile) is called ''metheglin''. A mead that contains fruit (such as strawberry, blackcurrant or even rose-hips) is called ''melomel'' and was also used as a delicious way to store summer produce for the winter. Mulled mead is a popular winter holiday drink, where mead is flavoured with spices and warmed, traditionally by having a hot poker plunged into it. ''Hippocras'' is spiced grape wine sweetened with honey. A grape-based wine with added honey is called a ''pyment''. ''Cyser'' is made with apple juice and honey; ''braggot'' or ''bracket'' is made with malted barley and honey.
Production of mead for private consumption should be considered to be submitted to the same regulations as the production of [[Cookbook:Wine|grape wine]]. See also the numerous warnings on the [[Cookbook:Alcoholic_Drink#Warnings|alcoholic drink]] page.
==Equipment== [[Image:Homebrew Fermenter.jpg|right|thumb|Fermenter with airlock fitted]] Mead is made in a fermentation vessel, preferably a glass [[w:Carboy|carboy]], with an [[w:Airlock|airlock]] and a rubber bung. These items can usually be found at a brewer's supply store. The ingredients of mead are honey, filtered water, and yeast. Fruit or spices are optional.
Mead should be made in sanitized equipment to ensure food safety. Potassium metabisulphite is a common sanitizing agent. Those who are allergic to sulphites can use other sanitizing methods. Failure to remove all traces of this chemical from the equipment may result in poisonous or otherwise undrinkable mead.
==Ingredients==
*3 [[Cookbook:Pound|pounds]] of [[Cookbook:Honey|honey]] per [[Cookbook:Gallon|gallon]] (U.S.). (For example, 15 pounds of honey are used with a 5 gallon (U.S.) carboy.) *1 pound of [[Cookbook:Raisin|raisins]]. (optional) *1 packet of dry winemaker's [[Cookbook:Yeast|yeast]] (Lalvin EC1118, K1V1116 or similar) as well as yeast nutrient.
==Procedure==
Some mead makers prefer to create a starter culture by preparing a mixture of one cup of room temperature sanitized fruit juice and the freeze dried winemaking yeast and placing it into a smaller one [[Cookbook:Quart|quart]] sanitized container fitted with a rubber stopper and airlock for a day or two until the mixture is bubbling. This container is kept at room temperature out of direct sunlight. This starter culture will cause the fermentation below to begin with vigor and may prevent the mead from failing to ferment.
Honey is slowly added to a large pot half-full with water while heating. There is a common disagreement among mead makers as to whether you should boil the honey or not; mead makers have had success with either method. Boiling will alter the flavor, but will enhance the clarity of the finished mead. As the mead is heated over medium heat, it will nearly boil after the honey has been completely dissolved.
After a time of heating the honey (which helps it dissolve and can also pasteurize it), the mixture is cooled to between (170°F/76°C) and (140°F/60°C) and the raisins are added. The mixture continues to cool, then is transferred to the [[Wikipedia:carboy|carboy]]. Once it has cooled to room temperature (68°F/20°C), yeast which has been rehydrated is added to the honey/water mixture (must) and the airlock is put on. After being placed in a cool (68°F/20°C), dark place for a few hours or a day, the airlock should start to allow bubbles to escape. This is waste carbon dioxide (CO<sub>2</sub>) and shows that the yeast is processing the sugar into alcohol. The raisins rise to the surface of the fermenting mixture. If they block the airlock, the mead maker will have to rack. Stirring or agitating the mixture is avoided, as it may cause the liquid to rise up and spill out of the airlock.
After a four to six week period the mead maker may want to [[Cookbook:Racking|rack]] the mead into a second sanitized carboy. An airlock is not necessary during primary (aerobic) fermentation. This racking will clear out the lees and allow the mead to clear faster. The mead is siphoned into the second carboy via a sanitized tube, usually filled it with sterile water to start the siphon. The mead is siphoned carefully to avoid splashing as excess oxygen at this point may cause an unpleasant taste in the final product. An airlock is placed on the second carboy. It is imperative that sterile conditions be maintained while the carboys are open to avoid infection. The mead is racked in another 3 months or when all signs of fermentation have stopped (usually when the airlock doesn't produce any bubbles for a long period of time—typically over 30 seconds between bubbles) and your mead has cleared. Excessive racking will promote oxidation, resulting in an undrinkable mead. The carboy is clear enough when it is possible to read a newspaper through it. The mead will then need to age, usually one year, and anywhere up five or more. Bulk aging can be done done in a tertiary carboy, but bottle aging is also common.
Then next step is to bottle the mead. Mead is generally sealed in sanitized bottles using airtight caps or quality corks. If the fermentation is not complete, pressure will build up inside the sealed bottles and cause them to explode. Mead is generally aged for at least 6 months in the bottle before drinking.
{{Wikipedia|Mead}} ---- :''This module uses text from the [[w:Main Page|Wikipedia]] module ''[[w:Mead|Mead]]'' under the terms of the [[w:GNU Free Documentation License|GNU Free Documentation License]]. Please see that module for the authors of the text prior to its adaptations in Wikibooks.''
[[Category:Beverage recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Honey recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Brazil|Brazilian Cuisine]]
==Ingredients==
* One dozen big [[Cookbook:Tangerine|tangerines]] * 2 kilos of [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] * 2 litres of [[Cookbook:Water|water]] * 6 [[Cookbook:Lime|limes]]
==Preparation==
# Cut the tangerines into small pieces, leaving the peel, but removing the seeds. # Add the water. # Let sit until the next day. # Boil the mixture until the fruit is very soft. # Add the sugar, and leave cooking until the jelly is firm when dripped on a cold plate.
{{wikipedia|Tangerine}}
[[Category:South American recipes|Tangerine jelly]] [[Category:Brazilian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Jam and Jelly recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Tangerine recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Lime recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}}
'''Bigos''' is considered the Polish national dish by many. For more information see [[w:Bigos|wikipedia's article on Bigos]].
== Ingredients == : 2.5 kg fresh [[Cookbook:cabbage|cabbage]] : 2 kg fermented cabbage ([[Cookbook:sauerkraut|sauerkraut]]) : 500 g [[Cookbook:pork|pork]] or [[Cookbook:venison|venison]] : 250 g [[Cookbook:sausage|sausage]] : 250 g [[Cookbook:bacon|bacon]] : fresh or dried [[Cookbook:mushroom|mushroom]]s : whole [[Cookbook:Pepper|black pepper]], [[Cookbook:salt|salt]], [[Cookbook:Bay Leaf|bay leaf]]
== Procedure == #Chop the cabbage, add pepper and salt, a part of the mushrooms and bay leaf, and cook until soft (about 2-3 hours). #Chop the bacon and let it melt in a frying pan. #Fry the chopped meat and sausage in the bacon grease. #If necessary, drain excess water from the stewed cabbage and add the fried meat, bacon, and sausage along with the grease out of the pan. Stew everything as long as possible - the longer, the better (sometimes it is done for 3 hours a day in 3 following days, or even longer). #When ready, the dish should be a thick mash that does not "leak" water on the plate; it should be mildly sour and have a strong flavour of smoked bacon.
==Notes, tips, and variations== There are countless variations of this basic recipe. According to some, the amount of meat should be equal to the amount of cabbage; others prefer to use only fermented cabbage as in German sauerkraut.
A very particular feature of this dish is that it can be safely stored even for a few days without refrigerating. This is why bigos used to be a common soldiers' dish.
[[Category:Cabbage recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Pork recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Bacon recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Venison recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Sauerkraut recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Recipes_with_metric_units|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Veal recipes|4 persons|2 hours + 45 min prep|3}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Italy|Cuisine of Italy]] | [[Cookbook:Meat|Meat]]
'''Ossobuco''' (Italian for 'holed bone'), in English often spelled 'osso buco' or 'osso bucco', is a Milanese specialty of veal shanks cooked in meat broth and flavored with white wine. Slowly braised, this relatively tough, yet flavorful cut of meat becomes meltingly tender, and the connective tissues and marrow dissolve into the sauce, making it rich and creamy.
The shank is a relatively cheap cut of veal which is readily available in most good supermarkets and butcher shops. Look for meaty hind-shanks cut from the top of the thigh with a high proportion of meat-to-bone; each piece should be about 5" across and 1" to 1½" thick.
Traditionally, ossobuco is made without tomatoes (these being unknown in Milan until the late 19th century). However, the traditional version, prepared with cinnamon, allspice, bay leaf and gremolata called ''in bianco'', has by and large been replaced with the newer version which includes tomatoes and the 'holy trinity' of Italian cooking: carrot, celery and onion, flavoured with a bouquet garni and without gremolata (although 'hybrid' versions exist which include both tomato and gremolata). It should be noted that while the traditional combination with risotto alla milanese is perfect for the former version (for which is was intended), the modern-day version with tomato, which is both moister and bolder in flavour and does not combine well with saffron, is better served with polenta. The following recipe is for a 'modern' version.
== Ingredients == * 4 slices [[Cookbook:Veal|veal]] hind shank, about 1" to 1½" (2.5cm to 4cm) thick * 1 medium [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]], chopped fine * 3 ribs [[Cookbook:Celery|celery]] with leaves, chopped fine * 1 medium [[Cookbook:Carrot|carrot]], chopped fine * 2 cloves [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]], [[Cookbook:Mincing|minced]] * 3 tbs. [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]] * 4 tbs. [[Cookbook:Vegetable oil|vegetable oil]] * 1 cup (240ml) dry white [[Cookbook:Wine|wine]] or white [[Cookbook:Vermouth|vermouth]] * 2 cups (about 480ml) meat [[Cookbook:Stock|broth]] * 3 tbs. [[Cookbook:Tomato Paste|tomato paste]] * 6 [[Cookbook:Anchovy|anchovy]] fillets, mashed * ½ tsp. dried [[Cookbook:Thyme|thyme]] * 2-3 [[Cookbook:Bay Leaf|bay leaves]] * 2 strips [[Cookbook:Lemon|lemon]] peel * kosher [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * fresh ground [[Cookbook:Pepper|pepper]] * [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]]
== Procedure == # Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C). # If the butcher has not done so, tie the shanks around the middle with kitchen twine; this will keep them from falling apart during cooking. # Choose a heavy, covered roasting pan or Dutch oven which will just accommodate the veal shanks in one layer. Put the butter, 2 tablespoons of the oil, the onions, celery and carrots in the pan and sauté over medium heat until the vegetables have wilted, about 8 minutes. Add the garlic and lemon peel and sauté until they're fragrant, about 2 minutes more. Remove from the heat. # Meanwhile, heat the remaining oil in a skillet until it is near the smoking point. Lightly flour the veal shanks and slip them into the oil. Richly brown the shanks on both of the cut sides, then place them in the roasting pan on top of the vegetables. # Place the wine in the skillet and boil until reduced by one-half, scraping up any brown residue. Pour this over the veal shanks. # Heat the beef broth to a boil in the skillet, whisking in the tomato paste and anchovies. Add this to the veal shanks, along with the herbs, several grindings of pepper, and a large pinch of salt. The liquid should cover ¾ of the shanks. If not, add extra water. # Bring the pot to a simmer, cover, and place in the oven. Cook for approximately 2 hours, turning and basting the shanks every ½ hour. If you notice that the cooking liquids have nearly evaporated, add hot water, about ½ cup at a time. The veal is done when it is fork tender and falling from the bone. # Transfer the shanks to a platter, remove the strings, and cover to keep warm. If the sauce seems watery, as is probable, place the pan on the stove top over high heat and reduce the cooking liquid until the sauce has a thick, creamy consistency. Pour the sauce over the shanks and serve.
== Notes == * The recipe calls for anchovies, which enrich the finished sauce without adding a "fishy" flavor: don't omit them, even should you not be fond of anchovies. * Traditionally, the cooking sauce is finished with a mixture of garlic, lemon zest and parsley called ''Gremolata.'' It adds a burst of freshness to the finished dish and is highly recommended. Gremolata consists of the grated zest of one lemon, one finely minced clove of garlic, and one tablespoon of finely chopped parsley. Add this mixture to the sauce at the end of the cooking, as it's being reduced. * Osso buco is almost ''always'' served with [[Cookbook:Risotto|risotto]]–indeed; it's one of the few examples in Italian cooking where a starch is served with the main course and is a marriage that no man should put asunder. One may, for a change, substitute orzo or acini de pepe cooked in meat broth and finished with butter and [[Cookbook:Parmesan Cheese|Parmesan cheese]].
[[Category:Veal recipes]] [[Category:Italian recipes]] [[Category:Recipes_with_metric_units]]

{{recipesummary|Cake recipes|36-48|45 minutes|3}}
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Confections|Confections]] | [[Cookbook:Fudge|Fudge]]
'''Chocolate fudge''' is a traditional, rich candy, especially around the holidays in the [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|United States]].
==Ingredients==
* 2 1/2 c [[Cookbook:Sugar|Sugar]] * 1/2 c [[Cookbook:Margarine|Margarine]] or [[Cookbook:butter|butter]] * 2/3 c [[Cookbook:Evaporated milk|Evaporated milk]] * 1 Jar (7 oz.) [[Cookbook:marshmallow creme|marshmallow creme]] * 2 c Semi sweet [[Cookbook:chocolate chips|chocolate chips]] * 3/4 c Chopped [[Cookbook:walnuts|walnuts]] * 1 ts [[Cookbook:Vanilla|Vanilla]]
==Procedure==
# Line 9 inch square or 13x9 inch pan with foil so that foil extends over sides of pan; butter foil. #In large saucepan, combine sugar, margarine and evaporated milk. Bring to a boil over medium heat, stirring constantly. # After 5 minutes of constant stirring remove saucepan from heat. # Add marshmallow creme and chocolate chips; blend until smooth. Stir in walnuts and vanilla. # Pour into buttered, foil-lined pan. Cool to room temperature. # Score fudge into 36-48 squares. Refrigerate until firm.
==Notes, tips, and variations==
* Remove fudge from pan by lifting foil; remove foil from sides of fudge. Using large knife, cut through scored lines. Store in refrigerator.
[[Category:Confection recipes]] [[Category:Chocolate recipes]] [[Category:American recipes]] [[category:Gluten-free recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]
