{{recipe}}
'''Tri-colored Autumn Rice Balls''' (San-Shoku Ohagi)
Ohagi is a simple a tea sweet, which was at one time served during the autumn equinox celebration. The name comes from a type of bush clover that only blooms in the fall. Serve these rice balls with your finest cup of tea.
==Ingredients== * 3 cups prepared [[Cookbook:Steamed Sweet Rice|Steamed Sweet Rice]] *1/4 cup toasted black sesame seeds, lightly crushed *1 tablespoon sugar *1 cup smooth Japanese bean paste (koshi-an), chilled *1/2 cup roasted soybean powder (kinako) or toasted ground pecans.
==Procedure== Mix sesame seeds and sugar in a small bowl. Moisten your hands with water and divide warm rice into 12 equal portions. Shape 4 portions into balls. Moisten a clean dish towel and squeeze dry. Place 2 1/2 tablespoons bean paste on towel; pat into 4 inch circle. Place 1 rice ball in centre of bean paste circle and use towel to mould bean paste around the rice ball. Repeat this 3 more times, using another 1/2 cup of bean paste and the other 3 rice balls. Place these on a nice serving tray. Flatten the remaining eight rice portions. Form the remaining bean paste into 8 balls (about 2 teaspoons per ball). Place a bean paste ball in the centre of each piece of flattened rice and shape the rice around it. Mould these stuffed rice balls into oval shapes. Roll 4 ovals in the sesame-sugar mixture. Roll the other 4 balls in the roasted soybean powder. Add these to the serving tray. Makes six servings of 2 rice balls each.
[[Category:Rice recipes|Tri-colored Autumn Rice Balls]] [[Category:Japanese recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Indonesia|Cuisine of Indonesia]]
'''Ayam Goreng Mentega''' (''Fried Chicken in Sweet Butter Sauce'')
Serves 5-6 people with rice:
== Ingredients == * 1 medium-sized [[Cookbook:chicken|chicken]], cut into small pieces (12 - 16 pieces) * 2 cup frying [[Cookbook:oil|oil]] * Juice of 2 [[Cookbook:lemon|lemon]]s * 2 tsp [[Cookbook:salt|salt]]
=== Sauce === * 4 tbsp of [[Cookbook:butter|butter]] * 2 tbsp [[Cookbook:Worcestershire Sauce|Worcestershire sauce]] * 2 tbsp regular [[Cookbook:Soy Sauce|soy sauce]] (tamari) * 2 tbsp Chinese cooking [[Cookbook:wine|wine]] * 8 tbsp [[Cookbook:Soy Sauce|Indonesian sweet soy sauce]] (kecap manis) * 4 cloves [[Cookbook:garlic|garlic]], thinly sliced * 1 small [[Cookbook:onion|onion]], thinly sliced
=== Garnish === * Slices of 2 [[Cookbook:lime|lime]]s
== Procedure == # [[Cookbook:Marinating|Marinate]] chicken in salt and lemon juice for 15-20 minutes. # Heat up oil, and [[Cookbook:Frying|fry]] chicken until it is golden, then set aside to drain. # [[Cookbook:Sautéing|Sauté]] the garlic and onion for a minute or two, then add the remaining sauce ingredients. # [[Cookbook:Stir-frying|Stir fry]] for a minute and then add chicken pieces.
Serve hot.
[[Category:Chicken recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Indonesian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}}
'''Anjing Panggang''' is a specialty from Eastern Indonesia and Southern Philippines.
== Ingredients ==
=== Meat === * Small or Medium-sized [[Cookbook:dog|dog]]
=== Marinade === * 1 cup [[Cookbook:vinegar|vinegar]] * 3 tbsp [[Cookbook:salt|salt]] * 6 cloves [[Cookbook:garlic|garlic]], crushed * 20 spicy [[Cookbook:Chili Pepper|Thai pepper]]s * 3 [[Cookbook:tomato|tomato]]es, puréed * 3 cups [[Cookbook:lemon|lemon]] juice
== Procedure == # First, kill the dog, then burn off the fur over a hot fire. # Carefully remove the skin while still warm and set aside for later (may be used in other recipes) # Remove the entrails and cut dog up into sections, about 12 to 16 large pieces. # In a food processor, mix all the marinade ingredients together. Put dog pieces into this marinade in a large container, then let it sit for at least 2 hours. # Put dog pieces on a charcoal grill, cover and let it burn over warm coals. Flip and baste occasionally for about 1 hour or until meat is tender
Serves 12
[[Category:Dog recipes]] [[Category:Indonesian recipes]] [[Category:Filipino recipes]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Vegan_cuisine|Vegan Cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Breakfast_Recipes|Breakfast]]
A vegan cheese that mainly consists of potato, oil and soy.
==Ingredients==
[[Image:Bfast2005_vegan_cheese_2.jpg|frame|right|Vegan cheese]]
*[[Cookbook:mashed potatoes|mashed potatoes]] (5 large, hard boiling [[Cookbook:Potato|potatoe]]s, 750g - 1kg) (or potato starch?) *[[Cookbook:corn flour|corn flour]] (or [[Cookbook:breading|breading]] mixture, [[:de:w:Paniermehl|Paniermehl]]) *[[Cookbook:soy sauce|soy sauce]] (20ml) or [[Cookbook:yeast extract|yeast extract]] *optional: **[[Cookbook:salt|salt]] or [[Cookbook:celery salt|celery salt]] **[[Cookbook:bear's garlic|bear's garlic]], [[Cookbook:garlic|garlic]], any other [[Cookbook:herbs|herbs]], e.g. [[Cookbook:paprika|paprika]], [[Cookbook:thyme|thyme]], [[Cookbook:rosemary|rosemary]], [[Cookbook:cumin|cumin]], [[Cookbook:oregano|oregano]] and [[Cookbook:savory|savory]] **[[Cookbook:onion|onion]]s **seasoning mix (corn flour, salt, [[Cookbook:Chili Pepper|chili]], onion, garlic, paprika, [[Cookbook:MSG|sodium glutamate]]), or Mexican [[Cookbook:Taco Seasoning Mix|Taco Seasoning Mix]] **seasoning mix "Chili" (1-3g), e.g.: Chilies, [[Cookbook:orange zest|orange peelings]], [[Cookbook:sesame|sesame]], paprika, traces: [[Cookbook:celery|celery]] and [[Cookbook:mustard|mustard]]. **[[Cookbook:vegetable stock|vegetable stock]] (1-5g) (salt, yeast extract, corn flour, [[Cookbook:sun flower oil|sun flower oil]], onions, [[Cookbook:carrot|carrot]]s, spices, [[Cookbook:parsley|parsley]]) (commercially available) **[[Cookbook:unrefined sugar|unrefined sugar]] (or [[Cookbook:sugar|sugar]] not refined using the char method) **[[Cookbook:pepper|pepper]] **[[Cookbook:rice|rice]] **[[Cookbook:popcorn|popcorn]] **[[Cookbook:rapeseed oil|rapeseed oil]] or other [[Cookbook:vegetable oil|vegetable oil]] (20ml) **[[Cookbook:vinegar|vinegar]] (10ml) **[[Cookbook:agar|agar]] (that wasn't very successful, it didn't change consistency much)
==Procedure== #[[Cookbook:Boil|Boil]] potatoes until they are not quite done. If the potatoes are not completely done the resulting substance may be sliceable, although it will be easy to spread anyway. #Take the mashed potatoes and add soy sauce and yeast extract generously and mix it with some margarine and/or some rapeseed oil. Some corn flour, breading mixture or wheat flour help to make the substance drier and, in case of corn flour, add significantly to the taste. (soy flour is unsuitable here due to its taste). A small amount of lecithin powder can be added as an [[Cookbook:emulgator|emulgator]] but is not really necessary. It it's healthy and, being hydrophilic and lipophilic, it binds together the water and the oil. #Mix the ingredients. The substance should take on the consistency of [[Cookbook:peanut butter|peanut butter]] but have more the color of cheese than anything else. #The taste isn't yet close to cheese but getting closer. Corn flour, either in a seasoning mix or just plain corn flour gets us closer to cheese now. If you add enough seasoning mix the color will be much closer to peanut butter now but you may opt to leave away the seasoning mix altogether and just add corn flour, separately or with the vegetable stock. Adding cumin is also highly recommended. Another alternative is the Chili season mix, which can also be combined with other spices, for example vegetable stock, sugar and cumin. Vinegar may increase durability in the refrigerator but more than 4 days are not recommended. #You can add bear's garlic, garlic, onions and/or any herbs you like (e.g. fresh Thyme) to the cheese. A pinch of sugar can add to the taste but may not be compatible with all other spices. #Fill the substance into a small, round form, to give it the form of a cheddar cheese.
[[Image:Bfast2005_vegan_cheese.jpg|frame|right|Vegan cheese with rice]]
==Variant with rice==
In the variant with rice about half (up to two thirds) of the base substance is replaced by mashed rice. The advantage of mashed rice is that it results in a more cheese like substance, which dries better.
==Variant with vegetable stock==
The variant with vegetable stock can be made with less soy sauce. Mexican Taco Seasoning Mix can be used but is not required, because the vegetable stock is already very spicy. The variant can be combined with rice.
==Variant with vegan cheese sauce==
A dairy free cheese flavor sauce mix can be suitable to acquire a stronger cheese flavor.
==Freezing==
Freezing is not recommended. There was a single case where freezing seemed to even have improved the consistency (making it a bit like tofu) but this lacks reproducibility.
== Best served ==
=== With tomato, basil and garlic ===
Best served slightly heated (e.g. on a [[Cookbook:solar oven|solar oven]]) on [[Cookbook:Ciabatta|ciabatta]] with a splash of warm [[Cookbook:olive oil|olive]] or rapeseed oil, mixed with a mashed clove of garlic and with a slice of [[Cookbook:tomato|tomato]] and a leaf of [[Cookbook:Basil|basil]].
=== With onions and grapes ===
Put the cheese on a slice of bread and sprinkle hackled onions on top. Bake in a [[Cookbook:toaster oven|toaster oven]] or [[Cookbook:grill|grill]] until the onions turn only slightly glassy. [[Cookbook:Grapes|Grapes]] cut in halves make a good topping and complement the taste.
[[Category:Vegan recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Potato recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]
[[de:Veganes Leben: Ernährung: Rezepte: Veganer Cheddar]]

{{recipesummary|Vegan recipes|1 bowl|15 minutes|1}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Vegan_cuisine|Vegan Cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Breakfast_Recipes|Breakfast]]
A spread consisting of two base ingredients, tofu and oat flakes.
==Ingredients== *[[Cookbook:Oats|oat]] flakes (or raw [[Cookbook:spelt|spelt]] flour) (250g) *[[Cookbook:tofu|tofu]] (250g) *1 (or more) [[Cookbook:carrot|carrot]](s) *1 (or more) [[Cookbook:Paprika|paprika]](s) (may substitute with [[Cookbook:Bell Pepper|red bell peppers]], [[Cookbook:Pepperoncini|sweet peppers]]) *1 (or more) [[Cookbook:onion|onion]](s) *[[Cookbook:margarine|margarine]] *[[Cookbook:Canola Oil|rapeseed oil]] or other [[Cookbook:vegetable oil|vegetable oil]] *[[Cookbook:Soy Sauce|soy sauce]] *[[Cookbook:mustard|mustard]] *[[Cookbook:Ketchup|catsup]] *[[Cookbook:garlic|garlic]] *[[Cookbook:pepper|pepper]] *[[Cookbook:Soy Lecithin|soy lecithin powder]]
==Procedure== # Take equal amounts of oat flakes and tofu and mix the two ingredients and some water for the base substance. The recommended amount is about 250g of both. You might want to add lecithin powder as an emulsifier. # Mash (at least) one carrot, one paprika and one onion. If you prefer larger pieces you can also cut some of it instead. # Add a spoon of margarine and/or a spoon of rapeseed oil, or any other vegetable oil. # Add mustard, catsup, garlic and pepper to taste.
[[Category:Vegan recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Tofu recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Oat recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Carrot recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Vegan recipes|1 bowl|15 minutes|1}}
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Vegan_cuisine|Vegan Cuisine]]
A spread that consist of the three base ingredients tofu, oat flakes and raw spelt flour.
==Ingredients== *tofu (250g) *oat flakes (150g) *raw spelt flour (150g) *3 (or more) whole spring oinions. *1 (or more) pickled gherkin(s) *magarine *rapeseed oil or other vegetable oil *soy sauce *salt *garlic *pepper *soy lecithin powder
==Procedure== # Take oat flakes, raw spelt, tofu and some water for the base substance. # The recommended amount is about 250g of tofu and 150g of oat flakes and spelt flour each. # You might want to add lecithin powder an an emulsifier. # Cut the spring onions and the gherkin into small pieces # Add a spoon of magarine and/or a spoon of rapeseed oil, or any other vegetable oil. # Add salt and pepper to taste.
[[Category:Vegan recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Spelt recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Tofu recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of India|Indian Cuisine]] {{recipesummary |Category=Fermented food recipes |Time=soak: 8-12 hours
prep: 10 minutes
ferment: 12-24 hours
cook: 20 minutes |Rating=3 |Image=[[Image:Idli1.jpg|300px]] }} '''Idli''' is a round, fluffy bread roughly eight centimetres in diameter. Idli is made from ground rice or rice flour mixed with ground urad dal, salt, methi (fenugreek seeds) and water. The mixture is allowed to [[Cookbook:Fermentation|ferment]] prior to being steamed in an idli steamer. They are traditional to Southern India and are most often eaten with [[Cookbook:Sambar|sambar]]. ==Ingredients== * 1½ cups [[Cookbook:Rice|rice]] * 1 cup [[Cookbook:Urad Bean|white urad dal]] (black gram, skinless) * 2 teaspoons [[Cookbook:Salt|non-iodised salt]] * 1 teaspoon [[Cookbook:Fenugreek|fenugreek seeds]] (methi) * 4 cups [[Cookbook:Water|water]] for soaking rice and urad dal * 2 cups [[Cookbook:Water|chlorine-free water]] for fermenting (see note) * optional: fermentation starter (see note) ==Procedure== ===Making the Batter=== # Soak the rice and urad dal in separate bowls for eight hours. You will need about twice as much water in the bowl as urad dal, as it expands as it soaks up water. # Drain the rice and urad dal, discard water (good for watering plants). # Grind the urad dal to a fine paste with about 1 cup of chlorine-free water. # Grind the rice to a paste with about 1 cup of chlorine-free water, less if you can. Grind coarsely if the batter will only be used for idli, but grind finely if it will later be used for [[Cookbook:Dosa|dosa]]. # Mix the rice and urad dal pastes together well, with salt and methi. # Optional: add fermentation starter and mix well (see note). # Set aside somewhere warm to ferment for 12-24 hours (see note). [[Image:Idli pan.png|right|thumb|An idli pan]] ===Making the Idli=== # Grease one or more [[Cookbook:Idli Pan|idli pans]] well with [[Cookbook:Ghee|ghee]] or [[Cookbook:Vegetable oil|vegetable oil]]. # Spoon the batter into the round indentations of the idli pans. # Steam for 10 minutes in a steamer, 20 minutes if using brown rice. # Remove idli from pans with a sharp knife or thin [[Cookbook:Spatula|spatula]]. ==Notes, tips, and variations== Idli is a very temperamental creature: it is not easy to get soft fluffy idlis. These tips may help. # A traditional stone grinder is recommended for making idlis. The modern high speed mixer with metal blades won't work as well, but a blender will do a reasonable job. # Idli is made of black lentil and rice. The southern parts of India use boiled rice, while the rest uses raw rice. It depends on your taste. The black lentil should be the full, round variety. Avoid broken dal. # The ratio of black lentil to rice should not exceed 1:2 by volume. If you have good quality dal, you can stretch this ratio by increasing the quantity of rice. # Soak dal and rice separately for at least three hours, preferably eight. You can add half a teaspoon of fenugreek (methi) seeds to the dal for a good twist. # The rice is typically long grain white rice, but brown rice works well also and adds flavour, colour, and more nutrition. Brown rice needs to be soaked at least eight hours. # Use plenty of water for grinding the dal and make it a very smooth paste. But grind the rice coarse and granular. # Add salt. Don't be afraid of salt - idli needs a lot of it. # Mix the dal and rice batters thoroughly. It takes more time and energy than you might think. Uneven mixing causes many failures. Mixing them by hand works best! # A warm temperature is essential for fermentation. 25 to 28 °C (77 - 82.4 °F) will be ideal. If the weather is cold, keep some warm water in a large bowl and immerse the vessel containing the dough. To help maintain the temperature of the warm water bath, cover it with a blanket, or better, use a regulated heater, like a heating pad or aquarium heater. Even easier, turn on the light in the oven, and use that to keep the batter warm. # Allow at least 8 hours to ferment. If you don't see tiny bubbles the next morning, the dough will not rise and you have to start all over again. # If you can't get it to ferment by itself, try a good fermentation starter like a teaspoonful of [[Cookbook:Kefir|kefir]]. Just bread yeast will not make for good flavour, as bacteria are needed also. # Use chlorine-free water when grinding, as this will be the water that the batter will have in it when fermenting. Tap water will work, but will inhibit the ferment a little. Most modern water filters remove both [[w:Chlorine|chlorine]] and [[w:Chloramine|chloramine]]. # In the morning, gently scoop the top layer of the batter and steam it. DO NOT stir or otherwise break the batter. The trapped bubbles should not escape; they are necessary for sponginess. # Steam the idlis in the idli pan. An open stove is preferable over microwave. The vessel should steam like an old locomotive. # Steam it for 10 minutes. You know it is done from the characteristic smell. If you are not sure, poke it gently with a spoon and make sure the batter does not stick to the spoon. # Allow it to cool for a minute. Sprinkle the idlis liberally with [[Cookbook:Sesame Oil|sesame oil]] and eat them with suitable side dishes, such as [[Cookbook:Coconut Chutney|chutni]], [[Cookbook:Sambar|sambaar]] and idli powder. # Leftover batter that has lost its froth can still be used to make [[Cookbook:dosa|dosa]]. ===Ready-made idli batter=== Some Indian groceries in the USA (and elsewhere, presumably) may stock fresh ready-to-cook idli batter. Balaji Idli Mix by Sri Sai Foods of Somerville, NJ is a fresh batter marked with a freshness date that is found in the refrigerated section. Simply spoon the batter into idli pans well brushed with ghee, and steam. This produces a very good idli, light and fluffy with a characteristic tangy flavor. Idli pans are inexpensive and available in the same Indian grocery stores. ==External links== {{wikipedia|Idli}} *[http://forums.egullet.com/index.php?showtopic=31133 A Sampling of South Indian Breads], pictorial instructions (see bottom of page) *[http://www.indiacurry.com/recipessouth.htm South Indian (Idli/Dosa) Homepage] [[Category:Indian recipes]] [[Category:Vegan recipes]] [[Category:Gluten-free recipes]] [[Category:Rice recipes]] [[Category:Bean recipes]] [[Category:Fermented food recipes]] [[Category:Bread recipes]] [[Category:Breakfast recipes]]

{{recipesummary|Meat recipes|6|1 hour|2}}
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Meat Recipes|Meat Recipes]]
'''Pennsylvania Pot Pie''' is a Pennsylvania Dutch soup, with meat, vegetables, and squares of pie crust.
==Ingredients== Dumplings/noodles: * 2 1/2 c [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] * 1 t [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * 1 t ground [[Cookbook:Pepper|pepper]] * 1 c [[Cookbook:Shortening|shortening]] * 1/3 c plus 1 T cold water Soup: * 2 quarts water * 1 can [[Cookbook:Green Bean|green beans]] * 1 to 3 lb. stewing [[Cookbook:Chicken|chicken]] * salt and pepper to taste
==Procedure== #Boil chicken in water until tender. #Meanwhile, prepare noodle dough following the first 5 steps of [[Cookbook:Flaky Pie Crust|Flaky Pie Crust]] procedure, from the ingredients above. ''Note: [[Cookbook:Sugar|Sugar]] and [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]] are replaced with pepper and shortening, respectively.'' #On a floured board, roll dough about twice as thick as ordinary pie crust (about a 9" circle or 8" x 10" rectangle). #Cut dough into roughly 2" squares. #Remove chicken from broth. Shred chicken, discarding bones and skin. #Stir pot pie squares into boiling broth a few at a time, being careful not to let them stick together. Simmer 6 minutes. #Add chicken and green beans. Simmer for 10 to 15 minutes. #Remove from heat. Let stand 5 minutes before serving.
==Notes, tips, and variations== *Note: Pot pie squares will dissolve into the broth around the edges, but remain relatively firm in their centers. This is normal. *A range of fresh vegetables including fresh green beans, cubed [[Cookbook:Potato|potatoes]], finely diced [[Cookbook:Carrot|carrots]], [[Cookbook:Onion|onions]], etc. can be added after the chicken if cooking times are planned carefully. *Cooked chicken or [[Cookbook:Turkey|turkey]], or bite-sized pieces of [[Cookbook:Ham|ham]] can be substituted for the raw chicken. In this case, substitute chicken [[Cookbook:Broth|broth]] for water.
[[Category:American recipes|Pennsylvania Pot Pie]] [[Category:Chicken recipes|Pennsylvania Pot Pie]] [[Category:Pot Pie recipes|Pennsylvania Pot Pie]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Salad|Salads]]
'''Dill Cucumber Salad'''
==Ingredients== * 1/2 cup reduced fat [[Cookbook:sour cream|sour cream]] * 2 Tbsp. [[Cookbook:cider vinegar|cider vinegar]] * 1 tsp. [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] * 3/4 tsp. [[Cookbook:garlic powder|garlic powder]] * 3/4 tsp. [[Cookbook:Dill|dill weed]] * 1/2 tsp. [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * 3 medium [[Cookbook:Cucumber|cucumber]], sliced * 1/2 cup sliced [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]]
==Procedure== Combine first 6 ingredients, add cucumbers and onion, toss to coat. Cover and refrigerate for at least 1 hour. Serve with slotted spoon.
[[Category:Salad recipes|Dill Cucumber Salad]] [[Category:Dill recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Cucumber recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}}
"A national dish of Scotland, composed of a forcemeat of the heart, liver and lungs of a sheep mixed with oatmeal, well seasoned and put into bags made from the paunch of the sheep. The haggis is then boiled for 2-3 hours and left to get cold. When required for use it is simmered again for about an hour and is traditionally served with mashed turnips, potatoes and whisky." <cite>from www.tedcancook.com/terms1.htm</cite>
{{wikipedia|Haggis}}
The accompaniments, "neeps and tatties", refer to mashed [[Cookbook:Swede|swede]] or [[Cookbook:Turnip|turnip]], and [[Cookbook:Potato|potatoes]] (in this context, mashed.)
In fish and chip shops, a long, sausage-shaped haggis is often available deep-fried in batter with chips.
==Recipe== '''Major Ingredients''' *1 pound beef heart, cut into 2-inch-wide strips. *1 pound beef liver. *1/2 pound lamb stew meat, cut in 1-inch cubes. *1 1/2 cups peeled and finely chopped yellow onion. *4 tablespoons Scots whisky. *1 tablespoon of Egg nog *2 cups oatmeal, toasted on a cookie sheet in a 375F oven for 10 minutes).
'''Seasonings''' *2 teaspoons salt. *1/2 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper. *1 teaspoon dried thyme, whole. *1/2 teaspoon dried rosemary. *1/4 teaspoon freshly grated nutmeg.
'''Casing''' *3 beef CAPS (Talk to a sausage shop about these). *1 cup distilled white vinegar. *1/2 tablespoon salt for soaking.
== Procedure == # Place the beef heart in a 4-quart covered pot and just cover with cold water. Simmer, covered, for 1 hour and 10 minutes. # Add the beef liver and lamb stew meat, and cover and simmer for 20 minutes. Remove the contents of the pot and cool. Reserve 1 cup of the liquid. Grind everything coarsely. # In a large bowl mix all of the ingredients, except for the beef caps, vinegar, and salt for soaking. Mix well and set aside. # Rinse the beef caps in cold water. Turn them inside out and soak them in 2 quarts of cold water with the salt and vinegar for 1/2 hour. Drain them and rinse very well, inside and out. # Divide the meat mixture into three parts. Fill the beef caps with the meat mixture and tie the ends off with string. Two will have to be tied on just one end, but the third piece will be tied on both ends. Prick the Haggis all over with corn holders or a sharp fork. Place in a steamer and steam for 1 hour and 20 minutes.
Serve the Haggis, sliced, with beef or lamb gravy.
[[Category:Scottish recipes|Haggis]] [[Category:Sheep recipes|Haggis]]

{{recipesummary|Appetizer recipes|12|30 minutes|2}}
{{recipe}}
'''Angels on Horseback''' are oysters wrapped in bacon strips and broiled.
==Ingredients== Yield: 1 dozen appetizers
* 1/2 cup dry white [[Cookbook:Wine|wine]] * 1 clove [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]], chopped * [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] & [[Cookbook:Pepper|pepper]] to taste * 12 shucked [[Cookbook:Oyster|oysters]] * 6 slices lean [[Cookbook:Bacon|bacon]]
==Procedure== #Mix the wine, garlic, salt and pepper together. Add the oysters and marinate 10 to 20 minutes. #Preheat the [[Cookbook:Broiler|broiler]]. #Cut each bacon slice in half and wrap each oyster with a piece of bacon, securing with a toothpick. #Broil on both sides until the bacon is crisp. You may also cook these "angels" on an outdoor or rangetop grill.
[[Category:Oyster recipes|Angels on Horseback]] [[Category:Appetizer recipes|Angels on Horseback]] [[category:Gluten-free recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary |Category = Indian recipes |Rating = 2 |Image = [[Image:Aloo gobi.jpg|300px]] }} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of India|India]] | [[Cookbook:Vegetarian cuisine|Vegetarian]]
'''Aloo gobi''' is an [[Cookbook:Cuisine of India|Indian]] [[Cookbook:Curry powder|curry]]. Aloo means [[Cookbook:Potato|potato]] and Gobi means [[Cookbook:Cauliflower|cauliflower]]. This dish has a prominent role in the movie ''[[Wikipedia:Bend It Like Beckham|Bend It Like Beckham]]''. The DVD contains a featurette titled ''How to cook Aloo gobi'', however, the recipe given differs from the following one and the one in the external link below, demonstrating the variety of ways the dish can be prepared. Also, sometimes aloo gobi is made without the tomato.
==Ingredients== * 750 [[Cookbook:Gram|g]] [[Cookbook:Tomato|tomatoes]], [[Cookbook:Dice|diced]] or [[Cookbook:Purée|puréed]] * 1 big [[Cookbook:Cauliflower|cauliflower]] cut into chunks * 4-5 [[Cookbook:Potato|potatoes]], peeled, cut into cubes * 1 [[Cookbook:Lemon|lemon]] * 4-5 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoons]] of [[Cookbook:Ghee|ghee]] * 1 teaspoon [[Cookbook:Cumin|cumin seeds]] * 1 tablespoon [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * 1 tablespoon [[Cookbook:Turmeric|curcuma]] (turmeric) * 2 tablespoon ground [[Cookbook:Coriander|coriander]] * 1-2 tablespoon ground [[Cookbook:Chili Pepper|chilli]] * 2-4 tablespoon [[Cookbook:Garam Masala|garam masala]] * 1 sprig of [[Cookbook:Mint|mint]]
==Procedure== # Heat the ghee/oil in frying pan, wok or karahi (an Indian utensil specially used for frying purposes) # Add jeera (cumin seeds) and wait until they turn a light brown color. # Add the spices (except for garam masala) and the tomatoes. # When the mixture turns oily, add the vegetables. # Roast the cauliflower and the potatoes until they turn soft. Stir occasionally. # Add the garam masala, mint and lemon juice.
== External links == * [http://www.recipesindian.com/indian_recipes/indian_vegetarian_recipes/Aloo-Gobi.html Authentic Indian recipes] * [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aloo_gobi Wikipedia article] * [http://www.route79.com/food/aloo-gobi.htm Illustrated recipe] * [http://www.ifood.tv Video recipe]
[[Category:Indian recipes|Aloo Gobi]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|Aloo Gobi]] [[category:Gluten-free recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{cookwork}} {{recipe}} '''READ THIS ALSO:'''Adapted from http://alfredo.octavio.net/soft_drink_formula.pdf, [http://66.102.7.104/search?q=cache:ZJ5HL71eALoJ:alfredo.octavio.net/soft_drink_formula.pdf+open+cola&hl=en&start=3 View as HTML with Google] == Background == OpenCola is unique in that the instructions for making it are freely available and modifiable. Anybody can make the drink, and anyone can modify and improve on the recipe as long as they, too, license their recipe under the GNU General Public License. The legal grounds for this are dubious however, as recipes are exempted from copyright as they are techniques, not artworks. Although originally intended as a promotional tool to explain free software/open source software, the drink took on a life of its own and 150,000 cans were sold. The Toronto-based company Opencola founded by Grad Conn, Cory Doctorow and John Henson became better known for the drink than the software it was supposed to promote. Laird Brown, the company's senior strategist, attributes its success to a widespread mistrust of big corporations and the "proprietary nature of almost everything." == Flavoring Formula == * 10.0 g Food Grade Gum Arabic (Important: Do NOT use Art Grade Gum Arabic!) * 3.50 mL Orange oil * 3.00 mL Water * 2.75 mL Lime oil * 1.25 mL Cassia oil * 1.00 mL Lemon oil * 1.00 mL Nutmeg oil * 0.25 mL Coriander oil * 0.25 mL Neroli oil * 0.25 mL Lavender oil == Concentrate Formula== * 2.36 kg plain granulated White Table Sugar * 2.28 L Water * 30.0 mL Caramel color * 3.50 tsp. 75% Phosphoric acid or Citric acid * 2.00 tsp. Flavoring Formula * 0.50 tsp. Caffeine (optional) == Preparation == '''Flavoring:'''
Mix oils together in a cup. Add food-grade gum arabic, mix with a spoon. Add water and mix well. A mixer may be used for this step, mixing for 4-5 minutes. You can also transfer to a blender for this step. The mix can be kept in a sealed glass jar in the fridge or at room temperature. Please note that this mixture will separate. The gum arabic is essential to this part of the recipe, as you are mixing oil and water.
'''Syrup:'''
In a one gallon container, take 5 mls of the Flavoring Formula, add the 75% phosphoric or citric acid. Add the water, then the sugar. While mixing, add the caffeine, if desired. Make sure the caffeine is completely dissolved. Then add the caramel color. Mix thoroughly.
'''Cola:'''
To finish drink, take one part syrup and add 5 parts carbonated water. == External Links == {{wikipedia}} {{wikisource}} * [http://www.colawp.com/colas/400/cola467_recipe.html OpenCola soft drink] * [http://sparror.cubecinema.com/cube/cola/ Cube Cola Bristol UK] * [http://www.guardian.co.uk/food/Story/0,,1832135,00.html Guardian Newspaper Article] * [[Media:OpenCola_soft_drink_recipe.pdf|OpenCola's soft drink formula]][[Image:Page white acrobat.png]] * [http://www.wikihow.com/Make-OpenCola How to Make OpenCola - WikiHow] [[Category:Beverage recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Recipes_with_metric_units|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Spices and herbs|Spices and herbs]]
A '''dry rub''' useful for ribs, pork roast or whatever you like. After rubbing on the meat, let it sit in the refrigerator for about an hour.
== Ingredients == * ¼ cup. [[Cookbook:Paprika|paprika]] * ¼ cup. [[Cookbook:Brown Sugar|light brown sugar]] * 3 tbsp. [[Cookbook:kosher salt|kosher salt]] * 1 tsp. [[Cookbook:Mustard|dry mustard]] * 1 tsp. ground [[Cookbook:Pepper|black pepper]] * ½ tsp. [[Cookbook:cayenne pepper|cayenne pepper]] * ½ tsp ground [[Cookbook:cumin|cumin]]
== Procedure == Combine ingredients in a Zip-Lock bag, shaking thoroughly. Store in airtight container.
[[Category:Spice Mix recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Paprika recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{cookwork|Provide measurements}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Southern cuisine|Southern cuisine]]
'''Fried okra''' means summer in the South. A quick mid-day meal; a side-dish at the evening meal -- easy to make and always tasty.
For 1 person
# Wash and drain a couple of handfuls of fresh [[Cookbook:Okra|okra]]. # Cut each okra into three or four slices, about 3/4 to one inch long. Discard the stem. # Soak the okra in buttermilk or plain milk, drain, then dredge in seasoned flour & corn meal. A quick way to do this is to put a half cup of flour and a cup of corn meal in a plastic bag, add the spices you like (salt, pepper, cayenne, cumin, thyme, etc), put in the okra and shake. # Let the okra rest a few minutes. If any pieces look soggy, dredge them again in a flour/corn meal mix. # Fry the okra in hot oil. They're done in 2-3 minutes. # Drain, and enjoy!
[[Category:Southern recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetable recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Okra recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Salad Dressing recipes|4|10 minutes|1}}
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Salad Recipes|Salad Recipes]]
'''Vinaigrette''' (from [[French]] ''vinaigre'', vinegar) is an emulsion of [[Cookbook:vinegar|vinegar]] and [[Cookbook:oil|oil]]. It is one of the most basic salad dressings.
==Ingredients== * 1 clove of garlic, smashed * 2 tablespoons vinegar * 1 teaspoon mustard * 6 tablespoons oil (vegetable, extra virgin olive, almond, hazlenut, etc.) * salt and freshly ground pepper to taste * herbs to taste
==Procedure== # Mix garlic, salt, mustard and vinegar until smooth. # Add oil and mix until smooth. # Add pepper and herbs to taste. # Let stand; the longer the herbs and mustard soak in the oil, the better-blended the flavor will be. You may need to quickly remix the vinaigrette just before dressing the salad if the oil and vinegar have separated while standing.
==Notes, tips and variations==
* The classical ratio of vinegar to oil is 1:3. Some recipes, however, suggest a ratio as low as 1:5. * It is important to mix the mustard and vinegar first, then add the oil. This helps the emulsion hold better, resulting in a smooth vinaigrette that is slow to separate out. Adding the oil in a stream and mixing as it is added helps even more. * Use a pleasantly flavored vinegar such as balsamic vinegar or red wine vinegar. * Mustard powder may be used instead of regular mustard. * Instead of the garlic, a similar amount of very finely diced shallot may be used. * Toss the dressing with the salad just before serving. Greens that have been dressed wilt and become unappetizing within a few minutes. * Different oils can be used for different flavors. Some suggest the use of vegetable oil, but this tends to add little in the way of flavor and most would find it unsuibtable. Extra virgin olive oil is always a good choice, but nearly any plant oil can be used and experimentation is always good.
[[Category:Salad Dressing recipes|Vinaigrette]] [[Category:Vinegar recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Oil recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Vegan recipes|3 glasses|15 minutes|1}}
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Vegan_cuisine|Vegan Cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Breakfast_Recipes|Breakfast]]
A spread that consist of the two base ingredients rice and wheat (optionally oat flakes).
==Ingredients== *rice (400g) *wheat flour (150g) *magarine *rapeseed oil or other vegetable oil *optionally: **soy sauce **mustard **catsup **garlic **pepper **onions **thyme **seasoning mix (corn flour, salt, chili, onion, garlic, paprika) (e.g. Mexican Taco Seasoning Mix)
==Procedure== Take boiled rice (for example left over rice from lunch) and mash it. Mix the mashed rice with the wheat flour and magarine or rapeseed oil and some water. Mix the substance until you get a homogenous mass. Add the optional ingredients to taste: mustard, catsup, garlic and pepper or any other herbs (e.g. fresh Thyme). You can also try to just add your favorite herbs and no other ingredients. Give the spread some time to adopt the taste of the herbs.
[[Category:Vegan recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Rice recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Wheat recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]
[[de:Veganes Leben: Ernährung: Rezepte: Brotaufstrich aus Reis und Weizen]]

{{cookwork|Page should be split}}
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Southwestern cuisine|Southwestern cuisine]]
'''Queso''' (''cheese'' in Spanish, also known as '''Chile con Queso''') is a common dip found in [[Cookbook:Southwestern cuisine|southwestern]] and [[Cookbook:Tex-Mex cuisine|Tex-Mex]] cooking.
==Killer queso dip==
* 1 [[Cookbook:pound|lb.]] (450g) hot pork [[Cookbook:sausage|sausage]] *1 lb. (450g) [[Cookbook:Velveeta|Velveeta]] cheese * 10 [[Cookbook:ounce|oz.]] (280g) can [[Cookbook:Tomato|tomato]]es stewed with green [[Cookbook:Chili Pepper|chilies]] (i.e. Rotel brand)
Serve with [[Cookbook:tortilla chip|tortilla chips]] or Fritos. Recipe makes about 3 cups.
===In a saucepan=== Brown sausage in saucepan and drain grease. Add cubed cheese, diced tomatoes and diced chilies. Heat over low, stirring until cheese is melted and ingredients are well blended.
===In a slow cooker===
Brown sausage in a skillet and drain grease. In a slow cooker, melt cheese with tomatoes and chilies, stirring. Add browned sausage. Stir until well melted and mixed.
==Quick and easy queso dip==
* 10 oz. (280g) of stewed tomatoes with green chilies *1 small [[Cookbook:onion|onion]], chopped * 1 lb. (450g) Velveeta cheese, cubed *0.5 lb. (225g) monterrey jack cheese, grated
In small pan, heat undrained tomatoes and onion, cooking until the juice is gone. While tomatoes are cooking, place Velveeta in microwave-safe bowl and melt in microwave. Add monterrey jack cheese and melt mixture using 50% power. Add tomato mixture.
Can also be made using crock pot.
[[Category:Southwestern recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Slow cooker recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Cheese recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Pork recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Recipes_with_metric_units|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|Cuisine of the United States]]
==Ingredients== *2 cans (2 lb. 8 oz.) [[Cookbook:Yam|yams]], drained (or 4 lbs. cooked, peeled, sliced yams) *2/3 cup orange juice *1 tablespoon orange rind, grated *1/2 cup bourbon *2 teaspoons salt *1 teaspoon ginger, ground *4 tablespoons butter, melted *1/3 cup brown sugar, packed *3 egg yolks *fresh pepper to taste
===Topping=== *2/3 cup brown sugar, packed *1/4 lb. butter, melted *1 cup pecans, chopped (about 4 oz.) *1 teaspoon ground cinnamon
==Procedure== In mixing bowl with electric mixer, beat yams (or [[Cookbook:Sweet Potato|sweet potatoes]]). Add in remaining main ingredients, beating until mixture is light and fluffy. Butter a 12" porcelain quiche dish or a shallow 2 quart casserole dish (7"x11"). Pour in yam mixture, smoothing top evenly.
Make praline topping by mixing all ingredients together in small bowl. Spread evenly over the yams. May be refrigerated covered overnight. Bake at 350 degrees for 45-50 minutes or until golden brown and bubbly. Remove from oven and let stand ten minutes before serving.
Serves 10-12.
==External links== *[http://allrecipes.com/advice/coll/all/articles/641P1.asp Sweet Potatoes vs. Yams] *[http://allrecipes.com/sweetpotatocasserole.asp Sweet Potato Casserole Recipes] Allrecipes has over 100 free sweet potato casserole recipes.
[[Category:Casserole recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Thanksgiving recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:American recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Yam recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Vegan cuisine|Vegan cuisine]]
[[Image:WheatGrass.jpg|thumb|right|280px|One week old wheat grass]]
'''Wheat grass juice''' is the extracted juice from young (5 - 10 inch) [[Cookbook:Wheat|wheat]] plants. The juice is touted for many health benefits due to its high concentrations of Chlorophyll, enzymes, vitamins (especially B's) and minerals. Another benefit of drinking wheat grass juice is a significant energy ''buzz'', due to the very high concentrations of B vitamins, that lasts several hours.
A typical portion is two fluid ounces, requiring the juicing of 1/3 to 1 square foot of wheat grass. The juice has a pungent, sweet odor/taste which is an [[Cookbook:acquired taste|acquired taste]]. It may be drunk straight, or mixed with other juices, such as carrot or apple.
Wheatgrass juice should always be consumed immediately after juicing.
==Materials== * 1 - 2 cups Wheat berries * 1 Tray (cafeteria type, to grow shoots on) * 2 cups potting soil * Large jar
[[Image:WheatGrassJuicing.jpg|thumb|right|280px|Wheat grass juice from a manual juicer.]]
==Growing== * Soak the wheat berries overnight * Drain, cover with damp paper towel allow a day or so to sprout (still in the large jar) * Spread the potting soil on the tray, and then the sprouts. * Keep watered. * The sprouts should be ready for use in about a week
==Juicing== *Use an electric or manual juicer *Drink two to four ounces straight, or mixed with the juice of your choice.
[[Category:Vegan recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetable recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Beverage recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Cuba|Cuban Cuisine]]
==Ingredients== * 1 [[Cookbook:Pound|lb.]] dried [[Cookbook:black bean|black bean]]s * 10 [[Cookbook:Cup|cups]] [[Cookbook:water|water]] * 1 large [[Cookbook:bell pepper|green pepper]] (cut in half, seeds & stem removed) * 1/3 cup [[Cookbook:Olive Oil|olive oil]] * 1 large [[Cookbook:onion|onion]], chopped * 4 cloves of [[Cookbook:garlic|garlic]], smashed and chopped * 1 large [[Cookbook:green pepper|green pepper]] (seeds & stem removed, then chopped) * 4 teaspoons [[Cookbook:salt|salt]] * 1/2 teaspoon [[Cookbook:pepper|pepper]] * 1 teaspoon [[Cookbook:oregano|oregano]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Bay Leaf|bay leaf]] * 2 tablespoons [[Cookbook:sugar|sugar]] * 2 tablespoons [[Cookbook:cider vinegar|cider vinegar]] * 2 tablespoons dry [[Cookbook:white wine|white wine]] (cooking wine or dry sherry is fine) * 2 tablespoons [[Cookbook:Olive Oil|olive oil]]
==Procedure== # The night before you plan to cook, wash the beans and put them in a large pot to soak in the water and green pepper. (the one cut in half) # The next day, cook them in the same water until they are softer (a low [[Cookbook:boil|boil]], stirring occasionally, about an hour). # In a [[Cookbook:frying pan|frying pan]], heat the oil and [[Cookbook:sauté|sauté]] the chopped onion, garlic, and green pepper (this is called a sofrito) until soft (about 5-10 min.) # Take a cup of the soft black beans in some liquid and put in a [[Cookbook:blender|blender]]. Liquefy the beans. Add this to the frying pan and mix the bean liquid with the sofrito. Then, add the contents of the frying pan to the big pot of beans. Add salt, pepper, oregano, bay leaf, and sugar. # Boil about another hour, stirring occasionally. Add vinegar and cooking wine. # Boil for about another hour to thicken. Add the 2 tablespoons of olive oil and serve.
Yields about eight portions (unless they're Cubans).
Note: If the beans are too watery, boil until the right consistency. They keep for about a week in the refrigerator – or they freeze well.
Source: Nitza Villapol, Cocina Criolla
[[Category:Bean recipes|Cuban Black Beans]] [[Category:Cuban recipes|Cuban Black Beans]]

__NOTOC__{{recipe}}
'''Arroz Con Pollo''' (''Rice with Chicken'') is a pretty standard [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Cuba|Cuban]] dish, very similar to [[Cookbook:Paella|Paella]], but without seafood.
== Ingredients == === Marinaded chicken === * [[Cookbook:Chicken|Chicken]] - 9 drumsticks and 9 thighs * 1 [[Cookbook:orange|orange]] * 1/2 [[Cookbook:lemon|lemon]] * 1/2 [[Cookbook:lime|lime]] * [[Cookbook:Adobo|Adobo]] (or [[Cookbook:salt|salt]])
=== Rice === * 2 1/2 c. chopped [[Cookbook:green pepper|green pepper]] (about 2 whole) * 2 1/2 c. chopped [[Cookbook:onion|onion]] (about 2) * 3 cloves [[Cookbook:garlic|garlic]] * 15 oz. [[Cookbook:tomato sauce|tomato sauce]] * 1 small jar chopped [[Cookbook:pimentos|pimentos]] * 1 1/2 c. cooking [[Cookbook:sherry|sherry]] * 2 c. [[Cookbook:water|water]] * 3 c. [[Cookbook:long-grain rice|long-grain rice]] * 1 tbsp. [[Cookbook:salt|salt]] * [[Cookbook:bay leaf|bay leaf]] * pinch of [[Cookbook:saffron|saffron]] * can of [[Cookbook:petit pois|petit pois]] (small [[Cookbook:peas|peas]]) * [[Cookbook:olive oil|olive oil]]
== Procedure == # Marinate the chicken for about 6 hours in the juice of 1 orange, 1/2 lemon, and 1/2 lime. Sprinkle with Adobo (or salt). # Brown chicken in a pan. # [[Cookbook:Saute|Saute]] onion, pepper, and garlic to make a sofrito. # Add tomato sauce to sofrito, cook for 5 min. # Add pimento, liquid from can of peas, bay leaf, salt, saffron, sherry, and water. Add chicken, cover pot, and cook for 1/2 hour on low. # Add rice, cook on stove on low or in oven at 350 °F until liquid is almost absorbed (about 30-45 min.). # Mix in peas and let them warm up before serving.
Makes 9 servings.
[[Category:Cuban recipes|Arroz Con Pollo]] [[Category:Chicken recipes|Arroz Con Pollo]] [[Category:Rice recipes|Arroz Con Pollo]]

{{recipe}} {{recipesummary|Sandwich|1|5-10 minutes|1}} This sandwich should keep well because it has peanut butter on both pieces of bread, providing a waterproof layer to keep the bread from getting soggy. The downside is that one is more likely to get peanut butter into the jar of jam or jelly. Serve with a glass of milk.
==Ingredients (for 1 person)== * 2 slices of [[Cookbook:White Bread|White Bread]] * [[Cookbook:Peanut Butter|Peanut Butter]] * [[Cookbook:Jelly|Jelly]] or [[Cookbook:Jam|Jam]]
==Preparation== #Using a spreading knife, spread an even coat of peanut butter on one side of each slice of bread. #When the bread is evenly covered, spread an even coat of jelly atop the peanut butter. #After applying the jelly, put one of the slices on a plate (jelly side up) and place the other slice on top of the first (jelly side down).
==Variations== * Use whole wheat bread or an all-grain bread, whatever kind of bread you want. * Add in some sliced banana. * If using a crab apple jelly, a dash of cinnamon will nicely compliment the flavours of the sandwich. * Replace the jelly with [[Cookbook:Honey|honey]]. * Replace the jelly with whipped cream cheese (a healthier fluffer-nutter) or keep the jelly and just add the cream cheese.
[[Category:American recipes|Peanut Butter and Jelly Sandwich]] [[Category:Sandwich recipes|Peanut Butter and Jelly Sandwich]] [[Category:Peanut Butter recipes|Peanut Butter and Jelly Sandwich]]

{{cookwork}} {{recipe}}

{{recipesummary|Pie recipes|8 slices|prep: 45 minutes (including crust)
baking: 1 hour|3|Image=[[Image:Rhubarb_Pie.jpg|300px]]}} {{recipe}} | [[:Category:Rhubarb recipes|Rhubarb Recipes]] This pie is fairly sweet but is also quite tangy since rhubarb is its main ingredient. It is best served warm with a scoop of [[Cookbook:Vanilla|vanilla]] [[Cookbook:Ice Cream|ice cream]]. ==Ingredients== * 1 recipe [[Cookbook:Flaky Pie Crust|Flaky Pie Crust]] * 5 [[Cookbook:cup|cup]]s (1100g) of [[Cookbook:Rhubarb|rhubarb]] stalks (about 2 1/2 pounds) * 1 & 1/2 cups (360ml) of [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] * 1/4 cup of (60ml) [[Cookbook:Cornstarch|cornstarch]] or [[Cookbook:Tapioca|tapioca]] pearls * 1/4 tsp of [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] ==Procedure== ===Crust=== # Prepare the [[Cookbook:Flaky Pie Crust|flaky pie crust]] and refrigerate while preparing the rhubarb. ===Filling=== # Clean and trim the rhubarb stalks. # Cut the stalks into 1/2 inch to 1 inch (1.25 to 2.5cm) sections. # Add sugar, cornstarch or tapioca, and salt. # Stir until rhubarb is evenly coated with dry ingredients. Image:01-rhubarb_stalks.jpg|storebought rhubarb stalks Image:02-cleaned_rhubarb_stalks.jpg|cleaned rhubarb stalks Image:04-rhubarb_and_strawberries.jpg|filling for two pies Image:05-filling_ingredients.jpg|dry ingredients for filling Image:06-filling_mixed.jpg|mixed fruit and dry ingredients for pie filling ===Forming and cooking the pie=== # Follow the instructions in the [[Cookbook:Flaky_Pie_Crust#To_Form_a_Covered_Pie|flaky pie crust]] recipe. ==Notes, tips and variations== * If cornstarch is used as the thickener, the pie requires a longer cooling time before the filling is gelled. * Another variation is to use a whole egg in the mix. * This cookbook also has a recipe for [[Cookbook:Strawberry Rhubarb Pie|strawberry rhubarb pie]]. [[Category:Pie recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Rhubarb recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegan recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Dessert recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Featured recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}}
Lechon Asado al horno
==Ingredients:== *1 6-pound pork shoulder *5 teaspoons salt *5 medium garlic cloves *1/2 teaspoon pepper *1/2 teaspoon crushed oregano *3 tablespoons vegetable oil *1 tablespoon vinegar
==Directions:== # Wash the pork shoulder. # With a sharp knife make incisions in different places of the pork shoulder. # Rub the salt well into the incisions and on the outside. # Grind together the garlic, pepper, oregano, and 1 tablespoon of salt. # Spread this mixture on the outside of the pork. # Mix the vinegar and the remaining oil and spread on the outside of the pork. # Put away in the refrigerator for 1 day. # If you planned to cook it the same day, prepare the pork at least 1 hour ahead of time. # Remove the pork shoulder from the refrigerator 2 hours before putting it in the oven. # Preheat the oven at 350ºF for at least 10 minutes before you begin cooking the pork shoulder. # Cook the pork for 3 1/2 hours. # Raise the temperature to 375ºF and cook for 15 to 30 minutes until the skin is toasted and browned.
[[Category:Pork recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Mexican recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Dessert recipes|8 slices|prep: 45 minutes (including crust)
baking: 1 hour|3}} {{recipe}} | [[:Category:Rhubarb recipes|Rhubarb Recipes]] | [[:Category:Strawberry recipes|Strawberry Recipes]] ==Ingredients== * 2 1/2 c rhubarb stalks (about 1 1/4 pounds) * 2 1/2 c sliced strawberries * 1 1/4 c sugar * 1/4 c cornstarch or tapioca pearls * 1/4 tsp salt ==Procedure== ===Crust=== # Prepare the [[Cookbook:Flaky Pie Crust|flaky pie crust]] and refrigerate while preparing the filling. ===Filling=== # Clean the strawberries and remove the leaves. # Cut the strawberries in halves (or quarters for larger berries) # Clean and trim the rhubarb stalks. # Cut the stalks into 1/2 inch to 1 inch sections. # Add sugar, cornstarch or tapioca, and salt. # Stir until rhubarb is evenly coated with dry ingredients. Image:01-rhubarb_stalks.jpg|storebought rhubarb stalks Image:02-cleaned_rhubarb_stalks.jpg|cleaned rhubarb stalks Image:03-cut_strawberries.jpg|strawberries cut for pie Image:04-rhubarb_and_strawberries.jpg|filling for two pies Image:05-filling_ingredients.jpg|dry ingredients for filling Image:06-filling_mixed.jpg|mixed fruit and dry ingredients for pie filling ===Forming the pie=== # Follow the instructions in the [[Cookbook:Flaky_Pie_Crust#To_Form_a_Covered_Pie|flaky pie crust]] recipe. Image:17-crust filled.jpg|crust filled with strawberries and rhubarb [[Category:Pie recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Rhubarb recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Strawberry recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegan recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Dessert recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Vegan recipes|3 cups|1–1 1/2 hours|1}}
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Basic_foodstuffs|Basic Foodstuffs]] | [[Cookbook:Vegan_Substitutions|Vegan Substitutions]]
==Ingredients== * 1 1/2 cup shredded dried [[Cookbook:Seaweed|seaweed]] * 4 cups water * 3 very large cloves [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]], crushed but not peeled. * 1 1/2 tbsp. black [[Cookbook:Peppercorn|peppercorns]] * 1/2 cup dark Chinese [[Cookbook:Soy Sauce|soy sauce]] * Extra boiling water as needed
==Procedure== # Place the seaweed in a pot and add 4 cups of water. # Bring to a boil, then turn down the heat to keep it bubbling along. # Cook for 20 minutes. # Add the rest of the ingredients and enough water to make about 6 cups total in the pot. # Bring back to a boil, then boil fairly high for at least 1/2 hour. # At that point, begin to taste (just a little, though--it's strong). # When the stock is reduced by about half, it will be almost too salty to eat, and that means it is ready. # Strain through fine mesh or a coffee filter and allow to cool.
[[Category:Vegan_recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Basic_Foodstuffs]]

{{recipe}}
==Ingredients== *1 large fish (weighing about 2 lbs/1 kg) *1 cup [[Cookbook:Olive oil|olive oil]] *2 cups uncooked [[Cookbook:Rice|rice]] *1 1/2 cups chopped [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]] *[[Cookbook:Salt|salt]], [[Cookbook:Lemon|lemon juice]] and water
== Procedure == # Fry fish in olive oil until well cooked. Remove the fish and allow to cool. # Fry the chopped onions in the same oil until well browned. Meanwhile, bone the fried fish, reserving the cooked fillets to be served over the rice. # Add the head, bones and skin of the fish to the fried onions and cook with four cups of water in a pressure cooker for 15 minutes, or for a longer time in an open pan. # Strain the broth and boil the rice in it using 1-4 cups of broth for each cup of rice (this will depend on the absorbency of the rice you use). # Simmer the rice on a low fire so that most of the broth will be absorbed.
Some of the broth may be flavored with a few drops of lemon and served on the side as a sauce for this dish.
[[Category:Rice recipes|Rice in Fish Broth-Sayyadieh]] [[Category:Fish recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Lebanese recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine|Cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Caribbean cuisines|Caribbean cuisines]] | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Trinidad and Tobago|Cuisine of Trinidad and Tobago]]
{{Need Photo}}
Serves 8-10 ==Ingredients== *2 cups (300g) [[Cookbook:flour|flour]] *2 tsp [[Cookbook:baking powder|baking powder]] *1 tsp [[Cookbook:sugar|sugar]] *1/2 lb (225g) chopped [[Cookbook:shrimp|shrimp]] *2 [[Cookbook:Spring onion|spring onions]] chopped. *1/4 cup (~60g) [[Cookbook:green pepper|green pepper]] chopped *1 small [[Cookbook:onion|onion]]s chopped *4 cloves [[Cookbook:garlic|garlic]] *1 tsp [[Cookbook:Thyme|thyme]] *1 tsp [[Cookbook:parsley|parsley]] *[[Cookbook:water|water]] *1 [[Cookbook:Scotch bonnet|scotch bonnet]] or hot pepper *[[Cookbook:black pepper|black pepper]] and [[Cookbook:salt|salt]] (really optional here) to taste
==Directions== # Combine green pepper, spring onions, onions, scotch bonnet, in bowl. # Add remaining ingredients except water and mix thoroughly. # Add enough water to make a soft mixture using a table spoon. # Beat mixture until is smooth. # Using a pan or deep fryer, drop spoonfuls in to the hot oil and fry until all sides are brown
[[Category:Caribbean recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Recipes_with_metric_units|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary| Caribbean recipes |4|45 minutes|2||500 Cal}}
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine|Cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Caribbean cuisines|Caribbean cuisines]] | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Trinidad and Tobago|Cuisine of Trinidad and Tobago]]
{{Need Photo}}
Serves 6-8 ==Ingredients== *2 cups [[Cookbook:all purpose flour|all purpose flour]] *2 tsp. [[Cookbook:baking powder|baking powder]] *½ tsp. [[Cookbook:salt|salt]] *¾ cups [[Cookbook:water|water]] *4 medium [[Cookbook:potato|potato]]es, apporximately 600g or 1lb *[[Cookbook:Salt|Salt]] and [[Cookbook:black pepper|black pepper]] *[[Cookbook:Hot pepper|Hot pepper]] *Ground or whole [[Cookbook:cumin|cumin]] ([[Cookbook:jeera|jeera]]) to taste, approximately 1 - 1½ tsp. *[[Cookbook:Oil|Oil]] for [[Cookbook:deep frying|deep frying]]
==Directions== # Mix flour, baking powder, salt and water and knead lightly. # Set aside to relax, covered with a bowl or wet cloth # Boil potatoes in salt water until tender # Peel and mash potatoes well #*If whole cumin is used, heat in a dry pan for a few minutes to release the flavour # Season with salt, black pepper, hot pepper and geera # Divide dough into 9 balls called a [[loyah]] # Flatten out balls into 10cm, 4" circles and fill with potato # Wet one edge with water, fold over and seal, enclosing all potato # Deep fry in oil until golden brown # Drain on brown paper or kitchen towel..
If loyah are made smaller, 12 medium sized aloo pies can be made
[[Category:Caribbean recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes]] [[Category:Vegan recipes]]

{{recipe}}
Serves 2
==Ingredients== * 2 [[Cookbook:cup|cup]]s [[Cookbook:rice|rice]] (preferably Basmati) * 500[[Cookbook:g|g]] [[Cookbook:chicken|chicken]] * 6 [[Cookbook:tablespoon|tablespoon]]s [[Cookbook:oil|oil]] * 300ml [[Cookbook:yoghurt|yoghurt]] * 3 cloves of [[Cookbook:garlic|garlic]], crushed and chopped * 1.5cm [[Cookbook:ginger|ginger]], peeled and sliced
* 5 large [[Cookbook:onion|onion]]s, chopped * ½ cup [[Cookbook:tomato|tomato]]es, pureed * 2 [[Cookbook:chili|chili]]s, chopped * 1 [[Cookbook:teaspoon|teaspoon]] [[Cookbook:turmeric|turmeric]] powder * 5-6 strands [[Cookbook:saffron|saffron]] * 8 [[Cookbook:clove|clove]]s * 10cm [[Cookbook:cinnamon|cinnamon]] stick * 5 [[Cookbook:black pepper|black pepper]] corns * 8 [[Cookbook:cardamom|cardamom]] pods * 1 teaspoon [[Cookbook:cumin|cumin]] * [[Cookbook:Salt|Salt]] to taste
==Procedure== # cook soaked and washed rice.(Preferably Basmati Rice) # [[Cookbook:Marinate|Marinate]] the chicken in [[Cookbook:lemon juice|lemon juice]], yoghurt, ginger, garlic, salt, turmeric powder, cumin powder, cloves, chillis, chopped tomatoes, tomato puree # Heat oil in a cooker and add onions, cook till onions turn golden brown. Add these to the chicken. # Grease a heavy bottomed deep and wide mouthed pan. Place a layer of rice. Put in the masala (the chicken and marinade) Top with the rest of the rice and put the saffron on top # Heat in the oven for 1 - 1 1/2 hours at 150 degrees celsius, to check whether ready, cut into a piece of chicken to see if it is cooked. # Serve the biryani with yoghurt on the side
[[Category:Rice recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Cardamom recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Saffron recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Chicken recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} ==Ingredients== *18 [[Cookbook:Clam|clams]] (2lbs) *2 [[Cookbook:Celery|celery]] stalks (finely chopped) *1 [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]] finely chopped *1 [[Cookbook:Bell Pepper|bell pepper]] diced *2 [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]] cloves minced *2 tbs [[Cookbook:Parsley|parsley]] *1 tbs [[Cookbook:Thyme|thyme]] *½ cup of [[Cookbook:Lemon|lemon]]
==Directions== #Preheat oven to 450°F (230°C). #Cut four 18-inch [[Cookbook:Aluminium foil|aluminum foil]] squares. #Clean clams. #Make squares into double foil pockets and put ingredients in them. #Fold edges so there is plenty of space for them to open. The edges themselves should be tightly folded several times to close up. #Cook 15-25 minutes. #Eat right out of the foil or empty onto plate.
[[Category:Clam recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}}
Serves 3.
== Ingredients ==
* 6 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoon]] [[Cookbook:Oil|oil]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoon]] [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * 3 Green [[Cookbook:Chile|chilies]] finely chopped * 1 teaspoon ginger garlic paste * 1 [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] Onions chopped * 1/2 teaspoon [[Cookbook:Cumin|cumin]] seeds * 1/2 teaspoon red chilli powder * 1/4 teaspoon [[Cookbook:Tumeric|turmeric]] powder * 1 teaspoon [[Cookbook:Coriander|coriander]] powder * 3/4 cup (200ml) [[Cookbook:Water|water]] * 1 cup pureed [[Cookbook:Tomato|tomatoes]] * 8oz (200gms) [[Cookbook:Paneer|paneer]] (cheese) diced in 1” cubes * 1/2 cup [[Cookbook:Pea|peas]] * 1 tablespoon chopped coriander
== Procedure == # Heat oil in a pan. Fry cumin seeds in oil. Add onions and cook till onions turn golden brown. # Add pureed tomatoes, ginger-garlic paste, green chillies, Turmeric powder, Coriander powder, Red chilli powder, salt and cook till fat separates. # Add water and bring to a boil. Churn the curry in blender. # Return the curry in pan and add paneer and peas. Cook till peas are tender. # Garnish with chopped coriander. Served with a roti such as [[Cookbook:Naan|naan]], [[Cookbook:Chapati|chapati]], [[Cookbook:Puri|puri]] or parantha.
{{wikipedia|Paneer}} [[Cookbook:Paneer|Paneer]] is a pressed uncured cheese usually made fresh. It can be bought in Indian or specialty grocery stores, or [[Cookbook:tofu|tofu]] can be substituted if paneer is not available.
[[Category:Pea recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Cheese recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Indian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

[[Image:Naan shiva.jpg|right|thumb|Naan]] {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of India|Indian Cuisine]]
==Ingredients== To make approximately 4 large naan breads: * 3 [[Cookbook:Cup|cups]] (450g) plain [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] * 1 cup (240ml) [[Cookbook:Yogurt|yogurt]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoon]] [[Cookbook:Baking Soda|baking soda]] * 2 teaspoons [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * 3/4 cup (180ml) water
==Procedure== # [[Cookbook:Kneading|Knead]] the dough by combining all the ingredients and sufficient water (this will be approximately 3/4 cup but some judgement is required). # Wrap the dough in a damp muslin cloth and leave it to rise for 2-3 hours. # Divide the dough into small balls. # Roll out the balls in oblong or round shape with a rolling pin or by slapping and stretching with your hands. # Smear the surface with water and bake in a tandoor or preheated oven (as hot as your oven will go). # The naans should puff up a little, and be ready to remove from the oven in 4 to 5 minutes. # Brush the naan with butter. Serve hot.
==Notes, tips and variations== * To add an extra crispy finish, pop the baked naans under a preheated grill for 30 seconds before brushing with butter and serving. * To add extra flavour, consider adding finely chopped garlic and coriander to the butter you brush over your cooked naan breads. Then return them to the oven (or place under a grill) for a short time to cook the garlic.
[[Category:Flatbread recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Indian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Recipes_with_metric_units|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Pasta recipes|6|2-3 hours|2}}
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Italy|Cuisine of Italy]] | [[Cookbook:Pasta Recipes|Pasta Recipes]]
There are as many ways of preparing '''Pasta e Fagioli''' (or ''Basta Fazool'' if you come from southern Italy) as there are Italians. I remember, growing up in Brooklyn in the 1940's, all the Italians would have it every Friday night because it is meatless. Usually it is a soup dominated by tomatoes. This recipe, in contrast, is the consistency of a stew, and is dominated by the [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Umami#Umami umami] flavor.
{{see also|Cookbook:Pasta and bean soup}}
==Ingredients== *1 pound dried white [[Cookbook:Legumes|beans]] *1 cup of [[Cookbook:Olive Oil|olive oil]] *a whole clove of [[Cookbook:garlic|garlic]], unshelled *1 [[Cookbook:Bay Leaf|bay leaf]] *1 teaspoon or more crushed or ground [[Cookbook:Chili Pepper|hot red pepper]] *fresh [[Cookbook:parsley|parsley]] *½ pound of small diameter [[Cookbook:Pasta|macaroni]], whole [[Cookbook:wheat|wheat]] is best *[[Cookbook:salt|salt]] to taste.
==Procedure== #Put washed beans in salted water, 3 parts to 1 part beans. #Soak overnight OR bring to boil, boil 2 minutes and let stand, covered, for 1 hour. #Do not drain beans, but bring to a boil. #Skim off foam and add oil, garlic and bay leaf. #Simmer for about 2 hours, or until tender. #Cook pasta for 6 or 7 minutes, but don't let it get too soft. #Drain pasta and save some of the water. #Stir pasta and red pepper into beans and simmer until pasta is eatably soft, adding some of the saved water if necessary. #Garnish with red pepper to taste and parsley.
==Notes, tips and variations== *Beans: Use whichever sort is the favorite in your neighborhood and likely to be freshest. In Southern California that would be [[Cookbook:Pinto Bean|pinto beans]], in the deep South, [[Cookbook:Black-Eyed Pea|black-eyed peas]] or perhaps [[Cookbook:Lima Bean|butter beans]]. [[Cookbook:Chickpea|Garbanzos]] might be good. [[Cookbook:Navy Bean|Navy beans]] are always safe. *Olive oil: Use the best grade you can get: Cold pressed, Extra Virgin. *With a salad and some red wine this is a hearty meal, and can be eaten the next day, cold or reheated. *Stop laughing at the name. It's not that funny.
[[Category:Vegan recipes]] [[Category:Pasta recipes]] [[Category:Bean recipes]] [[Category:Italian recipes]] [[Category:Stew recipes]]

{{recipe}}
'''Mexican Seasoning''' is sometimes just chili powder, though many variations on this theme exist. Make your own mixture ahead of time and store in a small shaker for easy use.
==Ingredients==
*1/2 cup [[Cookbook:Chili powder|chili powder]] *1 tablespoon of [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] *1 or 2 teaspoons of [[Cookbook:Cumin|cumin]] (seed or powder) *1 or more teaspoons [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]]
Add to this as you prefer, a teaspoon or more of;
* Mexican [[Cookbook:Oregano|oregano]] * [[Cookbook:Basil|Basil]] * [[Cookbook:Coriander|Coriander]] * [[Cookbook:Onion|Onion]] (powder or granulated) * [[Cookbook:Cinnamon|Cinnamon]] * Crushed [[Cookbook:Red pepper|Red pepper]] * [[Cookbook:Black pepper|Black pepper]]
[[Category: Mexican recipes|Mexican Seasoning]] [[Category:Spice Mix recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Beverage recipes||30 minutes|2}}
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Beverages|Beverages]] | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Iran|Iranian Cuisine]]
(Iran - Sharbat bil Loz)
== Ingredients == * 4 [[Cookbook:Cup|cups]] [[Cookbook:Blanching|blanched]] [[Cookbook:Almond|almonds]] * 4 cups water * 3 cups [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]]- optional, it is healthier without sugar * 1/4 cup orange blossom water (or [[Cookbook:Rose water|rose water]])
== Procedure == # Grind the almonds finely in blender. # Add the water and continue to grind. # Strain the liquid through a sieve lined with cheesecloth. # When drained, squeeze the remaining pulp to extract as much liquid as possible. Discard the pulp. # Pour into a heavy saucepan, then stir in the sugar (optional only). # Boil, stirring constantly, then lower the heat and simmer very gently for 5-10 minutes. # Turn off the heat, add the orange flower water, and let the syrup cool.
To serve, pour 1/4 cup of syrup into a glass, add ice water and stir well.
== Notes == Instead of throwing away the almond pulp, you can mix it into almond [[Cookbook:Agar Jelly|agar jelly]].
[[Category:Iranian recipes|Almond milk]] [[Category:Nut and Grain Milk recipes|Almond milk]] [[Category:Beverage recipes|Almond milk]]

{{recipe}}
==Ingredients== * 5 g [[Cookbook:Agar|Agar]] powder * 100 g [[Cookbook:Sugar|Sugar]] * 500 g [[Cookbook:Water|Water]] * 75 g [[Cookbook:Milk|Milk]] * 1/2 tsp [[Cookbook:Almond extract|Almond extract]] * 6 T [[Cookbook:Fruit cocktail|Fruit cocktail]] * 150 ml [[Cookbook:Syrup|Syrup]]
== Procedure == # Put agar, sugar, and water in a saucepan and bring to boil. # Take off heat, and drain some of the water. # When cool, add in milk and almond extract. # Pour mixture into tin. # When completely cool, chill in the refrigerator for about 15 minutes until set. # Cut almond jelly into cubes. # Serve with fruit cocktail and syrup in a glass bowl
[[Category:Agar recipes|Agar recipes]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes]]

{{recipesummary|Bread recipes|Varies|45 minutes|3}}
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|United States]] | [[Cookbook:Southern cuisine|Southern cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Bread Recipes|Bread Recipes]]
'''Skillet Cornbread''' - Commonly found in the Southern United States, this delicious and easy to make dish is often served beside a pot of brown beans. It can be made a day or two ahead of time, as long as care is taken to keep it from drying out.
==Ingredients== *3/4 cup white all-purpose [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] *2 1/2 teaspoons [[Cookbook:Baking Powder|baking powder]] *1 to 2 tablespoons [[Cookbook:White sugar|white sugar]] *3/4 teaspoons [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] *1 1/4 cups yellow or white [[Cookbook:Cornmeal|corn meal]] *1 [[Cookbook:Egg|egg]] *2 to 3 tablespoons melted [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]] or [[Cookbook:Lard|pan drippings]] *1 cup [[Cookbook:Milk|milk]] or buttermilk.
==Procedure== #Preheat the oven to 425°F #Grease the skillet with bacon drippings (ideal) or oil. Butter isn't recommended, since it can burn when you preheat the skillet. #Preheat the skillet until the drippings/oil is smoking. This ensures a good crust on the bottom of the cornbread. #In a bowl, sift together the flour, baking powder, sugar, and salt. Thoroughly mix the sifted ingredients together and add the corn meal. #In a second bowl, beat the egg well. Add the melted butter (or pan drippings) and the milk and continue to beat until well mixed. #Pour the wet ingredients into the dry ingredients and mix using fast strokes. Take care not to overmix. #Pour the batter into the skillet and place in the oven. Bake for 25-30 minutes. The cornbread should have a golden brown color when done, and a knitting needle or knife-point will come out "dry" when inserted in the bread.
==Notes, tips, and variations== *Ideally, all ingredients should be at room temperature (about 75°F) for this recipe. However, a good result can still be had if this is not the case. *Yellow corn meal is preferable to white corn meal, but this can vary according to locality and personal taste. *Optionally, 1/4 to 1/2 cup of diced cooked ham or crumbled bacon can be added to the batter before pouring into the skillet. This may add a few minutes to the baking time.
==Warnings== *The skillet must be oven-safe. Ideally, skillet cornbread should be baked in a cast-iron skillet.
[[Category:Bread recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Corn recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]
