{{recipesummary|Salad recipes|8|5 minutes preparation, must be frozen overnight|1}} {{recipe}}
A great-tasting salad that goes wonderfully with pizza.
== Ingredients == * 1/2 head of [[Cookbook:Cabbage|white cabbage]] (500 [[Cookbook:Gram|grams]]) * 100 [[Cookbook:ML|ML]] [[Cookbook:Rape Oil|rape oil]] * 2 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoons]] [[Cookbook:White Vinegar|white vinegar]] * A pinch of [[Cookbook:salt|salt]] * A pinch of coarsely-ground [[Cookbook:Pepper|pepper]]
== Procedure == #Slice the cabbage finely (about 1-2 mm thick) #Make a dressing of oil, vinegar, salt, and pepper, mix it with the cabbage. #Put the salad in the fridge overnight.
==Notes, tips, and variations== Goes great with pizza!
[[Category:Salad recipes|Pizza Salad]]

{{recipe}}
==Ingredients== * 1 3/4 [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] all-purpose [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] * 2 T. [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] * 2 tsp. [[Cookbook:Baking Soda|baking soda]] * 1 1/2 tsp. [[Cookbook:Cream of Tartar|cream of tartar]] (or baking powder) * 1/2 tsp. [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * 1 tsp. [[Cookbook:Cinnamon|cinnamon]] * 1 tsp. [[Cookbook:Nutmeg|nutmeg]] * 1 tsp. [[Cookbook:Vanilla Extract|vanilla extract]] * 2 cups [[Cookbook:Buttermilk|buttermilk]] * 4 [[Cookbook:Eggs|eggs]], separated * 1/4 cup [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]] (optional) * 1 cup frozen [[Cookbook:Blueberry|blueberries]]
==Procedure==
# Sift together flour, sugar, baking powder, cream of tartar, salt, cinnamon and nutmeg. Set aside. # Whisk together buttermilk, butter and egg yolks in a large bowl. Beat flour mixture onto buttermilk mixture. Mix in blueberries. # Beat egg whites in a small bowl until stiff, but do not let dry peaks form. Fold into pancake batter. # Heat a large pan or griddle over medium heat. Lightly spray or brush with vegetable oil. Ladle in a ¼ cup of batter for each pancake; cook until set and bubbly on the top. Turn pancake over, cook for 1 more minute. # Serve warm with whatever topping you prefer.
[[Category:Pancake recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Bread recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Blueberry recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Breakfast recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}}
== Ingredients == *1 [[Cookbook:cabbage|cabbage]], chopped *3 [[Cookbook:garlic|garlic]] cloves, minced *3 large [[Cookbook:beet|beet]]s, cubed (or 2 cans of beets) *5 large [[Cookbook:carrot|carrot]]s, chopped *1 large [[Cookbook:onion|onion]], chopped *4 stalks of [[Cookbook:celery|celery]], chopped *2 lb. [[Cookbook:meat|meat]], cubed *1 lb. [[Cookbook:stew bone|stew bone]]s *3 [[Cookbook:lemon|lemon]]s (optional) *2 24 oz. cans crushed [[Cookbook:tomato|tomato]]es *½ cup [[Cookbook:sugar|sugar]] (optional)
== Procedure == # If you are using fresh beets, you first need to place them in boiling water for an hour and a half to two hours. For better flavor bake at 350 °F for an hour and a half. When they are soft enough that a fork will go in easily they are done. Put them in a sink or large bowl full of cool water. Once they are cool pick up a beet and press your thumbs into the skin to start peeling them, sometimes they are not soft enough for this you just need to cook them longer. If you use canned beets they will be ready right out of the can. # While the beets are cooking you should start cooking the meat. Place the meat and bones into a large 12 qt. stock pot. Add the two cans of crushed tomatoes and two cans of water. Stir it up and bring to a boil. # While the meat and beets are cooking chop up all of the veggies, mince the garlic and squeeze the lemons. # After the meat has been boiling for an hour to 90 min. you should add all of the veggies except the beets which are still cooking, the lemon juice and the sugar. # Finish peeling and cubing the beets, when the simmering veggies are soft add the beets, stir well. Then add as much or as little lemon juice and sugar as you like, to suit your own taste. Cook for five more minutes and it’s done.
[[Category:Stew recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Beet recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Cabbage recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|Cuisine of the USA]] {{recipesummary|Cheesecake recipes|10|prep: 40 min,
baking: 50 min
chill: 2 hr|3||807 Cal}} '''Chocolate cheesecake''', rich in both chocolate and cheese. It is noticeably less sweet than many other American desserts, and somewhat more complicated. ==Helpful equipment== *[[Cookbook:Mixer|Electric mixer]] *[[Cookbook:Springform Pan|Springform pan]] ==Ingredients== ===Crust=== *5 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|Tbs]] [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]], melted *2 [[Cookbook:Cup|cups]] chocolate wafer crumbs, or the equivalent in chocolate [[Cookbook:Cookie|cookies]] or chocolate [[Cookbook:Graham Cracker|Graham crackers]] ===Filling=== *3 packages (8 [[Cookbook:Ounce|ounces]] each) [[Cookbook:Cream Cheese|cream cheese]], at room temperature *1 cup brown [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]], packed *5 large [[Cookbook:Egg|egg]]s *4 ounces (4 squares) [[Cookbook:Chocolate|semisweet chocolate]], melted ===Frosting=== *6 ounces (6 squares) semisweet chocolate, melted *½ cup [[Cookbook:Sour Cream|sour cream]] ==Procedure== #Place rack in center of the oven. Preheat oven to 150 °C (300 °F). #If starting with whole cookies, crackers, or wafers, place them in a sturdy plastic bag a few at a time and crush using a [[Cookbook:Rolling Pin|rolling pin]], or grind using a [[Cookbook:Food Processor|food processor]]. #Mix together chocolate crumbs and melted butter. #Press crumb mixture into bottom and sides of 9-inch springform pan. #In a large bowl, beat together sugar and eggs at medium speed, slowly adding cream cheese, until smooth and fluffy. #Spoon half of cream cheese mixture into crust. #Melt 4 ounces of chocolate using a [[Cookbook:Double Boiler|double boiler]] or, with care, a [[Cookbook:Microwave Oven|microwave]]. Stir into remaining cream cheese mixture until well blended. #Drizzle over batter in crust. Draw a spoon or other implement through the batter a few times to make swirls. Spread evenly. #Bake cheesecake for 50 minutes. After the first 30 minutes has gone by, place aluminum foil on top to prevent cracking and scorching. #Cool completely. #Cover with plastic wrap, and chill for about 2 hours, up to several days. #Transfer cheesecake to a serving plate. #Uncover cheesecake; carefully remove side of pan. === Frosting === #Melt remaining chocolate. #Mix with sour cream. #Spread over cake, and chill to set. ==Notes, tips, and variations== *Brown sugar is not absolutely necessary (can substitute granulated), but it provides better flavor. *If no electric mixer is available, the cream cheese can be mixed with egg yolks one-at-a-time before the whites are added. Unless you find separating eggs extremely difficult, this will be worthwhile for the effort saved in mixing. *Without a springform pan, a cake this stiff will require that at least the first piece be broken up in the process of serving. Fortunately, it's often easy to find someone who [[Cookbook:Aesthetics|doesn't care]]. *Without aluminum foil, the top of the cake will crack and brown somewhat, but frosting covers it effectively, making it practically unnoticeable. [[Category:Vegetarian recipes]] [[Category:American recipes]] [[Category:Cheesecake recipes]] [[Category:Chocolate recipes]] [[Category:Halal recipes]]

{{recipesummary|Dessert recipes|6|1 ½ hours|2}}
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Desserts|Desserts]]
Bread Pudding is a British Dessert. This version has banana and chocolate.
==Ingredients== * ¼ cup semisweet [[Cookbook:Chocolate|chocolate]] chips * ¼ cup plus 2 tablespoons spiced [[Cookbook:Rum|rum]] * 4 [[Cookbook:Egg|eggs]] * 2 cups [[Cookbook:whipping cream|whipping cream]] * 1 teaspoon [[Cookbook:Vanilla extract|vanilla extract]] * 5 tablespoons [[Cookbook:sugar|sugar]] * 1 16 oz loaf of [[Cookbook:french bread|french bread]] or other non-sour white [[Cookbook:bread|bread]] (stale bread is traditionally used) * 2 tablespoons [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]] * 3 [[Cookbook:Banana|bananas]]
==Preparation== # in a cup or other small container, add 2 tablespoons of rum to the chocolate chips and soak them until they are needed in step 9 # in a bowl, whisk together the eggs, whipping cream, vanilla extract, ¼ cup rum and 3 tablespoons sugar. # slice the bread, trim off the crusts and cut it into strips. divide the bread strips into three parts. # butter a loaf pan # peel the bananas, cut them in half crosswise and then lengthwise # in a skillet over medium heat, melt the butter and add the banana pieces with 2 tablespoons of sugar. cook 2 minutes, then flip the bananas over and cook the other side for 2 minutes. # cover the bottom of the loaf pan with bread strips (use 1/3 of the bread strips for this) # spread half of the banana pieces on top of the layer of bread strips # spread half of the chocolate chips on top of the bananas # add another layer of bread strips # pour half of the egg mix into the loaf pan and let it soak in for a minute. # add the rest of the bananas, then the rest of the chocolate chips, then the rest of the bread strips. pour the rest of the egg mixture on top # let the loaf pan sit for about 15 minutes while preheating the oven to 350°F # bake for 50 minutes. let cool for 10-15 minutes
serve with Rum Sauce, whipped cream or vanilla ice cream.
[[Category:Dessert recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Pudding and Custard recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Chocolate recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Bread recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Bread recipes|2-5 depending on appetites.|50 Minutes|3}}
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Australia]]
'''Damper''' is Australian bushman's bread, made while camping or "waltzing matilda" (carrying a swag around looking for work). It is meant to be made outside by a campfire.
==Ingredients==
* 1 large cup [[Cookbook:Self Raising Flour|self-raising flour]] * generous pinch of [[Cookbook:salt|salt]] * 1/4 cup [[Cookbook:water|water]] [[Image:Mustering camp.jpg|250px|thumb|Damper and camp oven used, Walcha, NSW]]
==Procedure== # Add salt to flour. # Add scant 1/4 cup water (more and it will be as tough as an old boot). # [[Cookbook:Mix|Mix]] and form into a round loaf. # Dig a foot-deep hole near a fire and add 2 shovelsful of hot coals and ash. # Add damper mixture to a greased [[Cookbook:dutch oven|camp oven]] (traditonal cast iron round pot with lid). # Cook for maximum of 40 minutes. If undercooked it will be flat and rubbery. # Your first try may be inedible. Keep trying, you'll soon be an expert.
==Variations== * This cookbook also has a [[Cookbook:Drover's Damper|Drover's damper]] recipe. * You can do this in a barbecue grill with mixture in greased metal foil as well. During cooking, damper increases volume by 1/3 to 1/2, so allow room for expansion. * If you aren't outdoors, just add mixture to greased oven tray and cook in a moderate oven for 30 - 40 minutes.
==External Links== *[http://www.australianoutdoors.com/damper.htm Australian Bush Damper] Gerry & Mo Noterey from Australian Outdoors (Variation recipes with pictures!) *[http://www.discountcamping.com.au/index/products/campovens/cooking Camp Ovens Discount Camping] *[http://www.millmerran.qld.gov.au/events/2006/Camp_Oven_Festival.shtml Australian Camp Oven Festival]
{{wikipedia|Damper (food)}}
[[Category:Australian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Bread recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Bread recipes|5-10 depending upon appetites!|50 minutes|3}}
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Australia|Australian Cuisine]]
'''Drover's Damper''' is Australian bread, made by stockmen while taking care of or rounding up stock. It is meant to be made outside by a campfire. This is the "flash" version, made when butter and milk is available.
==Ingredients==
* 2 cups [[Cookbook:Flour|self-raising flour]] * 1/4 teaspoon [[Cookbook:salt|salt]] * 2 teaspoons [[Cookbook:sugar|sugar]] * 1 tablespoon [[Cookbook:butter|butter]] * 1 cup [[Cookbook:milk|milk]] [[Image:Mustering camp.jpg|250px|thumb|Damper and camp oven used, Walcha, NSW]]
==Procedure==
# Add salt to flour # Add sugar # Rub in butter. # [[Cookbook:Mix|Mix]] in milk to make a medium-soft dough. # [[Cookbook:Knead|Knead]] lightly on flat surface until smooth. # Pat into a round shape. # Place damper mixture on coals or hot ash. # Cook for maximum of 40 minutes. # Discard burnt outside and eat the inside. # Serve with [[Cookbook:butter|butter]], ([[Cookbook:golden syrup|golden syrup]]) or [[Cookbook:jam|jam]].
==Variations== * This cookbook also has an [[Cookbook:Damper|"ordinary" damper]] recipe. * You can do this using a hole near the fire in a greased [[Cookbook:dutch oven|camp oven]] or greased [[Cookbook:aluminium foil|aluminium foil]] in a barbecue. * If you aren't outdoors, just add mixture to greased bread tin, [[Cookbook:glaze|glaze]] with [[Cookbook:milk|milk]] and cook in a hot oven, reducing heat until cooked (20 minutes). * You can add dried [[Cookbook:fruit|fruit]] - then it's "[[Cookbook:Johnny Cake|Johnny Cake]]". * As a variation, add grated [[Cookbook:cheese|cheese]]. * Use [[Cookbook:beer|beer]] instead of milk for "Beer Damper".
==External Links== *[http://www.nla.gov.au/ntwkpubs/gw/49/p09a01.html Drovers Oral History Project ] National Library of Australia *[http://www.australianoutdoors.com/damper.htm Australian Bush Damper ] Gerry & Mo Noterey from Australian Outdoors (Variation recipes with pictures!) *[http://www.discountcamping.com.au/index/products/campovens/cooking Camp Ovens Discount Camping] *[http://www.millmerran.qld.gov.au/events/2006/Camp_Oven_Festival.shtml Australian Camp Oven Festival]
{{wikipedia|Damper (food)}}
[[Category:Australian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Bread recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}}
This is a simple recipe for baked sweet potatoes.
==Ingredients== *4 large "yam style" [[Cookbook:Sweet Potato|sweet potatoes]]
==Procedure== #Scrub the sweet potatoes very well. (do not peel) #Place into large glass baking dish. Cover loosely with [[Cookbook:Aluminium foil|aluminum foil]]. #Place into pre-heated 400°F (205°C) oven. #Bake for 90 minutes or until very soft.
That's all there is to it and it is so so so good!
[[Category:Sweet Potato recipes|Lovie's yam recipe]]

{{recipesummary|Vegan recipes|1 bowl|10 minutes|1}}
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Vegan_cuisine|Vegan Cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Breakfast_Recipes|Breakfast]]
A spread that consist of the three base ingredients: mashed beans, oat flakes and raw spelt flour.
==Ingredients== *250 [[Cookbook:g|g]] mashed [[Cookbook:beans|beans]] ([[Cookbook:white beans|white beans]] or [[Cookbook:kidney beans|kidney beans]]) *150 g [[Cookbook:oat flakes|oat flakes]] *150 g raw [[Cookbook:spelt flour|spelt flour]] *[[Cookbook:vegetable oil|vegetable oil]] *optional: **[[Cookbook:salt|salt]] **[[Cookbook:garlic|garlic]] **[[Cookbook:pepper|pepper]] **[[Cookbook:herbs and spices|herbs and spices]] **seasoning mix ([[Cookbook:corn flour|corn flour]], [[Cookbook:salt|salt]], [[Cookbook:Chili Pepper|chili|]], [[Cookbook:onion|onion]], [[Cookbook:garlic|garlic]], [[Cookbook:paprika|paprika]], [[Cookbook:MSG|sodium glutamate]]) (e.g. Mexican Taco Seasoning Mix)
==Procedure== # Take oat flakes, raw spelt, beans and some water and oil for the base substance. # Mash the beans and mix the ingredients. # Add the optional ingredients to taste.
The substance can be used as spread or can be fried as [[Cookbook:Spelt Burger|burgers]].
[[Category:Vegan recipes|Bean Spelt Oat Spread]] [[Category:Oat recipes|Bean Spelt Oat Spread]] [[Category:Spelt recipes|Bean Spelt Oat Spread]] [[Category:Bean recipes|Bean Spelt Oat Spread]]
[[de:Veganes Leben: Ernährung: Rezepte: Brotaufstrich aus Bohnen, Dinkel und Hafer]]

{{recipe}}
This "jolly good" dessert was originally created in an old London bakery. At one point in time it was very popular throughout all of England. It has now has spread throughout Europe and the Americas, especially the north-east region of North America (with Bostonians having developed a particular liking for it). The ingredients are simple, the time it takes to prepare is short, and the dessert is simply delicious!
== Ingredients == * 2 bananas, peeled and sliced * 1 tablespoon vanilla extract * 2 tablespoons melted butter * 1 refrigerated can of cinnamon rolls * 1 cup caramel topping (similar to sundae toppings) * 2-3 cups vanilla ice cream '''(optional)'''
== Procedure == # Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C). # In a small bowl, combine bananas, vanilla, and melted butter, until bananas are well coated. On a cookie sheet, unroll two cinnamon rolls, leaving the two triangles attached to form a square. Place 1/4 of banana mixture in the center of each pair of rolls. # Bake for 11 to 13 minutes, or until the pastry is golden brown. Heat the caramel topping and drizzle over dessert. Serve warm. It can also be served with a side dish of ice cream if one chooses.
[[Category:Dessert recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Banana recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:English recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Recipes_with_metric_units|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}}
'''Roast Potatoes''' also known colloquially as 'roasties'. Roast potatoes are usually used as the prime potato-based accompaniment to a [[Cookbook:Roast Dinner|roast dinner]] (usually made up of a roast meat and several different vegetables). Some people, however, prefer to make and eat them by themselves.
==Ingredients== *[[Cookbook:Potato|potatoes]] *[[Cookbook:Oil|oil]] (vegetable, sunflower or Olive Oil) *[[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] (optional) *[[Cookbook:Water|water]]
==Procedure== #Pre-heat the oven to [[Cookbook:Oven temperatures|gas mark 7]] (425°[[Cookbook:Fahrenheit|F]], 220°[[Cookbook:Celsius|C]]). #Pour enough oil into the bottom of the roasting tin to leave a thin layer on the bottom and put it in the oven. #Peel the potatoes and slice them into quarters or eighths depending on the size of the potato. Smaller pieces tend to make crispier roast potatoes, larger pieces tend to make softer ones. #Put the potatoes in a saucepan of water and add a pinch of salt if you wish. #Cover, and bring the saucepan to the boil and then allow to simmer for 10 minutes. #Drain the potatoes. #Replace the lid and shake the potatoes vigorously for 20-30 seconds. #Remove the roasting tin from the oven and tip the potatoes from the saucepan into the tin. #Sprinkle salt over the top of the potatoes. #Replace the roasting tin in the oven. #Roast for 20-25 minutes, or until the potatoes are golden brown; remove them from the oven.
Serve hot.
==Notes, tips, and variations== * For garlic potatoes; after draining the potatoes, add 1-2 cloves of crushed garlic. * Times & quantities are rough and can vary to suit individual tastes. * Halfway through roasting you may wish to remove the tin and move the potatoes with a spoon and/or spoon some of the oil from the bottom of the tin onto the potatoes * Potatoes can also be cooked in the same roasting tin as the meat if being included as part of a roast dinner; they should go in half an hour before the meal is to be served.
== Warnings == *The oil in the roasting tin will be well over 100°[[Cookbook:Celsius|C]]. Be extremely careful when handling the tin.
[[Category:Potato recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}}
==Ingredients== *4 hot dog buns *4 hot dogs *12 slices mozzarella cheese *1 jar pizza sauce *grated parmesan cheese
==Procedure== # Split hot dogs and hot dog buns lengthwise. # Place buns on a cookie sheet. # Sprinkle mozzarella cheese over buns. # Place split hot dog on each bun. # Spread pizza sauce over the hotdogs, sprinkle with parmesan cheese and broil until cheese bubbles and the hot dogs are hot.
[[Category:Cheese recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Hot Dog recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Spices and herbs|Spice]] | [[Cookbook:Middle Eastern cuisines|Middle Eastern cuisines]]
'''Baharat''' is typically used in the countries surrounding the Persian Gulf to flavour [[Cookbook:mutton|mutton]] dishes and is said to be the most-used spice in the Arabic cuisine.
==Ingredients== * 6 tbsp [[Cookbook:sweet pepper|sweet pepper]] * 6 tbsp [[Cookbook:Pepper|black pepper]] * 3 tbsp [[Cookbook:cinnamon|cinnamon]] * 3 tbsp [[Cookbook:coriander|coriander]] * 2 tbsp [[Cookbook:cumin|cumin]] * 1 tbsp [[Cookbook:nutmeg|nutmeg]] * 1 tbsp [[Cookbook:cloves|cloves]] * ½ tbsp [[Cookbook:cardamom|cardamom]]
==Procedure== Finely grind the ingredients using a mill. Mix well. To intensify the taste fry the powder in butter before use.
[[Category:Ingredients|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Spice Mix recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{cookwork|This recipe needs measurements and serving size}}
{{recipesummary|Salad recipes||30 minutes|3}}
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Side dishes | Side dishes]]
'''Karedok''' (raw vegetable salad)
== Ingredients ==
* [[Cookbook:Cucumber|cucumber]] * bean sprouts * cabbage, sliced very thin, and delicately * legumes * ''[[Cookbook:Kemangi|kemangi]]'' leaf * [[Cookbook:Eggplant|eggplant]]
=== Dressing ===
* red pepper * garlic * ''cabai rawit'' (a kind of small, hot chili pepper) * greater [[Cookbook:Galingale|galingale]] * peanuts * brackish water * palm sugar * salt * ''terasi'' (condiment made from pounded and fermented shrimp) * hot water
== Procedure ==
# Mix the red peppers, garlic, ''cabai rawit'', greater galingale, peanuts, palm sugar, salt, and the ''terasi''. # Add brackish water and hot water. Mix evenly. # Put all the other ingredients in. Mix until even. # Spread fried shrimp chips on top of it.
[[Category:Indonesian recipes|Karedok]] [[Category:Salad recipes|Karedok]]
[[id:Resep:Karedok]]

{{cookwork|Page should be split}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Scotland|Cuisine of Scotland]]
'''Colcannon''' is a rich mashed potato dish, with cabbage, butter and other ingredients.
This has always been a favorite in my house. It's very easy to make and is a nice change from ordinary mashed potatoes.
This is from an old Scottish recipe still used frequently to this day.
==Ingredients== *[[Cookbook:Potato|Potato]], boiled *[[Cookbook:Cabbage|Cabbage]], boiled *[[Cookbook:Butter|Butter]] *[[Cookbook:Salt|Salt]] *[[Cookbook:Pepper|Pepper]]
==Procedure== #Take equal quantities of [[Cookbook:Potato|potatoes]] and [[Cookbook:Cabbage|cabbage]]. #Mash the potatoes and mince the cabbage. #Melt a piece of [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]] or dripping in a saucepan, allowing approximately one ounce to one pound vegetables. #Put in the potatoes and cabbage, and [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] and [[Cookbook:Pepper|pepper]] to taste. #Mix well, make thoroughly hot and serve.
==Notes, tips, and variations== *The mixture may be turned into a greased pie-dish, sprinkled with grated cheese, dotted with butter or margarine, and browned in a hot oven.
== Irish Original == Colcannon is originally an Irish dish, a very rich and occasional treat. Its sloppiness is balanced by the crunch of the cabbage, and it should taste a little peppery.
'''Ingredients''' *450g spuds - floury maris piper/golden wonders are best; leave skin on if you want *150 ml single cream *mace/paprika *450g shredded cabbage - white or savoy *2 small leeks, or a bunch of spring onion tops, chopped *125g unsalted butter *200g mature gouda cheese grated *salt and pepper
'''Ready, steady....''' *Boil or steam the spuds, until soft, then shake the drained spuds in a deep pot with the lid on, until they crumble. Mash the crumbled spuds up with a fork and season with the salt, pepper and mace/paprika, before stirring in the cream. Add 100g of the butter in pieces and put the lid back on, leaving the butter to melt, before giving a hard stir. Transfer the mix to a deep pyrex bowl.
*Blanch the cabbage in boiling water for 2 mins and drain. Fry the leeks/onion tops in the remaining butter for a few minutes, then add the cabbage and toss around for a few more minutes. Spoon the cabbage into the pyrex bowl and mix with the mashed spuds.
*Stir the gouda in to the mix, leaving a little to coat the top, and put the bowl in an oven on 2/3 heat for 20 mins. - or until the cheese is melted.
The gouda is an innovation - leave it out, if you don't want the dish too rich. The oven heating is ideally done along with the final stage of your roast meat. Seasoning is very important: bear in mind that the cheese has plenty of salt. The perfect colcannon has a butter sogginess at the bottom of the bowl when removed from the oven.
[[Category:Scottish recipes|Colcannon]] [[Category:Irish recipes|Colcannon]] [[Category:Potato recipes|Colcannon]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisines|Cuisines]] | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of China|Cuisine of China]]
The '''century egg''' (a.k.a. preserved egg, thousand-year egg, thousand-year-old egg; Chinese: 皮蛋; pinyin: pídàn or Chinese: 松花蛋; pinyin: sōnghūadàn) is a Chinese delicacy made by preserving duck (or less commonly chicken) eggs in a mixture of charcoal and lime for (despite the name) around 100 days. It is greenish in color, and has a creamy cheese-like flavor and strong aroma.
==Ingredients== *4 Century [[Cookbook:egg|egg]]s *80g [[Cookbook:jinhua ham|jinhua ham]] *80g [[Cookbook:pickled stem ginger|pickled stem ginger]] *320g [[Cookbook:butter|butter]] *1 tablespoon [[Cookbook:oil|oil]]
===Seasoning=== *1/2 teaspoon [[Cookbook:salt|salt]] *1 small bowl of dark [[Cookbook:vinegar|vinegar]] (use for dipping)
== Procedure == #Wash preserved egg clean. Steam for 10 minutes. #Shell the eggs. Cut into 4 parts. Cut the pickled stem ginger into thin slices. #Cut the Jinhua ham into thin slices. Soak in water for a while. #Sandwich a sliced ginger with a sliced ham and a sliced preserved egg. #Leave the preserved egg sandwiches in a dish for later use. #Mix the water, oil, salt, batter well to make pasta. Pour the pasta over the preserved egg sandwiches. #Heat the wok. Pour in dash of oil. Bring the oil to medium heat. Dump in the preserved egg sandwiches. #Fry until preserved egg sandwiches float on the surface. {{wikipedia|Century egg}}
[[Category:Egg recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Ginger recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Ham recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[category:Gluten-free recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{cookwork|This recipe has no procedure}} {{recipesummary|Egg recipes|4|prep: 15 minutes
cooking: 45 minutes|3}} {{recipe}} [[Category:Egg recipes|Egg recipes]] | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Mexico|Cuisine of Mexico]] | [[Cookbook:Breakfast|Breakfast]] '''Huevos Divorciados''', or "Divorced Eggs," is a Mexican breakfast featuring two fried eggs separated by a column of [[Cookbook:Chilaquiles|chilaquiles]]. Typically, one egg is covered in [[Cookbook:Salsa roja|salsa roja]], while the other is covered in [[Cookbook:Salsa Verde|salsa verde]], giving them distinctly different and complementary flavors. ==Ingredients== * 8 ounces plum tomatoes * 8 ounces fresh [[Cookbook:Tomatillo|tomatillos]], rinsed, husks discarded * 2 fresh jalapenos * 1 (1-inch) wedge of a large white onion * 2 cloves [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]] * 2 tsp salt * 3 Tbsp chopped fresh cilantro * 1/4 to 1/2 cup water * 4 to 8 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|Tbsp]] [[Cookbook:Corn oil|corn]] or [[Cookbook:Vegetable oil|vegetable oil]] * 8 large [[Cookbook:egg|egg]]s * Ground [[Cookbook:Black pepper|black pepper]] * 8 (6- to 7-inch) corn tortillas [[Category:Egg recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Mexican recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}}
'''Banana Crème Pie'''
==Ingredients== * 3 or 4 [[Cookbook:banana|banana]]s, sliced * 3/4 [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] [[Cookbook:sugar|sugar]] * 1/3 cup all purpose [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] or *:3 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|Tb]]s [[Cookbook:Cornstarch|cornstarch]] * 1/4 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|tsp]] [[Cookbook:salt|salt]] * 2 cups [[Cookbook:Milk|milk]] * 3 [[Cookbook:egg yolk|egg yolks]], slightly beaten * 2 Tbs [[Cookbook:butter|butter]] * 1 tsp [[Cookbook:vanilla extract|vanilla extract]] * 1 9-[[Cookbook:Inch|inch]] baked [[Cookbook:Flaky Pie Crust|pastry shell]] * [[Cookbook:meringue|meringue]] made from the leftover [[Cookbook:egg white|egg white]]s (optional)
==Procedure== # Combine sugar, cornstarch, and salt in a [[Cookbook:Saucepan|saucepan]]. # Add milk gradually. # Cook, stirring constantly, over medium heat til bubbly. # Cook and stir an additional 2 minutes and remove from burner. # Stir small amount of hot mixture into egg yolks, then immediately add egg yolk mixture to hot mixture and cook for 2 minutes, stirring constantly. # Remove from heat. # Add butter and vanilla and stir til smooth. # Slice 3-4 bananas into the cooled baked pastry shell. # Top with pudding mixture and spread meringue (if desired) on top of the pie. # [[Cookbook:Bake|Bake]] at 350 °F for 12-15 minutes.
Cool before serving.
== Notes, tips, and variations == * Fresh whipped cream can be substituted for meringue after the pie is baked.
== References == * Based on [http://www-2.cs.cmu.edu/~mjw/recipes/pie/sweet/ban-crm-pie.html Recipe Archive: Banana Cream Pie July 1993]
[[Category:Dessert recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Pie recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Banana recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Dairy recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Cake recipes|8 slices|3 hours|4}}
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Germany|German Cuisine]]
'''Black Forest Cake''', sometimes called by the French ''gateau'', ''gateaux'' or ''gâteau'' (meaning "cake"), is a chocolate cake with a strong cherry element, popular throughout North America. The recipe originates from Germany, where it is called '''Schwarzwälder Kirschtorte'''.
== Ingredients ==
=== Cake ===
* 4oz/100g Irish [[Cookbook:butter|butter]] * 8oz /225g [[Cookbook:brown sugar|brown sugar]] * 4oz /100g plain [[Cookbook:chocolate|chocolate]] * 7oz /200g [[Cookbook:self-raising flour|self-raising flour]] * 1/4 teaspoon ground [[Cookbook:cinnamon|cinnamon]] * 1/4 pint [[Cookbook:Sour Cream|sour cream]] * 3 tablespoons strong cold black [[Cookbook:coffee|coffee]] * 2 [[Cookbook:egg|egg]]s * pinch of [[Cookbook:salt|salt]]
=== Pastry base ===
* 4oz/100g [[Cookbook:cream flour|cream flour]] * pinch of [[Cookbook:salt|salt]] * 2oz /50g [[Cookbook:Powdered Sugar|icing sugar]] * 2 oz/50g Irish [[Cookbook:butter|butter]] * 1 [[Cookbook:egg yolk|egg yolk]] * a few drops of [[Cookbook:Vanilla|vanilla essence]]
=== Misc. ===
* 1 pint [[Cookbook:cream|cream]] * 1-lb tin black [[Cookbook:cherry|cherries]] * 4 tablespoons [[Cookbook:black cherry jam|black cherry jam]] * [[Cookbook:brandy|brandy]] or [[Cookbook:cherry juice|cherry juice]] * 4oz/100g grated [[Cookbook:chocolate|chocolate]]
== Procedure ==
=== Cake ===
# [[Cookbook:Creaming|Cream]] the butter and sugar together well. # Melt the chocolate and beat into the creamed mixture, then mix in the eggs. # Sift flour, salt and cinnamon together. # Fold the dry mix lightly into the liquids, then fold in the sour cream and cold coffee. # Pour the mixture into a lined and greased 9-inch round, deep tin,and bake for 1 hour and 25 minutes. # Set to cool on a wire rack.
=== Pastry base ===
# Mix all the ingredients together in a bowl and bind until the mixture stiffens. # Roll the pastry onto a floured board worktable until pastry is about the same size as the base of the tin. # Lay out on baking sheet and bake for 20-25 minutes.
=== Assembly ===
# Whip cream until it holds its shape. # Put some whipped cream into pastry piping bag with a star pipe attached, and reserve this for the decoration. # Slice the cake into 3 equal-sized layers. # Drain the cherries, reserve 8 for decoration and remove the stones from the remainder. # Put pastry on serving plate and spread the pastry with black cherry jam. # Soak the cakes with spirit. # Put one layer of cake on top of coated pastry. # Spread a layer of cream with half the stoned cherries. # Put the second layer of cake and add another layer of cream and cherries. # Add the final layer of the cake. # Cover the entire cake with the remaining cream and press on the grated chocolate. Decorate the top with piped rosettes of cream and the reserved whole black cherries.
== Notes, tips and variations ==
* Using 3 identical cake pans instead of 1 large one is acceptable.
* Margarine, vegetable oil or regular butter will substitute for Irish butter.
* In some countries (e.g. Austria and Australia) the brandy is often replaced by rum, in Germany itself it is almost always replaced by Kirschwasser.
* '''This did not come with a temperature to bake at for either the pastry or cake.''' Cakes usually work at between 325°F and 400°F (160°C and 205°C). Pastries usually work at between 350°F and 425°F (175°C and 220°C).
[[Category:Dessert recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Cake recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}}
== Ingredients == *1 lb [[Cookbook:Ground Beef|ground beef]] *1 tsp [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] *1 tsp [[Cookbook:Pepper|black pepper]] *1 tsp [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]] powder *1 tsp [[Cookbook:Cayenne Pepper|cayenne pepper]] *about 1/2 cup [[Cookbook:Feta Cheese|feta cheese]]
== Procedure == # Mix spices into beef, using hands, until well-mixed. # Form eight small balls of meat, then press into very flat [[Cookbook:Pancake|pancake]] shapes. # Top four with about 2 tbsp. crumbled feta cheese, then cover with the other four. # Press together firmly to flatten, then crimp edges tightly to make four [[Cookbook:Burger|burger]]s. # Chill. # Cook as regular burgers in a [[Cookbook:Skillet|skillet]] or on the [[Cookbook:Grill|grill]]. Handle gently to avoid crumbling.
Serve on toasted white or [[Cookbook:Rye|rye]] [[Cookbook:Bread|bread]] with spicy [[Cookbook:Mustard|mustard]].
Makes four burgers.
== Notes, tips and variations == * Any other [[Cookbook:Cheese|cheese]] that doesn’t melt easily can be substituted for feta in this recipe. Some possibilities are [[Cookbook:Parmesan Cheese|parmesan]], [[Cookbook:Swiss Cheese|Swiss]], and [[Cookbook:Jarlsberg Cheese|Jarlsberg]]. If you use a cheese that melts and becomes runny, however, it will all drip out. * If you plan to grill the burgers, you can opt to mix the feta in with the beef and simply treat as regular burgers. Don’t try this on a skillet, however, as the cheese will stick and burn.
[[Category:Cheese recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Beef recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}}
A small simple corn [[Cookbook:Cake|cake]], similar to a [[Cookbook:Johnnycake|johnnycake]], originally cooked in ashes, and introduced to early European settlers by indigenous Americans. Also known as "corn pone" in the the Southern United States.
==Ingredients== * 1 [[Cookbook:Quart|qt]] [[Cookbook:Water|water]] * [[Cookbook:Cornmeal|Indian meal (cornmeal)]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Ounce|oz]] [[Cookbook:butter|butter]] * [[Cookbook:salt|salt]] (optional)
==Procedure== # Put on the water in a pot, and as soon as it [[Cookbook:Boiling|boil]]s stir in as much cornmeal as will make a very thin [[Cookbook:Batter|batter]]. # Beat it frequently while it is boiling, which will require ten minutes; then take it off, pour it in a pan, and add the butter, and salt to taste. # When the batter is [[Wikipedia:luke-warm|luke-warm]] stir in as much Indian meal as will make it quite thick. # Let rise overnight. # Pat the dough out into small cakes. # Butter a baking tin and bake in a moderate oven '''or''' butter a cake pan, fill it 3/4 full, and bake.
== Notes, tips and variations == * This recipe did not originally have an oven temperature; 350 degrees Fahrenheit is probably safe.
==References== * {{1881}} * [http://www.etymonline.com/index.php?term=pone "pone" etymology]
[[Category:Corn recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Native American recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Bread recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

revision.text:
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Meat Recipes|Meat Recipes]]
==Ingredients== * 1.5 [[Cookbook:kg|kg]] leg of [[Cookbook:Lamb|lamb]] or other tender cut * 1 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|tsp]] [[Cookbook:Nutmeg|nutmeg]] * 1 tsp [[Cookbook:Cinnamon|cinnamon]] * 1 tsp [[Cookbook:Cardamon|cardamon]] * 3 cloves of [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]] * 1 tsp [[Cookbook:Black Pepper|black pepper]] * 1 tsp [[Cookbook:Cayenne Pepper|cayenne pepper]] * 1/2 [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] [[Cookbook:Lemon|lemon]] * 1/4 cup of [[Cookbook:Vinegar|vinegar]]
==Procedure== #Cut the lamb into large 4[[Cookbook:cm|cm]] chunks. #Combine the nutmeg, cinnamon, cardamom, garlic cloves, black pepper, cayenne pepper, lemon, and vinegar to a small mixing bowl and pour over meat. #[[Cookbook:Marinade|Marinade]] for 2 hours or more. #[[Cookbook:Chop|Chop]] up 2 [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]]s. Grill the onions with some [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]] for few minutes. #Then drain meat, pat meat dry and grill till golden brown.
Serve with [[Cookbook:Pita Bread|pita bread]], [[Cookbook:Tomato|tomato]], fresh onion, [[Cookbook:Tabouleh|tabouleh]], [[Cookbook:Tzatziki|tzatziki]], [[Cookbook:Lettuce|lettuce]] and [[Cookbook:Chili|chili]] sauce.
[[Category:Lamb recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] EAT AND ENJOY!

{{cookwork}} {{recipe}}
'''Calabash noodle soup''' ([[Chinese]]: 葫蘆麵 or 葫子麵) is a [[Cookbook:Cuisine of China|Chinese]] dish composed of cooked [[Cookbook:Calabash|calabash]], shredded meat, noodles, and soup.
== Ingredients == * [[Cookbook:Calabash|Calabash]] * [[Cookbook:Pork|Pork]] tenderloin * [[Cookbook:Soy Sauce|Soy sauce]] * [[Cookbook:Cornstarch|Cornstarch]] * [[Cookbook:Sugar|Sugar]] * [[Cookbook:Garlic|Garlic]] * [[Cookbook:Stock|Stock]] * [[Cookbook:Water|Water]] * 2 [[Cookbook:Eggs|Eggs]]
== Procedure ==
# Peel the calabash and cut into finger-sized strips. # Cut the pork tenderloin meat into tiny strips. # Marinate the meat with corn starch, soy sauce, and sugar. # In a [[Cookbook:Wok|wok]], stir-fry the meat until it is slightly brown. Remove the meat from the wok. # In the wok, stir-fry the calabash strips and garlic for a couple of minutes. # Place the meat back into the wok and add soup stock, soy sauce, and water. # Simmer for a couple of minutes until the calabash strips look tender. # Crack two eggs and pour the white and the yolk into the soup.
Serve the soup with noodles.
[[Category:Chinese recipes]] [[Category:Pork recipes]] [[Category:Calabash recipes]]

{{recipe}}
{{recipesummary| | Category = Muffin recipes | Servings = 12 | Time = 20 | Rating = 2 | Energy = | Image = [[Image:Blueberry muffins.jpg|300px]] }}
'''Blueberry muffins''' are a pastry common in many parts of the world.
==Ingredents== * 1¾ cups (420g) [[Cookbook:flour|flour]] * ⅓ cup (160ml) [[Cookbook:sugar|sugar]] * 2 teaspoons [[Cookbook:baking powder|baking powder]] * ¼ teaspoon [[Cookbook:salt|salt]] * 1 [[Cookbook:egg|egg]]s, [[Cookbook:beat|beat]]en * ¾ cup (180ml) [[Cookbook:milk|milk]] * ¼ cup (60ml) cooking [[Cookbook:oil|oil]] * ¾ cup (180ml) [[Cookbook:Blueberry|blueberries]], fresh or frozen
==Procedure== #Grease muffin cups or line with paper cups; set aside. #Preheat the oven to 400°F (200c). #In a medium bowl, combine flour, sugar, baking powder, and salt. Make a well in the center of the mixture and set aside. #In a small bowl, combine beaten egg, milk, and oil. Add this mixture all at once to the flour mixture. Fold in blueberries and stir just until combined. Do not overstir. #Spoon batter into prepared cups, filling each about two-thirds. #Bake for 18 to 20 minutes or until golden. When a wooden toothpick is inserted near the middle, it should come out clean. #Remove from muffin cups and let cool on a wire rack for 5 minutes.
==Notes and Tips== *The mixture should be lumpy after stirring. Otherwise, the muffins will be tough. *Leaving the muffins in the muffin cups can make them soggy. *To make jumbo muffins, reduce the temperature to 350° (180c) and bake for 30 minutes. *To make mini muffins, bake for about 10 minutes at 400° (200c)
[[Category:Blueberry recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Muffin recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Recipes_with_metric_units|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Dessert recipes||55 - 60 minutes|3}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Desserts|Desserts]]
A delicious pudding dish.
==Ingredients== * 3 [[Cookbook:egg|eggs]] * ¼ [[Cookbook:pint|pint]] [[Cookbook:milk|milk]] * 2 [[Cookbook:ounce|ounces]] moist [[Cookbook:sugar|sugar]] * 2 [[Cookbook:ounce|ounces]] grated [[Cookbook:nutmeg|nutmeg]] * 4 [[Cookbook:ounce|ounces]] [[Cookbook:flour|flour]] * 8 [[Cookbook:ounce|ounces]] finely chopped [[Cookbook:suet|suet]] * 3 [[Cookbook:ounce|ounces]] [[Cookbook:bread|breadcrumbs]]
==Method== *Beat the eggs, strain them through a [[Cookbook:sieve|sieve]], gradually add them to the milk. Stir. *Mix in the sugar and nutmeg. Stir. *Add the flour, beating the mixture until it becomes a smooth batter. *Gradually add suet and bread-crumbs. Mix all thoroughly together, at least half an hour before putting the pudding into a pot. *Put it into a buttered mould. Cook for 50 minutes at 350°F.
{{1881}} [[Category:Pudding and Custard recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Dairy recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United Kingdom|Cuisine of the United Kingdom]] | [[Cookbook:Dessert|Dessert]] | [[Cookbook:Rhubarb|Rhubarb]]
'''Rhubarb crumble''' is a traditional [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United Kingdom|British]] [[Cookbook:Dessert|dessert]]. Served with [[Cookbook:Custard|custard]], [[Cookbook:Cream|cream]] or [[Cookbook:Vanilla Ice Cream|ice cream]] it is a hearty, filling, and warm feast, best served after a light meal.
==Ingredients==
*1 [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] [[Cookbook:Brown sugar|brown sugar]] *3/4 cup [[Cookbook:Oats|oat]]s *1 cup [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] *1/2 cup [[Cookbook:butter|butter]] *1 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tsp]] [[Cookbook:Cinnamon|cinnamon]] *4 cup uncooked cut up [[Cookbook:Rhubarb|rhubarb]] *1 cup [[Cookbook:White Sugar|white sugar]] *2 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tbsp]] [[Cookbook:Corn Starch|corn starch]]/cornflour *1 cup [[Cookbook:Water|water]] *1 tsp. [[Cookbook:Vanilla|vanilla]]
==Method== #Mix brown sugar, oats, flour, butter and cinnamon until crumbly. #Press 1/2 of mixture into a 9 inch square pan. # Cover crumb mixture with cut up rhubarb. # Mix white sugar, cornstarch and water. Cook until clear and thick, [[Cookbook:Stirring|stirring]] constantly. Add vanilla and stir. # Pour over rhubarb. Sprinkle with remaining crumb mixture over the top. # [[Cookbook:Baking|Bake]] for 1 hour at 180°[[Cookbook:Celsius|C]].
==Alternative method== Many cooks use cold butter and rub the fat into the dry ingredients. It is also common not to have a crumble layer on the bottom, just on top of the rhubarb. Finally the cornstarch sauce is frequently omitted. Raw rhubarb and sugar alone are used. The rhubarb juice acts as a sufficient sauce.
[[Category:Rhubarb recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:English recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Crumble recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Dessert recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Duplicate recipes]]

{{recipesummary|Muffin recipes|12 muffins|prep: 15 minutes
baking: 15–20 minutes|2}} {{recipe}} ==Ingredients== * 400g (2 [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]]s) self-raising [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] * 60g [[Cookbook:butter|butter]] * 120g (1/2 cup) [[Cookbook:sugar|sugar]] * 12[[Wikipedia:centiliter|cL]] (1/2 cup) milk [[Cookbook:Chocolate|chocolate]] chips * 12cL (1/2 cup) [[Cookbook:Chocolate|white chocolate]] chips * 2 [[Cookbook:egg|egg]]s, beaten lightly * 12cL (1/2 cup) [[Cookbook:Milk|milk]] * 12cL (1/2 cup) [[Cookbook:Orange|orange]] juice * 15mL (1 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|T]]) orange rind ==Procedure== # Preheat oven to 220°C (350°F). # Sift flour onto bowl, rub in butter. # Add sugar, chocolate bits, eggs, milk, orange juice, and orange rind. # Mix well. # Spoon heaped tablespoons of mixture into greased muffin pans. # Bake for 15–20 minutes until cooked when tasted. [[Category:Chocolate recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Muffin recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Orange recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Recipes_with_metric_units|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{cookwork|Needs measurements}} {{recipe}} '''Lettuce Soup''' (Zuppa d' Erbe)
==Ingredients== * [[Cookbook:stock|stock]] * 2 bunches of [[Cookbook:sorrel|sorrel]]s, washed and cut up * 1 bunch of [[Cookbook:endive|endive]], washed and cut up * 1 head of [[Cookbook:lettuce|lettuce]], washed and cut up * 1 small bunch of [[Cookbook:chervil|chervil]], washed and cut up * 1 stick of [[Cookbook:celery|celery]],washed and cut up * 1 [[Cookbook:carrot|carrot]], washed and cut up * 1 [[Cookbook:onion|onion]], peeled and cut up * Sliced French roll, toasted * [[Cookbook:Cheese|Parmesan cheese]], grated
==Procedure== #Boil everything except for the French roll and the cheese in very good stock for an hour. #Put some slices of toasted French roll into a bowl and pour the soup over them. #Serve with grated Parmesan.
{{decameron}}
[[Category:Soup recipes|Lettuce soup]]

{{recipe}}
This is a recipe made up by a Mexican who has eaten this dish hundreds if not thousands of times throughout his lifetime. Growing up with a single mother, from a remote part of Jalisco, Mexico, who made this dish as a quick meal, one can appreciate the simplicity of this dish. A lot of what goes into the making of this dish is up to your own taste: how much and what kind of cheese for example, or what type of chili sauce is used (i.e. green or red and the intensity of its heat level). The three main components of this dish include: deep fried tortilla strips, some sort of chili sauce and a good serving of cheese that is crumbled over the finished dish towards the end. In addition, one can add any number of extra ingredients to his or her own delight. The following recipe is quite common in most of Mexico as a breakfast item, due to the addition of eggs, but is also eaten throughout the day including during dinner time. Remember, keep it simple and tasty. You definately don't need to bake this dish, it never is in Mexico (except for a variant of this dish called Pastel Azteca which is considerably more elaborate). I've included an additional recipe for a ''salsa de chile de arbol'' that will be used as the primary sauce. It's a little spicy and may take some time to prepare but is well worth the extra effort. The following recipe is intended as a single serving, adjust the ingredients exponentially to make larger quantities.
= Ingredients = * Vegetable Oil (enough to cover the tortillas to deep fry them) * 2 Corn Tortillas cut into strips and then into squares (preferably day old) * 1 large Egg * 1/4 of an Onion diced (white onion is mainly used in Mexican cooking)
* '''Salsa de Chile de Arbol''' * 1 cup of Tomatillos, husks taken off and roasted (these are found extensively in most Mexican groceries and are somewhat common in larger urban supermarkets) * 4 to 6 dried Chiles de Arbol roasted (these are quite hot and you should adjust to your liking) * 1 roasted Garlic * 1/2 cup of Water * Salt and Pepper to taste
* crumbled or shredded Cheese (you can use anything that melts well, i like to use monterey jack or manchego, however you can utilize your favorite cheese for this recipe)
== Procedure ==
# Begin by making the ''Salsa de Chile de Arbol'': roast the tomatillos by wrapping them in heavy duty aluminum foil and placing them on a comal over your stovetop (this does not need to be done in the oven, it never is in Mexico). After roasting the tomatillos for approximately 15 to 20 minutes you can pull them off the fire and roast the dried chilies and garlic directly on the comal (caution, the dried chilies will roast in less than a minute while the garlic will take longer). Combine the roasted tomatillos, chilies and garlic along with the water, salt and pepper in a blender. Liquify the mixture thoroughly for a few minutes to insure that the sauce is smooth and consistent with no large pieces left floating around. You will probably end up with more salsa than you need for this recipe. Use it as a condiment for any other of your favorite Mexican dishes! # Next, heat the vegetable oil in a frying pan until it is hot enough so that when you drop the pieces of tortillas into it they immediately begin to fry at a rapid pace. # Allow the tortillas to fry until they become a chestnut brown, just not too dark or burnt. At this point, drain most of the oil out of the pan leaving only enough to fry the rest of the ingredients. # Crack the egg into the fried tortillas and scramble it, folding the fried tortilla strips into the egg. At this point season this mixture with salt and pepper if desired. Take this mixture out of the pan and let it rest on a plate while you continue with the rest of the dish. # Add some of the oil that was taken out of the pan earlier back into it and heat it up again. To this add the diced onion and allow it to soften for a few minutes. Add the ''Salsa de Chile de Arbol'' to the oil and onions and saute it for a minute or two. Add a little bit of water to dilute it if it becomes too thick. # Finally, return the fried tortilla and egg mixture to the onion and chili sauce in the pan and allow it cook only for about a minute, enough time to allow the tortillas to soak up some of the sauce. Before plating it, add the cheese and enjoy!
[[Category:Chile recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]
Variations
In Mexico, very rarely is this dish made with tortilla chips but rather day-old tortillas that have stiffened. If you don't have day-old tortillas you can leave out fresh tortillas until they are stiff to get the right texture. The recipe for the chili sauce used in this recipe is of course a red sauce. If you prefer a green sauce, simply subsitute the chiles de arbol for fresh jalapeno chilies that you can also roast in the same way. After you have roasted the chilies on the comal and thoroughly burnt the skins, place the chilies in a plastic bag with a small amount of water so as to allow them to steam. After about 5 minutes, remove the jalapenos from the bag and simply rub the skin off of them. Continue to make the sauce as indicated above.
Also this dish can be made with strips of chicken in addition to or as a replacement for the egg. In Mexico chilaquiles are often served throughout the day and as such the addition of chicken strips will complement it as a dinner item. Using all the same ingredients just add some warmed and shredded chicken meat during the last step before you add the cheese. Often times, my mother would add a little bit of mexican cream (somewhat like sour cream but more akin to creme fraiche) over the top of the chilaquiles right before we enjoyed them on our serving plate as a way to tone down the spicy heat of the dish.
Retrieved from "http://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Chilaquiles

{{recipe}}
An '''oatcake''' is a type of [[Cookbook:Pancake|pancake]] made from [[Cookbook:Oatmeal|oatmeal]], cooked on a [[Cookbook:Griddle|griddle]].
==North Staffordshire Oatcakes== North Staffordshire oatcakes are a local delicacy in the North [[w:Staffordshire|Staffordshire]] ([[w:Stoke-on-Trent|Stoke-on-Trent]]) area of [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United Kingdom|England]], and so may be known to non-locals as a ''North Staffordshire oatcake'' or ''Potteries oatcake''. These use [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] and [[Cookbook:Yeast|yeast]], whereas other oatcakes do not. When pre-cooked, they are a form of fast food, and catering outlets in the area usually offer oatcakes with fillings such as [[Cookbook:Cheese|cheese]], [[Cookbook:Bacon|bacon]], [[Cookbook:Sausage|sausage]] and [[Cookbook:Egg|egg]]. They can be re-heated by [[Cookbook:Frying|frying]] in butter, or by [[Cookbook:Grilling|grilling]]. In addition, [[Cookbook:Pikelet|pikelets]] are often served alongside oatcakes in a similar fashion.
=== Ingredients === * 8oz fine oatmeal * 8oz wholewheat or plain flour * 1 teaspoon salt * 1/2oz fresh yeast * 1 1/2 pints warm milk and water, mixed half and half * 1 teaspoon sugar
=== Procedure === # Add the salt to the flour and oatmeal. # Dissolve the yeast with a little warm liquid and add the sugar. Allow the mixture to become frothy. # Mix the dry ingredients with the yeast liquid to make a batter. # Cover the batter with a clean cloth and leave it in a warm place for an hour. # Bake the oatcake on a well-greased griddle. Put enough batter onto the griddle to produce an oatcake about 8-9 inches in diameter. The surface will be covered in holes as it cooks. # Turn the oatcake after 2 - 3 minutes when the upper side appears dry and the underneath is golden brown, and cook for another 2 - 3 minutes.
[[Category:Pancake recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:English recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Oat recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{cookwork}} {{recipe}}
==Ingredients== *1/4 pound of forcemeat of fowl *1 tablespoon of [[Cookbook:flour|potato flour]] *1 tablespoon of [[Cookbook:Bechamel sauce|Bechamel sauce]] (No. 3) *1 yolk of an [[Cookbook:egg|egg]] *[[Cookbook:Pea|Pea]]s *[[Cookbook:Asparagus|Asparagus]] *[[Cookbook:Spinach|Spinach]] *[[Cookbook:Clear soup|Clear soup]]
==Procedure== #Mix the fowl with potato flour, Bechamel sauce (No. 3), and the yolk. #Put this into a tube about the size round of an ordinary [[Cookbook:macaroni|macaroni]]. #Twenty minutes before serving, squirt the forcemeat into a saucepan with boiling [[Cookbook:stock|stock]], and nip off the forcemeat as it comes through the pipe into pieces about an inch and a half long. #Let it [[Cookbook:simmer|simmer]], and add boiled peas and asparagus tips. #If you like to have the fowl macaroni white and green, you can color half the forcemeat with a spoonful of spinach colouring. #Serve in a good clear soup.
{{decameron}} [[Category:Italian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Soup recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

revision.text:
__NOTOC__{{recipe}}
A vegetable pie using tomatoes, aubergines (eggplant), onions, and mushrooms. You can make vegetable pie with many kinds of vegetables.
== Ingredients == === Crust === For 4 or 5 persons, here are the ingredients:
* 250 g (1 cup) of [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] * 100 g (0.4 cups) of medium soft [[Cookbook:butter|butter]] (leave it out for a half-hour before making the crust) * 1 [[Cookbook:egg|egg]] * some lukewarm water * a pinch of [[Cookbook:salt|salt]]
=== Filling === *1 or 2 [[Cookbook:Eggplant|aubergine]]s (eggplants) *1 or 2 [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]]s *4 [[Cookbook:Tomato|tomato]]es *150 g (0.6 cups) of [[Cookbook:Mushroom|mushroom]]s *some grated [[Cookbook:Cheese|cheese]] *some [[Cookbook:Milk|milk]] *an [[Cookbook:egg|egg]] yolk *near the end, some fresh [[Cookbook:Cream|cream]]
== Procedure == === Crust === # Pour the flour into a large bowl. # Add the portions of butter. # Knead everything until the pastry is nearly consistent. # Add the egg, then some water bit by bit while working the pastry with your hands until it becomes soft and smooth. # It should not be sticky, and it should look shiny and medium yellow.
=== Filling === # Cut the vegetables into thin slices. # Brown the vegetables in oil or butter, or you may steam them. # Begin with the onions and aubergines (eggplant), then the mushrooms. # Keep the tomatoes raw.
=== Putting it together === # Butter the pie pan and shape the pastry into the pan. # Pre-heat the crust for about 10 minutes at medium heat after making small holes in the base of the pan. # So the pastry does not swell up, place some aluminum foil in a curved shape over the pastry. # Once the pastry is precooked take it out of the oven and arrange the cooked vegetables over the crust in whatever arrangement pleases you. # In a bowl, mix the egg yolk with some milk and a bit of fresh cream, then pour the mixture on top of the vegetables. # Cover with grated cheese. # Cook for 15 to 20 minutes at medium heat.
[[Category:Pot Pie recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetable recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{cookwork|Recipe needs measurements.}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Soups|Soups]] Venetian Soup ==Ingredients:== [[Cookbook:Soup|Clear soup]],
[[Cookbook:butter|butter]],
[[Cookbook:Flour|flour]],
[[Cookbook:Cheese|Parmesan cheese]],
[[Cookbook:egg|egg]]s.
==Procedure== Make a [[Cookbook:Roux|roux]] by frying two ounces of butter and two ounces of flour, add an ounce of grated [[Cookbook:Cheese|cheese]] and half a cup of good [[Cookbook:Soup|stock]]. Mix up well so as to form a paste, and then take it off the fire and add the [[Cookbook:egg|yolk]]s of four eggs, mix again and form the paste into little [[Cookbook:Quenelle|quenelle]]s. Boil these in a little soup, strain off, put them into the tureen and pour a good clear soup over them. {{decameron}} [[Category:Soup recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Egg recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}}
A refreshing topping for carbohydrate and meat-style foods. The [[:Category:South American recipes|South American]] equivalent of [[Cookbook:Salsa|salsa]]. Sarza Criolla goes well on [[Cookbook:Toast|toast]], slabs of boiled potatoes, [[Cookbook:Seafood|seafood]], [[Cookbook:Meat|meat]], [[Cookbook:Rice|rice]], [[Cookbook:Tamales|tamales]], and [[Cookbook:Quesadilla|quesadillas]].
== Ingredients == * 1 [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Lime|lime]] * chopped [[Cookbook:Cilantro|cilantro]] (optional) * chopped boiled [[Cookbook:Potato|potatoes]] (optional) * chopped boiled or pickled [[Cookbook:Beet|beets]] (optional) * chopped (not mashed) [[Cookbook:Avocado|avocado]] (optional)
==Procedure== # Cleave the onion from top to bottom, along the grain, then slice it fine across the grain, forming half-rings. # Rinse in cold water, soak in cold water for around 5 minutes, and rinse again. This procedure washes away the contents of the plant cells destroyed by the knife, taking the sting out of the onion's flavor. # Squeeze over it the juice of the lime. # Optionally toss in the cilantro, potatoes, beets, or avocado.
[[Category:Onion recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Lime recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Sauce recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:South American recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Beet recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Avocado recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Potato recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Cilantro recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Cookie recipes|Makes about a dozen and a half|½ hour|1}} {{recipe}}
'''Peanut Butter Cookies''' are one of the most popular kinds of cookies.
== Ingredients ==
[[Image:2006-June-26-Peanut-Butter-Cookies-Cooked.JPG|thumb|right|180px|Peanut butter cookies from the alternate recipe, made with chunky peanut butter.]]
* 1/2 cup of [[Cookbook:peanut butter|peanut butter]] * 1/2 cup of [[Cookbook:granulated sugar|granulated sugar]] * 1/2 cup of [[Cookbook:brown sugar|brown sugar]] * 1/2 cup of [[Cookbook:butter|butter]] or [[Cookbook:margarine|margarine]], melted * 1 [[Cookbook:egg|egg]] * 1/2 teaspoon of [[Cookbook:vanilla|vanilla]] * 1 1/4 cup of [[Cookbook:flour|all-purpose flour]] * 1/4 teaspoon of [[Cookbook:salt|salt]] * 3/4 teaspoon of [[Cookbook:baking soda|baking soda]]
== Procedure ==
# Start by preheating oven to [[Cookbook:Oven_Temperature|375° F]]. # Cream together sugars, melted butter, egg, and vanilla until creamy and smooth. If you're low on brown sugar, seek tip section below. # Combine flour, peanut butter, salt, and baking soda in the mixture from step 2. # After mixture is complete, flatten small pieces into cookie shapes with a fork and place on ungreased cooking pan at least 2 inches apart. # Bake in oven for 8-10 minutes, or until golden brown. # Pull out of oven and allow to cool.
== Notes, tips and variations ==
* If low on brown sugar, combine white sugar and 1 tablespoon of molasses together. * To give a sparkly look, dip cookie in step 4 on a small saucer sprinkled with sugar. * Smooth peanut butter works much better than chunky. * To flatten with a fork, press the tines of the fork across the cookie and then repeat going in the other direction to give a crisscross pattern. * For the alternate recipe (see below), you can use peanut oil instead of vegetable oil.
== Alternate Recipe ==
[[Image:2006-June-26-Peanut-Butter-Cookies-Uncooked.JPG|thumb|right|200px|In the process of being flattened by fork.]]
This recipe has no egg or baking soda, and uses vegetable oil instead of butter / margarine; it adds honey.
==Ingredients:==
* 1/2 cup peanut butter * 1/4 cup [[Cookbook:honey|honey]] * 1/4 teaspoon salt * 1/4 cup [[Cookbook:oil|vegetable oil]] (see tip above) * 1/4 cup brown sugar (or white sugar and molasses, as above) * 1 teaspoon vanilla * 1 1/4 cup whole wheat pastry flour (other flours likely work fine)
==Procedure:==
# Preheat oven to 375ºF # Cream all ingredients except flour together. # Add flour and mix sparingly (should be dry enough to form into balls by hand without sticking). # Form into walnut-sized balls and place on ungreased cookie sheet. # Flatten with fork (see tip above). # Bake for about 8-10 minutes.
A double recipe makes about seventy 1 1/2" cookies.
[[Category:Dessert recipes|Peanut Butter Cookies]] [[Category:Cookie recipes|Peanut Butter Cookies]] [[Category:Peanut Butter recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}}
==Ingredients== * 1 T [[Cookbook:Matzo|matzo meal]] * 2 [[Cookbook:Eggs|eggs]] * 1 T [[Cookbook:Cornstarch|fecula]]
==Procedure== # Whip the egg whites # Add the yolks # Add the matzo and fecula # Mix everything # Cook like an [[Cookbook:Omelette|omelette]]
When its cooked, sprinkle [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] and serve
== Notes, tips and variations == * Before sprinkling the sugar, cut into small squares, so it can be eaten with your fingers. * Goes well with [[Cookbook:Maple Syrup|maple syrup]]
[[Category:Jewish recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Breakfast recipes|About 4|30 minutes|2}}
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Breakfast|Breakfast]]
Biscuits & Gravy is a dish enjoyed nearly everywhere in the United States, though it is most commonly associated with the southern states. It is a staple breakfast of most US [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diner diners].
This recipe makes about 4 servings, and relies on this [[Cookbook:Biscuit|biscuit recipe]]. ==Ingredients== *1 [[Cookbook:Pound|lb]] (500 [[Cookbook:g|g]]) Ground [[Cookbook:Sausage|Breakfast Sausage]] *3 [[Cookbook:Table_spoon|T]] (15 [[Cookbook:mL|mL]]) [[Cookbook:Bacon|Bacon]] grease *1/4 [[Cookbook:Cup|c]] (60 mL) [[Cookbook:Flour|Flour]] *3 c (720 mL) [[Cookbook:Milk|Milk]] *1/2 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|tsp.]](2.5 mL) [[Cookbook:Salt|Salt]] *1/4 tsp. (1.25 mL) Ground [[Cookbook:Pepper|Black Pepper]] ==Procedure== '''Biscuits''' #Make [[Cookbook:Biscuit|'cut' biscuit]] dough. #Place the cut biscuits in the oven at the same time as step 3 of the gravy procedure. #Remove from oven after 10 to 12 minutes; the biscuits should be warm when served with the gravy. '''Gravy''' #Brown the sausage in a large skillet. #Remove the browned sausage from the skillet and reserve in a bowl, be careful to leave as much of the drippings as possible in the pan. #Add the bacon grease to the skillet, place the skillet on low to medium-low heat. #Once the bacon grease is up to temperature mix the flour into the grease. #Add the milk slowly, mixing as you pour. #Bring to a gentle boil, stir constantly scraping the bottom and edges of the skillet. Stirring keeps the gravy from becoming too lumpy or burnt. #Continue stirring until the gravy has nearly reached the desired consistency, usually about 10 minutes. #Add the browned sausage held in reserve. #Remove from heat and allow to set for 1 minute.
==Serving== Traditionally this breakfast is served on a plate. A common serving is two biscuits, each halved, insides face up, covered in gravy. Common side dishes are strips of bacon, hash browns, or grits.
[[Category:Breakfast recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Southern recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}}
'''Mother-In-Law's Milk''', or '''Latte di Suocera'''
La Suocera is as proverbial in [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Italy|Italy]] as she is anywhere else, and Italians (especially daughters-in-law) have come up with all sorts of ways to keep them content; one of the most popular items in candy stands at fairs is ''addormenta suocere'', candied nuts that supposedly send mothers-in-law off into a deep sleep (my mother-in-law simply enjoys them). Those who like to make liqueurs at home can also try this milk.
It will be a nice after dinner drink -- so nice I'd probably drink more than I gave my Suocera -- and will also work very well over vanilla ice cream.
==Ingredients==
* 1 1/8 pounds (500 g, or 2 1/8 cups) [[Cookbook:sugar|sugar]] * 1 pint (500 ml) whole [[Cookbook:milk|milk]] * 1 pint (500 ml) grain [[Cookbook:alcohol|alcohol]] * grated zest of an organically grown [[Cookbook:lemon|lemon]] * 1/2 [[Cookbook:vanilla|vanilla]] bean, split lengthwise
==Procedure== #Combine all the ingredients in a wide-mouthed jar, screw the lid on tightly, #give them a good shake, and #put the jar in a dark place. #Shake it once a day for 8 days, and then #filter it and bottle it. #Stopper the bottle, put it in a cool dark place, and let it rest for a month before you open it.
[[Category:Italian recipes|Latte di Suocera]] [[Category:Beverage recipes|Latte di Suocera]] [[Category:Dairy recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vanilla recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

revision.text:
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Peru|Cuisine of Peru]] | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Chile|Cuisine of Chile]]
==Ingredients (for 5 people)== [[Image:Peru Anticuchos.jpg|250px|thumb|right|Anticuchos accompanied by lettuce,potato and corn-on-the-cob]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Beef heart|Beef heart]] * 2 cloves of [[Cookbook:garlic|garlic]] * ¼ of a cup ground spicy [[Cookbook:chili peppers|red chili]] * 2 cups of [[Cookbook:brown vinegar|brown vinegar]] * 1 teaspoon of ground [[Cookbook:cumin|cumin]] * 1 teaspoon of achiote ([[Cookbook:annatto|annatto]]) * 1 teaspoon of [[Cookbook:salt|salt]] * 1 teaspoon of ground [[Cookbook:black pepper|black pepper]]
==Preparation== #Place all the above ingredients, other than the heart, in a bowl and mix thoroughly. #Clean the heart, removing all fat. Cut into bite size cubes. Place the heart pieces into the marinade mixture and leave to marinate for about 10 hours or overnight. The heart should be completely covered. #After marinating, insert meat on skewers. At this stage if desired , some additional ingredients such as green pepper or red pepper (capsicum) or corn-on-cob (cut to a similar size to the heart, may be also inserted on the skewers.) #The skewered heart should then be cooked on a barbecue grill, turning frequently and brushing with the marinade mix. When they are well done they should be served immediately.
==Description / variations==
Anticuchos, is one of the most popular dishes in Peru. It is often sold by street vendors and accompanied by corn-on-the-cob and portions of cold boiled potato with a spot of chili sauce. Those whose tastes do not extend to trying beef heart may substitute any good cut of red meat, though this is not the authentic Peruvian style.
[[Category:Chilean recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Peruvian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Beef recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[category:Gluten-free recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]
[[es:Artes culinarias / Recetas / Anticuchos de corazón]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Peru|Cuisine of Peru]]
8 Servings
==Ingredients==
* 4 lb (1300g) [[Cookbook:chicken|chicken]] * 1/2 cup (120ml) of [[Cookbook:olive oil|olive oil]] * ¼ lb (110g) of chopped [[Cookbook:pecan|pecan]]s * 3 hot [[Cookbook: Yellow Chili Pepper|yellow South American chilis]] (seeds removed) (Adjust quantity for individual taste) * ¼ loaf of [[Cookbook:bread|bread]] * 1 can [[Cookbook:evaporated milk|evaporated milk]] * 4 oz (110g) grated [[Cookbook:Parmesan cheese|Parmesan cheese]]. * 1 large finely chopped [[Cookbook:onion|onion]] * 1 [[Cookbook:chicken stock|chicken stock]] cube * [[Cookbook:Salt|Salt]] and [[Cookbook:pepper|pepper]] to taste * 6 [[Cookbook:Potato|Potato]]es * 1/2 cup (120g) of [[Cookbook:black olive|black olive]]s * 4 hard boiled [[Cookbook:egg|egg]]s * Boiled [[Cookbook:rice|rice]]; sufficient for 8 servings
==Preparation== #[[Cookbook:Boil|Boil]] chicken in salted water together with the stock cube. Remove bones and break into bite size pieces, keeping the resulting chicken stock. #In a [[Cookbook:saucepan|saucepan]], heat oil and [[Cookbook:sauté|sauté]] the onion, garlic, and finely chopped chili peppers and add salt and pepper. Fry this until the onions are cooked and golden. #Soak the the bread in 2 cups of the stock from the boiled chicken and place in a [[Cookbook:blender|blender]] for a couple of minutes and then add the resulting liquid to the saucepan. #Cook slowly for 10 minutes. Cook slowly, stirring to thicken. #Add the chopped pecans, grated cheese, and chicken pieces. Cook until it it has a thick creamy texture. About 5 minutes before serving add the evaporated milk and continue cooking on low heat. #Serve over the boiled rice and garnish with halved potatoes, eggs quartered lengthwise, and olives.
[[Category:Peruvian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Chicken recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Rice recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Recipes_with_metric_units|{{PAGENAME}}]]
[[es:Artes culinarias / Recetas / Ají de gallina]]

{{recipe}}
Granola bars are a very tasty and easy food to make. They can be sold at the market in small bars, such as the size of a candy bar. However, by following these commonly used steps you can create your own tasty granola bars right at home.
This recipe is for ''chewy'' granola bars.
== Ingredients ==
* 1/2 cup (120g) of soft butter or margarine * 3/4 cup (180g) of brown sugar * 1/3 cup (80ml) of corn syrup * 1 egg * 1/2 teaspoon vanilla * 3 1/2 cups (900g) of uncooked oats * 1 cup (240g) of chocolate chips
== Procedure ==
# Preheat oven to 350° F (180c). # Grease 13 x 9" (30cm x 23cm) baking pan. # Combine butter, sugar and corn syrup. # Blend in egg and vanilla. # Add oats and chocolate chips. # Bake 20 - 22 minutes. # Let cool and enjoy.
== Notes, tips, and variations ==
To create granola with extra taste, add a desired amount of nuts and raisin.
[[Category:Oat recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Chocolate recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Recipes_with_metric_units|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of France|French Cuisine]]
'''Flammekueche''' or '''Tarte flambée''' is a well-known Alsacian speciality. It is like pizza in that a thin crust of dough is baked in a very hot oven, but its topping is primarily crème fraîche, onions, and bacon. Like many traditional regional dishes there are innumerable ways of preparing it. Here is one example.
==Ingredients== ===Starter for the dough=== * ¼ cup flour * ¼ cup moderately hot water, about 110 degrees F (45 deg C) * 1 tablespoon sugar * 1 package yeast
===Dough=== * 2 cups all-purpose flour * 1 teaspoon salt * ¼ cup beer (Homebrew) * 6 tablespoons (¼ cup plus 2 tablespoons) milk
===Covering=== * 2 tablespoons oil * 1 medium onion (3 ounces), finely chopped * 1 cup crème fraîche, commercial or homemade (see note) * ½ teaspoon salt * ¼ teaspoon pepper * 4 pinches nutmeg * 3 ounces bacon, cut into matchsticks
==Procedure== # Mix the starter ingredients together in a small bowl, cover tightly, and set aside in a warm place for 30 minutes. # When the starter is light and bubbly, mix the beer and milk into the mixture. # Put the flour and salt into a food processor, then, with the motor running, add the yeast mixture through the feeding tube. Process the dough until it forms a ball. Add very small amounts of additional flour or milk if necessary. # Process the ball until it is smooth, elastic, and warm, about 45 seconds to 1 minute. # Butter a medium-sized bowl, roll the ball around in the butter, then cover and let rise in a warm place until doubled. Punch down and let rise a second time. # While the dough is rising, heat 1 tablespoon of the oil in a nonstick skillet. Add the onion and cook, stirring, over low heat for 5 minutes or until golden brown. Let cool. # Combine the crème fraîche, salt, pepper, and nutmeg. Add the cooled onion. # Heat the remaining oil in the skillet and fry the bacon until lightly browned, stirring constantly. Remove and drain through a strainer. # Preheat the oven to 450 degrees F (220 deg C) (or as hot as it will go) If using a pizza stone, preheat the oven for at least 30 minutes. # Lightly oil a 14 x 16 inch baking sheet. Roll the dough until slightly smaller than the baking sheet. Place it on the sheet. If using a pizza stone you may roll the dough onto a sheet of parchment paper. # Spread the onion mixture over the dough, leaving a very small raised rim all the way around, then dot with the bacon. # Bake for 4 to 20 minutes depending on oven temp. Tart should is lightly browned & bubbling. Burned/blackened edges are traditional. Serve very hot.
'''NOTE:''' To make crème fraîche, combine 1 cup heavy cream with 2 tablespoons buttermilk, stir, cover with plastic wrap, and leave at room temperature for 12 to 24 hours, or until it has become very thick. Refrigerate, and it will become even thicker.
[[Category:French recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Bacon recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Appetizer recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}}
'''Queen's Soup''', or ''Zuppa Regina di Riso'', is a rice soup. One recipe is as follows.
== Ingredients == * [[Cookbook:Stock|fowl stock]] * 1 tablespoon ground [[Cookbook:Rice|rice]] * ½ pint (285ml) [[Cookbook:Milk|milk]] * 1oz (30g) [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]]
== Equipment == * [[Cookbook:Saucepan|saucepan]] * [[Cookbook:Bain-marie|bain-marie]] * [[Cookbook:Sieve|sieve]]
== Procedure == * Put a tablespoonful of ground rice into a saucepan * Gradually add half a pint (285ml) of milk * Boil gently for twelve minutes in a bainmarie, stirring the whole time, until very smooth. * Add an ounce of butter * Pass through a sieve * Mix in some good fowl stock * Serve immediately
{{decameron}}
[[Category:Rice recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Soup recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Recipes_with_metric_units|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}}
==Ingredients== * 1 lb chopped [[Cookbook:chicken|chicken]] * 14 oz of frozen [[Cookbook:broccoli|broccoli]] * 1 10.5 oz can of [[Cookbook:cream of celery soup|cream of celery soup]] * 4 oz cup [[Cookbook:mayonnaise|mayonnaise]] * 6 oz [[Cookbook:skim milk|skim milk]] * 1 teaspoon [[Cookbook:curry powder|curry powder]]
==Procedure== # Cook chicken in [[Cookbook:sauce pan|sauce pan]]. # Place chicken, broccoli, and other ingredients into [[Cookbook:casserole dish|casserole dish]]. # Cover with [[Cookbook:tin foil|tin foil]] and bake in oven at 375 °F for 30 minutes. # Serve on [[Cookbook:rice|rice]].
[[Category:Chicken recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Broccoli recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Vegan cuisine|Vegan Cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Dessert|Dessert]]
This recipe originates with the New York chapter of [[w:Food Not Bombs|Food Not Bombs]]. These delicious cookies are very simple to make, and they require no unusual ingredients.
== Ingredients == * ¾ [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] [[Cookbook:vegetable oil|vegetable oil]] * 1½ [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] [[Cookbook:brown sugar|brown sugar]] * ⅓ [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] [[Cookbook:water|water]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|tsp]] [[Cookbook:vanilla extract|vanilla extract]] * 3 [[Cookbook:Cup|cups]] [[Cookbook:rolled oats|rolled oats]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] white [[Cookbook:flour|flour]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|tsp]] [[Cookbook:salt|salt]] * ½ [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|tsp]] [[Cookbook:baking soda|baking soda]]
== Procedure == #Put the oil, sugar, water, and vanilla together in a bowl. #Mix well. #Add the oats, flour, salt, and baking soda. #Place on a greased [[Cookbook:baking sheet|baking sheet]] in lumps about 1 inch across and about 3 inches apart. #Bake at 191 °C (375 °F) for 10 to 12 minutes, and serve if the cookies have begun to brown.
== Notes, Tips, and Variations ==
* Leftover dough can be spread in a thin layer on a cookie sheet and baked, turning every 4 or 5 minutes, to make a tasty and crunchy granola.
[[Category:Cookie recipes|Anarchist Oatmeal Cookies]] [[Category:Oat recipes|Anarchist Oatmeal Cookies]] [[Category:Vegan recipes|Anarchist Oatmeal Cookies]]

{{recipesummary|Salad recipes||30 minutes|3}}
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Side dishes | Side dishes]]
A tasty salad for any meat-eating salad lover. Salad consists of bacon, olive, carrot, and turkey piled on a bed of lettuce.
== Ingredients ==
*1 head of lettuce *2 cups of carrots, shredded *1 cup of sliced olives *4 to 5 slices of deli turkey *4 to 5 slices of cooked bacon
== Procedure ==
# Cook bacon completely. # Remove excess grease by pressing cooked bacon on disposable paper towel. # Chop bacon strips into small pieces. # Clean lettuce, carrots, and olives. # Shred lettuce either by hand or with a preparing knife. # Lay desired amount of lettuce in clean bowl, a minimum of 2 cups recommended. # Roll deli turkey to form a slender shape. # Slowly slice turkey into circular shapes. # Pile carrots, olive, bacon, and turkey on lettuce. # Top off with your favorite dressing.
