{{recipesummary|Crab recipes|4|prep: 15 minutes
cooking: 10 minutes}} {{recipe}} ==Ingredients== ===Crab cakes=== * 1 lb. [[Cookbook:crab|crab]]meat or [[Cookbook:imitation crabmeat|imitation crabmeat]] * 1 cup Italian style [[Cookbook:Bread Crumb|breadcrumbs]] * ¼ cup [[Cookbook:mayonnaise|mayonnaise]] * 1 tsp. [[Cookbook:mustard|ground mustard]] * 1 tsp. [[Cookbook:Worcestershire Sauce|Worcestershire sauce]] * 1 [[Cookbook:egg|egg]] * [[Cookbook:salt|salt]] and [[Cookbook:pepper|pepper]], to taste * 3 cups [[Cookbook:vegetable oil|vegetable oil]] ===Sauce=== * 1 cup mayonnaise * 2 tsps. Worcestershire sauce * 2 tsps. [[Cookbook:Caper|capers]], chopped * 1 tsp. minced [[Cookbook:garlic|garlic]] * 1 [[Cookbook:lemon|lemon]], juiced * ½ tsp. [[Cookbook:lemon zest|lemon zest]] == Procedure == # Combine crabmeat, Italian style breadcrumbs, mayonnaise, mustard, Worcestershire sauce, egg, salt, and pepper in a medium bowl for the cakes. # In a separate bowl, combine remaining ingredients, except the oil, to make the sauce. # Shape crab cake mix into 3-inch patties (about 2 per serving). # Add oil to a [[Cookbook:skillet|skillet]]. # [[Cookbook:Pan Frying|Pan fry]] the cakes for 3-4 minutes on each side or until golden brown. # Remove from skillet and drain on paper towels. # Serve cakes topped with the sauce. == External links == Modified version of a [http://www.chefs.com/Recipes/RecipeDetails.aspx?id=7614 crab cakes recipe]found at Chefs.com. [[Category:Crab recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}}
This is a simple dish for 4-5 people, but it does take time.
== Ingredients ==
*900g boneless chuck [[Cookbook:beef|beef]], snipped into 3cm pieces and rolled in flour *unsalted [[Cookbook:butter|butter]] *1 clove [[Cookbook:garlic|garlic]] *5/4 cups [[Cookbook:burgundy|burgundy]] *small [[Cookbook:bay leaf|bay leaf]] *5/4 teaspoon [[Cookbook:salt|salt]] *2 stalks [[Cookbook:parsley|parsley]] *25g [[Cookbook:pancetta|pancetta]], diced *18 [[Cookbook:pickling onion|pickling onion]]s peeled *1 Tablespoon [[Cookbook:tomato puree|tomato puree]] *1/2 teaspoon dried [[Cookbook:thyme|thyme]] *1/2 teaspoon ground [[Cookbook:asafoetida|asafoetida]] *1/4 teaspoon ground [[Cookbook:black pepper|black pepper]] *18 [[Cookbook:mushroom|mushroom]] caps *1 Tablespoon [[Cookbook:olive oil|olive oil]]
== Utensils == Wide [[Cookbook:frying pan|frying pan]] and [[Cookbook:casserole dish|casserole dish]] with lid
== Procedure ==
# [[Cookbook:Brown|Brown]] the beef in olive oil in the pan, then add the garlic for 1 min before removing. # Put the beef in the casserole dish (without the garlic) - add the wine and then enough hot water to barely cover the meat. Add the bay leaf, salt and parsley and put in an oven at 190 °C for 2 hours. # [[Cookbook:pan fry|Fry]] the pancetta in the pan, then add the onions and brown all over. Add to the casserole and cook for an extra 1/2 hour in the oven. # Fry the mushrooms in the pan with butter. # Stir the puree, thyme, asafoetida and pepper into the casserole and return to the oven for an extra 10 mins. Then spoon off the fat and adjust the salt. # Spread the mushrooms over the beef and serve from the casserole with [[Cookbook:Colcannon|colcannon]] and steamed [[Cookbook:vegetables|vegetables]]
The beef should be tender, and the sauce quite rich. The pickling onions come out sweet. The [[Cookbook:Asafoetida|asafoetida]] is a novelty, but is extremely good for adding a little pungency to stews.
==Related recipes== [[Cookbook:Boeuf_Bourguignon|Bœuf Bourguignon]]
[[Category:Beef recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{cookwork|Merge with [[Cookbook:Coq au Vin]] or delete}}
{{recipe}}
'''Coq au vin''' ("cock in wine") is a French dish, in which a capon or chicken is stewed in a red wine sauce.
==Ingredients== *1 free range [[Cookbook:capon|capon]]/[[Cookbook:chicken|chicken]], jointed (or drumsticks, thighs, breasts); get the giblets, and the blood if you can; season beforehand; marrow is important. *1 bottle red [[Cookbook:burgundy|burgundy]] (or côte du Rhône/Morgon) *8 thick slices [[Cookbook:pancetta|pancetta]], cut into strips less than width of little finger *1 strip of [[Cookbook:porkbelly fat|porkbelly fat]] *250g [[Cookbook:button mushroom|button mushroom]]s, whole *selection of [[Cookbook:wild mushroom|wild mushroom]]s, sliced - dried is OK (use the soaking liquor) *2 large [[Cookbook:onion|onion]]s, one for the stock, the other roughly chopped *12 small pickling onions (fresh, not pickled), peeled and whole *2 stalks [[Cookbook:celery|celery]], roughly diced *4 [[Cookbook:carrot|carrot]]s, cut in thick lengths *5 cloves [[Cookbook:garlic|garlic]], crushed, leaving one sliced *1/2 tsp ground [[Cookbook:asafoetida|asafoetida]] *5 sprigs [[Cookbook:thyme|thyme]] (2 tsps) & 5 [[Cookbook:bay leaves|bay leaves]] *[[Cookbook:butter|butter]], [[Cookbook:salt|salt]], [[Cookbook:black pepper|black pepper]], [[Cookbook:parsley|parsley]] *2 measures of [[Cookbook:brandy|brandy]]
==Gear==
Wide [[Cookbook:skillet|skillet]], deep [[Cookbook:pyrex|pyrex]] bowl with lid, and [[Cookbook:jug|jug]].
==Procedure== #For chicken stock, [[Cookbook:sear|sear]] the giblets in a bit of [[Cookbook:oil|oil]] in a pan, and [[Cookbook:simmer|simmer]] in water with an onion, a carrot and some peppercorns. For the vegetable stock, make up a cupful with ''Vegcon'', just salty (can act as the entire stock - make 1/2 pint). #In the skillet, fry pancetta and porkbelly fat with butter till golden brown. Remove pancetta. #To the skillet, add the seasoned chicken pieces skin side down and fry until honey-coloured, then turn. This is vital for the flavour; the skillet must be left sticky. There won't be enough room to do it in one go, so take it in turns. Remove, leaving the porkbelly behind, snipped into pieces. (If you're doing breasts off the bone, sear on skin side only and do not put back into the dish until the oven stage - otherwise they will toughen up.) #To the skillet add the chopped onion and the button mushrooms; fry for 5 mins, then add the sliced garlic and immediately flame off one of the measures of brandy. #To the skillet add the chicken pieces and pancetta, then pour over all the wine and the chicken & veg stocks. Bring to the boil, then reduce the heat and, adding the crushed garlic and herbs, simmer for 45 mins. Turn the chicken pieces twice. Remove the chicken pieces to the pyrex lid and pour the skillet sauce into the jug; put the jug in the freezer for 30 mins and then remove the fat. At this stage, it is recommended that you refrigerate the whole dish overnight. #In the skillet, add some butter along with the wild mushrooms; then pickling onions, carrots and celery; fry till mushrooms brown. Stir in the asafoetida and flame off the second measure of brandy. #Add the jug ingredients to the skillet sauce, along with another crushed clove of garlic, and push the veg to the edge of the skillet; reduce the sauce in the skillet until glossy (may need flour stirred in - but it shouldn't be thick): 15 mins. #Pour half the sauce into the pyrex bowl, then place the chicken pieces in, and pour the rest of the sauce on top; put the covered pyrex bowl in an oven on 170 C for 90 mins. #Sprinkle parsley over each portion, and serve with asparagus/green beans, and steamed potatoes/flat noodles/rice/orzo/[[Cookbook:Colcannon|colcannon]].
This is a difficult dish, but you've got to try it. The asafoetida is a novelty, but it does add pungency.
[[Category:Chicken recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:French recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Wine recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}}
== Ingredients == ===Meatballs=== * 3/4 lbs ground beef * 1/2 lbs veal * 1/4 lbs pork * 1 1/2 cups bread crumbs * 1/4 cup Cup Milk * 1/2 cup Chopped onion * 1/4 cup Ginger * pepper * 2 tbsp butter * 1 cup half & half * 1/4 cup parsley * 1 tsp salt * 1 tsp MSG (optional) ===Gravy=== * 2 tbsp butter * 1 tbsp flour * 3/4 cup half & half * 1 tsp instant coffee * 1/2 tsp concentrated meat extract (optinal) * dash MSG (optional)
== Procedure == # Grind meat together. # Soak bread 5 min in milk. # Cook onion in butter till tender. # Combine meat, bread crumbs, onion, 1 cup half & half, parsley and seasonings. # Make meatballs (1 inch in diameter) and brown in butter (add more butter if needed) # After browning meatballs, stir flour into drippings, add half & half, butter, coffee, meat extract, MSG. # Heat and stir until thickened. # Either add meatball and gravy to a croc pot and simmer until ready to eat, or add meatballs to sauce in pan and simmer for 10 minutes.
[[Category:Swedish recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Beef recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Duplicate recipes]]

{{recipe}}
== Ingredients ==
*1 2⁄3 cup [[Cookbook:Falafel|falafel mix]] *1 1/4 cup water * 1 head red leaf lettuce * 3 tomatoes * 1 cucumber
* 1/2 cup [[Cookbook:Tahini Yogurt Sauce|Tahini Yogurt Sauce]]
== Procedures == === Prepare Falafel === * In a large bowl, add water to falafel mix and stir well. * Let stand 15 minutes to absorb the water. * Form mix into 3/4 inch balls.
==== Baked! ==== Baked is delicious and healthy.
* Place balls into mini-cupcake tins or onto a cookie sheet. * Bake in oven at 375 for 12 minutes.
==== Fried! ==== For a more traditional falafel ball, * Heat about 1⁄2-inch vegetable oil to 375°F. * Fry balls until brown and crisp (about 3 minutes). * Drain and set aside.
=== Prepare Veggies === * Clean and chop lettuce. * Quarter the tomatoes. Chop again until large bite size. * Peel and slice cucumber.
Toss vegetables with falafels and douse with tahini yogurt sauce. Falafel may be cold or hot for a delicious salad straight outta the PNW.
== Notes, tips, and variations == Thanks to dry falafel mix and the nature of simple salads, this recipe is pretty fast and easy. Look in the bulk bins at your local hippie grocery store for dry falafel mix.
[[Category:Pacific Northwestern recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegan recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Salad recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{cookwork|This recipe needs measurements}}
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Meat Recipes|Meat Recipes]] | [[Cookbook:Midwestern cuisine|Midwest]]
Cashew chicken was invented at Leong's Tea House in Springfield, Missouri. Leong had difficulty popularizing Chinese cuisine in the area and based the dish on the popular fried foods common in the Ozarks. The dish is not truly Chinese, rather an American dish with a "Chinese" theme.
Note that there is also an unbreaded [[Cookbook:Cashew Chicken|Cashew Chicken]] recipe with softened cashews.
==Main Ingredients== * chicken breast * flour * eggs * milk * salt * cashews * green onions
==Sauce Ingredients== * chicken broth * cornstarch * soy sauce * oyster sauce
==Procedure== Debone and cut chicken breasts into bite-sized pieces. Scramble eggs and mix with milk. Dip breasts into egg/milk combination, then into flour (add a dash of salt) and deep fry.
For the sauce, take one can chicken broth and add 1 tablespoon cornstarch and heat in a saucepan on low to medium heat. Add 2 tablespoons each oyster sauce and soy sauce or to taste. Continue to add cornstarch as needed while heating until it reaches a thicker consistency.
Serve chicken on fried rice, cover liberally with sauce and garnish with cashews (chopped, if desired) and chopped green onions.
[[Category:Chicken recipes|Leong's Cashew Chicken]] [[Category:Midwestern recipes|Leong's Cashew Chicken]] [[Category:Cashew recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Desserts|Desserts]]
A delicious chocolate cake recipe.
==Ingredients== [[Image:Atomicfudge1.JPG|thumb|Atomic Fudge Cake]] *3 cups (710 ml) [[Cookbook:sugar|sugar]] *1 ¾ cup (415ml) [[Cookbook:flour|flour]] *1 ¾ cups (415ml) baking [[Cookbook:cocoa|cocoa]] *1 ½ teaspoon (7 ml) [[Cookbook:baking soda|baking soda]] *1 ½ teaspoon (7 ml) [[Cookbook:baking powder|baking powder]] *1 teaspoon [[Cookbook:salt|salt]] (5ml) *2 [[Cookbook:egg|egg]]s *1 cup(235 ml) [[Cookbook:milk|milk]] *½ cup (120 ml) [[Cookbook:vegetable oil|vegetable oil]] *2 teaspoons (10 ml) [[Cookbook:vanilla extract|vanilla extract]] *1 cup (235 ml)boiling [[Cookbook:water|water]]
== Procedure == #mix the dry ingredients well in a large bowl. For better texture, sift them together. #Add the eggs, milk, vanilla and vegetable oil and mix well. Then add the water. Mix it until it has a lot of little bubbles. This batter will be very thin. #Pour into two greased 9 inch round baking pans #[[Cookbook:Bake|Bake]] in a preheated oven at 350 °F (175 °C) for thirty minutes. (About 20 minutes for a convection oven)
== Frosting/filling == [[Image:Atomicfudge2.JPG|thumb|right|Atomic Fudge Cake]] Note: this should only be done after the cake has cooled and is ready for frosting. *1/8th cup (30 ml) [[Cookbook:cocoa|cocoa]] *7 oz (200 g) [[Cookbook:dark chocolate|dark chocolate]] *1/8th cup (30 ml) boiling [[Cookbook:water|water]] *1/16th cup (15 ml) [[Cookbook:sugar|sugar]] or [[Cookbook:powdered sugar|powdered sugar]] *2/3rds cup (156 ml) [[Cookbook:whipping cream|whipping cream]]
warning: don't try and substitute baker's chocolate for the dark chocolate. The huge amount of sugar you'd have to add would be a pain, especially if using the powdered sugar, and if you use regular sugar, it gets grainy and crunchy. Also, to make things more interesting, spices such as [[Cookbook:cinnamon|cinnamon]] can be added, if so desired.
#Melt the chocolate by placing it in a small bowl or pot and placing that in boiling water. #Mix the sugar and cocoa together in a small bowl and mix in the water. #Stir the sugar/cocoa/water mix into the melted chocolate #quickly stir in the cream and mix until it has a nice smooth consistancy. #Immediately 'frost' the cake with this, and make sure that there is quite a bit between the two layers of cake. The cake will need to be refrigerated to harden the fudge, so don't worry about its relatively liquid nature. #Refrigerate Cake
This cake is meant to be served warm - that is, after being refrigerated. So, slice a piece and microwave it for about 20 seconds. It is heavenly as the fudge melts and soaks into the cake. Serve with ice cream if you so desire. One final note: a higher quality of chocolate and baking cocoa will make a HUGE difference in this cake. It is very worth the extra expense.
[[Category:Cake recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Chocolate recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Recipes_with_metric_units|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{Recipesummary| |Category=Muffin recipes |Servings=12 |Time=24 minutes |Rating=2 |Energy=168 Cal / 705 kJ |Image=[[Image:Lemon_Poppy_Seed_Muffins_Cooking_Glazing.jpg|300px]] }} {{recipe}}
A delicious muffin recipe that is a treat on a special morning. Makes 12 muffins.
==Ingredients== *1/3 [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] (80ml) [[Cookbook:milk|milk]] *1/4 [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] (60ml) [[Cookbook:vegetable oil|vegetable oil]] *2/3 [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] (160ml) nonfat lemon [[Cookbook:yogurt|yogurt]] *1 [[Cookbook:Eggs|egg]] *1 3/4 [[Cookbook:Cup|cups]] (300g) all-purpose [[Cookbook:flour|flour]] *1/4 [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] (60g) white [[Cookbook:sugar|sugar]] *2 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|Tbsp]] [[Cookbook:poppy seed|poppy seed]]s *1 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|Tbsp]] [[Cookbook:lemon zest|lemon zest]] *1/4 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|tsp]] [[Cookbook:lemon extract|lemon extract]] *2 1/2 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|tsp]] [[Cookbook:baking powder|baking powder]] *1/2 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|tsp]] [[Cookbook:baking soda|baking soda]] *1/2 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|tsp]] [[Cookbook:salt|salt]] *1/2 [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] (120g) [[Cookbook:powdered sugar|confectioners' sugar]] *2 1/2 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|tsp]] [[Cookbook:lemon juice|lemon juice]]
==Procedure== #Preheat the oven to 400 °F (205 °C). #Grease with cold butter a 12-cup muffin tin. #Sift the flour, sugar, poppy seeds, lemon zest, lemon extract, baking powder, and salt into a medium bowl. #In a separate bowl, mix the the milk, oil, lemon yogurt, and egg together. #Fold the dry ingredients into the wet mixture in three steps. Take care not to over-mix the batter. #Bake for 16 minutes, or until golden brown. #While muffins are baking, prepare the glaze. #Stir confectioners' sugar with the lemon juice until smooth. #Muffins should be springy to the touch and a toothpick stuck in will come out clean. #Drizzle with glaze. #Let cool on rack for 3 minutes and remove from muffin tin.
==Tips== *Optional - 1/8 cup (30g) sliced almonds can be added when glazing for artistic flair. *Call 11 pals and enjoy a sunshine muffin.
[[Image:Lemon Poppy Seed Muffins Glazed In Box.jpg|center|500px|Muffins with optional almonds for flair packaged up and ready to go]]
[[Category:Muffin recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Lemon recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Poppy seed recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Featured recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Recipes_with_metric_units|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{cookwork|This recipe is missing some ingredients and procedure}} {{recipesummary|Dessert recipes|Makes Six Rolls
About 10 Servings Per Roll|Prep: ~ 4 Hours
Baking: ~ 40 Minutes|3}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Dessert|Dessert]] An Eastern European dessert that goes by many various names, but is often translated as ''Nut Roll'' in English. This variation is a traditional Slovakian version of walnuts, and coffee. =Bread= ===Ingredients=== ==Bread Ingredients== *4 [[Cookbook:Egg|Egg yolks]] *1 cup (240g) [[Cookbook:Baking sugar|Sugar]] *½ (120g) cup [[Cookbook:butter|butter]] *½ pound (225g) [[Cookbook:crisco|crisco]] *8 cups (1900g) [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] *2 cups (480ml) [[Cookbook:Milk|scalded milk]] *1 tbsp. [[Cookbook:Salt|Salt]] *1½ tsp. [[Cookbook:Vanilla|Vanilla]] *3 envelopes [[Cookbook:Yeast|dry yeast]] ==Nut Filling Ingredients== * ===Procedure=== #Dissolve yeast in 1 cup lukewarm milk. Mix well. #Add sugar, shortening and salt to mixture; cool. #Beat egg slightly, and add to mix. Then add yeast. #Put 1/2 of flour in bowl, add lukewarm mixture to flour slowly. Mix well. #Add the second half of flour so as to knead without sticking. #Cover and place somewhere warm; let rise until double in bulk (approximately 2 hours). #Knead dough slightly to get out puffiness. #Divide into 6 parts; let stand 10 minutes. #Roll out dough, spread with Nut Filling Mixture. Roll bread tightly so mixture forms a "swirl" #Place bread on greased baking sheet; let rise for 1 hour. #Brush top of each roll with slightly beaten egg. #Bake in 350 Degrees (180c) over for 35-40 minutes. #Take out of oven, brush with melted butter. === Other Notes === {{wikipedia|Nut roll}} *Nut Roll freezes well up to six months after being baked. [[Category:Dessert recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Bread recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Nut recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Recipes_with_metric_units|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Chicken recipes|4|15 minutes, 6-24 hours marinating|3}}
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Meat Recipes|Meat Recipes]]
'''Curry & Honey Chicken''' - This dish was an idea I got out of nowhere, and turned out to be an unbelievable delicacy. Due to the experimental birth of this recipe, the measures given are very vague and approximate and can be altered freely. The almonds can be omitted and if you make your rice a little more interesting (I tried flavouring it with Mexican-ish tomato soup, tasted great), then you can leave out the vegetable mix altogether.
==Ingredients== * 4 [[Cookbook:Chicken|chicken]] breasts * 1 handful of [[Cookbook:Almond|almonds]] * 1 teaspoon of [[Cookbook:Curry Powder|curry powder]] * 3 tablespoons of [[Cookbook:honey|honey]] ([[Cookbook:Maple Syrup|maple syrup]] has even better results, if you can get it) * 1/2 or 1 cup (120ml or 240ml) [[Cookbook:vegetable oil|vegetable oil]] or [[Cookbook:Olive Oil|olive oil]] * [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * vegetable mix - I recommend 1 [[Cookbook:onion|onion]] (can be substituted with [[Cookbook:leek|leek]]), 1 [[Cookbook:Bell Pepper|red pepper]], 2-4 [[Cookbook:tomato|tomato]]es, 1-3 [[Cookbook:celery|celery]] greens (if you add more, they can dominate the mix - interesting for a change), 1 [[Cookbook:zucchini|zucchini]] or [[Cookbook:eggplant|eggplant]], and you can add a lot more. * For special occasions, [[Cookbook:cherry tomato|cherry tomato]]es will make the meal very interesting (due to the contrast between the sweet chicken, bitter celery and sour tomatoes). * What also makes the meal a lot better is adding cubes of [[Cookbook:mango|mango]] to the meat just before it's done (and frying them a bit - you need to put salt on them, and don't hesitate, it tastes great when it's stronger). [[Cookbook:Kiwi|Kiwifruit]] works too, but not as well. Any sour-ish hard [[Cookbook:fruit|fruit]] should do the trick. [[Cookbook:banana|Banana]] is good too, but doesn't offer the same contrast. * [[Cookbook:Rice|rice]]
==Preparation== #[[Cookbook:Marinate|Marinate]] chicken at least 6 hours before preparing the meal. 24 hours is best. Marinate in honey (or maple syrup), curry, oil, salt (1 heaping teaspoon per kilogram of chicken works very well). Adding parsley, celery leaves or something similar adds a fine taste. #Peel almonds ([[Cookbook:boil|boil]] in small amount of water for a minute or two, let cool, squeeze out of peeling)
==Procedure== #Chop onion/leek finely and fry lightly on a large [[Cookbook:frying pan|frying pan]] with a bit of oil. #Add vegetables, roughly in the order you find logical (i.e., tomatoes don't take long, zucchini (courgette) can be in the pan from the start of cooking) #Add salt, about 1/2 teaspoon, add more if the taste doesn't seem right. The salt will extract water from the vegetables and make them 'stew' faster. You can cover the pan if it goes slowly - once again, this slows the evaporation and allows the vegetables to cook in the water they lose. #Dump the vegetables into a bowl or a small pot to keep them warm and use the remaining oil to fry the cherry tomatoes, if you have those - once done, keep them separate from the other vegetables. #Fry almonds gently on the pan. #Add chicken meat, fry on high temperature quickly - when it looks done, cut the largest piece open to see if it is done inside as well. The pieces should be lightly browned. Don't worry, this is the sugar in the honey turning to caramel. #Serve: Keep rice / vegetables / meat separate on plate, add cherry tomatoes in the center, about 2-4 a dish.
[[Category:Chicken recipes|Curry & Honey Chicken]] [[Category:Curry powder recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Recipes with metric units|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Soup recipes|6|10 minutes|1}}
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Soups|Soups]]
'''Mexican Tomato Soup''' - A very simple dish, can be made hot if wanted. Very nutritious for a soup too.
==Ingredients== * About 1/2 litre tomato sauce/purée or similar. Pure is good - don't use ketchup, or only very good ketchup. I used bio purée. * 2 large onions or equivalent * 2 red peppers * 2 tomatoes * Some greens. Onion greens work, leek does as well. * 1 can of sweet corn * 1/4 cup (60ml) vegetable/olive oil, salt, sugar * More vegetables according to your taste
==Procedure== #Cut onion fine and fry lightly in a large sauce pan with a bit of oil. #Add vegetables, roughly in the order you find logical (ie, tomatoes don't take long, peppers can be there from the start). #Add salt, about 1/2 teaspoon, and add if the taste doesn't feel right. The salt will extract water from the vegetables and make them 'stew' faster. You can cover the pot if it goes slowly - once again, this slows the evaporation and allows the vegetables to cook in the water they lose themselves. #Add tomato sauce and corn. #Add salt, sugar to taste. Be bold, tomato sauce takes a '''lot''' of salt and at least a heaping teaspoon of sugar to taste right. If unsure, seperate a small amount and try adding more salt - you will see the tastes changes significantly. #Serve with tortilla chips, or toasted bread if not available.
[[Category:Soup recipes|Mexican Tomato Soup]] [[Category:Tomato recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Mexican recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Recipes_with_metric_units|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Bread recipes|~7|prep: 45 min
1st rise: 12 hours
2nd rise: 2-3 hours
baking: 20 min|3}} {{recipe}} ==Ingredients== * 12 [[Cookbook:Eggs|eggs]] * 2 [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] * 1/2 [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] (120g) of [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]] * 3 [[Cookbook:Yeast|yeast]] cakes * 1/2 [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] (120ml) of warm water * Juice and zest of 2 lemons * 1 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tbl]] lemon extract * 1 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tbl]] anise extract * 1 pkg anise seed * 1 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|tsp]] [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * 10-12 [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] (enough to feel right) ==Procedure== # Dissolve the yeast cakes (yeast cakes seem to work better than dry yeast) in the warm water and set aside # Mix eggs, butter and sugar until well blended in a large bowl # Add the juices and spices next # Next add the water-yeast mix and stir until well blended # Add flour, mix until ready for kneading # Knead thoroughly (until dough springs back when finger-poked) # Allow dough to rise overnight, 12 hours or doubled in size # Shape the 7 or so portions into round loaves or into the shape of dolls # Allow to rise for 2 to 3 hours # [[Cookbook:Bake|Bake]] at 275°-300° F (around 140 - 160c) for 15-20 minutes ==Notes, tips, and variations== Alternately it is shaped into a couple of large rings with shell-on hard boiled eggs embedded in the dough at the cardinal points. The eggs were a symbol of resurrection and the four directions the sign of the cross. Don't forget the sweet glaze; 1lb (450g) of [[Cookbook:Powdered Sugar|confectioners' sugar]] enough water to make it spreadable. Spread on each loaf and cover generously with colorful sprinkles! [[Category:Bread recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Recipes_with_metric_units|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Israeli recipes|8|120 minutes|3}}
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Israel|Israeli Cuisine]]
Charcoal grilled squid, prawn and fish kebabs in Zhoug sauce (a spicy dipping sauce that can be used in a variety of different ways). The original recipe called for octopus, but I've expanded it with good results. Also, note that the original recipe didn't call for white wine in the marinade.
==Ingredients==
'''Kebabs'''
* ½ kg large prawns / [[Cookbook:Shrimp|shrimp]], peeled and deveined * ½ kg fish fillets, cut into 2½ cm (1 in) cubes * ½ kg [[Cookbook:Squid|squid]], cleaned and cut into 2½ cm (1 in) pieces
'''Marinade'''
* 5 cloves [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]], peeled and finely chopped * 2 bay leaves * 2 [[Cookbook:Jalapeño|jalapeños]], seeded and finely chopped * 1 cup (240ml) lemon juice * 1 tsp ground black pepper * ¾ cup (180ml) [[Cookbook:Olive Oil|extra virgin olive oil]] * ¾ cup (180ml) dry white wine
'''Zhoug sauce'''
* 1 cup (240g) [[Cookbook:Cilantro|coriander leaves]], washed, dried and chopped * 1 cup (240g) [[Cookbook:Parsley|parsley]], washed, dried and chopped * 1 tsp [[Cookbook:Caraway|caraway]] seeds * 1 tsp [[Cookbook:Cumin|cumin]] seeds * 1½ tsp [[Cookbook:Cardamom|cardamom]] seeds * 1 tsp [[Cookbook:Black pepper|black peppercorns]] * 1 tsp [[Cookbook:Garam Masala|garam masala]] * 8 cloves [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]], peeled and crushed * 8 [[Cookbook:Jalapeno|jalapeños]], seeded and chopped (adjust the quantity according to your heat tolerance) * ¼ cup (60ml) [[Cookbook:Olive Oil|extra virgin olive oil]]
==Procedure==
Combine all the marinade ingredients in a nonreactive (glass or ceramic) mixing bowl. Add the seafood and mix to coat well. Refrigerate overnight.
Dry roast the cumin, caraway and cardomom seeds for two or three minutes in a cast iron skillet or wok over low heat. Cool, then add the peppercorns and pound in a mortar and pestle to a fine powder.
In a blender or food processor, blend the coriander, parsley, spices, garlic, chilli peppers and olive oil together with half a cup of water until a thick, smooth paste is formed.
Transfer the paste into a sauce pan, heat until it starts bubbling, then reduce the heat and simmer, stirring constantly, until the water is evaporated. Cool, transfer to an airtight container and chill.
Remove the seafood from the marinade and drain in a colander. Save the marinade for basting the kebabs later. Thread the seafood onto skewers or satay sticks.
Char-grill the kebabs over hot coals, basting and turning every few minutes. It should take about ten minutes to cook.
When eating, use the zhoug sauce as a dipping sauce.
Serves 8
[[Category:Middle Eastern recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Israeli recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Seafood recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Recipes_with_metric_units|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}}
==Ingredients== * 3/4 fresh human [[Cookbook:Placenta|placenta]] * 1 potato * 4 tablespoons fresh parsley * 2 carrots * 3 celery * 1 zucchini (courgette) * 1 tomato * 1 onion
==Procedure== # Chop up the ingredients. # Roll the placenta in a mix of one table spoon flour, one teaspoon salt, a half teaspoon powdered paprika, some ground clove, some ground pepper and 6-8 coriander seeds. # Saute the placenta in two tablespoons oil, pour in the vegetables and about a litre of water. # Allow to boil and then let simmer for an hour.
Enjoy!
==Warning== As with any meat from uncontrolled sources (such as hunting or scavanging) people should be cautious of risks involved. Certain blood borne diseases can live in blood and tissue outside the body for some time. Be sure that sensible precautions have been taken.
[[Category:Placenta recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Stew recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}}
Moutabbal (Baba Ghanouzh) Eggplant and Tahini Puree
== Ingredients == * 1 large ripe [[Cookbook:Eggplant|eggplant]] (aubergine) * 2 - 3 tablespoons (30-45g) [[Cookbook:Tahini|tahini]] * 1 - 2 [[Cookbook:Lemon|lemons]], juiced and strained * 2 - 3 cloves fresh [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]] * Salt * [[Cookbook:Olive Oil|Olive oil]]
== Procedure == Roast the eggplant on open gas flame - range top or barbecue. If your stove is electric, split the eggplant lengthwise, place face down on cookie sheet and bake in hot oven on top rack 30-45 minutes. For open flame roasting, use a fork to turn often. Skin will wrinkle and char, and flesh will shrivel and become soft. When eggplant is completely soft all over, remove to a bowl, slash once or twice to drain out bitter juice, and let rest until cool enough to handle. Some authors suggest cooling the eggplant inside a brown paper bag.
Cut off stem and peel away skin. Scrape flesh into bowl of food processor or blender. Add garlic, tahini, lemon juice and process. Amounts depend upon size of eggplant and your taste - please sample frequently. Salt to taste.
If you don't have a food processor or blender, the eggplant is quite easy to mash by hand. Mash the garlic with the flat of a broad knife, then mince it fine. If you have a mortar and pestle, mash the garlic with salt into a paste. A large mortar and pestle can be used to mash all ingredients.
Serve at room temperature, drizzled with olive oil, garnished with a black or green Mediterranean olive, or sprigs of cilantro or parsley.
[[Category:Eggplant recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Tahini recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Mediterranean recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Recipes_with_metric_units|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}}
== Ingredients ==
*500gm (1lb) Fresh Trimmed Rhubarb. *75gm(3oz) Caster Sugar. *2tbsps Water. *150gm(6oz) Self Raising Flour. *75gm(3oz) Butter. *100gm(4oz) Brown Sugar.
== Procedure ==
# Preheat oven to 190C/375F/Gas Mark 5. # Cut the rhubarb into pieces & stew for a short time with the caster sugar & water until tender. # While the rhubarb is stewing, in a bowl mix the flour & butter until it resembles fine breadcrumbs. # Stir in the brown sugar. # Place the cooked rhubarb in a deep pie dish (1lt / 2pt). # Spoon over the crumble topping & spread out evenly # Cook crumble for about 25mins until the crumble is golden brown.
Serve with [[Cookbook:Custard|custard]] or [[Cookbook:Cream|cream]] or even [[Cookbook:Vanilla|vanilla]] [[Cookbook:Ice Cream|ice cream]].
[[Category:Dessert recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Crumble recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Rhubarb recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Duplicate recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Recipes_with_metric_units|{{PAGENAME}}]]

page.title: Cookbook:Tripes à la mode de Caen

revision.text:
{{recipesummary|French recipes|12 - 14|25 minutes|2}}
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of France|French cuisine]]
== Ingredients ==
* 6 lbs. tripe, cut into 2-inch squares * 1 calf's foot, boned and cut into pieces * 2 lbs. marrow bone * 1 cup apple brandy * 2 cups dry white wine * 4 cups beef broth * 2 cups carrots, diced * 2 cups onions, chopped * 3 garlic cloves, pressed or minced * 10 shallotts minced * 1/2 cup celery leaves * 1/4 cup parsley, finely chopped * salt and pepper
== Procedure ==
#Preheat oven to 300°F #Mix all of the ingredients together. #Place in a marmite, deep casserole or Dutch oven with a tight fitting lid. Then wrap the casserole completely in foil. #Cook for 10- 12 hours. Remove bones before serving.
[[Category:French recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Casserole recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Beef recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Dessert|Dessert]]
{{recipesummary| | Category = Dessert recipes | Servings = one cake | Time = 10-20 minutes | Rating = 1 | Energy = | Image = [[Image:Chocolate Sour-Cream Icing on cake.JPG|300px|on 1-2-3-4 Cake]] }}
'''Chocolate sour-cream icing''' is an [[Cookbook:Icing|icing or frosting]] with a bit of tang to take the edge off the sugar overload. It can be icing or frosting depending on what you want.
==Ingredients== [[Image:Chocolate Sour-Cream Icing ingredients.JPG|200px|left]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Cup|C]] (240g) [[Cookbook:Chocolate Chips|Chocolate Chips]] * 1/4 [[Cookbook:Cup|C]] (60g) [[Cookbook:Butter|Butter]] * 1/2 [[Cookbook:Cup|C]] (120g) [[Cookbook:Sour Cream|Sour Cream]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|t]] [[Cookbook:Vanilla|vanilla]] extract * 1/4 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|t]] [[Cookbook:Salt|Salt]] * 1-3 [[Cookbook:Cup|C]] (240g to 700g) [[Cookbook:Icing Sugar|Icing Sugar]]
<br clear="all"> ==Method== <gallery> <!--Image:Chocolate Sour-Cream Icing ingredients.JPG|The ingredients you'll need (Salt not shown here)--> Image:Melting chocolate - step 2.JPG|1.Melt the chocolate and butter together. (See [[Cookbook:Melting chocolate]]) Image:Chocolate Sour-Cream Icing before adding icing sugar.JPG|2. Remove from heat and stir in the sour cream, vanilla extract and salt. 3. Slowly beat or stir in the icing sugar until the mixure has the desired consistency. Icing will need far less than frosting. Image:Icing to be spread on cake.JPG|4. Spread on the [[Cookbook:cake|cake]] of your choice. </gallery>
[[Category:Frosting and Icing recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Sour Cream recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Chocolate recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[category:Gluten-free recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Recipes_with_metric_units|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Pages with illustrated tutorials|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}}
This is my grandmother's recipe, she refuses to measure things, so these are all approximates. It makes enough food for at least 4 people.
== Ingredients == * 1 whole [[Cookbook:chicken|chicken]], cut up (skin optional) * 2 standard size containers of [[Cookbook:sour cream|sour cream]] * [[Cookbook:Paprika|paprika]] * [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]] (not [[Cookbook:red onion|red]]) * 2-3 cups (480g - 700g) [[Cookbook:flour|flour]] * 2-3 [[Cookbook:egg|egg]]s * [[Cookbook:Water|water]] * [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * [[cookboo:Bacon grease|bacon grease]] or [[Cookbook:oil|oil]]
== Equipment == * big pot * pan with lid (or an old plate to cover)
== Procedure ==
Put on a (BIG) pot of water to [[Cookbook:boil|boil]] (for dumplings)
=== Chicken === # [[Cookbook:Chop|Chop]] up onions (we like them done very small to hide them from the kids) and [[Cookbook:brown|brown]] them in your pan (the heavier the better) with some bacon grease (traditional) or lard or your preferred kind of oil (healthier but, if you ''must'', then use olive oil for flavor). # When the onions have softened and well colored, add the chicken to the pan. Brown rapidly, then season with paprika (to taste), turn heat down, add enough water added to cover the bottom of the pan and cook on low. Keep covered but with the lid slightly cocked to prevent boiling.
=== Dumplings === Make these while the chicken is cooking.
# Take flour, eggs, salt (just a pinch) and water at room temperature (to be added as needed) and mix to a sticky consistency (for dumplings to be ‘sticky’ inside have wetter dough; for dry the same all through, make a dryer dough). # Use a desert spoon (or a [[Cookbook:melon-baller|melon-baller]] for smaller dumplings) to drop dough into boiling water (to keep them from sticking to the spoon, let it heat up in the water). # When the dumpling floats, its done. Remove, put in a bowl (a ''tiny'' slick of melted fat/oil on the bottom might help if they stick) and keep them to one side in a warm place.
=== Assembly === # Now your chicken is cooked (chicken should be cooked to 160 °F) and your dumplings are all done (make sure they are thoroughly drained). # Add dumplings and sour cream to pan, stir thoroughly but carefully to coat. # Add more paprika, until it is more pink (or orange) than white. # Taste sauce: it may need more paprika or salt. Sometimes it is easier to remove the chicken, and then pour the dumplings and sour cream over the top to coat (when serving), depending on how big your pan is.
Use [[Cookbook:rye bread|rye bread]] (with seeds) to sop up the sauce when you're done eating.
[[Category:Chicken recipes|Paprikash]] [[Category:Hungarian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Recipes_with_metric_units|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Sandwich recipes|1|prep: 5 mins
cooking: 10 minutes|2|Image=[[Image:Ruben sandwich.jpg|300px]]}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Sandwiches|Sandwiches]] The '''Reuben''' or '''Reuben sandwich''' is a grilled or toasted sandwich made with corned beef, sauerkraut, Swiss cheese, and Russian dressing. It is typically made with rye bread though originally it may have been served on pumpernickel bread. The origins of the Reuben are contested. One account holds that Reuben Kulakofsky (sometimes spelled Reubin), a grocer from Omaha, Nebraska, was the inventor, perhaps as part of a group effort by members of Kulakofsky's weekly poker game held in the Blackstone Hotel from ca. 1920-1935. The participants, who nicknamed themselves "the committee," included the hotel's owner, Charles Schimmel. The sandwich first gained local fame when Schimmel put it on the Blackstone's lunch menu. ==Authentic Recipe== === Ingredients === * ½ pound (225g) sliced [[Cookbook:Beef|corned beef]] * ¼ cup (60ml) drained [[Cookbook:Sauerkraut|sauerkraut]] * 2 tablespoons chopped [[Cookbook:Onion|sweet onion]] * 2 tablespoons creamy [[Cookbook:Russian Dressing|Russian dressing]] * 2 slices [[Cookbook:Rye|rye]] [[Cookbook:Bread|bread]] * 1-3 slices [[Cookbook:Swiss Cheese|Swiss cheese]] * chopped [[Cookbook:Parsley|parsley]] * 1 tablespoon [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]] === Procedure === # Combine the sauerkraut, onion, and parsley # Spread the dressing on two slices bread # Pile layers of corned beef, cheese, and sauerkraut mixture on one slice # Add second slice of bread # Butter the outside of the bread # Grill until lightly browned, roughly 5 minutes ==Modern Variation== ===Ingredients=== * 12 [[Cookbook:Ounce|ounces]] thinly sliced cooked corned [[Cookbook:Beef|beef]] or deli corned beef * 2 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoons]] [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]], softened * 8 slices [[Cookbook:Rye|rye]] or pumpernickel bread * 8 slices [[Cookbook:Swiss Cheese|Swiss cheese]] * 1½ cups [[Cookbook:Sauerkraut|sauerkraut]], well drained * ¼ [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] [[Cookbook:Thousand Island Dressing|Thousand Island dressing]] ===Procedure=== # Lightly spread butter on one side of each bread slice. # Heat large non-stick [[Cookbook:Skillet|skillet]] over medium heat until hot. # Place 2 bread slices, butter side down, in skillet. # Top each bread slice with 2 slices cheese, 1 tablespoon dressing, 3 ounces corned beef and ¼ of the sauerkraut. # Top sandwich with bread slice, butter side up. # Cook sandwiches 4 to 6 minutes or until bread is golden brown and cheese is melted, turning once. # Repeat with remaining sandwiches. # Serve with additional Thousand Island dressing, if desired. == Notes, tips, and variations == * A modern variation of the Reuben substitutes [[Cookbook:Thousand Island Dressing|Thousand Island Dressing]] for the traditional Russian dressing. * The Reuben has a "sister" sandwich, the Rachel, which is made with [[Cookbook:Pastrami|pastrami]] or [[Cookbook:Turkey|turkey]] in place of corned beef (and sometimes coleslaw in place of sauerkraut). * A Georgia Reuben is a Rachel made with corned beef and coleslaw instead of sauerkraut. * A Reuben served in a Jewish delicatessen would not contain cheese, as dietary laws forbid meat and dairy in the same dish. {{Wikipedia|Reuben Sandwich}} [[Category:Inexpensive recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:American recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Sandwich recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Beef recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Cheese recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Sauerkraut recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Recipes_with_metric_units|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Casserole recipes|6 servings|40 minutes|3}}
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Israel|Cuisine of Israel]]
Yerushalmi kugel is named after the city of [[w:Jerusalem|Jerusalem]]. Legend has it that it originated in Jerusalem with the followers of the [[w:Vilna Gaon|Vilna Gaon]] in the 18th century.
==Ingredients== *8 oz (200g) [[Cookbook:Noodles|noodles]] ([[Cookbook:Egg noodles|egg noodles]] are prefered, but others work fine as well) *2/3 cup (160g) [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] ([[Cookbook:White sugar|white sugar]] is helpful because it's more obvious when it begins to brown) *4 Tbsp [[Cookbook:Olive oil|olive oil]] *handful of raisins *1-2 tsp [[Cookbook:Pepper|pepper]] *1 tsp [[Cookbook:Cinnamon|cinnamon]] *3 [[Cookbook:Egg|eggs]]
==Instructions== #Boil noodles acording to the instructions and drain. #Heat the olive oil in a frying pan, and add 1/3 cup (80g) of sugar. #Stir continuously until the sugar begins to brown. Remove from heat. #The sugar will continue to brown for a few more minutes, creating a thick caramel. #Add the caramel to the noodles. #Add the sugar, eggs, cinnamon, pepper, and raisins. Stir. #Bake in a pan at 350 (180c) until the top begins to brown (about 40 minutes).
[[Category:Noodle recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Israeli recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Recipes_with_metric_units|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}}
Green Sauce is a dish that originates from the Frankfurt/Main (Hesse, Germany) region.
== Ingredients (four servings) == * 3 to 4 cups (200g/7oz each) of sour cream * milk * 1 tbsp. sunflower oil (or other oil of neutral taste) * 2 tsp. lemon juice * 4 hard-boiled eggs * 10 to 15 large potatoes * one to one and a half empty sour cream cups filled with dill * one to one and a half empty sour cream cups filled with other mixed herbs: chives, parsley, onion leaves, lemon balm, burnet, a small amount of sorrel if available
''(the amounts of herbs could need more precise measurements; this is all I have)''
== Preparation == Mix sour cream, oil and lemon juice and add milk until the mixture takes the consistency of a thick sauce. Chop herbs to very fine bits and mix them into the sauce. Cut hard-boiled eggs to small pieces and add them to the sauce along with some salt and pepper. Leave the sauce in the fridge for about one to one and a half hours.
Boil potatoes and serve hot with the cold sauce. More hard-boiled eggs can also be served along with this.
[[Category:German recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Sauce recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Egg recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Potato recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Sour Cream recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Recipes_with_metric_units|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Dessert recipes|8|Prep: 20 minutes
Cooking: 15-20 minutes|2|}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Dessert|Desserts]] A '''cinnamon bun''' (or a '''cinnamon roll''') is a type of pastry made with cinnamon, sugar and butter. ==Ingredients== ===Pastry=== * 2 [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]]s (480g) [[Cookbook:Flour|all-purpose flour]] * 4 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoon]]s [[Cookbook:Baking powder|baking powder]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoon]] [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * 1/2 [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] (120g) [[Cookbook:Shortening|shortening]] * 3/4 [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] (180ml) [[Cookbook:Milk|milk]] ===Filling=== * 3/4 [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] (180g) [[Cookbook:Brown sugar|brown sugar]] * 1/4 [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] (60g) [[Cookbook:White sugar|white sugar]] * 2 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoon]]s [[Cookbook:Cinnamon|cinnamon]] * [[Cookbook:Pinch|Pinch]] of [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoon]] [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]], melted ===Topping=== *1 [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] (240g) [[Cookbook:Icing sugar|icing sugar]] *1 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoon]] liquid (Cream is recommended, milk and water also work) ==Method== ===Pastry=== #Combine flour, baking powder and salt. [[Cookbook:Cut-in|Cut-in]] shortening. #Add the milk, stirring with a knife until the dough is soft and slightly sticky. #[[Cookbook:Knead|Knead]] the dough until it "springs back" when you push your hand into it. #Roll the dough into a 9" by 13" (23g by 30g) rectangle. Use a 9" by 13" (23g by 30g) baking pan as a mould for the size. ===Filling=== #Brush butter over the dough, leaving about 1/4" (0.75cm) around the edges unbuttered. #Combine brown sugar, white sugar, cinnamon and salt. Sprinkle on buttered dough, leaving about 1/4" around the edges unsprinkled. #Press the sugar mixture down. Roll the dough lengthwise, as tight as you can. #Trim the edges, cut into eight pieces. #Arrange the buns in a small pan, so that all the buns are touching. Bake at 425°F (210c) for 15-20 minutes. ===Topping=== #Combine icing sugar and liquid. Whisk together, spread on buns when they have finished baking. [[Category:Pastry recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Cinnamon recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Bread recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Recipes_with_metric_units|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Halal recipes]]

revision.comment: added some UK-related notes re quantities, prep and variations
revision.text:
{{recipesummary|Soup recipes|8 persons|2 hours|1}}
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of France|Cuisine of France]] | [[Cookbook:Soup|Soup]]
There are few things more versatile or more satisfying than '''Potage Parmentier''' (Leek and Potato Soup) or one of its myriad variations. It’s good freshly-made and better the next day. Hot or cold, it makes a lovely start to dinner; served with some left-over meat, a great lunch. It's a great mid-afternoon pick-me-up, either straight out of the 'fridge or zapped in the microwave.
As delicious as is basic leek-and-potato soup, we often include other vegetables or herbs: broccoli stems, asparagus stalks, a large handful of parsley or cress (pretty much whatever’s in the crisper): the variations are endless. This is one of the classic ways the French utilize left-over or less-than-perfect vegetables bought cheap from the market - a principle of both taste and economy that all would do well to adopt.
You shouldn't be a stickler about using leeks, either: while they have a more subtle flavor than onions, they can be expensive and/or difficult to source out of season. Feel free to use regular onions (the milder yellow/Spanish varieties are best) or use a couple of bunches of scallions (spring onions).
The only rub comes when it’s time to puree the soup. While it can be pureed in a blender, it’s much better to use a food mill. Blenders tend to make the potato starches glue-like and pulverize the woody parts of the other vegetables. The food mill doesn’t change the texture of the potato starch and strains out the vegetable pulp. It takes a little extra muscle, but it’s well worth the effort. Using the chopping blade in a food processor (Cuisinart) will also puree the soup without the potato separating provided the action is pulsed and not overdone, however the mixture should be sieved if woody-cored root vegetables such as turnips or parsnips are used
This recipe makes two quarts of soup, though it's worthwhile to double or triple it; left-overs easily last 7-10 days in the refrigerator, though you’ll probably eat them long before that time.
== Ingredients == * 3 - 4 cups sliced leeks or onions (about 1 lb. or 450g) * 3 - 4 cups (700-900g/2lb) floury potatoes (eg. Idaho, Maris Piper), peeled and thickly sliced * 2 quarts water (a proportion of light chicken or vegetable stock made be used) * 2 tbs. kosher or 1 tb. sea/rock salt * White pepper (ground) to taste * 4 - 6 Tbs. heavy (double) cream * 1 - 2 cups (up to 450g/1lb) vegetables (optional) * 1 - 2 handsful flat-leaf parsley or watercress (optional)
== Preparation == # Peel and thinly slice the ptatoes and onions. If using leeks, remove the roots and dark green leaves; wash twice as long as you think necessary to remove the grit. Thinly slice any optional vegetables or roughly chop any optional herbs. # Place the vegetables, water and salt in a pot and bring to a boil; Lower the heat and gently simmer (partially covered) for 45—50 minutes. The soup is done when you can easily mash the vegetables against the side of the pot. # Puree the soup using a food mill fitted with the fine disc. Optionally, “pulse” it in a blender until just smooth and pass through a fine sieve. # Chill the soup if it is to be served cold or gently reheat it to a simmer. Refrigerate any left-overs. It will keep for days if refrigerated in a covered container as soon as it cools. # Add 1½—2 tsp. cream (or whole milk) per portion just before serving. You’ll need more cream if you’re serving the soup hot or if it’s a bit watery; the idea is to create a smooth, silky puree, but you don’t want the taste or mouth feel of the cream to predominate. Taste and adjust for salt and pepper. # Snipped chives are the classic garniture for leek-and-potato soup. When we include asparagus, we use steamed asparagus tips as a garnish; with broccoli, use steamed broccoli flowerets—you get the idea. Of course, if you’re just pouring a mid-afternoon mug for yourself, who cares how it looks?
== Notes == * Raw vegetables should be added to the soup at the beginning of the cooking time; if using left-over vegetables or herbs, add them after the soup has been cooking for 30—40 minutes, so they cook just long enough to completely warm through. * If using "regular" table salt instead of kosher salt, reduce the amount of salt to 1½ tbs. A chilled soup may require slightly more seasoning which can be added individually to taste. * A combination of young buttery parsnips and mustard-and-cress makes the classic French ''Puree Pasternak''. Potato starch or cornstarch can be used to stabilise the puree which should be milled or sieved. [[Category:Potato recipes|Potage Parmentier]] [[Category:Soup recipes|Potage Parmentier]] [[Category:Leek recipes|Potage Parmentier]] [[Category:French recipes|Potage Parmentier]] [[Category:Recipes_with_metric_units|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{cookwork}} {{recipe}}
It has been said that it's hard to mess up a good steak, but cooking a "good" steak entirely depends on preparation and choice of meat. There are many good cuts of beef for steak, but the best of them will have been dry-aged for some amount of time, and will be well-marbled with fat. Also, a good cut of meat will always taste its best when cooked such that the meat is still pink, even bordering on red (rare or medium-rare). It has also been said that, if a person is prone to order his steak well-done, then he should simply stop ordering steak, as it is clear that he does not enjoy it.
Here are a few recipes for preparing a good ol' fashioned grilled steak.
==Grilled/oven-broiled Steak Recipe==
===Ingredients===
* a choice or prime cut of beef (rib-eye and New York strip are always good choices) * rock salt or coarse sea salt * peppercorns * olive oil
===Method===
Rinse the meat with cold water and dry it with a paper towel. Coat it very lightly with olive oil. Grind the salt and peppercorns into a small bowl (use your judgement as to how much to use), mix them together, and rub this onto the meat, coating both sides. The more salt and pepper you use, the more crust you'll get once it's done, but you may also cover up the natural flavor of the beef.
Heat a cast-iron skillet or grill pan (a non-stick one will work also, but a cast-iron one holds temperature better) on a stove for three to five minutes on high heat, until it is evenly heated. You can add more oil to the pan if you like, but this isn't necessary. While you're doing this, pre-heat your oven to as high a temperature as your pan will take. (For example, the average plastic-handled aluminum non-stick grill pan will only survive up to around 300 degrees F [160c], but a cast iron pan can go higher.)
Put the steak onto the pan, and let it cook for about two to three minutes. There will be a lot of smoke; if you have an over-the-range exhaust vent, turn it on max. Maybe open a window or two as well.
After about two or three minutes, flip the meat over, and cook for another two to three minutes.
After that's done, put the entire works (pan plus meat) into the oven, and let it sit for another two to four minutes. (Note that all these times are approximate, and will depend heavily on how well you want your steak cooked, as well as the temperature the pan can withstand, and the thickness and quality of the meat. It'll take a little practice to get right, but you can cheat a little by using an instant-read thermometer. 130 degrees F [50c] is medium-rare.)
Remove the steak promptly from the oven, put it on a plate, and let it sit for one or two minutes so that the juices inside the steak can re-distribute through the meat. Add red wine, some rice or potatoes, and enjoy.

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the Philippines|Cuisine of the Philippines]] {{recipesummary|Stew recipes|10|2 hours|2}}
'''Dinuguan''' (Pork Blood Stew) or '''Dinardaraan''' in Ilocano is a [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the Philippines|Filipino]] dish usually made from the blood, entrails and meat of a pig. It is sometimes known as "[[Cookbook:chocolate|chocolate]] meat" as the stew has a thick chocolate-like color and consistency. The name "dinuguan" is derived from the Filipino word "dugo", meaning blood. Likewise, in Ilocano, "dinardaraan" is derived from the from "dara", meaning blood. Dinuguan has more liquid, while dinardaraan is drier.
==Ingredients== *3 [[Cookbook:cup|cup]]s (700g) cubed boneless [[Cookbook:pork|pork]] butt with fat (½-inch cubes) *3 [[Cookbook:tablespoon|tablespoon]]s [[Cookbook:Lard|lard]] or [[Cookbook:Peanut Oil|peanut oil]] *½ cup (120ml) [[Cookbook:Vinegar|vinegar]] mixed with 1 cup (240ml) [[Cookbook:Water|water]] and 1 tablespoon [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] *1 medium-sized yellow [[Cookbook:onion|onion]], peeled and sliced *1½ cups (360ml) [[Cookbook:pork blood|pork blood]] (Ideally from [[Cookbook:cuisine of Vietnam|Vietnam]]ese, Filipino or Western European markets) *3 cloves [[Cookbook:garlic|garlic]], peeled and crushed *2 hot [[Cookbook:Jalapeño|jalapeño peppers]], seeded and chopped
== Procedure == #Place the pork in a 4-quart (560ml) covered stove-top [[Cookbook:Casserole|casserole dish]] and add the vinegar mixture. Bring to a [[Cookbook:Boil|boil]] and reduce the heat. #Cook, covered, for about an hour, until the pork is tender. Make sure that the liquid doesn't dry out. Add more water if necessary. # Heat a [[Cookbook:Frying Pan|frying pan]] and add the lard or oil. # When the oil is hot enough, [[Cookbook:Sautéing|sauté]] the onion and garlic until the onion appears translucent. Remove from heat. #Add the oil, garlic, and onion to the pork and continue cooking for 5 minutes. #[[Cookbook:Purée|Purée]] the pork blood in a [[Cookbook:Food Processor|food processor]]. #Add the blood to the pork gradually while stirring the mixture. Bring to a boil. #Add the chopped pepper and [[Cookbook:Simmering|simmer]] uncovered to reduce the sauce until desired thickness is achieved. Keep covered and serve hot.
This is most often served over [[Cookbook:rice|rice]] or [[Cookbook:puto|puto]] (sweet steamed rice [[Cookbook:muffin|muffin]]s).
[[Category:Filipino recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Stew recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Pork recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Recipes with metric units|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{cookwork}} {{recipe}}
'''Eintopf''' (German, lit.: ''one pot'' - because only one pot is needed for preparing it) is a traditional [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Germany|German]] [[Cookbook:stew|stew]] which can consist of a great number of different ingredients.
Most commonly, ingredients include [[Cookbook:pork|pork]], [[Cookbook:beef|beef]] or [[Cookbook:chicken|chicken]] meat along with a variety of assorted vegetables such as [[Cookbook:carrot|carrot]]s, [[Cookbook:peas|peas]], [[Cookbook:beans|beans]] (often [[Cookbook:french beans|french beans]]), [[Cookbook:potato|potato]]es, [[Cookbook:cauliflower|cauliflower]], [[Cookbook:celery|celery]], [[Cookbook:onion|onion]]s, [[Cookbook:asparagus|asparagus]], or [[Cookbook:garlic|garlic]]. To bring out the flavor of these ingredients, numerous different kinds of [[Cookbook:herbs|kitchen herb]]s like [[Cookbook:parsley|parsley]], [[Cookbook:lovage|lovage]] or [[Cookbook:chive|chive]] may be added, as well as [[Cookbook:salt|salt]], [[Cookbook:pepper|pepper]] and other spices.
[[Cookbook:Beef stock|Beef stock]], [[Cookbook:chicken broth|chicken broth]] or [[Cookbook:vegetable stock|vegetable stock]] are often used as a foundation, to which the other ingredients are gradually added. Eintopf is often served with bread and [[Cookbook:butter|butter]]; some people also top their Eintopf with a dash of grated [[Cookbook:cheese|cheese]].
Many different regional recipes for Eintopf are known in Germany.
[[Category:German recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Stew recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Salad recipes||20 minutes|2}}
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Side dishes | Side dishes]]
A '''Spinach Salad''' recipe I originally got from my mother.
== Ingredients ==
* 1 lb [[Cookbook:spinach|spinach]] - ''Must be dry'' * 3 hard boiled [[Cookbook:eggs|eggs]] * 6 strips vegetarian bacon (or bacon bits) * 1 [[Cookbook:Onion|red onion]]
===Dressing=== *¾ cup (180ml) [[Cookbook:olive oil|olive oil]] *¼ cup (60ml) [[Cookbook:Wine vinegar|red wine vinegar]] *¼ tsp [[Cookbook:pepper|pepper]] *¼ tsp [[Cookbook:Mustard|dry mustard]] *½ tsp [[Cookbook:salt|salt]] (optional) *1 TBL [[Cookbook:Worcestershire Sauce|Worcestershire Sauce]] *1.5 tsp [[Cookbook:paprika|paprika]] *2 tsp [[Cookbook:sugar|sugar]]
== Procedure ==
# Chop the eggs and add to the spinach in a large bowl. # Slice the red onion and add to spinach. # Combine all ingredients for the dressing. Mix well. # Pour the dressing on top of the salad, mix, and top with vegetarian bacon strips or bacon bits.
== Notes == # When mixing the salad, the egg yolks will tend to crumble and disappear into the salad - this is normal. # Add the dressing and bacon bits at the last minute. # If you can't find Worcestershire sauce, you can use [[Cookbook:soy sauce|soy sauce]] in a pinch.
[[Category:Spinach recipes|Spinach Salad]] [[Category:Salad recipes|Spinach Salad]] [[Category:Egg recipes|Spinach Salad]] [[Category:Recipes_with_metric_units|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}}
==Ingredients== *2 to 3 Big Carrots *4 pods Cardamom *1 pinch Cinnamon powder *2 to 3 tea spoons Sugar *1 pinch Salt *1 table spoon Butter *1/2 cup (120g) Cashew Nuts(Broken) *1/2 cup (120g) Raisins *1 cup (240ml) Milk
==Procedure== # Wash the Cashews and Raisins and keep them ready. # Cut off the blemished ends of the Carrots, wash them, and then peel them. # Grate the carrots, and empty the grated carrots into a saucepan. # Add the Cashews, Raisins, Salt, Sugar, Cardamom, Cinnamon and Milk. # Heat the saucepan and bring the contents to a boil, while mixing. # When the milk has mostly evaporated you are done. # Serve with a sprinkling of Cinnamon powder on top.
[[Category:Indian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Cashew recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Raisin recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Pudding and Custard recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Cardamom recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Dessert recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Recipes_with_metric_units|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary |Category = Indian recipes |Time = 15 minutes |Rating = 2 }} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of India|Cuisine of India]]
==Ingredients== *½ litre (1 pint) [[Cookbook:Yogurt|yoghurt]] *1 teaspoon [[Cookbook:Chickpea Flour|besan]] (Indian chickpea flour) *2 to 3 teaspoons [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] *1 pinch [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] *1 tablespoon [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]] *½ teaspoon [[Cookbook:Cumin|jeera seeds]] *1 inch piece of fresh [[Cookbook:Ginger|ginger]] *1 [[Cookbook:Chili Pepper|green chilli]]
==Procedure== #Mix the yogurt, chickpea flour, sugar, salt, grated fresh ginger and chopped green chilli. #Heat and bring to a boil with continuous stirring. #Taste and add more sugar or salt as needed. It should be sour, salty and sweet. #When it's ready to serve, fry the jeera seeds in the butter and pour the mixture into the Kuddi, mix well and serve.
[[Category:Soup recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Indian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Dairy recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Chickpea recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Gluten-free recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Low-GI recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Recipes_with_metric_units|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

revision.comment: /* Caramel Sauce */ Add the bits from Science
revision.text:
{{cookwork}} {{recipe}} __TOC__ Caramel is a form of sugar that is used in candies, baked goods, desserts, dips, sauces and other prepared food products. === The Science of Caramel === Essentially, caramel is melted sugar. As sugar increases in temperature, it reacts in a process similar to burning that results in the creation of a wide variety of complex molecules. These molecules provide the deep, rich flavors and colors that make caramel so special. There are two basic ways to make caramel: the dry method and the wet method. The dry method, which involves slowly heating sugar until it melts, is more difficult. The more commonly used wet method is easier and does not require any special tools. In the wet method, granulated sugar is dissolved in water, then boiled until the water starts to evaporate. As the water escapes, the solution passes through a series of stages that indicates the ratio of water and sugar. This ratio is directly proportionate to the temperature so if you understand the stages, you do not need a candy thermometer. Nevertheless, use of a thermometer minimizes the handling of the (very) hot mixture. The stages of a sugar solution are generally described by the solution's behavior when dropped into cold water:
  • Thread Stage (230°F) - the solution thickens into syrupy threads when you pull a spoon out.
  • Soft Ball Stage (234°F) - the solution can be pressed into a soft gooey ball. Used to make soft chewy candies like taffy.
  • Hard Ball Stage (250°F) - the solution can be pressed into a dense, slightly malleable ball. Used to make harder chewy candies.
  • Soft Crack Stage (270°F) - the solution solidifies into a glass-like solid that slowly bends under light pressure.
  • Hard Crack Stage (300°F) - the solution solidifies into a hard glass-like solid that breaks or cracks under pressure. Used to make hard candies and brittles.
  • '''Caramel Stage''' (310°F) - An advanced crack stage, defined by the development of an amber color that becomes tan, brown and eventually dark brown as the temperature continues to rise. Also defined by the development of caramel flavors which becomes deeper, less sweet and more bitter as it darkens.
  • Burned Stage (350°F) - The sugar is completely oxidized (burned) and turns black. It is inedible.
As the water evaporates, the solution becomes super-saturated (contains more dissolved solid than can normally be held by water). As a result, the sugar will want to re-crystalize. Once the sugar is dissolved, do not disturb or contaminate the pot or it may spontaneously crystallize into crunchy "candy" (yech) and you will have to start over. Adding a little corn syrup can help prevent crystallization because it is a different type of sugar. Caramelized sugar by itself solidifies to a glass-like consistency. For a more usable consistency liquid and fat are added. The ingredients listed in the recipes below result in thick but workable products that soften significantly when warmed. By using less liquid and fat, you can increase the thickness so that the caramel can be used for dipping apples, making chewy candy, nut brittles, or even art. == Caramel Sauce == The softer caramel products, such as this recipe for caramel sauce, contain fat and liquid in addition to the caramelized sugar. To create the texture of caramel sauce, you need a 1:1 ratio of fat and liquid. In this recipe, heavy cream (40% fat) is used along with butter to achieve the 1:1 fat:liquid ratio. If you want to substitute milk you will need to use less milk and more butter to keep the ratio. You can also substitute soy-milk and margarine to make a vegan caramel sauce, but make sure to keep the fat:liquid ratio. This recipe makes approximately 6 cups of caramel sauce. You can easily halve this recipe if you wish. It takes 30-60 minutes depending how quickly you are evaporating the water. If sealed in clean [[canning]] jars, the sauce can be stored for 3 months without refrigeration. Or store refrigerated for up to 6 months. Ingredients
  • 2 Cups Water
  • 4 Cups Sugar
  • 2 Tbsp Corn Syrup (optional)
  • Pinch Salt
  • 2 Cups Heavy Whipping Cream
  • 1/2 Cup (1 stick) Unsalted Butter, chopped into 1" cubes
Safety
  • Adding liquid to sugar that is over 300°F is dangerous! Some of the liquid will immediately flash to super-hot steam. To avoid steam burns, stay back from the pot and pour liquids at arms length. Use an oven mitt for your hand.
  • When you add your liquid to the hot sugar, it will boil violently. To avoid messy and dangerous boil-overs, a 2.5 quart heavy bottomed sauce pan or pot is the minimum, but 3-4 quarts is recommended
  • Use a heat proof spatula or spoon such as wood or silicone.
Directions
Dissolve the water, sugar and corn syrup over medium high heat until fully dissolved. [[Image:Caramel_sugar_water_th.jpg|none]]
Stop stirring and let the solution boil over medium heat. Check on the solution every 5 minutes. You will see the bubbles slow down and get larger. When the bubbles begin to reach 1/2" to 3/4" start monitoring the solution frequently. [[Image:Caramel_soft_ball_stage_th.jpg|none]]
When the solution begins to turn amber, get your cream and butter and watch it constantly. [[Image:Caramel_crack_stage_th.jpg|none]]
When the solution has turned a shade of caramel that you like (darker is deeper and will start to take on a little bitterness), step back and add the cream at arms length, stirring constantly and scraping the sides of the pan. [[Image:Caramel_added_cream_th.jpg|none]]
Add the butter and stir until incorporated. Pour the sauce into a serving dish for immediate serving with bread, drizzled on ice cream, as a garnish or for use in other desserts. [[Image:Caramel_Added_butter2_th.jpg|none]]
If you desire, follow standard canning procedures and distribute into canning jars. Allow to cool until the buttons are depressed. Any jars with buttons that are not depressed should be refrigerated and consumed first. To reheat the caramel sauce, microwave the jars (without covers) for 10-30 seconds depending how soft and hot you want it. [[Image:Caramel_filled_jars_th.jpg|none]] === Other Caramel Options === The following are all variations that can be made at different stages of the recipe above. Simple Syrup The first step in the recipe was to dissolve two parts sugar in one part water. This creates a simple syrup, perfect for sweetening cold drinks (e.g. Iced Tea) without having to wait for granulated sugar to dissolve. Caramel Chews Replace the cream with 3/4 Cup Half & Half. Pour the hot mixture onto a silicone mat or parchment paper to cool. When it is cool enough to handle, fold and knead the caramel a few times, then break into bite size pieces. Allow to cool completely before wrapping individually. Turtles Replace the cream with 3/4 Cup Half & Half. Pour the hot mixture over 4 cups of your favorite nut on a silicone mat or parchment paper to cool. When it is cool enough to handle, fold and knead the caramel until the nuts are fully distributed, then break into bite size pieces. Melt chocolate over a double boiler or in the microwave and dip the turtles or simply drizzle chocolate on top. Toffee Instead of cream, use 7 sticks of butter (a total of 8 sticks or 4 cups, so you have equal parts butter and sugar). Mix in chopped nuts if desired. Pour onto a silicone mat or parchment paper or molds. After cool drizzle or dip with chocolate and chopped nuts. Nut Brittle Do not use any cream or butter. Stir in 1/2 tsp. baking soda (optional), then pour the molten caramel over 4 cups of your favorite nuts on a silicone mat or parchment paper and let it cool. When it has reached room temperature, break it up with a mallet or by dropping the sheet on the counter. Wrap and store in an air-tight container. Sugar Art You can do this at any point during the hard crack or caramel stages. Remove the sugar from the heat and allow to cool for one minute. Using a spoon, let the syrup drip off. If it drips in globs, let it cool longer. If it drips in a continuous stream, you can start making art. Drizzle the syrup in patterns over a silicone mat or parchment paper and allow to cool, then carefully peel off. Or, spray bowls and other (clean) objects with cooking spray and drizzle the syrup to create domes and other shapes. Allow to cool to room temperature, then serve soon or store in an air tight container. These will eventually soften and droop from humidity in the air. === References === Scientific theories and explanations based on information from Good Eats by Alton Brown on the Food Network. *[http://www.altonbrown.com/ Alton Brown's official site] *[http://www.foodtv.com/food/show_ea FoodTV.com: ''Good Eats''] Images and Recipes taken from the DIY sections available from www.filtsai.com *[http://www.filtsai.com/cooking/caramel/ filtsai.com: 'Caramel Sauce'] *[http://www.filtsai.com/cooking/pecan_turtles/ filtsai.com: 'Homemade Caramel Turtles'] == PURE fudge © Caramel == Here is the recipe we use at PURE fudge© for our caramel. We have experimented for a while now, and this one seems to work best in even the most humid weather. Caramel is hard to make, it takes patience and practice. Caramel likes fat, so use real butter, and use cream if you can afford it. Milk is a good substitute but you have to use WHOLE milk, not skim or 2%. The other thing to remember is that you are CARMELIZING the sugar, so you need a hot temperature once you get going. Caramel will "spit" as it boils so wear long sleeves and use a long spoon to stir with. NEVER cook caramel naked... just a bad idea. Temperature is a funny thing with caramel. If you want a caramel sauce, cook it to about 230. If you want a hard candy, cook it to about 255 - 260. This recipe is for making our Artisan Caramel Apples, so it gets cooked to 248 exactly in the PURE fudge kitchens. When cool it is very firm but chewy, when it cools to about 180 degrees it is perfect for dipping. === Equipment ===
  • Candy Thermometer
  • LARGE saucepan or pot
  • Long handled wooden spoon
  • High Temperature Spatula (to get all the caramel out of the pot)
=== Ingredients ===
  • 1 stick of butter (1/4 pound - 110g)
  • 2 cups (480g) of Pure Cane Sugar (always use Pure Cane Sugar)
  • 1 1/2 cups (360ml) Heavy Cream OR Whole Milk (not skim or 2%)
  • 1 Cup (240ml) Light Corn Syrup
  • 1 - 2 teaspoons Vanilla
=== Directions === Use a large saucepan or pot,the liquid will boil up to about 3 times the amount of warm liquid, so use a large cooking vessel. NEVER cover the pot with a lid. the moisture will turn it into taffy or destroy it. All temperatures are Fahrenheit. On a low heat
  • Melt the butter
  • pour in the cream or milk
If you are using milk, heat on '''LOW''' for about 20 minutes so all the fats mix together, stiring occasionally. Remember, better too low heat at this stage than too high. If you scorch the milk or cream, you have to start over. If you are using cream, you can just go right to the next step. Next add
  • Corn Syrup
Let this cook into the mix for about 5 minutes, stir about once a minute for 15 seconds. Then add
  • Sugar
Stir this in until completely dissolved. Turn the heat up to medium at this point and continue to stir for about 5 minutes until you are certain the sugar is completely dissolved. It should look milky but feel smooth when you are stirring it. Turn the heat up to just below high on a gas range. Stir for 30 seconds, every 2 minutes. When the tempature reached 248 degrees take the pot and place the bottom of it in cold water to stop the mixture from continuing to cook. Keep stirring the entire time it is cooling. When it starts to thicken a little add
  • Vanilla
One teaspoon is fine, if you really like vanilla, you can add up to 2 teaspoons. Remember, vanilla has a high alcohol content so don't add it when the mixture is really hot, or it will just all burn up and you wont get any of the flavor. === Finishing up === If you are making apples, you can go ahead and start dipping once the tempature reaches around 180. Use clean refrigerated apples for a nice glaze. I hope this works for you, I know it works for us and don't be afraid to play around with it a little either. Just remember to keep the amounts of sugars and liquids and drys at about the same percentages. Regards, [http://www.PureFudge.com Patti at PURE fudge] [[category:Gluten-free recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[category:Gluten-free recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Recipes_with_metric_units|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary | Category = Albanian recipes | Servings = 4 or 5 }} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Albania|Cuisine of Albania]]
'''Hasude''' is an [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Albania|Albanian]] [[Cookbook:Dessert|dessert]].
== Ingredients == * 1 cup (240g) [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] * 1¼ cup (300g) [[Cookbook:Cornstarch|cornstarch]] * 6-7 tablespoons [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]] * 2 cups (480ml) [[Cookbook:Water|water]]
== Procedure == # Begin to dissolve the butter and add in the cornstarch in a pot while heating on a medium to high setting. # Continue to pour in the starch and cook until the mass becomes of yellow color. During this time also pour in some sugar. # Separately prepare a syrup using the remaining sugar and water. # After it is done cooking, shape the mass using a spoon or plastic shapes and pour the syrup on top.
[[Category:Albanian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Dessert recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Recipes_with_metric_units|{{PAGENAME}}]]

[[Image:Puri.jpg|right|thumb|Puri]] {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of India|Cuisine of India]] | [[Cookbook:Bread|Bread]]
'''Puri''', also '''Poori''' - an [[Cookbook:Cuisine of India|Indian]] [[Cookbook:Bread|bread]].
==Ingredients==
* 2oz / 60g [[Cookbook:Whole Wheat|whole-wheat flour]] * 2oz / 60g [[Cookbook:Flour#Wheat Flour|plain white flour]] * 2 oz fine [[Cookbook:Semolina|semolina]] * ¼ tsp. [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * 1 tbs [[Cookbook:Vegetable Oil|vegetable oil]] for the dough * about 500ml / a pint of vegetable oil for deep frying the pooris * [[Cookbook:Water|water]] to mix the dough
==Procedure==
===Dough Preparation=== # Put all the dry ingredients into a bowl. # Add salt and dribble the tbs. oil. # Mix well. Add water gradually to make it a stiff dough. # Knead well for a few minutes. # Cover the dough and leave to rest for about half an hour.
===Frying Puri=== # Pour the oil for deep frying in a wok and heat the oil. # Meanwhile divide the dough into 8 small balls and roll into small circle. (about 3" [7.5cm] in diameter) # You can use a bit of hot oil to roll the dough so it will not stick to the surface. # When the oil is hot (test - if you put a tiny dough in the oil it should come up straight away), lay the flatted dough over the oil, press the top slightly with the slotted spoon until it inflates itself, and turn to other side. Adjust the flame as necessary. # If it sinks quickly to the bottom of the wok, the oil is not hot enough (puri will absorb too much oil. ) It should balloon within a few seconds. # Remove from oil after the puri turn golden/light brown color and place on a wire rack or kitchen paper towel for excess oil to drain.
==Notes, tips and variations== * For chapattis dough, don't use semolina and plain flour. Only use whole meal flour, salt and oil.
{{Wikipedia|Puri (food)}}
[[Category:Indian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Bread recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Recipes with metric units|{{PAGENAME}}]]
