{{Recipesummary| |Category=Beef recipes |Servings=2-3 |Time=45 minutes |Rating=2 }} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Meat_Recipes|Meat recipes]]
== My Shepherd's Pie ==
Shepherd's Pie is a dish with either lamb or beef (although the beef version is generally known as Cottage Pie), and potato. The ingredients are in no way precise and you can substitute the vegetables with whatever you have in your cupboard. Be creative!
== Ingredients: ==
* 100g minced meat * clove of garlic * 4 large potatoes * one carrot * some peas * some sweetcorn * mixed vegetables * small amount of tomato ketchup * beef stock cube or gravy * 5g of flour * 10ml of water * 30ml of milk * 30g of butter or margerine * 5ml of olice oil or cooking oil
== Procedure: ==
* Peel and chop the potatoes. Boil the potatoes for 20 minutes whilst preparing the rest of the meal. * Cut the minced beef and add the chopped garlic. * Next gently heat some olive oil in a frying pan and add the meat and garlic * Then add the vegetables, ketchup, stock cube (or gravy) and cook on a very low heat for 5 minutes * Now add a touch of flour and the water and mix well. * Cook the mixture for about 25 minutes and stir every few minutes * Once the potatoes are ready drain them, add a touch of milk and butter (or margerine) and mash * Pour the mixture into an oven dish then add the mashed potatoes on top. Cover all of the meat mixture * Cook in the oven at 200c for about 15-20 minutes and take it out when the potatoes are turning golden.
[[Category:Recipes_with_metric_units|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{Recipesummary|Bread recipes|4-6|20 minutes|2}}
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of India|Indian Cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Bread Recipes|Bread]]
[[Image:Baati.jpg|200px|Baati with dal and shrikhand.]]
'''Baati''' is a hard, unleavened bread cooked in desert areas of Rajasthan, Malwa, and Gujarat in North [[Cookbook:Cuisine of India|India]]. It is prized there for its exceptionally long life and high energy content, as well as the minimal quantity of water required in its preparation.
==Ingredients== * 1 pound (450g) [[Cookbook:Wheat flour|wheat flour]] * 1/2 teaspoon [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * 3 tablespoons oil * 1 1/2 teaspoons [[Cookbook:Ghee|ghee]] (for serving)
==Procedure== # Mix the flour and salt. # Put about a cup of the mix in a small bowl and add a little oil, mixing it in well and breaking up any lumps. # Pour in water about a tablespoon at a time and keep kneading with your hands. You only need three or four tablespoons, but you must knead the dough very hard to make it stick together in a ball. The more compact the dough, the better and denser the baati will be. # Let the balls sit for 5 minutes. # Flatten out each ball with first your hands and then a rolling pin until they are smooth discs 4 inches (10cm) across and 1/2 (1.25cm) inch thick. # Cook in a dry metal pan on a low flame. # Flip once when the bottom begins to harden, then pinch all over with two fingers so the dough is not too thick and has a bumpy texture on one side. # Check the bottom until it browns in spots, then remove the baati and place it upside-down on a grate or pan with holes in it. This will blacken the top a little, especially on the tops of the pinched bumps. # To serve, drizzle liberally with ghee and accompany with a dhal or vegetable.
Makes 4-6 Baati
==Notes, tips, and variations== * Variation: Sprinkle [[Cookbook:Powdered sugar|powdered sugar]] on after the ghee for a sweet snack.
[[Category:Bread recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Indian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Recipes_with_metric_units|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Vegetarian cuisine|Vegetarian cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Sandwiches|Sandwiches]] {{recipesummary|Sandwich recipes|1|5 minutes|1}}
This recipe is meant to show you how to make the peanut butter sandwich to end all others.
==Ingredients== * Two slices of bread. * Butter * Peanut butter. * Honey. * More Butter * Preserves. * Super extra cold milk.
==Instructions== * Toast and butter bread * Mix Peanut butter, honey and butter and spread over one slice of toasted bread. * Spread preserves over other side. * Put halves of sandwich together. * Cut in half and serve with milk * Enjoy!
==Variations & Tips== * If the peanut butter is too sloppy, try spreading the honey thin on both slices of bread and omit the extra butter. * Rasins may be added. They have a honey-like flavor, which will compliment the honey in the sandwich * Bananas are traditional side items. They go well with peanut butter. * These directions can be variated by preference.
==Warnings== * Beware! The peanut butter mixture is sloppy.
==External links== [http://www.wikihow.com/Make-Homemade-Peanut-Butter Make Peanut Butter]
[[Category:Sandwich recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Peanut Butter recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Recipes_with_metric_units|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Vegetarian Recipes|3-4|15 minutes|1}}
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Vegetarian cuisine|Vegetarian cuisine]]
Cauliflower with Breadcrumbs is a popular dish and side-dish in Poland and many parts of Central Europe. It's really simple to make.
==Ingredients==
* 1 head of cauliflower * 50ml of butter * 2-3 tablespoons of breadcrumb * optional 0.5 teaspoon of fresh dill
==Preparation== #Boil the cauliflower for about 10 minutes. #Melt some butter in the oven or a microwave. #Mix the butter with the breadcrumbs and add dill if you choose. #Drain the cauliflower and add the mixture on top. #Eat!
[[Category:Vegetarian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Recipes_with_metric_units|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Fermented food recipes||prep: 45 minutes
ferment: at least 1 week|2}} {{recipe}} | [[:Category:Fermented food recipes|Fermented food recipes]] '''Sauerkraut''' is a traditional [[Cookbook:Fermentation|fermented]] vegetable food made from cabbage. This is a basic recipe that produces a tangy sauerkraut with live bacteria that provide [[w:probiotic|probiotic]] goodness. No cooking is required. ==Ingredients== * 1 large (2.5 [[Cookbook:Kg|kg]] - 5 lb) fresh [[Cookbook:Cabbage|cabbage]] * 2-3 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoons]] [[Cookbook:Salt|non-iodised salt]] ==Preparation== # Clean and dry a large (3 litre) preserves jar or crock, chopping board, and large bowls if needed # [[Cookbook:Quarter|Quarter]] the cabbage and remove the core # [[Cookbook:Slice|Slice]] the cabbage finely or thickly, as you prefer # Optional: bruise the sliced cabbage by beating with a [[Cookbook:Rolling Pin|rolling pin]] or [[Cookbook:Mortar and Pestle|mortar and pestle]] # Layer the cabbage in the jar or crock, sprinkling salt in between layers # Pack tightly into the jar, leaving 1cm space at the top; don't seal the jar yet # Juice should rise to top of jar as you tightly pack the cabbage in; if not, add a little [[Cookbook:Water|chlorine-free water]] ==Fermentation== Don't seal the jar while it is fermenting, as it will build up gas pressure and might break the jar. Just cover with a cloth, or cling-wrap. Set the jar in a bowl or on a plate, so that any juice that might overflow will be collected and won't make a mess. The sauerkraut will be fermented in about a week. Wipe any excess liquid from around the jar, and put the lid on tightly before moving it to a cool place (e.g. the refrigerator) to mature. It is ready to eat after the first week, but will improve with age and as the bacteria slowly consume the more complex sugars in the cabbage. ==Notes, tips, and variations== *The salt used should be non-iodised salt if possible - e.g. pickling salt, kosher salt. This is because the iodine in iodised table salt will inhibit the fermentation a little. Use what you've got, but best results will be obtained without the iodine. *Add other vegetables, fruits, or spices for variations, e.g. **[[Cookbook:Juniper Berry|juniper berries]] **[[Cookbook:Pineapple|diced pineapple]] **[[Cookbook:Onion|onion]] **[[Cookbook:Chili|chili]] **[[Cookbook:Grater|grated]] [[Cookbook:Carrot|carrot]] *The cabbage can be quickly sliced to a regular thickness by using a [[Cookbook:Mandoline|mandoline]]. Fingers can be sliced just as quickly... ==See also== *[[Cookbook:Kimchi|Kimchi]] *[[Cookbook:Kraut|Kraut]] ==External links== {{Wikipedia|Sauerkraut}} *[http://www.splammo.net/foodapplmicro/applkraut.html The Sauerkraut Fermentation] *[http://www.wildfermentation.com/resources.php?page=sauerkraut Wild Fermentation: Making Sauerkraut] [[Category:Sauerkraut recipes|*]] [[Category:Fermented food recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegan recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Raw recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Recipes with metric units|{{PAGENAME}}]]

revision.comment: /* External links */ rm link - en wikibooks, German-language link (and may be SPAM)
revision.text:
{{recipesummary|Fermented food recipes|5|prep: 5 minutes
ferment: 24 hours|1}} {{recipe}} | [[:Category:Fermented food recipes|Fermented food recipes]] '''Kefir''' is a fermented milk drink originating in the [[w:Caucasus|Caucasus]]. It is liquid, thicker than milk, sour, and a little yeasty. It can have small amounts of alcohol, but typically much less than ½% by volume. It is traditionally fermented using '''kefir grains''', a symbiotic culture of yeasts and bacteria passed down from generation to generation. ==Ingredients== * 50 [[Cookbook:Gram|grams]] (1¾ oz) of kefir grains (see note) * 500 [[Cookbook:ML|ml]] (1 pint) fresh [[Cookbook:Milk|milk]] (see note) ==Preparation== # Remove kefir grains from previous batch of starter, using a [[Cookbook:Sieve|sieve]] or [[Cookbook:Colander|colander]]. # Shake kefir grains to remove excess kefir. Rinsing is not necessary (but optionally, rinse in fresh milk) # Place kefir grains in glass jar or jug with fresh milk. Generally, keep a ratio of kefir grains to milk of about 1:10 # Set aside to ferment at room temperature for up to 24 hours (see note) ==Notes, tips, and variations== [[Image:Kefirpilze.jpg|right|thumb|250px|Kefir grains]] * Kefir grains are gelatinous lumps. You can often get them for free, or for the cost of postage - see link below. Once you've got some, they grow in the milk until you have enough to give to someone else. * As an alternative to kefir grains, some health food shops carry a powdered kefir starter. This will never make kefir grains, but the powdered starter will make good kefir and is easier for some people to manage. * Milk can be almost any milk from a mammal. Full cream cow's milk is best, but kefir can be made from low-fat milk, goat's milk, or sheep's milk. * Non-milk kefir can be made from sugary water, fruit juice, coconut juice, rice milk, or soy milk. However, the kefir grains will stop growing in these liquids, so it is best to only use excess kefir grains or powdered kefir starter for this. * In warm weather, kefir will ferment very quickly and can become separated into [[Cookbook:Curds|curds]] and [[Cookbook:Whey|whey]]. An easy way to prevent this is to start the new batch of kefir at night, when it's cooler, and put the fermenting kefir into the [[Cookbook:Refrigerator|refrigerator]] during the daytime when it gets hot. * In cold weather, kefir will ferment very slowly. Put the jar or jug in a warm place, but not where it will get too warm (see above!) ==Kefir as leavening agent== Kefir can be used as a [[Cookbook:Leavening agent|leavening agent]] when baking [[Cookbook:Bread|bread]], because it contains active yeasts and bacteria. It can be used directly in a recipe, by replacing the yeast and half the water with kefir. Recipes that specify [[Cookbook:Buttermilk|buttermilk]] or [[Cookbook:Yogurt|yoghurt]] can be made just as well (or better!) with kefir. Alternatively, kefir can be used to create a [[Cookbook:Sourdough Starter|sourdough starter]]. Add ½ teaspoonful of kefir to ½ cup flour and ½ cup water, mix well, and set aside to ferment for 12 - 24 hours. ==External links== {{Wikipedia|Kefir}} *[http://www.torontoadvisors.com/Kefir/kefir-list.php Where to find free kefir grains] *[http://www.webaware.com.au/ferment/finding_kefir.php Kefir grains for free] [[Category:Fermented food recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Beverage recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Milk recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Leavening Agents|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Recipes with metric units|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Bread|Bread]] {{recipesummary|Bread recipes|8|2 Hours|3}}
==Ingredients==
* 1 [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] [[Cookbook:Cornmeal|corn meal]] * 1 cup all-purpose [[Cookbook:flour|flour]] * 4 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoon]] [[Cookbook:Baking Powder|baking powder]] * ½ teaspoon [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * 1 cup [[Cookbook:Milk|milk]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Egg|egg]] * ¼ cup [[Cookbook:shortening|shortening]] * 1 tsp-¼ cup chopped [[Cookbook:Jalapeño|jalapeños]], to taste. * ¼ cup [[Cookbook:sugar|sugar]] ''optional'' * ½ of a 15 [[Cookbook:Ounce|ounce]] can [[Cookbook:Corn|whole corn]], drained ''optional''
==Procedure==
# Preheat [[Cookbook:Oven|oven]] to [[Cookbook:Oven_temperatures|425°F]]. Grease an 8 inch [[Cookbook:Pots and Pans|baking pan]]. # Combine corn meal, flour, baking powder, salt, and sugar in a large mixing bowl. # Add egg, sugar, and shortening. # [[Cookbook:Beat|Beat]] until fairly smooth; about a minute. # [[Cookbook:Baking|Bake]] for 20-25 minutes or until a toothpick inserted in center comes out clean. ''If corn added to batter, increase time ~50%'' # Serve hot!
[[Category:Bread recipes]] [[Category:Corn recipes]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Bread|Bread]] {{recipesummary|Bread recipes|14 Corn Sticks|1 Hour|2}}
==Ingredients==
*1 [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] (240ml) [[Cookbook:Cornmeal|cornmeal]] *1 cup (240ml) all-purpose [[Cookbook:flour|flour]] *4 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|tsp]] [[Cookbook:Baking Powder|baking powder]] *½ tsp [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] *1 cup (240ml) [[Cookbook:Milk|milk]] *1 [[Cookbook:Egg|egg]] *¼ cup (60ml) [[Cookbook:shortening|shortening]] *¼ cup (60ml) [[Cookbook:sugar|sugar]] (optional) *½ of a 15 ounce (about 150g) can whole [[Cookbook:corn|corn]], drained (optional)
==Procedure==
# Preheat oven to 425°F (220°C). Grease a corn stick pan well, and preheat with oven. ''Cast iron works best.'' # Combine corn meal, flour, baking powder, salt, and sugar in a large mixing bowl. # Add egg, sugar, and shortening. # [[Cookbook:Beat|Beat]] until fairly smooth, about a minute. # Pour into HOT, well-greased cornstick pan. # [[Cookbook:Baking|Bake]] for 15-20 minutes until golden brown. ''If corn is added to batter, increase time a little.'' # Serve hot and buttered.
[[Category:Bread recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Corn recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Dessert recipes|Varies|3 hours|4}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|United States]] | [[Cookbook:Holiday Recipes|Holiday Recipes]] | [[Cookbook:Bread Recipes|Bread Recipes]] | [[Cookbook:Desserts|Desserts]] '''Grandma-Ag's Orange Bread''' - ''This bread is a fond memory of my childhood, visiting Agnes Frances Primm, my Grandma-Ag. As a young adult, I tried to duplicate the recipe, and unable, I went back and begged her for the secrets of it. When I asked her how long it had taken to develop the tricky recipe, she flattened my ego by telling me she'd gotten it out of a magazine years before!''
I like to make it for Christmas. ==Ingredients== '''List 1''' *1 [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] grated orange peel *½ cup [[Cookbook:White sugar|white sugar]] '''List 2''' *1 beaten [[Cookbook:Egg|egg]] *1 cup [[Cookbook:White sugar|white sugar]] *3 tablespoons melted [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]] or [[Cookbook:Margarine|margarine]] *3½ [[Cookbook:tsp|tsp]] [[Cookbook:Baking Powder|baking powder]] *2½ cups white all-purpose [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] *1¼ cups [[Cookbook:Milk|milk]] *½ tsp [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] ==Procedure== #Cover grated orange peel with water and [[Cookbook:boil|boil]] 5 minutes. #Drain and rinse, discarding water. #Barely cover with cold water, about ¼ cup. #Add ½ cup sugar and cook until peel is tender and water is cooked away; cool. #Preheat the oven to 350°F. #Mix thoroughly all items under List 2. #Add cooled peel to this mixture and #Pour into greased and floured 9 x 5 x 3 inch pan. #[[Cookbook:Bake|Bake]] 55-65 minutes or until a toothpick comes out dry when inserted in the loaf. ==Notes, tips, and variations== *Good warm and plain, or toasted and buttered. [[Category:Bread recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Dessert recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Holiday recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

revision.comment: Protected "[[Cookbook:Magic Brownie]]": Frequent target of IP vandalism, protecting to temporarily prevent this. Registered users can still edit it. [edit=autoconfirmed:move=autoconfirmed]
revision.text:
{{recipe}}
Warning: The possession and use of cannabis is forbidden in many countries. '''Please read the wikibooks [[Wikibooks:Risk disclaimer|risk disclaimer]] before attempting to follow this recipe.'''
== Ingredients ==
* 300[[Cookbook:Gram|g]] [[Cookbook:Chocolate|chocolate]] chips * 180[[Cookbook:Liter|ml]] [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] * 250g self-raising [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] * 60g [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]] * 2 large [[Cookbook:Egg|eggs]] * a [[Cookbook:Pinch|pinch]] of [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * 5ml [[Cookbook:Vanilla|vanilla]] * 4g [[Cookbook:Cannabis|cannabis]] * grated [[Cookbook:Lemon|lemon]]
== Procedure ==
In order to properly extract the THC from the cannabis, it is necessary to melt the butter and add finely chopped greens. Cook slowly at a low temperature for a long time. Depending on preference, one can strain the remaining organic matter out with cheese cloth or something similar. Then simply mix your green butter in brownie batter with special batter and Voila! magic brownies. Cook in an oven at 360 °F/180 °C for about 20-25 minutes. This recipe should make about 9 medium-sized magic brownies.
== Different Methods ==
For a different style, why not try using brown cane sugar instead of normal sugar? Also, melt some chocolate, mix with a little sugar, vanilla and lemon with a little more weed, drizzle on the freshly cooked brownies for a little added flavour and high. This creates a nicer tasting brownie with more of a kick.
You can also try adding a few crushed up biscuits before cooking for a more varied taste.
[[Category:Recipes_with_metric_units|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Breakfast Recipes|Breakfast Recipes]] | [[Cookbook:Bread|Bread]] {{recipesummary|Breakfast recipes|four 4 section waffles|prep 10 minutes
then 5 minutes per waffle|1}} ==Ingredients== * 1 ¼ cups [[Cookbook:Whole Wheat|whole wheat flour]] * 1 cup wheat germ * 2 tablespoons [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] * 1 tablespoon [[Cookbook:Baking Powder|baking powder]] * 1 tablespoon [[Cookbook:Nutmeg|nutmeg]] * 1 teaspoon [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * 2 cups [[Cookbook:Milk|milk]] * ½ cup [[Cookbook:Vegetable oil|vegetable oil]] * 2 [[Cookbook:Egg|eggs]] ==Procedure== # Heat [[Cookbook:Waffle Iron|waffle iron]] to "waffle," until light goes out. # Combine dry ingredients and mix. # Add milk, vegetable oil, and eggs, mix until smooth. # Pour 1 cup of batter on oiled waffle iron grids, [[Cookbook:Baking|bake]] 5 minutes or until light goes out. ==Notes, tips and variations== * Generally served with butter melted on top, then sweet syrup. * Fruit may be spread on top. [[Category:Breakfast recipes]] [[Category:Waffle recipes]] [[Category:Egg recipes]] [[Category:Nutmeg recipes]]

{{recipesummary|Bread recipes|8|Prep 15 minutes
Bake 50-70 minutes|2}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Ireland|Irish cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Vegetarian cuisine|Vegetarian Cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Holiday Recipes|Holiday]] | [[Cookbook:Bread|Bread]] ==Ingredients== * 3 [[Cookbook:Cup|cups]] all-purpose [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoon]] [[Cookbook:Baking Powder|baking powder]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoon]] [[Cookbook:Baking Soda|baking soda]] * ⅛ cup [[Cookbook:White sugar|white sugar]] * 1 teaspoon [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Egg|egg]], lightly [[Cookbook:Beat|beaten]] * 2 cups [[Cookbook:Buttermilk|buttermilk]] * ¼ cup [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]], melted ==Procedure== # Preheat oven to [[Cookbook:Oven_temperatures|325°F]] (160°C). # Grease and flour a 9x5 inch loaf pan. # Combine flour, baking powder, baking soda, sugar, and salt in a large mixing bowl. # Blend egg and buttermilk together, and add all at once to the flour mixture. # Mix until just moistened. ''Too much mixing will make it tough.'' # Stir in butter; pour into prepared pan. # [[Cookbook:Bake|Bake]] for 65-70 minutes, or until a toothpick inserted in the bread comes out clean. The loaf should sound hollow if you tap the base. # Cool on a wire rack. # Wrap in tea-towel or foil several hours or overnight for best flavor. ==Tips, Notes, and Variations== * May serve [[Cookbook:toast|toast]]ed and buttered. * Soda bread rises as a result of acid being mixed with baking soda. The acid is commonly in the form of vinegar, lemon juice, or buttermilk. A tablespoon of [[Cookbook:Lemon Juice|lemon juice]] or [[Cookbook:Vinegar|vinegar]] in one cup of milk can be substituted for each cup of buttermilk. * For best results, bake it at 375°F (190°C), for about 50 minutes, on a preheated baking stone. ===Overview=== Conventional bread, containing live yeast, leavens (rises) as the micro-organisms make carbon dioxide gas as a by-product of their metabolism. Similarly, soda bread utilizes the reaction between baking soda and vinegar, or some other acid, to make the bread rise through the production of carbon dioxide. This recipe uses buttermilk, or optionally a combination of milk and vinegar, but other recipes use sour cream. [[Category:Inexpensive recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Irish recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Camping recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Bread recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}}
There are two basic forms of clams with pasta. There are countless regional variations around Italy, but let's stick with the two basic forms for now. * tomato-based sauce * white wine sauce
== Tomato-based sauce ==
===Ingredients=== * 1 pound dry [[Cookbook:Linguine|linguine]] * [[Cookbook:Olive Oil|extra-virgin olive oil]] * 2 cloves [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]] * 2 small [[Cookbook:Chili Pepper|chilis]] * 2 pounds [[Cookbook:Clam|clams]] * large glass of dry white [[Cookbook:Wine|wine]] * 1 medium [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]] * 1 can of [[Cookbook:Tomato|tomatoes]] (or, for a sharper flavour, replace half the can with chopped fresh tomatoes) * [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * freshly ground [[Cookbook:Pepper|black pepper]] * bunch of flat-leaf parsley or [[Cookbook:Cilantro|coriander]] (cilantro)
===Procedure=== #Heat the olive oil over medium heat in a large, wide pan with a lid. #Add the onion and fry until it starts to go soft. #Add garlic and the red chili (leave the seeds in if you like it spicy) and sauté for 2 minutes. #Add the tomatoes and simmer until it starts to congeal. #Start the pasta cooking in a large pot with plenty of vigorously boiling water. You're aiming to get this to be ''[[Cookbook:Al dente|al dente]]'' (soft, but with a bit of bite to it still) at the same time as the sauce is ready. This takes a different amount of time depending on which pasta you use. #Add the clams and wine to the other pan. Put the lid on and cook for about 8 minutes until all the clams have opened. Shake the pan to help them open. Throw any out that aren't fully open. #Drain the linguine and add it to the tomato sauce. Add salt and pepper to taste. #Toss the pasta with the clams, put it onto plates, and add chopped parsley/coriander.
Serves 4.
== White wine sauce == ===Ingredients=== * 1 pound dry linguine * extra-virgin olive oil * 4 cloves of garlic cloves * ¼ teaspoon mild [[Cookbook:Chili Powder|red pepper flakes]] * 2 pounds clams * large glass of dry white wine * 1 [[Cookbook:Lemon|lemon]] * 1 oz [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]] * salt * freshly ground black pepper * bunch of flat-leaf parsley or coriander.
===Procedure=== #Start the pasta cooking in a large pot with plenty of vigorously boiling water. You're aiming to get this to be ''al dente'' (soft, but with a bit of bite to it still) at the same time as the sauce is ready. This takes a different amount of time depending on which pasta you use. #Heat the olive oil over medium heat in a large, wide pan with a lid. #Add the garlic and red pepper and sauté for 2 minutes. Add the clams, wine, and lemon juice. Put the lid on and cook for about 8 minutes until all the clams have opened. Shake the pan to help them open. Throw any out that aren't fully open. #Drain the linguine and add it to the pan. Add the butter and salt and pepper to taste. #Toss the pasta with the clams, put it onto plates or dishes, and add chopped parsley and a thin sheen of olive oil.
Serves 4.
==Notes, Tips, and Variations== * Of course you don't have to use linguine. You can also use other sorts of pasta. Penne work well with the spicy sauce. Spaghetti also works. But make sure the pasta is al dente!
[[Category:Clam recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Pasta recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Italian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{ingredient}} | [[Cookbook:Seafood|Seafood]]
{{raw-seafood}}
[[Image:Oyster(L).jpg|thumb|300px|A shucked raw oyster on the half-shell]] The name '''Oyster''' is used for a number of different groups of molluscs which grow for the most part in marine or brackish water.
The "true oysters" are the members of the family Ostreidae, and this includes the edible oysters, which mainly belong to the genera ''Ostrea'', ''Crassostrea'', ''Ostreola'' or ''Saccostrea''. Examples are the Edible Oyster, ''Ostrea edulis,'' the Olympia Oyster ''Ostreola conchaphila,'' and the Eastern Oyster ''Crassostrea virginica''.
Oysters can be canned, eaten raw or cooked. When caught, like all shellfish they have an extremely short shelf-life. They should be fresh when consumed or serious illness can result. Additionally, oysters can host various illness-causing pathogens. Therefore, consumption of raw oysters should be done with caution. Researchers in Oregon have invented a self-shucking oyster.
Farm raised oysters are listed at a "Best Choice" by the Monterey Bay Aquarium's [http://www.mbayaq.org/cr/cr_seafoodwatch/sfw_factsheet.asp?gid=19 Seafood Watch Program].
==Oyster recipes== Recipes using oysters can be found in the [[:Category:Oyster recipes|oyster recipe index]]
[[Category:Featured ingredients|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Shellfish|Oyster]] [[Category:Recipes|Oyster]] [[Category:recipes_with_metric_units|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{seafood}}
[[Image:Common snail.jpg|right|thumb|common snail]] '''Snails''', known as ''escargot'' (ESS car GO) in [[Cookbook:Cuisine of France|French cuisine]], are mollusks found both on land and in the sea. Today they are commonly harvested in [[Cookbook:Citrus|citrus]] groves.
==Recipes using snails include== *[[Cookbook:Paella|Paella]]
[[Category:Shellfish|Snail]] [[Category:Recipes|Snail]]

[[Image:NCI_steamed_shrimp.jpg|thumb|steamed shrimp with shell mostly removed]] [[Image:Woda-6 ubt.jpeg|thumb|live shrimp]] [[Image:Prawns.jpg|thumb|whole prawns]] {{seafood}}
'''Shrimp''' and '''prawns''' are crustaceans, related to [[Cookbook:Lobster|lobster]], [[Cookbook:Crab|crab]], [[Cookbook:Crayfish|crayfish]], and [[Cookbook:Krill|krill]]. Prawns are not shrimp, but are generally indistinguishable in culinary usage; see the wikipedia articles listed below for details.
To remove the shells, start by pinching away the leg-like gill structure. Then split the shell from there, pulling it off the rest of the way. You may wish to remove the "vein" on the back, which is actually the digestive tract. If the shrimp are already deveined, they will be split along the back, and a good way to peel them is to simply squeeze forefinger and thumb against the tail. This will push the "meat" out and allow you to easily pluck off the remnants of the shell. Of course, this results in tail-less shrimp.
The easiest way to cook shrimp is by [[Cookbook:Boiling|boiling]]. Simply place them into a pot of boiling water and cook them until they change color, generally becoming pink. You can serve the shrimp with [[Cookbook:Lemon Juice|lemon juice]], [[Cookbook:Ketchup|ketchup]], a mixture of both, or a fancier [[Cookbook:Cocktail Sauce|cocktail sauce]].
Shrimp also go well in [[Cookbook:Stir-fry|stir-fry]], including [[Cookbook:Fried Rice|fried rice]].
A more difficult and dangerous [[Cookbook:Deep Fat Frying|deep fat frying]] procedure can be used to produce [[Cookbook:Fried Shrimp|fried shrimp]]. There are several types including [[Cookbook:Southern Fried Shrimp|Southern fried shrimp]] (non-puffy batter containing [[Cookbook:Cornmeal|cornmeal]]) or [[Cookbook:Chinese Fried Shrimp|Chinese fried shrimp]] (puffy cornmeal-free batter, as used in westernized [[Cookbook:Cuisine of China|Chinese]] cooking), and [[Cookbook:Tempura|tempura]] (thin and sometimes flakey [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Japan|Japanese]] style).
==Recipes using shrimp== *[[Cookbook:Fried Shrimp|Fried Shrimp]] *[[Cookbook:Keralan Prawns|Keralan Prawns]] *[[Cookbook:Ceviche of Shrimp and Sea Bass|Ceviche of Shrimp and Sea Bass]] *[[Cookbook:Low Country Shrimp and Grits|Low Country Shrimp and Grits]] *[[Cookbook:Pad Thai|Pad Thai]] *[[Cookbook:Fried Rice|Fried Rice]] *[[Cookbook:Miso Soup|Miso Soup]]
{{Wikipedia|Prawn}} {{Wikipedia|Shrimp}}
[[Category:Shellfish|Shrimp]] [[Category:Recipes|Shrimp]]

revision.text:
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of India|Cuisine of India]] '''Hyderabadi Biryani''' is a popular variety of [[Cookbook:Biryani|Biryani]]. The Hyderabadi Biryani is so named as it is seen mainly in the city of Hyderabad, [[Cookbook:Cuisine of India|India]]. The blending of [[Cookbook:Mughlai cuisine|mughlai]] and [[Cookbook:Andhra cuisine|Andhra cuisine]]s in the kitchen of the Nizam (leader of the historical Hyberabad state), resulted in a dish called the Hyderabad Biryani. It, like other biryanis, is made using [[Cookbook:Basmati rice|Basmati rice]] which is only found on the [[Cookbook:South Asian cuisines|Indian subcontinent]]. The [[Cookbook:Spices and herbs|spices]] and other ingredients remain the same, however the method of preparation involves more time. It is usually accompanied with [[Cookbook:Dahi ki Chutney|Dahi ki Chutney]], [[Cookbook:Raita|Raita]] (a yogurt dish) or [[Cookbook:Mirchi ka Salan|Mirchi ka Salan]]. There are 2 styles of preparing this variety. The ''Katchi'' Biryani is prepared with the ''Katchi Yakhni'' method (with raw gravy). The raw [[Cookbook:meat|meat]] is marinated in [[Cookbook:curd|curd]] and cooked only by the ''dum'', or the baking process, which is done with [[Cookbook:rice|rice]]. This is a challenging process as it requires meticulously measured time and heat to avoid overcooking or undercooking the meat. In ''Pakki'' Biryani, where the meat is cooked with all the accompanying spices and then the rice is simmered with the resultant gravy redolent of mace, ''ittar'' and ''kewra'' in a sealed vessel with [[Cookbook:saffron|saffron]] and [[Cookbook:cardamom|cardamom]]. It is accompanied by side dishes like ''Mirchi ka Salan'', ''Dhansak'' and ''Bagara Baingan''. The meat used in the preparation is usually [[Cookbook:mutton|mutton]], [[Cookbook:beef|beef]] - popularly called Kalyani Biryani - or, less frequently, [[Cookbook:chicken|chicken]]. There is also a [[Cookbook:Vegetarian cuisine|vegetarian]] version of the Hyderabadi Biryani in which the place of the meat is taken by a mixture of vegetables such as [[Cookbook:Carrot|carrots]], [[Cookbook:Pea|peas]], [[Cookbook:Cauliflower|cauliflower]] and [[Cookbook:potato|potato]]. The vegetarian version is called 'tarkari' biryani. The Hyderabadi Biryani version of the mixed Vegetable Biryani is the "''Tahiri''". {{see also|Cookbook:Katchi Biryani}} ==Ingredients==
* 1 kg [[Cookbook:chicken|chicken]] preferably in 16 pieces and a couple of drumsticks * 1 kg [[Cookbook:Basmati rice|Basmati rice]] * 1 cup finely chopped [[Cookbook:onion|onion]]s * 2 tsp [[Cookbook:ginger|ginger]] and [[Cookbook:garlic|garlic]] paste * 3 tsp [[Cookbook:Chili Powder|chilli powder]] * ½ tsp [[Cookbook:turmeric|turmeric]] * 100 g [[Cookbook:cashew|cashew]] nuts * 4 or 5 [[Cookbook:Bay Leaf|bay leaves]] * 4 or 5 [[Cookbook:Clove|cloves]] * 2 cm long [[Cookbook:cinnamon|cinnamon]] sticks * 6 to 10 green [[Cookbook:Chili Pepper|chile]]s ground to paste * 3 or 4 [[Cookbook:cardamom|cardamom]] pods * 1 or 2 tsp [[Cookbook:cumin|cumin]] * 2 cups [[Cookbook:mint|mint]] leaves * 1 cup [[Cookbook:Cilantro|coriander leaves]] (cilantro) * 2 tsp [[Cookbook:Coriander|coriander powder]] * ½ tsp [[Cookbook:Garam Masala|garam masala]] powder * 1 cup [[Cookbook:coconut milk|coconut milk]] * 1 [[Cookbook:lemon|lemon]] * 1½ tsp [[Cookbook:salt|salt]] (according to taste) * 1 cup [[Cookbook:ghee|ghee]] (clarified butter) * ½ cup [[Cookbook:yogurt|yogurt]] * 1 cup [[Cookbook:Oil|oil]], * 2 tsp dried [[Cookbook:coconut|coconut]] powder, * few strands of [[Cookbook:saffron|saffron]], * 2 cups finely sliced [[Cookbook:onion|onion]]s,
==Procedure== # Make deep incisions on the chicken flesh - deep enough for spices to get absorbed but making them too deep could render the pieces smaller. Mix turmeric, chilli powder, salt, garlic paste, yogurt, and half-lemon's juice. Thoroughly apply this paste onto the meat flesh and let marinate for an hour. # Heat about 100 ml of oil. Roast cumin, cloves, cinnamon, depodded cardamom, bay leaves, ½ spoon cumin, 1 spoon coriander powder, and finally add onions(2). Wait a couple of minutes to add mint leaves. When onions turn slight brown, add marinated chicken and cook for about 20-30 min. It should NOT be fully cooked at this stage; add garam masala and coconut powder and turn off flame when about ¾ cooked. Gravy should not be much, chicken pieces should look roasted. # Meanwhile, while the chicken is still cooking, prepare the biryani rice. Slightly rinse 3 cups of basmati, and add water little less than the volume of the rice itself so that its only half cooked preferably in an electric cooker. Amount of water actually depends on kind of rice at hand and your experience helps to judge it. Also add 1-2 teaspoons of salt to it. Take a few semi-cooked grains of rice and colour them with diluted saffron for garnishing. # You will need a utensil of about 12" (300 mm) base. Place about half of semi-cooked rice in it. Next, layer half of chicken on it again topped by a layer of rice (half of the remaining). One more layer of remaining chicken, finally with layer of rest of the rice on top ends the rice-chicken layering stage. # Heat oil and deep fry half the sliced onions to golden brown. Similarly fry cashew. Garnish the top layer with these two along with 100 ml ghee, coconut milk, saffron rice grains and coriander. Lid the vessel and try making it airtight (but no pressure should build up). Put on high flame for 5 min before reducing it to low flame. The flame should NOT be at the vessel's centre, but on one side of it. Wait for 2-3 min and turn the vessel to heat other next part on its circumference. This way, keep rotating the vessel every 2-3 min for about 20 min. Every time you turn it, carefully disturb the contents by a shake/jerk so as to avoid settling of ghee at the bottom. # Put off the flame and wait for about 10 min before opening. Before serving, mix the medley from the bottom. Serve with boiled egg halves. Enjoy. Rightly and carefully made, its an epicure's paradise. {{Wikipedia|Hyderabad biryani}} [[Category:Rice recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Indian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

__NOTOC__{{recipe}}
This is an Indian dish with Mediterranean influence.
== Ingredients == === Marinade === * chicken (preferably a big pair of breasts, with bones) * 2 tbsp olive oil * 6 cloves of garlic, smashed * 1/2 lemon * 5 medium spicy long green chillies (slit in half along their length) * 5 tbsp milk * 2 tbsp chicken masala (mix of redchilli, coriander, blackpepper, ginger, cumin, cardamom, cinnamon, cloves and aniseed) * 2 tbsp dried basil * salt to taste
== Procedure == # Marinate the chicken for about 1/2-1 hr in the rest of the ingredients. # Heat a pan and cook, covered, over low heat, until tender.

{{recipesummary|Dessert recipes|2|prep: 20+30 minutes
cooking: ~15 minutes|2}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Dessert|Desserts]] This is a sweet and warm chocolate based dessert ==Ingredients== * 125 g [[Cookbook:flour|flour]] * 40 g [[Cookbook:cocoa powder|cocoa powder]] * 20 g [[Cookbook:powdered sugar|powdered sugar]] * 1 huge [[Cookbook:egg|egg]] * 25 g [[Cookbook:mascarpone|mascarpone]] * a pinch of [[Cookbook:salt|salt]] * 20 g [[Cookbook:butter|butter]] * 5 teaspoons [[Cookbook:crystal sugar|crystal sugar]] * 2 [[Cookbook:egg yolk|egg yolk]]s * 40 g [[Cookbook:brown sugar|brown sugar]] * 100 ml [[Cookbook:milk|milk]] * 5 table spoons of [[Cookbook:sweet cream|sweet cream]] (the stuff used for [[Cookbook:whipped cream|whipped cream]]) * 1/2 [[Cookbook:vanilla stick|vanilla stick]] ==Procedure== * Mix the flour, cocoa powder, powdered sugar, egg, mascarpone and salt to create a smooth dough in 5 to 10 minutes. * Cover the dough and let it rest for 30min * Boil some water in a big pan and add the butter and crystal sugar * Roll out the dough on a flour covered plate and cut it in thin stripes * Boil the stripes for about 4min, pour out the water and and dry the stripes with some kitchen paper towels, keep the noodles warm * Mix the brown sugar and the egg yolks for the sauce in a cup and put it aside. * Put the milk and cream in a pan with the vanilla stick and stir for a few minutes, then remove the vanilla stick. * Warm the milk and cream and stir gently, then pour the warm mixture onto the egg mix * Pour the mixture back into the pan and stir it gently until it thickens.. watch out not to boil the mixture! * Place the chocolate noodles on a plate and pour the vanilla sauce over ==Suggestions== * Add some fresh fruits when serving * Replace the vanilla stick with vanilla essence [[Category:Dessert recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Salad recipes|4|15 minutes|3}}
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Side dishes | Side dishes]] | [[Cookbook:East Asian cuisines| Asian Cuisine]]
'''Asian Chicken Salad'''
== Ingredients ==
*1½ cups [[Cookbook:broccoli|broccoli]] flowerets *½ cup [[Cookbook:pea pod|pea pod]]s *6 cups torn mixed [[Cookbook:greens|greens]] *2 cups thinly sliced [[Cookbook:Nappa Cabbage|Nappa cabbage]] *½ cup julienne-cut [[Cookbook:Carrot|carrots]] *1 package (6 oz.) grilled [[Cookbook:chicken|chicken]] breast cut in strips *¾ cups teriyaki [[Cookbook:Ginger|ginger]], Asian sesame with ginger or balsamic vinaigrette salad dressing *1 [[Cookbook:mango|mango]], peeled, seeded, thinly sliced (optional) *Sesame crackers (optional)
== Procedure ==
# In large [[Cookbook:saucepan|saucepan]] quickly plunge broccoli and pea pods into boiling water for 30 seconds. Drain vegetables. Quickly rinse with cold water. Drain well. # In large bowl toss together broccoli, pea pods, greens, cabbage and carrots. Add chicken. Drizzle with salad dressing. Toss to coat. Arrange on 4 serving plates. Top with mango, if desired. Serve with crackers.
[[Category:Salad recipes|Asian Chicken Salad]]

revision.text:
{{cookwork}} {{recipe}} '''Chicken Bog''' is a chicken and rice dish from the [[Pee Dee]] area of [[South Carolina]].
== Loris Bog-off == On the second weekend in [[October]], [[Loris, South Carolina|Loris]], [[South Carolina]], is host to the annual Loris Bog-off. The event is held just outside the town on the Horry County Fairgrounds.
== Recipes == ===Chicken Bog 1===
:(serves 10) **'''Ingredients''' **1 5lb to 6 lb fat hen **1 small onion (about the size of a lemon or smaller) **1 small green bell pepper **1 stick butter (1/4 lb.), if needed **2 lb. long grain white rice ''(not instant rice)'' **1/4 lb bacon **salt & black pepper :Use a heavy aluminum pot with lid - (use lid while cooking all phases except bacon.) :To cook: :Put chicken in pot; cover with hot water (be sure there is enough water so that there will be at least six cups of broth after cooking chicken); bring water to a boil, reduce heat and simmer until chicken is very tender (approx: an hour or more). :While chicken is cooking: ::(1) Slice and chop one and bell pepper into very small pieces. ::(2) Put 4 cups of rice into a bowl, cover with cold water and let soak. :When very tender, remove pot from stove and let cool until the chicken can be handled; take chicken from pot; pull meat from bones in large pieces (do not cut up); discard and fat heavy skin. Pour broth from pot into a bowl (if chicken was very fat and broth is very fat, pour off about 1 cup of fat from broth).
:Wash pot; put bacon in pot and cook slowly until bacon is crisp; take bacon from pot and drain; leave bacon grease in pot; put in chopped onion, green pepper and brown slightly; add 6 cups chicken broth to pot; season to taste with salt and pepper (at least a tablespoon of each -- use a heavy hand since rice will absorb salt); increase heat, bring broth to a boil; put chicken in pot; drain rice and put rice in pot; put stick of butter in pot; mix well; Reduce heat and simmer very slowly for about an hour. :To avoid gooey rice,avoid stiring when ever possible. When rice is tender and has absorbed the liquids, removed from stove. Serve hot; you can crumble bacon and put on the top of serving or not, depending on taste. :Chicken bog can be kept in refrigerator and reheated or it can be frozen and later reheated.
===Grand Strand Chicken Bog=== (Found in the Vertical File of Chapin Library, Myrtle Beach, South Carolina) :(Serves 8) **'''Ingredients''' **2 1/2 lb. chicken pieces **1 cup. chopped onion **1 1/2 lb. smoked sausage **1 tsp. black pepper **2 cups. long grain rice :Boil chicken and onions in 4 cups of water until tender. If desired, debone chicken. Slice sausage in 1/2" pieces, add sausage, pepper and rice to chicken. Simmer until all broth is absorbed and rice is cooked.
===Chicken Bog 2=== Recipe by: Come and Get It! by Jr. Welfare League of Talladega :(6 servings) **'''Ingredients''' **6 cups Water **1 tb Salt **1 med Onion; finely chopped **1 3 lb chicken **1 cup Long-grain rice **1/2 lb Smoked sausage; sliced **2 tb Herb seasoning **1 pk "chicken and herb" seasoning :Put water, salt, onion, and chicken in pot. Boil until tender. (About 1 hour.) Remove chicken, let cool and remove bones. Chop meat in bite-sized pieces. Skim off fat from juices. Measure 3 1/2 cups of this broth into a 6-qt saucepan. Add rice, chicken pieces and smoked sausage, herb seasoning and "chicken and herb" seasoning. Cook these ingredients for 30 mins. Bring to a boil and reduce heat and simmer, keeping covered the entire time. If rice mixture is too juicy, cook uncovered until desired consistency.
===Chicken Bog 3===
:(8 to 10 servings) **'''Ingredients''' **1 whole onion **2 ribs celery, washed and snapped in halves or quarters (leaves and all) **2 carrots, halved or quartered **1 tablespoon poultry seasoning **1 tablespoon dried parsley flakes **2 bay leaves **Salt and fresh-ground black pepper, to taste **1 (3 to 3 1/2 pound) whole chicken **Water **2 1/2 cups long-grain rice **2 tablespoons butter
:In a large soup pot, kettle, or deep-sided heavy casserole with top, put onion, celery, carrots, poultry seasoning, parsley flakes, bay leaves, salt and pepper. Rinse the chicken and place on top of the other ingredients in the pot. Add enough water to cover the chicken and bring to a boil, uncovered, over medium-high heat. Reduce heat, cover and simmer for about 1 hour, or until juices run clear when the chicken is pricked with a fork. Remove chicken to a platter to cool. Strain broth from pot (you should have about 8 cups; if you have more, set aside for another use). :Return 8 cups broth to the pot and bring to a boil over high heat. Pour in rice and return to a boil. Adjust heat to lowest possible setting, stir and cover. Cook 20 minutes, stirring occasionally and keeping an eye on the pot to be sure it does not cook dry. Add more of the broth if necessary. :While the rice is cooking, skin and remove chicken meat from the bones; discard bones and skin. Cut meat into bite-sized pieces; set aside. :When the rice is cooked, add the boneless chicken and butter. Stir together carefully, taste to correct seasoning and serve. Or keep pot covered over low heat until ready to serve.
:Per serving (with 2 teaspoons butter per serving): 60 calories, 2 grams protein, 4 grams fat, 6 grams carbohydrates, 10 milligrams cholesterol, 43 milligrams sodium, 60 percent calories from fat.
[[Category:Chicken recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary |Category = Middle Eastern recipes |Servings = 2 - 4 |Rating = 3 }} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Middle Eastern cuisines|Middle Eastern cuisines]]
'''Musakhan''', also مسخّن (Arabic). A Palestinian country dish. It is chicken baked with onions, sumac, allspice, and garnished with fried pine nuts.
==Ingredients== * 1 whole free-range [[Cookbook:Chicken|chicken]] (about 3½ pounds / 1.5 kg) * [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]], to taste * freshly ground [[Cookbook:Pepper|black pepper]], to taste * ½ cup [[Cookbook:Olive Oil|extra virgin olive oil]] * 3½ pounds (1.5 kg) [[Cookbook:Onion|onions]], peeled and sliced thin * ¼ cup [[Cookbook:Sumac|Soumak]] * 2 large [[Cookbook:Khubz|khubz 'arabi]] (Arabic [[Cookbook:Flatbread|flatbread]] or [[Cookbook:Pita Bread|pita bread]]), split open and separated * [[Cookbook:Pine Nut|pine nuts]] to decorate
==Procedure==
# Cut the chicken into up into two breasts, two thighs, two legs, and two wings. Salt and pepper the chicken. # In a large, deep casserole, heat ¼ cup of the olive oil, then lightly brown the chicken on all sides over a medium heat, about 20 minutes. Remove and set aside. # Add the remaining ¼ cup olive oil to the casserole and cook the onions until translucent, about 35 minutes, stirring occasionally. # Add the sumac and cook for 2 minutes to mix. # Preheat the oven to 350°F (175°C). # Cover a 9 x 12-inch baking dish with the Arabic bread. Spoon half the onions over each, then arrange the chicken on top of the onions and cover with the remaining onions and the juices from the casserole. # Bake until the chicken is golden crisp and almost falling off the bone, about 1½ hours. # Roast the pine nuts in a pan until Golden in olive oil. # Sprinkle with the roasted pine, and serve with yoghurt.
[[Category:Mediterranean recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Middle Eastern recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Jordanian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Palestinian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Chicken recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary| |6|45 minutes|1}}
{{recipe}}
==Ingredients==
*3 cans of tuna in water *1 can each of cream of celery, cream of chicken, and cream of mushroom (substitute cream of potato if you don't like mushrooms) *1 bag of frozen vegetables *1 large bag of egg noodles *1 can of fried onion rings
==Procedure== # Cook egg noodles as directed on package. While boiling water, pre-heat oven to 400-degrees F. # Drain egg noodles. Mix together all ingredents except fried onion rings. Put in a casserole dish or a 9"x13"x2" pan. Cook for 20 minutes. # Sprinkle fried onion topping on top of baked casserole. Bake for an additional 3 minutes, or until fried onion is slightly brown. # Let cool for 5 minutes and serve.
==Notes, tips, and variations== You can substitute any of the cream soups with the flavor of your choice.
Sprinkling with Old Bay or any other seafood seasoning for added taste.

revision.comment: New page: {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Vegetable Recipes|Vegetable Recipes]] | [[Cookbook:North American cuisines|North American cuisines]] | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|United States cuisine...
revision.text:
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Vegetable Recipes|Vegetable Recipes]] | [[Cookbook:North American cuisines|North American cuisines]] | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|United States cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Cajun cuisine|Cajun cuisine]]
'''Smothered okra''' is a easy dish that works well as a side vegetable. It can also be added to seafood and okra [[Cookbook:Gumbo|gumbo]] as the okra base. It is made with [[Cookbook:Okra|okra]] and [[Cookbook:Tomatoes|tomatoes]] and is best served over [[Cookbook:Rice|rice]].
<br clear="all"> ==Ingredients==
* 1 Lb okra, washed (remove tips and heads and slice into ¼ - ½ inch wide pieces) * 4-5 medium tomatoes, diced * ½ medium-large yellow onion, diced * 2-3 stalks celery, sliced or diced * 1 green bell pepper, diced * 2-3 cloves garlic, sliced or diced * butter (1 stick/½ Lb/113 g) * Salt, pepper, etc. to taste
==Procedure==
# Saute onion, celery, and bell pepper in butter until soft over medium heat, adding garlic to saute shortly before the onion is soft. # Add okra and tomatoes. Stir a few times to incorporate. If the mixture seems a bit dry, add a small amount of water. # Simmer over medium heat until the okra is no longer sticky and stringy. (The okra will change to a darker green color.) # Serve over rice or freeze to use in your next gumbo.
[[Category:Rice recipes|Jambalaya]] [[Category:Southern recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Louisiana recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Sandwiches|Sandwich]] | [[Cookbook:North American cuisines|North American cuisines]] | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|United States cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Louisiana Creole cuisine|Louisiana Creole cuisine]]
The '''muffuletta''' is a sandwich found in New Orleans, LA, USA. It originates from the Italian community and was first made and popularized at the French Quarter's Central Grocery. It is made from a variety of [[Cookbook:Sausage|sausages]] and [[Cookbook:Cheese|cheeses]], and served with an [[Cookbook:Olive|olive]] spread on a muffuletta loaf. (Other types of [[Cookbook:Bread|round loaves]] can be substituted.)
==Ingredients== * 1 muffuletta loaf (or other round bread loaf, approximately 10" in diameter) * [http://www.gumbopages.com/food/samwiches/muff.html Olive spread] * Capicola, sliced * Mortadella, sliced * Salami, sliced * Emmantal (Swiss) cheese, sliced * Provolone cheese, sliced
==Procedure== # Slice bread loaf in half horizontally and spread each cut side with olive spread. # Layer bottom half of the loaf with sausages and cheeses as you wish. # Cover with top half of the loaf and press down. # Quarter the muffuletta and serve or wrap the muffuletta tightly in plastic wrap to save for later.
[[Category:Louisiana recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Southern recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Casserole recipes|4-6 servings|prep: 30-45 minutes (preparing mirliton)
baking: 15-30 minutes |2}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Vegetable Recipes|Vegetable Recipes]] | [[Cookbook:North American cuisines|North American cuisines]] | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|United States cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Cajun cuisine|Cajun cuisine]] '''Mirliton casserole''' is a easy dish that works well as a side vegetable. It can be made with either [[Cookbook:Seafood|seafood]] or [[Cookbook:Meat|meat]], though it is most commonly made with [[Cookbook:Shrimp|shrimp]] or [[Cookbook:Beef|ground beef]]. ==Ingredients== * 6 medium mirliton (chayote squash), halved lengthwise * 1 medium yellow onion, diced * 2-3 stalks celery, sliced or diced * 1 medium to large green bell pepper, diced * 2-3 cloves garlic, diced * 1 Lb (500g) shrimp (whole), peeled (or 1/2 Lb. [250g] ground beef) (can be left out) * 1 bay leaf * salt, pepper, and parsley to taste * bread crumbs * butter (1 stick, 1/2 cup, 113 grams) (olive oil may be substituted -- enough to cover your pan) ==Procedure== # Place mirliton halves seed-side up in a microwave or oven-safe dish with approximately 1 inch (2.5cm) of water in the dish. Cover with foil (for oven) or plastic wrap (for microwave) and cook in oven (350F/175C) or microwave (high at 10 minute intervals) until mirliton are soft enough to stick a fork or knife through easily. Allow mirliton to cool enough to be handled and dice into large pieces. # Saute onion, celery, and garlic in butter over medium heat, adding garlic to saute just before onion, celery, and garlic are fully softened. # Add shrimp or beef to pan until beef is lightly browned or until shrimp is just turning pink. (Skip this step if you aren't adding meat.) # Incorporate mirliton and bay leaf and allow to simmer for five to ten minutes. # Remove from heat and add salt, pepper, and parsley to taste. Pour mixture into a casserole dish and cover with bread crumbs. Bake in the oven at 350F (175C) until the merliton is bubbling and the bread crumbs are browned. [[Category:Casserole recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Louisiana recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Southern recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cajun cuisine|Cajun cuisine]]
'''Dirty Rice''' is a traditional [[Cookbook:Cajun cuisine|Cajun]] dish made from white rice cooked with small pieces of chicken liver or giblets, which give it a dark ("dirty") color.
== Ingredients ==
* 2 tablespoons [[Cookbook:chicken fat|chicken fat]] * 1 teaspoon [[Cookbook:Pepper|black pepper]] * ½ lb [[Cookbook:chicken gizzards|chicken gizzards]] (optional) * 2 teaspoons [[Cookbook:paprika|paprika]] * ¼ lb [[Cookbook:pork|pork]], Ground * 1 teaspoon [[Cookbook:Mustard|dry mustard]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Bay Leaf|bay leaf]] * 1 teaspoon [[Cookbook:cumin|cumin]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Onion|yellow onion]] * ½ teaspoon [[Cookbook:thyme|thyme]] * 1½ stalks [[Cookbook:celery|celery]] * ½ teaspoon [[Cookbook:oregano|oregano]] * ½ [[Cookbook:Bell Pepper|bell pepper]], green * 2 tablespoons [[Cookbook:butter|butter]] * 1 [[Cookbook:garlic|garlic]] clove * 2 cups [[Cookbook:Stock|pork stock]] * 1 teaspoon [[Cookbook:Tabasco Sauce|Tabasco sauce]] * ½ lb [[Cookbook:Liver|chicken livers]] (optional) * 1 teaspoon [[Cookbook:salt|salt]] * 1 cup [[Cookbook:rice|rice]]
== Procedure ==
# [[Cookbook:Mincing|Mince]] onion, bell pepper, celery and garlic. # [[Cookbook:Purée|Grind]] livers and gizzards. # Place fat, gizzards, pork and bay leaves in large heavy [[Cookbook:skillet|skillet]] over high heat; cook until meat is thoroughly [[Cookbook:Brown|browned]], about 6 minutes, stirring occasionally. # [[Cookbook:Stirring|Stir]] in the onion, celery, bell pepper, garlic, Tabasco, salt, pepper, paprika, mustard, cumin, thyme, and oregano; stir thoroughly, scraping pan bottom well. # Add the butter and stir until melted. # Reduce heat to medium and cook about 8 minutes, stirring constantly and scraping pan bottom well. # Add the stock or water and stir until any mixture sticking to the pan bottom comes loose; cook about 8 minutes over high heat, stirring once. # Then stir in the chicken livers and cook about 2 minutes. # Add the rice and stir thoroughly; cover pan and turn heat to very low; cook about 5 minutes. # Remove from heat and leave covered until rice is tender, about 10 minutes. # Remove bay leaves and serve immediately.
[[Category:Rice recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Chicken recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Louisiana recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

revision.comment: /* Ingredients */ (though a coated pan isnt necessary)
revision.text:
{{recipesummary |Czech recipes| approx. 7 pieces|20 min.|2|}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Czechia|Cuisine of Czechia]] | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Austria|Cuisine of Austria]]
'''Palatschinken''' or '''Palačinky''' are flat round cakes, similar to pancakes, but with a different dough, and much thinner, also similar to the French crêpes, though again with a different dough and a little bit thicker.
They can be rolled with sweet and other fillings (jam, vegetables, stews, mushrooms, cheese), they can be cut into thin stripes and put into broth, which is then called Frittatensuppe (roughly translatable as: soup soup of fried things) - Palatschinken are a very versatile dish.
The recipe originated in Czechia, but has been integrated very thoroughly into Austrian cooking.
==Ingredients== *3 eggs *250 ml milk *150 g flour (wheat or spelt) *possibly some mineral water (which makes the dough more fluffy) *possibly some salt (yes, it makes even sweet dishes better as well) *to your own taste, some drops of rum
use a coated pan that is as flat as possible and has a diameter of about 25-30 cm
==Procedure== #Mix the flour with the milk, stir thoroughly, then add the eggs one by one and stir them into the mixture separately. #Heat the pan well, #add a drop of oil, distribute it with a kitchen towel, put one dipperful of the dough into the pan, dip the pan so that the dough spreads as evenly as possible over the whole floor of the pan (alternatively you can use a special wooden tool, used for crepes, for spreading). #Let bake until the top of the palatschinke is dry (should take about 45 seconds to a minute), then turn around carefully and #let get brown on the other side as well (about 30 seconds max). #restart at step 3 to produce the other palatschinken.
If you want to keep the palatschinken warm for use, put them into the oven at 50°C.
==Variations== * Add spices and/or herbs to the dough, according to the intended filling * replace part of the milk with beetroot juice to produce bright pink palatschinken * add spinach to the dough to produce green ones * add saffron to produce golden ones * filled palatschinken can be covered with cheese and baked
[[Category:Vegetarian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Czech recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Austrian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Dessert recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Recipes_with_metric_units|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Greece|Cuisine of Greece]]
==Ingredients==
* 1 large egg plant (aubergine) * Greek olive oil * Salt
===Meat Sauce===
* One large onion, chopped * Six cloves of garlic, chopped * Three tablespoons of olive oil * One kilogram of minced/ground beef or lamb * One large tin of tomatoes * One cup of red wine * Two tablespoons of chopped, fresh parsley * Two tablespoons of chopped, fresh Greek basil (optional) * Two bay leaves * One teaspoon of sugar * One cinnamon stick * Freshly ground black pepper * Two tablespoons of tomato paste
===Cheese Sauce===
* Three tablespoons of butter * Four tablespoons of plain flour * Two cups of milk * Sprinkle of nutmeg, cinnamon and black pepper * Half a cup of freshly-grated parmesan cheese * One cup of grated cheese (tasty, edam, whatever) * One egg
==Method==
Cut egg plant into 5mm slices. Lay the slices out and sprinkle liberally with salt. This leaches out the bitterness. Leave these for at least an hour.
Heat olive oil in a saucepan and add onion and garlic. Sauté these until the onion starts to change colour. Add the meat and brown thoroughly. Add bay leaves and cinnamon stick, and continue to stir the meat until all the moisture from the meat is gone. Add tomatoes, herbs and sauces. Mix through and allow to cook for fifteen minutes, stirring occasionally. Add wine and continue to cook until the sauce is very thick. It should have very little moisture in it all. Remove the bay leaves and cinnamon stick! Allow to cool.
In another saucepan, melt butter over a low heat. Remove from heat and add the flour. Blend this through thoroughly, then return to the heat and cook gently for three minutes, stirring continuously so that it does not catch. Remove from heat and add the milk. Mix this through then return to the heat and allow mixture to boil. Allow sauce to cook gently for one minute, stirring continuously. Remove from heat, add cheeses, nutmeg, cinnamon and pepper and mix through. Stand sauce aside and allow to cool.
Rinse the slices of egg plant under running water and dry on paper towels. Heat olive oil in a frying pan. Place slices of egg plant in the pan and quickly turn to coat both sides in the hot oil. Fry until the slices are cooked (when they change colour and become soft). Repeat with remaining slices.
In a large casserole dish, lay slices of egg plant to cover the bottom. Cover with a layer of the meat sauce. Repeat layering egg plant and meat sauce until within three centimetres of the top of the dish.
Add the egg to the cool, cheese sauce and mix through thoroughly. Spoon this on the top layer in the casserole dish and sprinkle with extra grated cheese. Bake at 200 degrees C for 45 minutes. Remove from oven and allow to cool and set for ten minutes.
Serve with a tossed Greek salad, red wine and crusty garlic bread.
[[Category:Greek recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Recipes with metric units|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Snacks|Snacks]]
{{recipesummary|snacks recipes|8|4 Hours|2}}
==Ingredients==
*½ tablespoon [[Cookbook:Dijon mustard|Dijon mustard]] *1 tablespoon [[Cookbook:butter|butter]], room temperature *2 tsp dried [[Cookbook:sage|sage]] *¼ cup [[Cookbook:apple juice|apple juice]] *2 cups sharp [[Cookbook:cheddar cheese|cheddar cheese]], shredded *½ tsp [[Cookbook:pepper|pepper]] *8 oz. package [[Cookbook:cream cheese|cream cheese]], softened *1 loaf [[Cookbook:French bread|French bread]], cut in small slices
==Procedure==
# In a large bowl, mix together mustard, butter, and sage. # Add the apple juice, cheddar cheese, and pepper, stir well. # Add the cream cheese, blending well. # Cover and refrigerate for 3 hours. # When ready to serve, remove from refrigerator and allow to stand for ½ hour. # Spread on bread and serve with [[Cookbook:milk|milk]].
* Makes 2 cups.
[[Category:Snacks recipes]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Indonesia|Cuisine of Indonesia]]
'''Bubur Candil''' are traditional Indonesian glutinous rice balls in a sweet soup
==Ingredients== *225 gram [[Cookbook:Glutinous Rice Flour|glutinous rice flour]] *120 gram [[Cookbook:Tapioca Starch|tapioca flour]] *175 ml [[Cookbook:water|water]] *¼ tsp [[Cookbook:salt|salt]]
===Sauce=== *750 ml [[Cookbook:water|water]] *250 ml [[Cookbook:coconut milk|coconut milk]] *125 ml diluted [[Cookbook:Gula Jawa|gula jawa]] (palm sugar) *1 piece [[Cookbook:pandan leaves|pandan leaves]] (or optionally, some [[Cookbook:Pandan Essence|pandan paste]]) *¼ tsp [[Cookbook:salt|salt]]
===Condiments=== *300 ml [[Cookbook:coconut milk|coconut milk]], boiled for few minutes
==Procedure== #Mix Glutinous Rice Flour and Tapioca Flour until well mixed. Make a well in the middle, pour in water and salt little by little. Mix well with hand until it formed a soft dough, so you can make a little balls shape with 1 cm diameter. Make sure that the dough is not to hard, if necessary add a bit more of water. #Boil a lot of water in a big stock pot. Put the little balls one by one in the boiling water. Cook for about 5 minutes until they emerge on the surface of the boiling water. Take them out and drain. #For the sauce, mix all the sauce ingredients and boil until bubbly. Place the rice balls in the sauce. Cook for further 20 minutes and set aside.
''To serve, pour the coconut milk on top of Bubur Candil. Best to serve while it's hot and this dish is great in Winter''.
[[Category:Rice recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Coconut recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Soup recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Indonesian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Bread recipes|2½ cups biscuit mix|10 minutes
plus cooking time|1}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|American cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Midwestern cuisine|Midwestern cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Vegetarian cuisine|Vegetarian Cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Holiday Recipes|Holiday Recipes]] | [[Cookbook:Bread|Bread]] | [[Cookbook:Dessert|Dessert]] | =Biscuit Mix= ===Ingredients=== * 2 [[Cookbook:Cup|cups]] (280g) all-purpose [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] * 2½ [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoon]] [[Cookbook:Baking Powder|baking powder]] * ½ teaspoon [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * ⅓ cup (80g) [[Cookbook:Shortening|shortening]] * ¼ cup (60ml) powdered [[Cookbook:Milk|milk]] * (⅓-½ cup / 80ml-120ml [[Cookbook:Water|water]]) ===Directions=== # Blend together dry ingredients, then cut in shortening with [[Cookbook:Pastry Blender|pastry blender]] to make mixture as granular as possible. # Use as Bisquick© in recipes. =Variations= ==Backpacking Mix== ===Ingredients=== * 12 cups flour * 2 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoons]] salt * ¼ cup baking powder * 1 [[Cookbook:Pound|pound]] shortening ===Mixing=== # Mix into a coarse texture. # Keep in refrigerator until leaving for camping/backpacking trip. # Divide into 2 or 4 cup portions in baggies or other container for convenient use. ==Directions for [[Cookbook:Dutch oven|Dutch oven]]== # Mix 2 cups with ½ cup water, milk, or condensed milk to use. # Knead no more than 5 times, or biscuits will be tough. # Roll out about ¾ [[Cookbook:Inch|inches]] or 2 [[Cookbook:Centimetre (cm)|centimeters]] thick. # Cut into biscuit size circles. # Place in preheated Dutch oven, starting at the wall and working toward the center. # Replace lid, turning about ⅛ turn for a good fit. # If heat is right, biscuits will be done in about 15 minutes, if brown in 10 minutes or less, the centers may not be done. ===Tips and Notes=== * About 2 cups of mix will pretty well fill a 12 inch Dutch oven. * Place a few more coals or charcoal briquettes on lid than beneath it. * Preheat Dutch oven until '''lightly''' smoking; a moistened finger tapped lightly on the metal will sizzle. [[Category:Inexpensive recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:American recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Midwestern recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Camping recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Bread recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Recipes_with_metric_units|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Side Dish recipes|16 of 150 [[Cookbook:g|g]] each|1-24 hours|3|[[Image:Hummus.jpg|300px|Hummus]]|1400 [[Cookbook:kJ|kJ]] (338 [[Cookbook:kcal|kcal]]) per serving}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the Mediterranean|Mediterranean cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Greece|Greek Cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Hummus|Hummus]] {{basicnutritionsummary|950 [[Cookbook:kJ|kJ]] (227 [[Cookbook:kcal|kcal]]) |7.4 g |12.8 g |1.3 g |4.5 g |7.0 g |23.5 g |4.1 g |5.8 g |430 [[Cookbook:mg|mg]] }}
'''Hummus''' is a tasty and nutritious dip.
==Ingredients== * 3 [[Cookbook:Cup|cups]] raw dried [[Cookbook:Chickpea|chickpeas]] (or skip the soaking and cooking steps, and use 7 cups of drained tinned chickpeas) * 9 cups water (twice) * 1 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|T]] [[Cookbook:Oil|cooking oil]] * ¾ cup (175 [[Cookbook:g|g]]) [[Cookbook:Tahini|tahini]] * ¾ cup freshly squeezed [[Cookbook:Lemon Juice|lemon juice]] * 12 cloves of [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]] (peeled and roughly chopped) * ½ cup extra virgin [[Cookbook:Olive Oil|olive oil]] * 1 T [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * ½ [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|t]] freshly ground black [[Cookbook:Pepper|pepper]] * approximately ¾ cup chickpea cooking liquid
==Procedure== # Soak the chickpeas in the water overnight, then drain. # Gently simmer the chickpeas with the next lot of water (generously salted) and the tablespoon of oil until very soft, but still whole (about 3 hours, or 10 minutes + cooling time if using a pressure cooker). # Drain the chickpeas, and reserve a few cups of the cooking liquid (you will need it later). # Rinse the chickpeas with plenty of cold water, while doing so, gently rub them between your hands to release the skins, they should float away with the rinsing water. After a several changes of water, and removing a majority of the skins, drain the chickpeas again. # Using a [[Cookbook:Food processor|food processor]] (or other means), mix the lemon juice with the tahini. # [[Cookbook:Purée|Purée]] (or mash) the chickpeas in batches, using the lemon juice and tahini mixture, the olive oil, and the cooking liquid as required to maintain the desired consistency (add the garlic to the batch with the olive oil, and process until smooth). # In a large bowl, using a spoon, mix the salt and pepper into the other blended ingredients (add additional cooking liquid, if still too thick).
==Notes, tips, and variations== * Use a pot that will hold several times the volume of the chickpeas and the water for cooking the chickpeas, because they will foam (the tablespoon of oil minimises that, however). * Use olive oil (or Canola oil, it's cheaper) instead of the reserved cooking liquid to thin the hummus, it's nicer, but not as good for you. Alternatively, mix in a tablespoon of olive oil into a serving before eating. * It's particularly good when eaten with sliced French stick ([[Cookbook:Bread|bread]]), but is also a nutritionally sound alternative to most other dips. * Hummus freezes really well, so consider making a double batch, and then freezing most of it in containers small enough to hold two servings (they can be defrosted overnight in the refrigerator, as needed).
[[Category:Greek recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Mediterranean recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Breakfast recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegan recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Bean recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Side Dish recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Chickpea recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Featured recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Gluten-free recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

page.title: Cookbook:Jamaican Chicken Fingers with Honey-Mustard Sauce

revision.text:
{{recipesummary|Chicken recipes|4|15 minutes|3}}
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Jamaica|Jamaican Cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Chicken|Chicken entree]]
'''Jamaican Chicken Fingers with Honey-Mustard Sauce'''
== Ingredients == *1 pound (500 g) boneless, skinless [[Cookbook:Chicken|chicken]] breast *2 [[Cookbook:Egg White|egg whites]] *1 tablespoon (15 mL) [[Cookbook:Honey|honey]] *3 cups (750 mL) cornflakes (crushed to 1 1/2 cups) *1 1/2 teaspoons (7.5 mL) jerk seasoning *1/2 cup (125 mL) honey-mustard salad dressing *1 teaspoon (5 mL) grated [[Cookbook:Lime|Lime]] peel *2 [[Cookbook:Mango|mangoes]], seeded, peeled and sliced
== Procedure == #Pre-heat oven to 450°F. #Trim fat from chicken. #Cut chicken lengthwise into 3/4-inch-wide strips. #In shallow dish whisk together egg whites and honey. #In another shallow dish combine cereal and jerk seasoning. #Dip chicken pieces in egg mixture and then roll dipped pieces in cereal mixture. #Place the cereal-coated pieces in a single layer on an ungreased baking sheet. #Bake at 450°F for 11 to 13 minutes or until tender and no longer pink. #While baking, in small bowl stir together salad dressing and lime peel. #Serve chicken and mango slices with salad dressing mixture.
==Notes, tips, and variations== *This recipe can also be served as an appetizer; it will make 12 servings. *Jerk seasoning can be bought ready-made or you can follow this recipe: [[Cookbook:Jamaican Jerk Spice|Jamaican Jerk Spice]]
[[Category:Chicken recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Appetizer recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Jamaican recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Norway|Cuisine of Norway]]
'''Komle''' is a Norwegian food dish, often eaten along with sausages, boiled carrots and bacon. Made from potatoes, it's a mass of potato shavings, boiled in about fifteen minutes. Also called '''Raspeball.'''
==Ingredients== * 2kg [[Cookbook:Potato|potatoes]] (peeled) * 100g [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] * 20g [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] (about 3-4 tsp) * 150g [[Cookbook:Pork|salted pork]]
==Procedure== # Peel raw potatoes and chop them in a kitchen machine. # Press the water out of the potato mass. # Mix the potatoes with the flour and wait for 10 minutes. # Make big round balls and fill them with pieces of the salted pork. # Boil the balls in light salted beef stock in about 15-20 minutes.
[[Category:Norwegian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Potato recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Pork recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of India|Cuisine of India]]
==Ingredients== * 2 [[Cookbook:Eggplant|bainganas]] (eggplant / brinjal / begun) * 10 [[Cookbook:Curry Leaf|curry leaves]] (kadi patta / bhersunga patra) * 2 tbsp [[Cookbook:Yogurt|dahi]] (yogurt) * [[Cookbook:Oil|oil]] * [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] * [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * [[Cookbook:Panch Puran|panch puran]] (futana / Bengali five spice) * 250ml (1 cup) [[Cookbook:Water|water]] * 2 [[Cookbook:Chili Pepper|red chilies]] (sukhila lanka)
==Procedure==
# Cut medium size eggplant into thin slices, length wise. Deep fry in oil. Keep aside. # Mix dahi with water. # Heat 1 tbsp of oil in a pan, add panch puran, red chili until the spices splutter. # Add dahi-water mix. Add salt (according to taste), and sugar (1 tbsp). Stir properly and make a gravy. # Add fried eggplant to the gravy and lower the flame. # Heat it for 2-3 minutes and then take it out and leave it to cool down.
Serve with rice.
[[Category:Indian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Gluten-free recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}}
'''Chraime''' is a popular [[w:Cuisine of the Sephardic Jews|Sephardic]] fish and vegetable [[Cookbook:casserole|casserole]] often eaten as the first course at [[w:Rosh Hashanah|Rosh Hashanah]]. It can also be eaten as an entrée. Normally served with [[Cookbook:challah|challah]].
==Ingredients== *2 large baking [[Cookbook:potato|potato]]es *2 medium red [[Cookbook:Bell Pepper|bell pepper]]s, cored, seeded, and cut into ½ inch thick wedges *5 [[Cookbook:garlic|garlic]] cloves, peeled and smashed *1 small [[Cookbook:Jalapeño|jalapeño]] or other hot [[Cookbook:Chili Pepper|chili pepper]], quartered and seeded *[[Cookbook:salt|salt]], to taste *1¼ to 1½ pounds of [[Cookbook:white fish|white fish]] fillets ([[Cookbook:sole|sole]], [[Cookbook:halibut|halibut]], or [[Cookbook:cod|cod]]) *1 tablespoon sweet [[Cookbook:paprika|paprika]] *3 ripe [[Cookbook:tomato|tomato]]es, coarsely chopped *1 cup chopped fresh [[Cookbook:Cilantro|cilantro]] or [[Cookbook:parsley|parsley]] *1 cup [[Cookbook:water|water]] *⅓ cup [[Cookbook:Olive Oil|olive oil]] *coarse salt, to taste
==Procedure== # In a large flame-proof casserole or [[Cookbook:Dutch Oven|Dutch oven]], set the potato slices on the bottom. Scatter the bell peppers, garlic, and jalapeño pepper on the potatoes. Sprinkle with salt. Place the fish on top and sprinkle it with paprika and salt. Add the tomatoes and cilantro or parsley. # Pour the water in at the edges. Sprinkle the top with oil and sprinkle generously with salt. # Set the pan over high heat, cover, and bring the mixture to a boil. Reduce the heat slightly and simmer for 25-30 minutes or until the vegetables are tender and the fish is cooked through. Check the pan after 20 minutes; if there seems to be too much liquid, uncover the pan for the remaining cooking time. Serve hot or warm with challah.
[[Category:Fish recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Jewish recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Holiday recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Rice recipes|4|45 minutes|3}}
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Iran|Iranian Cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Side dishes| Rice Side dish]]
'''Zereshk Palau''' is an Iranian rice dish cooked with barberries.
==Ingredients== *1 [[Cookbook:onion|onion]] *1 package of dried [[Wikipedia:Berberis|barberries]] *1 [[Cookbook:tsp|tsp]] [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] *a dash of salt *cooked, diced [[Cookbook:chicken|chicken]] *2 [[Cookbook:cup|cups]] [[Cookbook:Basmati rice|basmati rice]] *vegetable oil *a few threads of saffron
==Procedure== #Soak barberries in water for 20-30 minutes. #Chop onion and saute in oil. #Strain barberries to remove any stones. #Combine barberries with onion and cook on low heat. #Cook chicken on top of rice in a rice cooker. #When rice is done, fluff and put in a large bowl. #Grind saffron with mortar and pestle. #Add a teaspoon of water to ground saffron. #Add some rice to the saffron water and stir. #Return yellow rice to the main dish and add the onion and zereshk mixture. #Fluff ingredients to mix well. #Serve with [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lavash Lavash] or barbari bread.
[[Category:Rice recipes]] [[Category:Iranian recipes]]

{{recipesummary|Beverage recipes|1|5 minutes|1}}
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Beverages|Beverage]]
'''Yoda Soda''' is a fun drink that looks like Master Yoda's head.
== Ingredients == *1 cup Mountain Dew soda *2 scoops vanilla ice cream *pinch of chocolate sprinkles
== Procedure == #Fill glass with soda. #Add ice cream. #Drop a few chocolate sprinkles on the ice cream to look like hair.
[[Category:Dessert recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Beverage recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]
