{{recipe}} [[Image:NCI_flour_tortillas.jpg|thumb|right|Flour tortillas]]
[[Cookbook:Tortilla|Tortillas]] are a type of [[Cookbook:Flatbread|flatbread]] popular in [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Mexico|Mexico]] and [[:Category:Central American recipes|Central America]] commonly made from [[Cookbook:Flour#Wheat Flour|wheat flour]] or [[Cookbook:Corn Masa|masa]]. This recipe is for the wheat flour variety.
== Ingredients == * 4 cups (950ml) unbleached all purpose flour * 2 teaspoons salt * 4 teaspoons baking powder * 2 tablespoons vegetable shortening * 1 1/2 cups (360ml) warm water, more if needed
== Procedure == # In a large bowl, stir together the flour, salt and baking powder. # With a pastry blender, a fork or your hands, gradually work in the lard or shortening until it is all incorporated. # Add enough warm water to make a soft but not sticky dough. # Turn out onto a lightly floured board and knead for 5 minutes. # Divide the dough into 1/4 cup (3 oz / 90g) portions and form them into balls. # Roll each ball into a flat round about 6 inches (10cm) in diameter and 1/8 inches (0.25cm) thick. # Heat a large heavy skillet over medium high heat. # Place the tortillas one at a time into the dry hot skillet; cook until brown on one side, then turn and brown the other side. # Remove from the skillet and keep warm in cloth towel.
==Recipes using flour tortillas include== *[[Cookbook:Burrito|Burrito]] *[[Cookbook:Turkey Wrap|Turkey Wrap]] *[[Cookbook:Crab Quesadillas with Mango Salsa|Crab Quesadillas with Mango Salsa]]
[[Category:Ingredients|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Flatbread recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Mexican recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary |Category = Bread recipes |Servings = 1 |Rating = 2 }} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Finland|Cuisine of Finland]]
'''Maitorieska''' (''rieska'' = milk , pronounced "re-ehskuh", stress on the first syllable, no pause) is a [[Cookbook:Barley|barley]]-based [[Cookbook:Flatbread|flatbread]] that is a local specialty and a very traditional food in the Ylivieska area of [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Finland|Finland]].
==Ingredients==
Makes one flatbread:
* 250[[Cookbook:mL|ml]] (1 cup) [[Cookbook:Milk|milk]] * ⅓ teaspoon [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * 250 - 330ml (1 - 1½ cups) [[Cookbook:Barley|barley]] [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]]
==Procedure==
# Set oven to 300°C (570°F), or as high as it will go. # Mix milk and salt, add flour. Mix the ingredients well. # [[Cookbook:Knead|Knead]] into a flat, round bread (about 0.5 cm / ¼ inch thick). # Bake on an [[Cookbook:Oven Tray|oven tray]] for about 15 minutes or until the surface gets some darker spots. Alternatively, [[Cookbook:Pan fry|fry it in a pan]] on the stove or on open fire.
Eat fresh with [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]] and cold milk.
[[Category:Flatbread recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Finnish recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} {{cookwork}}
'''Quince pudding''' recipe from the 1881 ''Household Cyclopedia'':
Scald the [[Cookbook:quince|quince]]s tender, pare them thin, scrape off the pulp, mix with [[Cookbook:sugar|sugar]] very sweet, and add a little [[Cookbook:ginger|ginger]] and [[Cookbook:cinnamon|cinnamon]]. To a pint of [[Cookbook:cream|cream]] put three or four yolks of [[Cookbook:egg|egg]]s, and stir it into the quinces till they are of a good thickness. [[Cookbook:Butter|Butter]] the dish, pour it in, and bake it.
And, translated into English:
#Scald quinces until tender. #Skin them and scrape the pulp into a mixing bowl. #Blend the pulp with sugar until very sweet. #Add ginger and cinnamon to taste. #Mix 3-4 egg yolks into a pint of cream. #Stir this into the quince pulp until thick. #Butter a pudding-pan. #Pour in the quince-cream mixture. #Bake until firm but still slightly wobbly in the centre. Remove from oven and leave till set.
{{1881}}
[[Category:Pudding and Custard recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|American cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Bread|Bread]] | [[Cookbook:Vegetarian cuisine|Vegetarian Cuisine]]
{{recipesummary|Bread recipes|8|2 Hours|2}}
==Ingredients==
* 1 [[Cookbook:Cup|Cup]] corn meal * 1 Cup all-purpose [[Cookbook:flour|flour]] * 4 [[Cookbook:Tsp|tsp]] [[Cookbook:Baking Powder|baking powder]] * ½ tsp [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * 1 cup [[Cookbook:Milk|milk]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Egg|egg]] * ¼ cup [[Cookbook:shortening|shortening]] * ¼ cup [[Cookbook:sugar|sugar]] ''optional'' * ½ of a 15 ounce can whole corn, drained ''optional''
==Procedure==
# Preheat oven to 425° F. Grease an 8 inch baking pan. # Combine Corn meal, flour, baking powder, salt, and sugar in a large mixing bowl. # Add egg, sugar, and shortening. # [[Cookbook:Beat|Beat]] until fairly smooth; about a minute. # [[Cookbook:Bake|Bake]] for 20-25 minutes or until a toothpick inserted in center comes out clean. ''If corn added to batter, increase time ~50%'' # Serve hot!
[[Category:Inexpensive recipes|Corn Bread, Golden]] [[Category:American recipes|Corn Bread, Golden]] [[Category:Camping recipes|Corn Bread, Golden]] [[Category:Bread recipes|Corn Bread, Golden]] [[Category:Corn recipes|Corn Bread, Golden]] [[Category:Egg recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Milk recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|Corn Bread, Golden]]

{{recipesummary|Dessert recipes|Not nearly enough|Prep 30 minutes
Bake 35-40 minutes
Final Prep 1 hour|5}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|American cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Vegetarian cuisine|Vegetarian Cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Dessert|Dessert]] ==Torte== ===Ingredients=== * 1 [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] semi-sweet [[Cookbook:Chocolate Chips|chocolate chips]] * ½ cup [[Cookbook:Margarine|margarine]] or [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]] * ½ cup all-purpose [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] * 4 [[Cookbook:Egg|eggs]], separated * ½ cup [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] ====Topping==== * chocolate glaze * caramel sauce * chocolate curls, if desired * ½ cup [[Cookbook:Chop|chopped]] [[Cookbook:Pecan|pecans]] ===Procedure=== # Preheat oven to [[Cookbook:Oven_temperatures|325°F]]. # Grease a 9x3-inch springform pan. # Heat chocolate chips and margarine in a two-quart saucepan over medium heat until chocolate chips are melted; cool 5 minutes. # Stir in flour until smooth. # Stir in egg yolks until well blended. # [[Cookbook:Beat|Beat]] [[Cookbook:Egg White|egg whites]] in large bowl on high speed until foamy. # Beat in sugar, 1 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoon]] at a time until soft peaks form. # Fold chocolate mixture into egg whites. # Spread in greased a 9x3-inch springform pan. # [[Cookbook:Bake|Bake]] for 35-40 minutes or until top of cake appears dry and cracked; cool 10 minutes. # Run knife along side of cake to loosen, remove side of pan. Cook cake completely. # Place on serving plate. # Spread top of cake with chocolate glaze; drizzle with caramel sauce. # [[Cookbook:Garnish|Garnish]] with chocolate curls and pecans. =Chocolate Glaze= ===Ingredients=== * 1 [[Cookbook:Ounce|ounce]] unsweetened [[Cookbook:Chocolate|chocolate]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoon]] [[Cookbook:Margarine|margarine]] or [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] [[Cookbook:Powdered Sugar|powdered sugar]] * 5 teaspoons [[Cookbook:Boiling|boiling]] [[Cookbook:Water|water]] [[Cookbook:Boil|boil]] ===Procedure=== # Heat chocolate and margarine over low heat until melted. # Blend in powdered sugar and water until smooth. # Stir in additional boiling water, ½ teaspoon at at time, until of drizzling consistency. ''Makes about ½ cup glaze.'' =Caramel Sauce= ===Ingredients=== * 1 [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] packed [[Cookbook:Brown Sugar|brown sugar]] * ½ cup [[Cookbook:Cream|heavy whipping cream]] * ¼ cup [[Cookbook:Corn Syrup|corn syrup]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoon]] [[Cookbook:Margarine|margarine]] or [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]] * 2 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoon]] ground [[Cookbook:Cinnamon|cinnamon]] ===Procedure=== # Heat all ingredients to [[Cookbook:Boil|boiling]] over medium heat, stirring constantly, reduce heat to low. # [[Cookbook:Simmer|Simmer]] uncovered for 5 minutes. ''Makes about 1¾ cup sauce.'' =Easy Chocolate Curls= ===Procedure=== # Place a bar or block of [[Cookbook:Chocolate|chocolate]] on waxed paper. Make chocolate curls by pulling a [[Cookbook:Vegetable Peeler|vegetable peeler]] toward you across the flattest side of the chocolate, pressing firmly in long, thin strokes. Small curls can be made by using the side of the chocolate bar. # Transfer each curl carefully with a toothpick to wax-lined [[Cookbook:Cookie Sheet|cookie sheet]] or directly onto frosted cake, pie or other dessert. The curls will be easier to make if the chocolate is slightly warm, so let the chocolate stand in a warm place for about 15 minutes before making curls. Semi-sweet chocolate can be used, but the curls will be small. Also, the thicker the bar of chocolate, the larger your curls will be. [[Category:American recipes|Torte, Indulgent Chocolate]] [[Category:Camping recipes|Torte, Indulgent Chocolate]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|Torte, Indulgent Chocolate]] [[Category:Dessert recipes|Torte, Indulgent Chocolate]]

{{recipesummary|Beverage recipes|~75|1 hour|1}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|American cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Vegetarian cuisine|Vegetarian Cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Holiday Recipes|Holiday Recipes]] | [[Cookbook:Beverages|Beverages]]
==Ingredients==
* 1½ [[Cookbook:Gallon|gallons]] [[Cookbook:Apple|apple]] juice * 2x64 [[Cookbook:Ounce|ounces]] [[Cookbook:Cranberry|cranberry]] juice * 2x64 ounces white [[Cookbook:Grape|grape]] juice * 2 [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]]s [[Cookbook:Orange|orange]] juice * 6-ounce package [[Cookbook:Mulling Spices|mulling spices]] * sliced [[Cookbook:Orange|oranges]]
==Procedure==
# Mix together liquid ingredients, then stir in mulling spices. # Warm, but do not boil. # Serve hot.
[[Category:American recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Beverage recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{Recipesummary| |Category=Avocado recipes |Servings=8 |Time=1-2 h |Rating=2 }}
{{Nutrition Summary| |ServingSize=1/8 of recipe |Servings=8 |Cals=250 |FatCals=196 |TotalFat=5.5 g |SatFat=0.7 g |Cholesterol=2.1 mg |Sodium=53.9 mg |Carbs=1.7 g |Fiber=0.8 g |Sugars=0.4 g |Protein=0.6 |VitaminA=46% |VitaminC=78% |Calcium=6% |Iron=14% }}
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Appetizers|Appetizers]]
"Perfect for your next party, this guacamole is decorated to look like your favorite ballpark. A cream cheese baseball tops it off."
=Ingredients= * 4 ounces Neufchatel [[Cookbook:cream cheese|cream cheese]], softened * 1 teaspoon packaged dry buttermilk salad dressing and seasoning mix * 3 large fresh, ripe Hass [[Cookbook:avocados|avocados]], halved, pitted, peeled * 3 tablespoons fresh [[Cookbook:lime juice|lime juice]] * 2 teaspoons coarse ground [[Cookbook:garlic powder|garlic powder]] * 1 teaspoon [[Cookbook:salt|salt]] * 1 teaspoon [[Cookbook:red pepper sauce|red pepper sauce]] * 1/2 cup finely chopped [[Cookbook:red onion|red onion]] * 1/2 cup chopped, prepared roasted [[Cookbook:red bell pepper|red bell pepper]] * 1 [[Cookbook:red bell pepper|red bell pepper]] * 1/2 cup low fat [[Cookbook:sour cream|sour cream]] * Thin wheat crackers * For dipping, bell pepper strips cut 1/2 inch wide, [[Cookbook:tortilla chips|tortilla chips]] and/or crackers
=Procedure= # In bowl, blend cream cheese and buttermilk seasoning. Place in plastic wrap, roll into a ball and chill in freezer for 1 hour or refrigerate overnight. # In bowl, coarsely mash avocado with lime juice, garlic, salt and red pepper sauce. # Stir in red onion and roasted bell pepper. # Using rubber spatula, scoop guacamole onto square plate. Spread out evenly, making a slight mound in center to create a 'pitchers mound'. # Spoon sour cream into pastry bag with fine tip or plastic bag with 1/8 inch corner cut out. Pipe thin 'base lines' onto guacamole 'field'. # To create the red 'stitching' for the baseball, cut the red bell pepper into 1 inch strips. Using a sharp knife, carefully remove fleshy inside of the pepper, reserving the red shiny skin. Slice the skin into very thin strips to create stitch lines for baseball. # To make baseball: Remove cream cheese from freezer or refrigerator. Roll to make a round baseball shape. Remove plastic wrap. Using a wooden pick, form the stitch lines on the ball. Use the very thin pieces of red bell pepper skin to lay over stitch lines. Place 'baseball' on the 'mound' in the center of the guacamole 'field'. # Use thin wheat crackers for 'bases'. # Serve crackers, tortilla chips and/or bell pepper strips as dippers.
[[Category:Avocado recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Appetizer recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

revision.comment: This is an essential ingredient for Wassel.
revision.text:
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Vegetarian cuisine|Vegetarian Cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Holiday Recipes|Holiday Recipes]] ''I've not tried these recipes, but Mulling Spices are also available from [http://www.crownspice.com Instant Gourmet]. The [[Cookbook:Wassel|Wassel]] I had the other night that was so good, was made with the commercial version.'' ==Mulling Spices I== ===Ingredients=== * 2 [[Cookbook:Cup|cups]] dried [[Cookbook:Orange|orange]] peel * 2 cups broken [[Cookbook:Cinnamon|cinnamon]] sticks * 1 cup whole [[Cookbook:Allspice|allspice]] berries * 1 cup whole [[Cookbook:Cloves|cloves]] * 4 broken [[Cookbook:Star Anise|star anise]] ===Directions=== Mix ingredients together well. Store in closed jar. ===Use=== Mix ¼ cup of spices per gallon of wine, cider, or apple juice.
Simmer for 30 minutes.
Serve hot in mugs with cinnamon stick stirrers or fill a punch bowl and garnish with orange slices. ==Mulling Spices II== ===Ingredients=== * 6 [[Cookbook:Cinnamon|cinnamon]] sticks * 1 small whole [[Cookbook:Nutmeg|nutmeg]] * ½ [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] whole [[Cookbook:Cloves|cloves]] * ½ cup whole [[Cookbook:Allspice|allspice]] * Grated peel of one whole [[Cookbook:Orange|orange]] ===Directions=== # Place whole cinnamon sticks and nutmeg in a large Ziploc bag. # Use a hammer to crush the spices into rough chips. # Combine the chips with cloves and allspice. # Store in an airtight container. Makes 1-1/2 cups of mulling spice. ===Use=== To make spiced wine or cider: # Add 2 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoons]] of the spice mixture to 4 [[Cookbook:Cup|cups]] of wine or cider. # Add peel of one fresh orange. # Simmer slowly over medium heat for 5 to 10 minutes. # Strain liquid; serve hot wine or cider in mugs. ==Mulling Spices III== ===Ingredients=== * 2 [[Cookbook:Cup|cups]] [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] * 2 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoons]] ground [[Cookbook:Cinnamon|cinnamon]] * 1 teaspoon ground [[Cookbook:Cloves|cloves]] * 1½ teaspoons ground [[Cookbook:Allspice|allspice]] * ½ teaspoons ground [[Cookbook:Mace|mace]] * ¼ teaspoons ground [[Cookbook:Nutmeg|nutmeg]] ==Mulling Spices IV== ===Ingredients=== * 1 [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] [[Cookbook:Brown Sugar|brown sugar]] * 2 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoons]] ground [[Cookbook:Cinnamon|cinnamon]] * 1 teaspoon ground [[Cookbook:Cloves|cloves]] * 1 teaspoon dried ground [[Cookbook:Orange|orange]] peel * 1 teaspoon ground [[Cookbook:Allspice|allspice]] * ½ teaspoons ground [[Cookbook:Nutmeg|nutmeg]] ===Directions=== # Combine all ingredients in a medium bowl. # Stir with wire whisk until well blended. # Store in airtight containers in a cool place. [[Category:Beverage recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary |Category = Mexican recipes |Servings = 10 |Rating = 2 |Image = [[Image:Machacado con huevo.jpg|300px]] }} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Mexico|Cuisine of Mexico]]
'''Machacado con huevo''' is a dish which consists of shredded dry [[Cookbook:beef|beef]] that is [[Cookbook:Scrambled Eggs|scrambled]] with [[Cookbook:egg|eggs]]. Its name means "shredded with eggs" in Spanish. The shredded dry beef, ''carne seca'', is said to have originated in the town of Ciénega de Flores, about an hour north of Monterrey, [[Cookbook:cuisine of Mexico|Mexico]]. The early settlers in the area air-[[Cookbook:curing|cured]] beef so that it would be preserved. This particular dish was made famous by Tía Lencha, a local woman who prepared it and eventually sold it in a restaurant. Today there is a commercially available Tia Lencha dried beef in most supermarkets in Mexico.
The basic machacado con huevo is made with eggs and dried beef. Chopped [[Cookbook:tomato|tomato]]es, [[Cookbook:onion|onion]]s and [[Cookbook:jalapeño|jalapeño]]s or serrano [[Cookbook:Chili Pepper|chile pepper]]s can be added, or [[Cookbook:Salsa|salsa]] can be cooked into it, to create another version.
Machacado con huevo often comes as a "[[Cookbook:taco|taco]]" presentation.
==Ingredients== *1 tablespoon [[Cookbook:butter|butter]] or [[Cookbook:margarine|margarine]] *6 large [[Cookbook:egg|egg]]s, lightly beaten *2 cups shredded [[Cookbook:beef|beef]] filling *10 (8-inch) soft taco-size [[Cookbook:Flour Tortilla|flour tortilla]]s, warmed *1 (16-ounce) can [[Cookbook:Refried Beans|refried beans]], warmed *2 cups (8-ounces) shredded [[Cookbook:Cheddar Cheese|cheddar]] or [[Cookbook:Monterey Jack Cheese|Monterey Jack Cheese]] *[[Cookbook:Salsa|Salsa]] for accompaniment
==Procedure== #Heat butter in large [[Cookbook:Frying Pan|skillet]] over medium-high heat. Add eggs; cook, stirring frequently, for 2 to 3 minutes or until eggs just begin to set. #Stir in shredded beef filling. Cook, stirring occasionally, for 2 to 3 minutes or until eggs are cooked and beef is heated through. Serve beef filling with tortillas, beans, cheese and salsa.
==Notes, tips, and variations== Machacado con huevo can be served in a big bowl, and with some soft tortillas at hand can be prepared in your plate, can be served in the table as tacos, or can be eaten without using tortillas at all.
Queso fundido con [[Cookbook:chorizo|chorizo]] (Melted cheese with chorizo) is also something that can be found at the table when eating machacado con huevo. It is usually served at the table in a pan, and added to the taco.
[[Category:Mexican recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Egg recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Beef recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

revision.comment: Looks like a cooking-receipt to me.
revision.text:
{{recipesummary|Pasta recipes|4|1 hour|3}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|American cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Italy|Italian cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Meat Recipes|Meat Recipes]]
'''American style Carbonara sauce''': This recipe was shown to me by Dottore (Doctor) Roberto Schirra, in the Italian Army, who welcomed us into his Turin apartment at the end of our strenuous deployment. He explained that it was named for the charcoal that it was first cooked over.
{{see also|Cookbook:Spaghetti alla Carbonara}}
==Ingredients==
* 3-4 [[Cookbook:Quart|quarts]] [[Cookbook:Boiling|boiling]] [[Cookbook:Salt|salted]] [[Cookbook:oil|oiled]] [[Cookbook:Water|water]] * 8 [[Cookbook:Ounce|ounces]] [[Cookbook:Pasta|spaghetti]] * 3 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoons]] [[Cookbook:Olive Oil|olive oil]] * 4 slices smoked [[Cookbook:Bacon|bacon]], [[Cookbook:Dice|diced]] * 1 medium [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]], [[Cookbook:Chopping|chopped]] * ½ [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoon]]-1 tablespoon [[Cookbook:Red Pepper|crushed red pepper]] * 12-16 ounces [[Cookbook:Tomato Sauce|tomato sauce]] * 2-4 ounces freshly grated [[Cookbook:Parmesan Cheese|Parmesan cheese]]
==Procedure==
# Boil spaghetti 6 minutes or so, just [[Cookbook:al dente|al dente]], drain. # As water is put on to boil, start heating olive oil in medium saucepan, and [[Cookbook:Sauté|sauté]] bacon until fat is just clear. # Add onion and sauté until soft. # Add crushed red pepper and cook 2-3 minutes more. # Add tomato sauce and heat through. # Remove from heat, add Parmesan cheese, and serve immediately over spaghetti. # May [[Cookbook:Garnish|garnish]] with additional Parmesan cheese.
==Tips, Notes, and Variations==
* As this is for cooking, virgin or extra virgin olive oil is not necessary, any grade, even "pure" olive oil is sufficient. * "Al dente" means "to the tooth." The pasta should be firm in the center when bitten. * Amount of crushed red peppers is widely variable to suit your taste. * As we sat down to eat, one of my fellow troops reached behind him and got some bread from the counter, Dottore Schirra frowned and said, "You would eat bread with bread?"
[[Category:Inexpensive recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:American recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Italian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Camping recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Bacon recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Meat recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Pasta recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Meat recipes|8-10|30 minutes|2}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|American cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Midwestern cuisine|Midwestern cuisine]] |
==Ingredients==
* ⅔ [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] (160g) [[Cookbook:Cornmeal|corn meal]] * ⅓ cup (60g) [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoon]] [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * ½ cup (120ml) [[Cookbook:Milk|milk]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Egg|egg]], [[Cookbook:Beat|beaten]] * 2 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoon]] [[Cookbook:Vegetable oil|vegetable oil]] * 8-10 [[Cookbook:Hot dog|hot dogs]] * 8-10 wooden skewers
==Directions==
# Preheat [[Cookbook:Deep Fat Frying|deep fat fryer]] to 375°F (190°C). # Combine corn meal, flour, and salt. Add milk, egg, and oil; mix well. # Insert a wooden skewer into one end of each frankfurter. # Coat with flour, then coat with corn meal mixture. # [[Cookbook:Fry|Fry]] a few at a time in deep hot oil until golden brown.
==Tips, Notes, and Variations==
* Dab with mustard, like at a fair.
[[Category:Inexpensive recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:American recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Midwestern recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Camping recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Ham recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Meat recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Recipes_with_metric_units|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|Cuisine of the United States]]
The '''Original Texas-Style Chili''' version of [[Cookbook:chili con carne|chili con carne]] contains no [[Cookbook:Vegetable|vegetables]] at all, except [[Cookbook:Chili Pepper|chili peppers]]. If using fresh peppers, they should have been prepared by being [[Cookbook:Boiling|boiled]], peeled, and chopped. If using dried peppers, they need to be soaked in hot water for 1 hour before being chopped.
==Ingredients== *3 [[Cookbook:Pound|lbs.]] (1.3 {{kg}}) [[Cookbook:Beef|beef]] or other [[Cookbook:Meat|meat]] *2 [[Cookbook:Ounce|oz.]] (55 {{g}}) [[Cookbook:Beef|beef]] kidney [[Cookbook:Suet|suet]] *4 [[Cookbook:Chili Pepper|chili]] pods (previously skinned and blistered, or else buy sun-dried chili peppers) *1 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoon]] dried [[Cookbook:Oregano|oregano]] *1 tablespoon crushed [[Cookbook:Cumin|cumin]] seeds *1 tablespoon [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] *1 teaspoon [[Cookbook:Cayenne Pepper|cayenne pepper]] *1 tablespoon [[Cookbook:Tabasco Sauce|Tabasco sauce]] (optional but frequently included) *2 [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]] cloves, chopped (or more, to taste) *2 heaping tablespoons ''[[Cookbook:Corn Masa|masa harina]]''
Many of the above quantities may be somewhat adjusted up or down, depending on personal taste.
==Procedure== #[[Cookbook:Sear|Sear]] beef in a little cooking [[Cookbook:Oil|oil]] (not [[Cookbook:Lard|lard]]) until lightly browned. Drop the seared beef, [[Cookbook:Suet|suet]], and chile pods in a large iron [[Cookbook:Skillet|skillet]] or pot (at least four [[Cookbook:Quart|quarts]]), and enough water (the reserved "pepper water" if you prepared the pods yourself) to keep the meat from burning. Bring to a boil, then lower heat, cover, and [[Cookbook:Simmer|simmer]] about 30 minutes. #Take pot off the stove and add spices and garlic. Put back on the stove, bring to a boil again, lower heat, and simmer another hour, keeping the lid on as much as possible. Stir when necessary, but remember that too much stirring will tear the meat. Add a little more water if anything seems seriously in danger of burning (but as little water as possible). #Take pot off the stove and skim off all or most of the [[Cookbook:Grease|grease]]. (The old-timers left it all.) Mix in ''masa harina'', which "tightens" or thickens the chili con carne and adds a subtle [[Cookbook:Tamale|tamale]]-like flavor. Simmer about 30 minutes more, until meat is done. Do a lot of tasting during this time, (1) to adjust the seasoning, and (2) just because a chili cook should do a lot of tasting. Serves 6-8.
==Notes, tips, and variations== *The [[Cookbook:Meat|meat]] is simply bite-size - traditionally, it was the size of a [[Cookbook:Pecan|pecan]] nut - or coarsely ground, with 1/2-inch plate holes in a [[Cookbook:Meat Grinder|meat grinder]] as standard. It must always be [[Cookbook:Beef|beef]], [[Cookbook:Venison|venison]], or other mature meats. Stewing meat also works well. Prime beef or [[Cookbook:Veal|veal]], on the other hand, are not suitable for chili con carne, as they tend not to remain solid. *Many cooks omit the [[Cookbook:Suet|suet]] as being much too greasy, although it does add flavor. *[[Cookbook:Ancho pepper|Ancho]] or [[Cookbook:Anaheim pepper|Anaheim]] peppers are recommended. For an "elevated" flavor, use four pepper pods per pound of meat; for a milder "beginners" version, use only 2-3 pods. *[[Cookbook:Chili Powder|Chili powder]] is a barely adequate substitute in the original recipe, but lacks the subtle sting of the pods. A heaping [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoon]] of chili powder is the approximate equivalent of one average-size chili pod. *Crushed tortilla chips can be substituted for masa harina (this is what Alton Brown did on the Food Network show Good Eats)
[[Category:Southwestern recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Beef recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Stew recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Chili recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Recipes_with_metric_units|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|Cuisine of the United States]]
This is a modern version of '''Jailhouse Chili''', as served in the Texas prison system. In the early part of the 20th century, those likely to regularly spend time in local detention facilities in the [[Cookbook:Southwestern cuisine|American Southwest]] were said to rate the accommodations among themselves by the quality of the [[Cookbook:chili con carne|chili con carne]] they were served. This became a matter of local pride and competition with other communities.
==Ingredients== *25 [[Cookbook:Pound|lbs.]] (11 {{kg}}) coarse-ground [[Cookbook:Beef|beef]] *1/2 lb. (225 {{g}}) [[Cookbook:Cumin|cumin]] *1/4 lb. (110 {{g}}) [[Cookbook:Chili Powder|chili powder]] *1/8 lb. (55 {{g}}) [[Cookbook:Paprika|paprika]] *2 handfuls crushed dried red [[Cookbook:Chili Pepper|chili peppers]] *1/2 lb. (225 {{g}}) finely-chopped [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]]
==Procedure== #[[Cookbook:Sear|Sear]] beef in a little cooking [[Cookbook:Oil|oil]] (not [[Cookbook:Lard|lard]]) until lightly browned. Drop the seared beef and chili peppers in a large [[Cookbook:stock pot|stock pot]], and add enough water to keep the meat from burning. Bring to a boil, then lower heat, cover, and [[Cookbook:Simmer|simmer]] about 30 minutes. #Take pot off the stove and add spices and garlic. Put back on the stove, bring to a boil again, lower heat, and simmer another 90 minutes, keeping the lid on as much as possible. Stir when necessary, but remember that too much stirring will tear the meat. Add a little more water if anything seems seriously in danger of burning (but as little water as possible). #Take pot off the stove and skim off all or most of the [[Cookbook:Grease|grease]]. Serve hot.
[[Category:Southwestern recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Beef recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Stew recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Chili recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Recipes_with_metric_units|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|Cuisine of the United States]] | [[Cookbook:Southwestern cuisine|Southwestern cuisine]]
'''New Mexico Chile Verde''' is the most popular version of [[Cookbook:chili con carne|chili con carne]] in the U.S. state of New Mexico. While there apparently is no canonical recipe for Chile Verde (''green chile''), <!--- that I have been able to find---> all versions involve roasting fresh green chile peppers and cooking them slowly with meat (usually [[Cookbook:Pork|pork]] but also [[Cookbook:Beef|beef]], [[Cookbook:Chicken|chicken]], or [[Cookbook:Turkey|turkey]]), [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]], [[Cookbook:Oregano|oregano]], and [[Cookbook:Cumin|cumin]]. The consistency is usually much thinner than Texas-style chili and is sometimes listed on restaurant menus as "green chile stew". In additon to being eaten by the bowl (sometimes with [[Cookbook:Pinto Bean|pinto beans]] or diced [[Cookbook:Potato|potatoes]] added), Chili Verde often is treated as a [[w:condiment|condiment]] and is ladled over [[Cookbook:Burrito|burrito]]s, [[Cookbook:Enchilad|enchilad]]s, [[Cookbook:Hamburger|hamburger]]s, and [[Cookbook:Fried Egg|fried egg]]s.
The following is a representive recipe for Chile Verde, but there are many variations:
==Ingredients== *2 green [[Cookbook:Bell Pepper|bell peppers]], chopped *4 large, mild green [[Cookbook:Chili Pepper|chile peppers]] *5 [[Cookbook:Cup|cups]] water *1 large can (16-[[Cookbook:Ounce|oz.]]) stewed [[Cookbook:Tomato|tomatoes]] *2 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoons]] [[Cookbook:Pork|pork]] [[Cookbook:Bouillon|bouillon]] granules *1 tablespoon dried [[Cookbook:Oregano|oregano]] *1 tablespoon [[Cookbook:Cumin|cumin]] seeds (''not'' powdered) *1 tablespoon [[Cookbook:Coriander|coriander]] *8 [[Cookbook:Ounce|oz.]] ground [[Cookbook:Pork|pork]] *1 large [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]], chopped *6 tablespoons [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]] or [[Cookbook:Margarine|margarine]] *1/3 [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] (240ml) all-purpose [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]]
==Procedure== #Combine bell peppers, chili peppers, water, tomatoes, bouillon, oregano, cumin, and coriander in a large pot. Cook over medium heat until peppers are tender. #Meanwhile, cook pork and onion in a [[Cookbook:Skillet|skillet]] over medium heat, stirring occasionally, about ten minutes, or until pork is browned and crumbly. Drain pork and add to chile mixture. [[Cookbook:Simmer|Simmer]] for 20 minutes. #Heat butter in the skillet over medium-low heat. Add flour. Cook, stirring frequently, until flour browns, about 2 minutes. Add flour mixture to chile. Continue cooking and stirring until thickened to preference. Serves 5-6, usually accompanied by [[Cookbook:Corn Bread|cornbread]].
==Notes, tips, and variations== *If fresh green chili peppers are not available, dried [[Cookbook:Anaheim chili|Anaheim]] chili peppers may be substituted, but the results will be substantially different.
[[Category:Southwestern recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Pork recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Tomato recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Stew recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Chili recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

revision.comment: New page: {{recipesummary|Side Dish recipes|2|5-10 minutes|1}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Vegetarian cuisine|Vegetarian cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Side dishes|Side dishes]] ''This recipe is incredibly qu...
revision.text:
{{recipesummary|Side Dish recipes|2|5-10 minutes|1}}
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Vegetarian cuisine|Vegetarian cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Side dishes|Side dishes]]
''This recipe is incredibly quick to prepare, rich in flavor, and makes a great side dish. The butter adds flavor but can be excluded for vegan/low-fat diets.''
==Ingredients== *½ to 1 T unsalted butter *1 to 2 T olive oil *1 T chopped garlic or shallots *1 head (3-4 cups of leaves) tat soi or any other dark leafy green, base removed (tear into smaller pieces if using a large leaf plant like chard) *soy sauce
==Directions==
Rinse greens thoroughly. Melt butter and olive oil in a wok or sauté pan over Medium High heat. Add garlic and sauté until golden. Stir in tat soi and cook - stirring constantly - until lightly wilted. Remove from heat and cover, allowing the greens to steam in the pan for a minute or two.
When ready to serve, toss with about 1T of soy sauce.
[[Category:Vegetarian recipes|Wilted Greens]] [[Category:Side Dish recipes|Wilted Greens]]

{{recipesummary|Bread recipes|~18 muffins|2 hours|2}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|American cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Breakfast|Breakfast Cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Vegetarian cuisine|Vegetarian Cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Bread|Bread]] |
These are a favorite for American breakfast, with butter, or jelly on top, even though they're not really muffins... and they've never heard of them in England!
==Ingredients==
* 1 [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] warm (105°-115°F) [[Cookbook:Milk|milk]] * 2 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoons]] [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoon]] [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * 3 tablespoons [[Cookbook:Margarine|margarine]] * 1 cup warm (105°-115°F) [[Cookbook:Water|water]] * 1 package [[Cookbook:Yeast|active dry yeast]] * 5 to 6 cups all-purpose [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] * [[Cookbook:Cornmeal|cornmeal]]
==Directions==
# Combine milk, sugar, salt and margarine. # Measure water into large warm bowl, sprinkle in yeast, and stir until dissolved. # Stir in milk mixture and 3 cups flour; beat until smooth. # Add enough additional four to make a stiff dough. # Turn out onto floured board and knead about 2 minutes, or until dough is manageable and can be formed into a ball. (Dough may be slightly sticky.) # Place in greased bowl, turning to grease top. # Cover; let rise in a warm place, free from draft, until doubled in bulk, about an hour. # Punch dough down; divide in half. # On a board, heavily sprinkled with cornmeal, pat each half into a ½-inch thickness. # Cut into circles with a floured 3-inch cookie cutter. # Place on ungreased baking sheets about 2 inches apart. # Cover and let rise in a warm place, free fom drafts, until doubled in size, about ½ hour. # Place on lightly greased medium hot griddle or skillet, cornmeal side down. # [[Cookbook:Bake|Bake]] until well browned, about 10 minutes on each side. # Cool on wire racks. * To serve, split in half and toast.
==Tips, Notes, and Variations==
* You can also start the dough by mixing the yeast, the dry ingredients, and half or more of the flour, with the liquids at 145°-150°F, then continuing the rest of the instructions. * After punching the dough down, many bakers let it rest 10 minutes. * ½ cup of [[Cookbook:Currant|currants]] may be added to the warm milk mixture. * You can substitute 1½ cups [[Cookbook:Flour|whole wheat flour]] for 1½ cups of the all-purpose flour.
[[Category:Inexpensive recipes|Muffins, English]] [[Category:American recipes|Muffins, English}}]] [[Category:Breakfast recipes|Muffins, English]] [[Category:Camping recipes|Muffins, English]] [[Category:Bread recipes|Muffins, English]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|Muffins, English]]

revision.comment: New page: {{recipesummary|Meat recipes|6|4 hours|3}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|American cuisine]] | ==Ingredients== * 2 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoons]] [[Cookbook:...
revision.text:
{{recipesummary|Meat recipes|6|4 hours|3}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|American cuisine]] |
==Ingredients==
* 2 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoons]] [[Cookbook:Olive oil|olive oil]] * 2 tablespoons Montreal steak seasoning * 4 to 5-[[Cookbook:Pound|pound]] boneless [[Cookbook:Pork|pork loin roast]] * 1 large red [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]], [[Cookbook:Chop|chopped]] * 1½ [[Cookbook:Cup|cups]] [[Cookbook:Red Wine|red wine]]
==Directions==
# Heat olive oil in 10-inch [[Cookbook:Dutch oven|Dutch oven]] over campfire. # Rub seasoning on roast. # Add roast to Dutch oven, turning to brown on all sides. # Add onion, [[Cookbook:Sauté|sauté]] 5 minutes. # Pour wine over roast. # Cover and cook slowly for three hours over fire.
[[Category:Inexpensive recipes|Pork Roast, Wine-Roasted]] [[Category:American recipes|Pork Roast, Wine-Roasted]] [[Category:Camping recipes|Pork Roast, Wine-Roasted]] [[Category:Ham recipes|Pork Roast, Wine-Roasted]] [[Category:Pork recipes|Pork Roast, Wine-Roasted]] [[Category:Meat recipes|Pork Roast, Wine-Roasted]]

{{recipesummary|Camping recipes|8|1 hour|3}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|American cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Beans|Beans]] | [[Cookbook:Rice|Rice]]
==Ingredients==
* 6 slices [[Cookbook:Bacon|bacon]] * 1 medium [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]], [[Cookbook:Dice|diced]] * ½ [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] diced [[Cookbook:Celery|celery]] * ½ cup diced [[Cookbook:Bell Pepper|bell pepper]] * 4½ cups [[Cookbook:Water|water]] * 2 packages Uncle Ben's Original Recipe Long Grain and Wild Rice * 3 cans black-eyed peas * 3 [[Cookbook:Jalapeño|jalapeños]], seeded and diced
==Directions==
# Dice bacon, brown in large [[Cookbook:Dutch Oven|Dutch oven]], remove bacon, and reserve 2 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoons]] of grease in pan. # Add onion, celery, and bell pepper, and [[Cookbook:Sauté|sauté]] 5 minutes. # Add rice and seasoning packet, water, and black-eyed peas; cover and [[Cookbook:simmer|simmer]] 25 minutes. # Add bacon and jalapeños, cover and heat 5 to 10 minutes more.
[[Category:Inexpensive recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:American recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Camping recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Bacon recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Meat recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Rice recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Camping recipes|8|1½ hours|3}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|American cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Beans|Beans]]
==Ingredients==
* ½ [[Cookbook:Pound|pound]] [[Cookbook:Bacon|bacon]] (cut into bite-sized pieces) * 1 pound [[Cookbook:Ground Beef|ground chuck]] * 1 large [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]], [[Cookbook:Chop|chopped]] * 2 [[Cookbook:Garlic|cloves garlic]], minced * ⅓ [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] [[Cookbook:Brown Sugar|brown sugar]] * ⅓ cup [[Cookbook:White sugar|white sugar]] * 2 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoons]] [[Cookbook:Molasses|molasses]] * ¼ cup [[Cookbook:barbecue sauce|barbecue sauce]] * 2 tablespoons [[Cookbook:Mustard|mustard]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoon]] [[Cookbook:Pepper|pepper]] * 2 teaspoons [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * ½ teaspoon [[Cookbook:Chili Powder|chili powder]] * 32-[[Cookbook:Ounce|ounce]] can pork and beans
==Directions==
# Brown bacon, ground chuck, and onion. # Stir in remaining ingredients in order; mix well in between each addition. # [[Cookbook:Bake|Bake]] at [[Cookbook:Oven_temperatures|350°F]] for about 40 minutes, or until thickened.
==Tips, Notes, and Variations==
* Good with [[Cookbook:Corn Bread|corn bread]]
[[Category:Stew recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:American recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Camping recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Bacon recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Ham recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Beef recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Meat recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Russia|Cuisine of Russia]] | [[Cookbook:Soups|Soups]]
'''Montreal Russian Borscht'''; this recipe was a prize winner in Montreal, Canada's Russian community
==Ingredients== * 7 litres [[Cookbook:water|water]] * 1 can stewed [[Cookbook:tomato|tomato]]es, or an equivalent amount of fresh tomatoes * 1 small can [[Cookbook:tomato paste|tomato paste]] * [[Cookbook:sugar|sugar]] and [[Cookbook:salt|salt]], to taste * 1 large [[Cookbook:onion|onion]], thinly sliced * 1 or 2 cloves [[Cookbook:garlic|garlic]] * 5 or 6 medium [[Cookbook:beet|beet]]s, peeled and julienned * 3 medium [[Cookbook:carrot|carrot]]s, peeled and julienned * 1 [[Cookbook:potato|potato]], julienned (optional) * ½ large [[Cookbook:white cabbage|white cabbage]], shredded
==Procedure== # Fill large [[Cookbook:stock pot|stock pot]] with water. Add can stewed tomatoes, tomato paste, sugar, salt, onion, garlic, and beets, and bring to a [[Cookbook:boil|boil]] for 20 minutes. # Add carrots, cabbage, and optionally the potato. # Return to a boil and cook for 1.5 hours
==Notes, tips, and variations== It's very important to remember that this particular recipe is somewhat like wine. The older it gets, the better it gets. It is recommended to let sit in refrigerator for at least two days, before serving. The difference is truly remarkable.
[[Category:Soup recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegan recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Russian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Canadian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Borscht recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Beet recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Cabbage recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Vietnamese recipes|4|15 minutes|1|Image=[[Image:East-asian-food-spring-rolls-3.jpg|300px]]}}
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Vietnam|Cuisine of Vietnam]]
'''Summer Rolls''', or ''Gỏi Cuốn'' in [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Vietnam|Vietnamese]], are wraps of various ingredients in rice wafers, and are often confused with [[Cookbook:Nem|Nem]] or spring rolls (which, in turn, are often confused with [[Cookbook:Egg Roll|egg rolls]]).
==Ingredients== * 4 [[Cookbook:Rice Wafer|rice wafers]] (rice paper, tapioca sheet) * 4-8 [[Cookbook:Shrimp|prawns]] * 50g cooked [[Cookbook:Pork|pork]] or [[Cookbook:Chicken|chicken]] meat * 50g cooked [[Cookbook:Vermicelli|vermicelli]] (thin rice noodles) * 1 [[Cookbook:Cucumber|cucumber]], sliced into fingers * 4 leaves of [[Cookbook:Lettuce|lettuce]] (leafy variety - Romaine/Cos, Mignonette, etc.) * 2 leaves of [[Cookbook:Nappa Cabbage|Chinese cabbage]], halved lengthways * fresh herbs, to taste (e.g. [[Cookbook:Cilantro|coriander]], [[Cookbook:Basil|basil]], [[Cookbook:Mint|mint]]) * a bowl of warm [[Cookbook:Water|water]]
==Procedure== [[Image:East-asian-food-spring-rolls-1.jpg|thumb|right|Ingredients before rolling]] Repeat for each summer roll: # Dip a rice wafer into the warm water and remove immediately when it is completely wet - it only needs to be in the water for a few seconds # Lay the rice wafer on a board or plate # Arrange a portion of the ingredients near the edge of the rice wafer in a neat pile, with the fingers of cucumber roughly parallel to the edge of the wafer # Fold the edge of the wafer over the pile of ingredients, and roll it over once # Fold the sides of the wafer inwards, to close of the ends of the roll you just made # Roll the wafer up the rest of the way, to enclose the roll completely # Set aside for 5 minutes to dry a little before eating
==Notes, tips, and variations== * Summer rolls can easily be made vegetarian by omitting the prawns and meat, and adding more greens and vegetables like [[Cookbook:Bean Sprouts|bean sprouts]], [[Cookbook:Snow Pea|snow pea sprouts]], fingers of [[Cookbook:Carrot|carrot]]
==External links== {{Wikipedia|Summer roll}} *[http://www.chooseveg.com/summer-roll.asp Video demonstrating how to make summer rolls]
[[Category:Vietnamese recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Gluten-free recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Recipes_with_metric_units|{{PAGENAME}}]]

revision.comment: There are no carrots in a traditional Cornish pasty
revision.text:
{{recipesummary|Meat recipes|8|Prep 30 minutes
Bake 1 hour|3}} {{recipe}} A '''pasty''' (Cornish: ''pasti'', ''hoggan'', incorrectly written as ''pastie'') is a type of pie, originally from Cornwall, in the [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United Kingdom|United Kingdom]]. It is a [[Cookbook:Baking|baked]] savory pastry case traditionally filled with diced meat and sliced vegetables. The ingredients are uncooked before being placed in the unbaked pastry case. Pasties with traditional ingredients are specifically named "Cornish pasties". Traditionally, pasties have a semicircular shape, achieved by folding a circular pastry sheet over the filling. One edge is crimped to form a seal. ==Ingredients== * 1 medium [[Cookbook:Rutabaga|rutabaga]] * 4 large [[Cookbook:Potato|potatoes]] * 4 medium [[Cookbook:Onion|onions]] * 2 [[Cookbook:Pound|pounds]] [[Cookbook:ground beef|ground beef]] * 4 [[Cookbook:Pie Crust|pie crusts]] * [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] and [[Cookbook:Pepper|pepper]] to taste ==Directions== # Preheat oven to [[Cookbook:Oven_temperatures|325°F]] # [[Cookbook:Cube|Cube]] [[Cookbook:Vegetable|vegetables]] into bite-sized pieces, except the carrots and onions. Cut the carrots in half length-wise and then cut into quarter-inch slices. [[Cookbook:Dice|Dice]] the onions. # Mix all the ingredients together, similar to a [[Cookbook:meatloaf|meat loaf]]. Make sure hamburger is mixed completely through the vegetables. # Roll out your pie crust and cut in half. # Put a spoonful of the mixture on half the pie dough. Bring the other half of the dough over the top of the mixture. # Use a fork to seal the dough around the edges. # Poke holes in the top of the pastry to allow steam to escape. # [[Cookbook:Bake|Bake]] for one hour. ==Rewarming== * Place on a cookie sheet in the oven and make a tent with foil over them so only the inside is heated, and not the pie crust. * By a campfire, just lay on a hot rock or on a plate tilted towards the fire; before long they are warm and ready to eat. ==Tips, Notes, and Variations== * Substitute venison burger or dove for hamburger. * Vegetables - try corn or different types of beans. {{Wikipedia|Pasty}} [[Category:Inexpensive recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Pot Pie recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Cornish recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Meat recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Beef recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Pastry recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetable recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Cake recipes|8, ''unless you LIKE cake''|1 hour|1}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|American cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Vegetarian cuisine|Vegetarian Cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Bread|Bread]] | [[Cookbook:Dessert|Dessert]] |
''This is a fast and easy cake to make.''
==Ingredients==
* 1 can (20 [[Cookbook:Ounce|ounces]]) crushed [[Cookbook:Pineapple|pineapple]] with juice, undrained * 1 can (21 ounces) [[Cookbook:Cherry|cherry]] pie filling * 1 package yellow cake mix * 1 [[Cookbook:Cup|cups]] [[Cookbook:Chop|chopped]] [[Cookbook:Pecan|pecans]] * ½ cup [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]]
==[[Cookbook:Dutch Oven|Dutch Oven]] Directions==
# Preheat Dutch Oven and grease. # Dump in pineapple with juice and spread evenly. # Dump in pie filling and spread evenly. # Sprinkle cake mix evenly over cherry layer. # Dot with butter # [[Cookbook:Bake|Bake]] about 50 minutes. # Sprinkle chopped pecans on top.
==Conventional oven Directions==
# Preheat oven to [[Cookbook:Oven_temperatures|350°F]]. # Grease 13x9 inch pan. * Proceed as above starting with #2.
==Tips, Notes, and Variations==
* Coals for Dutch Oven: very few on bottom, more on top. * Put a glass full of water in the middle of the Dutch Oven before baking to help it bake evenly, from inside and out. * Use any pie filling you want. * Serve warm or room temperature.
[[Category:Inexpensive recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:American recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Camping recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Bread recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Dessert recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Cake recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Sauces|Sauces]]
'''Cheese sauce''' is a variation of [[Cookbook:Béchamel Sauce|Béchamel Sauce]].
==Ingredients==
*1 tablespoon [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]] *1 tablespoon [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] *1 or 2 cloves of crushed & minced [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]] (optional) *1 cup [[Cookbook:Milk|milk]] *1 cup [[Cookbook:Cheese|cheese]] *½ teaspoon mustard (optional) *[[Cookbook:Salt|Salt]] as desired
==Procedure== # Melt the butter in a [[Cookbook:Saucepan|saucepan]]. Add the flour and garlic and [[Cookbook:whisk|whisk]] together over medium heat for 2-3 minutes, to make a white [[Cookbook:Roux|roux]]. Do not allow to brown. Remove from heat and allow to cool nearly to room temperature. # Add hot milk to the roux and whisk to combine. (This will also work with a hot roux and room temperature milk.) # Add the salt, cheese and mustard and heat till just simmering and cheese has melted. # If desired, you may bring the sauce to a [[Cookbook:boil|boil]]; once the cheese sauce has come to a boil, lower the heat to low and very slowly [[Cookbook:simmer|simmer]] for about 45 minutes. Stir it every so often to avoid sticking to the bottom (a whisk is appropriate here). Do not allow the sauce to brown. The longer the sauce is simmered, the smoother it becomes due to the cooking and swelling of the starch grains.
[[Category:Sauce recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Cheese recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary | Category = Appetizer recipes | Servings = 8 | Rating = 2 }} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|Cuisine of the United States]] | [[Cookbook:Appetizers|Appetizers]]
'''Hornickels' Glazed Onion Canapes'''
This recipe is a slightly modified version of the onion canapés that I find very enjoyable. Notice that the recipe is for 8 canapés and may need to be doubled or tripled to meet needs.
==Ingredients== *1 [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]] *1/2 cup [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]] or [[Cookbook:margarine|margarine]] *2 teaspoons [[Cookbook:Brown Sugar|brown sugar]] *1 tablespoon of [[Cookbook:Honey|honey]] *8-10 [[Cookbook:Cracker|crackers]] *[[Cookbook:Sour Cream|Sour cream]]
==Procedure== #Prepare all ingredients by finely dicing the onion and melting half the butter in a small saucepan. #Turn the burner up to gas mark 5 or medium heat. Add the diced onions into the saucepan. #Slowly caramelize the onions, adding in the rest of the butter as needed to keep from burning. #Once caramelized, add the brown sugar and the honey. Combine thoroughly until all the onions are glazed. #Place onions attractively onto the crackers and finish with a small dollop of sour cream.
==Notes, tips, and variations== *Keep an eye on the onions, they burn easily. *All measurements are not exact, play around to see what you like. *Makes 8-10 canapés.
[[Category:Appetizer recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:American recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Meat recipes|6-12|½ hour|2}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|American cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Mexico|Mexican cuisine]] |
''When I visited San Antonio, TX, years ago, my cousin took me to the Texas Folklife Festival, where he introduced me to fajitas, telling me that they were originated by poor people who cut "beef skirts" (skirt steak) across the grain to make this tough cut much more tender.''
==Ingredients==
* 1 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoon]] [[Cookbook:Vegetable oil|vegetable oil]] * 2 [[Cookbook:Pound|pounds]] skirt steak or flank steak * 4 small [[Cookbook:Onion|onions]] * 2 small red, yellow, or [[Cookbook:Green Pepper|green peppers]] * 12 [[Cookbook:Tortilla|tortillas]] * [[Cookbook:Salsa Fresca|salsa fresca]] * [[Cookbook:Chunky Guacamole|chunky guacamole]]
==Directions==
# Heat the oil in a large frying pan over medium-high heat. # Cook the steak on both sides, about 12 minutes for medium, and remove from pan. # Slice the onions and peppers and [[Cookbook:Sauté|sauté]] until soft. # Warm tortillas in a skillet. # Thinly slice the steak on the diagonal, and arrange on a platter with the vegetables. # Serve with salsa, guacamole, and the tortillas.
[[Category:Inexpensive recipes|Fajitas, Beef]] [[Category:American recipes|Fajitas, Beef]] [[Category:Mexican recipes|Fajitas, Beef]] [[Category:Camping recipes|Fajitas, Beef]] [[Category:Meat recipes|Fajitas, Beef]] [[Category:Beef recipes|Fajitas, Beef]]

{{recipesummary|Sauce recipes|3 cups|15 minutes|2}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|American cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Mexico|Mexican cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Vegetarian cuisine|Vegetarian cuisine]]
==Ingredients==
* 2 [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]] cloves * 4 [[Cookbook:Jalapeño|jalopeño]] chilis, sliced in half, seeded, and veined * 1 medium [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]] * ¼ [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] [[Cookbook:Cilantro|cilantro]] leaves * 2 large, or 6 small [[Cookbook:Tomato|tomatoes]], cored
==Directions==
# [[Cookbook:Chopping|Chop]] the ingredients in order listed. # If using [[Cookbook:Food Processor|food processor]] or [[Cookbook:Blender|blender]], drop in with the blades running, but avoid liquefying the tomatoes.
==Tips, Notes, and Variations==
* If you plan to store the sauce in the refrigerator, place in a jar and pour a [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoon]] of [[Cookbook:Vegetable oil|vegetable oil]] over the top.
[[Category:Inexpensive recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:American recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Mexican recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Sauce recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Salsa recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetable recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

revision.comment: I you can't make this, just go to Tacky-Bell!
revision.text:
{{recipesummary|Vegetable recipes|6|½ hour|1}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:North American cuisines|North American cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Mexico|Mexican cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Southwestern cuisine|Southwestern cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Vegetarian cuisine|Vegetarian Cuisine]] ==Ingredients== * 3 ripe [[Cookbook:Avocado|avocados]] * 2 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoons]] [[Cookbook:Lime|Lime juice]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] of [[Cookbook:Salsa Fresca|salsa fresca]] ==Directions== # Peel and [[Cookbook:Dice|dice]] avocados. # Sprinkle the avocados with lime juice. # Add salsa fresca. ==Tips, Notes, and Variations== * If you don't plan on serving immediately, place an avocado pit in the bowl to prevent browning and cover tightly with plastic wrap and store in refridgerator. ==See Also== [[Cookbook:California cuisine|California cuisine]]
[[Cookbook:Tex-Mex cuisine|Tex-Mex cuisine]]

revision.comment: New page: {{recipesummary|Rhubarb recipes|a bunch|2 hours +|3}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|American cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Dessert|Dessert]] ==Ingredients== * 1 [[Cookb...
revision.text:
{{recipesummary|Rhubarb recipes|a bunch|2 hours +|3}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|American cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Dessert|Dessert]]
==Ingredients==
* 1 [[Cookbook:Lemon|Lemon]] * 2 [[Cookbook:Orange|oranges]] * 4 [[Cookbook:Pound|pounds]] [[Cookbook:Rhubarb|rhubarb]] * 1 pound [[Cookbook:Raisin|raisins]] * 3 pounds [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]]
==Directions==
# Remove juice from lemon and oranges and combine with rhubarb cut into small pieces. # [[Cookbook:Chop|chop]] lemon and orange rind along with raisins; add to rhubarb. # Mix all and let stand for 30 minutes. # Add sugar and bring to a [[Cookbook:Boil|boil]], then [[Cookbook:simmer|simmer]] one hour, stirring often. # When the mixture gets thick, pour into glasses or crock. # When cool, seal.
[[Category:Inexpensive recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:American recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Dessert recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Camping recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetable recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Rhubarb recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Pastry|Pastry]] | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Latvia|Latvia]]
'''Alexandertorte''' or '''Aleksander Torte''' (Raspberry Filled Pastry Strips).
==Ingredients==
* ½ lb (225g) [[Cookbook:Butter|unsalted butter]], chilled, cut in bits * 3½ cups [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] * 3 tbsp [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Egg|egg]] * 1½ cups [[Cookbook:Jams and Jellies|raspberry preserves]] (12-oz) * 2 tbsp [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]], softened * 2 cups [[Cookbook:Powdered Sugar|confectioner's sugar]] * ¼ cup [[Cookbook:Water|cold water]] * 2 tsp [[Cookbook:Lemon Juice|lemon juice]]
==Procedure==
# In a large mixing bowl, combine the chilled butter, 3 cups of the flour and the sugar and, with your fingertips, rub until the mixture resembles flakes of coarse meal. Beat in the egg and continue to mix until the pastry is smooth. Shape it into a ball, wrap it in wax paper, and refrigerate 1 hour, or until the dough is firm. # With the back of a spoon, rub the preserves through a fine sieve set over a 1-quart saucepan, then cook over moderate heat, stirring constantly, for 3 to 5 minutes, or until they thicken into a thin purée. Set aside off the heat. # Preheat the oven to 250°F (120°C). # Cut the chilled pastry in half and shape each half into a rectangle. One half at a time, roll the pastry between two sheets of lightly floured wax paper into a rectangle approximately 10 inches wide and 15 inches long. # With a pastry brush, coat each of 2 cookie sheets with 1 tablespoon of butter and sprinkle them with flour, tipping the sheets from side to side to coat them evenly. Then invert the sheets and tap them against a hard surface to dislodge any excess flour. # Peel off the top sheets of wax paper and use the bottom ones to lift the 2 rectangles of pastry onto the 2 cookie sheets. Peel off the remaining sheets of wax paper. # Bake 40 minutes, or until the pastry begins to turn a pale gold. Watch carefully for any sign of burning and regulate the heat accordingly. # With a metal spatula, spread the raspberry purée evenly over one sheet of the pastry, covering it completely and smoothly. Slide the second sheet of pastry gently onto the first. # With a spoon stir the sugar, water and lemon juice together in a large mixing bowl to form a thin paste. Spread the icing over the top layer of pastry with the spatula, and set the cake aside to cool to room temperature. # With a small, sharp knife or pastry wheel, slice the Aleksander Torte into strips 1 inch wide and 2 inches long, cutting the ends on the diagonal.
[[Category:Latvian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Pastry recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes]]

{{recipesummary|Dessert recipes|6|Prep 15 minutes
Bake ½ hour|2}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:North American cuisines|North American cuisine]]| [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|American cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Vegetarian cuisine|Vegetarian Cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Vegetables|Vegetables]] | [[Cookbook:Bread|Bread]] | [[Cookbook:Dessert|Dessert]] ==Ingredients== * stale [[Cookbook:Cake|cake]] or [[Cookbook:Bread|bread]] * 2 [[Cookbook:Cup|cups]] [[Cookbook:Rhubarb|rhubarb]] * 4 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoons]] [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] * 2 [[Cookbook:Egg White|egg whites]] ==Directions== # Line a [[Cookbook:Butter|buttered]] baking dish with slices of plain stale cake or bread. # Fill with sweetened rhubarb. # Cover and [[Cookbook:Bake|bake]] in a moderately slow [[Cookbook:Oven_temperatures|325°F]] oven about 30 minutes. # Make a [[Cookbook:Meringue|meringue]] of the egg whites by [[Cookbook:Beating|beating]] until very stiff and adding sugar. # Remove pudding from oven and cover with the meringue. # Return to slow oven to brown the meringue. {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Flatbread|Flatbread]] | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of India|Cuisine of India]]
'''Bhatoora''' is a soft and fluffy [[Cookbook:Cuisine of India|Indian]] fried bread, and is generally eaten with a [[Cookbook:Chickpea|chickpea]] [[Cookbook:Curry|curry]], ''choley''.
==Ingredients==
*5 cups [[Cookbook:Flour#Wheat Flour|wheat flour]] *1 cup [[Cookbook:Yogurt|yoghurt]] *1 tsp [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] *2 tsps [[Cookbook:Ghee|ghee]] *2 tsps [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] *½ tsp [[Cookbook:Yeast|yeast]] OR 1 tsp [[Cookbook:Baking Soda|baking soda]]
==Procedure==
# Sieve the flour and salt together. # Mix the yeast with half a cup of lukewarm water and keep aside for ten minutes. # Mix the ghee (clarified butter) and the sugar with the flour. Add the yoghurt and dissolved yeast or the baking soda. A little more lukewarm water may be added if necessary. Knead well until the dough becomes soft and pliable. Use a little oil to knead well. # Cover it with a wet cloth and keep aside for four hours. # Heat the ghee in a frying pan. Make small balls and roll them, spread a little with your palms and fry in hot ghee until golden brown. Serve hot with ''Channa'' or ''choley'' (chickpea curry).
==See also== * [[Cookbook:Batooru|Batooru]]
[[Category:Indian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Flatbread recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Flatbread|Flatbread]] | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of India|Cuisine of India]]
'''Batooru''' is a [[Cookbook:Cuisine of India|North Indian]] [[Cookbook:Fermentation|fermented]] bread similar to [[Cookbook:Bhatoora|bhatoora]], but is mostly popular in traditional Himachali cuisine. This bread requires overnight preparation.
==Ingredients==
* [[Cookbook:Flour#Wheat Flour|wheat flour]] * 1 tsp [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * 2 tsps [[Cookbook:Ghee|ghee]] * [[Cookbook:Water|water]] as required to knead the dough
==Procedure==
# Mix wheat flour and salt together. Add ghee and mix well so that there are no lumps and the ghee is evenly absorbed. Add water in small amounts and knead well until the dough becomes soft and pliable. # When the dough is ready, form the dough into balls and roll them flat. Keep it slightly thick, unlike a bhatoora which is rolled to be very thin. Place the rolled batooru on a clean cloth and cover them with another moist cloth. Leave them covered overnight. # The next morning, take the batooru out from cloth and shallow fry them like a [[Cookbook:Parantha|parantha]] and serve them hot. These are usually served with [[Cookbook:Sabzi|sabzi]] (spicy cooked vegetables), [[Cookbook:Lassi|lassi]] and [[Cookbook:Mango Chutney|mango pickles]].
[[Category:Indian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Flatbread recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Vietnam|Cuisine of Vietnam]]
'''Bánh Xèo''' are [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Vietnam|Vietnamese]] [[Cookbook:Crêpe|crêpe]]-type pancakes made out of rice flour and [[Cookbook:Coconut Milk|coconut milk]](optional), and are pan-fried and stuffed with slivers of fatty pork, shrimp, and bean sprouts. Served wrapped with lettuce leaves and stuffed with mint (optional) and other herbs, and dipped in [[Cookbook:Fish Sauce|Nước mắm]].
''The recipe from [http://dinnercoop.cs.cmu.edu/dinnercoop/Recipes/loan/VietnamesePancakes.html Dinner Co-Op] is as follows:''
''Vietnamese Pancakes (Banh Xeo), Loan Ly, Makes 10 pancakes''
==Ingredients==
* 1¾ cups of [[Cookbook:Rice Flour|rice flour]] * ¼ tsp [[Cookbook:Turmeric|turmeric]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Scallion|scallion]], thinly sliced * ¼ cup plus 2 Tbs of [[Cookbook:Vegetable Oil|vegetable oil]] * 1 pound (450g) of lean [[Cookbook:Pork|pork]] shoulder or loin, cut into ¼ inch thick slices * 1 pound (400g) of medium [[Cookbook:Shrimp|shrimp]], peeled and deveined * 1 small [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]], thinly sliced * 10 medium [[Cookbook:Mushroom|mushrooms]], sliced (optional) * 1¼ tsp. [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * 1¼ tsp. freshly ground [[Cookbook:Pepper|pepper]] * 2½ cups of [[Cookbook:Bean Sprouts|mung bean sprouts]]
==Procedure==
# In a medium bowl, whisk the rice flour together with 2 cups of water. Add turmeric and scallion and mix well. Set batter aside. (Can be kept in refrigerator for up to three days.) # In a large non-stick skillet, heat 1½ tsp of oil over high heat. Add 3 slices of pork, shrimp, few slices of onion, and 1 slice of mushroom. Seasoned with salt and pepper. Cook until onion starts to brown slightly, about 1 min. # Stir the rice flour batter and ladle ⅓ cup of it into the pan. Tilt the pan to distribute the batter evenly. Keep the heat high, cover, and cook until the sides of the pancake turns deep brown and curled up, about 3-4 minutes. # Scatter ¼ cup of sprouts onto the pancake. Fold it in half and slide it onto a warm plate. # Serve the pancakes with dipping sauce on the side. You can eat it wrapped in lettuce and herbs or plain. Suggested herbs are [[Cookbook:Mint|mint]] and [[Cookbook:Basil|basil]].
[[Category:Pancake recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vietnamese recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[ja:バインセオ]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Dessert|Dessert]]
'''Hazelnut Tort'''
==Ingredients==
* 10 [[Cookbook:Egg White|egg whites]] * 1 cup [[Cookbook:Caster sugar|caster sugar]] * 200g (7oz) [[Cookbook:Hazelnut|hazelnut meal]] * 250ml (8 fluid oz) [[Cookbook:Cream|cream]] * ½ teaspoon [[Cookbook:Coffee|instant coffee powder]] * ½ teaspoon [[Cookbook:Chocolate|cocoa powder]]
==Procedure==
# Pre-heat oven to Very Hot. # Beat egg whites with electric mixer till stiff. During mixing, add caster sugar in small amounts to make sure it dissolves into egg. # Once mixture forms stiff peaks, gently fold in the hazelnut meal. # Line a lamington or slice tray (approximately 40cm X 25cm) with foil. Spread mix evenly into tray. DO NOT BANG TRAY - it is important to keep as much air in the cake as possible. # Once cake is in oven, IMMEDIATELY turn temperature down to 180°C (350°F). Bake for 20 minutes, or until cake is sealed and springs back when touched lightly with finger. # Allow cake to cool in the tray. Cake should only be about an inch high. # Once cooled, cut cake into 3 equal sections to be stacked on top of each other. # In a bowl, dissolve coffee and cocoa into cream. Once dissolved, whip cream until stiff. # Layer cream between the sections of cake to make a log. Decorate top with extra cream.
==Notes, tips and variations== * Cake is best made the day before serving to allow the flavors to mature.
[[Category:Dessert recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Confection recipes|about 25|10 - 12 minutes (plus refrigeration time)|1}}
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Confections|Confections]]
An easy snack named from their resemblance to the nut of the [[w:Aesculus|Buckeye tree]].
==Ingredients== * 1 [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] [[Cookbook:peanut butter|peanut butter]] * 2 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoons]] [[Cookbook:butter|melted butter]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoon]] [[Cookbook:vanilla|vanilla]] * 3 [[Cookbook:Cup|cups]] [[Cookbook:powdered sugar|powdered sugar]] * 1 small bag [[Cookbook:chocolate chip|semi-sweet chocolate chips]] * 25 [[Cookbook:Toothpick|toothpicks]]
==Method== *Mix peanut butter, melted butter, vanilla, and powdered sugar in a bowl. *Form the mixture into 1-inch balls. *Place a toothpick into each ball. *Refrigerate or freeze for an hour. *Melt the semi-sweet chocolate chips in a double boiler. *Dip the balls in the melted chocolate, leaving a small exposed circle. *Place on wax paper and remove toothpick. *Refrigerate or freeze.
==Related recipes== * [[Cookbook:Chocolate balls|Chocolate balls]]
