{{recipesummary | Category = Fermented food recipes | Servings = About 2 litres | Time = prep: 1 hour
ferment: 2-3 months | Rating = 3 }} {{recipe}} | [[:Category:Ingredients|Index of Ingredients]] | [[Cookbook:Fermentation|Fermentation]] '''Cider vinegar''' - also '''apple cider vinegar''', '''ACV''', is a type of [[Cookbook:Vinegar|vinegar]] made from apples. Cider vinegar has a unique flavour, coming from the apples used to make it. Some recipes require cider vinegar, although other vinegars may be substituted. Being made totally from apples, cider vinegar is [[Cookbook:Gluten-Free|gluten free]] unlike, say, [[Cookbook:Malt vinegar|malt vinegar]]. However, some commercial brands add wheat-derived substances such as [[Cookbook:Caramel|caramel]] (as colouring), so it is important to read the labels when purchasing. Cider vinegar isn't hard to make; in fact, it's easier to make cider vinegar than it is to make cider! The basic procedure is to make cider from fresh apples, but use no preservatives and keep the lid open to let oxygen in. A recipe follows. ==Ingredients== * 4kg (8 lb) fresh [[Cookbook:Apple|apples]] ==Equipment== * two 3 litre fermenters (can be large bottles or food-grade plastic buckets) * apple crusher or juice maker * food-grade siphon hose (from hardware store or homebrew shop) ==Procedure== # Wash the apples to remove obvious dirt, and cut out any bruised or bird-struck bits. # Crush the apples, or put them through a juice maker, and collect the juice in one of the fermenters. # Cover the fermenter with a cloth, or plug the opening with cotton wool if narrow, to keep out dust and insects. Don't worry that the fermenter isn't full, as it should be for making cider. With vinegar, air space is good, as it brings oxygen to the bacteria. # Set aside somewhere to ferment, not too warm or too cool (about 18-22°C / 64-72°F is best). # Allow the juice to ferment. It should start getting bubbly within a couple of days. Note the progress, so that you can tell when fermentation has peaked and is slowing down. # When the fermentation is slowing down and not bubbling so vigorously, siphon into the other fermenter carefully. Try not to get too much of the gunk that has settled to the bottom, or the froth on top - the aim is to get a clear cider without too many floating chunks! # Set the second fermenter aside to ferment for two to three months. After a while, you should see a white film forming on top. Don't despair - this is the ''vinegar mother'', a structure built by the vinegar-making bacteria ([[w:Acetobacter|acetobacter]]) # After a couple of months, you can draw off two thirds of the vinegar for use, and top up with fresh, clear cider made in the first fermenter. ==Notes, tips and variations== * Use only glass, stainless steel, or food grade plastic when making cider vinegar. The acids in apple juice, and further created by fermenting to vinegar, will leach chemicals from other plastics and corrode some metals. * Cider vinegar is better when made with a blend of apples including cider varieties - e.g. sharps and bitters, not just sweets - but pretty much any apples will do. * Apple juice that is free of preservatives can be used instead of crushing fresh apples. Just add [[Cookbook:Yeast|yeast]] to get the initial fermentation going, and stir occasionally for the first two weeks to help encourage the acetic bacteria. ==External links== *[http://ourworld.compuserve.com/homepages/andrew_lea/ Andrew Lea's pages on cider and cider vinegar] [[Category:Ingredients|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Fermented food recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Gluten-free recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Cake recipes|4|1 hour|3}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|American cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Vegetarian cuisine|Vegetarian Cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Dessert|Dessert]] | [[Cookbook:Cake|Cake]]
==Ingredients==
* 1 [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] * 3 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoons]] [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] * juice and [[Cookbook:Zest|zest]] of 1 [[Cookbook:Lemon|lemon]] * 2 [[Cookbook:Egg|eggs]], separated * 1 tablespoon [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]] * [[Cookbook:Pinch|pinch]] of [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * 1 cup [[Cookbook:Milk|milk]]
==Directions==
# Slightly beat egg yolks. # Mix the sugar and flour together and add the lemon juice and zest, yolks, butter and salt. # Stir in the milk and mix well. # [[Cookbook:Beat|Beat]] the [[Cookbook:Egg White|egg whites]] untill stiff and fold into the first mixture. # Pour into custard cups (or [[Cookbook:Ramekin|ramekins]]). # Set the cups in a pan of hot water and bake at [[Cookbook:Oven_temperatures|350°F]] for about 40 minutes.
==Tips, Notes, and Variations==
* The sponge may also be baked in a pie shell.
[[Category:Inexpensive recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:American recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Dessert recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Cake recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Bread Recipes|Bread Recipes]]
{{recipesummary|Bread recipes|8|6-8 Hours|3}}
==Ingredients== *1 [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] warm [[Cookbook:Water|water]] (95-110 degrees F) *2 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoons]] dry [[Cookbook:Yeast|yeast]] *2 tablespoon [[Cookbook:Honey|honey]] *1 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoon]] [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] *3 ½ cups [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] *¼ cup [[Cookbook:Olive Oil|olive oil]]
==Procedure== #In a mixing bowl, mix warm water, salt and honey. Start off with extra warm water so that it is still at the proper temperature for yeast. #With the honey and salt fully dissolved, stir in the yeast and set aside for 5 minutes. #Add 1 cup of flour and stir completely. #Keep adding flour until dough begins to form a ball and is not sticky. #Now knead dough thoroughly for a minute then cover bowl with lid. #Let rise 1 hour. Then punch dough down. Let dough rise again for 1 1/2 - 5 hours. #Preheat oven to 475°F (245°C) (add 20 minutes if using a pizza stone) #Shape or freeze (See below) #If using crust immediately, add desired toppings. #Bake 15-25 minutes.
==Notes, tips and variations== * This recipe will produce two 16" pizza crusts * Add crushed/pressed garlic to dough with first cup of flour. * Substitute [[Cookbook:Olive Oil|olive oil]] with [[Cookbook:Sesame Oil|sesame oil]]. * If you're baking on a cookie sheet, sprinkle flour lightly on the sheet and pat dough to desired shape and size. * If baking on a pizza stone, lightly flour a wooden pizza peel or paddle, and pat out dough on peel. * At this point, the crust can be frozen for later use or used immediately. To freeze, place entire cookie sheet in the freezer. When it is frozen, remove crust from sheet, wrap tightly in plastic wrap and return to freezer. When ready to use, put toppings on frozen crust and bake as directed.
[[Category:Bread recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Pie recipes|2 Pies|2 hours (with pre-prepared crusts)|3}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|American cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Vegetarian cuisine|Vegetarian Cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Dessert|Dessert]]
''Raisin Crumb Pie - makes two pies.''
==Ingredients==
* 1 [[Cookbook:Pound|pound]] [[Cookbook:Raisin|raisins]] * 1½ [[Cookbook:Cup|cups]] cold [[Cookbook:Water|water]] * 3 cups [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] (divided) * 2 cups [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] * ¼ cup [[Cookbook:Shortening|shortening]] * 1 cup [[Cookbook:Milk|milk]] * 2 [[Cookbook:Egg|eggs]], well-beaten * 2 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoons]] [[Cookbook:Baking Powder|baking powder]]
==Directions==
# Wash and clean raisins and add the cold water and 1½ cups of sugar. # Cook until the raisins are tender and plump. # Set aside to cool. # Preheat oven to [[Cookbook:Oven_temperatures|440°F]]. # Mix the flour, 1½ cups of sugar, and the shortening, [[Cookbook:Crumble|crumbling]] well with the fingers. Take out one cup of these crumbs and set aside. # To the remaining crumb mixture, add the eggs and milk; mix well. # Stir in the baking powder. # Line two large pie tins with [[Cookbook:Pie Crust|pie crust]] and fill with cooked raisins. Pour over this the batter and sprinkle the top with the cup of reserved crumbs. # [[Cookbook:Bake|Bake]] in a hot oven at 440°F for 10 minutes, reduce heat to moderate oven (350°F) and finish baking, about 35 minutes.
[[Category:Inexpensive recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:American recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Dessert recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Pie recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}}
'''Bizcochito''' or '''biscochito''' is a crispy butter biscuit flavored with anise and [[Cookbook:cinnamon|cinnamon]]. It was developed by residents of New Mexico over the centuries from the first Spanish colonists of New Mexico. The recipe for making the cookie has been greatly influenced not only by local and indigenous customs, but also by recipes brought to New Mexico by immigrants from other Hispanic countries. It is served during special celebrations, such as wedding receptions, baptisms, and religious holidays (especially during the Christmas season). It is usually eaten with morning [[Cookbook:coffee|coffee]] or milk, after lunch in the early afternoon, or dinner late at night. The cookie is seldom known outside its various territories.
There is no 'official' recipe, or formula for making bizcochitos. Each region or area, and often each family, has its own distinct recipe for baking bizcochitos. Below is a basic, traditional recipe. However it can normally be divided into two different recipes, the Gonzales and Lucero recipes are the most popular.
==The Gonzales Recipe (Southern New Mexico)== ===Ingredients=== *1 pound (.5kg) pure [[Cookbook:lard|lard]] *1½ cups (150g) [[Cookbook:sugar|sugar]] *2 tsp. (20g) [[Cookbook:Anise|anise seed]] (crushed) *2 [[Cookbook:Egg|eggs]], beaten *6 cups (400g) [[Cookbook:flour|flour]] *3 tsp. (30g) [[Cookbook:Baking Powder|baking powder]] *1 tsp. (10g) [[Cookbook:salt|salt]] *½ cup (125ml) [[Cookbook:brandy|brandy]] * [[Cookbook:Cinnamon Sugar|cinnamon sugar]] for topping
===Procedure=== #Cream the lard, sugar, and anise in a large mixing bowl. Add eggs and beat well. #Combine flour, baking powder, and salt in a large mixing bowl. #Alternately add flour and brandy to creamed mixture until a stiff dough has formed. #Knead dough slightly and pat or roll to a ¼ to ½ inch (.5 to 1cm) thickness. #Cut into desired shapes. #Bake in an oven preheated to 350°F (180°C) for 10-12 minutes or until golden brown. #Dust, while still hot, with cinnamon sugar. #Let cool.
==The Lucero Recipe (Northern New Mexico)== ===Ingredients=== *½ cup butter, softened *½ cup granulated sugar *1 egg yolk *1 tablespoon milk *1½ cups all-purpose flour *1 teaspoon baking powder *½ teaspoon anise seed *¼ teaspoon ground cinnamon *cinnamon sugar for topping
===Procedure=== #Heat oven to 350°F (180°C). Combine butter and ½ cup sugar in large bowl. Beat at medium speed, scraping bowl often, until creamy. Add egg yolk and milk; beat until well mixed. Reduce speed to low. Add flour, baking powder, anise seed and ¼ teaspoon cinnamon; beat until mixture forms a ball. #Roll out dough on lightly floured surface to ¼-inch thickness. Cut with 1-inch cookie cutters. #Combine 2 tablespoons sugar and ¾ teaspoon cinnamon in small bowl. #Put one face of the cookie into the cinnamon sugar mixture. Place one inch apart, with the cinnamon sugar-covered side up, onto ungreased cookie sheets. #Bake for 5 to 8 minutes or until edges are lightly browned. #Let cool.
[[Category:Mexican recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Dessert recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Cookie recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} ==Recipe 1== ===Ingredients=== * 4 tablespoons (½ stick) unsalted [[Cookbook:butter|butter]] * 1 cup whole, 2 percent fat, or 1 percent fat [[Cookbook:milk|milk]] * 1¼ cups [[Cookbook:flour|flour]] * 1 tablespoon [[Cookbook:sugar|sugar]] * 4 teaspoons [[Cookbook:Baking Powder|baking powder]] * ¾ teaspoon [[Cookbook:salt|salt]] * 2 [[Cookbook:egg|egg]]s * 6 ounces semisweet [[Cookbook:chocolate chips|chocolate chips]], or less to taste * [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]], for cooking ===Procedure=== #Combine the butter and milk in a small [[Cookbook:saucepan|saucepan]]. #Place over low heat just until warm and the butter is melted. Let cool slightly. #In a bowl, combine the flour, sugar, baking powder, and salt; mix well. #In a large bowl, [[Cookbook:whisk|whisk]] the eggs with a fork. Whisk in the milk mixture. #Add the dry ingredients and mix just until barely blended. #Add the chocolate chips and mix. #Heat a [[Cookbook:griddle|griddle]] or large [[Cookbook:skillet|skillet]] over medium heat. #Add about 1 teaspoon of butter and melt until bubbly. #Ladle 3 tablespoons of batter for each pancake onto the hot surface and cook until bubbly on the top and golden brown on the bottom. #Turn and cook until golden brown on the other side, about 30 seconds more. #Repeat until all the batter is used. #Serve hot. ==Recipe 2== {{recipesummary|Pancake recipes|8 4-inch pancakes|prep 10 minutes
5 minutes per skillet of pancakes|2}} ===Ingredients=== * 1 [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] all-purpose bleached [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] * 2 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoons]] [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] * ½ teaspoon [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * ½ teaspoon [[Cookbook:Baking Powder|baking powder]] * ¼ teaspoon [[Cookbook:Baking Soda|baking soda]] * ¾ cup [[Cookbook:Buttermilk|buttermilk]] * ¼ cup [[Cookbook:Milk|milk]] * 1 large [[Cookbook:Egg|egg]] * 2 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoon]] unsalted [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]], melted * 1 teaspoon [[Cookbook:Vanilla|vanilla extract]] * [[Cookbook:Vegetable oil|vegetable oil]] for brushing [[Cookbook:Griddle|griddle]] * 8 tablespoons miniature [[Cookbook:Chocolate Chips|chocolate chips]] ===Procedure=== # Heat a large non-stick [[Cookbook:Skillet|skillet]] or griddle over low heat while preparing ingredients. # Mix flour, sugar, salt, baking powder, and baking soda in medium bowl. # [[Cookbook:Microwave Oven|Microwave]] buttermilk and milk in a 2-cup Pyrex (glass) measuring cup to room temperature, 20 to 30 seconds. # [[Cookbook:Whisk|Whisk]] in egg, butter, and vanilla. # Add wet ingredients to dry ingredients and whisk until just mixed. # Return batter to measuring cup, stirring in a teaspoon or two of [[Cookbook:Water|water]], if necessary, to make a thick but pourable batter. # Increase heat to medium and generously brush skillet or griddle with oil. # When oil starts to spider, but before it starts to smoke, pour batter, about ¼ cup at a time. # Work in batches, if necessary, to avoid overcrowding. # Sprinkle 1 tablespoon miniature chocolate chips on uncooked side of each pancake as it cooks. # When pancake bottoms are golden brown and tops start to bubble (2 to 3 minutes), flip pancakes. # Cook until pancakes are golden brown on remaining side. # Repeat, brushing skillet or griddle with oil. # Serve hot. ===Tips, Notes, and Variations=== * Use all-purpose flour (which is softer than unbleached), not unbleached flour, to make a tender pancake. * If using salted butter, reduce salt to ¼ teaspoon. * I usually substitute a tablespoon of lemon juice (or vinegar) in milk for the buttermilk. * Pancake batter should pour, not glug! On the other hand, runny batter makes thin, oddly shaped pancakes that frequently collide on the griddle. Stir in a touch more flour into thin batter. For batter that's too thick, whisk in water, a teaspoon at a time. * The temperature of the pan or griddle is important: too hot and the pancakes are dark and raw; too cool and they're blond and hard. For tender, golden brown pancakes, heat the pan or griddle on low while you make the batter. Then increase the heat to medium and generously brush the pan or griddle with oil. It's ready when the oil starts to shimmer and, in any skillet or griddle other than non-stick, sends out tendrils that resemble an octopus or spider. But if the pan starts to smoke, set it down off the burner until the smoking subsides and the oil cools a bit. * This recipe easily doubles for a crowd. [[Category:Inexpensive recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:American recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Camping recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Breakfast recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Pancake recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Chocolate recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Egg recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Milk recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vanilla recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|American Cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Salad Recipes|Salad Recipes]] | [[Cookbook:Salad dressing|Salad dressing]]
There are many variations of this salad dressing. This should serve as a basic template. {{recipesummary|Salad Dressing recipes|1.5 cups|15 minutes|2}} ==Ingredients== *1 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoon]] (15 [[Cookbook:mL|mL]]) [[Cookbook:Dijon Mustard|Dijon-style mustard]] *2 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoons]] (30 [[Cookbook:mL|mL]]) [[Cookbook:Honey|honey]] *3 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoons]] (45 [[Cookbook:mL|mL]]) [[Cookbook:Lemon|lemon]] juice *½ [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoon]] (7.5 [[Cookbook:mL|mL]]) [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] *½ [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoon]] (7.5 [[Cookbook:mL|mL]]) freshly ground [[Cookbook:Pepper|black pepper]] *¾ [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] 250 [[Cookbook:mL|mL]] [[Cookbook:Safflower oil|safflower oil]]
==Procedure== #Combine the mustard, honey, lemon juice, salt and pepper. #Gradually whisk the safflower oil into the mixture to form a creamy dressing.
==Notes, tips, and variations== *When whisking in a bowl on the counter, put a towel under it to keep it from spinning around.
[[Category:Salad Dressing recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Dessert recipes|8|prep 15 min, setting 120 min|2|Image=[[Image:Key limepie.jpg|thumb|300px|Key lime pie]]}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Southern cuisine|Southern US Cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Dessert|Dessert]] '''Key lime pie''' is made of [[Cookbook:Key lime|Key lime]] juice, [[Cookbook:Egg|eggs]], [[Cookbook:condensed milk|condensed milk]], and [[Cookbook:sugar|sugar]] in a pre-baked [[Cookbook:Pie crust|pie shell]]. The pie is then baked, often with a [[Cookbook:Meringue|meringue]] on its top. Other recipes (with slightly different ingredients) call for it to be chilled or frozen, using an unbaked [[Cookbook:Graham Cracker|Graham cracker]] crust. This makes it a popular summer dessert. The dish is named after the small Key limes (''[[W:Citrus aurantifolia|Citrus aurantifolia]]'' 'Swingle') that are naturalized throughout the Florida Keys. Their ferocious thorns make them less tractable and their thin yellowish rind makes them less shippable, but they are both tarter and more aromatic than the common [[Cookbook:Persian lime|Persian limes]] seen year-round in most U.S. grocery stores. Proper Key lime pie is made with canned sweetened condensed milk, since fresh milk was not a common commodity in the Florida Keys before modern refrigerated distribution methods. Key lime juice, unlike regular lime juice, is a pale yellow. As such, Key lime pies are also pale yellow."Conch Cooking" L.P. Artman, Jr., August 1975 Florida Keys Printing & Publishing, page 74 Green Key lime pies, such as the one in the opening scene of ''Natural Born Killers'', are not authentic,http://sneakykitchen.com/Recipes/key_lime_pie.htm Authentic Key Lime Pie and the green color is due to added food coloring. Many "Key lime" pies are made with standard Persian limes since they tend to be larger and yield more juice, thus making them easier to work with. During mixing, a reaction between the condensed milk and the acidic lime juice occurs which causes the filling to thicken on its own without requiring baking. Many early recipes for key lime pie did not instruct the cook to bake the pie, relying on this chemical reaction to produce the proper consistency of the filling. Today, in the interest of safety due to consumption of raw eggs, pies of this nature are usually baked for a short time. The baking also thickens the texture more than the reaction alone. ==Ingredients== *1 prepared 9-inch (9 [[Cookbook:Ounce|oz.]]) [[Cookbook:Graham Cracker|Graham cracker crust]] *1 can (14 [[Cookbook:Ounce|oz.]]) [[Cookbook:Condensed milk|sweetened condensed milk]] *½ [[Cookbook:cup|cup]] fresh [[Cookbook:key lime juice|Key lime juice]] *1 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|tsp.]] grated [[Cookbook:zest|lime zest]] *2 [[Cookbook:cup|cups]] [[Cookbook:whipped topping|whipped topping]] or [[Cookbook:whipped cream|whipped cream]] *lime slices (optional) ==Equipment and supplies== small [[Cookbook:Mixing Bowl|mixing bowl]], [[Cookbook:spatula|spatula]], [[Cookbook:Mixer|stand mixer]]. ==Procedure== #Begin by beating the sweetened condensed milk and lime juice in a small mixer bowl. #Pour the milk and lime juice mixture into the Graham cracker crust. #Spread with whipped topping. #Refrigerate for 2 hours or until it is set. #Lime slices can be used for garnish. ==Notes, tips, and variations== *There are several variations that require cooking. *There are several variations that call for raw egg yolks. *If eggs are used, the yolks go in the pie and the whites can be used to make a meringue. *Raw eggs can be hazardous to your health. ==References==
{{Wikipedia|Key lime pie}} [[Category:Southern recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Dessert recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Pie recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Lime recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

__NOTOC__ {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Austria|Austrian Cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Dessert|Dessert]] {{recipesummary|Cake recipes|8|prep: 30 min, baking 45 min|5|Image=[[Image:Sachertorte_DSC03027.JPG|thumb|right|250px|''Sachertorte'' from Hotel Sacher, Vienna.]]}}
'''Sachertorte''' (Ger. ˈzɑxər ˈtɔrtə; Eng.ˈsɑkər ˈtɔrt) is a chocolate cake, invented by Franz Sacher in 1832 for Klemens Wenzel von Metternich in Vienna, Austria. It is one of the most famous Viennese culinary specialties.
The cake consists of two layers of dense, not overly sweet chocolate dough with a thin layer of apricot jam in the middle and dark chocolate icing with shreds of chocolate on the top and sides. This is traditionally eaten with whipped cream, as most Viennese consider the Sachertorte too "dry" to be eaten without.
The trademark for the "Original Sachertorte" was registered by the Hotel Sacher, which was built in 1876 by the son of Franz Sacher. The original recipe is a well-kept secret.
== Ingredients == * 6 [[Cookbook:egg|egg]]s, [[Cookbook:separating eggs|separated]] * 1/2 cup (120ml) [[Cookbook:granulated sugar|granulated sugar]] * 1 cup (240ml) [[Cookbook:flour|flour]] * 1 cup (240ml) [[Cookbook:confectioners sugar|confectioner's sugar]] * 9 tbsp (135mL) [[Cookbook:butter|butter]] * 1 tsp (4mL) [[Cookbook:vanilla extract|vanilla extract]] * 4 1/2 oz (130g) [[Cookbook:dark chocolate|dark chocolate]]
== Procedure == # Butter 9 in. (22cm) pan and line bottom with parchment paper. Preheat oven to 325°F (163°C). # Melt chocolate in [[Cookbook:microwave oven|microwave]], remove, and let cool, while stirring often. # Beat butter in mixer, then, on low, add confectioners sugar. Return to high, beat for 2 more minutes, beat in [[Cookbook:egg yolk|egg yolk]]s one at a time, then add chocolate and vanilla. # [[Cookbook:Whisk|Whisk]] [[Cookbook:egg whites|egg whites]] and granulated sugar together in a bowl. Stir 1 quarter of it into the chocolate mix, then [[Cookbook:fold|fold]] in the rest. # [[Cookbook:Sift|Sift]] half the flour into mixture, fold in, and repeat with remaining flour. # Spread evenly in pan, then [[Cookbook:bake|bake]] for about 45 min. # Let cool 10 min, then remove from pan. # Glaze and frost cake to your liking.
== Notes, Tips and Variations == *[[Cookbook:Sachertorte (Duramecho version)|Sachertorte (Duramecho version)]]
{{Wikipedia}}
[[Category:Recipes with metric units|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Austrian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Dessert recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Cake recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Chocolate recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

__NOTOC__ {{recipesummary|Dessert recipes|8|prep: 30 min, baking: 80 min|5|Image=[[Image:Sachertorte_DSC03027.JPG|thumb|right|250px|''Sachertorte'' from Hotel Sacher, Vienna.]]}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Austria|Austrian Cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Dessert|Dessert]]
'''Sachertorte''' (Ger. ˈzɑxər ˈtɔrtə; Eng.ˈsɑkər ˈtɔrt; Ger. zah-khuhr tawr-tuh; sah-ker tawrt); is a [[Cookbook:chocolate|chocolate]] [[Cookbook:cake|cake]], invented by [[Wikipedia:Franz Sacher|Franz Sacher]] in 1832 in Vienna, Austria. It is one of the most famous Viennese culinary specialties. The word is sometimes split into Sacher torte.
The cake consists of two layers of dense, not overly sweet chocolate dough with a thin layer of [[Cookbook:apricot|apricot]] jam in the middle and dark chocolate icing with shreds of chocolate on the top and sides. This is traditionally eaten with whipped cream, as most Viennese consider the Sachertorte too "dry" to be eaten without.
The trademark for the "Original Sachertorte" was registered by the Hotel Sacher, which was built in 1876 by the son of Franz Sacher. That original recipe is a well-kept secret.
==Ingredients== '''Cake''' *6 [[Cookbook:Egg|eggs]] *200 [[Cookbook:gram|g]] [[Cookbook:Caster sugar|caster Sugar]] *125 [[Cookbook:gram|g]] dark eating [[Cookbook:Chocolate|chocolate]] ([[Cookbook:Semisweet chocolate|semisweet]] or [[Cookbook:Bittersweet chocolate|bittersweet]]) *125 [[Cookbook:gram|g]] plain [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] *100 [[Cookbook:gram|g]] unsalted [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]] *5 [[Cookbook:mL|mL]] [[Cookbook:Vanilla|vanilla]] extract
'''Filling''' *150 [[Cookbook:g|g]] [[Cookbook:Apricot|apricot]] [[Cookbook:Jam|jam]] '''Glaze''' *150 [[Cookbook:g|g]] [[Cookbook:Golden Syrup|golden syrup]] *150 [[Cookbook:gram|g]] dark eating [[Cookbook:Chocolate|chocolate]] ([[Cookbook:Semisweet chocolate|semisweet]] or [[Cookbook:Bittersweet chocolate|bittersweet]])
==Equipment and supplies== Oven. 2 mixing bowls. Whisk. Knife. Scales. Microwave oven with microwaveable bowl or a hob & saucepan. Round cake tin (preferably [[Cookbook:Springform pan|springform]] with removeable bottom) about 20 cm diameter & 10 cm high. A cup (or similar as temporary egg yolk container). Greaseproof paper.
==Procedure== '''Cake''' *Preheat the oven to 170°C.
''Egg White Foam'' :#Split eggs, putting the whites in a mixing bowl. :#Whisk until fairly stiff and foamy. :#Add three quarters of the sugar. :#Whisk until fully stiff and foamy, incorporating as much air as possible.
''Butter Foam'' :#Butter should be room temperature and soft. Alternatively, carefully soften butter in microwave (do not melt). :#Put the remaining sugar in a mixing bowl. :#Add the butter. :#Add vanilla. :#Put the first load of chocolate in the microwave bowl and melt the chocolate in the microwave, avoiding cooking or burning it. :#Meanwhile, return to the butter/sugar mix and whisk until it goes pale & creamy looking. :#Add the egg yolks. :#Add the molten chocolate. :#Gently (not whisking) mix the ingredients in the bowl.
#Add the whites foam to the butter/yolk/sugar mixture. #Add the flour to the mix via a sieve, carefully avoiding lumps of flour. #Mix very gently, folding the ingredients together. Ensure the heavy chocolate does not all end up at the bottom of the bowl. #Line the cake tin with greaseproof paper. #Fill cake tin with the mix. #Bake at 170°C for about 70 min. #Allow to cool in the tin upside down until at room temperature (about 30 min).
'''Filling''' :#Microwave the jam until it melts. :#Cut the cake body in half horizontally and place the halves with inner (cut) faces uppermost. :#Pour the molten jam onto both halves of the cake. :#Allow it to soak in. :#Reassemble the cake, with cut surfaces together. :#Allow the surface to cool again.
'''Glaze''' :#Microwave the golden syrup (150 g of syrup is about 100 ml) and remaining chocolate together until the syrup just starts to bubble. :#Stir until they are smoothly mixed. :#Allow to cool to about 25°C. :#This should now be spreadable and able to support a thickness of about 2 mm on a vertical surface (test on the wall of the bowl) yet return to shiny soon after being spread. If it is too hard or soft, add more golden syrup or chocolate and go back to the microwaving stage. (The exact amount of syrup needed depends on the sugar content of the chocolate. You want about equal weights of syrup and chocolate for normal UK plain eating chocolate (which is 50% cocoa solids) but more syrup if using darker (e.g. 70%) chocolate.) :#Spread cake body with the glaze. :#Leave it to set.
==Notes, tips, and variations== *Do not accidentaly get any fat (from the egg yolks, butter or chocolate) in the egg white mix or it will go flat. *The little bubbles in the egg white foam are what inflate the cake. *Do not allow flour lumps in the mix because lumps of white flour show up badly in this brown cake. *To get the traditional perfectly cylindrical shape, trim the cake body into a circle with vertical edges & cut the top off flat before glazing. *Adding alcohol to the cake is not a good idea. It is already very moist and more liquid will make it soggy. *Don't use white chocolate in the cake body because it is fairly unnoticeable by flavour and colour, leaving only the moistening effect. *Don't use self-raising flour. It creates large bubbles in the cake. *If carried out in the order above, no tool should need to be washed up more than once. *There are several other recipes for [[Cookbook:Sachertorte|Sachertorte]], some use even more eggs in the cake and egg and cream in the glaze.
==References== *Orginal Source: [http://duramecho.com/Food/Sachertorte/index.html Duramecho Sachertorte] included here in slightly edited format under [http://www.gnu.org/copyleft/gpl.html GNU General Public License]
{{Wikipedia|Sachertorte}}
[[Category:Austrian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Dessert recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Cake recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Chocolate recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Recipes with metric units|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary |Category = Indonesian recipes |Servings=6-8 |Time = prep: 30 minutes
ferment: 2-4 days |Rating = 2 }} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Fermentation|Fermentation]] | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Indonesia|Cuisine of Indonesia]] '''Tapai''', also '''tape''' (pronounced "tah-pay"), is a traditional [[Cookbook:Fermentation|fermented]] food of [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Indonesia|Indonesia]], although present in some form throughout [[Cookbook:Southeast Asian cuisines|South-East Asia]]. It can be made from various starchy staple foods including [[Cookbook:Cereal Grain|grains]] and [[Cookbook:Rhizome|tubers]], each giving it a distinctive taste and texture, and often a specific local name. Tapai tastes sweet, tangy, a bit yeasty, and is slightly alcoholic (or not so slightly, if left to ferment longer). The following recipe is for a common variant called ''tape ketan'' (ketan means ''glutinous rice''; when made with black glutinous rice, it is ''tape ketan-hitam''). ==Ingredients== * 2 cups [[Cookbook:Rice|glutinous rice]] (sticky rice) * 4 cups [[Cookbook:Water|water]] * 1 cake of ''ragi tapai'' (see notes) * Optional: a couple of drops of [[Cookbook:Pandan Essence|pandan paste]] (to colour it green) ==Procedure== # Rinse the rice and cook it in the water, unsalted. If adding pandan paste, add it now. The absorption method is usually easiest: bring the water to boiling point with the rice in it, then put the lid on the pot and turn the element or flame down to lowest possible setting and simmer for 15 minutes. # Allow rice to cool down to about 30°C / 86°F. To help it cool down faster, sit the pot in a basin of cold water. # Crumble the cake of ''ragi tapai'' over the rice and mix in well. # Loosely pack the mixture into a large jar, cover with a cloth, and set aside in a warm place to ferment (about 30-35°C / 86-95°F). ==Fermentation== The tapai will ferment over the next two to four days. After about two days, it should start to show a little liquid at the bottom of the jar, and will start producing a distinctive smell of tapai. At this point, the tapai can be considered complete, although it will taste better after a couple of days kept in the refrigerator. ==Notes, tips and variations== {{Wikipedia|Tapai}} * Tapai can be made from plain white rice (''tape nasi''), or [[Cookbook:Cassava|cassava]] (''tape ketala'', ''tape telor'', ''peuyeum''), or even [[Cookbook:Sweet Potato|sweet potato]]. * ''Ragi tapai'' (or ''ragi tape'') can be a little difficult to track down outside of South-East Asia, but a little persistence should help find it. The same (or very similar) product is used to ferment Chinese rice wines, and runs under the names "wine yeast", "yeast cake" and "rice cake" in Asian grocery stores. They look like crumbly little white balls, about 2-3cm (1 inch) in diameter. Just ask the shopkeeper whether it can be used to make wine. They can also be purchased on-line from some stores; try this [http://www.google.com/search?q=%22ragi+tape%22+%22shopping+cart%22 Google search]. * The liquid that collects at the bottom is actually a rice wine, called ''brem''. It will be very low in alcohol after only a few days, but if kept and allowed to ferment, it will become more alcoholic. [[Category:Indonesian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Fermented food recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegan recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Gluten-free recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Rice recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Bread recipes|½ sheet|4 hours, total|3}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|American cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Italy|Italian cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Vegetarian cuisine|Vegetarian Cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Bread|Bread]]
Focaccia Genovese Dough
==Ingredients==
* 5¾ [[Cookbook:Cup|cups]] unbleached [[Cookbook:Bread|bread]] [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] * 2 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoons]] [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] or 4 teaspoons [[Cookbook:Kosher|kosher]] salt * 2 teaspoons [[Cookbook:Yeast|instant yeast]] * 2⅛ cups cold [[Cookbook:Water|water]] * ⅛ cup [[Cookbook:Olive oil|olive oil]] plus 2 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoons]] for the pan, divided
==Directions==
# In a 4-[[Cookbook:Quart|quart]] bowl (or the bowl of an [[Cookbook:Mixer|electric mixer]]), combine flour, salt, yeast and water. # With a large metal spoon, stir together until all the flour is absorbed. If you are mixing by hand, repeatedly dip one of your hands or the spoon in cold water and use it, much like a dough hook, to work the dough vigorously into a smooth mass while rotating the bowl in a circular motion with the other hand. # When the dough sets up, wash and dry your hands and let the dough rest for 5 minutes. Then add ¼ cup olive oil and dip your hand or spoon again in water and continue to work the dough for another 5 minutes until it is smooth and stretchy. The dough should be very sticky, but it should also have some texture and structure. Even if mixed with the wet hands method, it should still pass the windowpane test. (Snip off a small piece of dough and gently stretch it until it forms a paper-thin, translucent membrane.) # If the dough seems like a batter and does not have enough structure, work in some more flour. # Transfer the dough to an oiled bowl, turn it to coat the dough with the oil, cover it with plastic wrap and refrigerate overnight. The next day, the dough should have nearly doubled in size. If not, allow it to sit at room temperature for about 2 hours or until it doubles in size. # Line a 12-by-17-inch sheet pan (technically called a "half sheet pan" as a 24-by-17-inch or full sheet pan will only fit in a commercial oven) with either baking parchment or a silicon baking pad (Silpat). #Drizzle about 2 tablespoons of olive oil on the parchment or pad and spread it over the surface. Using a plastic bowl scraper dipped in water, gently transfer the dough from the bowl to the pan, taking care to de-gas the dough as little as possible. # Drizzle the remaining ¼ cup olive oil on the surface of the dough. # Using only your fingertips, press down on the dough, creating dimples and pockets all over the surface for the oil to fill. Do not press the dough outward toward the edges of the pan; instead simply press downward at only a slight angle toward the edges. When the dough fills the pan a little more than half full and springs back toward the center, stop pressing and let the dough relax at room temperature for about 15 minutes. # Repeat the dimpling process, beginning at the center and gradually working out toward the edges of the pan. This time the dough will nearly fill the pan. Again let the dough relax at room temperature for about 15 minutes. # Repeat the dimpling. This time the dough should fill the pan. Let the dough rise for approximately 2 to 3 hours at room temperature or until it fills the pan. # Your dough is now ready for topping and baking.
==Tips, Notes, and Variations==
* Makes enough dough for 1 (12-by-17-inch) half sheet pan. * This bread spends more time in the pizza oven than most crusts, 30 to 40 minutes, so it requires special toppings that can take the heat: ** [[Cookbook:Caramelized Sweet and Sour Onion Marmalade|Caramelized Sweet and Sour Onion Marmalade]] ** paper thin slices of [[Cookbook:Potato|potatoes]] and [[Cookbook:Onion|onions]], seasoned with [[Cookbook:Rosemary|rosemary]] ** [[Cookbook:Marinara Sauce|Marinara Sauce]] ** [[Cookbook:Pesto|Pesto Sauce]] ** [[Cookbook:Roasting|roasted]] [[Cookbook:Pepper|peppers]] and [[Cookbook:Olive|olives]] ** Genoa style: just sprinkle with salt
[[Category:Inexpensive recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:American recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Italian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Bread recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Curry|Curry]]
This is a '''beef curry''' which can be made out of ingredients which you might find in your fridge normally, so no need to buy extra ones.
=== Ingredients === * 1 lb (450g) [[Cookbook:Ground Beef|minced beef]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Onion|Onion]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Bell Pepper|Bell pepper]] or 1 cup (200g) frozen mixed bell pepper * [[Cookbook:Curry Powder|curry powder]] to taste * 1 [[Cookbook:Bouillon Cubes|Beef stock cube]] * 2 Tblspn [[Cookbook:Tomato Paste|tomato purée]] * 2 Tblspn "Branston" (brand) or other sweet pickle * 2 oz (55g) [[Cookbook:Rice|rice]] per person * 1 [[Cookbook:Lemon|lemon]]
===Optional=== * 1 Tbls [[Cookbook:Mango Chutney|mango chutney]] * 1 teaspoon [[Cookbook:Paprika|paprika]]
== Procedure == # Peel and chop the onion and pepper # Brown the mince in a pan and add the curry powder # Add the chopped onion and pepper to the pan and fry this for one minute # Add a crumbled stock cube, tomato purée, pickle,(mango chutney and paprika) to the pan and stir # Pour water into the pan till it covers the mixture # Bring to a boil and simmer for 1 hour stirring every 10 minutes # Boil the rice till fluffy # Add lemon to the rice # Put the rice on a plate with the curry on top
[[Category:Curry recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Beef recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Recipes_with_metric_units|{{PAGENAME}}]]
