revision.text:
{{recipesummary |Category = French recipes |Time = 15-30 minutes |Servings = 16 (or 8, twice!) |Rating = 1 |Image = [[Image:Socca.jpg|300px]] }} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of France|Cuisine of France]] | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Italy|Cuisine of Italy]]
'''Socca''' (French), '''Torta di ceci''' or '''Farinata''' (Italian).
''See also: [[Cookbook:Calentita|Calentita]]''
==Ingredients==
* 300g (2 cups) [[Cookbook:Chickpea Flour|chickpea flour]] * 500ml (2 cups) [[Cookbook:Water|water]] * 2 Tbs [[Cookbook:Olive Oil|olive oil]] * 1 tsp [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * [[Cookbook:Pepper|black pepper]] to taste; 2-3 decent grinds of a grinder should do
==Equipment==
Apart from having the usual kitchen equipment and a good oven, you will need something to cook the ''socca'' on. Traditionally, a 50cm (20 inch) copper plaque is used as it spreads the heat evenly to all parts of the ''socca'', but a good [[Cookbook:Frying Pan|cast iron pan]] will suffice if preheated in the oven first.
==Procedure==
# Heat oven – super hot, around 300°C / 570°F is traditional, but whatever your oven can manage that gets close to this. If using a cast-iron pan, get it into the oven at the start so that it is hot when the batter goes into it. # [[Cookbook:Whisk|Whisk]] the ingredients together well, ensuring there are no lumps. This should make a very thin batter, easy to pour. # Once the oven is up to temperature, pour some of the batter into the pan or onto the plaque, and put into the oven for 8-9 minutes at 300°C / 570°F, or 13-15 minutes at 250°C / 480°F. With a 50cm plaque or pan, cook half the batter at a time – the batter should cover the plaque or pan very thinly. # Remove from the oven and cut into triangular wedges. Serve hot. # Repeat for the rest of the batter.
[[Category:French recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Italian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Gluten-free recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Flatbread recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Dessert|Dessert]]
== Ingredients == * 6 oz (170g) [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] (self raising) * 6 oz (170g) [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]] or [[Cookbook:Margarine|margarine]] * 6 oz (170g) [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] * 3 [[Cookbook:Egg|eggs]] * [[Cookbook:Jam|jam]] and [[Cookbook:Cream|cream]]
== Procedure == #Preheat the oven to 200°C(400°F, [[Cookbook:Oven temperatures|Gas mark 6]]) #Put the butter into a bowl and mix with a wooden spoon until softened #Add the sugar and mix #Add the 3 eggs to this and the flour and mix until smooth #divide it between two 7 inch (18cm) greased circle pans #bake in the oven at [[Cookbook:Oven temperatures|gas mark 6]] (200°C, 400°F) for 20 - 30 minutes (10-15 in a fan-assisted oven) until firm to the touch #leave to cool #turn one upside down and spread jam and cream over it and place the other on top
[[Category:Dessert recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary |Category = Indian recipes |Rating=2 |Image=[[Image:Bonda2.jpg|300px]] }} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of India|Cuisine of India]]
'''Bonda''' is a typical [[Cookbook:Cuisine of India|South Indian]] snack. The process of making Bonda involves deep frying a filling of potato (or other vegetables) dipped in gram flour batter.
== Ingredients ==
===For filling===
* [[Cookbook:Potato|Potato]] - 2 medium sized * [[Cookbook:Onion|Onions]] - 1 medium sized * [[Cookbook:Chili Pepper|Green Chilis]] - 3-4 medium sized * [[Cookbook:Cilantro|Coriander Leaves]] - 2 TBS, finely chopped * [[Cookbook:Ginger|Ginger]] - Finely chopped, 1 Tsp * [[Cookbook:Garlic|Garlic]] - Finely chopped, 1 Tsp * [[Cookbook:Salt|Salt]] - To taste
===For Batter===
* [[Cookbook:Chickpea Flour|Gram Flour]] (besan) - 4 portions * [[Cookbook:Rice Flour|Rice Flour]] - 1 portion * [[Cookbook:Baking Soda|Baking Soda]] - ½ tsp * [[Cookbook:Salt|Salt]] - To taste
===Other===
* [[Cookbook:Oil|Oil]] for Frying
== Procedure ==
'''Filling:''' Boil potatoes, remove skin and mash coarsely. Heat 2 TBS of oil in a pan and heat. When the oil is hot throw in green chilis and fry for a few seconds. Add onions and fry until browned. Add ginger and garlic and fry for a minute. Add the chopped coriander leaves and the coarsely mashed potatoes and fold well. Allow it to cool and make small golf ball sized balls.
'''Batter:''' Mix the gram flour and the rice flour with baking soda and add salt to taste. Make a smooth batter using water or beer. The batter consistency must be slightly thicker than ketchup
'''Assembly:''' Once the batter and filling are ready heat some oil to fry in a deep pan. You will need at least 1½ inch layer of oil to deep fry. Take the golf sized balls of filling, dip it in the batter making sure the ball is completely coated and drop it into the oil. Fry until it becomes golden and remove.
Bonda is served with [[Cookbook:Ketchup|ketchup]] or [[Cookbook:Chutney|chutney]].
[[Category:Indian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Appetizer recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegan recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

page.title: Cookbook:Caramelized Sweet and Sour Onion Marmalade

revision.text:
{{recipesummary|Sauce recipes|2 cups|½ hour|3}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|American cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Italy|Italian cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Vegetarian cuisine|Vegetarian Cuisine]]
Caramelized Sweet and Sour Onion Marmalade
==Ingredients==
* 4 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoons]] [[Cookbook:Olive oil|olive]] or [[Cookbook:Vegetable oil|vegetable oil]] * 4 large yellow or white [[Cookbook:Onion|onions]], sliced into thin strips * ½ [[Cookbook:Cup|cups]] [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] * ¼ cup [[Cookbook:Vinegar|balsamic vinegar]] * ¼ [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoon]] [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * ⅛ teaspoon coarse ground [[Cookbook:Black Pepper|black pepper]]
==Directions==
# Heat oil in a large frying pan over medium heat. Add onions, and [[Cookbook:Sauté|sauté]], stirring, for about 15 minutes, or until they begin to brown. (Do not cook over high heat, as the outside of the onions will char too quickly before the insides have softened and sweetened.) When onions have softened and turned a light golden brown, add sugar. # Continue stirring until sugar melts and begins to bubble. # As the onions turn a richer brown, clear a space in the center of the pan. Pour balsamic vinegar directly onto the hot pan, then stir it into onions. # When vinegar has reduced, leaving a syrupy coating on the onions, turn off the heat. Stir in salt and pepper, and allow onions to cool.
==Uses==
* Used in [[Cookbook:Focaccia|Focaccia]] ([[Cookbook:Focaccia with Onion Marmalade, Blue Cheese, and Walnuts|Focaccia with Onion Marmalade, Blue Cheese, and Walnuts]])
[[Category:Inexpensive recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:American recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Irish recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Italian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Sauce recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetable recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

page.title: Cookbook:Focaccia with Onion Marmalade, Blue Cheese, and Walnuts

revision.text:
{{recipesummary|Vegetarian recipes|8|1 hour|3}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|American cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Italy|Italian cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Vegetarian cuisine|Vegetarian Cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Bread|Bread]]
Focaccia with Onion Marmalade, Blue Cheese and Walnuts
==Ingredients==
* [[Cookbook:Focaccia Genovese Dough|Focaccia Dough]] * 1½ [[Cookbook:Cup|cups]] [[Cookbook:Caramelized Sweet and Sour Onion Marmalade|Sweet and Sour Onion Marmalade]] * ¼ [[Cookbook:Pound|pounds]] [[Cookbook:Cheese|blue cheese]], crumbled or cut into ½-inch pieces * 1 cup [[Cookbook:Chop|coarsely chopped]] [[Cookbook:Walnut|walnuts]]
==Directions==
# Preheat oven to [[Cookbook:Oven_temperatures|500°F]]. # When the focaccia is fully risen and ready to bake, gently spread onion marmalade evenly over surface. Evenly distribute blue cheese over onion marmalade and scatter walnuts over the top. # Place the sheet pan on the middle shelf of the oven, lower temperature to 450 degrees and [[Cookbook:Bake|bake]] for 20 minutes. Rotate pan 180 degrees and bake for 20 to 25 minutes, until the dough is golden on the bottom and top. # When the baking is complete, set up a cooling rack inside a sheet pan and immediately remove the focaccia from the pan by using a metal [[Cookbook:Spatula|spatula]] or pastry blade to break all contact with the walls of the pan. Place the spatula or blade between the focaccia and the parchment or pad and lift the edge up. Then jiggle the focaccia out of the pan onto the cooling rack. Pour any excess oil from the pan over the top of the focaccia. Let the focaccia cool for at least 20 minutes before slicing and serving.
[[Category:Inexpensive recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:American recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Italian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetable recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Stew recipes|6|Marinade 2 hours
Cook 2 hours|3}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Caribbean cuisines|Caribbean cuisine]] Sancocho, popular in the Dominican Republic, called by many its national dish. ==Ingredients== ===Marinade and chicken:=== * 1 large [[Cookbook:Orange|orange, juiced]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoon]] fresh [[Cookbook:Lemon Juice|lemon juice]] * ¼ bunch [[Cookbook:Parsley|curly parsley]], large stems removed * ¼ bunch [[Cookbook:Cilantro|cilantro]], large stems removed * 2 tablespoons fresh [[Cookbook:Oregano|oregano leaves]] * 2 [[Cookbook:Garlic|cloves garlic]], minced * [[Cookbook:Salt|Salt]] and [[Cookbook:Black Pepper|freshly ground black pepper]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Pound|pound]] [[Cookbook:Chicken|boneless, skinless chicken breasts]], cut into bite-size pieces ===Soup:=== * 1 tablespoon [[Cookbook:oil|clear oil]], such as [[Cookbook:Canola Oil|canola]] * 2 [[Cookbook:Cup|cups]] [[Cookbook:Stock|vegetable stock]] * 4 cups [[Cookbook:Water|water]] * 1 medium [[Cookbook:Onion|white onion]], [[Cookbook:Chop|chopped]] * 1 medium [[Cookbook:Sweet Potato|sweet potato]], peeled and cut into ½-inch chunks * 1 medium [[Cookbook:Potato|boiling potato]], unpeeled and cut into bite-size chunks * 1 [[Cookbook:Plantain|green plantain]], peeled and sliced into ½-inch thick slices (see Note) * 1 [[Cookbook:Corn|ear corn]], quartered * 1 [[Cookbook:Jalapeño|jalapeño]] or [[Cookbook:Habanero|habanero]] [[Cookbook:Chile|chile]], seeded and minced * Salt and pepper, to taste * Hot cooked [[Cookbook:Rice|rice]], optional * Hot sauce, optional * Chopped cilantro, optional ==Directions== ===Marinade:=== # In bowl of a [[Cookbook:Food processor|food processor]] or [[Cookbook:Blender|blender]], combine orange juice, lemon juice, parsley, cilantro, oregano, garlic, salt, and pepper, and process until combined. # Pour mixture into a non-reactive bowl, add chicken and stir to combine. # Cover and refrigerate 1 to 2 hours. ==Soup:== # Heat oil in a large soup pot over medium heat. When hot, use a slotted spoon to lift the chicken out of the marinade and place in the pot, reserving marinade. Cook chicken until opaque, stirring occasionally. # Add reserved marinade, vegetable stock and water to the pot, and bring to a [[Cookbook:Boiling|boil]]. # Add onion, sweet potato, potato, plantain, corn, jalapeño, salt and pepper. # Bring back to a boil, reduce to low and cook partially covered for 1 to 1½ hours. ==Tips, Notes, and Variations== * To serve, ladle soup into bowls and top with a small scoop of rice, if desired. Pass hot sauce and cilantro at the table. * Because this soup has a long simmering time, choose an unripe green plantain rather than a ripe yellow or black-colored plantain, which has a softer texture. * Each cook makes his own recipe for sancocho, combining root vegetables with different kinds of meat, some with up to seven meats. * To make the soup even more authentic, add a small peeled cubed [[Cookbook:Cassava|yuca root]] to the broth, along with the other vegetables. [[Category:Inexpensive recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Stew recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Caribbean recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Meat recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Chicken recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetable recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

revision.comment: New page: {{recipesummary|Pasta recipes|4|1 hour|3}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|American cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Italy|Italian cuisine]] | ==Ingredients== * ...
revision.text:
{{recipesummary|Pasta recipes|4|1 hour|3}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|American cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Italy|Italian cuisine]] |
==Ingredients==
* 8 [[Cookbook:Ounce|ounces]] whole grain thin [[Cookbook:Pasta|spaghetti]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoon]] [[Cookbook:Olive oil|olive oil]] * 1 small [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]] * ½ [[Cookbook:Pound|pound]] mild or hot Italian [[Cookbook:Sausage|sausage]] * ½ [[Cookbook:Cup|cups]] [[Cookbook:Red Wine|red]] or dry [[Cookbook:White Wine|white wine]] * 2 (14-ounce) cans no-salt-added [[Cookbook:Dice|diced]] [[Cookbook:Tomato|tomatoes]] * 1 (6-ounce) can no-salt-added tomato paste * 1 teaspoon bottled minced [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]] * 1 teaspoon [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] * 1 teaspoon dried Italian seasoning * ¼ cup grated [[Cookbook:Parmesan cheese|Parmesan cheese]]
==Directions==
# Prepare [[Cookbook:Pasta|pasta]] according to package directions. # Meanwhile, heat oil in a 4½-[[Cookbook:Quart|quart]] saucepan or [[Cookbook:Dutch Oven|Dutch Oven]] over medium-high heat. # Peel and finely [[Cookbook:Chop|chop]] onion, adding to pan as you chop. # Remove casings from sausage, if necessary, and [[Cookbook:Crumble|crumble]] sausage into the pan. Stir and cook, breaking up the sausage, until the sausage is cooked through and the onion is tender, about 5 minutes. # Add wine to pan and stir to loosen any brown bits on the bottom of the pan. # Add canned tomatoes and their juice, tomato paste, garlic, sugar and Italian seasoning. # Stir to combine, then reduce heat to medium-low. # Stir in Parmesan cheese, and cook until pasta is ready.
==Tips, Notes, and Variations==
* May substitute ½ cup chopped onion for small onion. * Sauce can simmer on low, after cheese is added, up to 30 minutes, if necessary. * Serve over hot, cooked pasta.
[[Category:Inexpensive recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:American recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Italian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Sauce recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Camping recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Meat recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Ham recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Sausage recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Pasta recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Soups|Soups]]
This is one of my favorites that my mom used to make for me.
==Ingredients== *1 pound [[Cookbook:Beef|beef]] round steak, cut into ¾-inch cubes *1 tablespoon [[Cookbook:Margarine|margarine]] *½ cup chopped [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]] *2 (13¾-ounce) cans [[Cookbook:Broth|beef broth]] *4 cups [[Cookbook:Water|water]] *½ cup sliced [[Cookbook:Celery|celery]] *2 teaspoons dried [[Cookbook:Basil|basil leaves]] *1 (14½-ounce) can stewed [[Cookbook:Tomato|tomatoes]] *2 cups sliced [[Cookbook:Carrot|carrots]] *2 cups bow tie [[Cookbook:Pasta|noodles]] *2 cups torn fresh [[Cookbook:Spinach|spinach leaves]]
==Procedure== # In a 4-quart saucepan, over medium-high heat, brown beef in margarine. # Add onion; cook until tender. # Stir in beef broth, water, celery, and basil; bring to a boil. # Cover; reduce heat and simmer 1 hour. # Add tomatoes, carrots, noodles; bring to a boil. # Reduce heat and simmer, uncovered, 25 minutes. # Stir in spinach; cook 5 minutes more.
Makes 10 cups.
==Notes, tips and variations== * For a hearty stew, remove 1 cup broth from soup; stir in 3 tablespoons flour until smooth. Return to soup mixture; cook and stir until thickened.
[[Category:Soup recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary |Category = Beverage recipes |Time = 5 minutes |Rating = 1 |Servings = 1 |Image = [[Image:AyranGetränk.jpg|300px]] }} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Beverages|Beverages]] | [[Cookbook:Middle Eastern cuisines|Middle Eastern cuisines]]
'''Ayran''' is a popular Turkish drink made of a yoghurt and water. The ayran made from sheep yoghurt has a quite thick taste, fatty but also delicious. It is very similar to the Iranian drink, Doogh. Salt is usually added to ayran for flavour. It is served cool, and usually accompanies doner, kebab or pastry. Some forms of fresh ayran include some foam.
In Turkey McDonalds also includes ayran in their standard menu as a local menu addition. Ayran is also very popular elsewhere in the Middle East. In rural areas of Turkey, ayran is offered as a "standard" drink to guests. "We have come to drink your ayran" say the guests.
Another recipe common to Turkey includes finely chopped mint leaves mixed into the Ayran. This variation is particularly popular during summertime in Turkey and is considered very refreshing. Ayran has become so popular in Turkey that it is often regarded as a separate market in contrast to the juice and soda industries, and is a challenge for "modern" soft-drink companies such as Coca-Cola.
==Ingredients== * 1½ cup plain [[Cookbook:Yogurt|yoghurt]] * 1½ cup [[Cookbook:Water|water]] * [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]], to taste * crushed [[Cookbook:Mint|dried mint]] (optional)
==Preparation== Pour yoghurt into a bowl and beat until smooth, add water and continue beating until thoroughly blended, or combine in an electric blender and blend until smooth. Season to taste with salt and dried mint. Chill thoroughly and serve in tall glasses, with ice.
==See also== {{Wikipedia|Ayran}} * [[Cookbook:Lassi|Lassi]]
[[Category:Beverage recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Milk recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Middle Eastern recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes]]

revision.comment: New page: {{recipesummary|Beverage recipes|~1 gallon after reconstitution|1 hour|2}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|American cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Vegetarian cuisine|Vegetaria...
revision.text:
{{recipesummary|Beverage recipes|~1 gallon after reconstitution|1 hour|2}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|American cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Vegetarian cuisine|Vegetarian Cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Beverages|Beverages]]
==Ingredients==
* 2 [[Cookbook:Pound|pounds]] tender [[Cookbook:Rhubarb|rhubarb]] ([[Cookbook:Chop|chopped]]) * 5 [[Cookbook:Cup|cups]] [[Cookbook:Water|water]] * ¼ cup [[Cookbook:Lemon Juice|lemon juice]]
==Directions==
# Combine and cook until mushy. # Strain well, reserving only the juice. # Add lemon juice.
==Tips, Notes, and Variations==
* '''Remember to cook only in non-aluminum pots only due to the acidic nature of rhubarb.'''
==Uses==
* For each cup of concentrate, add ⅓ cup [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] and ½ cup [[Cookbook:Grapefruit|grapefruit juice]], and chill well. * Just before serving, add 1 [[Cookbook:Quart|quart]] chilled ginger ale and stir well.
[[Category:Inexpensive recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:American recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Camping recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Beverage recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetable recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Rhubarb recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Beverage recipes|20|2 hours|1}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|American cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Vegetarian cuisine|Vegetarian Cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Beverages|Beverages]] | [[Cookbook:Alcoholic Drink|Alcoholic Drink]]
Fruity White Sangria
==Ingredients==
* 2 [[Cookbook:Quart|quarts]] pine-orange-guava juice * 2 [[Cookbook:Cup|cups]] fruity [[Cookbook:White Wine|white wine]] * ¼ cup orange-flavored liqueur * ¼ cup [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Orange|Orange]], thinly sliced * 1 [[Cookbook:Lime|Lime]], thinly sliced * 2 cups sliced [[Cookbook:Strawberry|strawberries]]
==Directions==
# Combine all ingredients in 2 very large pitchers; cover and refrigerate for 2 hours to blend flavors. # Serve over ice cubes.
==Tips, Notes, and Variations==
* Makes 20 servings
[[Category:American recipes|Sangria, Fruity White]] [[Category:Camping recipes|Sangria, Fruity White]] [[Category:Beverage recipes|Sangria, Fruity White]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|Sangria, Fruity White]]

{{recipesummary|Beverage recipes|6|15 minutes|1}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|American cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Vegetarian cuisine|Vegetarian Cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Beverages|Beverages]] | [[Cookbook:Alcoholic Drink|Alcoholic Drink]]
Hot Peach Drink
==Ingredients==
* 1 bottle (40 [[Cookbook:Ounce|ounces]]) pure [[Cookbook:Peach|peach]] drink * ¼ [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] packed [[Cookbook:Brown Sugar|brown sugar]] * 2 [[Cookbook:Cinnamon|cinnamon sticks]] * ½ cup peach schnapps (optional) * Cinnamon sticks for [[Cookbook:Garnish|garnish]] (optional)
==Directions==
# Combine juice, brown sugar, cinnamon sticks, and margarine in a [[Cookbook:Dutch Oven|Dutch Oven]]. # Heat to [[Cookbook:Boiling|boil]]. # Remove from heat. # Discard cinnamon sticks. # Add schnapps, if desired. # Garnish with additional cinnamon sticks, if desired.
[[Category:American recipes|Peach Drink, Hot]] [[Category:Camping recipes|Peach Drink, Hot]] [[Category:Beverage recipes|Peach Drink, Hot]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|Peach Drink, Hot]]

{{recipesummary |Category = Chickpea recipes |Time = soak: 12 hours
prep: 45 minutes |Rating = 2 |Image = [[Image:Chana masala.jpg|300px]] }} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of India|India]] | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Pakistan|Pakistan]] | [[Cookbook:Vegan cuisine|Vegan]] '''Cholley''', also '''chole''', '''cholay''', '''white cholay''', '''chana masala''', is a popular and versatile [[Cookbook:Cuisine of India|Indian]] and [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Pakistan|Pakistani]] chickpea dish, that is sometimes referred to as chana or channa. It is commonly cooked in Northern India (especially Punjab) and Pakistan for breakfast, but is not limited to the first meal of the day, being regularly found at dinner parties, picnics, wedding receptions and other special events. Cholley features chickpeas, onions, tomatoes and spices, with variations including additions of [[Cookbook:Potato|potato]] (alu). This dish works well with a range of accompaniments including [[Cookbook:Samosa|samosas]], [[Cookbook:Puri|puri]], [[Cookbook:Roti|roti]], [[Cookbook:Naan|naan]], [[Cookbook:Rice|rice]] and [[Cookbook:Bhatoora|bhatura]]. ''See also: [[Cookbook:Masaledaar chole|Masaledaar chole]]'' ==Ingredients== * 1 tablespoon of [[Cookbook:oil|oil]] * 1 clove of [[Cookbook:garlic|garlic]] * 1 teaspoon of [[Cookbook:Coriander|coriander seeds]] * 1 sliced [[Cookbook:onion|onion]] * 2 chopped [[Cookbook:Tomato|tomatoes]] (medium size) * 2 tsp [[Cookbook:Turmeric|turmeric]] * 1 tablespoon of [[Cookbook:Garam Masala|garam masala]] (spice mix) * fresh [[Cookbook:Cilantro|coriander leaves]] (as a garnish) * 500ml of [[Cookbook:water|water]] for cooking * 500ml of water for soaking the chickpeas overnight * 250g [[Cookbook:chickpea|chickpea]]s (white chana, i.e. European chickpeas) * [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] (to taste). * optional: 1 tsp each [[Cookbook:Cumin|cumin seeds]], [[Cookbook:Nigella|nigella]] ==Procedure== #To prepare the cholley dish, commence by washing then soaking the chickpeas overnight in water, allowing them to soften somewhat. Once 12 hours have elapsed, drain the water and place the chickpeas in a [[Cookbook:Pressure Cooking|pressure cooker]] or large cooking pot. Add fresh water and salt, then cook until the chickpeas are tender (10 minutes at 15psi in a pressure cooker). #Subsequently, heat the oil in a thick-based pan. Add the coriander seeds, and optionally the cumin and nigella seeds, cooking them briefly until they crackle. Quickly add the onions, reduce the heat to medium, and [[Cookbook:sautéing|sauté]] until the onions are transparent. Add garam masala, tomato and salt and cook for one minute before adding the boiled chickpeas. #Reduce the heat, and allow the cholley to [[Cookbook:simmering|simmer]] for around 15 minutes. Check that the gravy has thickened before removing from the heat. #Once done, place the cholley in a serving bowl, add your coriander garnish and serve with [[Cookbook:Samosa|samosas]], [[Cookbook:rice|rice]] or [[Cookbook:bread|bread]]. == External links == * [http://www.cooking-with-gusto.com/cover/video-cholley/ Cholley cooking demonstration] [[Category:Indian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Pakistani recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegan recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Chickpea recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Gluten-free recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Low-GI recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary |Category = Middle Eastern recipes |Time = 60 minutes |Rating = 2 |Servings = 4-6 }} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Middle Eastern cuisines|Middle Eastern cuisines]]
'''Tahdiq''', or '''tahdig''' is a popular Persian way of preparing rice.
==Ingredients==
*2 medium size [[Cookbook:Potato|potatoes]] *2 cups [[Cookbook:Basmati rice|basmati rice]] *⅓ cup [[Cookbook:Vegetable oil|vegetable oil]] *[[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] (as desired) *[[Cookbook:Water|water]]
==Procedure==
# Peel and slice the raw potatoes into ½ inch thick slices. # Rinse and drain rice. Bring 4-5 cups of water to a boil in a 3 qt pot, add salt if desired. Add rice & continue to boil the water, stirring occasionally, for about 10 minutes. Check to be sure that the rice doesn't cook completely at this point. # When rice is roughly half cooked, drain into a [[Cookbook:Colander|colander]]. # Pour ¼ cup of cooking oil into the pot and lay the potato slices in the bottom close together in a single layer. Add a small amount of salt (if desired). Layer the half cooked, drained rice loosely atop the potatoes. # Place pot on stove over medium high heat for 4-5 minutes or until rice begins to steam. # Lower heat and add 5 Tbs of water and 2-3 Tbs of oil on top of rice. Cover & let simmer for about ½ hour or until cooked and tender. The higher the heat, the crunchier the Tahdig. # Scoop out the rice and use a soft spatula to remove Tahdig at bottom, or try to make the contents of the pot come out as an entire cake of rice on the serving dish.
Tahdig can also be made by substituting the potatoes with bread (for ex. [[Cookbook:Pita|pitta]] or Lavash) or with the rice alone. Other common additions include slices of onion, beet or other rootstock.
[[Category:Middle Eastern recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Rice recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

revision.comment: New page: {{recipesummary|Rice recipes|8|1½ hours|3}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|American cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Italy|Italian cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Vegetarian...
revision.text:
{{recipesummary|Rice recipes|8|1½ hours|3}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|American cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Italy|Italian cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Vegetarian cuisine|Vegetarian Cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Rice|Rice]] | [[Cookbook:Dessert|Dessert]]
Italian Rice Pudding
==Ingredients==
* 2 [[Cookbook:Cup|cups]] [[Cookbook:Water|water]] * 1 cup risotto [[Cookbook:Rice|rice]] (plump, medium grain rice that contains a lot of starch, the types Arborio or Carnaroli are traditionally best. Other rices that work well are Roma, Nano, Maratelli, and Vialone.) * ¼ [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoon]] [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoon]] [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]] * 3 cups [[Cookbook:Half and Half|half and half]] * 1 cup [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Cinnamon|cinnamon stick]] * 1 piece of [[Cookbook:Lemon rind|lemon peel]] * [[Cookbook:Cinnamon|ground cinnamon]] to [[Cookbook:Garnish|garnish]]
==Directions==
# Bring water to a [[Cookbook:Boiling|boil]], add rice, salt, and butter # Cover, lower heat to [[Cookbook:simmer|simmer]] and cook for 20 minutes. # Place rice in upper part of [[Cookbook:Double Boiler|double boiler]] with half and half, sugar, cinnamon stick, and lemon peel. # Bring to boil over direct heat. # Place over simmering water in double boiler and cook for 45 minutes. # Remove cinnamon stick and lemon peel. # Pour rice mixture into a 2-[[Cookbook:Quart|quart]] casserole and allow to cool. # Sprinkle with cinnamon powder.
==Tips, Notes, and Variations==
* Mixture will thicken as it cools. * Best at room temperature or slightly warm.
[[Category:Inexpensive recipes|Rice Pudding, Italian]] [[Category:American recipes|Rice Pudding, Italian]] [[Category:Italian recipes|Rice Pudding, Italian]] [[Category:Midwestern recipes|Rice Pudding, Italian]] [[Category:Dessert recipes|Rice Pudding, Italian]] [[Category:Pudding and Custard recipes|Rice Pudding, Italian]] [[Category:Camping recipes|Rice Pudding, Italian]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|Rice Pudding, Italian]] [[Category:Rice recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Rice recipes|6|1 hour|2}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Italy|Italian cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Rice|Rice]]
Italian Rice with Wild Mushrooms
==Ingredients==
* 5 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoons]] extra virgin [[Cookbook:Olive oil|olive oil]] * 3 [[Cookbook:Chop|chopped]] [[Cookbook:Shallot|shallots]] * 2 [[Cookbook:cup|cups]] risotto [[Cookbook:Rice|rice]] (Plump, medium grain rice that contains a lot of starch, the types Arborio or Carnaroli are traditionally best. Other rices that work well are Roma, Nano Maratelli, and Vialone.) * 1 cup dry [[Cookbook:White Wine|white wine]] * 3 [[Cookbook:Cup|cups]] [[Cookbook:Chicken|chicken]] [[Cookbook:Stock|stock]] * ¼ cup [[Cookbook:Parmesan cheese|Parmesan cheese]] * 4 [[Cookbook:Ounce|ounces]] (commercial) [[Cookbook:Mushroom|wild mushrooms]], sliced and [[Cookbook:Sauté|sautéed]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoon]] [[Cookbook:Truffle|truffle oil]] * [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] and [[Cookbook:Pepper|pepper]] to taste
==Directions==
''Make sure your stock is [[Cookbook:simmer|simmering]] before you begin. It's important that the temperature is as high as possible, without letting the stock boil. The surface of the stock should just be moving a little.'' # Sauté the shallots in olive oil until soft. # Add the rice, stirring for 3 to 5 minutes, until coated with oil. # Pour in wine and about ½ cup of the [[Cookbook:Boiling|boiling]] [[Cookbook:Broth|broth]] and continue stirring. # Keep adding liquid as necessary and stir for an additional 15 minutes, keeping the rice creamy. # Remove from heat and add Parmesan cheese, mushrooms, and truffle oil. # Serve immediately.
[[Category:Inexpensive recipes|Rice with Wild Mushrooms, Italian]] [[Category:Italian recipes|Rice with Wild Mushrooms, Italian]] [[Category:Camping recipes|Rice with Wild Mushrooms, Italian]] [[Category:Chicken recipes|Rice with Wild Mushrooms, Italian]] [[Category:Cheese recipes|Rice with Wild Mushrooms, Italian]] [[Category:Mushroom recipes|Rice with Wild Mushrooms, Italian]] [[Category:Rice recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

revision.comment: New page: {{recipesummary|Rice recipes|4|1 hour|2}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Italy|Italian cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Rice|Rice]] Tuscan Mushroom Risotto ==Ingredients== * ¼ [[Cookbook:Cup...
revision.text:
{{recipesummary|Rice recipes|4|1 hour|2}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Italy|Italian cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Rice|Rice]]
Tuscan Mushroom Risotto
==Ingredients==
* ¼ [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] unsalted [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]] * 2 [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic cloves]], [[Cookbook:Chop|chopped]] * 2 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoons]] [[Cookbook:Shallot|shallots]], chopped * ~½ cup dry porcini [[Cookbook:Mushroom|mushrooms]] * 1 cup white mushrooms, [[Cookbook:Dice|diced]] * 1½ cups risotto [[Cookbook:Rice|rice]] (plump, medium grain rice that contains a lot of starch, the types Arborio or Carnaroli are traditionally best. Other rices that work well are Roma, Nano, Maratelli, and Vialone.) * ½ cup [[Cookbook:White Wine|white wine]] * 5 cups [[Cookbook:Broth|chicken broth]] or vegetable broth * ¼ cup [[Cookbook:Cream|heavy cream]] * 1 cup choice of [[Cookbook:Parmesan cheese|Parmesan]], Romano cheese, or Asiago cheese * [[Cookbook:Salt|Salt]] and freshly ground [[Cookbook:Pepper|pepper]] to taste * 1 tablespoon [[Cookbook:Parsley|parsley]], chopped
==Directions==
# Keep broth heated in a medium-size saucepan # On medium heat in a large pan combine butter, garlic or garlic oil, shallots, mushrooms, and rice. # Heat for about 2 minutes, stirring well. # Add white wine and let [[Cookbook:simmer|simmer]] on low for 2 minutes. # With lid off, add chicken or vegetable broth, add cream, and let simmer on low until liquid is absorbed, approximately 25 minutes, stirring regularly. # Add cheese of choice and salt and pepper to taste. # [[Cookbook:Garnish|Garnish]] with parsley and grated choice.
==Tips, Notes, and Variations==
* May substitute vegetable broth for chicken broth.
[[Category:Italian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Chicken recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Cheese recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Mushroom recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Rice recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Appetizer recipes|3|35-45 minutes|2|}}
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Appetizers|Appetizers]]
==Ingredients== *[[Cookbook:Egg|eggs]], depending on appetite and number of people *[[Cookbook:Mayonnaise|Mayonnaise]], depending on desired texture and taste *[[Cookbook:Mustard|Mustard]] to taste *[[Cookbook:Paprika|Paprika]] to taste
==Equipment== *A small 2-quart pot [[Cookbook:Saucepan|saucepan]] *A small spoon or [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoon]] *[[Cookbook:Fork|Fork]] *[[Cookbook:Paring Knife|Paring Knife]] *Plate or small bowl *Gas or electric stove, at medium-high to high heat
== Procedure == Follow the procedure for [[Cookbook:Hard Boiled Eggs|Hard Boiled Eggs]]. Allow the eggs to cool, then cut them in halves, so that half the yolk is in each half. Carefully remove the yolk and mash them together with a fork, until the yolk is like a coarse powder. Add a spoonful of [[Cookbook:mayonnaise|mayonnaise]] (about one spoonful per three medium eggs) to the yolks and mix it with the fork until evenly mixed. Use more [[Cookbook:mayonnaise|mayonnaise]] for a richer, smoother texture. Add about half a spoon of [[Cookbook:mustard|mustard]] or more or less to taste. Scoop the mixture into the empty egg whites until each is evenly filled. Sprinkle a little dried [[Cookbook:Paprika|paprika]] on the yolk of each re-filled egg. Keep covered and refrigerated until ready to consume. Enjoy!

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Bread|Bread]]
==Ingredients== *soft [[Cookbook:Baguette|baguette]], or [[Cookbook:Cuisine of France|French]] [[Cookbook:Bread|bread loaf]] *1 stick (¼ lb or a bit over 100g) of [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]] *3 cloves [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]], peeled *If you're a garlic lover, up to 5 cloves of garlic can be used, and/or additional [[Cookbook:Garlic Powder|garlic powder]]
==Procedure== # Place oven rack to middle setting, preheat to 350°F (175°C). # Using a [[Cookbook:Bread Knife|bread knife]], cut baguette in half, lengthwise, then cut diagonal slices towards the bottom but not all the way through. # With a garlic crusher or [[Cookbook:Chef's Knife|chef's knife]], [[Cookbook:Mincing|mince]] the peeled garlic cloves. # In a medium bowl, soften butter in a microwave. Around 10-15 seconds. # With a fork, mash minced garlic into softened butter and mix until even. # With a [[Cookbook:Butter Knife|butter knife]], spread butter mix onto both halves of bread and in the diagonal cuts # Wrap each half with [[Cookbook:Aluminum Foil|foil]], and place in oven on middle rack. Bake for 15-20 minutes. # Remove bread from oven, remove foil, serve fairly quickly before it cools off.
[[Category:Garlic recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Recipes_with_metric_units|{{PAGENAME}}]]

revision.comment: [[Cookbook:Coconut chutney]] moved to [[Cookbook:Coconut Chutney (North Indian)]]: Should not be merged, but rather exist as separate variant of [[Cookbook:Coconut Chutney]]
revision.text:
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of India|Indian Cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Vegan cuisine|Vegan Cuisine]]
'''Coconut chutney''' is served as an accompaniment to many South [[Cookbook:Cuisine of India|Indian]] dishes, such as [[Cookbook:Dosa|dosa]] and [[Cookbook:Idli|idli]]. This recipe is a North Indian variant.
==Ingredients== * 2 cups fresh shredded [[Cookbook:Coconut|coconut]] * 1-2 split [[Cookbook:Chilli Pepper|green chillies]] * 5 cloves [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]] * ½ cup chopped [[Cookbook:Cilantro|cilantro]] * ½ teaspoon [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * ½ cup water
==Procedure== # Grind all ingredients well in a blender.
Do not keep for more than 2 days.
==See also== *[[Cookbook:Coconut Chutney|Coconut Chutney]]
[[Category:Vegan recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Indian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Coconut recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Chutney recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[category:Gluten-free recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

revision.comment: [[Cookbook:Moussaka]] moved to [[Cookbook:Moussaka (Bulgarian)]]: This is a Bulgarian variant; making generic name a disambig page
revision.text:
{{recipe}}
'''Moussaka''' is a [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Bulgaria|Bulgarian]] minced meat dish, resembling a casserole. For the Greek version of this dish, see [[Cookbook:Greek_Moussaka|Greek Moussaka]].
==Ingredients== *1/2 kg of minced meat (usually [[Cookbook:Pork|pork]] in Bulgaria, but don't hesitate to experiment!) *1 kg of [[Cookbook:Potato|potatoes]], peeled and finely chopped *two [[Cookbook:Tomato|tomatoes]], finely chopped *[[Cookbook:Parsley|Parsley]], 1/3 cupful, finely chopped *one [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]], finely chopped *3 [[Cookbook:Egg|eggs]], beaten *1 cup [[Cookbook:Yogurt|yogurt]] *2 spoonfuls [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] *[[Cookbook:Salt|Salt]] and [[Cookbook:Pepper|pepper]], to taste *[[Cookbook:Oil|Oil]] for cooking
==Procedure== #Fry the onion and the minced meat in a little oil. The more fatty the meat is, the less oil you need. #When it is no longer red, mix it with the potatoes, tomatoes, and parsley. Add salt and pepper to taste. #Bake for about 1 hour, or until the potatoes are cooked. #Stir the eggs, the yogurt and the flour together and pour it over the dish. Bake for 10 more minutes. It's delicious with cold yogurt on the side. Enjoy!
[[Category:Bulgarian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Pork recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Casserole recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Potato recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}}
'''Crystallised Orange peel'''
== Ingredients == # 3 organic or unwaxed [[Cookbook:oranges|oranges]] (Sevilles are good) # 90 g [[Cookbook:caster sugar|caster sugar]] (twice) # 220 ml [[Cookbook:water|water]] (twice)
== Instructions == You will need to start 3 or 4 days in advance.
#Peel just the skin of the washed, dried orange with a potato peeler (skin, no white pith). #[[Cookbook:Boil|Boil]] this in a syrup made from the sugar and water for 5 minutes. Dry on a wire rack for 4 hours. Boil again in a fresh syrup. Dry again on the wire rack until brittle (about 48 hours). #To serve, grind in a clean [[Cookbook:coffee grinder|coffee grinder]] and store in a sealed container.
==Notes, tips, and variations== *Using a fan oven set on the lowest setting (100 °C) with the door slightly ajar to allow free passage of air will dry the peel in under 8 hours.

{{recipe}}
This is a basic recipe detailing how to prepare basic '''Roast Chicken'''. The dish is popular worldwide.
==Ingredients== * 1 [[Cookbook:Chicken|chicken]], plucked with giblets removed * 1 [[Cookbook:Lemon|lemon]], halved * [[Cookbook:Olive_Oil|Olive Oil]] * [[Cookbook:Salt|Salt]] and freshly ground [[Cookbook:Pepper|pepper]]
== Procedure == #Preheat your oven to 200°C (390°F) #Rub salt in the cavity of the chicken, then insert the two halves of lemon. #Rub the chicken skin all over with olive oil, then season generously with salt and pepper. Place in a lightly oiled roasting tin. #Cook your chicken for 20 minutes per 450g (1lb) plus an additional 30 minutes at the end. #Remove the chicken from the oven, cover loosely with foil and allow to rest for 20 minutes before carving.
==Notes== #The chicken will be cooked when the juices run clear after it is removed from the oven. To check this, insert a knife tip into through the thickest part of the thigh and, using the flat of the knife, push against the flesh and look at the juice running out of the thigh.
==Techniques to keep the meat moist== A common problem with roasting chicken is dry breast meat. There are numerous techniques to try and avoid this :- #Always make sure that your chicken is well rested before carving. Resting allows the juices to go back into the flesh thereby moistening the meat. #Baste the chicken in the fat that runs from it during cooking. #Put the chicken in the oven breast side down for the first half an hour of cooking, so that the juice in the chicken runs into the breast. However, this will make it diffiult to crisp the breast skin. #Cover the breast with rashers of streaky [[Cookbook:Bacon|bacon]] or [[Cookbook:Pancetta|pancetta]]. The fat in the bacon will cook out into the breast meat underneath. #You can part the skin from the breast meat prior to cooking. Carefully separate the two with your fingers taking care not to tear the skin. Into the gap between the skin you can insert softened [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]] to keep the meat moist. This butter can be flavoured to impart flavour to the meat using chopped bacon, herbs and other seasonings.
[[Category:Chicken recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

revision.comment: [[Transwiki:Zucchini bread]] moved to [[Cookbook:Zucchini bread]]: cleanup after transwiki
revision.text:
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Bread|Bread]]
'''Zucchini bread''' is a sweet fluffy bread that has zucchini in it. It is delicious. There are many different ways of making it. Here is one. This recipe was derived from the lyrics of a song by a band called Chuga Chuga, from Michigan/Washington, DC, USA. They broke up in 2006.
== Ingredients ==
*3 [[Cookbook:Egg|eggs]] worth of [[Cookbook:Egg Replacer|egg replacer]] (It works better than real eggs!) *¼ tsp [[Cookbook:Baking Powder|baking powder]] *1 tsp [[Cookbook:Baking Soda|baking soda]] *1 tsp [[Cookbook:Vanilla|vanilla essence]] *1 tsp [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] *2 tsp [[Cookbook:Cinnamon|cinnamon]] *1 cup of [[Cookbook:Oil|oil]] *2 cups of [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] *2 cups of [[Cookbook:Grater|shredded]] [[Cookbook:Zucchini|zucchini]] *3 cups of [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]]
== Procedure ==
# Mix it all together, though just enough so that it is thoroughly wet. Don't overwork the glutens in the flour. # Bake it for 1 hour at 325°F (160°C).
[[Category:Bread recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

revision.comment: [[Transwiki:Colonial Goose]] moved to [[Cookbook:Colonial Goose]]: ready for prime time
revision.text:
{{recipe}}
'''Colonial Goose''' is the name for a surprisingly effective preparation of roast leg of [[Cookbook:lamb|lamb]].
Early colonial pioneers in [[Cookbook:Cuisine of New Zealand|New Zealand]] had [[Cookbook:sheep|sheep]] aplenty, but [[Cookbook:goose|goose]] was relatively scarce. To prepare dishes similar to those they had back home in [[Cookbook:English cuisine|England]] the pioneers were very inventive. Colonial Goose is now a recognised classic, with some restaurants featuring it as a main attraction at midwinter festivities (June 21 in NZ). It involves the careful boning out a leg of lamb, stuffing it with honey and dried apricots, and then marinating it in a red wine based marinade which even gives it the appearance of goose when cooked.
==Ingredients== You need a large leg of [[Cookbook:lamb|lamb]]. If you don’t know how to bone it out, ask your butcher to do it, stressing that you need to be able to stuff it.
;For the stuffing * 30g [[Cookbook:butter|butter]] * 1 large tablespoon clear [[Cookbook:honey|honey]] * 125g dried [[Cookbook:apricot|apricot]]s, finely [[Cookbook:diced|diced]] * 1 medium sized [[Cookbook:onion|onion]], finely diced * 1 cup fresh [[Cookbook:bread crumbs|bread crumbs]] * quarter teaspoon of [[Cookbook:salt|salt]] * quarter teaspoon of dried [[Cookbook:thyme|thyme]] * freshly ground [[Cookbook:black pepper|black pepper]] * 1 beaten [[Cookbook:egg|egg]]
;For the marinade * 250g sliced [[Cookbook:carrot|carrot]]s * two large [[Cookbook:onion|onion]]s, sliced * 1 [[Cookbook:bay leaf|bay leaf]] * 3 or 4 crushed [[Cookbook:parsley|parsley]] stalks * not quite full cup of [[Cookbook:red wine|red wine]] such as [[Cookbook:claret|claret]]
==Procedure== #To prepare the stuffing, melt the butter and honey over low heat, add the other ingredients and combine well. #Force the stuffing into the cavity in the meat, and sew it up with fine string. #Place the leg into a plastic bag (which sits in a large bowl), and add the marinade mixture. #The meat is best prepared just after breakfast, so it can then be regularly turned over in the marinade throughout the day. #Cook in oven at 180 °C for two hours but check on progress at 90 minutes. If the meat looks like over browning, it can be covered by foil. #Remove the string before carving. #Strain the marinade and use three or four tablespoons of the liquor to make [[Cookbook:gravy|gravy]].
[[Category:New Zealand recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Lamb recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of New Zealand|Cuisine of New Zealand]]
'''Lolly cake''' is a [[Cookbook:Cuisine of New Zealand|New Zealand]] cake which features [[Cookbook:candy|lollies]] in the ingredients and thus can be thought of as "candy cake".
The traditional candy used is Fruit Puffs which are like firm, slightly chewy [[Cookbook:marshmallow|marshmallow]]s and are obviously fruity. Malt biscuits and coconut are also used and other ingredients can be added or substituted.
==Ingredients== * 120 g (1.5 sticks) of [[Cookbook:butter|butter]] * 250 g of [[Cookbook:malt biscuits|malt biscuits]] (one packet) * 180 g of [[Cookbook:Fruit Puffs|Fruit Puffs]] (one packet) * 200 g (1/2 can or 7 ounces) [[Cookbook:condensed milk|condensed milk]] * shredded [[Cookbook:coconut|coconut]] * a pinch of [[Cookbook:cinnamon|cinnamon]] (optional)
==Directions== # Crush the biscuits. They don't need to be a fine dust, some pieces can be left partially smushed to give the cake a nicer texture. # Mix in cinnamon, if you want it. # Warm the butter and condensed milk in the [[Cookbook:microwave oven|microwave]] for 30 seconds until the butter is very soft. It's ok if the butter melts a bit. # Cut the fruit puffs in half if you want or leave them whole. # Mix the fruit puffs with the crushed biscuits, add the butter and condensed milk. Mix well. # Scoop up the mixture and roll it into a log shape, or take small amounts and roll into little balls. # Roll in the shredded coconut until the log or each ball is completely covered. # Place on a tray in the refrigerator and wait for it to harden. This takes a few hours. Put plastic wrap over the tray to keep the lolly cake moist.
<!-- Image with unknown copyright status removed: [[Image:IMG_0164.jpg|''Non-traditional Lolly cake with Irish moss and chocolate licorice'']] -->
<!-- Image with unknown copyright status removed: [[Image:IMG_0322.jpg|''The finished product will be rounded and brown in color.Pieces of the Fruit Puffs are visible'']] --> '''References/External Links''' *[http://www.suzy.co.nz/suzysworld/Factpage.asp?FactSheet=183 Suzy's World:Steel] Shows photo of cake. *[http://isaac.freeman.org.nz/archives/lolly_cake/a_natural_histo.html Isaac Freeman:A Natural History of Lolly Cake] Website about Lolly cake, with good pictures.. *[http://www.recipezaar.com/recipe/getrecipe.zsp?id=10385 New Zealand Lolly Log Cake] Shows substitute ingredients for USA
[[Category:New Zealand recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Cake recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Rice recipes|6|1 hour|2}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Italy|Italian cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Rice|Rice]]
Traditional Italian Risotto
==Ingredients==
* 5 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoons]] extra virgin [[Cookbook:Olive oil|olive oil]] * 1 medium [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]], [[Cookbook:Chop|chopped]] * 2½ [[Cookbook:cup|cups]] risotto [[Cookbook:Rice|rice]] (plump, medium grain rice that contains a lot of starch, the types Arborio or Carnaroli are traditionally best. Other rices that work well are Roma, Vialone, Nano and Maratelli.) * ¾ cup [[Cookbook:White Wine|white wine]] * 6 [[Cookbook:Cup|cups]] [[Cookbook:Broth|chicken broth]] * ½ [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoon]] [[Cookbook:Saffron|saffron powder]] * ½ cup [[Cookbook:Parmesan cheese|Parmesan cheese]] * [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] to taste
==Directions==
''Make sure your stock is [[Cookbook:Simmer|simmering]] before you begin. It's important that the temperature is as high as possible, without letting the stock boil. The surface of the stock should just be moving a little. '' # [[Cookbook:Sauté|Sauté]] the onion until soft. # Add the rice and mix well until it is coated the oil. # Add the wine and stir constantly over medium heat until it evaporates. # Add enough broth to cover the rice and continue to stir until the liquid is absorbed. # Keep adding broth, a little at a time, while constantly stirring until the rice is done. # In a small bowl, dissolve the saffron in a little hot broth and add it to the rice. # Stir in the Parmesan cheese and season with salt to taste. # Serve immediately.
[[Category:Italian recipes|Risotto, Traditional Italian]] [[Category:Camping recipes|Risotto, Traditional Italian]] [[Category:Chicken recipes|Risotto, Traditional Italian]] [[Category:Cheese recipes|Risotto, Traditional Italian]] [[Category:Mushroom recipes|Risotto, Traditional Italian]] [[Category:Rice recipes|Risotto, Traditional Italian]]

{{recipesummary|Dessert recipes|8|1 hour|3}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|American cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Vegetarian cuisine|Vegetarian Cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Dessert|Dessert]]
Apple Pudding
==Ingredients==
* ¾ [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Egg|egg]] * 2 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoons]] [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] * 1¼ [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoons]] [[Cookbook:Baking Powder|baking powder]] * [[Cookbook:Pinch|pinch]] of [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * 1 teaspoon [[Cookbook:Vanilla|vanilla]] * 1 cup [[Cookbook:Chop|chopped]] [[Cookbook:Walnut|walnuts]] or hickory nuts * ½ cup chopped [[Cookbook:Apple|apples]]
==Directions==
# [[Cookbook:Beat|Beat]] sugar and egg until smooth. # Beat in flour, baking powder, salt, and vanilla. # Stir walnuts or hickory nuts and apples into the mixture. # Pour into a greased baking pan (a [[Cookbook:Dutch Oven|Dutch oven]] pan or a 9 x 9 pan). # [[Cookbook:Bake|Bake]] at [[Cookbook:Oven_temperatures|325°F (160°C)]] for 30 minutes.
==Tips, Notes, and Variations==
* If you like topping, use whipped cream or ice cream.
[[Category:Inexpensive recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:American recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Dessert recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Pudding and Custard recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Camping recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Egg recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Salad Dressing recipes|3 cups|1 hour|3}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of France|French cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Vegetarian cuisine|Vegetarian Cuisine]]
Champagne Vinaigrette
==Ingredients==
* 1 [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic clove]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] [[Cookbook:Vinegar|champagne vinegar]] * ½ [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoon]] [[Cookbook:Black Pepper|freshly ground black pepper]] * [[Cookbook:Pinch|Pinch]] [[Cookbook:Kosher|kosher]] [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * 2 teaspoons [[Cookbook:Dijon Mustard|Dijon mustard]] * 2 cups [[Cookbook:Olive oil|extra virgin olive oil]]
==Directions==
# Crush garlic clove with the side of the blade of a chef's knife or other flat object. Transfer the clove, leaving it in one piece, to a mixing bowl. # Add the vinegar, pepper and salt, and allow to sit for 30 minutes. # Remove and discard the garlic. Whisk in the mustard. Slowly add the oil, whisking constantly to emulsify.
==Tips, Notes, and Variations==
* If not using immediately, store in a covered container in the refrigerator. Whisk again or shake container vigorously to re-emulsify before serving.
[[Category:Inexpensive recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:French recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Sauce recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Soup recipes|6|1 hour|3}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|American cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Spain|Spanish cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Vegetarian cuisine|Vegetarian Cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:beans|beans]] | [[Cookbook:Soups|Soups]]
''Fast and cheap, this soup will warm you on a cold day!''
==Ingredients==
* 3 (15-[[Cookbook:Ounce|ounce]]) cans [[Cookbook:Chickpea|garbanzo beans]] (chickpeas), divided * 4½ [[Cookbook:Cup|cups]] [[Cookbook:Broth|vegetable broth]] or [[Cookbook:Water|water]] (or a combination), divided * 1 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoon]] [[Cookbook:Olive Oil|olive oil]] * 2 heaping cups [[Cookbook:Chopping|chopped]] [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]] * 1 tablespoon minced or crushed [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]] * 1 small waxy [[Cookbook:Potato|potato]] (yellow Finn or Yucon gold), [[Cookbook:Dice|diced]] (~1 cup) * 1 medium [[Cookbook:Carrot|carrot]], diced * 1 medium stalk [[Cookbook:Celery|celery]], diced * [[Cookbook:Salt|Salt]], to taste * 1 [[Cookbook:Bay Leaf|bay leaf]] * 2 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoons]] [[Cookbook:Mustard|dry mustard]] * 2 teaspoons ground [[Cookbook:Cumin|cumin]] * A thread or two of [[Cookbook:Saffron|saffron]] (optional) * ½ cup [[Cookbook:Pea|green peas]] (fresh or frozen) * 3 tablespoons [[Cookbook:Vinegar|red wine vinegar]] * 2 medium-sized ripe [[Cookbook:Tomato|tomatoes]], peeled and seeded - or 1 cup chopped canned tomatoes * Freshly ground [[Cookbook:Pepper|black pepper]] and [[Cookbook:Cayenne pepper|cayenne pepper]], to taste * Minced fresh [[Cookbook:Basil|basil]], for [[Cookbook:Garnish|garnish]]
==Directions==
# Rinse and thoroughly drain garbanzo beans. Place about ⅔ of them in a [[Cookbook:Blender|Blender]] or [[Cookbook:Food Processor|food processor]] with 2 cups of broth and/or water, and [[Cookbook:Purée|purée]] until mostly smooth. Set aside. # Place a soup pot or [[Cookbook:Dutch Oven|Dutch Oven]] over medium heat and wait for about a minute. Add olive oil and swirl to coat the pan. # Add onion and [[Cookbook:Sautéing|sauté]] over medium heat for about 5 to 8 minutes, or until onion is translucent. # Add half the garlic plus the potato, carrot, and celery and about ⅛ teaspoon salt, and sauté over medium-low heat for 5 to 8 minutes. # Add garbanzo purée, plus remaining broth and/or water and garbanzo beans, and the bay leaf, mustard, cumin, and saffron. # Bring to boil, then lower the heat. # Cover and simmer for about 30 minutes, stirring occasionally. # Stir in the remaining garlic, plus the peas, vinegar, and tomato. # Taste to correct salt. # Add black pepper and cayenne. # Simmer for only about 5 minutes longer.
==Tips, Notes, and Variations==
* Serve topped with minced fresh basil. * Serve with a green salad decked out with a mustard-themed dressing, thick slices of pumpernickel bread, and a light Pinot Noir. * Vegetable broth comes in 1 [[Cookbook:Quart|quart]] boxed in most supermarkets. Choose a [[Cookbook:Gluten-Free|gluten-free]] one if your require, or make your own [[Cookbook:Stock|stock]].
[[Category:Inexpensive recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Soup recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:American recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Spanish recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Camping recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetable recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Chickpea recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Gluten-free recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Low-GI recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

revision.comment: New page: {{recipesummary|Cheese recipes|8 cakes|1 hour|3}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|American cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Vegetarian cuisine|Vegetarian Cuisine]] Goat Cheese ...
revision.text:
{{recipesummary|Cheese recipes|8 cakes|1 hour|3}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|American cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Vegetarian cuisine|Vegetarian Cuisine]]
Goat Cheese Cakes
==Ingredients==
* 11 [[Cookbook:Ounce|ounces]] goat [[Cookbook:Cheese|cheese]], room temperature * 1 (5.2-ounce) package Boursin brand cheese, room temperature * 4 ounces Ricotta cheese, room temperature * 1 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoon]] [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]] * 1 tablespoon [[Cookbook:Garlic|minced garlic]] * 1 tablespoon [[Cookbook:Shallot|minced shallot]] * 1 tablespoon [[Cookbook:Chives|minced chives]] * 2 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoons]] [[Cookbook:Thyme|minced fresh thyme]] * 2 teaspoons [[Cookbook:Basil|minced fresh basil]] * 2 teaspoons [[Cookbook:Tarragon|minced fresh tarragon]] * 1 cup [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]], for dredging * 3 [[Cookbook:Egg|eggs]], [[Cookbook:Beat|beaten lightly]] to make an egg wash * About 1 cup [[Cookbook:Bread Crumbs|bread crumbs]] * 4 tablespoons [[Cookbook:Olive oil|olive oil]]
==Directions==
# In a mixing bowl, combine goat cheese, Boursin and ricotta cheese. Set aside. # Melt butter in a small saucepan over medium-low heat. # Add the garlic, shallot, chives, thyme, basil and tarragon. # Cook just until soft and fragrant, about 2 minutes. # Fold herbs into cheese mixture. # Cover and refrigerate until mixture is firm, at least 30 minutes. # When cheese mixture is firm, divide it into 8 equal portions and form each portion into a cake about 3/4-inch thick. # Dredge each cake in flour, then shake off excess flour. # Dip each cake in egg wash, then into breadcrumbs, covering well on both sides. Set on a wire rack. # Heat oil in a large skillet or [[Cookbook:Sauté|sauté pan]] over medium-high heat. # Gently add cheese cakes and fry until golden on both sides, 1 to 2 minutes per side. # Drain on a wire rack.
[[Category:American recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Cheese recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]
