revision.text:
{{recipesummary|Meat recipes|8|1 hour|1}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of France|French cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Vegetarian cuisine|Vegetarian Cuisine]]
Salade Frisee
==Ingredients==
* 16 [[Cookbook:Cup|cups]] (loosely packed) [[Cookbook:Frisee|frisee]] * About ½ cup [[Cookbook:Champagne Vinaigrette|Champagne Vinaigrette]] * 8 [[Cookbook:Goat Cheese Cakes|Goat Cheese Cakes]] * Crumbled crisp [[Cookbook:Bacon|bacon]] pieces, for [[Cookbook:Garnish|garnish]]
==Directions==
# In a large mixing bowl, toss frisee with the Champagne Vinaigrette. # Divide salad among 8 salad plates. # Top each salad with a Goat Cheese Cake. # Garnish with crumbled bacon.
[[Category:Salad recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetable recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

revision.comment: New page: {{recipesummary|Fruit recipes|6|1 hour|2}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|American cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Vegetarian cuisine|Vegetarian Cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Dessert...
revision.text:
{{recipesummary|Fruit recipes|6|1 hour|2}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|American cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Vegetarian cuisine|Vegetarian Cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Dessert|Dessert]]
Hot Pineapple Side Dish
==Ingredients==
* 1 (20-[[Cookbook:Ounce|ounce]]) can [[Cookbook:Pineapple|pineapple chunks]] * ½ [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] * 3 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoons]] [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] * ¼ cup [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]], melted * 1½ cups shredded [[Cookbook:Cheddar Cheese|cheddar cheese]], divided * ⅔ cup coarsely crushed saltines (14 crackers)
==Directions==
# Preheat oven to [[Cookbook:Oven_temperatures|350°F]]. # Grease a 1½-[[Cookbook:Quart|quarts]] baking dish. # Drain the pineapple, reserving ¼ cup juice; set aside. # In a small bowl, combine sugar and flour. # Add the butter and 1 cup cheese; mix well. # Gently stir in pineapple. # Pour into a prepared baking dish. # Sprinkle crushed crackers on top; drizzle with reserved pineapple juice. # [[Cookbook:Bake|Bake]], uncovered, for 30 to 35 minutes or until bubbly around the edges. # Remove from oven and sprinkle with remaining cheese.
[[Category:Inexpensive recipes|Pineapple Side Dish, Hot]] [[Category:American recipes|Pineapple Side Dish, Hot]] [[Category:Dessert recipes|Pineapple Side Dish, Hot]] [[Category:Fruit recipes|Pineapple Side Dish, Hot]] [[Category:Cheese recipes|Pineapple Side Dish, Hot]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|Pineapple Side Dish, Hot]]

revision.comment: New page: {{recipesummary|Snack recipes|30 cookies|1 hour|3}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|American cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Vegetarian cuisine|Vegetarian Cuisine]] | [[Cookboo...
revision.text:
{{recipesummary|Snack recipes|30 cookies|1 hour|3}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|American cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Vegetarian cuisine|Vegetarian Cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Dessert|Dessert]]
Nutty Buddy Chocolate Cookie Bars
==Ingredients==
* ¾ [[Cookbook:Cup|cups]] (1½ sticks) [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]] * 3 cups graham cracker crumbs * 2 (14-[[Cookbook:Ounce|ounce]]) cans sweetened condensed milk (not evaporated milk) * 3 cups (12 ounces) [[Cookbook:Chocolate Chips|chocolate chips]] * 1 cup [[Cookbook:Pecan|pecan]] pieces or [[Cookbook:Chop|chopped]] [[Cookbook:Pecan|pecans]] * ⅓ cup sliced (not slivered) [[Cookbook:Almond|almonds]]
==Directions==
# Preheat the oven to [[Cookbook:Oven_temperatures|350°F]]. # Place butter in [[Cookbook:Microwave|microwave]]-safe dish, cover with a paper towel and microwave on high, for about 45 seconds, or until melted. Remove carefully and stir to melt completely. # Place the graham-cracker crumbs in a metal 13-by-9-inch baking pan. # Pour melted butter over crumbs, and stir and fold until all the crumbs are moistened with the butter. Press crumbs firmly and evenly into the bottom of the pan. # Pour the sweetened condensed milk over the crunb crust. Spread to the edges with the back of a spoon. # Top evenly with chocolate chips, pecans, and almonds. Press down with a fork. # [[Cookbook:Bake|Bake]], uncovered, for 25 to 35 minutes or until bubbling slightly along the edges. # Remove from oven and cook to roomtemperature. # Refrigerate until firm for 1 to 2 hours before slicing. # Store at room temperature, covered with foil.
[[Category:Inexpensive recipes|Chocolate Cookie Bars, Nutty Buddy]] [[Category:American recipes|Chocolate Cookie Bars, Nutty Buddy]] [[Category:Dessert recipes|Chocolate Cookie Bars, Nutty Buddy]] [[Category:Cookie recipes|Chocolate Cookie Bars, Nutty Buddy]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|Chocolate Cookie Bars, Nutty Buddy]]

{{recipesummary|Dessert recipes|6|1 hour|3}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:North American cuisines|North America]] | [[Cookbook:Native American cuisine|Native American cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Vegetarian cuisine|Vegetarian Cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Dessert|Dessert]]
Indian Pudding
==Ingredients==
* 1 [[Cookbook:Quart|quart]] [[Cookbook:Milk|milk]] (remove ½ [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]], set aside) * 1 cup cold [[Cookbook:Water|water]] * 6 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoons]] [[Cookbook:Cornmeal|cornmeal]] * ½ [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoon]] [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * 1 cup [[Cookbook:Molasses|molasses]] * 1 teaspoon [[Cookbook:Baking Soda|baking soda]] * 3 tablespoons [[Cookbook:Brown Sugar|brown sugar]] * ½ teaspoon [[Cookbook:Nutmeg|nutmeg]] * 1 tablespoon [[Cookbook:Ginger|ginger]] * ½ teaspoon [[Cookbook:Cinnamon|cinnamon]] * 4 [[Cookbook:Egg White|egg whites]], [[Cookbook:Beat|beaten]] * 4 [[Cookbook:Egg|egg yolks]], beaten stiff
==Directions==
# [[Cookbook:Boiling|Boil]] the milk (less ½ cup removed). # Add cold water to cornmeal to wet it. # Slowly pour the cornmeal mixture into the boiling milk. Add salt. # Boil for 15 minutes, stirring constantly. If skin forms, remove it. Remove from heat, set aside. # In a small bowl, mix molasses with baking soda; the ½ cup cold milk (set aside previously) and brown sugar. # Add the spices and the beaten egg yolks to this mixture. # Slowly pour the molasses mixture into the cornmeal mixture. # Fold in stiff beaten egg whites. # Grease or [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]] the pan and [[Cookbook:Bake|bake]] for an hour at [[Cookbook:Oven_temperatures|350°F]].
[[Category:Inexpensive recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:American recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Native American recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Dessert recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Pudding and Custard recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Milk recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Molasses recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Nutmeg recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Ginger recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Cinnamon recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Egg recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Camping recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Gibraltar|Cuisine of Gibraltar]]
'''Calentita''' – the quintessential 'Yanito' dish. Every Gibraltarian knows how to cook calentita! Or so they should, it is a matter of national pride.
It is believed this dish is based on the Genoese '[[Cookbook:Socca|farinata]]' which is cooked thinner and often with toppings whereas calentita is cooked in a deeper pan and is never topped with anything but black pepper.
The name 'calentita' has a most interesting history. When Gibraltarian evacuees returned to Gibraltar after World War II many were forced to live in cramped and often inadequate housing. Not all homes had workable ovens and people cooked mainly Spanish style stews (potajes) and similar dishes. However, the local bakeries took advantage of this and would use their ovens in slack periods to make calentita which was sold by street vendors (this had been the fashion before the war when almost no-one had an oven at home). The calentita would be baked in a large low pan (similar to a frying pan of diameter about 90 cm with two small grab handles) with a metal hinged lid. The vendor would then walk along the streets on the Rock shouting out his wares. His shout would be similar to this: 'La llevo caliente, calentita! Calentita, caliente!' A simple translation would be: 'Hot! Come and get it! I still have it hot!'. Caliente means hot and calentita is an endearing version of hot! Everyone would rush to him and buy a portion which was invariably about 8cm by 5cm and cost 6d (about 2 1/2p of today's money) and was served on a piece of greaseproof paper. The vendor would sprinkle ground pepper on it and off you went!
== Ingredients ==
* 250g [[Cookbook:Chickpea Flour|chickpea flour]] * 1 litre [[Cookbook:Water|water]] * [[Cookbook:Olive Oil|Olive oil]] * [[Cookbook:Salt|Salt]] and [[Cookbook:Pepper|pepper]]
== Procedure ==
# Mix chickpea flour and water and salt/pepper in a bowl. Leave to stand, preferably overnight. # Preheat oven to 175°C (350°F). Take a tin 9x6 inches (15x23cms) or oven dish and put enough oil to cover bottom of tin or bowl. Heat in oven. # Then spread hot oil up sides of tin with a pastry brush or by tilting. Stir mixture and pour immediately into tin, and put back in oven for about 1 hour approximately or until set in the middle. # Leave to stand for a while. # Good for two or three servings.
[[Category:Gibraltarian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Bread recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Chickpea recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegan recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Gluten-free recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Low-GI recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Gibraltar|Cuisine of Gibraltar]]
'''Rosto''' is a dish is of [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Italy|Italian]] origin, and provides for two complete courses cooked in one pot without the need for an oven. Originally the pasta was served as a first course with the tomato sauce over it. This was followed by the sliced meat, usually a cheaper cut of pork instead of loin and a small piece at that, with the potatoes, carrots and mushrooms.
It is still extremely popular although many people nowadays also cook it with chicken thighs or even a piece of beef instead of the traditional pork.
== Ingredients ==
* 1 kg [[Cookbook:Pork|Pork]] loin * 2 [[Cookbook:Carrot|Carrots]] * 4 [[Cookbook:Potato|potatoes]] cut in quarters * 1 [[Cookbook:Onion|Onion]], chopped * ½ kg Penne or Macaroni ([[Cookbook:Pasta|pasta]]) * ¼ kg [[Cookbook:Mushroom|Mushrooms]] * ½ kg Fresh [[Cookbook:Tomato|Tomatoes]] * 1 tin ‘[[Cookbook:Tomato Paste|tomate triturado]]’ (tomato paste, or three peeled, de-seeded and puréed tomatoes) * [[Cookbook:Salt|Salt]] and [[Cookbook:Pepper|Pepper]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Garlic|Garlic Clove]] * [[Cookbook:Olive Oil|Olive Oil]] (To [[Cookbook:Frying|fry]]) * [[Cookbook:Wine|White wine]] * [[Cookbook:Sugar|Sugar]] to taste * [[Cookbook:Grater|Grated]] [[Cookbook:Cheese|cheese]] ([[Cookbook:Edam Cheese|Hard Edam]] or [[Cookbook:Parmesan Cheese|Parmesan]])
== Procedure ==
# Fry crushed garlic clove and chopped onions till soft. # Add tomatoes; fry for five minutes then add pork loin and brown till sealed. # Add tin of ‘tomate triturado’ and a dash of white wine. # Add potatoes and carrots then cook till meat, potatoes and carrots are done. # Add the mushrooms about ten minutes before the end. # Add salt, pepper and sugar to taste. # Boil the macaroni until ‘al dente’. # Remove the meat from the stew and slice. # Serve meat, potatoes and pasta on same plate pouring sauce over pasta and topping with grated cheese.
[[Category:Gibraltarian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Pork recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Pasta recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Gibraltar|Cuisine of Gibraltar]]
'''Minestra''' - a typical [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Italy|Genoese]] dish not to be confused with the [[Cookbook:Basque cuisine|Basque]] ‘[[Cookbook:Menestra|menestra]]’ which is simply mixed boiled vegetables, or with [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Italy|Italian]] [[Cookbook:Minestrone|minestrone]], a thick vegetable soup.
==Ingredients==
* 2 [[Cookbook:Zucchini|courgettes]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Eggplant|aubergine]] * 1 large piece [[Cookbook:Pumpkin|pumpkin]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Kohlrabi|kohlrabi]] (colinabo) * 2 [[Cookbook:Turnip|turnips]] * 1 head of [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]] * fresh [[Cookbook:Basil|basil]] * [[Cookbook:Olive Oil|olive oil]] * [[Cookbook:Pasta|fideua]] (spaghetti) * [[Cookbook:Kidney Bean|kidney beans]] (previously soaked overnight) * [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] and [[Cookbook:Pepper|pepper]] * 1 UK pint (600ml) [[Cookbook:Stock|vegetable stock]]
==Procedure== # In a large pot or [[Cookbook:Pressure Cooking|pressure cooker]], place the first six ingredients, roughly [[Cookbook:Dice|diced]]. Add a pint of vegetable stock and a tablespoon of oil. Bring to pressure and cook for 8 – 10 minutes, or simmer in a large pot for an hour. Cool, then [[Cookbook:Purée|purée]] the whole thing. # Place a large handful of basil leaves and about 6 cloves of garlic in a [[Cookbook:Mortar and Pestle|mortar]] and pound until roughly crushed and a gritty paste is achieved. Add to the pot, stir and season to taste. # Meanwhile, boil the beans separately and, when soft, add to purée mixture. # Boil the pasta until ''[[Cookbook:Al dente|al dente]]'' then add to mixture. # Serve with [[Cookbook:Grater|grated]] [[Cookbook:Parmesan Cheese|Parmesan]] or hard [[Cookbook:Edam Cheese|Edam]] sprinkled over it.
[[Category:Gibraltarian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Stew recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Pasta recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Eggplant recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Zucchini recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Pumpkin recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Gibraltar|Cuisine of Gibraltar]]
'''Torta de acelga''' (Chard pie) is believed to be based on a [[Cookbook:Spinach|spinach]] pie eaten in parts of [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Italy|Italy]] and is also very similar to the [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Greece|Greek]] '[[Cookbook:Spanakopita|spanakopita]]'. This pie is traditionally eaten on [[w:Good Friday|Good Friday]] here in Gibraltar.
==Ingredients==
* 1 small pkt [[Cookbook:Puff pastry|puff pastry]] (or else make a pastry by mixing one glass each of [[Cookbook:Olive Oil|olive oil]] and [[Cookbook:Water|water]] then adding [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] until a soft [[Cookbook:Dough|dough]] is achieved) * 6 bunches of [[Cookbook:Chard|acelga]] (chard) * 6 [[Cookbook:Egg|eggs]] * [[Cookbook:Bread Crumb|Breadcrumbs]] * [[Cookbook:Grater|Grated]] [[Cookbook:Cheese|cheese]] * [[Cookbook:Parsley|Parsley]] * 2 teaspoons [[Cookbook:Mincing|minced]] [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]] * Season to taste
==Procedure==
# Remove the stems of the acelga (these stems will become useful for another recipe called Potaje de acelga). # Wash the leaves very well to remove any grit or soil. Boil the acelga leaves, drain really well and chop them. Fry them for a few minutes in hot olive oil then set aside. # Roll out the pastry and lay on an oven proof pie dish leaving sufficient pastry to close the pie later. # Beat the eggs and add all the ingredients to make a nice filling. # Add to the acelga and mix all together. # Fill the pie dish with this “relleno” or filling and close the pie with the pastry. # Cook in the oven (150°C / 300°F) for about 30 mins or until the pie is nice and golden.
N.B. I always boil the acelga the night before to save time.
[[Category:Gibraltarian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Pie recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Gibraltar|Cuisine of Gibraltar]]
'''Panissa''' – there is also an original [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Italy|Italian]] one. What is referred to as Panissa in Italy nowadays is more akin to the Gibraltarian '[[Cookbook:Calentita|Calentita]]'. My grandmother always used to make Panissas on the same day she made [[Cookbook:Minestra|Minestra]] as a light second course.
==Ingredients ==
* 500g [[Cookbook:Chickpea Flour|chickpea flour]] * 2 litres [[Cookbook:Water|water]] * [[Cookbook:Olive Oil|Olive oil]] for [[Cookbook:Frying|frying]] * [[Cookbook:Salt|Salt]] * [[Cookbook:Lemon Juice|Lemon juice]] * [[Cookbook:Mincing|Minced]] [[Cookbook:Parsley|parsley]] (optional)
==Procedure==
# Stir the chick pea flour into 2 litres of lightly salted water over a moderate flame, and stir the mixture steadily in the same direction with a wooden spoon until you obtain a soft, lump-free paste. # When the paste begins to pull away from the sides of the pot, turn it out into oiled wooden moulds, or spread it out about ¼ inch high (½ cm) on your work surface (dust the surface with parsley before you spread if you're including it). # Alternatively pour into saucers and cut into wedges when set. # Once the paste has cooled, cut it into 1 by 3-inch (3x7 cm) rectangles and fry them in hot oil.
[[Category:Gibraltarian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Chickpea recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegan recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Gluten-free recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Low-GI recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Gibraltar|Cuisine of Gibraltar]]
'''Rolitos'''
==Ingredients==
* 8 slices thinly sliced [[Cookbook:Veal|veal]] * 4 slices of [[Cookbook:Ham|ham]] cut in halves * 2 [[Cookbook:Hard Boiled Eggs|hard boiled eggs]] cut into quarters * 8 [[Cookbook:Olive|Olives]] (''con morrones'' - stuffed with peppers) cut in halves * 1 crushed or chopped [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic clove]] * 1 chopped [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]] * 1 cup [[Cookbook:Stock|beef stock]] * [[Cookbook:Salt|Salt]] and [[Cookbook:Pepper|pepper]] * [[w:Bisto|Bisto]] (as required)
==Procedure== # Lay out one slice of veal on worktop; place on it half a slice of ham, quarter egg and two olive halves. # Carefully roll up the veal to make a package or roll with everything inside. Use two toothpicks to hold the roll together. # Place rolls on a plate and store in a cool place or fridge. # Fry garlic and onions till soft. # Add stock and two teaspoons of Bisto and bring to boil. # Carefully place veal rolls into the boiling mixture being careful not to break them up. # Lower heat and simmer till done. If sauce is too thin add Bisto till the right consistency is achieved.
This meal is traditionally served with mashed potatoes. There is an alternative method made with a tomato sauce instead of brown gravy.
[[Category:Gibraltarian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Veal recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Ham recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Fish recipes|4 sandwiches|⅛ hour|1}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|American cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Midwestern cuisine|Midwestern cuisine]]
Mozzarella Tuna Melts
==Ingredients==
* 1 (6-[[Cookbook:Ounce|ounce]]) can water-packed [[Cookbook:Tuna|tuna]], drained and flaked * ¼ cup finely [[Cookbook:Chop|chopped]] [[Cookbook:Celery|celery]] * ¼ cup finely chopped [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]] * ¼ cup [[Cookbook:Mayonnaise|mayonnaise]] * 4 [[Cookbook:Bread|hamburger buns]], split * 4 [[Cookbook:Mozzarella Cheese|mozzarella cheese]] slices * 4 [[Cookbook:Tomato|tomato]] slices * 4 [[Cookbook:Lettuce|lettuce leaves]]
==Directions==
# Preheat oven to [[Cookbook:Oven_temperatures|350°F]]. # In a small bowl, combine tuna, celery, onion and mayonnaise. # Spread on bottom of buns. # Top tuna mixture with a slice of cheese and tomato. # Place on an ungreased baking sheet. # [[Cookbook:Bake|Bake]] for 12 to 15 minutes or until heated through and cheese is melted. # Top each with a lettuce leaf; replace bun tops.
[[Category:Inexpensive recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Sandwich recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:American recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Midwestern recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Tuna recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Bread recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Cheese recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Pie recipes|1 pie crust|1 hour|3}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|American cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Vegetarian cuisine|Vegetarian Cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Dessert|Dessert]]
==Ingredients==
* 2¾ [[Cookbook:Cup|cups]] (350g) [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] * 1 ⅛ cups [260g] (2 sticks plus 2 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoons]]) [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]] (see Note) * 1 cup plus 2 tablespoons (220g) [[Cookbook:Sugar|confectioner's sugar]] * 2 [[Cookbook:Egg|eggs]] * 1 egg yolk
==Procedure==
# With an [[Cookbook:Mixer|electric stand mixer]] or hand-held mixer, combine flour, butter and sugar until the mixture has the consistency of small peas. # With the machine on low speed, add eggs and yolk, and mix just until well-incorporated, about 25 seconds. # Wrap dough tightly in plastic wrap and chill for at least 30 minutes before rolling out.
==Tips, Notes, and Variations==
* European-style butter, which has a higher fat content than American butter, is recommended. Most supermarkets now stock at least one variety of European-style butter, Plugra being one of the most popular brands.
[[Category:American recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Dessert recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Bread recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Recipes_with_metric_units|{{PAGENAME}}]]

revision.comment: New page: {{recipesummary|Bread recipes|16|1 hour|3}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|American cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Midwestern cuisine|Midwestern cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Breakf...
revision.text:
{{recipesummary|Bread recipes|16|1 hour|3}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|American cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Midwestern cuisine|Midwestern cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Breakfast|Breakfast Cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Vegetarian cuisine|Vegetarian Cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Holiday Recipes|Holiday Recipes]] | [[Cookbook:Bread|Bread]] | [[Cookbook:Dessert|Dessert]]
Pumpkin Bread
==Ingredients==
* 4 [[Cookbook:Egg|eggs]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Cup|cups]] [[Cookbook:Canola Oil|canola oil]] * 1 (15-[[Cookbook:Ounce|ounce]]) can [[Cookbook:pumpkin|pumpkin]] [[Cookbook:Puree|puree]] * 3 cups [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] * 3½ cups [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] * 1½ [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoons]] [[Cookbook:Baking Soda|baking soda]] * 2 teaspoons [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * 2 teaspoons [[Cookbook:Allspice|ground allspice]] * 2 teaspoons [[Cookbook:Cinnamon|ground cinnamon]] * 1½ teaspoons [[Cookbook:Nutmeg|nutmeg]] * 2 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoon]] raw pumpkin seeds, for [[Cookbook:Garnish|garnish]]
==Directions==
# Preheat oven to [[Cookbook:Oven_temperatures|375°F]]. # Butter and lightly flour 2 medium loaf pans (8 1/2 by 4 1/2 by 2 1/2 inches). # Using a [[Cookbook:Mixer|stand mixer]] fitted with the paddle attachment, combine eggs, oil, pumpkin and sugar until smooth. # In a separate bowl, combine the flour, soda, salt, allspice, cinnamon and nutmeg. # With the machine on low speed, add the flour mixture to the pumpkin mixture in ¼-cup increments. # Scrape down the side of the bowl and mix for another 30 seconds or so, until all ingredients are well-combined. # Divide the mixture equally between the 2 loaf pans. # Sprinkle the top of each loaf with 1 tablespoon pumpkin seeds. # Bake 40 to 45 minutes until a tester inserted into the center of each loaf comes out clean. # Allow loaves to cool in the pans for 5 to 10 minutes before unmolding, then allow loaves to cool on a wire rack to room temperature before cutting or wrapping.
[[Category:Inexpensive recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:American recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Dessert recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Cake recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Camping recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Bread recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Pumpkin recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetable recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

revision.comment: New page: {{recipesummary|Soup recipes|4|1 hour|2}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|American cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Vegetarian cuisine|Vegetarian Cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Soups|So...
revision.text:
{{recipesummary|Soup recipes|4|1 hour|2}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|American cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Vegetarian cuisine|Vegetarian Cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Soups|Soups]]
Spicy Tomato Soup
==Ingredients==
* 4 [[Cookbook:Cup|cups]] [[Cookbook:Dice|diced]] [[Cookbook:Tomato|tomatoes]] (canned is fine) * 4 cups [[Cookbook:Cream|heavy cream]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoon]] [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] * ½ teaspoon [[Cookbook:Pepper|ground white pepper]] * ¼ teaspoon [[Cookbook:Kosher|kosher]] [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * ¼ teaspoon [[Cookbook:Garlic|granulated garlic]] * 1/8 teaspoon [[Cookbook:Cayenne Pepper|cayenne]]
==Directions==
# In a [[Cookbook:Blender|blender]] or [[Cookbook:Food Processor|food processor]], working in batches if necessary, [[Cookbook:Puree|puree]] tomatoes, cream, sugar, pepper, salt, garlic and cayenne. # Transfer soup to a [[Cookbook:saucepan|saucepan]] and bring to a [[Cookbook:Boil|boil]] over high heat. # Reduce heat and [[Cookbook:simmer|simmer]], stirring occasionally, until soup thickens, 20 to 30 minutes. # Serve hot.
==Tips, Notes, and Variations==
* Variation: [[Cookbook:Garnish|Garnish]] soup with cooked [[Cookbook:shrimp|shrimp]] or slices of [[Cookbook:sausage|andouille sausage]].
[[Category:Inexpensive recipes|Tomato Soup, Spicy]] [[Category:American recipes|Tomato Soup, Spicy]] [[Category:Camping recipes|Tomato Soup, Spicy]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|Tomato Soup, Spicy]] [[Category:Vegetable recipes|Tomato Soup, Spicy]] [[Category:Tomato recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

revision.comment: Reverted edit of [[Special:Contributions/Michael Natkin|Michael Natkin]], changed back to last version by Redlentil
revision.text:
{{recipesummary|Dessert recipes|8|1 hour|3}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of France|Cuisine of France]] | [[Cookbook:Vegetarian cuisine|Vegetarian Cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Dessert|Dessert]]
'''Tarte Tatin'''
==Ingredients==
* 1 [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] * 4 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoons]] [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]] (see Note) * ¼ cup [[Cookbook:Water|water]] * 5 [[Cookbook:Apple|Golden Delicious apples]], peeled, cored and quartered * 1 [[Cookbook:Pastry Dough|Pastry Dough recipe]]
==Directions==
# Preheat oven to [[Cookbook:Oven_temperatures|400°F]]. # Place sugar, butter and water in a stovetop/oven-safe tarte dish (a 9-inch or 10-inch Pyrex pie plate works well) over medium-high heat. # Cook until mixture becomes golden brown and bubbly. # Remove from heat and allow mixture to cool to room temperature in the tarte dish. # When caramel mixture has cooled, arrange the apple quarters on their sides in the mixture. # Roll the Pastry Dough out to a thickness of about ½-inch and a diameter large enough to cover the tarte dish. # Place dough on top of the tarte, then trim and discard the edges. # [[Cookbook:Bake|Bake]] tarte for 40 minutes. # Allow to cool in the tarte dish for 15 minutes before inverting onto a serving platter.
==Tips, Notes, and Variations==
* European-style butter, which has a higher fat content than American butter, is recommended. Most US supermarkets now stock at least one variety of European-style butter, Plugra being one of the most popular brands.
[[Category:Dessert recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Southern cuisine|Southern cuisine (USA)]] | [[Cookbook:Fried Chicken|Fried Chicken]]
'''Fried chicken''' has a dual origin in the rural American South. The Scots had a tradition of shallow cooking chicken in fat (not quite pan frying), unlike their English counterparts who baked or boiled chicken. Later, as African slaves were introduced to households as cooks, seasonings and spices were added that are absent in traditional Scottish cuisine, improving the flavor and they brought the concept of deep fat frying. Since slaves were often allowed to keep only chickens, frying chicken as a special occasion spread through the African American community. After slavery, poor rural southern blacks continued the tradition since chickens were often the only animals they could afford to raise. Since fried chicken could keep for several days, it travelled well, and also gained favor during segregation when blacks normally could not find places to eat and had to carry their own food. Southern whites also continued the tradition of frying chicken. While not limited like blacks socially, poor whites were no better off economically. Therefore, fried chicken continued to dominate as "Sunday dinner" or on other special occasions.
==Ingredients==
*1 fryer [[Cookbook:chicken|chicken]], cut up (see notes below) *1 quart [[Cookbook:milk|buttermilk]] *½ cup [[Cookbook:salt|salt]] *[[Cookbook:Spice rub|Spice rub]] (Paprika is highly recommended. See below for how to prepare) *[[Cookbook:Flour|Flour]] *A quantity of [[Cookbook:Oil|oil]] suitable for the desired cooking method (see notes below)
==Procedure== ===Preparing the spice rub=== #Put a large amount of the spice in a bowl. #Add slightly less of some other seasonings, such as [[Cookbook:pepper|pepper]]. Mix it up. You now have a spice rub.
===Brining the chicken=== #Pour the buttermilk into a bowl and dissolve ½ cup of salt in the buttermilk. #Piece by piece, roll the chicken around in the spice rub. #Submerge each chicken piece in the buttermilk. #Cover the bowl of buttermilk and chicken and refrigerate. (You can get by with as few as two hours if you are in a hurry, but the flavor will suffer. You can also park it overnight, but you should reduce the salt to ⅓ of a cup) #Shortly before you want to cook the chicken, remove it from the buttermilk and drain. Roll it around in flour so that it is well covered in flour. Shake off the excess flour.
===Cooking the chicken, deep frying method=== #The safest cooking method is [[Cookbook:Deep Fat Frying|deep frying]]. Immerse chicken in 360°F oil. Cooking times are: #*Breasts: 10 minutes #*Drumsticks: 12 minutes #*Thighs: 13-14 minutes #*Wings: 10 minutes (though wings are often better suited to other applications) #Drain the chicken on a wire rack (place it over a sheet pan to catch the oil).
===Variation 1, pan frying method=== #The most traditional cooking method is [[Cookbook:Pan Frying|pan frying]] in a [[Cookbook:Cast iron|cast iron skillet]]. Care must be taken to avoid spilling and splattering. #Heat enough oil (or shortening) to come 3-4mm up the side of the pan to 325°F. #Carefully place chicken in pan, skin side down, and cook until brown, 10-12 minutes. Turn over and cook other side. #Doing this will require some careful placement in the pan so as to cook the slow-cooking meat (such as thighs) more intensely than the fast-cooking meat (such as wings and breasts). #Drain the chicken on a wire rack (place it over a sheet pan to catch the oil).
===Variation 2, pressure frying method=== #[[Cookbook:Pressure frying|Pressure frying]] gives excellent results, but special equipment is needed. A typical pressure cooker is not suitable for cooking with large quantities of oil; a pressure fryer must be used. Follow the manufacturer's instructions carefully. #Put the chicken pieces into hot oil (larger pieces first) and fry about 3 minutes until very light brown. Then put on the lid and lock it. #Cook at a pressure of 5-6 pounds for about 7 minutes. #Drain the chicken on a wire rack (place it over a sheet pan to catch the oil).
==Notes, Tips, and Variations== *The key to this recipe is the buttermilk brine, which seasons the chicken with a salty tanginess inside. Combined with a suitably zingy spice rub, this works out beautifully. *This recipe is death to oil, so it's one you might want to save until you're thinking about changing your fryer oil anyway. *As with all respectable fried chicken recipes, this recipe may be even better 24 hours after you cook it, when the chicken has been refrigerated. *If you can get a pre-cut chicken, this is ultimately easier. Alternatively, if you have a real preference for drumsticks, thighs, breasts, or some other part, feel free to buy just those. The quantities in the ingredient list, however, reflect two breasts, two thighs, and two drumsticks. (Don't waste the other parts on fried chicken; save them for chicken soup! But if you like fried chicken wings, increase the quantities a bit.) *If you are kosher, lactose intolerant, not fond of buttermilk, or feeling experimental, feel free to play around with other possible brines here. If you use a less [[Wikipedia:viscous|viscous]] liquid than buttermilk, however, you may need to use an egg wash to make sure that the flour sticks to the chicken in sufficient quantity. *Wings can also be saved, along with other leftover bits of carcass, to make [[Cookbook:Chicken Soup|chicken soup]]. *Personal preference chooses which spice to use as a base. A [[Cookbook:paprika|paprika]] based rub works very well for this recipe, but others will work just fine. [[Cookbook:Cumin|Cumin]] or [[Cookbook:Curry Powder|curry powder]] would also both be good choices.
[[Category:Chicken recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Southern recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of India|Cuisine of India]] | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Pakistan|Cuisine of Pakistan]]
'''Shirmal''', also '''sheermal''', is a traditional [[Cookbook:Flatbread|flatbread]] made by Muslims in [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Pakistan|Pakistan]] and in the [[w:Hyderabad State|Hyderabad]] region of [[Cookbook:Cuisine of India|India]], probably from Persian influences.
==Ingredients==
* 3 cups [[Cookbook:Flour|plain flour]] * 1 cup [[Cookbook:Milk|milk]] * 2 tbsp. [[Cookbook:Milk|milk]] extra * 1 tsp. [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] * ¾ cup [[Cookbook:Ghee|ghee]] * [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] to taste * a few [[Cookbook:Saffron|saffron strands]]
==Procedure==
# Soak saffron strands in 2 tbsp. milk warmed. Keep aside. # Sift together flour and salt, sprinkle in sugar. # Take in a large bowl, add melted ghee. Run in ghee with finger until evenly distributed. # Add milk a little at a time, and knead in dough. When it forms a soft smooth lump, cover with moist cloth. # Keep aside for 2 hours, knead, keep aside again for 2 hours. Knead again, divide into 7 parts. # Rub saffron strands in milk to dissolve. # Place an inverted heavy iron pan on lower shelf of oven. Keep the grill on upper rack. Preheat to 250°C (480°F). # Use dry flour for dusting while rolling. Roll to thick round about 6" in diameter. Prick with fork all over. Slap onto pan base. # Allow to bake until brown spots appear. # Move to grill with tongs. Dip fingers in saffron milk and splash on sheermal. Keep in oven few more seconds. # Or, bake in traditional [[Cookbook:Tandoor|tandoor]] or in inverted [[Cookbook:Pressure Cooking|pressure cooker]]. # Remove, serve hot or wrap in slightly moist towel to collect.
Apply butter or ghee on top if desired. Serve with gravies, veggies, curds, pickles or jams.
[[Category:Indian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Pakistani recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Flatbread recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

revision.comment: rv because I can't imagine using a whole cup of baking soda in such a recipe, so suspect this was a newbie test
revision.text:
{{recipesummary |Category = Dumpling recipes |Image = [[Image:Momo.jpg|300px]] }} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Nepal|Nepal]] | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Tibet|Tibet]]
'''Momos''' are a kind of [[Cookbook:Dumpling|dumpling]] popular in [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Nepal|Nepal]], [[Cookbook:Cuisine of India|Sikkim]] and [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Tibet|Tibet]], and are similar to [[Cookbook:Cuisine of China|Chinese]] [[Cookbook:Potsticker|potstickers]].
Momos are made of a simple flour and water dough. White flour is generally preferred, and sometimes a little yeast or baking soda is added to give a more 'doughy' texture to the finished product. The filling may be one of several mixtures, described below:
*[[Cookbook:Mincing|Minced]] [[Cookbook:Beef|beef]], or beef and [[Cookbook:Pork|pork]], combined with any or all of the following: [[Cookbook:Onion|onions]], [[Cookbook:Shallot|shallots]], [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]], and [[Cookbook:Cilantro|cilantro (coriander leaves)]]. The mixture is usually spiced with [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]], [[Cookbook:Pepper|pepper]], and often ground [[Cookbook:Cumin|cumin]]. Some people also add finely [[Cookbook:Purée|puréed]] [[Cookbook:Tomato|tomatoes]], though many variations are possible. *[[Cookbook:Vegetarian cuisine|Vegetarian]], predominantly made from onions and cabbage, and frequently curried. Finely diced vegetables are also added, as well as various spices. *[[Cookbook:Potato|Potato]], somewhat similar to Indian [[Cookbook:Samosa|samosas]], with small dice of firm potato in a tomato based sauce. *[[Cookbook:Cheese|Cheese]], usually a fresh cheese, this variety is common in Sikkim. These fillings are then enclosed in a round of the above dough, which is sealed in a circular fashion, resembling a pinwheel, though it's also not uncommon for them to be folded in half and sealed.
The resulting dumplings are then cooked by [[Cookbook:Steaming|steaming]] over a soup (either a stock based on bones or tomato-based), which is served with the dumplings, as well as chilli sauce.
==Ingredients==
'''Nepali Meat Momos (Nepalese Meat Dumplings)'''
===Wrapper=== * 3 cup [[Cookbook:All-purpose flour|All-purpose flour]] * 1 cup [[Cookbook:Water|water]] * pinch of [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] (Alternatively, buy egg roll wrapper )
===Filling=== * 1 lb ground or [[Cookbook:Mincing|minced]] [[Cookbook:Chicken|chicken]]/[[Cookbook:Turkey|turkey]]/[[Cookbook:Lamb|lamb]]/[[Cookbook:Pork|pork]] * 1 cup [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]] (finely chopped) * ½ cup [[Cookbook:Green onion|shallots/spring onions]] (finely chopped) * ½ cup [[Cookbook:Cilantro|cilantro]], chopped * ½ cup diced [[Cookbook:Tomato|tomatoes]] * 1 teaspoon [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]] paste * 1 teaspoon [[Cookbook:Ginger|ginger]] paste * ¼ teaspoon [[Cookbook:Turmeric|turmeric]] (optional) * 1 teaspoon [[Cookbook:Cumin|cumin]] powder * 1 teaspoon [[Cookbook:Coriander|coriander]] powder * 4 tablespoon [[Cookbook:Ghee|ghee]] or [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]] * Salt to taste
==Preparation== ===Filling=== # Combine all filling ingredients. Mix well, adjust seasoning according to taste.
===Wrapper=== (Disregard this section if you buy the ready-made wrappers) # In a bowl combine flour, salt and water. Mix well, knead until the dough becomes similar to pizza dough. # Optional step: Cover and let stand for about one hour. Knead well again before making the wrappers. # Prepare 1 inch dough balls and roll between your palms to spherical shape. # Dust working board with dry flour. On the board gently flatten the ball with rolling pin to about 2 inch diameter circle. # Repeat steps 3-4 again for more wrappers.
===Packing Dumpling=== # Hold wrapper on one palm. Put about 1 spoon of filling in middle of wrapper. # With the other hand bring all edges together to center, making the pleats. Pinch and twist the pleats to ensure the absolute closure of the dumpling. Closing the meat inside wrapper is the secret of tasty and juicy dumplings.
===Steaming Dumplings=== # Heat up water in steamers. # Oil the steamer rack well or put cabbage leaves on bottom to prevent dumplings from sticking to rack. Put dumpling in steamer. # When water boils, close the lid on rack. # Steaming until the dumplings are cooked through, about 10-15 minutes.
{{Wikipedia|Momo (food)}}
[[Category:Nepali recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Tibetan recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Dumpling recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

page.title: Cookbook:'Out of Salad Dressing' Salad Dressing

revision.text:
{{Recipesummary| |Category=Salad Dressing recipes |Servings=12 |Time=8 h, 10 minutes |Rating=1 }}
{{Nutrition Summary| |ServingSize=1/12 of recipe |Servings=12 |Cals=148 |FatCals=124 |TotalFat=1.2 g |SatFat=0.3 g |Cholesterol=1.3 mg |Sodium=45.5 mg |Carbs=0.2 g |Fiber=0.1 g |Sugars=0.1 g |Protein=0.4 g |VitaminA=3% |VitaminC=3% |Calcium=18% |Iron=2% }}
{{recipe|Out of Salad Dressing Salad Dressing}} | [[Cookbook:Sauces|Sauces]]
"This is a recipe I created when I realized that our bottled salad dressing was frozen and couldn't thaw quickly enough. It is very easy to make from ingredients usually already on hand. You can vary the amounts, or even substitute low-fat ingredients according to your personal taste. Tastes even better when chilled over night!"
==Ingredients== * 1 1/2 [[Cookbook:Lemon|lemons]], juiced * 1 cup freshly grated [[Cookbook:Parmesan Cheese|Parmesan cheese]] * 2 teaspoons [[Cookbook:Garlic Salt|garlic salt]] * 3/4 cup [[Cookbook:Mayonnaise|mayonnaise]] * 1 cup [[Cookbook:Milk|milk]]
==Procedure== # Mix together lemon juice, Parmesan cheese, garlic salt, and mayonnaise until smooth. Stir in milk, adjusting the amount or adding a little water, to make the dressing as thin or thick as you like. Cover and refrigerate 8 hours, or overnight.
==Notes, tips and variations== * Instead of garlic salt, crush a clove of [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]] and mix into the dressing with a little [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] (to taste).
<!-- don't use PAGENAME to order categorisation, because of leading apostrophe --> [[Category:Salad Dressing recipes|Out of Salad Dressing Salad Dressing]]

{{recipesummary|Soup recipes|4|1 hour|3}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Italy|Italian cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Vegetarian cuisine|Vegetarian Cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Soups|Soups]]
(Meatless) Tuscan Soup
==Ingredients==
* 1 small [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]], [[Cookbook:Chop|chopped]] * 1 small [[Cookbook:Carrot|carrot]], sliced * 1 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoon]] [[Cookbook:Olive oil|olive oil]] * 2 (14½-[[Cookbook:Ounce|ounce]]) cans [[Cookbook:Chicken|chicken]] [[Cookbook:Broth|broth]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] [[Cookbook:Water|water]] * ¼ [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoon]] [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * ¼ teaspoon [[Cookbook:Pepper|pepper]] * 1 (15- to 16-ounce) can [[Cookbook:Beans|kidney beans]] or [[Cookbook:Beans|great northern beans]], rinsed and drained * ⅔ cup uncooked [[Cookbook:Pasta|small spiral pasta]] * 3 cups thinly sliced fresh escarole or [[Cookbook:spinach|spinach]]
==Directions==
# In a 2-[[Cookbook:Quart|quart]] [[Cookbook:saucepan|saucepan]], [[Cookbook:Sauté|sauté]] onion and carrot in [[Cookbook:oil|oil]] until onion is tender. # Add broth, water, salt and pepper; bring to a [[Cookbook:Boil|boil]]. # Stir in beans and pasta; return to a boil. # Reduce heat; cover and [[Cookbook:simmer|simmer]] for 15 minutes or until pasta and vegetables are tender, stirring occasionally. # Add escarole or spinach and heat through.
==Tips, Notes, and Variations==
* Vegetarian: May substitute vegetable broth for chicken broth.
[[Category:Inexpensive recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Stew recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Italian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Camping recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Chicken recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetable recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Bean recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Spinach recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Carrot recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Lithuania|Cuisine of Lithuania]]
'''Kugelis''' (also ''bulvių plokštainis'', the lexically correct non-foreign name, literally "flat potato dish", or ''banda'', a dialecticism frequent especially in the [[w:Dzūkija|Dzūkija]] region) is a baked potato pudding that is a [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Lithuania|Lithuanian]] dish. Its main ingredients are potatoes, bacon, milk, onions, and eggs. It may be spiced with salt, black pepper, [[Cookbook:Bay Leaf|bay leaves]], and/or [[Cookbook:Marjoram|marjoram]]. It is usually eaten with sour cream and/or crumbled fried fat white bacon (''spirgai'').
==Ingredients== *5 lbs. [[Cookbook:Potato|potatoes]], peeled and [[Cookbook:Grater|grated]] (or ground with a [[Cookbook:Food Processor|food processor]]) *2 med. [[Cookbook:Onion|onions]], grated *1 lb. [[Cookbook:Bacon|bacon]], fried and crumbled (reserve about ¼ cup drippings) *1 [[Cookbook:Butter|stick of butter]], melted *6 [[Cookbook:Egg|eggs]] *1 lg. can [[Cookbook:Evaporated milk|evaporated milk]] *4 tsp. [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] *[[Cookbook:Pepper|pepper]] to taste (about a teaspoon)
==Preparation== # Peel and grate or grind (with a fine disc) potatoes and onions. Do not drain. # Fry and crumble bacon, add to potatoes and onions, along with ¼ cup drippings. Mix well. # Beat well 6 eggs, add evaporated milk, melted butter, salt and pepper, and mix well. # Add egg mixture to potato mixture, and mix together. # Pour into a well greased 9x13 cake pan (yes, it'll fit – barely). # Bake at 350°F (175°C) for 90 minutes.
To serve: slice into squares, and top with [[Cookbook:Sour Cream|sour cream]] ([[Cookbook:Applesauce|applesauce]] is also suitable).
Leftovers are best reheated sliced thin and [[Cookbook:Sautéing|sautéed]] in melted butter. Kugelis also reheats well in the [[Cookbook:Microwave Oven|microwave]] and freezes well.
[[Category:Lithuanian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Potato recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Vegetable recipes|5 pints
(1 pound of cabbage fills 1 pint jar)|6-8 days summer
12 days winter|3}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:European cuisines|Europe]] | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Germany|Cuisine of Germany]] | [[Cookbook:Midwestern cuisine|Midwestern cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Vegetarian cuisine|Vegetarian Cuisine]] | [[:Category:Fermented food recipes|Fermented Food Recipes]] ''If you like kraut, you will like this one.'' ''See also: [[Cookbook:Sauerkraut|sauerkraut]]'' ==Ingredients== * 5 [[Cookbook:Pound|pounds]] [[Cookbook:Cabbage|cabbage]] * 10 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoons]] [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] ==Directions== # Clean old leaves off cabbage heads. # Quarter heads and slice off cores. # Shred cabbage. # Put 5 pounds cabbage and salt in large pan and mix with hands. # Pack into crock with [[Cookbook:Potato Masher|potato masher]]. Pack gently. # When crock is nearly full, cover with cloth, plate, and weight. # Check daily and remove scum. # When kraut is sour enough, you can leave it in crock, and seal it with parafin wax; or kraut can be sealed in sterilized glass jars, adding enough brine to fill the jar. Process for 15 minutes below boiling point. ==Tips, Notes, and Variations== * It takes six to eight days to ferment in summer weather. * If it's cooler, it might take up to twelve days. ==Uses== * Is there anything better on a fat sausage or even just a hot dog? [[Category:Inexpensive recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:German recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Midwestern recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Fermented food recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetable recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Cabbage recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

revision.text:
{{Recipesummary| |Category=Meat recipes |Servings=Varies |Time=4-5 hours |Rating=3 |Energy='''Kebab (2 kg/4 lb.)''' 3000 Cal / 12 kJ
'''Pita (12"/120 g/4 oz.)''' 340 Cal / 1.4 kJ
'''Yogurt (2 dl/1 cup)''' 160 Cal / 0.7 kJ
|Image=[[Image:Döner kebab.jpg|250px|center|German döner kebab]] }} {{recipe|Doner kebab}} | [[Cookbook:Meat_Recipes|Meat recipes]] :''This article is about '''döner kebab'''. There is also another type of kebab called [[Cookbook:Shish kebab|shish kebab]].'' '''Döner [[Cookbook:Kebab|kebab]]''' ('''döner kebap''' in Turkish) literally means "rotating grilled meat" (any type of meat applies). First döner kebabs developed in Berlin by Turkish immigrants for the sake of fitting the food and taste Germans are used to. Authentic Turkish döner is made from lamb; regardless, mostly beef or a mix of beef and lamb is used in Europe. This article has the recipe for a complete European-style pita kebab. ==Meat== Although frozen kebab is available at convenient stores, they don't match fresh home-made kebab and may not be consistent with your taste and spicing.

'''Ingredients (four-pounder)'''
* ''2 [[Cookbook:Kg|kg]] (4½ [[Cookbook:Pound|lb.]])'' of [[Cookbook:Minced Meat|ground beef]] (or other [[Cookbook:Mincing|minced]] meat) * ''11-12 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tbsp.]]'' of [[Cookbook:chicken salt|chicken salt]] * ''6 tbsp.'' of [[Cookbook:black pepper|black pepper]] (amount depends on taste preference)
'''Two-pounder portion'''
* ''1 kg (21/4 lb.)'' of ground beef (or other minced meat) * ''5½ tbsp.'' of chicken salt * ''3 tbsp.'' of black pepper (amount depends on taste preference)
'''One-pounder portion'''
* ''500 [[Cookbook:Gram|g]] (1 lb.)'' of ground beef (or other minced meat) * ''2½-3 tbsp.'' of chicken salt * ''1½ tbsp.'' of black pepper (amount depends on taste preference)
''If you want, you can add other spices like [[Cookbook:Chile pepper|chili]], [[Cookbook:Cayenne pepper|cayenne]], [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]], [[Cookbook:Barbecue|BBQ]] sauces etc.''

'''Preparation'''
# [[Cookbook:Mix|Mix]] all the ingredients into a [[Cookbook:Farce|farce]]-like chunk. # Use a [[Cookbook:mixer|mixer]] or your hands to get air out of the chunk. # Optionally, you can make a hole with a knife to the chunk so that excess fat can drain out. # Wrap it ''tightly'' in [[Cookbook:Aluminum foil|aluminum foil]], and use more than two layers of foil (so it will not rupture). # Put it into the oven and set the temperature to 100 °[[Cookbook:C|C]] (210 °[[Cookbook:F|F]]). # Let it cook for 4 hours. #:''Note: 4 hours applies to any size. Let's say, if you want a 1 kg chunk (half of the original portion), you should NOT leave it for 2 hours, 4 hours apply for every size. The idea is that it gets cooked slowly.'' #When it is done, remove it from the oven, open the foil, and let it cool down. If you did everything correctly, you should be able to use a shredder or a knife to cut it in thin slices. ==Sauce== Kebab is never perfect without sauce or a dressing! Here are a couple of sauces that go with kebab:

'''Iskender-style dressing''' * ''2-3 [[Cookbook:Deciliter|dl]] (4/5-11/4 [[Cookbook:Cup|cups]])'' of unseasoned [[Cookbook:Yogurt|yogurt]] * ''1-3 cloves'' of [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]], chopped (amount depends on preference) * ''[[Cookbook:Pinch|pinch]]'' of [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * ''1 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|tsp.]]'' of [[Cookbook:Basil|basil]] * ''1-1½ tsp.'' of black and/or white [[Cookbook:Pepper|pepper]] (''Optional seasoning for taste'') * green-, lemon-, or red pepper * [[Cookbook:Chili Pepper|chile pepper]]/chili powder * [[Cookbook:Pepper|cayenne pepper]] * [[Cookbook:Tabasco|Tabasco sauce]]
'''Tomato sauce dressing''' * ''1 can'' of [[Cookbook:Tomato purée|tomato purée]] ''(70 g or 2½ [[Cookbook:Ounce|oz.]])'' * ''½-1 tsp. of salt * ''½-1½ tsp.'' of white pepper * ''½-1½ tsp.'' of black pepper * ''1 tsp.'' of basil * ''pinch'' of [[Cookbook:Oregano|oregano]] * [[Cookbook:Ketchup|ketchup]] (amount depends on preference) ==Pita== :''Main article: [[Cookbook:Pita|Pita]]'' You can either wrap the fillings into a reel or make it into a sandwich, with pita bread. You may want to make the pita slightly thinner if wrapping into a reel. If you want a relatively big kebab, then make the breads into a diameter of about 30 cm (12"). Pita Bread is more popular to Lebanese Bread ==Salad== A salad consisting of tomatoes, pickles, cucumbers, and Chinese cabbage with mayonnaise is probably the most common salad eaten with kebab in Europe. There are tons of variations, of course. If you want a healthy choice, make sure you balance the cereals class (pita), meat class (kebab), and vegetable class (salad) well! You can also add chile peppers, jalapeño, red onions and such for the salad to fit your taste! ==Serving== There are several ways and styles to serve döner. Here are a few: * '''Sandwich-style'''
Slice the pita bread from the middle, then lay the salad, kebab and dressings like you would do with a [[Cookbook:Hamburger|hamburger]]. * '''Reel-kebab'''
The roll wrap for a reel-kebab can be done using the [http://www.cuisinemag.com/main/videos/50-rollingBurritos.php same technique] as for burritos (using pita bread). * '''Kebab pizza'''
Simply prepare a pizza and top it with kebab. * '''Kebab with rice'''
Fill roughly over a half of a plate with kebab, and the rest with cooked rice. Dress with ketchup or any of the sauce recipes mentioned in this article. * '''Kebab with chips'''
Same as ''kebab with rice'' except that the rice has been replaced by chips (a.k.a French fries). ==Drink== Although it is obvious that the drink which one chooses is a matter of taste. Regardless, you should always remember in case you prepare really hot food and do not wish to burn your tongue, that milk, in fact, is an effective "anti-heat" agent, in case you think you may need one. ==External links== {{wikipedia|Döner kebab}} * [http://www.calorie-count.com/calories/item/74945.html Nutritional facts] [[Category:Beef recipes|Doner kebab]] [[Category:European recipes|Doner kebab]] [[Category:Lamb recipes|Doner kebab]] [[Category:Meat recipes|Doner kebab]] [[Category:Middle Eastern recipes|Doner kebab]] [[Category:Turkish recipes|Doner kebab]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of India|Cuisine of India]] | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Pakistan|Cuisine of Pakistan]]
[[Cookbook:Roti|Roti]], in general, refers to the Indian [[Cookbook:Flatbread|flatbread]] cooked on an iron griddle ([[Cookbook:Tava|tava]]). '''Makki di roti''' refers to a special roti in which, unlike the usual [[Cookbook:Flour#Wheat Flour|wheat flour]], [[Cookbook:Cornmeal|cornmeal]] is used. The name "makki di roti" literally means "roti made from cornmeal".
Makki roti is yellow in color when ready, and has much less adhesive strength, which makes it difficult to handle. Due to this, cooking makki roti is much more difficult than ordinary (wheat) roti.
Makki roti is cooked in [[w:Punjab region|Punjab]] in the winters and is a world famous delicacy from the north-Indian state, especially together with [[Cookbook:Saron Da Saag|saron da saag]] or sarson ka saag (cooked mustard leaves) and [[Cookbook:Lassi|lassi]].
==Ingredients==
*a cupped handful of [[Cookbook:Cornmeal|cornmeal]] for each serving *a spoonful of soft [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]] (best to have unsalted homemade butter) *a cupful of lukewarm [[Cookbook:Water|water]]
==Equipment==
*flat iron griddle ([[Cookbook:Tava|tahva]]), preheated *rolling pin (bailna) and flat board (chakla) *wide flat mixing tray ([[praant]]) *cooking fire on which the tahva will be heated
==Procedure==
# Place the measured quantity of cornmeal in a praant (a wide flat mixing tray). Heap up the cornmeal to form a hill. Make a well, and pour in a small quantity of the lukewarm water. # Start to mix the cornmeal and water into a dough. The dough should remain moist but not become sticky. Add water in small quantities to retain a moist feel. The final dough should not be sticky (sprinkle some extra cornmeal to help soak up excess moisture). # Add the soft butter (makhan) at the end and give it a final kneading. Leave the dough covered with a dry cloth for about 30 minutes before continuing. # Take a small hand-sized portion of the dough from the mixing tray and roll it into a small ball (ladu) between the two hands. Gradually start to flatten the ball between the palms of the two hands (wet the hands and fingers to help the dough to stretch). At the same time rotate the flattening dough so that the thinning of the roti is even. It may start to crack at the edges. Repair any cracks by pressing them at the rims. Wetting the fingers and the palm of the hand will help to spread and give the roti a circular shape. Aim for an evenly thinned roti. # When the roti is about the size of a small plate (or a little larger then a spread-out hand) place it on the preheated tahva. Leave the roti to take in the heat (it takes a while for roti to get cooked). Some areas of the roti will change in colour as the water evaporates. Soon after, the roti will be able to be moved on the tahva. With a dry cloth, press the areas of the roti that look moist. # It is a matter of judgement when the roti can be turned over and heated on the other side. When the roti have been well cooked they should not have any moist looking areas. Some areas will have burned slightly but this is normal. # The roti can be heated on open flames of the cooker. This process of placing roti on open flames is called rodhni. It takes time to get the thick roti to be well cooked. # The cooked roti is smeared with some butter. This is called "chopadni". The roti is then put into a serving dish. Traditionally, the roti is served as it gets prepared and is eaten fresh. On occasions when it has to be stored before serving it is placed in a dry tray called "chaba".
[[Category:Indian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Pakistani recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Flatbread recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Gluten-free recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

revision.text:
{{recipesummary|Dessert recipes|6|1 hour|2}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|American cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Southern cuisine|Southern cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Vegetarian cuisine|Vegetarian Cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Dessert|Dessert]]
==Ingredients==
* 2 [[Cookbook:Egg|egg]], well beaten * 4 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoons]] [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] * 1½ [[Cookbook:Cup|cups]] [[Cookbook:Brown Sugar|brown sugar]] * 3 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoons]] [[Cookbook:Baking Powder|baking powder]] * ½ teaspoon [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * 2 teaspoons [[Cookbook:Vanilla|vanilla]] * 2 cups [[Cookbook:Chop|chopped]] [[Cookbook:Apple|apples]] * 1 cup chopped [[Cookbook:Nut|nuts]]
==Directions==
# Preheat oven to [[Cookbook:Oven_temperatures|350°F]]. # Blend all ingredients, starting with eggs, ending with nuts. # Grease casserole dish, pour in casserole. # [[Cookbook:Bake|Bake]] for about 35 minutes. # Top with [[Cookbook:Whipped Cream|whipped cream]] or ice cream.
