revision.text:
{{recipesummary|Clam recipes|6|1 hour|3}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Southern cuisine|Southern cuisine (USA)]] | [[Cookbook:Seafood|Seafood recipes]]
==Ingredients==
* 1 [[Cookbook:Quart|quart]] [[Cookbook:Clam|clams]], canned or fresh * 1 quart rich [[Cookbook:Milk|milk]], [[Cookbook:Scald|scalded]] * ¼ [[Cookbook:Pound|pound]] salt [[Cookbook:Pork|pork]] * [[Cookbook:Salt|Salt]] and [[Cookbook:Pepper|pepper]] to taste * 1 quart [[Cookbook:Dice|diced]] [[Cookbook:Potato|potatoes]] * [[Cookbook:Butter|Butter]], if desired * 1 [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]], diced or [[Cookbook:Chopping|chopped]]
==Procedure==
# Remove black parts from clams, saving the liquor. # Cut pork in small pieces and [[Cookbook:Frying|fry]] until crisp and golden brown, then remove small pieces of pork from the fat. # Discard fat. # Add potatoes and onion, with just enough hot water to be seen through the potatoes. # Cook over low heat-just [[Cookbook:Simmering|simmer]]-until done. # When potatoes are done, add clams and pork and cook for 2 minutes after coming to a [[Cookbook:Boiling|boil]]. (Longer cooking will make the clams tough). # Remove chowder from heat and let stand for few minutes, then add hot milk, the clam liquor and seasoning to taste. (If seasonings are added before hot milk, chowder may curdle.) # May add butter to each bowl, for extra taste.
==Tips, Notes, and Variations==
* Chowder is usually better if left till the next day.
''This recipe comes from the [http://www.ncagr.com/markets/seafood/cbclam.htm North Carolina Seafood Cookbook], provided by the North Carolina Department of Agriculture and Consumer Services.''
[[Category:Southern recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Soup recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Clam recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Milk recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Onion recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Pork recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Potato recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[category:Gluten-free recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Turkey|Cuisine of Turkey]]
===Baklava===
==Ingredients== '''Syrup''' * 4 cups sugar * 2 cups water * 2 [[Cookbook:Cinnamon|cinnamon]] sticks – 3 inches long * ¾ cups [[Cookbook:Honey|honey]] * 1 tbsp lemon juice
'''Note:''' You can add more honey and reduce the amount of sugar.
'''Nut mixture''' * 1½ lbs [[Cookbook:Pistachio|pistachio]] nuts * 2 tsp cinnamon powder
'''Pastry''' * 1 lb [[Cookbook:Phyllo| Phyllo]] dough – thawed * 1¼ lbs unsalted butter – melted
'''Equipment''' * Tall large pot for making syrup * Candy thermometer * Baking pan about the size of the Phyllo sheets * 2-3 inch paintbrush for applying melted butter
==Directions== * Thaw the Phyllo inside its plastic package. Don’t open it until you’re ready to use it. If you’re in a hurry you can thaw it in its sealed plastic package in warm water.
* Chop the nuts with the powdered cinnamon in a food processor. '''You want a fine chop, not powder.'''
* Combine the sugar, honey, water, cinnamon sticks, and lemon juice in a large pot. Stir well and boil until the mixture reaches 220°F (100°C) on a candy thermometer (soft ball). Remove it from heat, skim the top, and let cool. Remove the cinnamon sticks. '''The lemon is an important ingredient in the syrup as it keeps it from crystallizing while cooling.'''
* Melt the butter in a saucepan while the syrup is boiling. You can clarify the butter but it’s not necessary.
* Preheat your oven to 350°F (180°C).
* Open the Phyllo and unfold it. Brush the inside of the baking pan with melted butter. While your assembling, cover the unused Phyllo with a damp towel. Make sure your butter is very liquid when you start. Put six (6) sheets of Phyllo in the pan, brushing each sheet with melted butter. Set aside another six (6) sheets which will be used for the top layers. After the first six sheets, sprinkle a handful of the nut mixture over the last sheet. Add another sheet and repeat the process until you get to the last six sheets. Place the last six sheets on top of the rest brushing each with butter. With a very sharp knife, cut the pastry into diamond shapes, all the way through. Sprinkle the top with water.
* Put the pastry into the preheated oven and bake for 1 hour or until the tops of the pastry are medium golden brown. When done, remove from the oven and ladle the cool syrup over the hot pastry.
* Let it sit for about 5-15 minutes, then drain off the excess syrup by tilting the pan as much as 45 degrees. Let it cool to near room temperature before eating.
[[Category:Dessert recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Pastry recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Turkish recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Egg recipes|6 to 8|1½ hours|1}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|American cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Vegetarian cuisine|Vegetarian Cuisine]]
==Ingredients==
* 1 (16-[[Cookbook:Ounce|ounce]]) package frozen [[Cookbook:Corn|corn]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] [[Cookbook:Milk|milk]] * 3 [[Cookbook:Egg|eggs]] * 2 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoons]] [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] * ⅛ [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoon]] [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * 1 tablespoon [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]], cut into 6 pieces
==Procedure==
# Preheat [[Cookbook:Oven|oven]] to [[Cookbook:Oven_temperatures|325°F]]. # Put frozen corn, milk, eggs, sugar, and salt into a [[Cookbook:Blender|blender]]. # Blend on medium until ingredients are mixed thoroughly. # Pour into medium sized baking dish coated with [[Cookbook:Cooking Spray|cooking spray]]. # Dot the top with butter pieces. # [[Cookbook:Baking|Bake]] for 70 minutes.
[[Category:Inexpensive recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:American recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Corn recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Egg recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Milk recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[category:Gluten-free recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Turkey recipes|20 - 30|Thawing: 3 to 5 days
Cooking: 45 minutes to an hour|3}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Southern cuisine|Southern cuisine (USA)]] | [[Cookbook:Poultry|Poultry recipes]] ==Ingredients== * 10 - 18 [[Cookbook:Pound|pound]] [[Cookbook:Turkey|turkey]] * 4 [[Cookbook:Gallon|gallons]] [[Cookbook:Vegetable oil|peanut oil]] ==Equipment== * Dedicated turkey frying set: cooking pot, propane burner, 550°F 16 inch thermometer with clip, turkey stand, and triangular handled handled hook * At least 10 pounds of propane * ABC fire extinguisher, at least 3 pounds ==Procedure== # Check fire extinguisher gauge. If not in safe/green zone, get a new one before proceeding to step #2. # If frozen, thaw turkey in a safe manner. Remove giblets bag from cavity. # Place turkey on its stand and set it in the dedicated turkey-frying pot. # Pour water into pot until turkey is covered completely and water level is two inches above the turkey. # Remove turkey from water, and mark level of water in pot. # Pour out water (discard). Dry the pot thoroughly and fill to line with peanut oil. # Heat oil in pot over propane burner to 400°F, by thermometer, in area at least TWENTY FEET FROM ANY BUILDING. # Slowly lower completely thawed, completely drained turkey (on its stand) into oil using the hook with an oven mitt. # The temperature of the oil will decrease to 350°F. Maintain that temperature closely! # Monitor temperature constantly until heat is turned off. Don't let it drop below 345°F or go over 355°F # [[Cookbook:Frying|Fry]] turkey 3 minutes per pound. Be careful not to over-cook it! If it floats, it's over-done! # Remove turkey using hook with oven mitt. # Check temperature using meat thermometer in deep part of meat, to be at least 160°F. # Turn off fire and allow to cool completely before even considering moving. # Rest turkey on tray, breasts down, 20-30 minutes before carving. ==Tips, Notes, and Variations== * '''If you are not willing to perform step #1 of directions, you are not safe to cook using this method.''' * '''If you cannot understand steps #3 through #6, do not use this method.''' * The safest way to thaw a turkey is in the refrigerator. Any other way invites Salmonella. [[Category:Inexpensive recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Southern recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Fried recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Turkey recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[category:Gluten-free recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

revision.comment: Enumarate recipe, preparatory to adding variations.
revision.text:
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United Kingdom|Cuisine of the UK]]
'''Figgie 'obbin1''', also '''Figgie Hobbin''', is an old Cornish recipe.
==Ingredients==
* 2 parts [[Cookbook:Flour|self raising flour]] (or plain flour & baking powder) * 2 parts figs ([[Cookbook:Raisin|raisins]]) * 1 part 50/50 mix of [[Cookbook:Suet|suet]] & [[Cookbook:Fat|fat]], i.e. half the weight of the flour in total. * [[Cookbook:Water|water]] or [[Cookbook:Milk|milk]]
==Procedure==
# Rub the [[Cookbook:Suet|suet]], fat and flour together. # Mix in the figs, and add enough water or milk to make a stiff dough. # Roll out to about an inch thick. Press gently into a prepared shallow baking tin or dish. # Bake in a [[Cookbook:Oven temperatures|hot oven]] for about 35-45 minutes. (Good served hot with [[Cookbook:Clotted Cream|clotted cream]], burnt cream or [[Cookbook:Custard|baked custard]], or cold with tea or coffee or cocoa.)
== Notes, tips and variations == * Currants and/or sultanas may be mixed with, or substituted for, raisins. * Vegetable suet and vegetable lard, can be used instead of [[Cookbook:Beef|beef]] or [[Cookbook:Mutton|mutton]] [[Cookbook:Suet|suet]] and [[Cookbook:Dripping|dripping]], although this is less traditional.
== Notes == * from Perranporth W.I. in Cornish Recipes, Ancient & Modern, 22nd Edition, The Cornwall Federation of Women's Institutes 1965. * First collected & published by Edith Martin, Tregavethan, Truro, 1929, for The Cornwall F. of W. I.
[[Category:Cornish recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Cake recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Raisin recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}}
==Ingredients== # 1 cup (240ml) grated [[Cookbook:Cheddar Cheese|cheddar cheese]] # 2 Tsp [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] # ¼ tsp [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] # 1 lb (500g) mild or hot [[Cookbook:Sausage|sausage]] # ¾ cup (180ml) fine cracker crumbs # ½ [[Cookbook:Vegetable oil|vegetable oil]]
==Procedure== # Combine the cheese, flour, sausage and cracker crumbs. # Using your hands mix well and shape into 1" (2.5cm) balls. # Heat the oil in a skillet, when it is hot, put the balls in the pan without crowding them. Cook over medium-high heat, turning so all sides until golden brown. Drain on paper towels.
===Alternate cooking method=== # Preheat oven to 375°F (230°C). # Mix all ingredients together thoroughly # Form into 1-inch (2.5cm) balls, and place on ungreased cookie sheets. # Bake for 15 minutes or until golden brown.
Sausage cheese balls can be frozen uncooked. Thaw and cook according to directions.
--Jack Cochran
[[Category:Cheese recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Sausage recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Recipes_with_metric_units|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}}
Serves 8.
==Ingredients== *426 g [[Cookbook:Ricotta Cheese|ricotta cheese]] *2 [[Cookbook:Egg|eggs]] *9 g dried [[Cookbook:Mixed Herbs|Italian seasoning]] *340 g shredded [[Cookbook:Mozzarella Cheese|mozzarella cheese]] *100 g freshly grated [[Cookbook:Parmesan Cheese|Parmesan cheese]] *284 g frozen chopped [[Cookbook:Spinach|spinach]], thawed and squeezed dry *[[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] and [[Cookbook:Pepper|pepper]] to taste *908 g frozen [[Cookbook:Dough|white bread dough]], thawed
==Procedure== # Preheat the oven to 400°F (200°C). # In a large bowl, mix together the ricotta cheese, eggs, Italian seasoning, mozzarella cheese, Parmesan cheese and spinach. Set aside. # Divide the bread dough into 8 pieces and roll each piece out to about an 8 inch circle. Spoon about ½ cup of the ricotta filling onto each circle, fold over and seal the edges. Place onto a greased cookie sheet. # Bake for 30 minutes in the preheated oven, or until nicely browned on the tops and bottoms.
[[Category:Vegetarian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Cheese recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Spinach recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Omelet Recipes|Omelet Recipes]]
Serves 8-10.
==Ingredients== *½ (1 pound) loaf [[Cookbook:Bread|white bread]], cut into cubes *680 g [[Cookbook:Cheddar Cheese|cheddar cheese]], shredded *135 g cubed cooked [[Cookbook:Ham|ham]] *8 [[Cookbook:Egg|eggs]] *475 ml [[Cookbook:Milk|milk]] *1 g [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] *1 dash [[Cookbook:Hot Pepper Sauce|hot pepper sauce]], or to taste *25 g chopped [[Cookbook:Green onion|green onion]]
==Procedure== # Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C). Lightly grease a 9x13 inch (23cm x 33cm) baking pan. # Place half of the bread cubes on bottom of baking pan. Sprinkle with half of the ham and then half of the cheese; repeat. # In a large bowl, beat together eggs, milk, salt, hot sauce and green onions. Pour egg mixture into pan. # Place pan on top of a baking sheet with a rim and place in oven. Pour water into baking sheet and bake for 60 minutes, or until eggs have set.
[[Category:Omelette recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Recipes_with_metric_units|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cake|Cake]]
Serves 12.
==Ingredients== *3 [[Cookbook:Egg|eggs]] *400 g [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] *355 ml [[Cookbook:Vegetable oil|vegetable oil]] *10 ml [[Cookbook:Vanilla|vanilla extract]] *375 g [[Cookbook:All-purpose flour|all-purpose flour]] *6 g [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] *5 g [[Cookbook:Baking Soda|baking soda]]
===Topping=== *115 g [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]] or [[Cookbook:Margarine|margarine]] *60 ml [[Cookbook:Milk|milk]] *220 g packed [[Cookbook:Brown Sugar|brown sugar]] *Pinch salt
==Procedure== # In a mixing bowl, beat eggs until foamy; gradually add sugar. # Blend in oil and vanilla. # Combine flour, salt and baking soda; add to egg mixture. # Pour into a greased 10-in. tube pan; bake at 350°F (175°C) for 1 hour and 15 minutes or until the cake tests done. # Cool in pan on a wire rack for 10 minutes. Remove cake to a serving platter.
===Topping=== # Combine all ingredients in a saucepan; boil 3 minutes, stirring constantly. # Slowly pour over warm cake (some topping will run down onto the serving plate.)
[[Category:Cake recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Dessert|Dessert]]
==Ingredients== *375 g [[Cookbook:All-purpose flour|all-purpose flour]] *3 g [[Cookbook:Cream of Tartar|cream of tartar]] *2 g [[Cookbook:Baking Soda|baking soda]] *0.8 g ground [[Cookbook:Nutmeg|nutmeg]] *205 g [[Cookbook:Shortening|shortening]], melted and cooled slightly *440 g packed [[Cookbook:Brown Sugar|brown sugar]] *2 [[Cookbook:Egg|eggs]] *5 ml [[Cookbook:Vanilla|vanilla extract]]
==Procedure== #Combine flour, cream of tartar, baking soda and nutmeg in a bowl and set aside. #Beat together in a large bowl the melted shortening and the brown sugar. Beat in the eggs, then the vanilla extract. Gradually blend in the dry ingredients. #Shape dough into a log measuring 1½ inches in diameter. Wrap log in waxed paper or foil and chill for 4 hours or overnight. #Preheat oven to 375°F (180°C). Lightly grease 2 baking sheets. # Slice log into slices 1/4 inch thick. Place slices 1 inch apart on the baking sheets. Bake for 8-10 minutes until lightly colored. Cool on wire racks.
[[Category:Confection recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{Recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cake|Cake]]
This cake can be frozen for up to 6 months.
==Ingredients== *115 g [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]] *120 ml [[Cookbook:Vegetable oil|vegetable oil]] *350 g [[Cookbook:Sugar|white sugar]] *2 [[Cookbook:Egg|eggs]] *120 ml [[Cookbook:Sour Milk|sour milk]] or [[Cookbook:Buttermilk|buttermilk]] *5 ml [[Cookbook:Vanilla|vanilla extract]] *250 g sifted [[Cookbook:All-purpose flour|all-purpose flour]] *5 g [[Cookbook:Baking Soda|baking soda]] *1 g ground [[Cookbook:Cinnamon|cinnamon]] *1 g ground [[Cookbook:Clove|cloves]] *3 g [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] *20 g unsweetened [[Cookbook:Cocoa|cocoa powder]] *280 g grated [[Cookbook:Zucchini|zucchini]] *20 g ground [[Cookbook:Walnut|walnuts]] *40 g semisweet [[Cookbook:Chocolate|chocolate chips]]
==Procedure== #[[Cookbook:Creaming|Cream]] together butter or margarine, vegetable oil and sugar. #Add eggs, sour milk, and vanilla. Blend well. #In a separate bowl, sift dry ingredients together. #Blend dry ingredients into the butter mixture. #Add grated zucchini, and mix well. #Spread in a greased floured 9 x 13 inch pan. Sprinkle walnuts and chocolate chips on top. #Bake in a preheated 325°F (165°C) oven for 45 minutes.
==Notes, tips and variations== * To make imitation sour milk, mix ½ cup milk with 2 teaspoons lemon juice and let stand 10 minutes.
[[Category:Cake recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Chocolate recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Zucchini recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Salad Dressing recipes|2½ ounces|30 seconds|1}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|American cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Vegetarian cuisine|Vegetarian Cuisine]]
=Thousand Island Dressing= ''This quick bootleg version has been used by fast food restaurant and hamburger joint workers, from time immemorial, to have a salad when no other dressing was available.''
==Ingredients==
* 1 [[Cookbook:Ounce|ounce]] [[Cookbook:Ketchup|ketchup]] * 1 ounce [[Cookbook:Mayonnaise|mayonnaise]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoon]] [[Cookbook:Pickle|pickle]] relish
==Directions==
# Mix ingredients thoroughly and spread on salad.
[[Category:Inexpensive recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:American recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Salad Dressing recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United Kingdom|Cuisine of the UK]]
'''Stargazy Pie''' – a rich fish pie from Cornwall in the [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United Kingdom|United Kingdom]].
== Ingredients == (Dependant on size of pie-dish) *As many fresh [[Cookbook:Fish|Herrings, Pilchards or Mackerel]] to fill your dish *Sufficient [[Cookbook:Pastry|pastry]] to cover your dish *Fresh chopped [[Cookbook:Parsley|parsley]] *[[Cookbook:Salt|Salt]] & [[Cookbook:Pepper|pepper]] *Up to 6 [[Cookbook:Egg|eggs]], or, ½ pint (300 mL) of [[Cookbook:Cream|cream]], or top-of-the-milk *Fine [[Cookbook:Bread Crumb|breadcrumbs]] *Fat [[Cookbook:Bacon|bacon rashers]], (green or smoked to your preference) *2 Tbs. [[Cookbook:Tarragon|Tarragon]] [[Cookbook:Vinegar|vinegar]] *[[Cookbook:Butter|Butter]]
== Procedure == #Scale, clean & bone the fish, retaining heads. #Season inside each with salt, pepper & parsley, roll neatly. #Butter dish, & sprinkle a thick layer of breadcrumbs on. #Lay in some of the fish, then alternate breadcrumbs & fish until dish is full. #Cover with rashers. #Beat eggs with vinegar, pour into pie, or use cream. #Cover with pastry. #Arrange heads on pastry, so as they are looking up (to the stars). #Bake in a hot oven. #Serve with a sprig of parsley in mouth of each fish.
== Notes == * ''from'' St. Agnes W.I. ''in'' Cornish Recipes, Ancient & Modern, 22nd Edition, The Cornwall Federation of Women's Institutes 1965. * ''First collected & published by'' Edith Martin, Tregavethan, Truro, 1929, ''for'' The Cornwall F.of W. I.
[[Category:Cornish recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Fish recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Recipes_with_metric_units|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Vegan cuisine|Vegan cuisine]]
==Ingredients== * One block of [[Cookbook:Tofu|firm tofu]] * Mixture of preferred vegetables (suggested combination: [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]], [[Cookbook:Bell Pepper|green pepper]], [[Cookbook:Tomato|tomato]]) * Half of an [[Cookbook:Apple|apple]] * [[Cookbook:Soy Sauce|Soy Sauce]] * [[Cookbook:Olive Oil|Olive Oil]] * Preferred seasonings (suggested seasonings: [[Cookbook:Pepper|pepper]], [[Cookbook:Hot Pepper Sauce|hot sauce]], [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]])
==Instructions== # Slice tofu into manageable slices. (no more than ¼ inch deep) # Slice all vegetable and apple # Simmer tofu and vegetable in a light mixture of olive oil and soy sauce on medium high heat # Cook until tofu is golden brown and vegetables have thoroughly soaked up juices # Serve with a side of [[Cookbook:Rice|rice]] or [[Cookbook:Couscous|couscous]] and season
[[Category:Vegan recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Tofu recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetable recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Stir fry recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

revision.comment: Revert to revision 847260 dated 2007-04-28 21:20:50 by Xania using [[:en:Wikipedia:Tools/Navigation_popups|popups]]
revision.text:
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Dessert|Dessert]] | [[Cookbook:Cake|Cake]]
[[Image:Fairy_cakes_close_up_on_tray.jpg|thumb|right|The finished product (using chocolate).]]
'''Cupcakes''' are small cakes placed in cake cases. This recipe produces 15 cupcakes.
==Ingredients== *100g self raising flour *100g caster sugar *100g margarine *2 eggs *15 cake cases ''Optional:'' *Replace two tablespoons of flour with drinking chocolate or cocoa
==Method== [[Image:Fairy cakes in oven stage 1.jpg|thumb|right|Cupcakes cooking in oven.]] [[Image:Fairy cakes in oven.jpg|thumb|right|Cupcakes cooking in oven.]] [[Image:Fairy cakes in oven stage 2.jpg|thumb|right|Cupcakes cooking in oven, a bit later on.]] # Preheat an oven to gas mark 5. # Place 15 cake cases on a baking tray. # Place flour, sugar, margarine and eggs into a mixing bowl. # Use a electric mixer (optional) to mix the ingredients together for 1 minute. # Use a spoon and knife to place the mixture into the cake cases. # Bake for 15 to 20 minutes. # When completed remove from oven and leave to cool, optionally decorate with [[Cookbook:Butter icing|butter icing]].
[[Category:Cake recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Recipes_with_metric_units|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Zucchini_Pie|Zucchini Pie]]
{{recipesummary| | Category = Vegetarian recipes | Servings = 6 to 8 | Time = 90 minutes | Rating = 3 <!--| Energy = --> | Image = [[Image:ZucchiniPie250px.jpg|250px]] }}
'''Zucchini pie''' is a savory Italian supper [[Cookbook:Pie|pie]]. Fresh zucchini squash, mozzarella cheese, and herbs give this pie its distinctive taste.
==Ingredients== ===Pie crust=== *1⅓ [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] *½ [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoon]] [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] *½ cup [[Cookbook:Shortening|shortening]] *3 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoons]] [[Cookbook:Water|water]]
===Pie filling=== *4 cups thinly sliced [[Cookbook:Zucchini|zucchini]] (about 3 small squash) *½ cup chopped [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]] (about 1/3 of a large onion) *¼ cup [[Cookbook:Parsley|parsley]] (or 2 tablespoons parsley flakes) *½ teaspoon [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] *½ teaspoon [[Cookbook:Basil|basil]] *¼ teaspoon [[Cookbook:Black pepper|black pepper]] *¼ teaspoon [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]] powder *⅛ teaspoon [[Cookbook:Oregano|oregano]] *2 beaten [[Cookbook:Egg|egg]]s *8 ounces (2 cups) shredded [[Cookbook:Mozzarella|mozzarella]] *1½ ounces [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]] for frying
==Procedure== #Preheat oven to [[Cookbook:Oven temperatures|375° F/191° C/Gas mark 5]]. #Sift flour and salt into a bowl. Cut in shortening until mixture forms coarse particles. Add water, one tablespoon at a time, and mixing to make a pliable dough. #Roll out the pie crust to a circle and then fit it into a pie plate; bake for 15 minutes. #Melt the butter in a [[Cookbook:Dutch oven|Dutch oven]]. Add the zucchini and onion. Cook over medium heat, stirring occasionally, until the onions are translucent (about 10 minutes). #Stir the seasonings into the vegetable mixture and set aside. #Combine 2 beaten eggs and grated cheese in a bowl, then stir into the vegetable and spice mix. #Pour the filling into the pie crust and bake for 20 minutes, or until center is set. #Serve hot.
Makes 6 to 8 servings.
[[Category:Vegetarian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Zucchini recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Pie recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Featured recipe candidate|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Radish_Pie|Radish Pie]]
{{recipesummary| | Category = Vegetarian recipes | Servings = 6 to 8 | Time = 2 hours +cooling time | Rating = 3 <!--| Energy = --> | Image = [[Image:2RadishPie250px.jpg|250px]] }}
'''Radish pie''' is a savory [[Cookbook:Pie|pie]] suitable for a vegetarian diet. Radishes, fresh goat cheese, and walnuts give the pie a unique taste, which is most flavorful when served cold.
==Ingredients== *1 to 2 bunches red [[Cookbook:Radish|radish]]es *1 to 2 tablespoons [[Cookbook:Olive oil|olive oil]] *1/4 cup (60 ml) [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]], divided *8 ounces (227g) phyllo dough *1 red [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]], chopped *2 tablespoons dry sherry [[Cookbook:Wine|wine]] *2 large [[Cookbook:egg|egg]]s, plus 1 yolk *3/4 cup (177ml) heavy [[Cookbook:cream|cream]] *4 ounces (113g) fresh goat [[Cookbook:cheese|cheese]] *3/4 cup (177ml) broken [[Cookbook:walnuts|walnut]] pieces *1/3 cup (80ml) fresh Italian [[Cookbook:parsley|parsley]]
==Procedure== #Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C). #Wash the radishes well, remove and discard tops. Put radishes into a small baking dish and drizzle with olive oil. Bake for about an hour. Let them cool and then cut into small dice. (See tip #2 below.) #Use half the butter to grease a pie pan, and then line it with pieces of phyllo dough, covering the pan evenly. Tuck under any stray bits to make a nice edge. #Heat the remaining butter in a large pan and sauté the onion in it for about five minutes. Add the wine and diced radishes, then cook for another minute. Remove from heat and pour into the pastry shell. #In a bowl, mix together the eggs and cream, and then pour over the vegetables in the pie crust. Crumble the goat cheese over the cream. #Bake the pie in a preheated oven at aforementioned temperature for 20 minutes. #Add the walnuts and cook for another 15 - 20 minutes. #Remove the pie from the oven and top it with the chopped parsley. #Let cool completely before serving.
Makes 6 to 8 servings.
[[Image:RadishPieSlice250px.jpg|250px]]
==Notes, tips, and variations== *Tip 1: Use fewer radishes for milder taste, or add more according to your own taste. *Tip 2: The radishes can be baked the day before and then refrigerated until you make the pie. *Tip 3: For a professional look, garnish each serving with a sprig of parsley.
{{DEFAULTSORT:{{PAGENAME}}}} [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Radish recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Pie recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Featured recipes]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Radish_Tart|Radish Tart]]
{{recipesummary| | Category = Vegetarian recipes | Servings = 6 to 8 | Time = 60 minutes | Rating = 2 <!--| Energy = --> | Image = [[Image:RadishPie250px.jpg|250px]] }}
'''Radish Tart''' is a tasty and colorful [[Cookbook:Pie|pie]], best served hot from the oven. Fresh red radishes and yellow cheese give this pretty pie any interesting look and taste.
==Ingredients== *1 cup all purpose flour *1/2 cup cold [[Cookbook:butter|butter]] *1 cup (4 ounces) shredded Edam, Gouda, or Gruyere [[Cookbook:cheese|cheese]], divided ([[Cookbook:Cheddar|Cheddar]] is also acceptable) *1 cup heavy [[Cookbook:cream|cream]], divided *4 [[Cookbook:egg|egg]] yolks *1/4 teaspoon [[Cookbook:salt|salt]] *1/2 to 1 small bunch of red [[Cookbook:radish|radish]]es
==Procedure== #Preheat oven to 425°. #Sift and measure flour into a bowl. Cut in the butter until the particles are coarse. Stir in 1/2 of the cheese. Pour in 1/4 cup of the cream; toss the mixture with a fork until all parts are moistened. #Turn the dough into a 9-inch round pie pan. With floured fingers, press the mixture into the bottom and sides of the pan, then prick the shell with a floured fork. #Bake the pie shell for 10 to 12 minutes. (The sides will slip down a little during baking.) Cool on a wire rack. #Lower the oven temperature to 325º. #Sprinkle the remaining cheese evenly over the bottom of the cooled pie shell. Beat together the egg yolks, the 3/4 cup cream, and the salt. Pour the egg mixture over the cheese. Place the radish slices evenly over the top of the pie. #Bake for 20 to 25 minutes, or until set. #Remove the pie from the oven, cut it into wedges, and serve it hot.
Makes 6 to 8 servings.
==Tips== *If you really like the taste of radishes, use 1/2 cup or more. For a milder pie, use 1/4 cup. *The cheese crust has a pleasant crisp texture when eaten fresh out of the oven. Leftovers can be refrigerated and reheated later, but the texture will not be as good. *A really sharp knife will aid in cutting the wedges without displacing the radishes.
[[Category:Vegetarian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Radish recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Pie recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{DEFAULTSORT:{{PAGENAME}}}} {{recipesummary|Manx recipes|6 people|1 hour|3}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine_of_Isle_of_Man|Cuisine of Isle of Man]] | [[Cookbook:Fish|Fish]]
Fish dishes are popular in Isle of Man, as they are in most islands and coastal regions. Kippers are especially popular in Mann and this recipe is a tasty alternative to many standard meals.
== Ingredients== * 450g kippers * 450g sliced, smoked salmon * 500-600ml cream * 20g chopped chives * 1/4 to 1/2 cucumber, thinly sliced * 1/2 tomato, sliced, de-seeded and skinned
==Procedure==
# Boil the kippers in a pot of salty water # Add 4 rings of smoked salmon to a greaseproof tray in foil (slices can go over the edge) # Wait for the kippers to finish boiling then refresh them with cold water for 3-5 minutes. Fillet them then skin and place them in a blender. # Add cream gradually and blend. # Add chives to the mix. # Add the mixture to the rings and remove any air pockets by shaking. # Fold over the salmon slices and turn over the rings. Cover with clingfilm and refrigerate. # Add about 6 slices of the cucumber to the centre of each plate. # Remove food from refrigerator, remove from oven tray and put them upside down on top of the cucumber slices # Add more strips of cucumber and tomato to the top of the food. Serve!
[[Category:Manx recipes]] [[Category:Salmon recipes]] [[Category:Smoked recipes]] [[Category:Recipes with metric units]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Pasta|Pasta]]
==Ingredients== * 1 lb [[Cookbook:Pasta|dried pasta]] * 6oz [[Cookbook:Pancetta|pancetta]] (small dice) * 1 head of [[Cookbook:Cauliflower|cauliflower]] (cut into florets) * 4 cloves of [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]], sliced thin * 1 14oz can of diced [[Cookbook:Tomato|tomatoes]], drained * [[Cookbook:Chili Pepper|red pepper flakes]] * 3 [[Cookbook:Egg yolk|egg yolks]] * ½ cup of grated [[Cookbook:Pecorino Romano Cheese|Pecorino Romano cheese]] * chopped [[Cookbook:Parsley|parsley]], additional grated Pecorino Romano cheese * [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] and [[Cookbook:Pepper|pepper]] to taste
==Procedure== # Bring 4 quarts of water to a boil. Add Cauliflower Florets to boiling water and cook for 4 minutes, and transfer Cauliflower to an ice bath (do not discard cooking water). # Heat 2 tablespoons of Extra Virgin Olive Oil over medium high heat in a large pan. Once hot, add the diced pancetta, and begin to brown. # Once pancetta begins to brown, add pasta to boiling water. # After pancetta is almost completely browned, reduce heat to medium and add the garlic and red pepper flakes. [[Cookbook:Sautéing|Sauté]] until garlic begins to turn golden, and then add the cauliflower and the drained diced tomatoes and toss to heat through. Add ¼ cup of the pasta water, as well as salt and pepper. # While pasta is finishing cooking, beat the egg yolks, grated cheese, salt and pepper until smooth. # When the pasta is about 2 minutes away from being [[Cookbook:Al dente|al dente]], drain. # Lower the heat on the sauce to low and add the pasta to the sauce and toss to combine. Once combined, pour on the egg yolk mixture and '''quickly''' toss the pasta to coat it with the mixture (the egg yolks should coat the pasta, and not scramble). # Once heated through, remove to serving bowl or individual plates and garnish with the chopped parsley and additional cheese.
[[Category:Pasta recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Bacon recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Dessert|Desserts]]
==Ingredients== *2 Pillsbury pie crusts *4 McIntosh [[Cookbook:Apple|apples]] *1 teaspoon [[Cookbook:Cinnamon|cinnamon]] *2 cups [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] *¼ cup [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] *2 cups [[Cookbook:Water|water]] *3½ tablespoons [[Cookbook:Cornstarch|cornstarch]] *[[Cookbook:Lemon|lemon]] juice (of ½ lemon) *½ teaspoon [[Cookbook:Nutmeg|nutmeg]]
==Procedure== #Core, peel, and slice the apples into ¼ or ⅛-inch segments. #Add lemon juice to the apple segments. #Transfer excess juices to the pie pan. #In a separate boiling pot, set the sugar and water to boil to make a simple syrup. #In a separate bowl, mix the cinnamon, nutmeg, flour, and cornstarch. #When the syrup is done boiling, gradually bring all of the ingredients together. #Arrange one of the pie crusts on top of the pie pan. #Add the apple filling into the pie pan. #Cover the filling with the other pie crust and make three slits on top. #Bake in the oven at 350°[[Cookbook:Fahrenheit|F]] for 60 minutes or until golden brown. #Take out the pie and set to cool. #Serve warm with [[Cookbook:Ice Cream|ice cream]] or [[Cookbook:Frozen Custard|frozen custard]].
[[Category:Dessert recipes|Apple Pie II]] [[Category:Pie recipes|Apple Pie II]] [[Category:Apple recipes|Apple Pie II]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Dessert|Desserts]]
An '''apple pie''' is a fruit [[Cookbook:Pie|pie]] (or [[Cookbook:Tart|tart]]) in which the principal filling ingredient is [[Cookbook:Apple|apple]]s. Pastry is generally used top-and-bottom, making a double-crust pie, the upper crust of which may be a pastry lattice woven of strips; exceptions are '''deep-dish apple pie''' with a top crust only, and open-face [[Cookbook:Tarte Tatin|Tarte Tatin]].
Here are two variations on apple pie: #[[Cookbook:Apple Pie I|Apple Pie I]]: an apple pie recipe which suggests a variety of apples. #[[Cookbook:Apple Pie II|Apple Pie II]]: a recipe that uses the first one as a model; uses McIntosh apples exclusively.
[[Category:Dessert recipes|Apple Pie]] [[Category:Pie recipes|Apple Pie]] [[Category:Apple recipes|Apple Pie]]

{{recipesummary|Pea recipes|6 to 8|½ hour|1}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:North American cuisines|North America]] | [[Cookbook:Vegetarian cuisine|Vegetarian Cuisine]]
==Ingredients==
* 1 (16-[[Cookbook:Ounce|ounce]]) package frozen [[Cookbook:Pea|green peas]] * 2 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoons]] [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]] * 1 (4-ounce) can sliced [[Cookbook:Mushroom|mushrooms]], reserve juice * 1 tablespoon [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] * 1 (8-ounce) can [[Cookbook:Water Chestnut|water chestnuts]] * [[Cookbook:Cooking Spray|cooking spray]] * ¼ [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] [[Cookbook:Bread Crumb|bread crumbs]] (optional)
==Procedure==
# Preheat [[Cookbook:Oven|oven]] to [[Cookbook:Oven_temperatures|350°F]]. # Cook peas according to package instructions, drain. # In a separate pan, melt butter. # Add mushroom juice and flour to melted butter. # Stir until thickened. # Add mixture to peas, then add water chestnuts and mushrooms. # Place in medium baking pan coated with cooking spray. # Sprinkle breadcrumbs on top if desired. # [[Cookbook:Baking|Bake]] for 12 to 15 minutes, or until heated through.
[[Category:Inexpensive recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:American recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Casserole recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Mushroom recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Pea recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

revision.comment: /* Ingredients */ on second thought, I think pork broth should really be recommended because it brings out the flavor of the pork
revision.text:
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Meat Recipes|Meat Recipes]]
==Ingredients== *2 Pillsbury pie crusts *⅓ cup [[Cookbook:Margarine|margarine]] (or [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]]) *⅓ cup [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]], chopped *⅓ cup all-purpose [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] *½ teaspoon [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] *¼ teaspoon [[Cookbook:Pepper|pepper]] *1½ cups pork [[Cookbook:Broth|broth]] *⅔ cup [[Cookbook:Milk|milk]] *3 cups [[Cookbook:Pork|pork]], cooked *1 cup frozen [[Cookbook:Corn|corn]], thawed *1 cup frozen [[Cookbook:Pea|pea]]s, thawed
==Procedure== #Heat oven to 425°[[Cookbook:Fahrenheit|F]]. #Prepare pie crusts as directed on package for two-crust pie using 9-inch pie pan. #In a medium saucepan, melt margarine over medium heat. #Add onion; cook 2 minutes or until tender. #Stir in flour, salt, and pepper until well-blended. #Gradually stir in broth and milk; cook, stirring constantly, until bubbly and thickened. #Add pork, corn, and peas; remove from heat. #Spoon pork mixture into crust-lined pan. #Top with second crust and flute; cut three slits on top. #Bake for 30 to 40 minutes or until crust is golden-brown. #Let stand 5 minutes before serving.
[[Category:American recipes|Pork Pot Pie]] [[Category:Pork recipes|Pork Pot Pie]] [[Category:Pot Pie recipes|Pork Pot Pie]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Dessert|Desserts]]
==Ingredients== *2 Pillsbury pie crusts *4 fresh Bartlett [[Cookbook:Pear|pear]]s *½ teaspoon [[Cookbook:Cinnamon|cinnamon]] *2 cups [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] *¼ cup [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] *1½ cups [[Cookbook:Water|water]] *½ cup [[Cookbook:Brown Sugar|brown sugar]] *2½ tablespoons [[Cookbook:Cornstarch|cornstarch]] *[[Cookbook:Lemon|lemon]] juice (of ½ lemon) *¼ teaspoon [[Cookbook:Nutmeg|nutmeg]]
==Procedure== #Core, peel, and slice the pears into ¼ or ⅛-inch segments. #Add the lemon juice to the pear segments. #Transfer excess juices to the pie pan. #In a separate boiling pot, set the water and white and brown sugar to boil to make a simple syrup. #In a separate bowl, mix the cinnamon, nutmeg, flour, and cornstarch. #When the syrup is done boiling, bring all of the ingredients together. #Arrange one of the pie crusts on top of the pie pan. #Add the pear filling into the pie pan. #Cover the filling with the other pie crust and make three slits on top. #Bake in the oven at 350°[[Cookbook:Fahrenheit|F]] for 60 minutes or until golden brown. #Take out the pie and set to cool. #Serve warm with [[Cookbook:Ice Cream|ice cream]] or [[Cookbook:Frozen Custard|frozen custard]].
[[Category:Dessert recipes|Pear Pie]] [[Category:Pie recipes|Pear Pie]] [[Category:Pear recipes|Pear Pie]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United Kingdom|Cuisine of the UK]]
== Ingredients == *4 or more [[Cookbook:Fish|Mackerel]] *2 chopped fresh [[Cookbook:Bay Leaf|bay leaves]] *6 [[Cookbook:Clove|cloves]] *blade of [[Cookbook:Mace|mace]] *sprig of fresh [[Cookbook:Thyme|thyme]] *1 chopped [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]] *10 [[Cookbook:Pepper|peppercorns]] *[[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] *[[Cookbook:Malt vinegar|malt vinegar]] ''(increase all as needed for amount of fish)''
== Procedure == # Clean & scale fish, place in dish large enough for fish & vinegar. # Mix other ingredients, except vinegar, with salt to taste, & cast over fish. # Pour over sufficient vinegar to cover well. # Place in moderate oven for 40 to 50 minutes. # Lift fish carefully onto serving dish, strain liquor over. # Let cool & serve.
==Notes== * ''from'' Boscastle W.I. ''in'' Cornish Recipes, Ancient & Modern, 22nd Edition, The Cornwall Federation of Women's Institutes 1965. * ''First collected & published by'' Edith Martin, Tregavethan, Truro, 1929, ''for'' The Cornwall F.of W. I.
[[Category:Cornish recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Fish recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of India|Cuisine of India]] {{recipesummary|Indian recipes|6-10|2 hours|4}} '''Undhiu''' is a mixture of a variety of different vegetables. == Ingredients ==
* small [[Cookbook:Eggplant|eggplants]] * [[Cookbook:Papdi|Papdi]] (small chapradowrakai) * [[Cookbook:Yam|yam]] * [[Cookbook:Sweet Potato|Ghenasu]] (sweet potato) * [[Cookbook:Fenugreek|methi leaves]] (fenugreek leaves) * small [[Cookbook:Potato|potatoes]] * [[Cookbook:Carrot|carrots]] * [[Cookbook:Pea|peas]] * [[Cookbook:Lima Bean|lima beans]] * [[Cookbook:Pigeon Pea|Thoghari]] (2 cups) (toor dal) * [[Cookbook:Onion|onions]] * [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * [[Cookbook:Chili Powder|chilli powder]] * [[Cookbook:Coriander|coriander]] powder * [[Cookbook:Turmeric|haldhi]] (turmeric) * [[Cookbook:Lemon|lemon]] * [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] * [[Cookbook:Chili Pepper|green chillies]] * [[Cookbook:Ginger|ginger]] * [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]] * [[Cookbook:Garam Masala|garam masala]] * [[Cookbook:Coconut|coconut powder]] * [[Cookbook:Cilantro|coriander leaves]] (cilantro) * [[Cookbook:Ajwain|ajwain]]
== Procedure == # Take ½ the amount thoghari dal and crush. Crush green chillies, garlic, and ginger. Take coriander powder and add all the other spices, add fresh grated coconut, and mix. Add coriander leaves and make a paste. # Stuff the eggplant with the masala, and stuff the potatoes with masala. # Add papdi first and then only take a bit of oil. Add mustard, hing, onion, ghenasu, potatoes, and all the other vegetables mixed in the masala, to add to the oil. Add a little water to keep from burning, and in the pressure cooker, just one whistle is enough to cook. # Garnish with coriander, coconut. Don't forget to add muthias before you cook. === Muthia (bonda) === Take ¼ cup [[Cookbook:Flour|wheat flour]], and 2 spoons [[Cookbook:Chickpea|channa powder]]. Add [[Cookbook:Rice Flour|rice flour]], [[Cookbook:Oil|oil]], [[Cookbook:Chili Powder|chilli powder]], [[Cookbook:Lemon|lemon]], [[Cookbook:Chili Pepper|green chillies]], [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]], and make a dough. Add [[Cookbook:Fenugreek|methi leaves]], make small, elongated balls, fry in oil, and keep aside. {{see also|Cookbook:Bonda}} === Chutneys === Grind ingredients. {| class='wikitable' style='width: 95%' ! Green chutney !! Brown chutney !! Red chutney |- | style='vertical-align: top; width: 33%;' | * [[Cookbook:Cilantro|coriander leaves]] * [[Cookbook:Cumin|jeera]] (cumin) * [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]] * [[Cookbook:Coconut|grated coconut]] * [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * [[Cookbook:Lemon|lemon]] * [[Cookbook:Chili Pepper|green chillies]] * [[Cookbook:Ginger|ginger]] | style='vertical-align: top; width: 33%;' | * [[Cookbook:Tamarind|tamarind]] * [[Cookbook:Mango|mango powder]] * [[Cookbook:Jaggery|jaggery]] * [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * [[Cookbook:Coriander|coriander powder]] (for smell) | style='vertical-align: top; width: 33%;' | * [[Cookbook:Bell Pepper|red bell pepper]] * [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]] * [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * [[Cookbook:Chili Pepper|red chilli]] * [[Cookbook:Cumin|jeera]] (cumin) |} == Serving == To serve, take undhiu, green chilli, brown chutney, chilli chutney, and serve, topped with coriander leaves and coconut. [[Category:Indian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegan recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Gluten-free recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} [[Image:ShepherdsPie-closeup.jpg|thumb|250px|Shepherd's Pie]]
{{see also|Cookbook:Shepherds Pie}}
==Ingredients== *1[[Cookbook:Pound|lb]] (450[[Cookbook:g|g]]) [[Cookbook:Mincing|minced]] [[Cookbook:Lamb|lamb]] ( or ground [[Cookbook:Beef|beef]] ) *3 lb (1.3[[Cookbook:kg|kg]]) powdery old [[Cookbook:Potato|potatoes]], such as King Edwards *1 large or 2 small [[Cookbook:Onion|onions]] *2 tbsp flour *2 cups [[Cookbook:Stock|beef stock]] (alternatively, [[Cookbook:Bouillon Cubes|bouillon cubes]] can be used, or gravy powder, if the flour is omitted) *[[Cookbook:Cheese|cheese]], grated (optional) *a handful of mixed [[Cookbook:Vegetable|vegetables]] such as [[Cookbook:Corn|corn]] or [[Cookbook:Carrot|carrots]] (optional) *[[Cookbook:Mixed Herbs|mixed herbs]] *[[Cookbook:Milk|milk]]
==Procedure== #Brown the mince in a frying pan. There is no need to add oil, as the meat is fatty enough. #Finely chop the onion and lightly fry in a little butter until clear. #Add the onions to the mince along with the mixed herbs and some pepper. #Sprinkle the flour over the mixture and stir and cook for 3 - 4 minutes (if using gravy powder, omit this step). #Cover with beef stock (or add water and beef bouillon/gravy powder) and [[Cookbook:Simmering|simmer]] for 30 minutes. #Meanwhile peel, chop and boil the potatoes for 20 minutes until cooked. #Once the meat is cooked, skim off the excess fat, then boil rapidly to reduce the liquid until it just covers the mince and onions. #Drain the potatoes very well until completely dry. Mash until smooth and free of any lumps. #Add butter to the mashed potato, taste and adjust the seasoning. Add enough milk to make the mash very soft (heavy mash will not float properly on top of the mince). #Put mince mixture in a shallow oven proof dish. #Spread the mash on top of the meat and brush the tops of the potatoes with melted butter. #If desired, sprinkle the grated cheese on top of the mash. #Spike the top with a fork. # Cook in a hot oven for about 30-50 minutes until the top is golden brown. #Serve with [[Cookbook:Legumes|peas or beans]].
==Notes, tips, and variations== *The dish is sometimes made with [[Cookbook:Beef|beef]] rather than [[Cookbook:Lamb|lamb]], though this might properly be called ''cottage pie''. *Adding the butter and milk to the potatoes before they are properly mashed is the best way to make ''lumpy'' mash.
[[Category:Lamb recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Recipes_with_metric_units|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Spices and herbs|Spice]]
'''Tandoori masala''' is a mixture of spices specifically for use with a [[Cookbook:Tandoor|tandoor]], or clay oven, in traditional north [[Cookbook:Cuisine of India|Indian]] and [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Afghanistan|Afghani]] cooking. The specific spices vary somewhat from one region to another, but typically include fenugreek, cinnamon, cumin, coriander, garlic, ginger, etc.
The spices are ground to a fine powder in a coffee grinder or with a [[Cookbook:Mortar and Pestle|mortar and pestle]]. The masala is mixed with plain [[Cookbook:Yogurt|yogurt]], and meat (usually [[Cookbook:Chicken|chicken]]) is coated with the mixture, then slow-roasted in the tandoor. Chicken prepared in this fashion has a pink-coloured exterior and a savoury flavor.
The masala can be stored in airtight jars for up to 2 months, and is used in dishes like [[Cookbook:Tandoori Chicken|tandoori chicken]], [[Cookbook:Chicken Tikka Masala|chicken tikka masala]], [[Cookbook:Butter Chicken|butter chicken]], etc., all of them mostly Punjabi dishes. It can be used with meat other than chicken, for example, in tandoori fish or paneer tikka.
Nowadays, packets of tandoori chicken masala are readily available at major Indian supermarkets, with varying tastes depending on the brand. This convenience has led to many Indians buying the masala rather than making it at home.
== Ingredients == *1 tablespoon fenugreek seeds *1/2 teaspoon onion seeds *1/2 teaspoon salt *1 teaspoon garam masala *1/2 teaspoon turmeric powder *1/2 teaspoon curry powder *1/2 teaspoon coriander powder *1/2 teaspoon cumin powder *1/4 teaspoon chili powder *1 1/2 teaspoons paprika *4 garlic cloves, peeled and cleaned *2 tablespoons vegetable oil * fresh ginger (1 thumb-sized piece) *2 jalapeno peppers (seeds and all) *1 bunch fresh cilantro (washed, long stems cut off) *1/4 cup lemon juice *1 cup plain yogurt (An unthickened type of yogurt works best)
== Procedure == *Roast the fenugreek and onion seeds first by heating and tossing in a sauté pan for several minutes. Grind them together using a mortar and pestle or spice grinder. *In a food processor, blend fenugreek and onion seeds with the salt, garam masala, turmeric, curry powder, coriander powder, cumin, chili powder, paprika, garlic, vegetable oil, ginger, jalapeños, cilantro and lemon juice until all the ingredients become a smooth paste. *Spoon the mixture into a large mixing bowl and stir in the yogurt. *Marinate meat or fish for eight hours (or bathe first in white distilled vinegar for shorter marination time). Tofu, vegetables or paneer can be tossed into the marinade just before grilling. Use the marinade to baste over the grill.
[[Category:Ingredients|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Indian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Spice Mix recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{cookwork|wikify, °C}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Dessert|Dessert]] | [[Cookbook:Cake|Cake]]
==Ingredients== ===Cake=== *2 [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]]s [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] *2 cups [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] *1 cup [[Cookbook:Cola|cola]] *2 sticks [[Cookbook:Margarine|margarine]] (1 cup) *3 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoon]]s [[Cookbook:Cocoa|cocoa]] *2 [[Cookbook:Egg|egg]]s *1/2 cup [[Cookbook:Buttermilk|buttermilk]] *1/2 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoon]] [[Cookbook:Baking Soda|baking soda]] *1 teaspoon [[Cookbook:Vanilla|vanilla]] extract *1 1/2 cup miniature [[Cookbook:Marshmallow|marshmallow]]s
===Frosting=== *6 tablespoons cola *2 tablespoons cocoa *1 stick margarine *1 teaspoon vanilla *1 box powdered sugar *1 cup chopped [[Cookbook:Nut|nut]]s (optional)
==Instructions== ===Cake=== #Combine flour and sugar in a bowl. #Mix cola, margarine, and cocoa in a saucepan, and bring to a boil. #Pour over flour/sugar mixture and mix well. #Beat eggs and mix in. Add milk, soda, vanilla and marshmallows. Batter should be thin. Marshmallows will float to the surface. #Bake in a 9x13 pan at 350 degrees Fahrenheit for 35 minutes. Make frosting before it cools.
===Frosting=== #Mix cola, cocoa, and margarine in a pan and bring to a boil. #Add vanilla, sugar, and nuts. Mix until smooth. #Spread the warm frosting on the cake.
[[Category:Cake recipes|Cola Cake]]

{{recipesummary|Beer recipes|18-24 brownies|1 hour|2|[[Image:oatmealstoutbrownies.jpg|300px|Oatmeal Stout Brownies plated with Framboise Lambic sauce]]}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Beer|Beer recipes]]
'''Oatmeal Stout Brownies''' This recipe, created by Joe Stutler, was a national finalist in the 2006 Cooking With Beer Challenge. The malt and oats in the beer enhance the flavor of the chocolate in these delicious brownies. Not overly cake-ey, not overly fudge-ey, the texture is nicely balanced. They're also decadently chocolate, and surprisingly light (thanks to the eggs). Great with a fruity beer, such as a lambic (Framboise, yum!).
==Ingredients== * 1 cup all-purpose [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] * ¾ cup unsweetened [[Cookbook:Cocoa|cocoa]] powder (Dutch-processed preferred) * ¼ teaspoon [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * 6 tablespoons unsalted room temperature [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]], cut into cubes * 8 ounces dark bittersweet [[Cookbook:Chocolate|chocolate]], chopped * ¾ cup white [[Cookbook:Chocolate|chocolate]] chips * 5 large [[Cookbook:Egg|eggs]], at room temperature (1 egg is for the topping) * 1 cup [[Cookbook:Granulated sugar|granulated sugar]] * 1¼ cups (10 ounces) oatmeal stout [[Cookbook:Beer|beer]](room temperature) * 1 cup semi-sweet [[Cookbook:Chocolate|chocolate]] chips
* 1 package (8 ounces) [[Cookbook:Cream Cheese|cream cheese]], softened * ⅓ cup [[Cookbook:Granulated sugar|granulated sugar]] * ½ teaspoon [[Cookbook:Vanilla|vanilla]]
==Procedure==
# Preheat oven to 375°F (190°C). # Line a 9 x 13-inch [[Cookbook:baking pan|baking pan]] with non-stick foil (or grease and flour - or parchment paper; your call). # In a medium bowl, [[Cookbook:whisk|whisk]] together flour, cocoa powder, and salt until evenly combined. Set aside. #Melt butter, bittersweet chocolate, and white chocolate chips in a [[Cookbook:Double Boiler|double boiler]] over very low heat, stirring constantly until melted. Remove from heat. #In a large [[Cookbook:Mixing Bowl|mixing bowl]], [[Cookbook:beat|beat]] 4 of the eggs with the sugar on high speed until light and fluffy, about 3 minutes. Add melted chocolate mixture, beating until combined. #Beat reserved flour mixture into melted chocolate mixture. Whisk in stout beer. The batter will seem a bit thin. Drop semisweet chocolate chips evenly on top of batter (some will sink in). #Pour into prepared baking pan. #Beat cream cheese in medium bowl with [[Cookbook:Mixer|electric mixer]] on medium speed until smooth. Gradually beat in sugar. Beat in vanilla and the remaining egg just until blended. #Pour cream cheese mixture over brownie batter in pan; cut through mixture with knife several times for marbled design. #[[Cookbook:Baking|Bake]] 25 to 35 minutes on center rack in the oven, until a toothpick inserted in the center comes out almost clean. #Let brownies cool, uncovered, to room temperature. Dust with [[Cookbook:confectioners' sugar|confectioners' sugar]] before serving if desired.
==Notes, tips, and variations== *Makes 18 (cut ~ 2x3 inch) to 24 (cut ~ 2x2 inch) if cut to dessert size. For finger-food/snack portions you could halve the above dimensions to get 36-48 brownies. * Plating suggestion: swirl a raspberry lambic reduction sauce (12 oz lambic [reduced to half], 4-6 oz seedless raspberry purée, 2-4 oz turbinado sugar, ½-1 teaspoon corn starch) on the plate, garnish with mint leaves, raspberries, lemon zest.
== External links == * [http://www.beer-u.com/academics_culinary.asp Other beer-related recipes]
[[Category:Beer recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Chocolate recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Dessert recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Cookie recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Featured recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Stew recipes|12|2 hours|2}}
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|United States]] | [[Cookbook:Meat Recipes|Meat]] | [[Cookbook:Stews|Stews]]
'''Beef and Barley Stew''' - This hearty stew can be prepared from freezer to table in under 2 hours. It's easy to prepare ahead of time and refrigerate or freeze for later use.
==Ingredients== *3 pounds (1.25kg) [[Cookbook:Beef|beef]], cubed *1 white [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]], diced *4 cubed [[Cookbook:Potato|potatoes]] *1 cup (240g) [[Cookbook:Barley|barley]] *¼ cup (60g) [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] *1 can [[Cookbook:Tomato Paste|tomato paste]] *1 small can [[Cookbook:Dice|diced]] [[Cookbook:Tomato|tomatoes]] *1 slug [[Cookbook:Worcestershire Sauce|Worcestershire sauce]] *1 bunch [[Cookbook:Parsley|parsley]] *[[Cookbook:Salt|salt]], [[Cookbook:Pepper|pepper]], [[Cookbook:Paprika|paprika]] to taste *1 teaspoon [[Cookbook:Thyme|thyme]] *2 teaspoons [[Cookbook:Marjoram|marjoram]] *2 tablespoons [[Cookbook:Vegetable oil|vegetable oil]] *2 cartons [[Cookbook:Broth|beef broth]] *1 lb (450g) [[Cookbook:Mushroom|mushrooms]] *1 pkg [[Cookbook:Green Bean|frozen green beans]] *3 cloves halved [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]] *3 stalks [[Cookbook:Celery|celery]] *4 large [[Cookbook:Carrot|carrots]] *water, enough to cover all ingredients in pot
Dust beef cubes with flour lightly. Brown in vegetable oil. Move to separate pot and clean pan with beef broth and add to pot. Sauté celery, garlic and onion briefly and add to pot. Simmer for 1.5 hours. Add barley and simmer additional ½ hour. Add potatoes, sliced mushrooms, frozen green beans, diced tomatoes and tomato paste. Add slug of Worcestershire sauce. Simmer additional hour. Chop parsley and stir into stew before serving.
Serves 12.
==Procedure== #Combine the flour, salt, pepper, and paprika on a plate, and dredge the cubed beef in the flour mixture. #Add the oil to a [[Cookbook:Dutch Oven|Dutch oven]] or large [[Cookbook:Saucepan|saucepan]] on medium high heat. [[Cookbook:Browning|Brown]] the beef in the oil. #When the beef is evenly browned on all sides, add the water, beef broth, bay leaf, onion, carrots and barley. Allow to come to a simmer and reduce heat. #Allow to simmer for 1 to 1½ hours, until the meat is tender. Remove the bay leaf and serve with noodles or rice.
==Notes, tips, and variations== *Don't overcrowd the beef when browning. If there is not enough room to brown all the meat at the same time, do it in batches, and then add the reserved beef with the other ingredients.
==Warnings== *Always follow safe handling guidelines when using raw meat.
[[Category:American recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Stew recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Beef recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Inexpensive recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Recipes_with_metric_units|{{PAGENAME}}]]
