{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Australia|Cuisine of Australia]] [[Image:Pie floater.jpg|right|thumb|Pie floater]]
The '''Pie Floater''' is a meal consisting of a Meat Pie served upside down in a dish of Pea Soup. It is common in South Australia, and sometimes seen in other parts of Australia. The pie floater is a popular midnight snack for drinkers and revellers.
==Ingredients== * 1 Meat Pie (commercial pies are fine) * 1 Can Pea Soup
==Procedure== # Heat the Pie in an oven. A microwave will not work as well, as the pie pastry will not be crisp. # Heat the pea soup separately. # Place the pie in the dish, and pour the pea soup around it until the dish is full.
{{Wikipedia|Pie floater}}
[[Category:Australian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{cookwork|Unsure of name, as another very famous Afghani dish exists with similar name (Qabuli pilau) and this isn't it.}}
{{recipe}} [[Cookbook:South Asian cuisines|South Asian cuisines]]
==Ingredients==
* 1kg [[Cookbook:Rice|rice]] * 500g [[Cookbook:Chickpea|chana lentil]] * [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * [[Cookbook:Red Pepper|red pepper]] * ½ tsp [[Cookbook:Ginger|ginger]] [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]] paste * 3 [[Cookbook:Onion|onions]] * ¼ tsp [[Cookbook:Turmeric|turmeric powder]] * [[Cookbook:Shortening|Shortening]] * ½ cup chopped [[Cookbook:Cilantro|cilantro]] * 4 to 5 [[Cookbook:Chili Pepper|green chillis]], chopped in half * [[Cookbook:Tomato Paste|tomato paste]]
==Procedure== # Soak the chana lentil for half an hour. # After half an hour, boil the lentil with salt, red pepper, and ginger garlic paste. # Be mindful that after the lentil has been cooked, there should not be any water remaining. # If there is water remaining, continue cooking until the water has boiled over. # Boil rice that has been previously soaked in salt water # When the rice is half cooked, turn the stove off. # Heat some shortening in a pan # Fry the onions until they are light brown and some tomato paste, salt, red chilly powder and turmeric powder. # Arrange the fried onion with the spices, boiled lentils, and rice in a large stock pot and cook covered until the rice is done. # Garnish with chopped cilantro and green chillies and serve hot.
[[Category:South Asian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Chickpea recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegan recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Gluten-free recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:South Asian cuisines|South Asian cuisines]]
==Ingredients== * 1 kg. lean [[Cookbook:Mincing|mince]] ([[Cookbook:Beef|beef]] or [[Cookbook:Lamb|lamb]]) * 3 medium [[Cookbook:Onion|onions]], skinned and thinly sliced * 1 cup [[Cookbook:Oil|oil]] * 1 tbsp. [[Cookbook:Ginger|ginger]] paste * 2 tbsp. unripe green [[Cookbook:Papaya|papaya]] (ground) * 1 tsp. [[Cookbook:Garam Masala|garam masala]] * 1½ tsp. [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * 7-8 whole [[Cookbook:Chili Pepper|red chilli]] * 2 tbsp. [[Cookbook:Yogurt|yogurt]] * 1 piece coal * 2 tbsp. freshly chopped [[Cookbook:Cilantro|green coriander]] (cilantro) * 1 tsp. finely chopped [[Cookbook:Chili Pepper|green chillies]] * 1 tbsp. roasted [[Cookbook:Chickpea|chickpea flour]]
==Procedure== # Heat oil in a heavy based sauce pan. Add onions and stirring frequently, fry for 8-10 minutes to a light golden color. Remove onions from oil and fry the whole chillies just for a moment, otherwise they will burn. Reserve the oil and put the onions and whole chillies in a chopper or food processor and blend to a smooth paste without using water. # Thoroughly wash the mince and squeeze out any water. # Put the mince in a bowl. Add onion paste, ginger paste, salt, garam masala and yogurt. Knead the mixture really well for a few minutes with your hands until it is smooth. # Cover and leave to marinate at room temperature for about 3-4 hours or overnight in the refrigerator. One hour before cooking mix in the ground papaya. # Put the charcoal over medium flame, wait until the coal is fully red and is covered by white ash. # Meanwhile place the mince in a metal pan. Make a well in the center. Put a small piece of aluminum foil in it. Place the burned coal over it and put 2-3 drops of oil on it. Cover it at once with a tight fitting lid and put aside for 20-25 minutes. # Take out ½ cup of oil from the reserved oil. Reheat the oil in a heavy based pan. Discard the charcoal and fry the mince over low heat for 4-5 minutes. Cover with a tight fitting lid and cook for 15-20 minutes or until all excess moisture has absorbed. # Transfer to a serving dish and decorate with onion ring, green chilli and coriander leaves.
[[Category:South Asian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Fish|Fish]]
Although the '''Tipitapa''' recipe is a secret, this is the most common substitute to it.
==Ingredients== * 5 spoonfuls [[Cookbook:Olive Oil|virgin olive oil]] * whole 8oz - 1lb (225g - 450g) [[Cookbook:Fish|carp fish]]
===Salsa=== * ½ an [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]] * [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] * 3 oz (85g) [[Cookbook:Tomato|tomato]] * [[Cookbook:Lemon|lemon]] * natural (fruit) [[Cookbook:Vinegar|vinegar]] * 1-2 spoonfuls virgin olive oil
==Procedure== # Fry half a yellow onion (vidalia onions are OK but purple or white onions are also acceptable). # When the onion is transparent, add a 3 ounces tomato cut in rings and cook for five minutes then add a drop or two of vinegar and a pinch of brown sugar. Let it cook for a few more minutes and save. # Use a carp fish (8 ounces to 1 pound) per serving. The fish must be fresh and the skin clean of scales but intact. The contents of the fish must be emptied (abdominal clean up). It is possible to use previously frozen fish but fresh unfrozen catch is preferable. # In five spoonfuls of virgin olive oil (to substitute Nicaraguan virgin oils) or the same amount of your favorite cooking oil that is already heated, fry one side of the fish until the skin is crispy (approximately 7 minutes per side) then put in the oven on pan with rack to cook at 350°F (175°C) during 15 minutes. # Let the fish cool, then salt as wanted and return to its pan. Fry again for 3 minutes each side low flame while re-heating the salsa, then add the salsa on top and serve.
[[Category:Fish recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Jamaica|Cuisine of Jamaica]]
A '''Jamaican patty''' is a street food that contains various fillings and spices baked inside a flaky pastry shell. As its name suggests, it is commonly found in [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Jamaica|Jamaica]], and is also eaten in other areas of the [[Cookbook:Caribbean cuisines|Caribbean]]. It is traditionally filled with [[Cookbook:Mincing|ground]] [[Cookbook:Beef|beef]], or with ground [[Cookbook:Mutton|mutton]] or [[Cookbook:Goat|goat]], and fillings also include [[Cookbook:Chicken|chicken]], [[Cookbook:Vegetable|vegetables]], [[Cookbook:Fish|fish]] and [[Cookbook:Cheese|cheese]]. Patties following recipes with [[Cookbook:Halal|halal]] meats or vegetable based substitutes can also be found.
In recent years, the Jamaican meat patty can be found pre-made and frozen in Great Britain and North America, primarily Canada.
Conventionally, patties are marked with a colored dot on the crust to indicate the filling: *no dot: ground beef *red dot: chicken *green dot: vegetables (often not vegetarian, containing animal suet, tallow, and/or other animal ingredients; vegetarians must inquire whether recipes are suitable for their diets)
Here is a common recipe provided for Jamaican Beef Patty.
==Ingredients== ===Filling=== *2 lbs ground [[Cookbook:Beef|beef]] *2 bundles fresh [[Cookbook:Thyme|thyme]] *1 tsp [[Cookbook:Paprika|paprika]] *half a loaf of French bread *½ tsp Island Spice Scotch Bonnet Pepper Soya Sauce *2 oz [[Cookbook:Green onion|scallion or spring onion]] *1 tsp [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]]
===Pastry=== *2 cups [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] *½ teaspoon salt *1 cup [[Cookbook:Lard|lard]] *1 cup cold water *1 teaspoon ground [[Cookbook:Turmeric|turmeric]] (or 1/2 teaspoon Jamaican Curry Powder and ½ teaspoon annatto for coloring) *Beef filling for patties *½ cup [[Cookbook:Milk|milk]]
==Procedure==
===Filling=== #Grind escallion and Island Spice Scotch Bonnet Pepper Soya sauce. #Add to ground beef with salt. #Add thyme. #Cook beef. #While beef is cooking, pour cold water over bread in a saucepan to cover and soak for a few minutes, squeeze dry saving the water. #Pass bread through mincing mill and return the ground bread to the water with thyme and cook until bread is dry. Combine meat and cooked bread. #Add paprika and cook for 20 minutes. #Remove from heat. #Allow to cool.
===Pastry=== #Sift flour, turmeric (for coloring), salt and knead in lard. #Bind with water to form a firm dough and knead for 2 minutes. #Roll pastry 1/8 inches thick. #Cut pastry round 6 inches. #For extra patty crust flakiness, roll out brush with lard, fold over and roll again. Do this about 3 times. #Divide beef filling between patties, brush edges with water. #Fold over and seal glaze with milk. #Bake on top shelf of oven for about 25 mins. at 450 degrees until golden brown
[[Category:Jamaican recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Pie recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{cookwork|Needs procedure}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Southern cuisine|Southern cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Cake|Cake]]
A '''Lane Cake''' is a baked cake traditional in the [[Cookbook:Southern cuisine|American South]]. A traditional Lane cake is a layered white cake. The outside usually has a white frosting. Each layer has different ingredients. For example, one layer may have pecans and coconut, the next layer almonds. Due to the complicated preparations and multiple ingredients, Lane cakes are considered difficult to make.
==Ingredients==
* ½ lb (225g) butter, at room temperature * 2 c (480g) sugar * 3½ c (525g) all-purpose [[Cookbook:flour|flour]] * 3½ ts baking powder * ½ ts salt * 1 c (240ml) milk * 8 egg whites
===Filling===
* 8 egg yolks * 1 c (240g) sugar * ½ lb (225g) butter, at room temperature * 1 c (240g) raisins, seeded, coarsely chopped * 1 c (240g) pecans, chopped * ½ c (120g) coconut, shredded
[[Category:Southern recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Cake recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Recipes_with_metric_units|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Tex-Mex cuisine|Tex-Mex cuisine]]
==Ingredients== * [[Cookbook:Hot Pepper Sauce|cayenne pepper sauce]] * 1 can prepared bean dip (9 oz) * [[Cookbook:Nachos|nachos]] or [[Cookbook:Tortilla Chip|tortilla chips]] * shredded [[Cookbook:Cheddar Cheese|cheddar cheese]] * [[Cookbook:Guacamole|guacamole]] (ready-made) * [[Cookbook:Sour Cream|sour cream]] * sliced [[Cookbook:Jalapeño|jalapeño peppers]]
==Procedure== # Stir cayenne pepper into the bean dip to taste and spread on chips. # Sprinkle with cheese and heat in 400 degree oven for 2 minutes or until cheese melts. # Top with guacamole dip and sour cream; garnish liberally with sliced jalapeño peppers.
''Attributed to Jack Cochran''
[[Category:Southwestern recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{cookwork|procedure needs fleshing out, ref: [[Cookbook:Mead]] and [[Cookbook:Ginger beer]]}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Beverages|Beverages]] | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Finland|Cuisine of Finland]] [[Image:Sima.jpg|right|thumb|A glass of sima]]
'''Sima''' is a Finnish [[Cookbook:Fermentation|fermented]] drink based on citrons (''Citrus medica'').
Gather your equipment. You will need a closeable container (a big plastic bucket for example) and empty bottles, their number and size depending on how much sima you are going to make.
You should sterilize all of your equipment as described in the [[Cookbook:Mead|mead]] recipe.
==Ingredients==
*5 liters of [[Cookbook:Water|water]] *1kg of [[Cookbook:Honey|honey]] *2 [[Cookbook:Lemon|citrons]] (lemons) *5g (1 tsp) [[Cookbook:Yeast|yeast]] *[[Cookbook:Raisin|raisins]]
==Procedure== # Boil 2 liters of water. # Wash the citrons well and peel them into the container you will making your mead in. # Add the honey into the container with the peels. # Pour the boiling water on top, and mix well. # Add 3 liters of cold water so that the mixture will be lukewarm. # Add a very small piece of yeast and slice the citrons into the mix, carefully removing the white part. # Let it stand overnight. # When you are ready to bottle it, add one spoonful of sugar and a few raisins to the bottle before you pour the mead in. # After bottling, let the bottles stand at room temperature for a few more days. # Finally, move the bottles to your refrigerator. The mead is ready, and should be served cold.
==Notes, tips and variations== * The honey is often replaced with 500g [[Cookbook:Brown Sugar|brown sugar]] and 500g [[Cookbook:Sugar|white sugar]].
[[Category:Finnish recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Beverage recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Lemon recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Honey recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Indonesia|Cuisine of Indonesia]]
'''Saus Kacang''' is a spicy Indonesian peanut sauce.
==Ingredients==
* 2 cans of [[Cookbook:Oil|oily]] [[Cookbook:Peanut Butter|peanut butter]], or add oil if dry * [[Cookbook:Water|water]] * [[Cookbook:Sambal Oelek|sambal oelek]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Lemon|lemon]] * [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * [[Cookbook:Soy Sauce|soy sauce]]
==Procedure==
# Mix the peanut butter with water and stir easy until one fluid sauce # Add some hot oelek, some lemon juice (from fresh lemon), some salt and soya sauce to it # Keep stirring and taste meanwhile to get the taste right! # You can also add a part of lemon to the sauce
[[Category:Indonesian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Sauce recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Peanut recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Chile recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Gluten-free recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Indonesia|Cuisine of Indonesia]]
'''Acar campur''' is a very simple Indonesian pickle salad.
==Ingredients==
* [[Cookbook:Pickle|Indonesian pickles]] * [[Cookbook:Onion|onions]] * [[Cookbook:Oil|oil]] * [[Cookbook:Vinegar|vinegar]] * [[Cookbook:Cucumber|cucumber]] * [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] * [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]]
==Procedure== # Mix it all together, and it's ready!
==Notes, tips and variations== * Indonesian pickles tend to include a variety of shredded [[Cookbook:Vegetable|vegetables]], including [[Cookbook:Carrot|carrots]], [[Cookbook:Cauliflower|cauliflower]], [[Cookbook:Cucumber|cucumber]], and [[Cookbook:Corn|baby corn]].
[[Category:Indonesian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Salad recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Serbia|Cuisine of Serbia]]
'''Proja''' (Serbian Cyrillic: ''Пpoja'') is a [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Serbia|Serbian]] national dish of cornbread.
==Ingredients==
*5 cups [[Cookbook:Cornmeal|corn flour]] (cornmeal) *3 cups [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] *3 [[Cookbook:Egg|eggs]] *3 cups [[Cookbook:Oil|oil]] *1 [[Cookbook:Baking Powder|baking powder]] *1 cup [[Cookbook:Yogurt|yogurt]] *1 glass [[Cookbook:Water|mineral water]] *1 big slice [[Cookbook:Cheese|cheese]] - crushed *[[Cookbook:Salt|salt]]
==Procedure==
Mix it all together and bake in greased pan (it should be 5 cm high) until golden. Best served with Kiseli kupus and Pavlaka.
[[Category:Serbian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Bread recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Pastry|Pastry]] [[Image:Appleturnover.JPG|240px|right|thumb|Apple turnover, made with puff pastry]]
In [[Cookbook:baking|baking]], '''puff pastry''' (French: '''''pâte feuilletée''''') is a light, flaky [[Cookbook:pastry|pastry]] made from [[w:en:Dough|dough]] of the same name. The dough, which is also called ''puff paste'', consists of many layers of fat sandwiched between layers of dough.<ref name=Gisslen>Gisslen, Wayne (2001) ''Professional Baking'', John Wiley & Sons, ISBN 0-471-34646-2</ref> Although ''Larousse Gastronomique'',<ref>''Larousse Gastronomique'' (1938), (1961 English translation), Crown Publishers, New York</ref> and some other writers,<ref name=Gisslen/> use the terms interchangeably, traditionally in the English language, the term puff pastry is distinguished from the term '''flaky pastry''', in the way in which the [[Cookbook:Shortening|shortening]] (fat) is folded into the dough.<ref>''The Concise Household Encyclopedia'', (1933), Amalgamated Press, London</ref>
[[Cookbook:Croissant|Croissant]]s are sometimes formed from puff pastry. Puff pastry shells used to be filled with [[Cookbook:crab|crab]] meat salad or [[Cookbook:chicken à la king|chicken à la king]] at ladies' luncheons. An [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|American]] fashion in the late 1970s was to bake a wedge of [[Cookbook:Brie Cheese|Brie]] in puff pastry and serve warm. [[Cookbook:Choux Pastry|Choux pastry]], used to make [[Cookbook:Cream Puff|cream puff]]s, is different, using eggs. [[Cookbook:Bourekas|Bourekas]] is also made out of puff pastry, filled with various ingredients.
There are several ways to make puff pastries below.
==Notes on baking and storing puff pastry== Puff pastry is cooked when the bottom of the item is browned and the pastry does not collapse into itself.
*Use a very sharp knife to cut puff pastry. A blunt knife will crush the layers together and prevent the pastry from rising to full height. *Do not get egg wash or milk wash on the sides of the pastry. This will glue the layers together during baking and result in uneven lift. *Excess flour left on the item will burn easily in the oven. Dust it off with a soft pastry brush. *Always bake puff pastry in a very hot oven ([[Cookbook:Oven temperatures|220°C/425°F]]). A hot oven ensures the moisture in the dough turns into steam, which is what makes puff pastry rise. *Open the oven flue during baking to allow steam to escape and the pastry to dry, or failing that, open the oven door near the end of the baking. *Puff pastry can be refrigerated for a week, or frozen for three months. Stored puff pastry will have less lift than fresh pastry.
==Method 1== ===Ingredients=== *1 [[Cookbook:Pound|pound]] [[Cookbook:flour|flour]] *1 pound [[Cookbook:butter|butter]] * [[Cookbook:water|water]]
===Directions===
#Sift the flour. #Divide the butter into four parts. #Cut one part of the butter into the flour with a knife. #Make the butter and flour into dough with water. #Roll the dough. #Flake the dough with part of the butter. #Flake until all the butter is in. #You have made enough crust for at least ten puffs. #Bake with a quick heat for 10 to 15 minutes.
==Method 2== ===Ingredients===
*2 [[Cookbook:quart|quart]]s (2.2 liters) flour *1 pound butter * cold water
Take a quarter of peck of flour, and rub it into a pound of butter very fine. Make it up into a light paste with cold water just stiff enough to work it up. Then lay it out about as thick as a silver dollar; put a layer of butter all over, then sprinkle on a little flour, double it up, and roll it out again. Double and roll it with layers of butter three times, and it will be fit for use.
==Method 3 (German method)== ===Ingredients===
*500g white flour *250g water *400g butter (or [[Cookbook:Margarine|margarine]])
Mix flour, water and 50g gram butter to make a dough. Knead well. Roll dough into a ball. Make a deep cut through the middle, and a second cut at a right angle again through the middle. Roll out the resulting four ends to about half the thickness of the base. It should now have the form of an equilateral cross. Stir butter until soft. Spread onto the middle part of the cross forming approximately a cube. Now take each end of the "cross", lift it, and put it on the top of the butter cube, literally wrapping it up like a gift. Cover in plastic foil and refrigerate overnight.
Take dough and start rolling it out. Always move in one direction. During the whole process, use as little flour as possible. Gently remove excessive flour with a brush. Roll out to about 10cm. Then perform a so-called "simple tour": take one end of the dough and fold it two-thirds of the dough's length toward the other end. Now, take the other end and fold it the opposite way. You should now have three layers of dough. Roll out again , but move the rolling pin along the folded sides (ie turn the dough 45 degrees). Repeat process up to 5 times. The more often you do this, the more layers you will get, the fluffier the dough will turn out.
== Flaky Pastry == '''Flaky Pastry''' is also known as "Quick Puff Pastry". ===Ingredients=== * 460 g butter, divided into four equal portions * 460 g all-purpose flour
===Method=== # Sift flour into a bowl # Cut one portion of butter into the flour till becomes crumbly. # Add cold water, as needed, to make a dough. # Lightly dust kneading board and rolling pin with flour. Roll dough till it is approximately half a centimetre thick. # Cut (smear) another portion of butter into the pastry. Fold pastry into quarters. Roll pastry back to a half a centimetre thickness. Repeat this step till there is no butter left. #Draw a sheet of plastic food wrap large enough to cover one side of the flattened pastry. Invert the kneading board. #Cover the other side with another sheet of plastic food wrap. Gently roll the pastry into a cylindrical shape. #Store in refrigerator until needed for use. Keeps well for a week or 6 months in freezer.
==Modernisation: Filo Puff Pastry== ===Ingredients=== * 2 and ⅓ cups plain (non–self-raising) flour * Additional flour for dusting * 450 g butter, diced * 550 g butter * chilled water
===Method=== # In a bowl, mix the first measure of flour and diced butter, until it becomes a fine crumb. # Add to the crumb, a little at a time, ice cold water until it becomes a very stiff dough. # Lightly dust the kneading board and rolling pin with flour. # Roll the pastry dough to the thickness of parchment paper, or thinner if possible. # Coat all of the visible dough with smears of butter. Sprinkle the pastry with a light dusting of flour, then fold in half. * While coating the dough in butter, keep the rolling pin as cool as possible. Either place a tea towel over the rolling pin, then a cold pack on top, or place the rolling pin in the freezer if near by. # Repeat steps #4. and #5. at least another two more times. At most, repeat another six times. Work as quickly and efficiently as possible. #Draw a sheet of plastic food wrap large enough to cover one side of the flattened pastry. Invert the kneading board. #Cover the other side with another sheet of plastic food wrap. Gently roll the pastry into a cylindrical shape. #Store in refrigerator until needed for use. Keeps well for a maximum of one day.
==Classic Puff Pastry== ===Ingredients===
* 2½ lbs (40 oz) Bread Flour (1125g) * ½ oz Salt (15g) * 1½ lbs (24 oz) Cold Water (775g) * 2½ lbs (40 oz) Room Temp Butter (1125g) * 4 oz Bread Flour (115g)
===Method=== # Mix the salt in with the larger portion of flour. # Add the cold water to the flour and salt and work it into a dough. # Knead about 80 times to make a soft dough and build some gluten. # Flatten out the dough (allows quicker cooling) and refrigerate. # Combine the room temperature butter and the smaller portion of flour and mix well. It will form a soft paste that is easy to spread. # Take the chilled dough and roll it into a rectangle about ¼-½ inch thick. # Leaving a one inch margin around the edge, spread the butter out over ⅔rds of the dough. # Fold the dough into thirds like you were folding a letter, starting with the portion of dough with no butter. # Refrigerate for 20-30 minutes to allow the dough to relax, and so the butter doesn't get displaced when rolling out again. # Roll out the dough again to a large rectangle the same size as the first. # Fold the dough so that the two short edges meet in the center and then fold the dough in half. This should give the dough four layers and is, as a result, called a four-fold. # Refrigerate the dough again and then roll out and do another four-fold. Repeat this step two more times. You now have classical puff pastry dough to use as you see please.
===Notes=== # Always always always salt your dough. It's not enough to be noticeable but it will help bring out the flavors of the butter and dough and whatever you decide to put in the puff dough. # The dough can be refrigerated for five to seven days. It will often take on a greyish tinge once it's getting old and it should then be thrown away. # Freezing dough generally isn't a good idea, but for something like this it's manageable. The water crystals that form can destroy the gluten that was formed while kneading and rolling and can lead to an improper rise while baking. Be sure to let the dough thaw completely and get to room temperature before rolling out and using. If you roll it out too early the butter will form spotty chunks within the dough which can tear your dough and cause it to rise unevenly in the oven. # Do not be afraid to add flour or water to your dough if you find it too sticky or dry. Location and humidity can alter the amount of moisture a dough needs to be just right. # Extra bread flour was added to the butter to help absorb any excess moisture in your dough and product. It will also help prevent a soggy baked good. # A little French terminology; the flour and butter mixture is called a Berrauge and the dough is called a Detremp.
==References== <references/>
[[Category:Pastry recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]
[[fr:Pâte feuilletée]]

{{recipesummary |Category = Confection recipes |Time = prep: 5 minutes
cook: 5 minutes |Servings = 64 (1 inch) pieces }} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Australia|Australia]] | [[Cookbook:Confections|Confectionery]] '''Rocky road''' is a type of confectionery commonly made in [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Australia|Australia]]. It is made from chunks of marshmallow in a matrix of chocolate. Common optional ingredients include [[Cookbook:Peanut|peanuts]] and blobs of chewy, coloured [[Cookbook:Gelatine|gelatine]]-based sweets, similar to jubes. ==Ingredients== * 12 oz [[Cookbook:Chocolate|chocolate]] * 2 tb [[Cookbook:Milk|milk]] * 2 tb [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]] * 3 c [[Cookbook:Marshmallow|marshmallows]] (mini) * ¾ c [[Cookbook:Walnut|walnut]] meats; chopped and shelled * 1 ts [[Cookbook:Vanilla|vanilla extract]] ==Procedure== # Measure all ingredients. # Butter an 8*8*2-inch square pan. Reserve. # Place chocolate morsels, milk and butter into wok. Set heat control dial at 350°F (175°C). # Begin stirring immediately. Stir constantly until chocolate is melted and milk and butter are incorporated. Stir in remaining ingredients. # Turn heat control dial to mixture into prepared pan. # Refrigerate until firm, about 2 hours. ==Note, tips, and variations== * For easy clean-up, fill wok half full with water, bring to a rolling boil and then rinse. [[Category:Australian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Confection recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Marshmallow recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Chocolate recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary |Category = Ice cream recipes |Servings = 2 }} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|USA]] | [[Cookbook:Ice Cream|Ice Cream]]
'''Rocky Road''' is an [[Cookbook:Ice Cream|ice cream]] flavor, second only to [[Cookbook:vanilla|vanilla]] in popularity in the [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|United States]]. Though there are variations on the flavor, it is traditionally composed of chocolate ice cream, [[Cookbook:Nuts and seeds|nuts]] and marshmallows. The flavor is claimed to have been created in 1929 by William Dreyer when he cut up [[Cookbook:walnut|walnuts]] and marshmallows with his wife's sewing scissors and added them to his chocolate ice cream during the Great Depression. The company claims it was then so named "to give folks something to smile about in the midst of the Great Depression."<ref>{{cite web| url = http://www.dreyersinc.com/about/WebHistory.pdf| title = Dreyer's History| accessdate = April 5|accessyear = 2006}}</ref>
Alternately, Fenton's Creamery in Oakland, California, claims that William Dreyer based his recipe on a Rocky Road ice cream invented by his friend, Fenton's George Farren, who blended his Rocky Road candy bar into ice cream; however Dreyer substituted [[Cookbook:almond|almond]]s for walnuts.<ref>{{cite web| url = http://www.fentonscreamery.com/blender.html| title = Fenton's Blender Club:Rocky Road Ice Cream| accessdate = April 5| accessyear = 2006}}</ref>
== Ingredients == *⅓ [[Cookbook:cup|cup]] unsweetened [[Cookbook:cocoa powder|cocoa powder]] *1 cup [[Cookbook:sugar|sugar]] *2 cups [[Cookbook:milk|milk]] *1 [[Cookbook:tablespoon|tablespoon]] [[Cookbook:Vanilla|vanilla extract]] *⅛ [[Cookbook:teaspoon|teaspoon]] [[Cookbook:salt|salt]] *2 cups [[Cookbook:Cream|whipping cream]] *1 [[Cookbook:ounce|oz]] semisweet [[Cookbook:chocolate|chocolate]] square *1 cup miniature [[Cookbook:marshmallow|marshmallow]]s *½ cup chopped [[Cookbook:Almond|almonds]] or [[Cookbook:Pecan|pecans]]
===Preparation=== #In a large [[Cookbook:saucepan|saucepan]], mix cocoa powder and sugar. #Gradually stir in milk. Stir over low heat until sugar and cocoa dissolve. #Cool to room temperature. #Stir in vanilla, salt and whipping cream; set aside. #Shred chocolate with coarse side of grater. #Stir shredded chocolate, marshmallows and almonds or pecans into cocoa mixture. #Pour into ice cream canister. #Freeze in ice cream maker according to manufacturer's directions. #Stir marshmallows evenly throughout frozen mixture before serving or ripening.
Makes about 2 quarts. <ref>{{cite web| url = http://www.recipesource.com/desserts/ice-cream/00/rec0095.html| title = Rocky Road Ice Cream| accessdate = April 5| accessyear = 2006}}</ref>
==Notes and references==
<references/>
[[Category:American recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Ice cream recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary |Category = German recipes |Servings = for 2 to 3 persons |Time = 1 hour }} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Germany|Germany]]
One has to eat [[Cookbook:Spaetzle|Spätzle]] with the [[Cookbook:Lentil|lentils]].
Best procedure is to prepare the dough before you cook the lentils, and afterwards you cook the Spätzle.
This one is a slightly modified recipe, the traditional one has no tomato and honey. But as on many "national meals" there is are different opinions. The best is to try around until you got your own best taste for it.
The most important things for a traditional taste is the vinegar and the bay (laurel) leaves.
==Ingredients==
* 250 grams [[Cookbook:Lentil|brown lentils]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Carrot|carrot]] * 2-3 [[Cookbook:Potato|potatoes]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]] * 2 pairs of [[Cookbook:Scalding|scalded]] [[Cookbook:Sausage|sausage]] * 1 large piece of [[Cookbook:Smoking|smoked]] [[Cookbook:Pork|pork belly]] * 2 cloves of [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]] * 1 litre of [[Cookbook:Water|water]] for the lentils *: it's needed to make the sauce, so don't use more water. * 40 g [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]] * 40 g [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] * ½ litre [[Cookbook:Water|water]] * 1 tablespoon [[Cookbook:Tomato Paste|tomato paste]] * 2 tablespoons [[Cookbook:Wine vinegar|red wine vinegar]] * 1 teaspoon [[Cookbook:Honey|honey]] * about 1 teaspoon [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * [[Cookbook:Pepper|pepper]] * one or more [[Cookbook:Bay Leaf|bay (laurel) leaves]]
==Equipment==
* A medium sized pot * A small pot * A sieve
==Procedure==
===Lentils=== # Wash the lentils in sieve and cook them on small heat in one litre water for 40 to 50 minutes (there are already done lentils to buy, and dry lentils etc. so best check instructions on the lentils package). # 20 minutes before the end of that time frame add the diced carrot and onion plus the peeled raw potatoes, also the garlic, the sausages (full or in pieces), the bay (laurel) leaves and the pork belly. # After those 20 minutes, put the pot on the side and keep it warm.
===Roux===
# Melt the butter in the little pot, add the flour and cook carefully until brown, keep stirring. # Slowly add the half litre of water in small portions and let it boil up once. # Add the tomato paste, the vinegar and honey, and spice with salt and pepper to your liking, pour the content into the pot with the lentils and mix well and keep it warm.
==Notes, tips and variations==
* Perhaps at first you think "how can fit vinegar in this stew" you will be surprised how good it fits, so don't be shy with it, or better place it on your table so everybody can do it as they like.. * Before eating, pick out the bay (laurel) leaves. * About the warming up etc. it's like with every stew, it is also great on the other day ;)
How do you like it? I would be happy to have feedback in the discussion panel. Also things to do better etc.
''Greetings from Suabia!''
==External links== *[http://www.safaribears.de/content.php?page=ChezTeddyspatzle Illustrated Spaetzle recipe]
[[Category:German recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Lentil recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary |Category = Venezuelan recipes |Servings = 10 }} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Venezuela|Venezuela]]
'''Lengua de Res''' – Cow Tongue.
==Ingredients==
* 1 [[Cookbook:Beef|beef]] [[Cookbook:Tongue|tongue]] * 5 fresh [[Cookbook:Chili Pepper|green chile peppers]] * 1 tablespoon [[Cookbook:Olive Oil|olive oil]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Onion|white onion]], sliced thinly * 4 cloves [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]], [[Cookbook:Mincing|minced]] * 4 small [[Cookbook:Tomato|tomatoes]], halved and sliced * 2 15-ounce cans whole kernel [[Cookbook:Corn|corn]], drained * [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]], to taste
==Procedure== # Wash tongue and place in a large pot of water to cover. Simmer until no longer pink, about 50 minutes per pound of tongue. Remove from water and let rest until cool enough to handle. Peel skin from tongue and trim gristle. Cut into ½" slices. # Place whole peppers in a skillet over medium-high heat and roast, turning, until all sides are charred. Let cool, rub off skins. Remove stems and seeds. # Heat olive oil in a large skillet over medium heat. [[Cookbook:Sautéing|Sauté]] chile peppers, onion, and garlic until onion is translucent. Stir in tongue and continue to cook until tongue is brown, 5 to 10 minutes. Stir in tomatoes and cook until limp, 5 minutes. Pour in corn and heat through, 2 to 5 minutes. Season with salt.
[[Category:Venezuelan recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Beef recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Chile recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Venezuela|Venezuela]]
A '''tequeño''' is prepared with a bread dough with white cheese (queso blanco) in the middle. It is formed into a bread stick and then fried. It is one of the most popular snack foods in parties, especially weddings. It is said that a party is not a true Venezuelan party without tequeños.
The name "tequeños" comes from the town of Los Teques, capital of the state of Miranda where it is believed this food originated from. The oldest known references to it come from the first decade of the 19th century. At that time the richest families of Caracas would spend long vacation periods in Los Teques and it is believed that they started preparing them with the left over dough of another Venezuelan food "pastelitos".
==Ingredients==
*1 kg [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] *1 cup [[Cookbook:Vegetable oil|vegetable oil]] *1 [[Cookbook:Egg|egg]] *1 teaspoon [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] *1 teaspoon [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] *1 kg [[Cookbook:Cheese|white soft cheese]]
==Procedure==
*Mix the flour, oil, egg, salt and sugar in a bowl. *While kneading, add a tablespoon or two of water. *Keep kneading until it does not stick to your hands. *Let the dough rest for 1-2 hours . *While the dough is resting, cut the cheese into finger-like strips, roughly 1 cm x 1 cm x 7 cm (½" by ½" by 3"). *After the dough has rested, shape it into palm sized balls. *Roll them out until they are ½ cm (¼-0.125 inch) thick. *Cut the rolled-out dough into long strips that are 1½ cm (¾") wide. *Wrap the cheese strips with the dough strips. *Make sure you cover all the cheese and seal it inside the dough, because otherwise the cheese will leak out of the dough when you fry them. *After you have wrapped the cheese in dough, dust the raw "tequeños" with flour and deep fry them in hot oil, until a golden tone is obtained.
Tequeños are best served with [[Cookbook:Guasacaca|guasacaca]], in either its mild (green) or spicy (red) formats.
[[Category:Venezuelan recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Bread recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

page.title: Cookbook:Buttermilk Fried Chicken with Pan Gravy

revision.text:
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Southern cuisine|Southern cuisine (USA)]] | [[Cookbook:Fried Chicken|Fried Chicken]]
'''Fried chicken''' is a Southern main meal in the [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|USA]], served often at "Sunday dinner" ("dinner" being the midday meal for many Southerners) or church "suppers" ("supper" being the term for the evening meal). Recipes are legion; every family has one handed down. Here's one:
==To make the Chicken==
===Ingredients===
*one whole [[Cookbook:Chicken|chicken]] *2 cups [[Cookbook:Buttermilk|buttermilk]] *1 tsp [[Cookbook:Mustard|mustard powder]] *1 tsp [[Cookbook:Cayenne pepper|cayenne powder]] *2 tsp cracked [[Cookbook:Pepper|black peppercorns]] *1 tsp [[Cookbook:Cinnamon|cinnamon]] *1 tablespoon [[Cookbook:Oregano|oregano]] *1 tablespoon [[Cookbook:Parsley|parsley]] *1 tsp [[Cookbook:Paprika|paprika]] *[[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] seasoned with herbs and spices (see procedure)
The spice mix isn't fixed. You can use more or less as desired.
===Procedure===
# Cut up a chicken into 8-10 pieces. # Mix other ingredients except seasoned flour together, and [[Cookbook:Marinating|marinate]] the chicken pieces for four hours in the mixture. # Take each chicken piece out of the marinade and allow it to drip dry a few seconds. Then dredge it in seasoned flour. (Seasonings could include pepper, cayenne, salt, ground coriander, cinnamon, thyme, oregano). An easy way to dredge: put flour and seasonings in a small plastic bag, drop the piece in, and shake. # Let the pieces rest (separately; do not stack) for about 10 minutes. Then dredge them again. The first dredging absorbs the buttermilk marinade. The second dredging gives a seasoned flour outer coat. # Fry pieces in a deep, wide pan. Use an oil with a high smoke-point (peanut oil is good, but corn oil is OK too). When oil is smoking hot, drop pieces into the pan, and be careful to not overcrowd (pieces should not touch; fry in two batches). After three or four minutes, turn the chicken, and reduce the heat. Let the chicken fry for 20-25 minutes, turning the pieces every few minutes. When the chicken is a deep golden-brown, and the juices run clear, it's done. The chicken will continue to cook after being removed from the pan, so err on the side of "just about done". # Drain the chicken on absorbent paper or cloth. If you are not serving the chicken immediately, place it in a lightly-warmed oven, uncovered, separately (not stacked).
==To make the gravy==
===Ingredients===
* [[Cookbook:Oil|oil]] * 1 small [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]] (or [[Cookbook:Green onion|shallots]]) chopped * [[Cookbook:Garlic|clove of garlic]] * 3-4 tbsp [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] * 3 cups [[Cookbook:Stock|chicken stock/bouillon]] (or 2 cups stock and 1 cup [[Cookbook:Cream|cream]]) * [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] and [[Cookbook:Pepper|pepper]]
===Procedure===
# Pour off the accumulated oil from the pan, though reserving 3-4 tablespoons and all the flour and chicken residue. Keeping the pan on medium flame, toss in one small chopped onion and a clove of garlic. [[Cookbook:Sautéing|Sauté]] for a few minutes. Whisk in 3-4 tablespoons of flour, and keep stirring until the mixture becomes light to medium brown. Do not burn. # Whisk in 3 cups of chicken stock or bouillon (or 2 cups stock and 1 cup cream). Simmer on low flame, covered, for 15 minutes. Salt and pepper to taste. # Serve chicken with [[Cookbook:Rice|rice]], and with some green vegetable. Spoon gravy over rice and chicken.
[[Category:Southern recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Chicken recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

revision.comment: Revert to revision 723693 dated 2007-01-19 04:19:05 by Webaware using [[:en:Wikipedia:Tools/Navigation_popups|popups]]
revision.text:
{{recipe}}
'''Dirt pudding''' is a dessert creation consisting primarily of [[Cookbook:pudding|pudding]] ([[Cookbook:vanilla|vanilla]] or [[Cookbook:chocolate|chocolate]]) and [[Cookbook:Oreo cookies|Oreo cookies]], with some recipes including [[Cookbook:gummy worms|gummy worms]]. This quick and easy dessert can be made in less than five minutes and is ready to eat in about one hour.
== Ingredients ==
* 3½ cups (840ml) cold [[Cookbook:milk|milk]] * 2 pkgs. (4 serving size) vanilla [[Cookbook:Instant Pudding|Instant Pudding]] * 1 12 oz tub (320g) [[Cookbook:Whipped Topping|Whipped Topping]], thawed * 1 16 oz pkg. (450g) [[Cookbook:Chocolate sandwich cookies|Chocolate sandwich cookies]], crushed
== Procedure ==
HINT: Crush cookies in zipper-style plastic bag with [[Cookbook:Rolling Pin|rolling pin]] or in [[Cookbook:Food Processor|food processor]].
Make the pudding as directed on the package using 3½ cups (840ml) milk; let stand 5 minutes. Stir 3 cups of the whipped topping and ½ of the crushed cookies into the pudding OR alternate layers of crushed cookies and pudding/whipped topping. Spoon it into any bowl or dish of your choice. Sprinkle the top with the remaining crushed cookies. Refrigerate for 1 hour.
[[category:Pudding and Custard recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Chocolate recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Recipes with metric units|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Thailand|Thailand]]
'''Tod Mun''' (Thai fish cakes) can be found sold on the streets of Thailand and they are a popular snack. At home they are perfect for an appetizer. There are many different recipes; the most common variant uses both fish and shrimp. This is the basic fish recipe.
==Ingredients== *1/2 [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] (120 [[Cookbook:mL|mL]]) vegetable oil (for frying) *1 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoon]] (15 mL) sugar *1/2 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoon]] (7.5 mL) salt *120 [[Cookbook:gram|grams]] green beans *360 [[Cookbook:gram|grams]] ground fish or fish paste (''pla kuud)'' *1 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoon]] (15 mL) red curry paste *1 [[Cookbook:Egg|egg]] *3 [[Cookbook:Kaffir Lime Leaf|Kaffir lime leaves]]
== Procedure == # Stack the lime leaves and roll them together into a tube shape. Slice them into thin strips. # Slice the green beans into small (½ inch) pieces. # Mince the fish. # Mix all the ingredients except the green beans and lime leaves in a bowl. # Stir until the mixture is smooth. # Add the green beans and lime leaves to the mixture and stir again. # Add the oil to a frying pan and heat to a medium temperature. # Drop a tablespoon of the mixture into the pan and flatten slightly. When the bottom is cooked, turn over. # When cooked on both sides, place on a paper towel to drain any extra oil. Continue with the rest of the mixture.
==Notes==
* If fresh Kaffir lime leaves are not available, do not substitute dried leaves as this will not work, and it is better to leave them out altogether. * You may substitute the fish with chicken.
[[Category:Thai recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Curry recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Fish recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Chicken recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Ireland|Ireland]]
'''Irish stew''' is a traditional [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Ireland|Irish]] dish made from [[Cookbook:Lamb|lamb]] or [[Cookbook:Mutton|mutton]] as well as [[Cookbook:Potato|potato]]es, [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]]s and [[Cookbook:Parsley|parsley]]. It originated in Ireland but appears in cookbooks all over Europe, including in [[w:Escoffier|Escoffier]]'s Guide Culinaire.
Irish stew is a filling, flavourful dish made with the most readily-available ingredients. The Irish raised primarily sheep and root crops for subsistence. The sheep provided wool for warm clothing, milk for drinking and making cheese, and eventually food. Potatoes were the main food crop, prior to the potato famine. (Sometimes the potatoes are boiled separately, and added before serving, as they tend to break down faster than other ingredients.)
Irish stew, or "stobhach gaelach" as it is called in Irish, is traditionally made of lamb or mutton (mutton is from less tender sheep over two years of age), potatoes, onions, and parsley. Sometimes, lamb or mutton neckbones, shanks, and other trimmings were the only basis for the stock. Yet these would-be discards still held enough flavor after a long simmering process to do justice to a hearty bowl of stew. The root vegetables added further flavor and thickening power, as well as filling sustenance. Some cooks added [[Cookbook:Turnip|turnips]] or [[Cookbook:Parsnip|parsnips]], [[Cookbook:Carrot|carrots]], and [[Cookbook:Barley|barley]] when available.
Although traditionally made with lamb or mutton, Irish stew was basically a cheap meal which was thrown together with left-overs and filled out with potatoes. More recently, Irish stew has been made with cheap [[Cookbook:Beef|beef]].
When the Irish people began immigrating to the United States, they naturally brought along their food traditions. The stew evolved and adapted to include the local offerings. Sheep were not as plentiful, so other types of meat were often substituted. The recipe has evolved to often include Guinness stout and [[Cookbook:Paprika|paprika]]. Some variations have exalted this original peasant dish to near gourmet status.
== Ingredients == * 2½ lb (1.1kg) boned [[Cookbook:Mutton|mutton]] * 4 large [[Cookbook:Potato|potatoes]] * 2 large [[Cookbook:Onion|onions]] * 3 or 4 medium [[Cookbook:Carrot|carrots]] * sprig of [[Cookbook:Parsley|parsley]] * 2 cups (480ml) [[Cookbook:Water|water]] * [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] and [[Cookbook:Pepper|pepper]]
==Procedure==
# Cut the meat into good size chunks. Peel the vegetables and slice thickly. Chop the parsley. # Choose a pot with a well-fitting lid and put in the ingredients in layers, starting and finishing with potatoes. Pour in the water and season to taste. # Cover and put on a very low heat for about 2½ hours until the meat is tender and the potatoes have thickened the liquid. The dish may also be made with [[Cookbook:Lamb|lamb]], in which case it requires only 1½ hours cooking time.
{{Wikipedia|Irish stew}}
[[Category:Irish recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Lamb recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Potato recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Stew recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Recipes_with_metric_units|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Spices and herbs|Herbs]] [[Image:Loewenzahn pae.jpg|right|thumb|Dandelions]]
'''Dandelions''' make a great free meal. Not only are they high in nutrition and very good for you, they also taste great!
== Where do I take them from? == Find some flowers in your yard or field that are not right by the road and collecting pollution from traffic. Larger varieties of dandelions and older, tougher leaves may be cooked like any greens. They are probably closest in character to mustard greens, though bitter. Young plants are a little less bitter; the very young ones make an excellent though slightly bitter salad.
With a knife, cut the whole plant at the top of the root so that it comes out of the ground intact. You should snap off the yellow flowers that have already opened up but be sure to leave any unopened buds - these are the tastiest part!
== Remove the bitterness == Once you have given your pickings a good washing to get off all the dirt, stick them in a pot with enough water to just cover and boil until they are nice and soft. When the water turns yellow, replace it with fresh water and re-boil. This will remove the bitterness. When they are done they will have the consistency of cooked spinach. If you have very young plants you may decide to skip this step.
== Recipes == * Strain and dress with [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]], a squeeze of [[Cookbook:Lemon|lemon]], or [[Cookbook:Vinegar|vinegar]]. Optionally, add little pieces of fried [[Cookbook:Bacon|bacon]]. * Dandelion salad is often accompanied with [[Cookbook:Hard Boiled Egg|hard boiled eggs]]. * Lightly [[Cookbook:Sautéing|sauté]] (or [[Cookbook:Roasting|roast]]) a clove of [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]], half an [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]] and a quarter teaspoon of [[Cookbook:Chili Pepper|red pepper flakes]] in a tablespoon and a half of [[Cookbook:Olive Oil|olive oil]]. Add a quart of damp greens to the sautéed vegetables, cover and steam over low heat for about thirty minutes. Season to taste and serve.
==External Links== *[http://www.backwoodshome.com/articles2/kallas82.html Making Dandelions Palatable by John Kallas of Wild Food Adventures] * [http://fxcuisine.com/default.asp?Display=78 Dandelion Syrup - step-by-step illustrated recipe in English]
[[Category:Ingredients|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Herbs and Spices|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Salad recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Dessert|Dessert]]
==Ingredients==
* 75g [[Cookbook:Butter|unsalted butter]] * 75g sieved [[Cookbook:Powdered Sugar|icing sugar]] or [[Cookbook:Caster sugar|caster sugar]] * 2 tbsp [[Cookbook:Brandy|brandy]]
==Procedure==
# [[Cookbook:Creaming|Cream]] together the butter and sugar until light and fluffy. # Gradually beat in the brandy. # Chill before serving.
Brandy butter can be kept for several weeks if made with fresh butter and stored covered in the fridge. Serve with Christmas pudding and warm mince pies.
Serves 8
[[Category:Dessert recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Dairy recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Spain|Cuisine of Spain]]
Pan tomaca, also called Pa amb tomàquet is a sandwich style tapa originated in Catalonia but now enjoyed all over Spain. It means bread with tomato. It is lightly toasted bread, rubbed with fresh tomato and sprinkled with olive oil and salt and served with, for example, slices of cured ham. Pan tomaca is typically served as a starter or as a sandwich.
==Ingredients== * two ripe red [[Cookbook:Tomato|tomatoes]] * 1 loaf [[Cookbook:French bread|French bread]] * 120g (1/4 lb.) sliced [[Cookbook:Cured ham|Cured ham]] * 2 tbsp [[Cookbook:Olive Oil|olive oil]] * [[Cookbook:Salt|Sea salt]]
==Procedure==
# Peel the tomatos. Optionally remove the seeds. # Blend the tomatos, 1 tbsp olive oil and salt to taste in an appropriate vessel with an immersion blender. # Cut the French bread loaf in appropriate sized portions and open those in halves. Optionally toast them very lightly also to increase tenderness. # Spread the mixture on one surface and sprinkle with olive oil. Place a slice of cured ham on top, and optionally cover with the other portion of bread for a sandwhich, or leave uncovered for a tapa.
* Makes 4-6 servings.
[[Category:Spanish recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Sandwich recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Beverages|Beverages]] [[Image:Indian filter coffee in Dabarah.jpg|right|thumb|South Indian filter coffee served in a traditional tumbler and dabarah / davarah]]
'''Madras filter coffee''' requires the use of specific fresh-roasted [[Cookbook:Coffee|coffee beans]] and [[Cookbook:Chicory|chicory roots]] which are not always available outside [[Cookbook:Cuisine of India|India]]. An alternative is to use a brand of Indian instant coffee that has chicory in it, and is available in some Indian stores and supermarkets. BRU instant coffee has 30% chicory added and in general has a near enough taste to authentic Madras filter coffee.
Indian coffee is generally not black coffee and is made using milk instead of water.
==Procedure== To make one cup of coffee: # Heat a small quantity (¼) cup of water until it boils. # Put ½ to 2 teaspoon (depending on how strong you want to have the coffee) of BRU instant coffee in it. # Stir the solution and ensure that there are no lumps of coffee. # Boil ¾ cup of milk and bring to boil. # Add the coffee mixture to the milk and add sugar as per your preference. # While the coffee is still boiling hot, pour it into a mug or, preferably, a stainless steel tumbler. While pouring the coffee, slowly raise the saucepan until the coffee falls into the mug/tumbler from a height of about 1 to 1½ ft. This will cause the coffee to froth (like [[Cookbook:espresso|espresso]]). # You can dip a teaspoon in the coffee and lightly spread a few drops of it over the froth in the mug. # Serve piping hot.
NOTE: filter coffee in india is actually made in a closed steel container called a coffee filter .coffee percolates into hot water.
{{Wikipedia|Indian filter coffee}}
[[Category:Indian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Beverage recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Pizza|Pizza]]
'''Chicken Alfredo pizza''' is a recipe for a medium sized pizza, feeding around four people.
==Ingredients==
* 2 boneless, skinless [[Cookbook:Chicken|chicken breasts]] ''(more if you like lots of chicken)'' * one large jar of [[Cookbook:Alfredo Sauce|Alfredo sauce]] * one or large package of shredded [[Cookbook:Cheese|cheese]] (e.g. [[Cookbook:Cheddar Cheese|cheddar]], [[Cookbook:Mozzarella Cheese|mozzarella]]) * pizza crust - e.g. [[Cookbook:Basic Pizza Crust|Basic Pizza Crust]] (or you can buy the packaged mix for convenience) * one package of [[Cookbook:Pepperoni|pepperoni]] ''(it gives it that pizza look)''
You can add whatever you like if you find this recipe a bit bland.
==Preparation==
# First you need to cut up the chicken and cook it. No one wants to eat raw chicken. # After that is done, make your crust and put in on a medium sized pizza pan. # Spread some Alfredo sauce on it, and plop some chicken on, make a couple of layers like this then sprinkle your cheese on. # Cook in the oven for about 20 minutes or until the crust is done. The oven temperature should be about 350°F (175°C)
Enjoy!
[[Category:American recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

revision.comment: move za'atar to notes, tips, variations
revision.text:
{{recipe}}
'''Chicken Broccoli Alfredo''' works with all types of pasta and noodles and can be modified for use with a variety of sauces. It is great for family dinners and recommended to serve with garlic bread.
{{see also|Cookbook:Alfredo Sauce}}
==Ingredients== * 1 pound boneless [[Cookbook:chicken|chicken]] breasts * 1 cup [[Cookbook:Cream|cream]], or [[Cookbook:Half and Half|half and half]] if preferred * 2 tablespoons [[Cookbook:Flour|white flour]] * ¼ cup chopped [[Cookbook:onion|small onion]] or [[Cookbook:Shallot|shallot]] * 1 teaspoon [[Cookbook:Thyme|thyme]] * ¼ teaspoon [[Cookbook:oregano|oregano]] * ½ teaspoon [[Cookbook:Garlic Powder|garlic powder]] * 1 tablespoon [[Cookbook:parsley|parsley]], chopped * ½ teaspoon [[Cookbook:Red Pepper|red pepper]] * 2 cups [[Cookbook:pasta|fettuccini pasta]] * ½ cup grated [[Cookbook:Parmesan Cheese|Parmesan cheese]] * 1 tablespoon cooking [[Cookbook:oil|oil]] * ½ cup [[Cookbook:Lemon Juice|lemon juice]] * 1 tablespoon [[Cookbook:butter|butter]]
==Procedure== #Heat up oil slightly in a [[Cookbook:Frying Pan|frying pan]] over a medium flame. #[[Cookbook:Sautéing|Sauté]] chicken breasts and shallots in hot oil for 5 minutes or until golden brown. Add lemon juice to chicken and cook for an additional 10 minutes. Remove chicken from flame. Reserve juices. Transfer chicken into a casserole dish. #Melt butter in clean frying pan. Add flour to butter and stir for about 3 minutes. #Slowly add half and half, stirring continuously. Add all spices and seasonings to sauce. #Stir in reserved juices and keep stirring. Reduce heat and slowly stir in Parmesan cheese. #Keep stirring until a smooth consistency is achieved. Pour sauce over chicken in [[Cookbook:casserole dish|casserole dish]]. #Cover and [[Cookbook:Baking|bake]] for 20 minutes at 350°F (175°C). #While chicken is cooking, prepare pasta. When chicken is done, serve immediately.
==Notes, tips and variations== * The thyme and oregano can be replaced by 1 teaspoon [[Cookbook:za'atar|zaatar]]
[[Category:Chicken recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Broccoli recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Pasta recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Meat recipes|1|10 minutes|1|[[Image:Njbrkfast.jpg|300px|thumb|right|Jersey breakfast dog]]}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|American cuisine]]
Jersey breakfast dog
==Ingredients==
* 1 beef [[Cookbook:Hot dog|hot dog]] * 1 strip [[Cookbook:Bacon|bacon]] * 1 large [[Cookbook:Egg|egg]] * 1 slice American or [[Cookbook:Cheddar_Cheese|cheddar cheese]] * 1 bun
==Directions== # Preheat [[Cookbook:Deep Fat Frying|deep fryer]] to 355°F. # Wrap bacon around the hot dog, securing at each end with a toothpick. # When oil reaches 355°F, lower wrapped hot dog into fryer. # Heat frying pan and fry one egg. # Place cooked egg on a small plate. # Open bun and place onto frying pan on low heat or in toaster oven to lightly toast. # When bacon is firm and crispy, remove hot dog from oil. # Place slice of cheese onto egg and microwave for 7-10 seconds. # Place egg and cheese onto bun. # Remove toothpicks from hot dog, and add to bun. # Add condiments and serve.
==Media== The Jersey breakfast dog is listed as number two of the ''"60 Things Worth Shortening Your Life For"'' by Esquire Magazine. [http://www.esquire.com/print-this/60things0507]
[[Category:Inexpensive recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Meat recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Sandwich recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Beef recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Hot Dog recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Cheese recipes|1-2|20 minutes|1|[[Image:Mozzarella_394.jpg|300px]]}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|American cuisine]]
The following is a recipe on how to make breaded mozzarella sticks.
==Ingredients==
* ¼ pound fresh [[Cookbook:Mozzarella Cheese|mozzarella cheese]] * ½ cup seasoned [[Cookbook:Bread Crumb|Italian bread crumbs]] * 1 large [[Cookbook:Egg|egg]]
==Directions== # Preheat [[Cookbook:Deep Fat Frying|deep fryer]] to 350°F (175°C). # Slice mozzarella into sticks 1-3 cm in diameter. # In a small bowl, whisk egg. # Fill another small bowl with bread crumbs. # Dip 3-4 sticks at a time into the egg. # Shake excess egg off sticks and place them in the bread crumbs. # Shake bowl of bread crumbs, evenly coating all sticks. Add more bread crumbs as needed. # Place coated sticks to the side and repeat for remaining sticks. # After all sticks have been coated, repeat the egg-dip and crumb-coat for each once more. # Place all sticks in fryer basket and submerge in 350°F oil. # Let sit for 30 seconds, gently rocking basket occasionally. # Lift basket and let cool for a few seconds. If cheese is not beginning to ooze out from half the sticks, resubmerge in oil for another 10-15 seconds, gently shaking the basket. Repeat until the cheese is just starting to ooze out. # Dump onto paper towel and pat off excess oil gently. # Serve hot.
==Alternate - Mozzarella bites== [[Image:Mozzbites2_577.jpg|thumb|right|Mozzarella bites]] # Slice mozzarella into cubes 2-3 cm on a side. # Dip 5-6 bites at a time into the egg. # Continue with the rest of the recipe as above, and enjoy mozzarella bites.
[[Category:Inexpensive recipes]] [[Category:Cheese recipes]] [[Category:Appetizer recipes]] [[Category:Fried recipes]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Appetizers|Appetizers]] | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Mexico|Mexico]]
'''Microwave Quesdilla''' is a dish in [[Cookbook:Tex-Mex cuisine|Tex-Mex]] or [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Mexico|Mexican cuisine]], which involves cooking ingredients, most popularly [[Cookbook:Cheese|cheese]], inside a corn or wheat [[Cookbook:Tortilla|tortilla]]
==Ingredients== *2 [[Cookbook:Tortilla|tortillas]] *Shredded cheese (typically [[Cookbook:Monterey Jack Cheese|Monterey Jack cheese]], but others cam be used), To Bind (about ¼ Cup or 30 mL) Fillings To Taste (Optional) * [[Cookbook:Salsa|salsa]] * [[Cookbook:Sarza Criolla|sarza criolla]] * [[Cookbook:Chili Pepper|chili pepper]]s * Chopped [[Cookbook:Tomato|tomatoes]] and [[Cookbook:Cilantro|cilantro]] * Cooked [[Cookbook:Meat and poultry|meat]] or [[Cookbook:Seafood|seafood]] * [[Cookbook:Avocado|avocado]] or [[Cookbook:Guacamole|guacamole]] * Fresh spinach--washed and torn into small pieces * Black beans--canned, rinsed and well drained Toppings To Taste (Optional) * [[Cookbook:Salsa|salsa]] * [[Cookbook:Guacamole|guacamole]] * [[Cookbook:Sour Cream|Sour cream]]
==Procedure== Place one tortilla on a [[Cookbook:Microwave|microwave]]-safe plate. Cover with half the cheese. Sprinkle on fillings as desired. Spread remaining cheese over the toppings, and place second tortilla on top. Place in microwave on high power for 30-60 seconds (or until cheese is melted and fillings are warm). Add desired toppings and enjoy.
==Notes, tips, and variations== *You are not limited to those fillings/toppings listed. However, ensure they can be thoroughly cooked/warmed in the short time necessary to melt the cheese.
[[Category:Mexican recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary |Category = Italian recipes |Servings = 6 |Time = 40 minutes |Rating = 2 }} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Italy|Cuisine of Italy]]
== Ingredients == * 500g (18 oz - 1½ lb) minced [[Cookbook:Veal|veal]] meat * ¼ tsp [[Cookbook:Oregano|oregano]] * ¼ tsp [[Cookbook:Parsley|parsley]] * 1 clove of [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]], minced * 1 large [[Cookbook:Egg|egg]] * 125 b (4 oz - ¼ cup) breadcrumbs * 30 g (1 oz - 1 Tbs) grated grated [[Cookbook:Parmesan Cheese|Parmesan cheese]] * [[Cookbook:Salt|Salt]] and [[Cookbook:Pepper|pepper]], to taste * [[Cookbook:Olive Oil|Olive oil]] for frying
== Procedure == # Mix all ingredients together in a large bowl-best using your hands, squeeze all ingredients. # Heat large skillet over medium heat, drizzle on a little olive oil and preheat oven to 175°C (350°F) in the meantime. # Use your hands to roll meat into bite sized balls. # Place the meatballs in the skillet and cook uncovered for 3 minutes, roll them over and cook another three minutes. # Transfer the meatballs onto a baking sheet and bake in the oven for 20-25 minutes.
[[Category:Italian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Veal recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|Cuisine of the United States]] | [[Cookbook:Dessert|Dessert]] [[Image:SaucepanFudgeCrackleCookies.jpg|right|thumb|256px|Saucepan Fudge Crackle Cookies and milk]] These are true [[Cookbook:Chocolate|chocolate]] cookies. They are brownie-like or cake-like. They tend to have a dome-like surface that stands 1/2-inch to 3/4-inch tall, and have a diameter of 2.5 to 5 inches. The surface is cracked.
==Ingredients==
* 1 [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoon]] [[Cookbook:Baking Powder|baking powder]] * 1/4 teaspoon [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * 1/4 cup [[Cookbook:Margarine|margarine]] * 3 [[Cookbook:Ounce|ounces]] unsweetened [[Cookbook:Baking Chocolate|baking chocolate]] * 1 cup granulated [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] * 2 [[Cookbook:Egg|eggs]] * 1 teaspoon [[Cookbook:Vanilla|vanilla]] extract * 1/2 cup coarsely chopped [[Cookbook:Nut|nuts]] (for example, 1/2-inch [[Cookbook:Walnut|walnut]] pieces) * additional sugar for coating
==Procedure== #Mix the flour, baking powder, and salt. #In a 3-[[Cookbook:Quart|quart]] [[Cookbook:Saucepan|saucepan]] on low heat, melt together the margarine and chocolate. #Remove the chocolate mixture from the heat. #Into the chocolate mixture, mix the eggs, sugar, vanilla, and nuts. #Mix the flour mixture into the chocolate mixture. #Cover and refrigerate until firm. Overnight would be good. #Make 1.5-inch balls of the mixture. As you make them, roll them in coarse sugar and place them onto a cool, ungreased, insulated cookie sheet. Be sure to allow room for expansion. #Bake at [[Cookbook:Oven_temperatures|300°F]] for 20 minutes. #Immediately remove the cookies from the cookie sheet. If you delay, the cookies will very strongly adhere to the cookie sheet.
==Variation== The original used [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]], which contaminates the taste of the chocolate. The insulated cookie sheet is also a recent modification, added to avoid burning parts of the cookie while failing to fully cook other parts. [[Cookbook:Hazelnut|Hazelnuts]] and [[Cookbook:Macadamia Nut|macadamia nuts]] go well in this recipe.
[[Category:Cookie recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Chocolate recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:American recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Appetizer recipes|20|2 -2½ hours|2}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|American cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Holiday Recipes|Holiday Recipes]] | [[Cookbook:Snacks|Snacks]]
''This party food, or just anytime snack recipe was given me by my friend Marvin in Rocky Mount, North Carolina.''
==Ingredients==
===Dry ingredients:===
* 2 boxes Rice Chex * 1 box Wheat Chex * ⅔ box Cheerios * 1 bag thin pretzels * 1 [[Cookbook:Pound|pound]] [[Cookbook:Peanut|peanuts]] * 1 pound [[Cookbook:Pecan|pecans]] * 1 can [[Cookbook:Cashew|cashews]] * [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] to taste
===Sauce:===
* 3 sticks [[Cookbook:Margarine|margarine]] * Heaping ½ [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] [[Cookbook:Bacon|bacon grease]] * 1¾ to 2 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoons]] [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic salt]] * 2 tablespoons plus dash [[Cookbook:Worcestershire Sauce|Worcestershire sauce]] * Heaping ½ [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoon]] Accent * 2 heaping tablespoons [[Cookbook:Peanut Butter|peanut butter]]
==Procedure==
# Melt and mix the sauce ingredients. # Mix all dry ingredients, but salt, in a large canning pot. # Sprinkle a little of the sauce mixture over dry ingredients and shake. # Repeat until sauce is gone. # Salt the mixture by sprinkling and shaking in the same way. # [[Cookbook:Bake|Bake]] 1½ to 2 hours at [[Cookbook:Oven temperatures|200°F]] in covered canning pot. # Remove frequently to shake.
==Tips, Notes, and Variations==
* Put the sauce in a canning jar, and punch several holes in the lid. Sprinkle by turning the jar upside down. * It took up to seven times of sprinkling and shaking to salt the mixture. * OK, substitute some vegetable oil for the bacon grease, but it won't taste nearly as good!
==Uses==
* PARTY!
[[Category:Inexpensive recipes]] [[Category:American recipes]] [[Category:Appetizer recipes]] [[Category:Camping recipes]] [[Category:Bacon recipes]]

{{recipesummary|South Asian recipes|4|½ hour|3}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of India|Indian cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Chicken|Chicken]]
''My collegue Venayagaratnam ("Sri" from Sri Lanka) gave me this recipe, and I enjoyed it the first time I made it.''
==Ingredients==
* 1 large [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]], [[Cookbook:Chopping|chopped]] * 1 clove [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]], crushed (see Tips) * 1 small piece [[Cookbook:Ginger|fresh ginger]], crushed * 8 pieces [[Cookbook:Chicken|chicken]] thighs, cut up * 2 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoon]] [[Cookbook:Olive Oil|olive oil]] or other [[Cookbook:Vegetable oil|vegetable oil]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoon]] [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * 2 to 3 tablespoons [[Cookbook:Tandoori masala|butter chicken masala powder]] * 1½ [[Cookbook:Cup|cups]] [[Cookbook:Water|water]]
==Procedure==
# In a cooking vessel, put oil and chopped onion, and [[Cookbook:Sauté|sauté]] until light brown. # In medium-high temperature, add chicken and salt and leave for 3 to 5 minutes, stirring in between. # Add crushed ginger and garlic and stir for 2 minutes and add curry powder and stir and leave it for 2 minutes. # Add water and let it [[Cookbook:Boil|boil]] for 5 minutes. # After that reduce heat to low flame and let it cook for 15 minutes.
==Tips, Notes, and Variations==
* May substitute 1 teaspoon garlic powder for crushed garlic * It took me several minutes more than 15 to cook it down in the last step. * "Parampara" Butter Chicken Mix is the spice mix Sri found for me in an Indian food store in North Carolina's Triangle area.
[[Category:Sauce recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Chicken recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Garlic recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Ginger recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Onion recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

page.title: Cookbook:Chicago Sirloin with Cabernet Balsamic Reduction

revision.text:
{{recipe}}
This is a classically inspired steak recipe, with influences from both [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|American]] and [[Cookbook:European cuisines|European cuisine]].
==Ingredients==
* Two 8 [[Cookbook:Ounce|oz]] [[Cookbook:Beef|sirloin steaks]] * [[Cookbook:Montreal Steak Spice|Montreal steak spice]] * 1 cup [[Cookbook:Wine|Cabernet Sauvignon]] * 1 cup [[Cookbook:Vinegar|balsamic vinegar]] * 8-10 cloves of [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]] * ⅓ large white [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]] * 4 cloves [[Cookbook:Shallot|shallots]] * 2 tbsp extra virgin [[Cookbook:Olive Oil|olive oil]] * [[Cookbook:Pepper|pepper]]
==Procedure== # Dice the onion, shallots, and garlic. Set these aside. # Pre-heat a medium-sized [[Cookbook:Saucepan|saucepan]] to low-medium heat, and pre-heat the barbecue to high. # Throw the onions in the pan, and [[Cookbook:Sautéing|sauté]] until light yellow. # Place the shallots and garlic in as well, and sauté for a few minutes more. Make sure all ingredients are lightly crisped. # Pour in about ⅓ of the wine and ⅓ of the vinegar. Let this boil off at lower heat for about 5-10 minutes. # Place the steaks on the [[Cookbook:Barbecue|barbecue]], seasoning with the Montreal steak spice. # Add the rest of the wine and vinegar, grinding some fresh pepper on top. Boil off until you no longer smell the alcohol coming from the steaming wine. # Flip the steaks. You want them to be soft on the inside (cooked rare) yet quite charred on the outside, to get that charcoal flavor. # Once the sauce has gone down to about ⅓ of its original volume, take off heat. # Remove steaks from grill, and take inside.
Place the steaks on your plates, cover with the reduction, and serve!
You may wish to serve this flavorful dish with a side that would complement its strong flavors, such as [[Cookbook:Asparagus|asparagus]], new [[Cookbook:Potato|potatoes]], or roasted [[Cookbook:Brussels Sprout|Brussels sprouts]].
Serves two people.
[[Category:Midwestern recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Beef recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Expensive recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}}
This is a nice, light, cooling salad or side dish to have during the hottest summer months. That's when my mother would make it.
== Ingredients == * 2 [[Cookbook:Cucumber|cucumber]]s * 1 white [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]] * 2 [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]]s (480 [[Cookbook:mL|mL]]) distilled white [[Cookbook:Vinegar|vinegar]] * 2 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoon]]s (10 mL) [[Cookbook:Vegetable oil|vegetable oil]] * 1 teaspoon (5 mL) [[Cookbook:sugar|sugar]] * 1 teaspoon (5 mL) [[Cookbook:salt|salt]] * These are estimates and you should mix the marinade ingredients to taste
== Procedure ==
# Mix vinegar, oil, salt and sugar for the marinade. # Trim the ends from the cucumbers, peel them and slice them. # Peel the onion and slice it as thinly as possible. # Pour the marinade over the cucumbers and onions and mix well. # Let it sit in a cool place or refrigerate for at least two hours, stirring occasionally.
Serve in a bowl, marinade and all, using salad tongs or a slotted spoon to dish out servings.
==Notes, tips, and variations== * Any light salad oil may be used. Avoid olive oil as it congeals when refrigerated. * The cucumber to onion ratio should be from 2:1 to 2.5:1. * There should be just a hint of oil in the marinade and just enough sugar to take the edge off of the vinegar's tartness.
[[Category:Very Inexpensive recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Very Easy recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Salad recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|United States]] | [[Cookbook:Dessert|Dessert]]
==Ingredients== *½ cup (1 stick) of [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]] *[[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] (optional-add only if butter is unsalted) *1 tsp [[Cookbook:Baking Powder|baking powder]] *1 cup [[Cookbook:Flour|self-raising flour]] *1 cup [[Cookbook:Milk|milk]] *1 cup [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] *1 cup fresh [[Cookbook:Fruit|fruit]] ([[Cookbook:Peach|peaches]], [[Cookbook:Blackberry|blackberries]], [[Cookbook:Cherry|cherries]], etc.)
==Procedure==
# Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C). # Place the butter in a 9½" x 12" deep baking dish. Put dish in oven to melt butter while preparing other ingredients. If butter is unsalted, add a touch of salt to the pan as well. # Add flour and sugar to a bowl and sift together lightly. Create a 'well' in the center of the mixture and to this pour in the milk. Mix together with a wire whisk until smooth. # Remove pan from oven. Pour batter into dish on top of melted butter. Do not stir. Spoon the fresh fruit out evenly across the top, but again, do not stir. # Place cobbler in oven and bake uncovered until golden brown.
==See also== *[[Cookbook:Apple Cobbler|Apple Cobbler]] *[[Cookbook:Apple Crisp|Apple Crisp]] *[[Cookbook:Cherry Cobbler in a Crock Pot|Cherry Cobbler in a Crock Pot]] *[[Cookbook:Peach Cobbler|Peach Cobbler]] *[[Cookbook:Picante Peach Cobbler|Picante Peach Cobbler]]
[[Category:Dessert recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Cobbler recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:American recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

revision.comment: please help by writing a module in the Cookbook for digestive biscuits (perhaps linking to the Graham crackers module)
revision.text:
{{cookwork|needs baking temp}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Dessert|Dessert]] | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United Kingdom|UK Cuisine]]
These instructions will make a sticky and indulgent lemon meringue pie. If you want the normal gel-like centre, use the [[Cookbook:Lemon Meringue Pie|other recipe]] instead.
==Ingredients== Serves 4.
*8 [[Cookbook:Digestive Biscuit|digestive biscuits]] (plain/tea biscuits) *2 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|imperial tbsp]] (36 [[Cookbook:mL|mL]], 2.4 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|US tbsp.]]) [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]] *1 tin [[Cookbook:Condensed milk|sweetened condensed milk]] *1-2 [[Cookbook:Lemon|lemons]] *3 [[Cookbook:Egg|eggs]] (1 yolk, 3 whites) *6 imperial tbsp (108 mL, 7.2 US tbsp.) [[Cookbook:Superfine Sugar|caster sugar]]
==Procedure==
# Find a 10 inch (25cm) diameter pie dish about 1 inch deep (2.5cm). There are 3 layers to make. # Make the bottom layer by pounding the digestive biscuits into crumbs with the end of a [[Cookbook:Rolling Pin|rolling pin]]. Add sufficient melted butter to make the mixture cohere, mix well, then smooth it into the bottom of the pie dish. Press down firmly with the tip of a spoon to make the base. # Make the filling. Take a tin of sweetened condensed milk, and add the yolk of one egg. Stir gently, and add the lemon. Add the lemon to taste: more will be better, but be careful not to add too much or it will spoil the texture. Do not stir too much. Pour this into the pie dish, covering the biscuit layer. # Make the top. Whisk all 3 egg whites, then add the caster sugar, then whisk some more. Spoon the meringue mix into the pie dish, sealing around the edges. # Cook the result in a moderately cool oven for about 45 minutes until the meringue is a light golden brown. The aim is to cook the meringue and partly cook the centre (unlike, say, [[Cookbook:Baked Alaska|baked Alaska]], where only the top of the meringue is flash-cooked). Remove from the oven, allow to cool, and place in the refrigerator for 2 hours to set. Enjoy.
==Notes, tips, and variations== *There are 2 types of lemon meringue pie. The more common version has a lemon "gel" in the centre (which is often a luminous yellow colour), and a hard pastry base. The version above is much stickier. *In an earlier version, the centre used all 3 egg yolks. It isn't necessary, and it is more healthful to omit 2 of them.
==Warnings== *One pie may not be enough... *The acidity of the lemon acts on the protein in the egg yolk to thicken the filling. Therefore, the egg yolk must be added and mixed in ''before'' the lemon; otherwise, the egg-yolk will go "stringy" when it hits the acidic mixture. *If there are children present, it is practically impossible to keep them from licking the contents of the condensed milk tin! Be careful of the edges.
[[Category:Dessert recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Pie recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Lemon recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

revision.comment: copy edit, removed instruction from ingredients
revision.text:
{{recipe}} {{cookwork}}
'''Irish Potato bread''', also known as '''fadge''', '''slims''', '''potato cake''' or '''potato farls''', is a form of unleavened [[Cookbook:bread|bread]] in which [[Cookbook:potato|potato]] replaces a major portion of the regular wheat flour. It is usually cooked by baking it on a hot griddle or pan. It can be served with an [[Cookbook:Irish breakfast|Irish breakfast]] and in [[Cookbook:Northern Irish cuisine|Northern Ireland]], where it is colloquially known as 'Tatie Bread', it can form part of the [[Cookbook:Ulster fry|Ulster fry]]. In [[Cookbook:Scottish cuisine|Scotland]] potato bread is colloquially known as ''Totty Scone'' or ''[[Cookbook:Tattie Scone|Tattie Scone]]''.
This bread started out in the late nineteenth century as a means of making use of mashed potato leftovers, the potato being a staple part of the Irish diet.
== Ingredients == *225 g (8 oz) warm cooked [[Cookbook:potato|potato]], mashed *1/2 tsp [[Cookbook:salt|salt]] *25 g (1 oz) [[Cookbook:butter|butter]], melted *50 g (2 oz) plain [[Cookbook:flour|flour]]
==Procedure== #Add salt and butter, then work in enough flour to make a pliable dough. Divide the dough in two and roll out on a floured surface to form two circles 22 cm (9 in) in diameter and 5 mm (1/4 in) in thickness. #Cut each circle into quarters and [[Cookbook:bake|bake]] on a hot griddle or pan for about 5 minutes or until browned on both sides.
(Recipe from ''Ireland's Eye'')
==Notes, tips, and variations== *Some people like to grease the baking surface, while others prefer a light dusting of flour for a drier effect. *Commercial recipes tend to use potato flour/flakes instead of mashed potato and have little to no fat. They are traditionally sold as thin rectangular slices in packs of four. *Potato bread is usually sold in its original form, but there are some rare variations: *#'''[[Cookbook:Pratie Oaten|Pratie Oaten]]''', with fine [[Cookbook:oatmeal|oatmeal]] instead of flour in the recipe above for more texture. *#'''[[Cookbook:Apple Potato bread|Apple Potato bread]]''', a specialty of Armagh, which is famous for growing [[Cookbook:apple|apple]]s. Potato bread wrapped, [[Cookbook:pasty|pasty]]-like, around a sweet filling of apples.
== How to eat potato bread == Popular ways to eat potato bread: *Fried as part of the traditional fried breakfast, the Ulster Fry, which includes other breads that have been fried, such as [[Cookbook:Irish Soda Bread|Irish Soda Bread]]. *[[Cookbook:Toasted|Toasted]] and smothered with butter, and perhaps also cheese. *With [[Cookbook:baked beans|baked beans]] or [[Cookbook:egg|egg]]s as a children's meal.
== External links == *[http://www.irelandseye.com/aarticles/culture/recipes/baking/potbread.shtm Ireland's eye - potato bread recipe] *[http://www.irwinsbakery.com/pro-knowyerfarls.asp Irwin's Bakery - know yer farls]
[[Category:Bread recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Irish recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Northern Irish recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Potato recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]
