revision.text:
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Mexico|Mexican Cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Side dishes|Side dishes]]
Serves 4 as a meal, or 12 as a snack
==Ingredients== *1 [[Cookbook:Pound|pound]] lean ground [[Cookbook:Beef|beef]] (92% lean or better) *1 can diced tomatoes with [[Cookbook:Green Pepper|green chiles]] *2 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoons]] or less taco seasoning mix (mostly [[Cookbook:Cumin|cumin]]) *2 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoons]] [[Cookbook:Sour Cream|sour cream]] *1 dash [[Cookbook:Mexican Seasoning|Mexican seasoning]] *corn [[Cookbook:Tortilla Chip|tortilla chips]]
==Preparation== #In a [[Cookbook:Skillet|skillet]], [[Cookbook:Browning|brown]] ground beef with Mexican seasoning and Taco Mix. #When beef is browned add the can of diced tomatoes with green chiles, cover and allow to [[Cookbook:Simmer|simmer]] an additional 5 minutes. #Put tortilla chips on a large plate. Place 2 tablespoons of sour cream on plate. Sprinkle beef and diced tomato mixture over top of the chips. #Serve and enjoy.
[[Category:Beef recipes]] [[Category:Mexican recipes]] [[Category:Side Dish recipes]] [[Category:Sour Cream recipes]]

revision.comment: [[Cookbook:Bess Storm's Mincemeat]] moved to [[Cookbook:Mincemeat]]: naming per [[Cookbook:Policy]]
revision.text:
{{recipe}}
If mincemeat in your experience has been a sorry disappointment, as most meatless mincemeats are, try this extraordinary recipe.
==Ingredients== Spices: :*2 1/2 tsp ground cinnamon :*1/2 tsp ground nutmeg :*1.2 tsp ground cloves :*1 Tbsp dried coffee (regular or decaffinated) :*1 tsp salt :*1/2 tsp ground black pepper — added after cooking *4 c sugar *6-8 lbs. Baldwin apples *1 whole lemon, remove only the seeds *3 to 4 lbs. stew beef (neck, plate, etc.) *2 c seedless black raisins
Liquids: *1 c meat stock ( 1 1/2 c if not using brandy) *1 1/2c sorghum (health food stores often have it, but molasses is easier to find in the supermarkets) *1 c cider vinegar *1/2 to 3/4 c brandy (optional, but don’t risk ruination with cheap brandy)
==Procedure== 1. Core apples; remove the seeds, but don’t peel. :For heart-healthy mincemeat—with less flavor, alas,—remove the suet before cooking and skim off the fat that renders from the meat as it cooks.
2. Cube meat and cover with salted water (salt optional). Simmer until tender—may take up to an hour.
3. Remove meat and cook the stock down to the amount needed, or thicken slightly with (ugh!) cornstarch.
4. Put meat through food mill (medium or coarse blade) or equivalent fineness in a food processor. For texture, I definitely prefer the grinder over the processor.
5. Cut lemon, remove seeds, and puree in a blender, rind and all, with some of the liquid ingredients, or process as finely as possible in a food processor.
6. Grind the apples, (or process using a coarse blade—but not too fine; ‘taint an applesauce.)
7. Mix into a large, heavy bottom, stew pot adding alternately apples, meat, raisins.
8. Add the sugar, spices, the liquids and the lemon puree to the to the meat and apples using hot meat stock to rinse the last of the sorghum into the mixture. Stir thoroughly.
9. Cook slowly uncovered, stirring often to prevent burning until the mixture is pasteurized and enough of the liquids have evaporated to produce the texture and thickness you want in the finished pie.
10. Let cool.
11. Stir in the ground pepper.
12. Refrigerate, allowing the spices to mellow for several weeks ...or until you can’t hold out any longer.
==Further thoughts== The apples are the most important ingredient, without doubt. Insipid apples make lousy mincemeat. A sharp, crisp, flavor-laden “pie” apple is best—we are very partial to the late maturing Baldwins—but Cortlands are also good. (Granny Smiths are plenty crisp and tart, but fall short in flavor, we think.)
If you can’t find Baldwins or Cortlands, use the best pie apple you can find. And at their peak of flavor and texture in the autumn.
In our home, late October or early November is mincemeat time—so the mincemeat will be ready for the Holiday season. Ready? Yes, mincemeat at its best needs a few weeks to season in the refrigerator, say 6-8 weeks. The spices and flavors continue to mellow and will be just right for Thanksgiving and the coming holidays.
Will it keep? You bet! After all, the Pennsylvania Dutch ancestors had no freezers or refrigerators. Look at the ingredients: spices, sugar, vinegar—a cool storm cellar was good enough, ‘specially if you made a heap of it and put it in one of those many-gallon, stoneware crocks to age.
Anyway, by spring when the weather turned warm, the mincemeat would be gone. Those hungry midwestern farmer ancestors who passed this recipe down the generations wouldn’t have left a scrap to spoil.
After aging, make up mincemeat pies and tarts to freeze un-baked; they will keep for several months. Pop them straight from the freezer into a hot oven for easy baking.
What else to do with mincemeat? *Use as a hot topping for rich, vanilla ice cream; *Fancy, lettuce & cottage cheese salad with mincemeat topping *Or simply as cold topping for plain cottage cheese or yogurt (at Sunday brunch, perhaps)? *Classy peanut-butter/mincemeat sandwiches *Oatmeal cookies made with mincemeat and raisins *A spicy mincemeat chutney! Simple and quick: Just sauté 1/2 tsp. red pepper in a Tbsp. of butter for five minutes. Stir into a cup of mincemeat and there's your sweet and hot chutney. *Tart filling *On toast *Our own secret sin is cold pie with a glass of even colder milk... for breakfast, of course!
Let your imagination go. There’s really no limit with mincemeat, don't you know!
==Discussion==
In 1880 when Bess Storm's mother, Anna Frances Lynch, packed her little, brown-paper covered trunk for the trip from Boston to Iowa, she slipped in a small applewood box. In the box she had put a few pieces of jewelry and a few of her favorite recipes, including this one for mincemeat that had been in her family for as long as anyone could remember.
Anna said that her grandmother, a devout temperance worker, took out the brandy and substituted vinegar and coffee, a combination that gives this recipe a distinct taste of its own.
This recipe has been a favorite family tradition for well over 100 years. If there exists a better mincemeat, we have yet to find it. What makes it special? Maybe the brandy. Maybe the coffee. (Recent generations have substituted dried coffee to hold down the excess liquid and shorten cooking time.)
[[Category: Desserts]] [[Category: Lunch and Dinner]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Puerto Rico|Puerto Rican Cuisine]]
==Ingredients==
*1 Cup of Margarine *1 Cup of Sugar *½ Tsp. of salt *4 Cups of flour *2 Eggs *1 Tsp. of vanilla extract
==Procedure== #Pre-heat oven to 350° #Mix the margarine and the sugar in a mixing bowl until it has a creamy consistency. #Next add the vanilla extract, salt and eggs. #While mixing the ingredients add the flour and stir until it becomes hard to stir the mix. #Make small balls and place on a flat baking pan without grease. #Bake for 15-20 minutes or until golden.
[[Category:Puerto Rican recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Pie recipes|2 pies|2 to 3 hours|3}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|American cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Southern cuisine|Southern cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Vegetarian cuisine|Vegetarian Cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Holiday Recipes|Holiday Recipes]] | [[Cookbook:Dessert|Dessert]]
==Crust==
===Ingredients=== ''Makes one to two crusts.''
* 4 [[Cookbook:Cup|cups]] [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoon]] [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] * 2 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoons]] [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * 1¾ cups [[Cookbook:Shortening|shortening]] * ½ cup ice [[Cookbook:Water|water]] * 1 teaspoon [[Cookbook:Vinegar|vinegar]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Egg|egg]]
===Directions===
# Mix flour, sugar, and salt together. # Add shortening and mix until crumbly. # [[Cookbook:Beat|Beat]] together ice water, vinegar, and egg and cut into mix. # Divide into four balls. # Wrap and refrigerate for a half-hour before rolling out.
==Pie==
===Ingredients===
* 5 [[Cookbook:Pound|pounds]] [[Cookbook:Peach|peaches]] * 1 teaspoon [[Cookbook:Lemon Juice|lemon juice]] * ¼ teaspoon [[Cookbook:Almond|almond extract]] * 2 tablespoons flour * ½ teaspoon [[Cookbook:Cinnamon|cinnamon]] * ¼ teaspoon salt * 4 tablespoons [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]]
===Directions===
# Preheat [[Cookbook:Oven|oven]] to [[Cookbook:Oven temperatures|450°F]]. # Peel and slice peaches. # Pour into a bowl and mix in lemon juice and almond extract. # In a separate bowl, mix dry ingredients, and add to peach mixture. # Pour into crust and dot with butter. # [[Cookbook:Baking|Bake]] at 450°F for 15 minutes, then 350°F for 35 to 40 minutes.
[[Category:Inexpensive recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Southern recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Pie recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Peach recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Cinnamon recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Dessert|Desserts]] [[Image:Nanaimo bar.JPG|thumb|Traditional Nanaimo Bars]] '''Nanaimo Bars''' are a layered chocolate and custard desert named after the mining town, Nanaimo, British Columbia, Canada. This winning recipe was submitted by Joyce Hardcastle in 1986 when the City of Nanaimo and Harbour Park Mall had a contest to find the best Nanaimo Bar recipe. Variations of this recipe include using different nuts and/or adding flavours to the custard layer. == Ingredients == Bottom Layer * ½ Cup unsalted [[Cookbook:butter|butter]] (European style cultured) * ¼ Cup [[Cookbook:sugar|sugar]] * 5 Tbsp. [[Cookbook:cocoa|cocoa]] * 1 [[Cookbook:egg|egg]] beaten * 1 ¼ Cups [[Cookbook:Graham Cracker|Graham wafer]] crumbs * ½ Cups finely chopped [[Cookbook:almond|almonds]] * 1 Cup [[Cookbook:coconut|coconut]] Middle Layer * ½ Cup unsalted [[Cookbook:butter|butter]] * 2 Tbsp. and 2 Tsp. [[Cookbook:cream|cream]] * 2 Tbsp. vanilla [[Cookbook:custard|custard]] powder * 2 Cups [[Cookbook:Powdered Sugar|icing sugar]] Top Layer * 4 squares semi-sweet [[Cookbook:chocolate|chocolate]] (1 Oz. each) * 2 Tbsp. unsalted [[Cookbook:butter|butter]] == Procedure == Bottom Layer #Melt first 3 ingredients in top of [[Cookbook:Double Boiler|double boiler]]. #Add egg and stir to cook and thicken. #Remove from heat. Stir in crumbs, coconut, and nuts. #Press firmly into an ungreased 8" x 8" pan. Middle Layer #Cream butter, cream, custard powder, and icing sugar together well. Beat until light. #Spread over bottom layer. Top Layer #Melt chocolate and butter over low heat. Cool. #Once cool, but still liquid, pour over second layer and chill in refrigerator. Once set, cut into squares and serve. Enjoy. [[Category:Canadian recipes]] [[Category:Almond recipes]] [[Category:Dessert recipes]]

{{cookwork|Needs copy editing}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Israel|Israel]] | [[Cookbook:Palestinian Cuisine|Palestine]] [[Image:Kibbeh.jpg|right|thumb|Kibbeh]]
==Ingredients== * Half kilo (500 [[Cookbook:Gram|g]]) of thin [[Cookbook:Bulgur|Bulgur]] * Half kilo of thick Bulgur * 2-2.5 glasses of [[Cookbook:Semolina|semolina]] * [[Cookbook:Water|water]] as needed
===For the filling=== * 1 [[Cookbook:kg|kg]] of [[Cookbook:Mincing|minced]] [[Cookbook:Meat|meat]] * 6-7 cut fried [[Cookbook:Onion|onions]] * [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * [[Cookbook:Raisin|raisins]] (optional) * [[Cookbook:Pine Nut|pine nuts]] (optional) * spicy [[Cookbook:Paprika|paprika]] or [[Cookbook:Chili Powder|chili]] (optional) * [[Cookbook:Turmeric|Turmeric]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Egg|egg]]
==Procedure== # Add the meat to the onion and fry, adding 1 spoon of flavor to the cutlets of Bulgur that to the meat. # Put both types of the Bulgur together, fill with warm water that will cover the Bulgur in several centimeters, and leave it for about an hour until part of the water is absorbed into the Bulgur. # Take every time a handful and squeeze properly and put it in a different bowls until everything is finished, then pour off all the remaining water and return all the squeezed wheatgroats into the big bowl. # Put 2 glasses of semolina, one teaspoon of Turmeric, a replete spoon of salt, and one egg, and massage everything together with your hands, including closing the hand fists until the dough gets a little like chewing gum. If semolina is missing, it is possible to add a little more to it according to the need, until we would get a sticky dough. # Create big balls of dough and put them aside. # Open every ball of dough and insert a full spoon of the meat and close. # Boil water in a pot with a little salt and Turmeric. When the water has boiled up, flatten every ball in the meat that we got in a somewhat shape of a flat full moon in the size of little plate. Put it gently in the boiling water until the Kibbeh will float, and this will be the sign that it is ready.
Kibbeh can be eaten immediately as it gets ready, or [[Cookbook:Pan Frying|pan fried]] on both sides.
''Absolutely delicious.''
[[Category:Middle Eastern recipes]]
[[he:ספר מתכונים/קובה בורגול]]

{{recipe}} {{recipesummary|Cheese recipes|6 |15-20 minutes|}}
==Ingredients== *12 prepared crepes *1 1/2 cups shredded Cheddar cheese *12 slices cooked, thinly sliced ham *2 tablespoons finely chopped green onion *1/2 teaspoon salt *1/8 teaspoon pepper *1/2 cup sour cream *1/2 teaspoon prepared mustard *1/3 cup bread crumbs *3 tablespoons melted butter
==Preparation== # Preheat oven to 350 degrees F. # In small bowl, combine onion, salt, pepper, sour cream and mustard and mix well. Spread about 1 tbsp. of the mixture over the ham. # Roll up and arrange in 13x9-inch baking pan. # Combine butter and bread crumbs and sprinkle over crepes. # Cover pan loosely with foil. # Bake for 15 to 20 minutes
[[Category:Cheese recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Appetizer recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{DEFAULTSORT:{{{PAGENAME}}}}} {{recipe}} '''Caramel Squares''' or Caramel Shortbread are a wonderfully rich and classic treat, very popular all over [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United Kingdom|Britain]] and [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Ireland|Ireland]]. They can often be found in cafes, served with morning coffee or afternoon tea. They're perfect for [[Cookbook:picnic|picnic]]s, lunches and your guests will love them! They have a crunchy base with a creamy caramel filling, topped off with chocolate. == Ingredients == Makes 8 - 12 squares ;Base *350g [[Cookbook:Self raising flour|Self raising flour]] *225g unsalted [[Cookbook:butter|butter]] *110g [[Cookbook:caster sugar|caster sugar]] ;Filling *225g [[Cookbook:Caster sugar|Caster sugar]] *225g unsalted [[Cookbook:butter|butter]] *5 Tablespoons [[Cookbook:golden syrup|golden syrup]] *397ml tin full cream [[Cookbook:condensed milk|condensed milk]] ;Topping *340g good quality [[Cookbook:chocolate|chocolate]] (milk or dark), melted ==Procedure== #For the shortbread, preheat the oven to 180 °C (gas mark 4). Rub flour butter and caster sugar together until it resembles breadcrumbs. #Press into a 25 cm x 38 cm x 4 cm swiss roll tin. #[[Cookbook:Bake|Bake]] for 20 minutes or till golden.
#For the filling, melt butter in a heavy based [[Cookbook:saucepan|saucepan]] over a low heat; add sugar, golden syrup and condensed milk. #Stir continuously for 40 - 50 minutes. It should be golden brown in colour when ready to eat. #To test drop a little blob into a bowl of cold water; it should firm up. #Pour this mixture over the base and let it cool.
#Pour over the melted chocolate and let set. [[Category:Irish recipes]] [[Category:English recipes]] [[Category:Cake recipes]]

{{recipe|Aebleskiver}} [[Image:Aebleskiver.jpg|thumb|right|Æbleskiver.]]
'''Æbleskiver''' (Danish meaning ''apple slices'' in English (singular: ''æbleskive'')) are traditional [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Denmark|Danish]] [[Cookbook:cake|cake]]s, somewhat similar in texture to [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|American]] [[Cookbook:Pancake|pancakes]]. Æbleskiver are cooked in a special æbleskive pan, a [[Cookbook:Pots and Pans#Cast Iron|cast-iron pan]] with several hemispherical indentations in the bottom of the pan.
The English language spelling is usually '''ebleskiver''' or '''aebleskiver'''.
There are many recipes for æbleskiver. The following is offered as an example.
== Ingredients == * 2 [[Cookbook:Egg White|egg white]]s * 2 cups all-purpose [[Cookbook:flour|flour]] * 2 teaspoons [[Cookbook:Baking Powder|baking powder]] * 1 tablespoon [[Cookbook:white sugar|white sugar]] * ½ teaspoon [[Cookbook:Baking Soda|baking soda]] * ½ teaspoon [[Cookbook:salt|salt]] * 4 tablespoons [[Cookbook:butter|butter]], melted * 2 cups [[Cookbook:buttermilk|buttermilk]] * 1 cup [[Cookbook:vegetable oil|vegetable oil]], for [[Cookbook:frying|frying]]
== Directions == #Beat the whites stiff. #Mix together the flour, baking powder, salt, baking soda, sugar, melted butter and buttermilk at one time and beat until smooth. Gently fold in the egg whites last. #Put about 1 tablespoon of vegetable oil in the bottom of each æbleskiver pan cup and heat until hot. Pour in about 2 tablespoons of the batter into each cup. #As soon as they get bubbly around the edge, turn them quickly. Alternatively, you can turn them halfway first, so that the baked crusts protruding from the pan will look like the [[w:Sydney Opera House|Sydney Opera House]]. And after a while you turn them the remaining 90°. This will give them a perfect ball-shape. (Danish cooks use a long knitting needle, but a fork will work). Continue cooking, turning the ball to keep it from burning.
==Notes, tips, and variations== *An æbleskiver pan is '''required''' to cook these properly. *They were traditionally cooked with bits of [[Cookbook:apple|apple]] (''æble'') or [[Cookbook:applesauce|applesauce]] inside but these ingredients are not normally included in modern Danish forms of the dish. *Æbleskiver are not sweet themselves but are traditionally sprinkled with [[Cookbook:Powdered Sugar|powdered sugar]], accompanied with [[Cookbook:raspberry|raspberry]] or sometimes [[Cookbook:strawberry|strawberry]] [[Cookbook:jam|jam]], and served with ''gløgg''.
==External links== *[http://www.solvangrestaurant.com/aebleskiver.html The Story of Aebleskiver] (Solvang Restaurant, Solvang, California) *[http://www.aebleskiver.net/ Information and Recipes]
[[Category:Danish recipes]] [[Category:Pancake recipes]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes]]

{{recipesummary|Eggplant recipes|2 persons|15 mins|2}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Japan|Japanese Cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Vegetarian cuisine|Vegetarian]]
== Ingredients ==
* 1 large (375g) [[Cookbook:Eggplant|aubergine]] (eggplant) * [[Cookbook:Vegetable oil|vegetable oil]] * 2 tablespoons [[Cookbook:Miso|miso]] * 1.5 tablespoons [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] * 2 tablespoons soup [[Cookbook:Stock|stock]] * 1 teaspoon white [[Cookbook:Sesame Seed|sesame seeds]]
== Procedure == # Wash the aubergine and cut it into 2.5cm lengthways slices. # Brush the cut surfaces with oil. # Grill 7 – 10 cm from the source of the heat until the aubergine is tender and browned all over (about 5 minutes). # In a small saucepan combine the miso, sugar and soup stock and cook, stirring, over low heat until the mixture is smooth and hot. Do not let it boil. # Pour the sauce mixture over the aubergine. # In a small frying pan toast the sesame seeds until they jump and sprinkle them over the aubergine.
[[Category:Japanese recipes]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes]] [[Category:Eggplant recipes]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of China|Chinese Cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Vegetarian cuisine|Vegetarian]]
{{recipesummary|Taro recipes|4 persons|20 mins|3}}
== Ingredients == * 1 small [[Cookbook:Taro|taro]] * 2 sheets [[Cookbook:Nori|nori]] * 1 tsp preserved black beans * 2 inch piece of [[Cookbook:Ginger|ginger]] * 1 green pepper * 2 spring onions * 1 tsp vegetable stock powder * 2 tbsp Shaoxing rice wine * vegetable oil
== Procedure == # Peel and chop taro into 1 inch chunks and steam until soft. # Meanwhile soak black beans in a little water. # Mash taro with the vegetable stock powder. # Place two sheets of nori on the bench, moistening one to join them together. # Place the mashed taro mixture in the centre of the sheets and roll the nori sheets over the top. # Cut the nori at one end to resemble fish fins. # Slice green pepper, ginger and spring onions into thin strips and stir fry for a few minutes. # Add the Shaoxing and black beans. # Make cuts halfway through the taro fish at about 1 inch intervals and pour the sauce over it. # Serve on a platter.
[[Category:Chinese recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Taro recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}}
== Ingredients == * 300g [[Cookbook:Broad Bean|broad beans]] (fresh or canned) * 1 [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]] * 2 strips of [[Cookbook:Ham|ham]] or [[Cookbook:Bacon|bacon]] (or [[Cookbook:Vegetarian cuisine|vegetarian]] bacon) * [[Cookbook:Olive Oil|olive oil]]
== Procedure == # Slice the onion. # Fry in olive oil with the ham. # Add the broad beans and [[Cookbook:Sautéing|sauté]] for a few minutes until the beans are soft.
[[Category:Spanish recipes]] [[Category:Bean recipes]] [[Category:Ham recipes]]

revision.comment: Reverted edit of [[Special:Contributions/97.96.106.216|97.96.106.216]], changed back to last version by 66.58.135.126
revision.text:
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Breakfast Recipes|Breakfast]] [[Image:Hard boiled egg.jpg|right|thumb|Inside a hard-boiled egg]]
==Ingredients== *any number of [[Cookbook:Egg|eggs]]
===Warnings===
* Unwashed eggs will keep 4-5 weeks in the coldest part of the refrigerator (NEVER in the door!) * Boiled or washed eggs will only keep about a week-the protective cover over the shell is gone. * Look at your eggs BEFORE you put them in your grocery cart! Never buy cracked or even dirty eggs. * Eggs left out too long should not be eaten, i.e., Easter eggs are left out...
==Method== # Put the eggs in a [[Cookbook:Saucepan|pot]]. # Fill pot with [[Cookbook:Water|water]]. Make sure that the tops of the eggs at covered by at least 25 mm (one inch). # Bring to a rolling [[Cookbook:Boiling|boil]]. # Reduce heat to a low boil. # Cook for 10 minutes. # Drain the pot. # Cool eggs immediately by running cold water over them or putting in iced water. # Crack and peel the eggs under very cold running water, starting by cracking the large (air pocket) end, then taking off the largest pieces first. Lowering the eggs' temperature keeps the shells from sticking, and prevents the greenish tinge sometimes seen on hard-boiled eggs. (The greenish tinge doesn't affect taste or safety.)
===Tips, Notes, and Variations===
* An alternate method is to turn off the heat, cover the pot, and let stand 15 or 18 minutes. * Salt in the water can help keep egg white from seeping out of a crack. * Multiple layers of eggs in the pot are more likely to crack: use only a single layer and do another batch. * Older eggs will be easier to peel, as the air space is larger. * If the peeling becomes tragic, you can always make egg salad!
[[Category:Ingredients]] [[Category:Egg recipes]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Romania|Cuisine of Romania]]
==Ingredients== * [[Cookbook:Eggplant|eggplant]] * [[Cookbook:Oil|oil]] * [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] a medium onion
==Equipment== * [[Cookbook:Frying Pan|pan]] * [[Cookbook:Fork|fork]] * [[Cookbook:Chef's Knife|chopper]] * [[Cookbook:Cutting Board|chopping board]] * [[Cookbook:Mixing Bowl|bowl]]
==Procedure== # Take one eggplant or more roast it in a old pan with oil. It is advisable that the pan would have ribs so that eggplant won't be cooking in its own juices. # During the roasting, make holes in the eggplant with a fork, the steam accumulates in it and needs to get out. # After the eggplant is absolutely soft and most of its peel is blackened, put the eggplant on a board and cut it lengthwise. Keep the flesh of the eggplant and remove all the burned skin. # [[Cookbook:Mincing|Mince]] the eggplant with a knife to a [[Cookbook:Purée|purée]], keeping the seeds whole. The cutting should be done with a stainless steel chopper or wooden chopper. (In my opinion it is best to use a stainless steel chopper). # Pass the roasted eggplant into a glass or plastic bowl and add between half a spoon to one full spoon of oil for every eggplant, and salt according to ones own taste. Then chop the onion in small pieces and add it in the eggplant salad. # Store in the refrigerator until serving time.
[[Category:Romanian recipes]] [[Category:Eggplant recipes]]
[[he:ספר מתכונים/חצילים קלויים]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of India|Cuisine of India]]
'''Aam panna''' is a green mango drink widely consumed in northern India during summer months. Apart from being delicious and refreshing, aam panna is believed to have several health benefits.
The recipe calls for green mangoes, sugar, rock salt, roasted cumin seeds and mint leaves. The quantities can (and should) be varied to suit individual taste preferences. This recipe yields a concentrate which can be stored for around 2 weeks in the refrigerator.
== Ingredients == *4 medium-sized green [[Cookbook:Mango|mangoes]] *½ cup [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] *2 level tablespoons [[Cookbook:Salt|rock salt]] *1 level teaspoon roasted [[Cookbook:Cumin|cumin]] seeds *A pinch of [[Cookbook:Chili Powder|red chilli powder]] / flakes *A handful of fresh [[Cookbook:Mint|mint]] leaves
== Procedure == #Cut mangoes into 3 slices each - two from either side of the seed and one with the seed in it. #[[Cookbook:Pressure Cooking|Pressure cook]] mangoes with one small cup of water. Turn off heat as soon as the pressure cooker whistles once. #Open cooker after 5-7 minutes and leave to cool. #Grind sugar and roasted cumin seeds using a [[Cookbook:Food Processor|food processor]]. (If using chilli flakes, grind that too.) #Mince mint leaves in a food processor. #When cool, squeeze pulp of mangoes into a [[Cookbook:Blender|blender]] using hands. Discard skin and seeds. #[[Cookbook:Purée|Purée]] mango pulp until smooth. #Add ground sugar, rock salt, roasted cumin leaves, chilli powder and minced mint leaves. Blend well. #Store in clean plastic/ glass bottle. Refrigerate.
To serve, add 4-5 teaspoons of concentrate to a glass of water. Enjoy!
{{Wikipedia|Aam panna}} [[Category:Beverage recipes]] [[Category:Indian recipes]] [[Category:Mango recipes]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes]] [[Category:Vegan recipes]]

{{recipesummary|Salad recipes|12|overnight|2}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Frog's_Eye_Salad|Frog's Eye Salad]]
==Ingredients==
*1 pkg [[Wikipedia:Acini di pepe|Acini di pepe]] *2 cans (15-20oz each) crushed [[Cookbook:Pineapple|pineapple]] *2 cans (15-20oz each) mandarin [[Cookbook:Orange|oranges]] *3 [[Cookbook:Egg yolk|egg yolks]] *1 [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] (240 [[Cookbook:mL|mL]]) [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] *1 tub [[Wikipedia:Whipped topping|whipped topping]] *1/2 pkg miniature [[Wikipedia:marshmallows|marshmallows]]
==Procedure== #Cook pasta in a large [[Cookbook:Saucepan|saucepan]]. #Drain & rinse pasta. #Drain cans of pineapple and oranges, reserving juice. #Mix juices, sugar and egg yolks in a medium saucepan. #Bring to full rolling boil then Pour over pasta. #Refrigerate overnight. #Next day, add fruit and mix well. #Fold in Cool Whip and marshmallows.
==Notes, tips, and variations== *Keep refrigerated *Lasts for several weeks
[[Category:Salad recipes]]

{{recipe}}
This a very easy and tasty [[Cookbook:Pasta|pasta]] [[Cookbook:Sauces|sauce]]. It's good with just pasta, and goes well with a lot of vegetables as well. The quantities of ingredients varies with the amount of pasta, and with your taste preferences.
== Ingredients == *[[Cookbook:Olive Oil|olive oil]] *[[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]] cloves *ripe [[Cookbook:Tomato|tomatoes]] *[[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] *ground [[Cookbook:Pepper|black pepper]] *fresh [[Cookbook:Cream|cream]] *[[Cookbook:Oregano|oregano]]
== Procedure == #Finely chop tomatoes or [[Cookbook:Purée|purée]] them in a [[Cookbook:Food Processor|food processor]] - this depends on what consistency you want. Chopping gives a chunkier sauce while using puréed tomatoes yields a smoother sauce. #Grind garlic to paste. #Heat oil in a pan. Using a pan with non-stick coating needs less oil. #When oil is hot (but not too hot), turn down heat and add garlic paste. #When garlic is golden-brown, add tomatoes. #Tomatoes have to be cooked until done - they'll look and smell cooked instead of raw, and will be a deeper, redder colour. #Half way there, add salt and pepper. #When tomatoes are almost done, add fresh cream (more if you want, but less is good too). #After half a minute, add oregano. #Cook for another minute, and your pasta sauce is ready. #Add cooked pasta and vegetables and serve hot.
[[Category:Pasta sauces]] [[Category:Tomato recipes]] [[Category:Garlic recipes]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Ethiopia|Cuisine of Ethiopia]]
'''Shiro wat''', sometimes '''shiro wet''', is a traditional Ethiopian Jewish pea stew.
==Ingredients== * ½ cup chopped [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]] * ¼ cup [[Cookbook:Oil|oil]] * 2 spoons [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]] (optional) * 4 spoon [[Cookbook:Berbere|berberei]] (a spice mix with [[Cookbook:Chili Powder|red pepper powder]]) * 4 spoon ''shiro powder'' (made from different cereals and beans, typically [[Cookbook:Pea|split green peas]]) * 2½ cups [[Cookbook:Water|water]]
==Procedure== # Take a medium-size cooking pan, add the onion and cook for 1 or 2 minutes. # Add the oil, and after 1 minute add berberei, then cook it for 4 or five minutes (use water if it tries to stick on the pan, and stir regularly). # Add 2½ cups of water. # When the water boils, add the shiro carefully stirring it in the pan; it should not make lumps. Then cook it for 5 minutes, stirring it regularly. # Finally, add salt and the butter, and after 2 or 3 minute remove it from the heat.
It can be served hot or cold with [[Cookbook:Injera|injera]].
==Notes, tips and variations== * Shiro powder can be bought from Ethiopian grocers. * Alternatively, split green peas can be used. Just extend the simmering period until the peas are tender and fall apart.
[[Category:Ethiopian recipes]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes]] [[Category:Gluten-free recipes]] [[Category:Low-GI recipes]] [[Category:Pea recipes]]

{{recipesummary | Servings = 2½ quarts | Category = Beverage recipes }} {{recipe}}
{{raw-eggs}}
== Ingredients == * 6 [[Cookbook:Egg|eggs]] * 240ml (1 cup + 1 tablespoon) [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] * 2ml (½ teaspoon) [[Cookbook:Vanilla|vanilla extract]] * 1ml ground (¼ teaspoon) [[Cookbook:Nutmeg|nutmeg]] * 180ml (¾ cup) [[Cookbook:Brandy|brandy]] * 80ml (⅓ cup) dark [[Cookbook:Rum|rum]] * 480ml (2 cups) cups [[Cookbook:Cream|whipping cream]] * 480ml (2 cups) [[Cookbook:Milk|milk]]
All liquids should be very cold. Refrigerate in advance.
== Procedure == # Beat the eggs for 2 or 3 minutes with an electric mixer at medium speed until very frothy. # Gradually beat in the sugar, vanilla and nutmeg. # Turn the mixer off and stir in the cold brandy, rum, whipping cream and milk. # Chill. # To serve, sprinkle individual servings with more nutmeg.
Makes about 2-1/2 quarts.
== Notes, tips, and variations == {{Wikipedia|Eggnog}} * Separate ''egg yolks'' from ''egg whites''. *# Beat ''egg yolks'' first, allowing them to lighten in color. *# Gradually beat in ''1 cup sugar'', vanilla and nutmeg (per step 2 of main recipe above). *# Turn the mixer off and add liquids (per step 3 of main recipe above). *# Beat ''egg whites'' separately, adding ''1 T sugar'' when peaks form. Continue beating until peaks stiffen. *# Whisk ''egg whites'' into the main mixture. *# Chill and serve (per steps 4 and 5 of main recipe above). * Cooked Eggnog: *# Heat milk/cream to scalding temp. *# [[Cookbook:Tempering|Temper]] beaten/sweetened egg yolks with milk, before mixing the two.
[[Category:Beverage recipes]] [[Category:Egg recipes]] [[Category:Dairy recipes]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Indonesia|Cuisine of Indonesia]] [[Image:Tempe mendoan fried tempeh.jpg|right|thumb|Tempe Mendoan]]
'''Tempe Mendoan''' is a kind of tempeh cooking that is made from thin tempeh, fried with flour so as to taste deliciously piquant. Traditionally in the Banyumas territory, tempe mendoan was made from thin, wide tempeh, one or two sheets cooked at a time. However, tempe mendoan also could be made from normal tempeh that was sliced very thin but wide.
==Ingredients== * 300 [[Cookbook:Gram|g]] [[Cookbook:Tempeh|tempeh]], size 10×15 cm * 2 pieces [[Cookbook:Green onion|green onion]], slice thinly * 199 g [[Cookbook:Rice Flour|rice flour]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tbs]] [[Cookbook:Flour#Wheat Flour|wheat flour]] * 125 [[Cookbook:mL|ml]] [[Cookbook:Water|water]] * ½ ml [[Cookbook:Oil|cooking oil]]
===For grinding=== * 2 cloves of [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]] * 1 piece [[Cookbook:Shallot|shallot]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|tsp]]. [[Cookbook:Coriander|coriander]] * ¼ tsp. [[Cookbook:Pepper|white pepper]] * 2 tsp. [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]]
==Procedure== # Mix well: the two kinds of flour, all ground ingredients, water, and green onion, mix well into a liquid dough. # Dip each piece of tempeh into the liquid dough until all surfaces are covered # Warm the oil in a frying pan, and put it on the stove until hot. Put each piece of coated tempeh into hot oil. # [[Cookbook:Deep Fat Frying|Fry]] the tempehs, and waiting it becomes hardened and well done. Please don't wait until it becomes yellow and crispy. Take out the tempeh from the warm oil. Let the oil drip from the tempeh so that there is not much oil on it. # Served tempeh with [[Cookbook:Soy Sauce|soy bean sauce]] and sliced small [[Cookbook:Chili Pepper|chilies]].
Serves 12.
==Variation==
===Ingredients=== * 250 g [[Cookbook:Tempeh|tempeh]], sliced into pieces 10×6×1 cm * 75 g [[Cookbook:Rice Flour|rice flour]] * 25 g [[Cookbook:Tapioca Starch|tapioca starch]] * 3 pieces [[Cookbook:Green onion|green onion]] * 125 ml [[Cookbook:Water|water]]
===For grinding=== * 2 tsp. [[Cookbook:Coriander|coriander]] * 1 piece [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]] * 1 cm greater [[Cookbook:Galangal|galingale]] * add salt according to taste
===Procedure===
# Put together the two kinds of flour and the ground ingredients. # Add water little by little until it forms a liquid dough. Mix together until it forms a smooth and complete mix. # Add the sliced green onion. # Warm the cooking oil in the frying pan. # Dip the tempeh into the dough. # Insert the tempeh into the hot oil, and fry it until done. # Take it out from the oil and serve it with small chilies.
[[Category:Indonesian recipes]] [[Category:Soy recipes]] [[Category:Fried recipes]]
[[id:Resep:Tempe Mendoan]]

{{recipe}}
Like the traditional [[Cookbook:Spanish_Omelet|Spanish omelet]], the frittata is a thick, hearty omelet filled with vegetables. A frittata may be filled with any variety of vegetables, cheeses, pastas, or meats. This recipe is for a simple vegetarian one.
==Ingredients== * 1 tablespoon [[Cookbook:Olive Oil|olive oil]] * 2 [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]] cloves, [[Cookbook:Mincing|minced]] * 1 bunch of fresh [[Cookbook:Asparagus|asparagus]], trimmed and chopped * 8 large [[Cookbook:Egg|eggs]] * 3 teaspoons of [[Cookbook:Milk|milk]] (whole fat milk is best, but part skim would be fine.) * 2 teaspoons of chopped fresh [[Cookbook:Basil|basil]] or 1 teaspoon dried basil * pinch of [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * pinch of ground [[Cookbook:Pepper|black pepper]] * 3 tablespoons of [[Cookbook:Parmesan Cheese|Parmesan cheese]], grated
==Equipment== *12-inch (30cm) oven-safe [[Cookbook:Frying Pan|frying pan]] (i.e. no plastic or wooden handles) *medium bowl *[[Cookbook:Whisk|whisk]] or fork
==Procedure== # In a bowl, beat together the eggs, milk, basil, salt and pepper. Set aside. # Preheat broiler. Heat the olive oil in a large, heat-safe skillet over medium heat. # When the oil is hot, add the garlic and sauté until fragrant, about a minute. # Add the chopped asparagus and sauté for about 5 minutes until it begins to become tender. # Pour the egg mixture into the skillet and cook about 4 minutes or until bubbles begin to form in the center of the eggs. # Sprinkle the Parmesan cheese on top of the eggs and immediately transfer the pan to the oven. # Cook under the broiler until the top puffs and browns, about 3 minutes. # Remove the pan from the oven (careful, it will be hot!) and cut the frittata into wedges.
Serve immediately with crusty bread and fresh fruit for a light spring dinner. Wrap leftovers (if there are any) in tin foil and chill in refrigerator. Leftover frittata makes a great sandwich: just allow the eggs to come to room temperature and place them between two slices of buttered, toasted bread.
Serves 2.
==Variations== * Try bitter greens like [[Cookbook:Swiss Chard|Swiss chard]], ruby chard, or [[Cookbook:Broccoli rabe|broccoli rabe]]. * [[Cookbook:Bell Pepper|Bell peppers]], [[Cookbook:Mushroom|mushrooms]], [[Cookbook:Potato|potatoes]], and [[Cookbook:Zucchini|zucchini]] are all delicious in a frittata. * For a meat version, try adding cubed [[Cookbook:Ham|ham]], chopped [[Cookbook:Bacon|bacon]] or [[Cookbook:Pancetta|pancetta]], or any variety of [[Cookbook:Sausage|sausage]]. * Different cheeses can be used, such as fontina, cheddar, havarti, Emmenthal, or Pecorino Romano. * For a heartier frittata, you may also add half a cup of cooked, drained [[Cookbook:Pasta|pasta]] such as linguine, spaghetti, or even macaroni. * Adding breadcrumbs to the beaten eggs is another good way of adding bulk.
Really, the possibilities are endless.
[[Category:Egg recipes]] [[Category:Omelette recipes]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes]] [[Category:Asparagus recipes]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Hungary|Cuisine of Hungary]]
'''Rakott Krumpli''' (potato casserole) is a traditional meal eaten by Hungarian Jews during the ''"nine days"''. These are the first nine days of the month of Av, when orthodox Jews refrain from eating meat, in remembrance of the destruction of the Temple.
==Ingredients== * 6 medium [[Cookbook:Potato|potatoes]] * 4 [[Cookbook:Hard Boiled Eggs|hard boiled eggs]] * 1 lbs Kolbasz (Hungarian sausage) * 350 grams [[Cookbook:Sour Cream|sour cream]] * [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] to taste
==Procedure== # Cook the potatoes for about twenty five minutes. # Peel the potatoes and the eggs. # Slice eggs, potatoes and kolbasz into thick slices and arrange in alternating layers of potatoes, eggs then kolbasz, with sour cream on the top. # Bake in a preheated oven at 220°C for about 35 minutes or until they turn a light brown.
==Notes, tips and variations== * Jewish Hungarians would likely leave out the Kolbasz. Aside from the fact that Hungarian sausage (kolbasz) is made from pork, our Jewish brethren would certainly not be combining any meat with the dairy sour cream (unless they are not strictly observant).
[[Category:Yiddish recipes]] [[Category:Hungarian recipes]] [[Category:Egg recipes]] [[Category:Potato recipes]]

{{recipesummary|Breakfast recipes|1|7 minutes|2|[[Image:Boiled eggs.jpg|300px]]|190 Cal (2 eggs)}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Breakfast Recipes|Breakfast]]
'''Soft boiled eggs''', a nice way to eat poached eggs without a plate, takes about 7 minutes to prepare. Often served with buttered toast, perfect for dipping into the runny yolk.
==Ingredients== *2 or 3 large [[Cookbook:Egg|eggs]], depending on appetite *[[Cookbook:Salt|Salt]] and [[Cookbook:Pepper|pepper]] to taste
==Equipment== *A small [[Cookbook:Saucepan|saucepan]] (1 - 2 [[Cookbook:Quart|quarts]] / [[Cookbook:Liter|litres]]) *A small spoon or [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoon]] *Gas or electric stove, at medium-high to high heat *A sharp pin or tack (optional - see method 2) *A [[Cookbook:Slotted Spoon|slotted spoon]] (optional - see method 2)
==Procedure==
There are several popular ways to make soft boiled eggs. Here are the most common ones.
===Method 1=== This is a method used widely in France that almost invariably leaves the yolk soft and runny but not watery. This method also avoids the requirement to pierce the shell.
#Using eggs which are more or less at room temperature (i.e. not straight from the refrigerator), place in water that has been brought to a "furious" boil. # After one minute, remove from heat and allow eggs to stand in the hot water in the pan for 5 minutes.
===Method 2=== #Fill the pot ¾ full with water and set on stove top to boil. #Using the pin, poke a small hole on the larger end of the egg. #When the water is boiling, use the slotted spoon to lower the eggs into the pot. #Let the eggs boil for 6-7 minutes (5 minutes 40 seconds for soft yolk). #Remove the eggs with the slotted spoon.
===Method 3=== #Mix ½ tsp salt into enough water to cover your eggs, and bring the water to a soft boil. #Put your eggs in the water and boil for 4-5 minutes. #When they're done, immediately run them under cold water so they stop cooking.
==Serving== #To serve, place eggs on an egg stand, shot glass, or anything that will allow the egg to stay upright. #Using the small spoon, repeatedly tap the top of the eggs until an area the size of the spoon is cracked #Dig the spoon across the bottom of the cracked area to remove the top. #Use the spoon to eat from the egg shell.
==Notes, tips, and variations== *If you wait too long to serve, the heat of the egg will continue to cook the yolk. This effect can be reduced by cooling the eggs in cold water for up to 1 minute. *Traditionally, people will slice buttered toast into long pieces and dip it into the eggs. This is called cutting bread into "soldiers." *Some people will add salt, pepper and sometimes butter, and scramble the eggs inside the shell. *Others will dig out the egg and layer on their buttered toast. *''Egg in a Cup'': dig out the egg and put it in a mug with buttered toast. Mix.
==Warnings== *Many people prefer their eggs not fully cooked. Please see the module ''[[Cookbook:Egg|Egg]]'' for possible health concerns of eating raw eggs.
[[Category:Breakfast recipes]] [[Category:Egg recipes]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes]]
[[he:ספר מתכונים/ארוחת בוקר/ביצה רכה]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of India|Cuisine of India]] [[Image:idly sambar vada.JPG|thumb|The South Indian staple breakfast item of idli, sambar, and vada served on a banana leaf.]]
'''Sambar''' or '''sambhar''' ([[w:Kannada language|Kannada]]: '''ಸಾಂಬಾರ್‍''', [[w:Tamil language|Tamil]] சாம்பார் (சாம்பாறு in Sri Lanka),[[w:Telugu language|Telugu]]: '''సాంబారు'''), pronounced "saambaar", is a dish common in southern India and Sri Lanka, made of [[Cookbook:Dal|dal]] (usually [[Cookbook:Pigeon Pea|red gram]], also called ''toor dal'') and vegetables in a spicy [[Cookbook:Tamarind|tamarind]] and dal flour soup base. Sambar is usually poured over or alongside steamed rice. In the south of India, vada sambar and idli sambar are popular breakfast foods.
Several minor variants exist depending on the meal of the day, region, and the vegetable used. Sambar without dal (but with vegetables or fish) is called ''kozhambu'' in [[w:Tamil Nadu|Tamil Nadu]]. There are major and minor variants of kozhambu (''mor kozhambu'', ''vetha kozhambu'', ''rasavangi'' etc.) Note that there are minor but subtle differences in preparation between all the variants (for instance, whether vegetables are added to the tamarind water or vice versa, which make them taste different).
Sambar with rice is one of the main courses of both formal and everyday south Indian cuisine. It is also served with [[Cookbook:Idli|idli]], [[Cookbook:Dosa|dosa]] and [[Cookbook:Vada|vada]]. It is not uncommon to eat sambar rice with appalam (papad).
== Ingredients == *1 cup (240ml) [[Cookbook:Pigeon Pea|yellow lentils]] (arhar or toor dal) *1½ cups [[Cookbook:Water|water]] *1 tbsp [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] *1 tbsp [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] *3 tbsp [http://www.bawarchi.com/contribution/contrib3453.html sambhar masala]* *3 tbsp thickish [[Cookbook:Tamarind|tamarind pulp]] OR 1 tsp tamarind concentrate *2 tsp [[Cookbook:Mustard|mustard seeds]] *7-8 leaves of [[Cookbook:Curry Leaf|curry leaves]] *2-3 whole dry [[Cookbook:Chili Pepper|red peppers]] *[[Cookbook:Fenugreek|methi seed]]s (Uhuluva) - ¼ tablespoon *1 tsp [[Cookbook:Asafoetida|asafoetidia]] (Kayam) (optional) *1 big [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]], cut into quarters *[[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]] - 1 teaspoon (chopped) *2 tbsp [[Cookbook:Oil|oil]] or [[Cookbook:Ghee|ghee]] *1 tbsp chopped [[Cookbook:Cilantro|coriander leaves]] (cilantro) to garnish. *1 cup (240ml) mixed [[Cookbook:Vegetable|vegetables]], cut into approx.1" cubes, e.g. **[[Cookbook:Tomato|tomato]] **a medium sized [[Cookbook:Potato|potato]] **[[Cookbook:Eggplant|brinjal]] (eggplant, aubergine, kath tharik kaai) **[[Cookbook:Drumstick|drumsticks]] **[[Cookbook:Lady's Finger|lady's fingers]] **[[Cookbook:Onion|small onions]]
*Sambar masala can also be made using this method
grind together but fry individually with a drop of sunflower/groundflower/gingily oil till u get a mild rosted smell. can be stored for a month
5 spoons of coriander seeds, 3 spoons of channa dal, 2 spoons of sesame seeds, 20 strands of chilli (increased or decreased based on your requirement), 3 spoons of desicated coconut, 20 curry leaves, 1/2 spoon fenugreek seeds , 1 spoon of asafoetida powder.
== Procedure == # Wash the dal, and cook in water with salt until absolutely tender, no grains remain. # Add sambhar masala, sugar and vegetables, including the onions, and cook until the vegetables are tender, and add tamarind. #:Note : It is better to add the tamarind juice after the vegetables are tenderly cooked. # Heat oil in a saucepan and add the mustard seeds. When they splutter, add the whole red peppers and the curry leaves. # Stir 2-3 times, then add the dal mixture. Bring to a boil, and then simmer for about 5 minutes.
==Variation - Kerala/Tamil style==
===Ingredients=== *[[Cookbook:Coconut|shredded coconut]] - ½ a coconut *[[Cookbook:Chili Powder|chili powder]] - 2 tablespoon *[[Cookbook:Coriander|coriander powder]] - 2 tablespoon *[[Cookbook:Coriander|coriander seeds]] - 1 tablespoon *[[Cookbook:Asafoetida|asafoetida]] (Kayam) - ¾ tablespoon *[[Cookbook:Turmeric|turmeric]] powder - ½ tablespoon *[[Cookbook:Tamarind|tamarind paste]] - 1 tablespoon *[[Cookbook:Toor dal|toor dal]] - 1 cup *vegetables (small [[Cookbook:Onion|onions]], [[Cookbook:Tomato|tomato]], [[Cookbook:Drumstick|drumstick]]) - 2 cups *[[Cookbook:Mustard|mustard]] -1 tablespoon *[[Cookbook:Cilantro|coriander leaves]] and curry leaves for garnishing
===Procedure=== # Wash and cook the dal until soft. #Heat the pan and pour 1 tsp oil, add asafoetida, chili powder and coriander powder and seed and fry them well. # Now add coconut and fry till the mixture is dark red in colour (do not burn it). # Wash the vegetables and boil them with turmeric powder. # When the vegetables are almost done add tamarind paste and allow it to boil for sometime (keep the stove in sim). # Now grind the coconut mixture and add mashed dal to it. # Add the mixture to the vegetables and let it boil for some time. Add desired salt. # When the sambar is done season it by spluttering mustard and adding curry leaves to it. # Finally add finely chopped coriander leaves and the sambar is done.
Serve hot, garnished with the coriander leaves.
[[Category:Indian recipes]] [[Category:Vegan recipes]] [[Category:Curry recipes]] [[Category:Tamarind recipes]] [[Category:Recipes_with_metric_units]]

{{recipe}} [[Image:Onion rings.jpg|right|thumb]]
'''Onion rings''' are a type of fast food commonly found in the [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|United States]], [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Canada|Canada]], [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United Kingdom|United Kingdom]], [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Australia|Australia]] and other places.
The rings are made from slices of onion, coated with [[Cookbook:Batter|batter]], breadcrumbs, flour, or other cooking substance and deep-fried until golden-brown and served as an [[Cookbook:Appetizers|appetizer]]. Here is one recipe:
==Ingredients== *5 medium [[Cookbook:Onion|white onions]], sliced *1 cup [[Cookbook:Milk|milk]] *3 [[Cookbook:Egg|eggs]], beaten *[[Cookbook:Salt|salt]], to taste *2 cups powdered [[Cookbook:Pancake|pancake]] mix *[[Cookbook:Parsley|parsley]] sprigs, for [[Cookbook:Garnish|garnish]]
==Procedure== #Separate the sliced onions into rings. #Combine milk, eggs and salt to taste in mixing bowl. #Soak onion rings in mixture 30 minutes. #Place pancake mix in shallow bowl. #Remove onion rings from milk mixture then dip in pancake mix. #[[Cookbook:Deep Fat Frying|Deep-fry]] rings in 375°F (190°C) oil until golden brown. #Drain fried onion rings on paper towels. #Pack fried onion rings loosely, without pressing, into 8" X 4" [[Cookbook:Loaf Pan|loaf pan]]. #Bake in a 400°F (200°C) oven for 10-15 minutes. #Turn onto serving plate and garnish with parsley.
[[Category:Appetizer recipes]] [[Category:Fried recipes]] [[Category:Onion recipes]]

{{recipe}}
'''Arroz con leche''' - creamed rice. Serves 4-6.
== Ingredients == * 1 cup of [[Cookbook:rice|rice]] * 2 cups of [[Cookbook:water|water]] * 7 cups of [[Cookbook:milk|milk]] * 2 [[Cookbook:cinnamon|cinnamon]] sticks * 2 cups of [[Cookbook:sugar|sugar]] or fruit syrup * ½ teaspoon of [[Cookbook:salt|salt]] * 1 peel of [[Cookbook:lemon|lemon]] * cinnamon powder * [[Cookbook:Mint|mint leaves]] (optional - for [[Cookbook:Garnish|garnish]]
== Procedure == # Put the rice in a [[Cookbook:strainer|strainer]] and wash it under water until the water gets transparent through to the other side. # Put the rice in a pot with the water, and boil it for 7 minutes until the rice get softer and the water has almost vanished. # Add the milk, the sticks of cinnamon, and the lemon peel. Boil it using moderate heat for 10 minutes. Take the cinnamon sticks and the lemon peel out, and cook for another 5 to 6 minutes until the rice is softer, stirring often with a wood spoon. # Add the sugar, and cook for another 30 minutes; then add the salt, and cook for 1 to 2 more minutes, stirring often. # Take it off the heat, put it in a deep glass dish, sprinkle the cinnamon powder over it, and refrigerate.
==Notes, tips, and variations== * [[Cookbook:Soy Milk|Soy milk]], rice milk, or almond milk can be used instead of milk. * Can be served with vanilla, chocolate, or Neapolitan ice cream, or with non-dairy ice creams.
[[Category:Rice recipes]] [[Category:Milk recipes]] [[Category:Pudding and Custard recipes]]

{{recipesummary|Salad recipes|6|10 minutes|1|Image=[[Image:Bowl'o'Coleslaw modified.jpg|300px]]}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Salad|Salads]]
==Ingredients==
* 1 head white [[Cookbook:Cabbage|cabbage]] * 1 medium red [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]], thinly sliced * 4 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoons]] [[Cookbook:Mayonnaise|mayonnaise]] * ¼–½ cup [[Cookbook:Cider vinegar|cider vinegar]] (optional)
==Procedure==
# If adding cider vinegar, add it to the mayonnaise and mix together well. # Slice or shred the cabbage, as coarsely or finely as desired. # Slice the onion thinly. # In a large bowl, mix cabbage and onion together with mayonnaise. # Set aside to allow the flavours to merge, at least 20 minutes but preferably for a couple of hours.
==Notes, tips and variations== {{Wikipedia|Coleslaw}} * Savoy cabbage can be used instead of white cabbage * other vegetables can be added to the coleslaw for greater variety, including: ** sliced [[Cookbook:Bell Pepper|bell peppers]] - red, yellow and orange ** [[Cookbook:Grater|grated]] [[Cookbook:Carrot|carrots]] ** chopped [[Cookbook:Nuts and seeds|nuts]] - e.g. [[Cookbook:Almond|almonds]], [[Cookbook:Walnut|walnuts]] * Some people prefer to sweeten the dressing by adding up to 2 tablespoons of [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] to the mayonnaise and vinegar * Spices can be added to the dressing to "liven it up" - e.g. ground [[Cookbook:Pepper|black pepper]], [[Cookbook:Celery|celery seeds]]

{{recipesummary|Vegetable recipes|8|1 hour|1}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Vegetarian cuisine|Vegetarian Cuisine]]
{{Nutrition Summary| |ServingSize=¼ cup (45 g) |Servings=about 10 |Cals=110 |FatCals=0 |TotalFat=0 g |SatFat=20g |Cholesterol=0 mg |Sodium=25 mg |Carbs=27 g |Fiber=11 g |Sugars=1 g |Protein=11 g |VitaminA=8% |VitaminC=0% |Calcium=0% |Iron=15% }}
==Ingredients==
* 2 [[Cookbook:Cup|cups]] dry split peas, picked over * 5 or 6 cups [[Cookbook:Water|water]]
==Directions==
# Rinse the split peas well, and discard the water (pot plants love it!) # Simmer ¾-1 hour. # Serve.
==Tips, Notes, and Variations==
* If you have hard water in your area, adding ⅛ teaspoon baking soda will reduce the cooking time. * [[Cookbook:Bacon|Bacon]], [[Cookbook:Ham|ham]], kielbasa, [[Cookbook:Pork|salt pork]], or [[Cookbook:Sausage|smoked sausage]] may be added during cooking for added flavor.

{{recipesummary|Pea recipes|10|2 hours to overnight|1}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Vegetarian cuisine|Vegetarian Cuisine]]
{{Nutrition Summary| |ServingSize=¼ cup (45 g) (dry) |Servings=about 10 |Cals=110 |FatCals=0 |TotalFat=0 g 0% |SatFat=0g 0% |Cholesterol=0 mg 0% |Sodium=20 mg 1% |Carbs=28 g 9% |Fiber=12 g 48% |Sugars=2 g |Protein=10 g |VitaminA=0% |VitaminC=0% |Calcium=2% |Iron=0% }}
These [[Cookbook:Legumes|legumes]] are flavorful and healthy, but require [[Cookbook:Soak|soaking]].
==Ingredients==
* ½ [[Cookbook:Pound|pound]] (225 [[Cookbook:gram|grams]]), about 1¼ [[Cookbook:Cup|cups]] dry yellow split peas * 3 or 4 cups (¾ to 1 [[Cookbook:Liter|liter]]) potable (drinking) [[Cookbook:Water|water]] * ⅛ [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoon]] [[Cookbook:Baking Soda|baking soda]], if needed (see tips)
==Procedure==
===quick method===
# Pick over beans, then add hot water. # [[Cookbook:Boiling|Boil]] for two minutes. # Set aside for 1 hour. # Drain and rinse. # [[Cookbook:Simmering|Simmer]] until tender.
===overnight method===
# Pick over beans, then add cold water. # Soak overnight, or 6 hours minimum. # Drain and rinse. # Simmer until tender.
==Tips, Notes, and Variations==
* As beans are a natural product, pick over beans, discarding any stones, dirt particles, or discolored beans before soaking or cooking. * If you have hard water in your area, adding ⅛ teaspoon baking soda will reduce the cooking time. * Make sure water covers beans by at least 2 [[Cookbook:Inch|inches]] (5 [[Cookbook:Centimetre (cm)|centimeters]]), check on water level every little while and don't let the top beans get above the water.
[[Category:Inexpensive recipes]] [[Category:Camping recipes]] [[Category:Soup recipes]] [[Category:Pea recipes]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes]] [[Category:Recipes_with_metric_units]]

{{recipesummary|Soup recipes|6|1-2 hours|1}} {{recipe}}
==Ingredients==
* 1 [[Cookbook:Pound|pound]] (½ [[Cookbook:Kg|kilogram]]) dry [[Cookbook:Yellow split peas|yellow split peas]] * 2 [[Cookbook:Chicken|chicken]] or [[Cookbook:Beef|beef]] bouillon cubes * 1 small [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]], [[Cookbook:Chopping|chopped]] * 1 medium [[Cookbook:Carrot|carrots]], [[Cookbook:Dice|diced]] * 1 stalk [[Cookbook:Celery|celery]], chopped * 6 [[Cookbook:Cup|cups]] (1½ [[Cookbook:Liter|liters]]) [[Cookbook:Water|water]] * [[Cookbook:Salt|Salt]] and [[Cookbook:Pepper|pepper]] to taste
==Procedure==
# [[Cookbook:Soak|Soak]] beans according to usual directions. # Put all ingredients into a 6 or 8 [[Cookbook:Quart|quart]] [[Cookbook:Stock Pot|stock pot]] or [[Cookbook:Dutch Oven|Dutch oven]] # Bring to a [[Cookbook:Boiling|boil]], then [[Cookbook:Simmering|simmer]] covered until peas are tender, 1-2 hours.
==Tips, Notes, and Variations==
* Watch water level and top up with (HOT!) water if necessary. * Croutons are good on top!
