{{recipesummary|Salad recipes|6|1 hour|2}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|American cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Southern cuisine|Southern cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Midwestern cuisine|Midwestern cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Vegetarian cuisine|Vegetarian cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Holiday Recipes|Holiday Recipes]] | [[Cookbook:Salad|salad]]
=Great American Potato Salad=
===Ingredients===
* 2 [[Cookbook:Pound|pounds]] (3 or 4 medium) [[Cookbook:Potato|russet potatoes]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoon]] plus ½ [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoon]] [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * 2 tablespoons [[Cookbook:Vinegar|distilled white vinegar]] * 1 medium [[Cookbook:Celery|rib of celery]] * ¾ teaspoon celery seed * ¾ [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] [[Cookbook:Mayonnaise|mayonnaise]] * ¾ teaspoon [[Cookbook:Mustard|powdered mustard]] * 2 tablespoons minced [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]] * 2 tablespoons minced fresh [[Cookbook:Parsley|parsley leaves]] * ¼ teaspoon ground [[Cookbook:Black Pepper|black pepper]] * 3 tablespoons sweet pickle relish
===Directions===
# Peel and cut potatoes into ¾ [[Cookbook:Inch|inch]] cubes. # Cover potatoes with an inch of water in a large saucepan and [[Cookbook:Boil|boil]]. # Add 1 tablespoon salt to boiling water and reduce heat to medium. # [[Cookbook:Simmer|Simmer]] about 8 minutes, stirring gently once or twice, until potatoes are tender. (Taste a piece-don't overcook!) # Drain potatoes and place in a large bowl. # Toss gently with vinegar, with a rubber spatula. # Cool potatoes. They must be no more than barely warm to mix. # [[Cookbook:Chop|Chop]] celery fine. # Stir together celery, celery seeds, mayonnaise, dry mustard, onion, parsley, pepper, and ½ teaspoon salt. # Gently fold together dressing mix and potatoes. # Cover and refrigerate at least an hour, until thoroughly chilled.
===Tips, Notes, and Variations===
* You may have to substitute celery salt for the celery seeds, but then leave out the salt in the dressing. * Do not mix too much once the potatoes are in, or they will break down. * A couple of hard-boiled eggs, diced about ¼ inch may be added when the final mix is made.
===Warning===
* Do not save for more than 24 hours.
[[Category:Inexpensive recipes|Potato Salad, Great American]] [[Category:American recipes|Potato Salad, Great American]] [[Category:Midwestern recipes|Potato Salad, Great American]] [[Category:Southern recipes|Potato Salad, Great American]] [[Category:Salad recipes|Potato Salad, Great American]] [[Category:Celery recipes|Potato Salad, Great American]] [[Category:Egg recipes|Potato Salad, Great American]] [[Category:Onion recipes|Potato Salad, Great American]] [[Category:Pickle recipes|Potato Salad, Great American]] [[Category:Potato recipes|Salad, Great American Potato]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|Potato Salad, Great American]] [[Category:Vegetable recipes|Potato Salad, Great American]] [[Category:Gluten-free recipes|Potato Salad, Great American]]

revision.comment: a delicious dessert or snack bread
revision.text:
{{recipesummary|Bread recipes|6|1 hour|1}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|American cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Southern cuisine|Southern cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Vegetarian cuisine|Vegetarian cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Holiday Recipes|Holiday Recipes]] | [[Cookbook:Bread Recipes|bread recipes]] | [[Cookbook:Dessert|dessert]]
=Chew Bread=
===Ingredients===
* 1½ sticks [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]] * 3 [[Cookbook:Egg|eggs]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoon]] [[Cookbook:Vanilla Extract|vanilla extract]] * 1 box [[Cookbook:Brown Sugar|light brown sugar]] * 2 [[Cookbook:Cup|cups]] [[Cookbook:Flour|self-rising flour]] * 1½ cups [[Cookbook:Nut|nuts]]
===Directions===
# Preheat [[Cookbook:Oven|oven]] to [[Cookbook:Oven_temperatures|350°F]]. # Combine all ingredients except nuts and mix well with [[Cookbook:Beater|cake mixer]]. # Add nuts and stir in well. # Pour into greased and floured 9x13-inch [[Cookbook:Pots and Pans|pan]] and [[Cookbook:Bake|bake]] oven for 35 to 40 minutes.
[[Category:Inexpensive recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:American recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Southern recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Camping recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Baked recipes|Chicken, Easy Onion]] [[Category:Bread recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Breakfast recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Dessert recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Egg recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Walnut recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Casserole recipes|5|45 minutes|1}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|American cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Fish|fish]] | [[Cookbook:Pasta|pasta]]
=Tuna Noodle Casserole=
===Ingredients===
* 2 cans (drained) or pouches (12 [[Cookbook:Ounce|ounces]] each) [[Cookbook:Tuna|tuna]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] [[Cookbook:Milk|milk]] * 4 cups hot, cooked [[Cookbook:Noodle|medium egg noodles]] * 2 cups [[Cookbook:Peas|frozen peas]] * 2 cans (10.75 ounces each) condensed cream of [[Cookbook:Mushroom|mushroom]] [[Cookbook:Soup|soup]] * 2 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoons]] dry [[Cookbook:Bread Crumbs|bread crumbs]] * 1 tablespoon [[Cookbook:Butter|melted butter]] Optional: * 1 or 2 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoons]] [[Cookbook:Onion|dried minced onion]] * 3 or 4 ounces [[Cookbook:Cheese|cheese]], shredded or sliced to cover casserole * ¼ to 1 teaspoon Texas Pete or other [[Cookbook:Hot Sauce|hot sauce]] * Replace breadcrumbs with crushed potato chips.
===Directions===
# Preheat [[Cookbook:Oven|oven]] to [[Cookbook:Oven_temperatures|400°F]]. # Shred tuna and stir into 3-[[Cookbook:Quart|quart]] [[Cookbook:Pots and Pans|casserole]] with milk, noodles, peas, and soup. Add onions and hot sauce if desired. # [[Cookbook:Bake|Bake]] until hot, about 25-30 minutes. # Remove from oven, and top with bread crumbs mixed with butter or with cheese. # Bake another 5 minutes.
===Variations===
*Replace half of mushroom soup with cream of celery.
[[Category:Inexpensive recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:American recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Midwestern recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Southern recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Baked recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Casserole recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Cheese recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Fish recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Milk recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Mushroom recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Onion recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Pasta recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Pea recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Tuna recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Soup recipes|6|1 hour|1}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|American cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Native American cuisine|Native American cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Corn|corn]] | [[Cookbook:Soups|soups]]
=Corn Chowder= ''This is the way your grandparents warmed up on a winter's day.''
===Ingredients===
* 2 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoon]] [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]] or [[Cookbook:Margarine|margarine]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] [[Cookbook:Chop|chopped]] [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]] * ½ cup chopped [[Cookbook:Celery|celery]] * 1½ cups [[Cookbook:Dice|diced]], pared [[Cookbook:Potato|potatoes]] (cut in ½-[[Cookbook:Inch|inch]] cubes) * 2 cups [[Cookbook:Corn|corn]]. fresh or frozen * 1½ cups [[Cookbook:Water|water]] * 2 chicken [[Cookbook:Bouillon Cubes|bouillon cubes]] * ¼ teaspoon [[Cookbook:Thyme|thyme]] * 1 cup [[Cookbook:Milk|milk]] * 1 cup [[Cookbook:Cream|light cream]] * [[Cookbook:Salt|Salt]] and [[Cookbook:Pepper|pepper]] to taste
===Directions===
# In a [[Cookbook:Saucepan|medium saucepan]], melt butter; add onion and celery and cook until tender. # Add potatoes, corn, salt, pepper, water, water, bouillon cubes, and thyme. # Cover and [[Cookbook:Simmer|simmer]] for 15 minutes, or until potatoes and corn are tender. # Add milk and cream. # Heat through.
===Tips, Notes, and Variations===
* If cooking outdoors, you can substitute evaporated milk or powdered milk.
[[Category:Inexpensive recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Native American recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:American recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Camping recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Soup recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Celery recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Corn recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Milk recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Onion recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Potato recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Thyme recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Gluten-free recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Dessert recipes|4|1 hour|2}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|American cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Breakfast|Breakfast cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Vegetarian cuisine|Vegetarian cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Holiday Recipes|Holiday Recipes]] | [[Cookbook:Bread Recipes|bread recipes]] | [[Cookbook:Dessert|dessert]]
=Apple Brown Betty=
===Ingredients===
* 2 [[Cookbook:Cup|cups]] soft [[Cookbook:Bread Crumbs|bread crumbs]] * ½ cup [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] * ¼ cup [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]] or [[Cookbook:Margarine|margarine]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoon]] [[Cookbook:Cinnamon|cinnamon]] * 3 cups [[Cookbook:Apple|apples]], sliced (they don't need to be peeled) * ¾ cup [[Cookbook:Water|water]]
===Directions===
# Preheat [[Cookbook:Oven|oven]] to [[Cookbook:Oven_temperatures|375°F]]. # [[Cookbook:Sauté|Sauté]] bread crumbs in butter. # Add apples, cinnamon. sugar, and water. # If the skillet is oven-proof, cover and place in the oven. If the skillet is not oven-proof, transfer to a greased [[Cookbook:Pots and Pans|casserole dish]]. # Cover and [[Cookbook:Bake|bake]] for 30 to 40 minutes, until apples are tender. # If mixture becomes too dry during baking, add another ¼ cup of water. (Apples vary as to moisture content.)
===Tips, Notes, and Variations===
* Serve with milk or whipped cream. * If cooking in a [[Cookbook:Dutch Oven|Dutch oven]], preheat with 15 charcoal briquettes, ⅓ on the bottom, and ⅔ on the top.
[[Category:Inexpensive recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:American recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Camping recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Baked recipes|Chicken, Easy Onion]] [[Category:Bread recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Breakfast recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Casserole recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Cookie recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Dessert recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Apple recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Cinnamon recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Bread recipes|6|1 hour|1}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|American cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Native American cuisine|Native American cuisine]]
==Ingredients==
* 1 [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] [[Cookbook:Cornmeal|corn meal]] * 1 cup [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] * 2 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoons]] [[Cookbook:Baking Powder|baking powder]] * ½ teaspoon [[Cookbook:Baking Soda|baking soda]] * ¼ cup [[Cookbook:Brown Sugar|brown sugar]] * ½ cup [[Cookbook:Milk|milk]] * ½ cup plain [[Cookbook:Yogurt|yogurt]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Egg|egg]], lightly [[Cookbook:Beat|beaten]] * ¼ cup melted [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]]
==Procedure==
# Preheat [[Cookbook:Oven|oven]] to [[Cookbook:Oven_temperatures|425°F]] (220°C). ''If using a [[Cookbook:Dutch Oven|Dutch oven]], preheat with 16-18 glowing charcoal briquettes, with 3 times as many on the top as on the bottom.'' # Grease an 8-[[Cookbook:Inch|inch]] square [[Cookbook:Pots and Pans|baking pan]] # In a large bowl, mix corn meal, flour, baking powder, baking soda, and brown sugar. # In another bowl, [[Cookbook:Whisk|whisk]] together the milk, yogurt, egg, and melted butter. # Gradually add the liquid mixture to the dry mixture and stir until just combined. # Pour into the greased pan and [[Cookbook:Bake|bake]] for 15 to 20 minutes, or until a toothpick inserted in the center comes out clean.
==Tips, Notes, and Variations==
* Over-mixing after adding together the liquid and dry mixtures will toughen the batter!
[[Category:Inexpensive recipes]] [[Category:American recipes]] [[Category:Native American recipes]] [[Category:Camping recipes]] [[Category:Bread recipes]] [[Category:Corn recipes]] [[Category:Egg recipes]] [[Category:Milk recipes]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes]]

{{recipesummary|Muffin recipes|20|1 hour total|1}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|American cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Vegetarian cuisine|Vegetarian cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Holiday Recipes|Holiday Recipes]] | [[Cookbook:Bread Recipes|bread recipes]] | [[Cookbook:Dessert|dessert]]
=Snappy Ginger Muffins=
===Ingredients===
* ½ [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] [[Cookbook:Vegetable oil|vegetable oil]] * ¼ cup [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] * ¼ cup [[Cookbook:Brown Sugar|brown sugar]] * 1 cup [[Cookbook:Molasses|molasses]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Egg|egg]] * 3 cups all-purpose [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] * 1½ [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoons]] [[Cookbook:Baking Soda|baking soda]] * 1 teaspoon ground [[Cookbook:Cinnamon|cinnamon]] * 1 teaspoon ground [[Cookbook:Ginger|ginger]] * ½ teaspoon [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * 1 cup [[Cookbook:Water|water]]
===Directions===
# Preheat [[Cookbook:Oven|oven]] to [[Cookbook:Oven_temperatures|350°F]]. # In a mixing bowl, [[Cookbook:Beat|beat]] the oil and the sugars. # Beat in molasses and egg. # Combine the flour, baking soda, cinnamon, ginger, and salt. # Stir into molasses alternating with water. # Fill greased or paper-lined [[Cookbook:Pots and Pans|muffin cups]] ⅔ full. # [[Cookbook:Bake|Bake]] for 20-25 minutes, or until a wooden toothpick comes out clean. # Cool in pan for 10 minutes before turning out to a wire rack.

{{recipesummary|Dessert recipes|6|½ hour prep, ½ hour to bake|2}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|American cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Vegetarian cuisine|vegetarian cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Holiday Recipes|Holiday Recipes]] | [[Cookbook:Bread Recipes|bread recipes]] | [[Cookbook:Dessert|dessert]] | [[Cookbook:Fruit|fruit]]
=Easy Peach Cobbler= ''See also [[Cookbook:Peach Cobbler|Peach Cobbler]]''
===Ingredients===
* 1 stick [[Cookbook:Margarine|margarine]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoon]] [[Cookbook:Baking Powder|baking powder]] * ¾ [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] all-purpose [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] * 1 cup [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] * ¾ cup [[Cookbook:Milk|milk]] * 5 fresh [[Cookbook:Peach|peaches]], sliced
===Directions===
# Preheat [[Cookbook:Oven|oven]] to [[Cookbook:Oven_temperatures|375°F]]. # Melt margarine in [[Cookbook:Quart|quart]] size [[Cookbook:Pots and Pans|baking pan]] or dish. Set aside. # Mix baking powder, flour, sugar, and milk. # Pour this over the melted margarine and '''do not stir'''. # Place peaches over mixture # [[Cookbook:Bake|Bake]] 20 to 30 minutes.
===Tips, Notes, and Variations===
* If camping, or if fresh peaches are not in season, you can use a #2 (½ size) can of sliced peaches, drained. * If using a [[Cookbook:Dutch Oven|Dutch oven]], preheat with about 15 charcoal briquettes, with 10 or 11 on the top and 4 or 5 on the bottom (for the 12-[[Cookbook:Inch|inch]] size).

{{recipe}}
<big>'''''1) with rice and ground meat'''''</big>
== Ingredients == *1 1/2 to 2 ounces (50 g) of white parboiled rice *1 pound (500 g) of ground meat, either beef, lamb or pork *6 large red bell peppers *1 egg *salt, pepper, paprika *oil
== Procedure == Cook the rice. Turn on the oven for pre-heat, while placing a lasagna form with the bottom covered in oil (or water or thin tomato sauce) inside. Cut out the stems and the seeds of the peppers so that the peppers form a cup. Mix the rice, the egg and the ground beef and spice everthing with salt, pepper and paprika. Fill the peppers, set them into the lasagna form and steam everything for 45 minutes at 390 degrees F/200 degrees C.
Serve with green salad and tomato sauce.
<big>'''''2) vegetarian option'''''</big>
== Ingredients == *4 green bell peppers *1 cup of water *half a cube of dried broth *1 cup of rice *1 cup tomatoes, pureed *salt, pepper, paprika *1 bundle parsley *5 ounces (150 g) of shredded cheese *1 onion *(garlic - optional) *(black olives - optional)
== Procedure == Cook the rice. Cut onion into small cubes and fry in olive oil until brown. Add water, tomato juice, parsley, soup cube, cheese, garlic, black olives and rice. Spice to taste. Fill into the peppers. Cook for 30 minutes. Rest as above.
(Calculated with one pepper per person.)
[[Category:Pepper recipes|Stuffed_peppers]] [[Category:Meat recipes|Stuffed_peppers]] [[Category:Rice recipes|Stuffed_peppers]] [[Category:Paprika recipes|Stuffed_peppers]] [[Category:Recipes_with_metric_units|Stuffed_peppers]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|Stuffed_peppers]] [[Category:Halal recipes|Stuffed_peppers]] [[Category:European recipes|Stuffed_peppers]]

revision.comment: [[Beer Cheese Risotto]] moved to [[Cookbook:Beer Cheese Risotto]]: wrong namespace
revision.text:
{{recipe}}
This variation on a classic cheese-flavored risotto is hearty and delicious. The beer adds a Welsh Rarebit overtone. The best beer is malty, not hoppy. A good amber or belgian ale works well.
==Ingredients==
*½ large [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]], diced *1 tablespoon [[Cookbook:Olive Oil|olive oil]] *1 cup [[Cookbook:Arborio Rice|arborio rice]] *1 ½ cups hot [[Cookbook:Stock|vegetable stock]] (approximate) *½ cup beer *¼ cup grated [[Cookbook:Parmesan Cheese|parmesan cheese]] *¼ cup shredded sharp [[Cookbook:Cheddar Cheese|cheddar cheese]] (to taste)
==Procedure== Heat the stock to near boiling.
[[Cookbook:Sweating|Sweat]] the onion in a heavy, medium saucepan with the olive oil, adding a generous pinch of [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]]. When the onions are soft and transparent, add the rice, sautéeing until each grain is coated.
Add the beer and heat to simmer, stirring constantly. When the beer is mostly absorbed, add around a third to a half cup of hot stock (this should be heated in another pan close by). Stir constantly while simmering. Repeat procedure for around twenty minutes--most of the stock should be consumed and the rice should be tender to the taste before proceeding. The rice will produce a thick, creamy sauce in the course of cooking (see [[Cookbook:Risotto|Risotto]]).
Remove from heat, adding the parmesan cheese and stirring to incorporate. Give the cheese a chance to dissolve and melt, then add the cheddar. Stir to melt and incorporate. If a cheesier rice is desired, add more.

revision.comment: [[Irish fruit cake]] moved to [[Cookbook:Irish fruit cake]]: naming
revision.text:
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Dessert|Dessert]] | [[Cookbook:Cake|Cake]] | [[Cookbook:Fruit cake|Fruit cake]]
{{recipesummary| | Category = Cake recipes | Servings = 6 to 8 | Time = ≈2 hours + cooling time | Rating = 3 | Image = }}
This is a variation of [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fruit_cake fruit cake] that originated in [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ireland Ireland].
==Ingredients== *1 lb [[Cookbook:Flour|cake flour]] *A pinch of [[Cookbook:salt|salt]] *½ tsp [[Cookbook:Baking_powder|baking powder]] *3 [[Cookbook:Egg|eggs]] *4 oz [[Cookbook:Raisins|sultanas or golden raisins]] *6 oz [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] *6 oz [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]] *2 oz [[Cookbook:Zest|citrus peel]] *2 oz [[Cookbook:Cherry|dried cherries]]
==Procedure== #Preheat the oven to 350°F. #Sift together flour, salt and baking powder. #Cream butter and sugar, this may take 5-10 min. #Add eggs individually, incorporating each fully before adding the next. #Fold in fruits then the dry mixture. #Turn on to a greased and [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parchment_paper#Plant-based_parchment lined] 8 inch cake pin. #Bake on the center rack for 75-90 minutes. (Check for doneness after 60 minutes.) #Let cake cool to room temperature in pan. #Remove to a wire tray, cover with towel and allow to sit until completely cool.
==Variations== *This particular version of the recipe does not include whiskey. If you were to add it, it would be added along with the butter and sugar. Approximately one quart should be used. *This recipe uses raisins and cherries but apples, strawberries, or raspberries can be substituted.

revision.comment: Reverted edit of [[Special:Contributions/Michael Natkin|Michael Natkin]], changed back to last version by Barak4wiki
revision.text:
{{recipesummary |Category = Palestinian recipes |Servings = 3-4 |Time = 30 minutes |Rating = 2 |Image = [[Image:Mejadrah.s.jpg|300px]] }} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Palestinian Cuisine|Palestinian Cuisine]]
Extremely simple to cook, this dish is a fundamental component of the Palestinian cuisine. It provides carbohydrates, proteins, and a full stomach. It also tastes great.
When cooked with rice, this recipe is [[Cookbook:Gluten-Free|gluten-free]]. It isn't gluten free when cooked with bulgur (wheat).
{{see also|Cookbook:Mjeddrah}}
== Ingredients == * 1 cup [[Cookbook:Rice|rice]] or [[Cookbook:Bulgur|bulgur]] * 1 cup [[Cookbook:Lentil|lentils]] * 1 medium sized [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]] * 4 cups water * [[Cookbook:Olive Oil|olive oil]] * [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * [[Cookbook:Baharat|baharat]] * [[Cookbook:Cumin|cumin]] * [[Cookbook:Cardamom|cardamom]]
== Method == [[Image:Mejadrah-cooking.s.jpg|thumb|right]] The more common recipe uses rice. Bulgur can be substituted for rice, with the exact same procedure.
# Fry the lentils in oil for 3-4 minutes, stirring continuously, until the first beans show signs of scorching. # Add salt, baharat, cumin, ground cardamom. # Add 2 cups water and cover. Bring to a boil, lower to a simmer. Cook for 20 minutes or until all the water is absorbed by the lentils. # Fry the rice in oil for 3-4 minutes, stirring continuously, until the grains change colour. # Add salt, black or white pepper, and ground cardamom. # Add 2 cups water and cover. Bring to a boil, lower to a simmer. After 5 minutes turn the heat off, and leave standing for another 10 minutes. # Cut the onion into thin strips (½cm x 4cm). # Fry the onion in mixed olive oil until crisp and translucent. # Mix lentils and rice, top with the fried onion.
[[Category:Featured recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Palestinian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegan recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Gluten-free recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Lentil recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Rice recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Onion recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}}
[[Image:Rainbow-Jello-Full-2004-July-30.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Rainbow Jell-O made from this recipe in a trapezoidal pyrex dish (uncut).]] [[Image:Rainbow-Jello-Cut-2004-Jul-30.jpg|thumb|right|200px|The same Jell-O, cut and viewed from the end.]]
'''Rainbow Jell-O''' - a multilayered, multiflavored Jell-O extravaganza; based on a recipe from [http://www.kraftfoods.com/main.aspx?s=recipe&m=recipe/knet_recipe_display&u1=keyword&u2=rainbow&u3=**6*6&wf=9&recipe_id=50315 Kraft].
This recipe takes about five hours to prepare, although the time is spent largely in waiting; it is therefore best to plan to intersperse it with other activity and, if they don't mind the constant smell of Jell-O, best done with other people. It yields ten (or as many as you want) layers, alternating opaque and clear, of five colors. (The sour cream or yogurt, used for opacity, cannot be tasted in the final product.)
== Ingredients ==
These ingredients will be divided between the layers of the rainbow Jell-O:
*6 1/4 cups (around 1.5l) boiling water *5 (or more) packages Jell-O gelatin (4-serving size each; different flavors and colors) *1 cup (240g) sour cream or plain or vanilla yogurt
== Procedure ==
Select one or more molds. The total volume will be approximately eight cups; a ring mold (as used by Kraft), two or three Pyrex containers (as pictured), or any other assortment should work; for best results, the container should be at least 3in (10cm) deep, allowing for about ten 1cm-thick layers.
*Stir 1 1/4 cups boiling water and one package gelatin in a small bowl for at least two minutes, until completely dissolved. (In practice, it may not quite completely dissolve.) *Pour 3/4 cups dissolved gelatin into the mold(s). *Refrigerate for about 15 minutes, until the gelatin sets but is not yet firm: the gelatin should stick to your finger when you touch it. (The aim is for the layers to stick, but not mix.) *Refrigerate the remaining gelatin for about 5 minutes, until it is slightly thickened (to the consistency of unbeaten egg white). *Gradually stir 3 tablespoons sour cream or yogurt into the remaining, thickened gelatin. *Spoon the gelatine on top of the previous layer (gently, so as to maintain a smooth surface). *Refrigerate again for about 15 minutes.
Repeat the above for each of the remaining flavors. Be sure to cool adequately between layers to prevent melting and mixing.
When finished, refrigerate for about 2 hours, until firm. Remove the gelatin from the mold and place it (probably upside down) on a plate or smooth cutting board. Store refrigerated under saran wrap or aluminum foil. For best effect, serve sliced perpendicular to the layers, so each slice (approximately 1cm thick) displays the full rainbow.
[[Category:Dessert recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Gelatin recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Recipes_with_metric_units|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary |Category = Israeli recipes |Rating = 1 }} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Israel|Cuisine of Israel]]

==Procedure==
# Mix cucumber, tomato, onion, and parsley. # Mix oil, lemon juice, salt, pepper, and za'atar. # Pour over vegetables. Correct seasoning, to taste.

revision.comment: [[Cookbook:Cafe au lait]] moved to [[Cookbook:Café au lait]]: Correct French spelling
revision.text:
{{recipesummary|Beverage recipes|4 servings|prep: 10-20 minutes|1}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Beverages|Beverages]]
Literally "coffee with milk", '''cafe au lait''' is a drink made of coffee and milk in a ratio of 1:1. It is the staple coffee drink of French Louisiana and is often served in bowls in [[Cookbook:Cajun cuisine|Acadiana]].
==Ingredients== * 5 Tbsp (70g) [[Cookbook:Coffee|Coffee]] grounds, can be: :* Dark (French) roast coffee :* Coffee and [[Cookbook:chicory|chicory]] blend :* 3 Tbsp (42g) ground coffee and 2 Tbsp (28g) ground chicory, mixed * OR: 1.5-2 cups (350-475 ml) cold [[Cookbook:coffee concentrate|coffee concentrate]] * 4 cups (950 ml) [[Cookbook:milk|milk]]
==Procedure== # Prepare four cups of coffee in your preferred manner -- drip, boil, seep, etc. # At the same time, heat the milk over a low to medium heat until scalded. # Pour equal amounts of coffee and scalded milk into bowls or cups. # Enjoy.
==Variations== * Steamed milk can be substituted for scalded milk. * The milk can be heated in the cups by half filling each cup with milk and [[Cookbook:Microwaving|microwaving]] briefly. A 1,000W microwave oven will heat one half-cup of milk in 50 seconds, two in 60 seconds.
[[Category:Louisiana recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Beverage recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Coffee recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Sauces|Sauces]] | [[Cookbook:Meat Recipes|Meat Recipes]]
==Ingredients==
*1 [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] tomato [[Cookbook:Ketchup|catsup]] (ketchup) *¾ cup [[Cookbook:Cider vinegar|cider vinegar]] *2 or 3 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoons]] [[Cookbook:Mustard|mustard]] *3 tablespoons [[Cookbook:Worcestershire Sauce|Worcestershire sauce]] *1 cup [[Cookbook:Brown Sugar|brown sugar]] *1 to 2 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoons]] [[Cookbook:Celery Seed|celery seed]] *3 tablespoons [[Cookbook:Margarine|margarine]] *¼ teaspoon [[Cookbook:Black Pepper|black pepper]] *¼ teaspoon [[Cookbook:Red Pepper|red pepper]] *1 teaspoon [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] *1 teaspoon [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]] flakes *[[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]] powder or [[Cookbook:Mince|minced]] garlic to taste (optional)
==Procedure== Combine together and bring to a boil. Reduce heat and [[Cookbook:Simmer|simmer]] 10 to 15 minutes, until thickens slightly.
Arrange [[Cookbook:Chicken|chicken]] pieces or [[Cookbook:Pork|pork]] chops in [[Cookbook:Grease|greased]] baking dish, pour half of sauce over and [[Cookbook:Bake|bake]] at [[Cookbook:Oven_temperatures|350°F (175°C)]] for 30 to 40 minutes. Pour remaining sauce over before serving.
Can also keep sauce in refrigerator and use like bottled BBQ sauce.

revision.comment: Charming dessert for holidays or any occasion
revision.text:
{{recipesummary|Cake recipes|8 (2 cookies each)|1 hour|2}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|American cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Breakfast|Breakfast cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Vegetarian cuisine|vegetarian cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Holiday Recipes|Holiday Recipes]] | [[Cookbook:Bread Recipes|bread recipes]] | [[Cookbook:Dessert|dessert]]
=Chocolate Chip Coffee Cake=
===Ingredients===
* [[Cookbook:Cooking Spray|Cooking spray]] * 2½ [[Cookbook:Cup|cups]] buttermilk pancake mix * ½ cup semi-sweet [[Cookbook:Chocolate Chips|chocolate chips]] * ⅓ cup [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] * ½ cup [[Cookbook:Sour Cream|sour cream]] * ½ [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoon]] [[Cookbook:Vanilla Extract|vanilla extract]] * ½ cup [[Cookbook:Water|water]] * ¼ cup sugar * ¼ teaspoon [[Cookbook:Cinnamon|cinnamon]] * ½ cup [[Cookbook:Chop|finely chopped]] [[Cookbook:Nut|nuts]]
===Directions===
# Preheat [[Cookbook:Oven|oven]] to [[Cookbook:Oven_temperatures|375°F]]. # Use cooking spray to lightly coat an 8 or 9 [[Cookbook:Inch|inch]] [[Cookbook:Pots and Pans|baking pan]]. # Combine baking mix, chocolate chips and (⅓ cup) sugar and stir until barely mixed. # Add sour cream, vanilla, and water, and mix well. # Spoon into 16 2-inch dough balls. # Place dough balls 2 or 3 inches apart in pan. # Combine remaining (¼ cup) sugar, cinnamon, and nuts and mix well. # Sprinkle nut mixture over dough balls. # [[Cookbook:Bake|Bake]] until golden brown, about 24-26 minutes.
===Tips, Notes, and Variations===
* [[Cookbook:Walnut|Walnuts]] are REAL good in this recipe. * If using a [[Cookbook:Dutch Oven|Dutch oven]], heat with about 15 briquettes of charcoal, with 9 or 10 on the top, and 5 or 6 on the bottom.
[[Category:Inexpensive recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:American recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Camping recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Baked recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Bread recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Breakfast recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Cookie recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Dessert recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Cake recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Cinnamon recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Chocolate recipes|Coffee Cake, Chocolate Chip]] [[Category:Nut recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vanilla recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Pie recipes|8|2½ hours total|3}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|American cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Vegetarian cuisine|vegetarian cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Holiday Recipes|Holiday Recipes]] | [[Cookbook:Dessert|dessert]]
=Peanut Butter Pie=
===Ingredients===
* 8 [[Cookbook:Ounce|ounces]] [[Cookbook:Cream Cheese|cream cheese]], at room temperature * 1 [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] plus 2 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoons]] [[Cookbook:Peanut Butter|smooth peanut butter]] * ½ cup [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] * 12 ounces (about 4½ cups) non-dairy whipped topping * 1 prepared chocolate cookie pie shell * 1 (11.75-ounce) jar plus 2 tablespoons hot fudge topping
===Directions===
# In a medium bowl, stir together cream cheese, peanut butter and sugar. # Carefully stir in 3 cups of the whipped topping. # Spoon into pie shell. # Softly spread mixture to edges of the pie shell. # Put all but 2 tablespoons of hot fudge topping in a microwave-safe container and [[Cookbook:Microwave|microwave]] for 60 seconds. # Spread hot fudge topping over peanut butter mixture in pie shell to cover. # Place in refrigerator for 2 hours. # Spread remaining ~1½ cups whipped topping carefully over top of refrigerated pie. # Knead last 2 ounces of hot fudge topping in plastic bag and cut off a corner and drizzle over top of pie. # Knead last 2 ounces of peanut butter in plastic bag and cut off a corner and drizzle over top in an artful pattern.
[[Category:Inexpensive recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:American recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Dessert recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Pudding and Custard recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Pie recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Chocolate recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Peanut recipes|Pie, Peanut Butter]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

revision.comment: Changed "mustard seeds" to "black mustard seeds". It is my understanding no one uses Yellow mustard seeds for vindaloo.
revision.text:
{{recipesummary|Indian recipes|4|1 hour|3|Image=[[Image:Chicken Vindaloo.jpeg|300px|The finished dish]]}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of India|Cuisine of India]]
'''Vindaloo''' is a hot and spicy dish from the Goa region of [[Cookbook:Cuisine of India|India]]. Its heavy use of vinegar and the traditional meat of pork are due to the Portuguese influence on the island. Vindaloo is a popular Indian restaurant meal, where it is often made with [[Cookbook:Pork|pork]], [[Cookbook:Beef|beef]], [[Cookbook:Chicken|chicken]], [[Cookbook:Lamb|lamb]], [[Cookbook:Prawn|prawns]], or vegetables such as [[Cookbook:Mushroom|mushrooms]].
There are many variations of the vindaloo recipe. Some derivatives use potato, or vary the amounts and types of spices used. Goans scoff at the usage of any other main ingredient besides high fat content pork in vindaloo, because the flavor is very different when prepared with a main ingredient other than pork. Authentic Goan vindaloo is not a curry but more of a dry sauce-based dish, which tastes better as it ages. The authentic taste of vindaloo comes from a unique blend of the fat in the pork, the garlic, vinegar, [[Cookbook:jaggery|jaggery]] and kashmiri chilli (this specific spice is very flavorful but not too pungent).
Vindaloo is often served with [[Cookbook:Rice|rice]], [[Cookbook:Chapati|chappatis]], [[Cookbook:Naan|naan bread]], or a combination of these. It can also be served with assorted pickles, such as aubergine or lime pickle. Given the spicy nature of the dish, it goes particularly well with [[Cookbook:Raita|raita]].
==Ingredients== *3 [[Cookbook:Chicken|chicken]] breast fillets *2-3 large [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]]s *2 fresh [[Cookbook:Chili Pepper|chilli peppers]] (I use 1 red and 1 green) *6 cloves of [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]] *2cm cube of [[Cookbook:Ginger|ginger]] (if you don't have fresh ginger use 2 cloves garlic + 1 tsp dried ginger powder) *1 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|tsp]] [[Cookbook:Turmeric|turmeric]] *2 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tbs]] [[Cookbook:Vinegar|white wine vinegar]] *1 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|tsp]] dried [[Cookbook:Coriander|coriander]] powder *1 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|tsp]] [[Cookbook:Garam Masala|garam masala]] *0.5 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|tsp]] [[Cookbook:Cinnamon|cinnamon]] powder *1.5 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|tsp]] [[Cookbook:Pepper|black peppercorns]] *1 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|tsp]] black [[Cookbook:Mustard|mustard]] seeds *0.5 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|tsp]] [[Cookbook:Salt|rock salt]] *1 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tbl]] chopped fresh [[Cookbook:Cilantro|coriander leaves]] *half a cup of water
==Procedure== # '''Make the onion sauce''' ## Take a thick-based [[Cookbook:Frying Pan|frying pan]], and pour into it enough vegetable oil to cover the base, with a little excess. Heat on a stovetop. ## Slice the onions into fairly thin slivers. When the oil is very hot, add the onions. ## Turn the stove down to a low heat, so the onions just gently [[Cookbook:Sautéing|sauté]]. After around 3 minutes they should be starting to caramelize. ## Gradually turn up the heat and keep stirring the onions. You want them to brown quite heavily without burning. ## Add the white wine vinegar, it will sizzle, and after a while will evaporate. Keep stirring. Fry for several more minutes, until they are very brown, but not burnt. ## Remove the onions from the pan into a bowl, taking care to let as much oil as possible drip back into the pan. You should now have a bowl of nicely crisped fried onions. ## Add the onions to a [[Cookbook:Blender|blender]] or [[Cookbook:Food Processor|food processor]]. Add around 1 tablespoon of oil, and process for around a minute until you have a fairly thick, dark brown sauce. This is the basic onion sauce from which vindaloo is made. It's also the onion sauce that gives the vindaloo the majority of its 'hot' taste, as it builds up as you eat the dish. ## Remove sauce from blender and set aside.
# '''Make the garlic/chili paste''' ## Coarsely chop the garlic cloves (and ginger if you're using it). De-seed the chilli peppers and chop in the same way. Add the chopped garlic and chillies to the food processor. ## Blend the garlic and chillis until you have a fairly grainy (but liquid) sauce. For this I used an attachment on my blender which is intended to grind coffee beans. It has a much smaller container and so there's less waste. ## Add the turmeric, coriander powder, garam masala and cinnamon to the sauce. Stir it until it's well mixed, and set aside. ## Gently crush the black peppercorns in a mortar and pestle. Once coarse, add the mustard seed and rock salt. Continue blending until all the spices form a nice coarse powder.
# '''Cook the paste and meat''' ## Pour a little oil into a saucepan. Add the spiced garlic and chilli paste to the pan. It needs to be slightly floating on oil, not touching the bottom of the pan. ## When the sauce is quite hot and bubbling, add the chopped meat. Keep stirring so the meat absorbs the spice mix, until it is browned and mostly cooked.
# '''Add onion sauce and simmer''' ## Now add the onion sauce to the pan. After stirring for 1 minute, add a little water and stir for another 2 minutes, then turn the heat to quite low. The sauce at this stage should be quite runny, and orange/tan in color. Remember a lot is going to evaporate off as it cooks. ## At this stage you can add some vegetables. Half a cup of frozen peas works well. ## Place a lid over the pan, and cook for around 30-40 minutes. Keep checking and stirring the pan every 5 or 10 minutes to make sure it doesn't stick or burn.The sauce will darken in color as it cooks. ## Towards the last 15 minutes of cooking time, boil 2 cups of pilau, or basmati rice in a pan. ## To serve- spoon the curry over the top of the rice. Sprinkle the chopped coriander leaves over the curry, and serve immediately.
==Notes, tips and variations== *Powdered or dried ingredients can be substituted for fresh, but at the expense of taste.
==Links== {{wikipedia|Chicken Tikka Masala}}
[[Category:Indian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Coriander recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Chicken recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Featured recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

revision.comment: Autumn is the right time for pumpkin
revision.text:
{{recipesummary|Bread recipes|2 loaves|1 hour total|1}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|American cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Native American cuisine|Native American cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Breakfast|Breakfast cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Vegetarian cuisine|vegetarian cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Holiday Recipes|Holiday Recipes]] | [[Cookbook:Bread Recipes|bread recipes]] | [[Cookbook:Dessert|dessert]]
=Pumpkin Bread III= ''see also [[Cookbook:Pumpkin bread|Pumpkin Bread]] and [[Cookbook:Pumpkin Bread II|Pumpkin Bread II]]''
===Ingredients===
* 1½ [[Cookbook:Cup|cups]] [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] * 1 cup [[Cookbook:Oil|oil]] * 3 [[Cookbook:Egg|eggs]], [[Cookbook:Beat|beaten]] * 1 (15-[[Cookbook:Ounce|ounce]]) can [[Cookbook:pumpkin|pumpkin]] * 3 cups [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] * ¾ [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoon]] [[Cookbook:Baking Powder|baking powder]] * 1 teaspoon [[Cookbook:Baking Soda|baking soda]] * 1 teaspoon [[Cookbook:Cinnamon|cinnamon]] * ½ teaspoon ground [[Cookbook:Nutmeg|nutmeg]] * ¾ teaspoon [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * ½ cup [[Cookbook:Chop|chopped]] [[Cookbook:Nut|nuts]] * [[Cookbook:Cooking Spray|Cooking spray]]
===Directions===
# Preheat [[Cookbook:Oven|oven]] to [[Cookbook:Oven_temperatures|350°F]]. # [[Cookbook:Beat|Beat]] sugar and oil using [[Cookbook:Mixer|electric hand mixer]]. # Add eggs and pumpkin and beat lightly. # Add flour, then baking powder, baking soda, cinnamon, nutmeg, salt, and nuts if desired. # Mix well. # Pour into two [[Cookbook:Pots and Pans|baking pans]] sprayed lightly with cooking spray. # [[Cookbook:Bake|Bake]] until toothpick comes out clean from the center, about 40 to 45 minutes. # Cool and serve.
===Tips, Notes, and Variations===
* Chopped [[Cookbook:Walnut|walnuts]], are particularly good in this bread, but your favorite nuts will do. * If cooking in a [[Cookbook:Dutch oven|Dutch oven]], preheat with about 14 charcoal briquettes, with about 10 or 11 on top and 3 or 4 on the bottom. If you're cooking outdoors, you'll have to use a hand mixer or a strong arm with the spoon.
[[Category:Inexpensive recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:American recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Native American recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Camping recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Baked recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Bread recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Breakfast recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Dessert recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Cinnamon recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Egg recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Fruit recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Nutmeg recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Nut recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Pumpkin recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Walnut recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetable recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}}
==Traditional Scottish recipe== ===Ingredients=== *75g of butter or margarine *50 - 75g light brown sugar *1 tablespoon of golden syrup *175g of porridge oats
===Method=== # Put the butter or margarine, sugar and golden syrup into a saucepan and stir over a low heat until the fat and sugar have melted. # Add the porridge oats and blend thoroughly. # Press into a well greased 18cm square sandwich tin. # Bake in the centre of a moderate oven at 180c or 350f or gas mark 4 for 25 minutes or until evenly golden brown. # Mark into fingers whilst warm. # Allow to become almost cold in the tin before removing. # Enjoy!
==Other recipe== ===Ingredients=== *250g oats *100g butter *100g honey *1/2 cup raisins
===Method=== #Heat the honey and butter together in a small saucepan until the butter is melted and add to the oats in a mixing bowl. #Mix well, adding the raisins and put the mixture onto a greaseproof paper lined baking tray and roll flat with a rolling pin. #:Note: mix enough oats so that the mixture isnt too sticky and is becoming dryish. #Bake for 20 mins at gas mark 4 or 175 'C.

revision.comment: A salsa as hot as you like it.
revision.text:
{{recipesummary|Salsa recipes|6|15 minutes|1}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|American cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Mexico|Mexican cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Southern cuisine|Southern cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Vegetarian cuisine|vegetarian cuisine]]
=Spicy Hot Salsa=
===Ingredients===
* [[Cookbook:Habanero|Habaneros]] * [[Cookbook:Jalapeño|Jalapeños]] * [[Cookbook:Onion|Onions]] * Green and red [[Cookbook:Bell Pepper|bell peppers]] * [[Cookbook:Tomato|Tomatoes]] * Onion salt or onion powder
===Directions===
# Open and seed habaneros, jalapeños, bell peppers, and tomatoes. # [[Cookbook:Chop|Chop]] all of them along with the onions. # If using a [[Cookbook:Blender|blender]], blend slowly and do not blend completely. # Season with onion salt or powder to taste. # Toss before dipping. # Save any left over in tightly sealed container in refrigerator.
===Tips, Notes, and Variations===
* All quantities are to taste.
===Uses===
* Dip for tostados or chips. * Garnish for main or side dishes.
===Warning===
* Do not touch eyes or face after handling habanero or jalapeño.
[[Cookbook:Tex-Mex cuisine|Tex-Mex cuisine]] [[Category:Inexpensive recipes|Salsa, Spicy Hot]] [[Category:American recipes|Salsa, Spicy Hot]] [[Category:Mexican recipes|Salsa, Spicy Hot]] [[Category:Southern recipes|Salsa, Spicy Hot]] [[Category:Camping recipes|Salsa, Spicy Hot]] [[Category:Sauce recipes|Salsa, Spicy Hot]] [[Category:Salsa recipes|Salsa, Spicy Hot]] [[Category:Sauce recipes|Salsa, Spicy Hot]] [[Category:Spice Mix recipes|Salsa, Spicy Hot]] [[Category:Bell Pepper recipes|Salsa, Spicy Hot]] [[Category:Chile recipes|Salsa, Spicy Hot]] [[Category:Onion recipes|Salsa, Spicy Hot]] [[Category:Tomato recipes|Salsa, Spicy Hot]] [[Category:Vegan recipes|Salsa, Spicy Hot]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|Salsa, Spicy Hot]] [[Category:Vegetable recipes|Salsa, Spicy Hot]] [[Category:Gluten-free recipes|Salsa, Spicy Hot]]

{{recipesummary|Appetizer recipes|4|½ hour|2}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|American cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Southern cuisine|Southern cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Holiday Recipes|Holiday Recipes]] | [[Cookbook:Cheese|cheese]] | [[Cookbook:Bread Recipes|bread recipes]] | [[Cookbook:Bacon|bacon]]
=Bacon and Cheese Stuffed Mushrooms=
===Ingredients===
* 3 [[Cookbook:Ounce|ounces]] [[Cookbook:Cream Cheese|cream cheese]] * ¼ [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoon]] [[Cookbook:Worcestershire Sauce|Worcestershire Sauce©]] * ¼ teaspoon [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * ¼ teaspoon [[Cookbook:Pepper|pepper]] * ¼ [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] [[Cookbook:Dice|diced]] [[Cookbook:Green Onion|green onions]] * 2 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoon]] diced [[Cookbook:Green Pepper|green peppers]] * [[Cookbook:Chop|Chopped]] mushroom stems * 2 slices cooked [[Cookbook:Bacon|bacon]], chopped * ½ cup [[Cookbook:Bread Crumbs|bread crumbs]] * 1 tablespoon [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]] * 2 dozen [[Cookbook:Mushroom|mushrooms]]
===Directions===
# Preheat [[Cookbook:Oven|oven]] to [[Cookbook:Oven_temperatures|325°F]]. # Soften cream cheese and put in [[Cookbook:Food Processor|food processor]]. # Add Worcershire sauce, salt, and pepper; pulsing on and off. # Fold in chopped bacon, chopped mushroom stems, diced green onions, and green peppers. # Set stuffing aside. # Mix bread crumbs with just enough butter to hold together. # Stuff mushroom caps with stuffing. # Top with bread crumbs. # [[Cookbook:Bake|Bake]] for 5 minutes.

revision.comment: tasty way to bake a potato
revision.text:
{{recipesummary|Potato recipes|4|90 minutes|3}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|American cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Cheese|cheese]] | [[Cookbook:Vegetables|vegetables]]
=Twice-Baked Potatoes II= ''see also'' [[Cookbook:Twice-Baked Potatoes|Twice-Baked Potatoes]]
==Ingredients==
* 4 medium Russet [[Cookbook:Potato|potatoes]] (7 to 9 [[Cookbook:ounce|ounces]]) * [[Cookbook:Aluminum Foil|aluminum foil]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoon]] [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]] * ½ [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] [[Cookbook:Sour Cream|sour cream]] * 1¼ cup shredded sharp [[Cookbook:Cheddar Cheese|cheddar cheese]] * 2 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoons]] [[Cookbook:Heavy Cream|heavy cream]] * ¼ cup [[Cookbook:Milk|milk]] * [[Cookbook:Salt|Salt]] and [[Cookbook:Pepper|pepper]] to taste * 2 strips [[Cookbook:Bacon|bacon]], cooked and [[Cookbook:Dice|diced]] * 1 or 2 [[Cookbook:Green Onion|green onions]], finely [[Cookbook:Chop|chopped]]
==Directions==
# Preheat [[Cookbook:Oven|oven]] to [[Cookbook:Oven_temperatures|400°F]]. # Pierce potato skins with a fork and wrap in foil. # [[Cookbook:Bake|Bake]] potatoes for 1 hour or until soft. # Reduce oven temperature to 350°F. # Carefully remove potatoes from oven and cool for 10 minutes. # Cut potatoes at top ⅓ lengthwise and remove tops. # Scoop out pulp with a small spoon, to about ¼ [[Cookbook:Inch|inch]] from skin. # Mash potato pulp with a fork until smooth. # Add butter, sour cream, ½ cup shredded cheese, heavy cream, milk, salt, and pepper, mash until well combined and smooth. # Stir in bacon and onion. # Spoon the mixture into the empty potato shells. # Top with the rest of the cheese. # Bake for 15 minutes, or until cheese is melted.
[[Category:Inexpensive recipes|Potatoes II, Twice-Baked]] [[Category:American recipes|Potatoes II, Twice-Baked]] [[Category:Bacon recipes|Potatoes II, Twice-Baked]] [[Category:Cheese recipes|Potatoes II, Twice-Baked]] [[Category:Potato recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] ?[[Category:Sour Cream recipes|Potatoes II, Twice-Baked]] [[Category:Vegetable recipes|Potatoes II, Twice-Baked]] [[category:Gluten-free recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Breakfast recipes|10|prep 30 minutes (while oven preheating)
cook 45 minutes
1½ hours total|3}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|American cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Southern cuisine|Southern cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Midwestern cuisine|Midwestern cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Breakfast|Breakfast cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Sausage|sausage]] | [[Cookbook:Cheese|cheese]] | [[Cookbook:Meat|meats]] | [[Cookbook:Bread Recipes|bread recipes]] =Wakeup Sausage Casserole= ===Ingredients=== * 2 [[Cookbook:Cup|cups]] (8-[[Cookbook:Ounce|ounce]] package) shredded [[Cookbook:Cheddar Cheese|cheddar cheese]] * 8 large [[Cookbook:Egg|eggs]], [[Cookbook:Beat|beaten]] * ¼ [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoon]] [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]] powder * 2 [[Cookbook:Green Onion|green onions]], tops only, sliced * 24 ounces evaporated [[Cookbook:Milk|milk]] * ½ teaspoon [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]] powder * ½ cup [[Cookbook:Chop|chopped]] [[Cookbook:Red Pepper|red pepper]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Pound|pound]] hot bulk [[Cookbook:Pork|pork]] [[Cookbook:Sausage|sausage]], cooked, drained, and crumbled * 8 cups (8 to 10 slices) ½ inch cubed [[Cookbook:French Bread|French]] or [[Cookbook:Italian Bread|Italian]] [[Cookbook:Bread|bread]] ===Directions=== # Preheat [[Cookbook:Oven|oven]] to [[Cookbook:Oven_temperatures|350°F]]. # (Cook, drain, and crumble sausage.) # Grease a 9 by 13 inch [[Cookbook:Pots and Pans|baking pan]]. # Combine shredded cheese, eggs, garlic powder, green onion tops, evaporated milk, onion powder, red pepper, and sausage. # Add bread cubes and gently stir to just moisten cubes. # Pour into baking dish. # [[Cookbook:Bake|Bake]] until set, about 45 minutes. ===Tips, Notes, and Variations=== * Serve warm. revision.comment: Removed unnecessary information from article (see [[Cookbook talk:Eton mess]])
revision.text:
[[Image:Etonmess.jpg|thumb|upright|Glasses of Eton mess.]] {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Dessert|Dessert]]
'''Eton mess''' is a [[w:Dessert|dessert]] of [[w:English cuisine|English]] origin consisting of a mixture of [[w:Strawberry|strawberries]], pieces of [[w:Meringue|meringue]] and [[w:Cream|cream]], which is traditionally served<ref>{{cite web|title=Glossary C–G|url=http://www.joyofbaking.com/other/glossaryCG.html|publisher=JoyofBaking.com|accessdate=[[w:10 July|10 July]] [[w:2007|2007]]}}</ref> at [[w:Eton College|Eton College]]'s annual prize-giving celebration picnic on the "Fourth of June" (actually celebrated on the last Wednesday in May).<ref>{{cite web|title=Dates of Halves|url=http://www.etoncollege.com/Eton.asp?state=load&di=171|publisher=[[w:Eton College|Eton College]]|accessdate=[[w:6 December|6 December]] [[w:2007|2007]]}} {{cite web|title=Eton Glossary|url=http://www.etoncollege.com/eton.asp?di=321#fourthofjune|publisher=[[w:Eton College|Eton College]]|accessdate=[[w:6 December|6 December]] [[w:2007|2007]]}}</ref>
==Recipe==
===Ingredients=== *4 medium-sized [[Cookbook:Meringue|meringues]] *280 ml double cream *50 g [[Cookbook:Icing sugar|icing sugar]] *10 ml (1 tbsp) [[Cookbook:Vanilla|vanilla essence]] *150 ml Greek yoghurt *500 g [[Cookbook:Strawberry|strawberries]]
===Method=== #Rinse the strawberries, remove the tops and cut into halves. #Break the meringues into pieces (not too small) and place into a bowl. #Put the double cream, vanilla essence and icing sugar into a bowl and whip until reasonably stiff. #Combine the cream, yoghurt, strawberries and meringue, being careful not to mash the meringue into pieces that are too small. #Serve in bowls.
==Notes== {{reflist|2}}
==External links== {{wikipedia}} *[http://www.joyofbaking.com/StrawberriesCreamMeringue.html Recipe for Eton mess from JoyofBaking.com] *[http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/103204 Recipe for Eton mess from Epicurious] *[http://uktv.co.uk/food/recipe/aid/571229 Recipe for Eton mess by Jean-Christophe Novelli from UKTV Food's ''Food Uncut''] *[http://www.deliaonline.com/recipes/eton-mess,1395,RC.html Recipe for Eton mess by Delia Smith from Delia Online] *[http://www.bbc.co.uk/food/recipes/database/etonmess_67916.shtml Recipe for Eton mess by Antony Worral Thompson from BBC's ''Saturday Kitchen''] *[http://www.bbc.co.uk/food/recipes/database/etonmess_72765.shtml Recipe for Eton mess by Brian Turner from BBC's ''Ready Steady Cook'']
[[Category:Dessert recipes]] [[Category:English recipes]] [[Category:Fruit recipes]] [[Category:Recipes with images]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Dessert|Dessert]]
==Ingredients== * 4C flour * 1/2 t salt * 1 t baking powder * 3/4 C butter * 1 C sugar * 1/4 pound currents * 1/4 t mace * zest of half a lemon * 3 eggs * candied cherries
==Directions== Preheat oven to 350 F.
Sift flour, salt, and baking powder; rub in butter. Add sugar, currents, mace, and lemon zest. Stir in eggs, well beaten.
Form into rough balls about 1" in diameter. If balls aren't holding together well, sprinkle with water. Garnish with 1/8 of a candied cherry. Bake for 9 minutes at 350 F.
[[Category:Cookie_recipes]]

{{recipesummary|Pizza recipes|8 slices, 4 servings|90 minutes, including rising dough|3| [[Image:Pepperoni_pizza.jpg|300px]]|212 cal. per serving}}
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Pizza|Pizza]]
[[Cookbook:pizza|Pizza]] is a traditional [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Italy|Italian]] fare that was introduced by immigrants to America in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. In America it has evolved to unique variations, including this '''Deep Dish Pizza''' variety. What makes this pizza special is the thicker raised crust which is baked with the pizza. The pizza itself is filled with sauce, cheese and other ingredients. It is served hot from the oven, cut in triangular pieces and served along with a salad and a good red wine, although many in the USA prefer a cold beer. Many in the midwest also call it '''Chicago style pizza'''
This receipe has many variants, which are found at the end of the receipe.
==Deep Dish Pizza Crust== ===Ingredients=== * 1 [[Cookbook:teaspoon|tsp]] active dry [[Cookbook:Yeast|Yeast]] (fast rising yeast is acceptable) * 3/4 cup warm water (about 90 degrees F)
* 1 cup [[Cookbook:flour|flour]] * 2 [[Cookbook:tablespoon|tbsp]] [[Cookbook:olive oil|olive oil]] * 1 [[Cookbook:tablespoon|tbsp]] [[Cookbook:sugar|sugar]] * 1/2 [[Cookbook:teaspoon|tsp]] [[Cookbook:salt|salt]]
* 2 cups additional [[Cookbook:flour|flour]] * ~1 cup warm water * 4 [[Cookbook:tablespoon|tbsp]] [[Cookbook:cornmeal|cornmeal]]
===Preparation=== In a mixing bowl or dough mixer, mix the yeast and 3/4 cup warm water. Let this stand for a few minutes to activate the yeast.
Add and mix the 1 cup flour, oil, sugar, salt into a smooth batter. Add the remaining flour and water. Mix this until the dough has a slightly sticky consistency. Add additional water or flour to adjust the consistency. Mix and knead the dough until the dough springs slightly when touched.
Let this rise in a warm location in a greased bowl until double. Punch down the dough in the bowl. Pout it onto a floured flat surface. Roll or shape the dough to the shape of a pizza pan and make an edge up the side of the pan for the crust. Roll the dough thicker for Deep Dish Pizza and thinner for a crisper and more traditional pizza crust.
Preheat the oven to 425 degrees F., add the toppings and bake as noted below.
==Toppings== ===Ingredients=== * 1 or more 6-8 oz. can(s) of prepared pizza sauce, or make your own [[Cookbook:Pizza Sauce|pizza sauce]] * 1 lb shredded [[Cookbook:Mozzarella Cheese|Mozzarella cheese]] * 1/4 cup grated [[Cookbook:Romano Cheese|Romano cheese]] (optional) * 1/4 cup grated [[Cookbook:Parmesan Cheese|Parmesan cheese]] (optional)
===Procedure=== Spread the pizza sauce on the dough which was previously prepared, leaving the edge crust uncoated. Add any optional ingredients (pepperoni, sausage, green pepper, etc.). Spread the grated mozzerella cheese evenly across the pizza, leaving the edge crust untouched. If desired, sprinkle the grated parmesan and romano cheeses evenly over the toppings.
Bake the pizza in the preheated 425 degree F. oven for 25-30 minutes or until the crust and cheese are lightly brown. If the pizza is browning on the crust and not in the middle, line the edge crust with aluminum foil to prevent burning. This rarely happens except on larger diameter pizzas of 16" or more.
When removing from the oven, cut into about 8 triangluar, pie shaped slices for serving. A pizza cutter with a crcular wheel does this nicely.
==Notes, Tips and Variations== There are a variety of options in the crust, baking and especially in the toppings. The baking of the deep dish pizza described above is a cheese pizza in a round pan baked on an oven rack.
===Baking Options=== *Use a heated baking stone. This is a flat stone which sit in the oven and preheats to the oven temperature. It accelerates the baking and makes the crust more consistently brown. Decrease the baking time by removing the pizza when the crust and cheese center is light brown. *A black pan will cook the crust faster and crisper. *Use a professional pizza oven or wood fired stone hearth. This is generally a professional pizza kitchen option.
===Crust Options=== *Cornmeal is specified to ''flour'' the pan. It provides a unique characteristic to the crust and dries it a bit. It may omitted, or substituted with [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]]. *The olive oil may be substituted by [[Cookbook:Vegetable oil|vegetable oil]] or [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]] for a different crust characteristic or for oiling the pan. Olive oil makes an italian bread type of raised crust. *If the crust is left to rise 15-30 minutes before it is baked, it will be thicker and more like an Italian bread crust *If a mozzerella cheese stick or rolled slice of cheese is rolled and sealed into the outer crust with a pinch of the dough, it adds a unique filling of melted cheese to the otherwise bready crust. Some commercial pizza restaurants offer cheese filled crust. *Brush some melted butter on the crust after it has baked. *Pinch, slice or form the outer crust into a design before baking, just for the visual appearance.
===Pizza Pan Options=== *A round aluminum or steel deep dish pizza pan is generally used. It is 12-16 inches in diameter and 1-3 inched deep. Optionally the side removes to facilitate the cutting and serving. See [http://chicago-metallic.kitchen-hills.com/Chicago-Metallic-Professional-Deep-Dish-Pizza-Pan-B0000VLGYI.htm this link for an example.] *Any flat pan may be substituted by rolling up the crust to form the edges. The edge crust tends to be like an Italian bread and less thick however. A rectangular pan tends to bake uneven. *A special wheeled pizza cutter or deep dish pizza pan grip may facilitate handling and serving
===Deep Dish Pizza Optional Toppings=== Consider adding or mixing the following. Many institutions in Chicago will add everything on their toppings option list and call it '''garbage pizza'''. *1 lb [[Cookbook:Pepperoni|pepperoni]], sliced as thick or thin as one likes *1 lb bulk (or casing removed) [[Cookbook:Sausage|Italian sausage]] (browned and crumbled) *1 [[Cookbook:Bell pepper|green pepper]], cleaned and sliced *1 medium or large [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]], sliced or diced *1 lb [[Cookbook:Beef|ground beef]] (skillet browned and crumbled) *1/4 cup [[Cookbook:Mushroom|mushrooms]] (fresh sliced or canned sliced) *1 lb cooked [[Cookbook:Bacon|bacon]] *1 lb diced [[Cookbook:Ham|ham]] *1 lb [[Cookbook:Salami|salami]] *1/2 cup [[Cookbook:Pineapple|pineapple]], diced or in rings *1/2 cup cooked [[Cookbook:Chicken|chicken]] pieces *1/4 cup [[Cookbook:Anchovy|anchovies]] *1/4 cup black [[Cookbook:Olive|olives]], pitted and sliced *any other ingredient
===The Order of the Toppings=== The order of the toppings on the pizza is an option as well. The photo above shows pepperoni placed on ''top'' of the cheese instead of under it.
By changing the order of placement of the toppings, the same ingredients make a pizza that looks and even tastes different. Of course, the crust always is at the bottom for a base. For instance, these variants will make different pizza styles. * Chicago Style Type Deep Dish (standard receipe noted above) ** Crust on bottom ** Add the sauce ** Add the toppings (pepperoni, sausage, etc.) ** Add the mozzarella cheese ** Add the grated cheeses
* Boutique Deep Dish (some "upper crust" restaurants do this) ** Crust on bottom ** Add the toppings (pepperoni, sausage, etc.) ** Add the mozzarella cheese ** Add the sauce over the cheese (may require more sauce to cover the ingredients) ** Add the grated cheeses
* Deep Dish Old World Style (similar to photo) ** Crust on bottom ** Add the sauce ** Add most of the toppings (sausage, green pepper, etc.) ** Add the mozzarella cheese ** Add the grated cheeses ** Add pepperoni or other decorative topping
Enjoy and feast on your experiments.
==Warnings== * Pizza from the oven is hot. Warn the diners when served. * Any meats added to the toppings must be cooked before baking. Raw meat or fish will not adequately cook in the pizza.
[[Category:Pizza recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

revision.comment: Revert to revision 1023536 dated 2007-11-07 22:48:38 by Jomegat using [[:en:Wikipedia:Tools/Navigation_popups|popups]]
revision.text:
{{recipe}}
==Ingredients== *3 table spoons Cream of Wheat *4 pods Cardamom *3 tea spoons Sugar *1 pinch Salt *1 table spoon Butter *1/2 cup (120g) Cashew Nuts(Broken) *1/2 cup (120g) Raisins *1 cup (240ml) Milk
==Procedure== # Wash the Cashews and Raisins and keep them ready. # Crush the Cardamom pods to remove the contents and discard the husks. Pound the contents of the pods into a black powder and mix with the Cream of Wheat. # Add the Sugar and Salt to the Cream of Wheat and mix thoroughly. # Melt the Butter in a saucepan and gently fry the Cream of Wheat in it. # Add the Cashews and Raisins to the saucepan and continue to fry until the Cream of Wheat is light brown. # Add the Milk to the saucepan and stir. The mixture will thicken and you will need to keep stirring to prevent it sticking to the bottom of the saucepan and burning. # When the mixture solidifies, turn off the heat and take the saucepan off the heat. # The Soji is ready for serving, but beware that it is hot.
[[Category:Indian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Breakfast recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Cashew recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Cardamom recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Wheat recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Recipes_with_metric_units|{{PAGENAME}}]]

revision.text:
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Venezuela|Cuisine of Venezuela]]
'''Cachapas''' are traditionally made with fresh corn, and are a summer favorite, but this easy recipe uses canned cream corn, pancake mix and whatever cheese you have on hand. Try this simple appetizer for a taste of Venezuela whenever you like.
== Ingredients == * 1 can [[Cookbook:creamed corn|creamed corn]] (14 fl oz, 398 g) * 3/4 cup [[Cookbook:pancake mix|pancake mix]] * 1/4 cup [[Cookbook:flour|flour]] * 1 [[Cookbook:egg|egg]] * 2 tablespoons melted [[Cookbook:butter|butter]] or [[Cookbook:margarine|margarine]] * 2 tablespoons [[Cookbook:sugar|sugar]], or to taste * [[Cookbook:cheese|cheese]] of your choice
== Procedure == # Mix all the ingredients in a [[Cookbook:blender|blender]]. The mix should become thick and heavy. If not, add more corn. # Shape the mix into small pancakes approximately 1/2 inch thick and about 5 inches in diameter. Let them cook on medium heat for about one minute on each side, or until small bubbles form on the top. # Pancakes should be served hot, and may be accompanied with cheese (feta cheese is a good option).
[[Category:Venezuelan recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Corn recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Pancake recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Korea|Cuisine of Korea]]
This recipe for gochujang is a quick preparation using non-traditional ingredients.
==Ingredients== *1 teaspoon [[Cookbook:Soy Sauce|soy sauce]] *1 teaspoon [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] (½ teaspoon table salt) *1 teaspoon [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] *2 teaspoons [[Cookbook:Vinegar|vinegar]] *1 teaspoon [[Cookbook:Chili Powder|red pepper powder]] *2 teaspoons chopped [[Cookbook:Green onion|green onion]] *1 teaspoon [[Cookbook:Sesame Seed|sesame]] salt
==Procedure== # Mix ingredients together thoroughly. # Refrigerate any leftover portions.
{{Wikipedia|Gochujang}}
[[Category:Korean recipes]] [[Category:Sauce recipes]]

'''Sour mix''' is a mixer used in many [[cocktail]]s, notably the [[Long Island Iced Tea]] family. It is made from approximately equal parts lemon and/or lime juice and [[simple syrup]] and shaken vigorously with ice. This produces a pearly-white liquid with a pronounced flavour. [[Egg white]] may be added as a foaming agent, to improve the texture of the finished product. Pre-mixed versions are available, and are in use in many bars - these typically consist of a powder which must be rehydrated by adding water prior to use.
One of the earliest known printed references to the word "cocktail" described a drink made from "[[Distilled beverage|Spirit]] of any kind, sugar, water and [[bitters]]". This is very similar to the drink that would these days be known as ''sours'' - a spirit or liqueur, shaken vigorously with ice, lemon juice and sugar.
==Recipes for sour mix== {{recipe}} # Whisk one [[Egg (food)|egg]] white in a medium-sized bowl until frothy # Stir in one [[Cup (unit)|cup]] (~2 dl) of [[sugar]] # Add two cups of (~4 dl) [[water]] # Add two cups of (~4 dl) [[lemon]] juice, preferably freshly squeezed # Stir all ingredients well
Store the mix refrigerated and use within three days of making it.
Alternately, try this "vegan" recipe: # 2 Parts Lime Juice # 2 Parts [[Simple_syrup#Simple_syrup|Simple Syrup]] (sugar water) # 1 Part Orange Juice # 1 Part Lemon Juice # Stir ingredients well.
This recipe is not as frothy as the above, but will keep longer and has a great flavor.
==See also== *[[List of cocktails]]
[[Category:Drink mixers]]
[[de:Sour]] [[es:Sour]]

{{recipe}}
== Ingredients == * 1/2 pound softened margarine * 2 cups grated sharp cheddar * 2 cups [[Cookbook:flour|flour]] * 1 teaspoon salt * 3/4 teaspoon powdered [[Cookbook:Cayenne_pepper|cayenne pepper]] * 2 cups [[w:Rice_Krispies|Rice Krispies]]
== Procedure == # Preheat oven to 300 [[Cookbook:F|F]]. # Grate the cheddar. # In a large bowl, blend the margarine and cheddar. # Add the flour, salt, and powdered cayenne pepper to the bowl. # Stir in the Rice Krispies. # Mix it thoroughly. # Shape into small balls, flattening each ball with a fork. Place each cookie onto an ungreased cookie sheet. # Bake at 300 for 20 minutes.
[[Category:Cookie recipes|Cheese Cookies]] [[Category:Dessert recipes|Cheese Cookies]]

revision.comment: New page: {{recipe}} ==Ingredients== * 2 pounds ground beef * 1 quart cold water * 1 (6-ounce) can tomato paste * 2 medium onions, finely chopped * 2 cloves of garlic, minced * 1 tablespoon vinega...
revision.text:
{{recipe}}
==Ingredients==
* 2 pounds ground beef * 1 quart cold water * 1 (6-ounce) can tomato paste * 2 medium onions, finely chopped * 2 cloves of garlic, minced * 1 tablespoon vinegar * 1 teaspoon Worcestershire sauce * 3 tablespoons chili powder * 1 tablespoon salt * 2 teaspoons unsweetened cocoa * 1 teaspoon cumin * 1/2 teaspoon oregano * 1/2 teaspoon cayenne pepper * 1/2 teaspoon black pepper * 1/2 teaspoon cinnamon * 1/2 teaspoon allspice * 1/4 teaspoon marjoram * 1/8 teaspoon ground cloves * 2 bay leaves
==Directions==
#Crumble the raw ground beef into the cold water. Add remaining ingredients and spices. Stir well, breaking the meat up before it cooks. Cover and simmer over low heat for two hours, stirring occasionally. Refrigerate and remove solidified grease. #Reheat and serve in a variety of combinations which can include spaghetti, cooked pinto or red beans, shredded cheese and minced onion depending on the way you like it. May also be used as coney sauce with shredded cheese, minced onions and mustard [[Category:Chili recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Dessert|Dessert]]
{{raw-eggs}}
==Ingredients==
* 8oz. semi-sweet chocolate * 1/2 C powdered sugar * 3/4 stick of butter * 2 egg yolks * 3 T rum
==Directions== Mix by hand. Cream butter with sugar then add egg yolks and finally the rum. Soften the chocolate in a double boiler (don't let the inner pan touch the water in the outer pan) or a microwave. Combine the melted chocolate with butter mixture and beat with a spoon for about 5 minutes.
Refrigerate overnight.
Form into balls using a plastic bag as a mitt. Roll the balls in chopped nuts or chocolate sprinkles, powdered sugar, or anything else.
Store in refrigerator.
== See also == * [[Cookbook:Rum balls]]
[[Category:Cookie recipes|Rum Truffles]] [[Category:Chocolate recipes|Rum Truffles]] [[Category:Dessert recipes|Rum Truffles]] [[Category:Rum recipes|Rum Balls]]
