revision.text:
{{recipesummary|North American recipes|30-40 tiny meatballs|1 hour|1}}
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:North American cuisines|North America]]
This recipe for '''Vegetarian Meatballs''' is delicious and easy to prepare. The meatballs don't come out spherical, though; they are more of squished hemispheres, flat on one side. The recipe costs US$5-7 to prepare.
== Ingredients ==
* 1 large [[Cookbook:onion|onion]] * 1 package (340 g) Yves Veggie Ground Round (any similar [http://thelazyvegetarian.blogspot.com/2005/06/fake-ground-meat.html veggie ground meat] should also work) * 3 [[Cookbook:Tbsp|Tbsp]] hickory smoked [[Cookbook:barbecue sauce|barbecue sauce]] (recommended) OR [[Cookbook:barbecue sauce|barbecue sauce]] OR [[Cookbook:tomato sauce|tomato sauce]] OR [[Cookbook:Ketchup|ketchup]] * 2 [[Cookbook:eggs|eggs]] * 3 Tbsp [[Cookbook:breadcrumbs|breadcrumbs]] * 1/8 [[Cookbook:Tsp|Tsp]] dried [[Cookbook:paprika|paprika]]
== Procedure ==
# Preheat oven to 350°F. # [[Cookbook:Sauté|Sauté]] onion; pour off oil; put aside. # In a large bowl, [[Cookbook:beat|beat]] eggs. # Add Ground Round and break up well with fork. # Add all remaining ingredients. # Mix well. # Line a large tray with [[w:parchment paper|parchment paper]]. # Drop mixture onto the paper in tablespoonfuls. You should get 30-40 meatballs. Don't worry if the mixture falls apart a little on tray. # [[Cookbook:Bake|Bake]] at 350°F for 22 minutes. # Flip meatballs over. # Bake for an additional 17 minutes.
== Notes ==
* Yes, the baking time is 22 minutes + flip + 17 minutes. The burgers come out crisp and delicious. * Questions? Comments? Email this recipe's maintainer at unforgettableid at gmail.com or simply click the "discuss" tab at the top of this page.
[[Category:Barbecue sauce recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Inexpensive recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Recipes with meat substitutes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cake|Cake]] {{recipesummary|Cake recipes|Unknown serving amount|From 1 hour - depends on decoration|2|Image=[[Image:Honey-Gingerbread-2008-Jan-02.jpg|300px]]}}
'''Honey Gingerbread''' is a simple and easy to prepare honey cookie. And you can decoreate it if you want to.
== Ingredients ==
*500g [[Cookbook:smooth flour|smooth flour]] *125g [[Cookbook:butter|butter]] *190g [[Cookbook:powdered sugar|powdered sugar]] *1 table spoon [[Cookbook:honey|honey]] *3 [[Cookbook:egg|egg]] *1 teaspoon [[Cookbook:cinnamon|cinnamon]] *1 teaspoon [[Cookbook:Baking Soda|baking soda]] *4 [[Cookbook:clove|clove]]
And you need some molds to cut forms of cakes.
=== Decoration (optional) ===
*1 [[Cookbook:egg white|egg white]] *150g and more [[Cookbook:powdered sugar|powdered sugar]]
== Procedure ==
#Take all ingredients except one egg and prepare a smooth dough. #Put the last egg to cup and mix it. #Divide the dough on five or six parts. Take one part and make cca 3mm film from it. Now molds come handy - cut some nice forms and put them on baking tin. #When the tin is full, take the mixed egg and glair top of every cake. #[[Cookbook:Baking|Bake]] at 180°C for few minutes minutes, until the cakes have nice light brown colour. #Repeat until you used all dough.
=== Decorating (optional) ===
If you have decidet to decorate the cakes you will have to invest another time - maybe few hours if the decoration is complex.
#Mix the egg white and sugar. You may have to add another sugar if the substance is not concrete enough. #If you do not have accesories needed to "paint" on cakes you can use plastic bag - just cut of corner of it to make small hole with about 1mm in diameter. #You can start painting now.
[[Category:Cake recipes]] [[Category:Recipes_with_metric_units]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Dessert|Dessert]]
{{Recipesummary| |Category=Dessert recipes |Servings=4 |Time=10 minutes |Rating=2 |Image=[[Image:Rhubarb_fool.jpg|300px]] }} [[Cookbook:Rhubarb|Rhubarb]] fool is a traditional desert in Swedish cuisine. Its sweet and sour taste makes it a perfect summer desert, to be served after a heavy meal.
== Ingredients == 500 g of fresh or frozen [[Cookbook:Rhubarb|rhubarb]] * 4 dl of [[Cookbook:water|water]] * 1 dl of [[Cookbook:sugar|sugar]] * 3 tbs of [[Cookbook:Potatostarch|potatostarch]] * [[Cookbook:Milk|Milk for serving]]
== Procedure == Rinse the rhubarb and cut it into smaller pieces, about 1-3 cm in length. If the rhubarb is coarse or of low quality, it may be necessary to peel it first. Bring the water and sugar to a boil. Add the rhubarb and boil until soft, about 3-5 min. Meanwhile, mix the starch with a bit of water until it dissolves.
When the rhubarb is soft, whisk or stir vigorously to make sure all the rhubarb pieces breaks up into strings. ''There should be no whole pieces left'', if necessary boil some more. Remove the rhubarb from the heat. Add the dissolved starch to the rhubarb while stirring. Keep stirring and bring the rhubarb to a boil once again. Pour the rhubarb fool into serving bowls and sprinkle some sugar on top to prevent skin from forming. Leave to cool off and then refrigerate.
Serve at room temperature or chilled, with milk.
== Notes and Variations == Depending on the type of rhubarb and whether it is peeled or not the color of the rhubarb fool can vary from pale yellow to clear red. The [[Cookbook:Potatostarch|potatostarch]] can be substituted for [[Cookbook:Cornstarch|cornstarch]].
[[Category:Dessert recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Recipes_with_metric_units|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Swedish recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}}
{{Recipesummary| |Category=Sauce recipes |Servings=4 |Time=10 minutes |Rating=2 |Image=[[Image:Chipolata.jpg|300px]] }}
Creamed [[Cookbook:Spinach|spinach]] makes a nutritious [[Cookbook:sauce|sauce]] that goes well with [[Cookbook:fish|fish]] and [[Cookbook:meat|meat]] dishes. In Swedish cuisine it has traditionally been used with boiled [[Cookbook:potatoes|potatoes]] and [[Cookbook:fish|fish]] or with [[Cookbook:chipolata|chipolata]], the Swedish "prince-sausage".
== Ingredients == * 500 g fresh [[Cookbook:spinach|spinach]] (or whole frozen spinach leaves) * 2 dl of [[Cookbook:water|water]] * 1/2 tsp of [[Cookbook:salt|salt]] * 1/2 dl of [[Cookbook:cream|cream]] * [[Cookbook:black_pepper|black pepper]]
'''or'''
* 400 g of [[Cookbook:chop|chopped]] [[Cookbook:spinach|spinach]], fresh or frozen * 1 1/2 tbs of [[Cookbook:flour|flour]] * 1 dl of [[Cookbook:milk|milk]] * 1/2 tsp of [[Cookbook:salt|salt]] * [[Cookbook:black_pepper|black pepper]]
== Procedure ==
Creamed spinach can be done in two different ways. Either with whole spinach or with [[Cookbook:chop|chopped]] spinach.
With '''whole spinach''', first [[Cookbook:boil|boil]] the fresh spinach leaves and the salt in the water for about 5 minutes. If you use frozen spinach, follow the instructions on the box. Note that spinach is high in [[Cookbook:nitrate|nitrites]] which means you may not have to use as much salt as you might think. After boiling for 5 minutes remove the water and let the spinach "dry" for a minute or so. Put the spinach back into the [[Cookbook:Pots_and_Pans|pan]] and add the cream. Boil for a few more minutes and add salt and pepper to taste. Instead of cream the spinach can be quickly fried in about 1 tbs of [[Cookbook:butter|butter]].
With '''chopped spinach''', first boil the fresh spinach leaves as above or gently [[Cookbook:thaw|thaw]] the frozen (chopped) spinach in a little bit of water in a pan. Mix the flour with the chopped spinach in the pan and add the milk. Bring the spinach to the boil and boil gently for 3-5 minutes. Add salt and pepper to taste.
== Variations == It is not uncommon to add a dash of [[Cookbook:garlic|garlic]] and/or [[Cookbook:nutmeg|nutmeg]] to the creamed spinach. The proportions of milk/cream to spinach can be varied to produce anything from a rich green color to something similar to a [[Cookbook:White_Sauce|white sauce]] with spinach in it, all according to taste.

{{recipe}} {{recipesummary|Potato recipes|4|10 min|3|Image=[[Image:Potato_stew.jpg|300px]]}}
Stewing is a great way to take care of left over [[Cookbook:potato|potatoes]]. Potato stew goes well with [[Cookbook:sausage|sausages]], [[Cookbook:meatballs|meatballs]], or [[Cookbook:smoking|smoked]], [[Cookbook:salting|salted]] or [[Cookbook:Gravlax|gravad]] fish.
== Ingredients == * 10 leftover boiled [[Cookbook:potato|potatoes]] * 30 ml of [[Cookbook:Wheat|wheat]] [[Cookbook:flour|flour]] * 4 dl of [[Cookbook:Milk|milk]], preferably with high fat content (about 3%) * 20 ml of [[Cookbook:butter|butter]] (optional) * [[Cookbook:salt|salt]] * [[Cookbook:pepper|white pepper]] * [[Cookbook:Dill|Dill]]
== Procedure == Peal and dice the cold, already boiled, potatoes; make the cubes about 1-2 cm across. Mix the flour with the milk in a saucepan. Be careful to get a smooth mix without lumps; it may help to add just a little bit of milk at the time until a smooth thick substance forms, then add the rest of the milk. Add the butter. For a low-fat alternative, omit the butter. Omitting the butter works perfectly fine but the stew will lose some of its smoothness and luster. Bring the sauce to a boil, add the potatoes and boil gently for 5 min. Add salt, pepper and dill to taste.
=== With raw potatoes === Dice the potatoes; make the cubes about 1 cm across. Put the diced potatoes in a saucepan an add milk until it almost covers the potatoes. ''Gently'' boil until the potatoes are soft, about 10 min, stirring occasionally. If the stew is too thin, add some [[Cookbook:Roux|roux]] to the potatoes and boil for a few more minutes. Finally add the dill.
== Variations == The dill can be substituted for [[Cookbook:parsley|parsley]] or [[Cookbook:chive|chive]]. Add one or two table spoons (15 ml) of [[Cookbook:Dijon_Mustard|Dijon mustard]] to touch up the flavor.

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Vegan cuisine|Vegan cuisine]]
'''Virgin Vegan Eggnog''' is not as thick as traditional eggnog.
==Ingredients== *2 cups unsweetened [[Cookbook:Vanilla|vanilla]]-flavored [[Cookbook:Almond milk|almond milk]] *1 large, ripe [[Cookbook:Pear|D'Anjou pear]] *1 [[Cookbook:Lemon|lemon wedge]]
==Procedure== #Cut the pear into chunks, discarding the core. Place the chunks of pear in a blender. #Squeeze the juice of the lemon over the pear. #Add the almond milk. Blend. Serve immediately
2 servings
''Per serving: 114 calories; 3g fat; 2g protein; 5g fiber; 12g sugars; 22g total carbohydrate''
[[Category:Vegan recipes]] [[Category:Beverage recipes]] [[Category:Pear recipes]] [[Category:Gluten-free recipes]] [[Category:Recipes_without_cooking_time]]

revision.comment: [[Cookbook:Scones]] moved to [[Cookbook:Basic Scones]]: to let [[Cookbook:Scones]] redirect to the overview page [[Cookbook:Scone]]
revision.text:
{{recipe}}
==Ingredients== *1 cup [[Cookbook:flour|flour]] (100 g) *1 tsp [[Cookbook:baking powder|baking powder]] (5 g) *1 pinch [[Cookbook:salt|salt]] *2 Tbs [[Cookbook:butter|butter]] (50 g) *1 Tbs [[Cookbook:sugar|sugar]] (50 g) *½ cup [[Cookbook:milk|milk]] (125 ml) + extra milk for glazing
;Servings: 4 ;Yield: 16 to 18 scones
==Directions== #Preheat the oven to 450° F (225° C). #Sift flour, baking powder and salt into a bowl. Rub in butter. Add sugar. Add the milk and mix with a knife until obtaining a soft, not sitcky, dough. #Turn the dough on to a lightly floured board and knead it quickly until it is smooth. #Roll out the dough to about 1/2 inch (12 mm) thickness. Cut 16 rounds with 2 inch fluted cookie cutter and transfer them to a buttered cookie sheet. glaze tops with milk. #Bake towards top of the hot oven for 8 to 10 minutes or until well risen and golden brown. #Cool on a wire rack.
Serve tea scones with butter, whipped cream, and jam.
==Variations== *Raisin scones - add 1-2 Tbs raisins with the sugar. *Lemon and raisin scones - add 1 tsp finely grated lemon peel and 1-2 Tbs raisins with the sugar. *Orange and cherry scones - add 1 tsp finely grated orange peel and 1-2 Tbs finely chopped candied cherries, washed and dried, with the sugar. *Date and walnut scones - add 1 Tbs finely chopped dates and 1 Tbs finely chopped shelled walnuts with the sugar. *Cinnamon scones - sift 1 tsp cinnamon with the flour. *Ginger scones - sift 1/2 tsp ground ginger with flour. *Honey scones - use 1 Tbs honey and 7 Tbs milk instead of 1 cup milk. choclate chip - 2 tbs choclate chips
[[Category:Scone recipes]]

{{recipe}}
This is a simple dish to throw together with leftover meat. I use frozen vegetarian steak strips, though sliced seitan, seared flank steak or any other protein would probably work.
==Ingredients==
*½ large [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]], sliced *2 large [[Cookbook:Bell Pepper|bell peppers]], sliced *2 tablespoons [[Cookbook:Olive Oil|olive oil]] *12 ounces steak strips *12 ounces crushed tomatoes *1 teaspoon [[Cookbook:Caper|caper]]s *7-10 leaves fresh basil *¼ teaspoon salt *1 pinch red pepper flakes
==Procedure== Heat the olive oil in a large skillet. Sear steak strips, bell peppers and onion together with salt and red pepper flakes for a few minutes, then turn heat down and add crushed tomatoes and capers. Simmer, covered, for ten minutes or until steak is cooked through and tender. [[Cookbook:Chiffonade|Chiffonade]] the basil and add, simmer for another couple of minutes.
Serves four. Good as a main dish with spinach and garlic and risotto.

{{recipe}}
== Ingredients == * 1 [[Cookbook:cup|cup]] [[Cookbook:water|water]] * 3 [[Cookbook:tablespoon|tablespoons]] fresh [[Cookbook:Lemon Juice|lemon juice]] * 1 [[Cookbook:teaspoon|teaspoon]] [[Cookbook:sugar|sugar]] * 1 [[Cookbook:pinch|pinch]] [[Cookbook:salt|salt]] * [[Cookbook:pepper|black pepper]] and [[Cookbook:Black Salt|black salt]] for taste
==Procedure== # Mix lemon juice in water. # Add sugar and a pinch of salt. # Add black pepper powder and pinch of black salt for taste. # Stir it well. Add some ice cubes while serving.
[[Category:Beverage recipes]] [[Category:Lemon recipes]]

{{cookwork|Needs measurements}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Nigeria|Cuisine of Nigeria]]
'''Moin Moin''', also ''moimoi'', ''moyin moyin'', is a traditional West African dish based on [[Cookbook:Black-Eyed Pea|black-eyed peas]] or other [[Cookbook:Legumes|beans]]. It is usually conical or cylindrical in shape, based on the shape of the mould used to make it.
==Ingredients== * [[Cookbook:Black-Eyed Pea|black-eyed peas]], or other [[Cookbook:Legumes|beans]] * [[Cookbook:tomato|tomatoes]] * [[Cookbook:oil|oil]] * [[Cookbook:water|water]] * [[Cookbook:salt|salt]]
===Optional=== * [[Cookbook:Hard Boiled Eggs|hard-boiled eggs]] * dried [[Cookbook:fish|fish]] * chunks or [[Cookbook:mincing|minced]] [[Cookbook:beef|beef]]
==Procedure==
# Soak some beans in a large container (some people recommend lightly grounding the beans first to make it easier to remove the skin) for about an hour or so. # Prepare foil or empty cans for the cooking: #* If using empty cans, make sure their interior is clean, and lightly greased. #* If using foil: #*#Tear off about 1 foot of the foil. #*#Fold the foil in half. #*#One of the edges is closed and fine. For two of the other edges, roll them a few times over to make sure they will take the weight of the mixture (at least an inch-worth of rolling). #*#When you are done, the foil will look like rectangles with only one edge open. # Rub the beans between your hands to peel the skin off. (The skin should float to the top of the container.) Keep doing this until you have most of the skin off the beans. # Grind the beans into a smooth, finely-ground, mostly-liquid paste. # Add blended tomatoes (or tomato sauce and paste), oil (just a few teaspoons), a little salt, and if you wish, you can also add hard-boiled eggs, or dried fish, or meat, or ground beef. # Place into either the foil or the cans. #* If using cans, simply pour some of the batter into the cans, making sure you leave enough room for the cooking moin moin to rise. #* If using foil, pour some of the batter into the foil, and then close up the last edge of the foil (once again, by rolling it securely). # Place some water in a large pot. # Place the cans or the foil into them. # Boil the moin moin until it forms a solid substance (at least half an hour) # Remove them from the cans or the foil before serving.
Usually eaten with rice, meat, and maybe other sides.
{{Wikipedia|Moin moin}}
[[Category:Nigerian recipes]] [[Category:Bean recipes]] [[Category:Gluten-free recipes]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Sandwiches|Sandwiches]]
A '''Monte Cristo sandwich''' is a sandwich composed of ham, chicken, and Swiss cheese enclosed in bread that is dipped in beaten egg and fried until golden brown. <ref>Encyclopedia of American Food and Drink, John F. Mariani [Lebhar-Friedman:New York] 1999 (p. 209)</ref>
==Ingredients== * sliced white [[Cookbook:bread|bread]] * sliced [[Cookbook:ham|ham]] * sliced cooked [[Cookbook:chicken|chicken]] * sliced [[Cookbook:Emmental Cheese|Emmental cheese]] * [[Cookbook:egg|egg]] [[Cookbook:batter|batter]]
==Procedure==
# Take three slices of white bread. # Butter the first and cover with lean baked ham and chicken. # Butter the middle slice on both sides, place on meat, and cover with thinly sliced cheese. # Butter the third slice and place, butter down, over cheese. # Trim crusts; cut sandwich in two; secure with toothpicks; dip in light egg batter; fry in butter on all sides until golden brown. # Remove toothpicks and serve with currant jelly, strawberry jam, or cranberry sauce.<ref>The Brown Derby Cookbook [Doubleday & Company:Garden City NY] 1949 (p. 183)</ref>
==References==
<references/>
[[Category:Sandwich recipes]] [[Category:Ham recipes]] [[Category:Chicken recipes]] [[Category:Cheese recipes]]

revision.comment: Reverted edit of [[Special:Contributions/131.123.185.79|131.123.185.79]], changed back to last version by Johan Jönsson
revision.text:
{{recipesummary|Cookie recipes|24 balls|20 minutes|1|[[Image:Chokladbollar.jpg|300px]]|140 calories/586 kJ}}
{{recipe}}
'''The chokladboll''' (or ''negerboll'') is a traditional [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Sweden|Swedish]] pastry often eaten with [[Cookbook:Coffee|coffee]] during [[w:Fika|fika]]. They are quick and easy to prepare, since they require no baking and only a few, common ingredients.
== Ingredients == * 8 [[Cookbook:dL|dL]] (3 1/4 cups) [[Cookbook:Oats|oats]] * 3 dL (1 1/4 cups) [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] * 6 [[Cookbook:Tbsp|Tbsp]] (90 mL) [[Cookbook:Cocoa|cocoa]] * 1 Tbsp (15 mL) [[Cookbook:Vanilla Sugar|vanilla sugar]] (or 1 tsp (5 mL) vanilla extract, added with the coffee) * 150 g (2/3 cup) [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]] or [[Cookbook:Margarine|margarine]] * 6 Tbsp (90 mL) cold [[Cookbook:Coffee|coffee]] * flaked [[Cookbook:Coconut|coconut]] or [[Cookbook:Pearl Sugar|pearl sugar]]
== Procedure == {{Wikipedia|Chokladboll}} # Mix oats, sugar, vanilla sugar, and cocoa in a large bowl. # Using your hands or a [[Cookbook:Potato masher|potato masher]], incorporate the butter into the dry ingredients until the dough has an even consistency. # Add the coffee and mix until incorporated. # Fill a small bowl with flaked coconut or pearl sugar. # With your hands, roll the dough into 3 cm (1 inch) diameter balls. # Roll each ball in the coconut or pearl sugar and place on a tray. # Chill chocolate balls for at least one hour before serving.
[[Category:Coffee recipes]] [[Category:Chocolate recipes]] [[Category:Cookie recipes]] [[Category:Dessert recipes]] [[Category:Oat recipes]] [[Category:Coconut recipes]] [[Category:Swedish recipes]] [[Category:Recipes with metric units]] [[Category:Featured recipes]]
[[sv:Chokladboll]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Italy|Cuisine of Italy]]
'''Pasta and Bean Soup''' (''Pasta Fagioli'') is a true classical Italian peasant dish, again overcomplicated all too often by highfallutin' chefs. But made properly, with simple ingredients, and maybe let to infuse in the pot for 24 hours, you have one of the most delicious and hearty soups imaginable.
{{see also|Cookbook:Pasta e Fagioli}}
==Ingredients==
*1 large slug of premium [[Cookbook:Olive Oil|olive oil]] *1 glass of dry white [[Cookbook:wine|wine]] *5 cloves of [[Cookbook:garlic|garlic]], peeled and chopped ''(use less garlic at your peril!!)'' *1 [[Cookbook:onion|onion]], peeled and chopped *4 very red [[Cookbook:tomato|tomatoes]], chopped finely or one tin (235 g) chopped tomatoes *3 large ''squeezes'' of Italian tomato [[Cookbook:purée|purée]] *2 235g tins of [[Cookbook:Borlotti Bean|borlotti beans]] *1 handful of fresh, chopped [[Cookbook:spinach|spinach]] (optional) *1 sprig of [[Cookbook:rosemary|rosemary]] about 3 inches long *A large handful of chopped [[Cookbook:parsley|parsley]] *1 ½ litres [[Cookbook:water|water]] *2 [[Cookbook:chicken|chicken]] [[Cookbook:Bouillon Cubes|stock cubes]] *1 pinch of [[Cookbook:salt|salt]] *large pinch of freshly ground [[Cookbook:pepper|pepper]] *large pinch of [[Cookbook:cayenne pepper|cayenne pepper]] *5 handfuls of [[Cookbook:pasta|pasta]] shells or penne *100 ml of single fresh [[Cookbook:cream|cream]] (optional)
==Procedure==
#Heat the olive oil in the pan, and add the chopped garlic and onions and fry gently for about 3 minutes until translucent but not coloured. Add the cayenne pepper and mix well in the pan. #Add the glass of white wine and allow to evaporate slightly #Add the water, the stock cubes, the tomato paste, pepper, salt, Pasta and the 2 tins of beans and allow to simmer gently for as long as the pasta needs to cook (see packet) stirring occasionally. #Once the pasta is [[Cookbook:Al dente|al dente]], stop the cooking process and add the chopped parsley and the cream and stir in well. #Now add the rosemary sprig and allow the whole thing to infuse for about 2 hours.
==Notes, tips and variations==
* Add a small piece of [[Cookbook:Parmesan Cheese|Parmesan]] rind to the pot once you have added the water. Take it out once you are ready to serve the soup. Adds a... well... a parmesany taste to the soup!! * The soup should be quite thick, but if it is not thick enough, take some of the soup out of the pot (preferably excluding any pasta) and blend it. Return the blended mixture to the soup to thicken. * This soup can be adjusted by the addition of extra beans, extra pasta, to suit your individual taste. As a general rule the pasta should form about 40 percent of the soup !
Buon Appetito Wikipedies !
[[Category:Italian recipes]] [[Category:Soup recipes]] [[Category:Pasta recipes]] [[Category:Bean recipes]]

{{recipesummary|Curry recipes|4|90 minutes|3}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Vegan cuisine|Vegan cuisine]]
==Ingredients== * 4 T [[Cookbook:Peanut Oil|peanut oil]] * 2 T chopped [[Cookbook:Shallot|shallots]] * 1 inch chopped [[Cookbook:Ginger|ginger]] * 1 chopped [[Cookbook:Jalapeño|jalapeño]] * 8 oz [[Cookbook:Tempeh|tempeh]] * 2 T [[Cookbook:Soy Sauce|soy sauce]] * 2 cups cooked [[Cookbook:Rice|jasmine rice]] * 1 medium kabocha [[Cookbook:Squash|squash]]
==Procedure== # Cut off top of kabocha squash and scoop out seeds. # [[Cookbook:Baking|Bake]] the squash for 45 minutes at 375°F (190°C) or until a sharp knife goes through the flesh easily. # Meanwhile, [[Cookbook:Frying|fry]] the tempeh, shallots, ginger, and jalapeño. Cook until tempeh is completely brown, and then add soy sauce and rice. Take off heat and [[Cookbook:Mixing|mix]] thoroughly. # Put tempeh mixture into kabocha squash and bake for 30 more minutes.
[[Category:Vegan recipes]] [[Category:Tempeh recipes]] [[Category:Squash recipes]] [[Category:Casserole recipes]]

revision.text:
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Beverages|Beverages]]
'''London Fog''' (also known as Vanilla Tea Misto) is the name of a drink which originated in Vancouver, British Columbia, [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Canada|Canada]], although the creator remains unknown, among several claims. One such claim is from the [[w:Island Coffeehouse|Island Coffeehouse]] in Langley, Washington, a non-profit student run organization, where it was originally made with Peppermint Tea in 2006. However, patrons of Starbucks in Calgary, Alberta have asked for this decadent drink since the winter of 2004. It is common in Washington and Oregon, as well as in the neighboring lower mainland of British Columbia and Alberta, Canada.
The "London Fog" was recently the subject of an investigation on the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation's afternoon show ''[[w:Freestyle (radio program)|Freestyle]]''.
== Recipe == * 16 oz of [[Cookbook:milk|milk]]. (2% or whole) * 1 shot of [[Cookbook:vanilla|vanilla]] syrup per 16 oz of milk * 1 bag of Earl Grey [[Cookbook:tea|tea]]
== Procedure == # Brew a small amount of Earl Grey tea. (Add about ½ cup of boiling water to your mug with the tea bag in it.) You are making Earl Grey tea concentrate. Let steep for 2-4 minutes to achieve optimum flavour. # Heat up Milk. Preferably you have access to a steamer, or you might be able to ask your local barista for help. # Add the vanilla syrup. (adjust according to taste)
== Notes, tips and variations == * Manchester Fog - steamed [[Cookbook:Soy Milk|soy milk]] with a sugar free vanilla syrup in Earl Grey tea. * Seattle Fog - soy misto (½ water, ½ soy, steamed) with 2 pumps of vanilla syrup and one pump of [[Cookbook:hazelnut|hazelnut]] syrup, in 2 bags of Earl Grey Tea. Also known as the "No Wang's Special". * Sweet Treat London Fog - a sweet, simple, tea-less version of a cold London Fog, which is best served in a punch bowl, consists of chilled ginger ale and copious amounts of either lime sherbet or orange sherbet. As the sherbet melts, it gives the drink a foggy appearance.
[[Category:Beverage recipes]]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Salad Recipes|Salad Recipes]]
== Introduction ==
Basic chicken salad is very similar in many respects to basic [[Cookbook:Tuna Salad|Tuna Salad]], although there are many variations on the dish which can set it apart. Chicken salad tends to work well with sweet fruit and vegetable flavors, and is ideal for lunch-time sandwiches.
== Basic Chicken Salad ==
== Sweet Southern Chicken Salad ==
{{recipesummary|Salad recipes|4|1 hour, 15 minutes|1}}
=== Ingredients ===
*4 skinless chicken breasts *2 stalks celery *1/4 cup peppercorns *2 bay leaves *1 teaspoon salt *1 cup mayonnaise *1 cup mango chutney *salt and pepper
=== Procedure ===
Add the chicken breasts to a small pot. Add enough water to cover. Slice stalks of celery into large sticks. Add celery, bay leaves, teaspoon salt, and peppercorns to the pot. Bring to a boil. Once boiling, lower temperature and simmer for at least one hour. Chicken should be tender, and should pull apart easily. Remove chicken from water. You may wish to reserve the water as a base for a stock or a soup.
slice chicken into small bite-size cubes. Take care not to shred the chicken, because the salad should be chunky. put cut chicken into a medium-sized bowl. Add mayonnaise and chutney, one spoonful at a time until salad reaches correct consistency. The salad should be moist and chunky, not wet and mushy. Add salt and pepper to taste.
Serve by itself in a bowl, or on bread, biscuits, or croissants.
=== Variations ===
*Dice a half-stick of celery into fine peices, and add to the salad. *Add a cut of sliced seedless grapes to the salad for extra sweetness. *Dice a hard-boiled egg and add to the salad. *Top with cranberry sauce, orange marmalade, or spicy brown mustard

{{recipe}} '''Steamed rice''' is a simple dish but many people have trouble cooking it - being too much rice or too much water. This recipe for steamed rice is failsafe and does not require special rice cookers or microwaves. ==Ingredients== *1 part rice *2 parts water *Deep saucepan with lid The universal rule with cooking steamed rice is that the proportion of water should be double that of the rice. If you use one cup of rice you must use two cups of water. If you use two cups of rice you must use four cups of water. 1 metric cup (250ml, 8.4535 fl oz) is enough rice for three adults. The rice pictured in the images is Basmati rice - but this recipe works for all long-grain white rice. ==Method== There is no need to wash the rice but you can if you choose to. 1. Fill cup with desired amount of rice. [[Image:Steamed Rice How to 01.jpg|right|250px|thumb]]














2. Pour rice into saucepan. [[Image:Steamed Rice How to 02.jpg|right|250px|thumb]]














3. Pour water into saucepan. [[Image:Steamed Rice How to 03.jpg|right|250px|thumb]] Remember - twice as much water as rice.














4. Stir water so that floating rice sinks. [[Image:Steamed Rice How to 04.jpg|right|250px|thumb]]














5. Place saucepan on stove and set temperature to "high". Do not cover. [[Image:Steamed Rice How to 05.jpg|right|250px|thumb]]














6. Wait until water begins to boil. [[Image:Steamed Rice How to 06.jpg|right|250px|thumb]]














7. Stir rice again. [[Image:Steamed Rice How to 07.jpg|right|250px|thumb]]














8. Set temperature to lowest setting. Cover saucepan with lid. [[Image:Steamed Rice How to 08.jpg|right|250px|thumb]]














9. After ten minutes turn the element off and uncover. The rice is ready to eat. [[Image:Steamed Rice How to 09.jpg|right|250px|thumb]] [[Category:Rice recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Recipes with images|{{PAGENAME}}]]
